Site_name_other: CARGURRA - Bronze Age findspot, Bronze Age barrow
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Workmen cutting or clearing a drain in 1860 in a marsh at Cargurra found a lunula at a depth of 1.5m. It was said to have been found with a human skeleton and in Christie's catalogue to have been 'found in a barrow'. However, as this was an accidental encounter by workmen, it is uncertain whether the lunulae was a later placed deposit into the fabric of the barrow, and whether this is a grave good or a later deposit that was not directly associated with the interment in the barrow.It was also noted that the lunula was found in marshy ground and may have placed in a bog as a votive deposit, removed from burial. Several authors refute the presence of a barrow here and reject Christie's observation Note that lunulae in Britain and Ireland are rarely found as grave goods (unlike in Iberia where they are sometimes found in EBA cist burials)
Site_description: Workmen cutting or clearing a drain in 1860 in a marsh at Cargurra found a lunula at a depth of 1.5m (b1). It was said to have been found with a human skeleton and in Christie's catalogue to have been 'found in a barrow' (b3). The lunula has fine incised zig-zag ornament around the edge, and zig-zags and triangles at the terminals. There is a trefoil button at each of the rounded ends. 'The precise location for this find is unknown but the landowner states that the traditional site is the field at SX 133 917. This was known as 'Marsh' in the Tithe Award, c1840 (b5). Almost certainly there was never a barrow here.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1976. OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: <gg summary>: A cairn removed during farm improvements in the C19 contained calcined bones, fragments of a ribbon-handled urn and a bronze dagger, and a strike-a-light
Site_description: A cairn 35ft (10.6m) in diameter and 3 or 4ft (0.9m-1.2m) in height, on the cliff edge at Angrouse, was removed during farm improvements in the C19. A pit, 4ft by 2ft by 2ft (1.2m by 0.6m by 0.6m), covered by two layers of flat stones was revealed. It contained many calcined bones, fragments of a Middle Bronze Age ribbon-handled urn, a bronze dagger 6.75in (17cm) long with three rivets, and a globular piece of iron pyrites. The urn and dagger were purchased by Truro Museum from the Borlase sale (b2-b4). The cairn is listed by the checklist, and sited at SW 6683 1929 (b4). However, in 1971, the OS surveyor visited and found that the checklist siting is almost certainly in error because it does not fall on the cliff edge, as stated by Borlase (b2), and it is not 'three or four hundred yards' from another barrow on the cliff (10540). The true site of the cairn was not established (h1).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1973. MJF/OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: The site of a barrow excavated by WC Borlase c1870, in which was found a ribbon-handled urn.
Site_description: A barrow on the cliff at Angrouse was explored by WC Borlase in about 1870 (h1). It was 30ft (9.0m) in diameter, 3ft to 4ft (0.9m-1.2m) high, and completely composed of earth. In a shallow pit in the centre was an upright ribbon-handled urn, with a flat stone on its mouth, filled with bones and ashes (b1). In 1973, the OS surveyor visited the probable site of the barrow (h2). He found a rough amorphous mound 10.4m across and up to 0.6m high, but it was impossible to tell whether this is the excavated remains of a barrow or a spoil heap from the dismantled radio station. Possibly the barrow was completely levelled by Borlase's excavation (h2).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1973. MJF/OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: One of a large barrow group, most of which is now destroyed.<gg summary>: Barrowfields 1 with inverted urned cremation
Site_description: Part of a large barrow group most of which is now destroyed (4666) this barrow was excavated by Canon Rogers in 1840 (b1, b2). He describes it as being on the cliff, a mile from Newquay and the largest in the area (3.7m high). It had a surrounding ditch, 1.5m wide by 1.5m deep, cut partly into the slate rock. Much of the mound had already been taken away for manure and urns had been found but not preserved. Rogers cut two trenches in to the mound; one 1.2m wide at its base and the second through the centre, which showed soft earth covering a 1.5m deep mounds of burnt stones which lay 1.8m below the mound summit. No internment was found beneath the stones, but an urn containing cremated bones was discovered in the mound. It rested mouth downwards on a flat stone as a middle Bronze Age Type E food vessel with everted rim, having coarse and badly fired dark fabric. It is now at Truro Museum. This excavated barrow may be the same site as the extant remains described in 4666.04 and / or the supposedly destroyed barrow described in 4666.09. A small mound is visible on vertical aerial photographs (p1) at this location, immediately to the south of barrow 4666.04.

Site_summary: One of a large barrow group, most of which is now destroyed.<gg summary>: This is Barrowfields Barrow 2. Cremation in inverted Food Vessel
Site_description: Part of a large barrow group most of which is now destroyed (4666). Borlase notes that fragments of another urn of similar type to that from Rogers 1840 excavation (4666.01) were found in the vicinity and are also at Truro Museum (b1). This urn find could represent a third barrow excavation during the C19, and it may have come from one of the surviving barrows (4666.03 or 4666.04).

Site_summary: One of a large barrow group, most of which is now destroyed.<gg summary>: This is Barrowfields Barrow 3. mound of burnt stones and cinerary urns containing cremated bones. Poor detail as the urns were found when the barrow was destroyed for manure in 1820 and five cinerary urns were found. Five cinerary urns were discovered near the top, each covered by a flat stone. A cist containing burnt bones was found at the bottom of the barrow, but had no grave goods Flint arrowheads were found around the bones but may be from mound rather that actual grave goods
Site_description: Part of a large barrow group most of which is now destroyed (4666). A destroyed barrow is described in the West Briton (b1, b2). It was destroyed for manure in 1820, when five cinerary urns were discovered near the top, each covered by a flat stone. A cist containing burnt bones was found at the bottom of the barrow. One of several flint arrowheads from the mound was presented to Truro Museum. Though this mound is described as being destroyed in 1820, it may be that excavated by Canon Rogers in 1840 (4666.01), as this barrow was partially removed for manure before he dug into it (JR).

Site_summary: One of a large barrow group, most of which is now destroyed.<gg summary>: Barrowfields 4, very close to the others. Cist found near top of barrow with capstone containing an urn (Trevisker) resting on a flat stone and covered by another and containing burnt bones. Larger cist at base of barrow with blue slate stone capping. Contained inhumation but no grave goods
Site_description: Part of a large barrow group most of which is now destroyed (4666). A destroyed barrow described in the West Briton (b1, b2). It was destroyed for hedging stone in 1821 and a cinerary urn was discovered near the top restng on a flat stone and covered by another. It was enclosed by two flat stones "placed so as to form a covering similar to the roof of a house". There was a central stone lined grave at the bottom of the barrrow, containing an inhumation, covered by a large flat stone.

Site_summary: One of a large barrow group, most of which is now destroyed.<gg summary>: Note several flint arrowheads were found in the mound ; it is possible that some of these (?barbed and tanged) were associated directly with the urned cremations but this cannot be proven (around the urns and in the cave were found a quantity of arrow points). This newspaper cuttiing (5th February 1819) describes this: "A few days since, as the workmen of Mr. Cardell of Tretherras in Lower St. Columb, were removing a mound or barrow, in one of his fields, they discovered at about nine feet from the surface, four urns and a stone coffin, all of which contained human bones, which had been exposed to the fire. Owing to the carelessness of the workmen, three of the urns were broken, the fourth was preserved, nearly perfect, by the attention of Mr. Martyn, of Lower Saint Columb, and is now in the possession of Mr. H. Willyams, one of the Vice Presidents of the Cornwall Philosophical and Literary Institution. It has the appearance of being of great antiquity. A number of flints, such as were anciently used for pointing missiles etc. were also found near the urns (Douch 1962, 93)Only the four urned cremation burials are recorded here
Site_description: Part of a large barrow group most of which is now destroyed (4666). A destroyed barrow (the exact site of which is unknown) described in the West Briton (b1-b3). It was destroyed in 1819, when four urns and a cist were found, 2.7m from the surface, all containing cremated bones. Three urns were broken, but the fourth is preserved and is in possession of Mr H Williams. A number of arrow heads were also found.

Site_summary: One of a line of barrows on Bears Down.<gg summary>: also known as Denzell Down. Digging the barrow produced a small handled cup and three cremations. The handled cup is a ceramic facsimile of the precious cups of amber or gold Two cremations without gg and both unurned
Site_description: The second northernmost of the line of barrows on Bears Down. It is a bowl barrow 3.0m high and 22m across. It is steep sided and has a large deep pit in the middle, dug by the army in 1945 (h4). Scheduled and under grass. According to the parish checklist, this is the barrow excavated by WC Borlase in 1871, which produced a small handled cup and three cremations (b3). The barrow is said to have had the interment placed centrally and to have contained "strata of different coloured soils" (b1, b2, b7). A miniature cup is fully described and illustrated by various authors (b8-b11). The monument was included in the Schedule on 10/2/1958 and the scheduling was revised on 11/8/2003.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1956. ADS / DOE2: 1959. UNKNOWN / DOE3: 1964. GHP / OS4: 1979. PAS / DOE5: 1981. PAS / DOE--------------------------------

Site_summary: An outlier to a line of barrows on Bears Down.<gg summary>: Bears Down or Denzell Down barrow 2. Collared Urn cremation with bronze knife Also known as Mawgan in Pyder.Note although this urn is described as massive (Borlase suggests 40-60cm tall), it is recorded by Longworth as quite small. Only 16.5cm tall and 31cm mouth diameter
Site_description: This barrow, first recorded by WC Borlase as "Densil barrow, a notable tumulus", is the western outlier to the line of barrows on Bears Down. In 1871, while ploughing around the outside, "of the barrow nearest Denzell farm", an urn between 60cm and 90cm high was found, and is illustrated by Borlase. The pottery was very heavy, up to an inch thick and very well fired, decorated with impressed cord. Within the urn was found burnt bones and a bronze knife (b6). The current location of the finds is unknown. The barrow remains as a mound 2.5m high and 18m across with a large crater in the middle. It is Scheduled and lies within moorland (h4). The monument was included in the Schedule on 8/1/1959 and the scheduling was revised on 11/8/2003.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1956. ADS / DOE2: 1959. UNKNOWN / DOE3: 1964. GHP / OS4: 1979. PAS / DOE5: 1981. PAS / DOE--------------------------------

Site_summary: Remains of a barrow excavated by Edmonds in 1847.<gg summary>: Cist in a barrow half way between the impressive stone circle of the Merry Maidens and the Pipers standing stones. Large two-handled pot of Early Bronze Age date containing cremated human skeletal material with two mullers and a quern associated, in a cist in a barrow near a stone circle. Quern covered pot mouth as a pot lid Could this vessel be transitional E-MBA (has Collared Urn tendencies and is ribbon-handled urn)
Site_description: A barrow at Boleigh is recorded by Edmonds in 1848 which when opened in 1847 was found to contain a cist (28210.1) in which stood an earthen pot (28210.2) containing a considerable quantity of ashes. The cist was surrounded by two circular walls 1.2m high, and of 3.0m and 5.4m diameters, each consisting of a row of unshapen stones laid on their edges (b1). Edmond's description is also mentioned in 1872 by WC Borlase, and the barrow is shown on his plan (barrow 'E') (b3). Marked on the OS map of 1908 (b4), the barrow was surveyed by the OS at 1:2500 in 1960. The remains are indicated on the ground by a group of large stones, probably retaining stones, which form a pear-shaped enclosure measuring 12m by approx 9.0m. The stones are from 0.5m to 1.0m high and are topped by modern building to make a wall up to 2.0m high. The interior is at normal ground level and there is no trace of a cist in the grass and bracken which covers the interior (h1). The site of a tumulus is shown on the OS map of 1962 (b5). Russell in 1971 lists the extant remains of a barrow at Boleigh, with part of the retaining wall now incorporated into a field wall (b6). The enclosure formed by the retaining wall of the barrow is visible on vertical aerial photographs taken in 1973 (p1).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. QUINNELL, NV / OS--------------------------------<MCO26961>: A barrow (28210) at Boleigh is recorded by Edmonds in 1848 which when opened in 1847 was found to contain a cist in which stood an earthen pot (28210.2) containing a considerable quantity of ashes. The cist was covered by a large heap of stones and earth (b1). Edmonds' description is also mentioned in 1872 by WC Borlase, and the barrow is shown on his plan (barrow 'E') (b3). The OS who surveyed the remains of the barrow at 1:2500 in 1960, record that there is no trace of a cist in the grass and bracken which covers the interior (h1).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. QUINNELL, NV / OS--------------------------------<MCO228>: A barrow (28210) at Boleigh is recorded by Edmonds in 1848 which when opened in 1847 was found to contain a cist (28210.1) in which stood an earthen pot, upright, and containing a considerable number of ashes (b1). WC Borlase in 1872 mentions Edmonds' drawing of the perforated handle of the urn, which he says resembles another found at Angrowse in Mullion, and which he illustrates (b3). Patchett in 1946 describes the urn which was destroyed during excavation but measured 51cm by 40cm. The fragments were preserved with handles attached and presented to the Penzance Natural History and Antiquarian Society, and are classified as a Middle Bronze Age, Class B, ribbon-handled urn (b4). Russell in 1971 records the find in her listings for the barrow (b5).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. QUINNELL, NV / OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: A reference to Norden describing the excavation of a barrow in the withiel area.Cist in barrow with a thick earthen pot with cremationNo further descriptive detail about this vessel <GREAT quote> <a buriall hill, wher of ther are manie in theis partes, in the time of the Romish, Saxon and Danish wars occasioned to be made, founde in the bottome of the borow, 3 whyte stones sett triangularly as pillar  supportinge another stone nere a yard square, and under it a earthern Pott verie thyck, haulfe full of black slymye matter, seeminge to have been the congealed ashes of some worthy man, ther comitted in this manner to his buriall ; the like wherof have been, and are often founde,>
Site_description: Borlase, quoting Norden, says that an "earthen pott verie thyck" containing a cremation was found within a cist while digging one of the many barrows in the Withiel area a few years before 1584 (b1, b3). Carew gives the name of the barrow as "Borns", identified with Bosneives at SW 998 662 (b4, b5). Gilbert says that "while digging down the barrow a workman found three white stones laid triangular wise as pillars and supporting a flat stone of about 2 and a half feet square" (b2). It is not possible to identify this barrow from those known in Withiel parish nor is there a site visible in the vicinity of Bosneives though the site may be identified with Tregawne barrow (26112) (h1).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1972. OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: A barrow found at Bosavern-ros c1840, containing three urns, bones and ashes.<gg summary>: This is the westernmost barrow . It state sthat there was a kind of door vault which led into this barrow. The ones that are mentioned are ribbon-handled urns in cists. Four urns with cremated bone - all of diffrent sizes
Site_description: A barrow was found at Bosavern-ros c1840. Buller records that it contained three urns, bones and ashes (b2, b3).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. GEARY, E/OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: Remains of a barrow partly excavated by WC Borlase in 1864.<gg summary>: Central cist with a cremation and dagger rivets. Tow other satellite pits with small quantities of cremated bone but no grave goods
Site_description: Overgrown stone and earth barrow lying 25m to the south-east of Boscawen-un stone circle (16030), within improved flat pasture. Partly excavated in 1864 by WC Borlase who unearthed a central stone cist containing cremated ashes and bronze rivets (b2). Two satellite pits were also discovered (b2). Shown on OS maps of 1908 and surveyed by the OS in 1960 (h1) and sketch surveyed by sharpe for CAU in 1985 (h2, b6, b7). Field visit by the OS in 1985 (h3), who noted that the north-east part of the mound had been effaced by a later hedge. In overgrown and poor condition, the barrow is an ill-defined stone and earth mound of up to 0.6m high and has been ploughed over, in recent times. Part of barrow group 16031 and associated with other ceremonial sites, 16029 and 16030 in the immediate locality. The monument is included in the Schedule.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. PITCHER, GH / OS2: 1985. SHARPE, A / CAU3: 1985. FLETCHER, MJ / OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: Site of barrow to the south-west of Boscawen-un stone circle.<gg summary>: Urned cremation accompanied by miniature vessel (mini Collared Urn), broken saddle quern, burnt animal bone and a burnt bronze pyre object
Site_description: Site of barrow 50m south-west of Boscawen-un stone circle (16030) within improved pasture on farming plain. Excavated by WC Borlase in 1864 (b1, b2) who discovered that the structure of this feature was essentially a ring of stones (a probable kerb) of unrecorded diameter which enclosed a large granite outcrop known as 'The Money Rock' (b3). Cremated remains and fragments of a large urn were found, together with a smaller complete upturned urn and part of a mortar stone (b2, b6). Patchett classified the complete urn as MBA class C (b6) and it was removed to Penzance Museum (b4). A site visit by the OS in 1960 noted no extant remains and no traces of 'The Money Rock' which Pitcher noted had been removed before 1901 (h1). Sketch surveyed by Sharpe for CAU in 1985 who noted area grassed over and no extant remains except a single lynchet of up to 4.0m wide (h2, b8, b9). Probably once part of barrow group 16031.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. PITCHER, GH / OS2: 1985. SHARPE, A / CAU--------------------------------

Site_summary: The eastern barrow in a group of three, excavated by WC Borlase in 1878. Also known as Carn Polpry.<gg summary>: Very interesting sequence of urned cremations in ribbon-handled vessels. Some unusual grave goods with a female cremation include faience beads and a stone V perforated button.  Also mention of a glass globular vessel Note some of the pots were seemingly fired on the pyre
Site_description: The eastern barrow in a group of three (28441) at Boscregan was excavated by WC Borlase in 1878 and described by him in 1879. A trench carried through the centre revealed a rough wall enclosing an area 1.8m in diameter. Within the inner wall ten deposits of pottery were found including two Middle Bronze Age urns (28441.11) and a food vessel (28441.12), three perforated stones (28441.13) and flints (28441.14) (b1). Mentioned by Russell in 1959 (b2), and surveyed by the OS at 1:2500 in 1960, who found a hollowed out mound of earth and stone 8.0m in diameter with a maximum height of 0.9m. Only one of the retaining stones still exists in the north west quadrant (h1). Russell in 1971 lists the extant remains of barrow (b3). The barrow was Scheduled c1960 and Sheppard in 1980 reports a grass interior with gorse exterior, in cliff pasture with a coastal footpath alongside, and having a good stone kerb (b4), with no change in 1982 (b5). Scheduled as Carn Polpry round barrow.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. GEARY, E / OS--------------------------------<MCO258>: WC Borlase in 1879 records ten deposits of pottery from the excavated east barrow at Boscregan in 1878 (28441.1), including two cinerary urns (b1). Patchett in 1944 classifies the urns as Middle Bronze Age Class B ribbon handled type (b2). Russell in 1971 lists the finds in her entry for the east barrow (b3).<MCO259>: WC Borlase in 1879 records ten deposits of pottery from the excavated east barrow at Boscregan in 1878 (28441.1) (b1). Patchett in 1950 identifies the fragment of a small urn as a probable food vessel accompanying a large cinerary urn. The fragment is now in the British Museum (b2). Russell in 1971 lists the find in her entry for the east barrow (b3).

Site_summary: The probable site of a barrow in which a cist was found in 1842<gg summary>: cist with two Collared Urns and other grave goods ; includes two perforated very rectangular-shaped whetstones, one of black marble. Also a dagger
Site_description: A cist found at Brane found during the removal of a hedge in 1842 (28663) suggests the site of a barrow. Patchett in 1946 refers to the urns (28663.1) described by WC Borlase, which were found in the hedge which were probably part of an old barrow (b6). The OS in 1960 were unable to identify any remains of a barrow in the area (h1).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. GEARY, E / OS--------------------------------<MCO27021>: A cist at Brane, found when a hedge was demolished in 1842 is mentioned by Buller (b1) and described by WC Borlase as having contained two urns (28663.1) with bones and ashes, two perforated whetstones (28663.2) and a knife (28663.3) (b2). Patchett in 1946 describes two urns found in a hedge on Brane Common in what was probably part of an old barrow (28663.4) (b6). Russell in 1971 lists the cist but records no extant remains (b8).<MCO301>:Two urns found in a cist at brane (28663) are described by wc borlase. One urn broke into pieces when removed from the cist. The other, presented to penzance museum, had rough unpierced bosses or handles. Both were filled with ashes and bones. The height of the intact urn is given as 0.3M and the diameter at the mouth, 0.22M (b2). Patchett in 1946, brom borlase's descfription, identifies the urns as middle bronze age class d, of overhanging rim type (b6). Russell in 1971 lists the urns in her entry for the cist (b8).<MCO302>: Two perforated whetstones found in a cist at brane (28663) are dewsribed by wc borlase. At the side of each of two urns (28663.1) In the cist, lay a neatly formed oblong stone perforated at one end (b2). Russell in 1971 lists the whetstones in her entry for the cict (b8).

Site_summary: One of a group of three barrows on Carloggas Downs.This is Caerloggas I<gg summary>: little evidence for human bone was noted, due to acidic nature of the soils. Two pits lay either side of the central stone; that on the north was undisturbed and contained unidentifiable bone, flints pebbles and a large quartz crystal. The southern pit was disturbed but also contained artefacts including amber beads, a piece of slag and parts of a dagger. The whole thing was later covered by turves and capped with clay. There was little evidence of any burials.Other finds included two fragments of a bronze dagger and seven pieces of glassy slag (or maybe even faience)  - all from one lump - from beneath the turfNote in cairn and levelling fabric and cairn material were other objects but not grave goods directly associated with burials. There were 2 bronze dagger fragments of Early Bronze Age date from the levelling turves. Tin slag was found in the levelling, in the form of glass slag with globules in it, evidence for smelting nearby. From the soil in the west interior came an amber fragment, possibly from an amulet.<cenotaph>
Site_description: One of a group of three barrows on Carloggas Down. The site was known in 1357 as Carludden (b5) and is the only one of the three barrows to appear on early OS editions. It was Scheduled until fully excavated by Henrietta Miles in 1972 (h2).The excavation revealed a ring cairn or enclosure 25m across and 1.0m high with an entrance to the south-west. It had been built in a manner indicating ritual purposes, focused on a central moorstone boulder. Two pits lay either side of the central stone; that on the north was undisturbed and contained unidentifiable bone, flints pebbles and a large quartz crystal. The southern pit was disturbed but also contained artefacts including amber beads, a piece of slag and parts of a dagger. The whole thing was later covered by turves and capped with clay. There was little evidence of any burials.Other finds included two fragments of a bronze dagger and seven pieces of glassy slag - all from one lump - from beneath the turf. One hundred and five quartz pebbles and two hundred and eight pieces of flint were found, including arrowheads, scrapers and various blades and flakes. A serpentine bead and a number of other worked stone artefacts were also recovered. The barrow is visible on aerial photos (p1) and has been plotted as part of the NMP.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1968. ANK / OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: The remains of a barrow at Carn Creis, excavated by WC Borlase in 1878.<gg summary>: some of this detail from this site has been conflated with SID_10020 BoscreganThis is Carn Creis 2. EBA Trevisker urns x 2, one containing cremation ; also 'olive green glass' - possibly faience bead?
Site_description: The remains of a barrow 5.5m in diamater at Carn Creis was excavated by WC Borlase in 1878. The remains consisted of a ring of stones with a large natural rock in the centre, with the filling removed on all but the south side where it was 0.6m deep. Within this four urns of varying size were found (28443.02), a possible button (28443.07) and a leaf shaped arrowhead (28443.09). The OS who surveyed the barrow at 1:2500 in 1960 found Borlase's description to be generally correct. Six stones of the circle are still in situ and a slight depression around the natural rock in the centre is probably due to excavation, a slight bank of earth and stones with an overall diameter of 8.0m and a maximum height of 0.5m is retained by means of the circle (h1). Russell in 1971 lists the extant remains of a barrow at Carn Creis (b3). The barrow was Scheduled in 1972 and is described by Sheppard in 1980 and 1982 as showning a 2.4m length of revetment in the interior which is almost denuded, surrounded by gorse and cliff grass (b4, b5).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. GEARY, E / OS--------------------------------<MCO26988>: WC Borlase records the find of burnt human bones contained in some of the four urns found during his excavation in 1878 of a barrow at Carn Creis (28443) (b1). Russell in 1971 lists the find in her entry for the barrow (b3).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. GEARY, E / OS--------------------------------<MCO367>: Four urns of varying size were found in a barrow at Carn Creis (28443) when excavated by WC Borlase in 1878 (b1), and are now at the RIC (b2). Henken records parts of a large biconical pot with knobs pierced with string holes, containing cremated remains. A biconical broken handled pot with cord ornament was also found, and a crude broken pot, again containing burnt remains (b3). Patchett in 1944 lists three Middle Bronze Age ribbon handled urns, biconical with sides somewhat rounded with an internal bevel to the rim of 20cm diameter, and with a base of 19cm. Each urn has two ribbon handles 5cm wide and a perforation of 1.3cm diameter. Their thickness ranges from 1.3cm to 0.95cm with a rather fine though black and earthy paste. The decoration is of pressed cord with very angled chevrons below the rim and over the handles and in lines on the bevel (b4). Russell in 1971 lists the find of three Middle Bronze Age urns in her entry for the barrow (b5).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. GEARY, E / OS--------------------------------<MCO368>: Four urns of varying sizes were found in a barrow at Carn Creis (28443) when excavated by WC Borlase in 1878 (b1), and are now at the RIC (b2). Hencken records a small pot of biconical shape with little knobs for handles (b3). Patchett in 1944 lists a Late Bronze Age biconical urn 10cm in height and with a base of 9.5cm. It has two truncated lugs, the paste is thick, and the colour is red inside and yellow outside with no decoration (b4). Russell in 1971 lists the find in her entry for the barrow (b5).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. GEARY, E / OS--------------------------------<MCO369>: Hencken records sherds of hard backed, sand glazed pottery found by WC Borlase in 1878 during excavation of a barrow at Carn Creis (28443) which was accompanied by burnt human remains (b2). Russell in 1971 lists the sherds in her entry for the barrow (b3).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. GEARY, E / OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: Site of a possible barrow containing a cremation urn, discovered in 1876.<gg summary>: Inverted Trevisker urn containing cremated remains of a young person
Site_description: A possible barrow containing bones in a pot, perhaps a cremation in an urn, was found in 1876 by a miner digging foundations for buildings at Carn Entral (b1). Tangye quotes a contemporary account from the West Briton, which describes the remains found as "a large earthenware pan or 'bussa' about 25 to 30 inches in diameter, with the mouth down, about three feet from the surface . . . (containing) the remains of a human body . . . (which) was about fifteen or sixteen years of age. No idea could be found how long it had remained there (b3).

Site_summary: One of a group of 3 barrows in Carnon Downs.<gg summary>: Two disturbed cremations, one with a small (miniature) pot. The cairn appeared to be heavily burnt. The centre was disturbed, a small Bronze Age pot being thrown out by intruders. There was a secondary burial in the north west quadrant, accompanied by a wooden spoon-like object, according to Bristow. However Dudley in the primary archive makes no reference to this wooden spoon, so this is dubious
Site_description: One of a group of 3 barrows in Carnon Downs (9028-9030). This barrow, 1.7m high in 1965 (h1), was excavated in 1967 by Dorothy Dudley in advance of building works on the site. It had been disturbed in the centre, though the soil had been carefully replaced, and this fill included a small Bronze Age pottery vessel. The mound was carefully built of local red clay, topsoil and peat. There was a secondary burial in the north-west quadrant. The barrow centre was surrounded by a ring of stake holes, diameter 6.0m. One sherd of Bronze Age pottery was found in the north-west quadrant. Neither burial area revealed any evidence except burning (b1). Now removed by building development.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1965. PALMER, J/OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: A barrow recorded by Thomas in 1851, excavated by Dudley in 1954, and now visible as a spread cropmark on aerial photographs.Actually comprised three small cairns <gg summary>: A quartz-covered bowl barrow 70 feet in diameter wasexcavated for the Ministry of Works by Miss D. Dudley. A pink-coated, staked platform was discovered with two quartz cairns over round and oval pits having three cremations—one inurned. Finds included stone discs, thumbstone whetstone and quern, and sherds of five pots, four probably food vessels, but it is unclear where  these came from. It is likely that most came from the mound. There were two scatterings of Trevisker II ware potsherds on the barrow top, one including 2 stone discs.The ceramic associations at Carvinack are significant because it is the only site in Cornwallwhere three different ceramic types, Beaker, Food Vessels and Trevisker Ware have been found in association sealed by a moundThe site profile appears to indicate that mourners stripped the original turf surface in a ring around a central area at some point in the history of the site before the ring and quartz cairn were built. On the central turf surface mourners excavated four circular hollows or shallow pits. Three of the hollows were 0.20 m deep.Note this site is useful for looking at complex mortuary practices and later funerary offerings etc. Several pits with quartz or just burnt material and charcoal and burnt stones Remains of at least four separate ceramic vessels in two groups lay near the surface of the barrow (one associated with two small slate discs), close to the top in the south-east quadrant. It is not entirely clear whether these sherds were deposited on, or concurrent with the white quartz and grey soil cap, though the excavator considers the former to have been the likely case. They consisted of a barrel shaped Trevisker Style I or 2 vessel, a Collared vessel decorated with bird bone impressions, a handled vessel, and several sherds of a fourth vessel (Owoc 2000: 277)
Site_description: One of a group of probably three barrows at Carvinack, described by Thomas in 1851 (b2) as a low barrow 40ft (12.2m) in diameter. It was excavated in 1954 by Dudley for the MOW and was written up in PPS 25 (1959). It was there described as being 70ft (21.3m) in diameter, covered in quartz, and containing three cremations, one of them inurned. Sherds of five pots were found, most of them probably food vessels (h2). The barrow was totally destroyed by this excavation. The barrow is clearly visible as a mound on vertical photographs taken in 1946 (p1). It was not completely destroyed by Dudley's excavations as it is visible as a very spread cropmark on aerial photographs taken in 1969 (p2).--------------------------------Site history:2: 1965. PITCHER, GH/OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: One of a line of six barrows that stood on Cataclews Point.<gg summary>: single burial of young woman with flake and smashed Trevisker pot smashed above Ribbon handled urn Several broken pots of Trevisker 1 and 2 not connected spatially with cremation so not a grave good Mrs Hurn's urn found nearby on adjacent cliff
Site_description: One of a line of six barrows that stood on Cataclews Point. It is now Scheduled but its condition is uncertain, the OS saying that it has been obscured by spoil from the quarry (h5), and the DOE saying that one third has been cut away on the west side (h7). The barrow is approx 12m across and 1.1m high (h6). Little is known about possible excavation, but apparently quarrymen took away some stone in the war, possibly from the area rather than from the barrow itself (h6). Mr Hellyar may have recovered an urn from this barrow.(b7) - Hellyar, L, 1954, Pers Comm to OS, , --------------------------------Site history:5: 1954. ALFR/OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: The westernmost of the line of six barrows on Cataclews Point.<gg summary>: Westernmost barrow in groups at Cataclews points. This is barrow 1. A low, double-kerbed mound covered a fire and a stone cist containing cremated bone. Sherds of several Bronze Age pots, which had been scattered over the central cairn, were recovered from the mound.Note previous excavations in 1912 by Dr Penrose Williams at this barrow recovered several grave goods. The finds from the previous excavations, at Harlyn Bay  which consist of a stone battle-axe, a food vessel and a collared urn, have been published (Crawford, 1921, 291—3) and are in Truro museum. (these may be from other barrow however)One Food Vessel was noted. Possibly from this barrow was a Collared Urn with handles and cord-ornament but there are no further details of the discovery Note: Four or five pots are represented by the 122 sherds found strewn over the centralarea of the cairn. The form and the cordimpressed decoration of P8 and P l l would attribute them to styles 1 or 2 of the Trevisker series. P10, a plain shoulder sherd, may be related to P8 by its similar, if not identical, fabric. The everted, cord-impressed rim of PI2 might be matched in the Trevisker or food vessel traditions. Also some stone tools and flakes found in mound
Site_description: The westernmost of the line of six barrows on Cataclews Point; it was excavated by CK Croft Andrew in 1944, apparently as the quarry was planned to extend into this area. The site was still visible as an area of cleared rock in 1954 (h6). The barrow was 9.1m in diameter and 0.6m high, sited on a natural knoll. Excavation revealed it to comprise a mound of earth over a cairn of small stones and earth which covered a pair of concentric kerbs of large stones. The kerbs enclosed a central area with a cist. The circular outer kerb was left open to view; the inner kerb, ellliptical in plan meauring 6.2m N-S  and 7.4m E-W, touched the outer kerb on the western side.  No entrance gaps were left in the kerbs. A low cairn of smallish stones and earth was raised over the kerbs and central area; on this was an outer covering of yellow sandy soil in which were four or five incomplete pots. Two vessels were in the Trevisker style, another possibly so, and one, perhaps two, were plain (b9). No organic layer representing a buried land surface was noted beneath the barrow mound: only 2.5-5.1cm of reddish soil.Burnt material was located immediately west of the mound's centre, beneath the barrow floor, represented by a charred area (1.2m x 2.3m) and on this lay a mass of charcoal with a few fragments of bone. The charring reached a depth of only 5.1cm (b8). Radiocarbon dating of an oak heartwood sample from this deposit returned a date of 3510 70 BP (HAR-8099) - current calibration provides a date of 2_ 2030-1660 cal BC. This date can be taken as a terminus post quem for the construction of the barrow and for the pottery incoporated in its capping (b10).A cist measuring 0.48m by 0.3m, constructed from Cataclews stone, was found in the south-east part of the inner kerb. The coverstone had rotted and collapsed into the cremation deposit beneath, which was 7cm deep, and contained the remains of what was possibly a single young female (b9).A number of pebbles were found in the barrow, and there was a number of flint and chert artefacts, but this was mostly Mesolithic in character and probably associated with earlier occupation of the area (b9).(b7) - Hellyar, L, 1954, Pers Comm to OS, , --------------------------------Site history:5: 1954. ALFR/OS--------------------------------

Site_name_other: CHAPEL CARN BREA - Bronze Age barrow
Site_summary: The remains of a barrow containing a stone-lined cist sealed by a capstone, which contained earth, a cremation urn and three flint flakes.<gg summary>: Chapel Carn Brea B. The cist contained earth, a few bones and three flint flakes, and a very finely decorated biconical urn of great size and with large handles which held the partially cremated bones of a small person, overhanging rim Collared type Note - Another incomplete urn was found on the western edge of the site away from the cist.
Site_description: On the densely overgrown south facing moorland slopes of Chapel Carn Brea are the remains of a barrow first recorded on the 1906 OS map (b1). Partly excavated by King and Polkinghorne in 1907 who showed that the site contained a stone-lined cist which was sealed by a capstone and which contained earth, a cremation urn and three flint flakes (h2, b2, b3, b6, b7). Another incomplete urn was found on the western edge of the site away from the cist. The cist was found within a mound of stone and earth and part of a retaining wall was uncovered (b8). The site was surveyed by the OS in 1960 (h3) who supply most up to date details, since Gerrard's sketch survey of the area in 1985 added no further information (h4, b9, b10). The OS record a very disturbed granite rubble and granite mound of 0.7m high and 7.0m in diameter. There were no remains of a cist only a displaced granite slab or capstone measuring 1.8m by 1.2m and 0.4m thick (h3). The site is overgrown and forms part of a barrow group (16073). Revisited by the OS in 1985 who add that the kerb lies only on the west of the site consisting of five contiguous slabs and blocks 0.3m high (h5). The barrow is visible on aerial photographs (p1,2,3) as a low earth mound and was plotted as part of the NMP.--------------------------------Site history:2: 1915. HENDERSON, C / -3: 1960. PITCHER, GH / OS4: 1985. GERRARD, G / CAU5: 1985. QUINNELL, N / OS--------------------------------

Site_name_other: CHAPEL CARN BREA - Bronze Age barrow, Bronze Age entrance grave
Site_summary: Remains of a complex round barrow partly excavated by WC Borlase in 1868.<gg sumary>: Chapel Carn Brea A. Entrance grave.  A central chamber, and beside it a narrow stone-lined trench: in both were cremated remains and pieces of broken pots. In the chamber was a (dubious) whetstone, a spindle whorl, and some sherds amid slimy earth and stone mingled with ashy material possibly fallen in from above. Higher up in the cairn was a fine but empty cist 'of the more usual Bronze Age type'.Empty cist higher up in cairn - tiny amount of ash suggests a disturbed cremation
Site_description: On the summit of Chapel Carn Brea are the remains of a complex round barrow which was partly excavated by WC Borlase in 1868 (h1) and 1879 (h2) and was planned by Lukis in 1885 (h3, b3). Excavations revealed a complex structure of three concentric walls within the cairn retained by a 15ft (4.6m) retaining wall (h4, b10). In the centre of the barrow was a drystone walled chamber half sunk in a pit measuring 2.3m long and 1.1m wide and standing up to 1.2m high. This contained a stone lined cist which held cremated remains and pot sherds. Another cist was found higher up in the cairn which is still visible. Pottery, a whetstone and a spindle whorl were found during excavations. A samian sherd (16075) was found in the upper layers. A medieval chapel (16074) stood on the cairn until 1816, when it was demolished to build a barn (b3). During WW2 a shelter was dug into the east side of the cairn (traces of which are still recognisable) and an observation post was built on the summit of the mound. The site is now in a very mutilated condition (h4, b10, b14). It requires sensitive conservation management, survey and perhaps limited investigation of the structure. The monument is included in the Schedule. The barrow is visible on aerial photographs (p1-2) as a low earth mound and was plotted as part of the NMP.--------------------------------Site history:3: 1885. LUKIS, WC4: 1960. PITCHER, GH / OS5: 1985. GERRARD, GAM / CAU6: 1990. THOMAS, N / CAU--------------------------------

Site_summary: A barrow called 'One Barrow' was demolished in 1801.<gg summary>: cremation in urn in cist - Collared Urn . There is confusion about this barrow as there is also a note of an urn with 4 lugs coming from this barrow but it is much more likely that thsi comes from another one (Barrow 4 not Barrow 1). See Sheppard 1971: 32-33
Site_description: A barrow called 'One Barrow' was demolished in 1801. A number of vertical slabs covered by a capstone were found, enclosing a square space of about 50cm, in which were found a number of badly degraded bones. The whole barrow rose to approx 3.0m and did not seem to have been disturbed (see 20341.9; this is clearly not the same barrow). The stones were rebuilt carefully in a hedge and the ashes and bones deposited there (b3). It is not known exactly which barrow this one was; there was no mention of an urn which was later said to have been found at this time. Although Sheppard suggests the records are not inextricably confused, he does not seem able to add any clarity (b9).

Site_summary: This barrow was given the same name as one later flattened and this barrow may have some survival.<gg summary>: Charlestown 2 barrowCremation of ?child in small 4-handled urn
Site_description: Although Williams investigated most of the barrows on the downs to the east of St Austell to some extent, he seems to have concentrated on one (b1, b7). He found it to be made of two circles of stone with an oblong pit in the middle, the bottom of which was black and greasy. A slab inside the outer ring of stone covered a carefully protected urn (20341.10). Although this barrow was given the same name as one later flattened it was probably different as the description was so different (20341.11). The barrow may be extant to a small extent (b8); the records of the excavation are discussed by Sheppard in (b7), without adding greatly to the clarity of the problem.

Site_summary: A barrow within Chycarne tenement in which 50 cinerary urns were recovered in 1733<gg summary>: all but the principal finely decorated urn were not kept. Note this sounds very much like a MBA flat cremation cemetery, but it most likely EBA or EBA transition
Site_description: Site of a barrow, now destroyed, within Chycarne tenement (b1). Discovered by Williams, a yeoman, in 1733 (h1) who removed a barrow allegedly containing 50 cinerary urns. A central stone-lined cist was reported (b1) around which had been deposited the urns containing cremated bone. A finely decorated urn, the principle one, formed the main deposit. All but this main urn were thrown away (h2). Borlase failed to find the exact location of this site (b2) and the OS in 1961 discovered no further information about the site (h2). Gerrard's recent survey for CAU in 1985 (h3, b4, b5) provided no further details. Hence the grid reference given is approximate. No details about present storage location of the principle urn.--------------------------------Site history:2: 1961. GEARY, E / OS3: 1985. GERRARD, GAM / CAU--------------------------------

Site_summary: A barrow in which a cist containing three urns was found is recorded at Chycarne, but the location is unknown.<gg summary> Two urns in pits with cremations - Collared Urn type ; also goat skull with one which is rare
Site_description: Site of barrow, location unknown, at Chycarne near Chapel Carn Brea. Hencken wrote in 1932 that a cist was found under a barrow at Chycarn and that it contained three "bucket-shaped" urns, as well as the skull of a goat or ram and possible human cremations (b3). Patchett dated the urns to later Bronze Age, Class F, ribbon handled and overhanging rim tradition (b4). The finds are at Truro Museum. The OS wrote in 1961 (h1) that location of this barrow was unclear and that source of Hencken's information undiscovered. Since there are other barrows in the area (16079, 16082), this may be anyone of them (h1). Quinnell adds that there is a marked similarity between this and the Borlase record of a Chycarne barrow (h2).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1961. GEARY, E / OS2: 1985. QUINNELL, N / OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: A barrow recorded by Thomas in 1840 could not be traced by the OS in 1972.<gg summary>: 4 urns roughly centrally. The first two comprised a large and a smaller biconical two handled vessel without recorded pits. A large biconical handled vessel was 0.9m to the north in a pit, a small vessel 0.9m to the west covered by a slab. Evidence of cremations was in two urns and by two stones 1.5m east of the last vessel. Three worked flints were found, two in close association with cremated material.At least two miniature cups from here
Site_description: A barrow is recorded on Thomas's map of c1840 at Clahar Garden (b1) which is recorded by him as having been removed c1850. It was probably about 11m in diameter and contained four cremation urns (28030.1) (b2). The OS who visited the site in 1972 record that patches of uncleared moorland exist in the ploughed field close to Thomas's siting but there is no evidence of the cairn site in any of them (h1).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1972. FLETCHER, MJ / OS--------------------------------<MCO475>: Thomas in 1851 records the removal of a round cairn (28030) on the Clahar garden estate in which was found four cremation urns. Three of the urns were middle Bronze Age, ribbon handled ii and one was late Bronze Age showing Deverel-Rimbury influence. All four urns are in the British museum (b1).

Site_summary: Cocks barrow was recorded on early maps and by Thomas; excavated in 1970 prior to removal by mineral extraction.<gg summary>: also a standing stone and several pits and also a cobbled area and 9 quartzite pebbles scattered in a pit fill. Possible burial at the foot of the Phase 1 post. The shape and size of the Phase 2 pit suggest an inhumation grave. The stones found on the bottom and sides may have been laid over a body. The acid soil would have dissolved all traces of unburnt bone.Composite barrow with double cairn ring and single cremation burial. There were also 3 'ritual pits'. which formed a rough line with the burial (pits X, Y & Z). One pit was filled with broken pieces of white quartziteNote Flint plano-convex knife and other flints in mound . Mainly blades including some microliths. Also scrapers
Site_description: Cocks barrow was recorded on early maps (b1, b2) and by Thomas (b4), who put it at 20m across. It lay on the junction of St Austell, St Mewan and St Stephen parishes. It was to be removed by mineral extraction and was therefore excavated in 1970 (h1). The excavation established the barrow as a double ring cairn. Covered by turf and capped by yellow clay, and was preceded by two post rings of  approx 45 posts, which were removed from their holes before the cairns were erected. Three non-post pits were found and contained stones and soil. The inner ring cairn was of single stones, 7.0m across with and entrance 1.0m wide at the NE. The outer ring cairn lay over the site of the post rings and was sparse in places, with an entrance 2.0m across in the SE. Various other stones were spread over the area. A burial was found in a central pit 0.8m wide and lined with rab. The body was cremated and placed in a compact mass in the hole. A horn ladle was put in the pit and it was filled with stone. The whole lot was covered by turf and then by a capping of yellow clay from a local source. The ladle was preserved by the anaerobic conditions and was 240mm long, probably from a domestic ox. 21 flints were found, mainly blades and scrapers. Two small quartz pebbles imported from the coast were found. Visible on aerial photographs (p1) and plotted as part of the NMP.

Site_summary: A previously disturbed barrow, excavated by Blight in 1865, who found animal bone and struck flint.<gg summary>: Cremation in inverted barrel urn
Site_description: A tumulus is recorded at Conquer Downs on current OS maps (b5). In 1865, this barrow was excavated by Blight, who dug a trench from the north side which had previously been disturbed. Traces of burning, animal bones and a struck flint were found (b1, b2). Survey by the OS in 1961 revealed the barrow is now an irregular grass covered mound of earth and stones. Its centre has been multilated by two pits dug almost to ground level and the perimeter has been encroached on by several trial mining pits (h1). Blight recorded the measurements of the barrow as 36ft (11m) diameter and 4ft (1.22m) high (b1).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1961. PITCHER, GH / OS2: 1975. QUINNELL, NV / OS--------------------------------

Site_name_other: COTNA - Bronze Age barrow, Bronze Age findspot
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Seven urns found at Cotna in 1854 in a field named 'Cruts Corner'.Trevisker urned cremations
Site_description: The Tithe Award of 1839 records the field-name 'Cruts Corner' which suggests the site of a barrow (b1). Sheppard lists the site but records no extant remains (b3). In 1854, "five earthen jars from twelve to twenty inches deep", filled with burnt bones, were found at a depth of 45cm, while planting trees and shrubs in the lawn at Cotna. Among the Truro Museum accessions for 1854 were portions of seven urns found at Cotna. Sheppard lists the finds and records them as now lost (b3).

Site_summary: Site of a barrow which contained two cists, excavated by Marsden in 1920.<gg summary>: disturbed round barrow with a retaining stone wall, with on the west side a cist 0.6m x 0.6m without a cover stone, containing earth in which was a coarse rim sherd and some ashes. More pottery and ashes and a few bone fragments were found in the east of the barrow. On the south side was an undisturbed  cist full of very fine mud in which was lying a Beaker like vessel (plain). No body noted but most llikely degraded inhumation One of the pots was most certainly Early Bronze Age in date
Site_description: A round barrow situated in a croft known as 'Flat Down' at Crean excavated by Marsden in 1920 is described by him as in fair condition although it had been opened previously. It had a diameter of 5.2m and contained a wall of upright stones. On the west of the barrow a cist (28273.1) was found containing a rim sherd and some ashes. In the east of the barrow was more pottery, ashes and a few bone fragments; the sherds were given to the museum of the RIC by Marsden. On the south side digging revealed a miniature cist (28273.2) full of mud and which contained an urn (28273. 21) (b2). Henderson mentions Marsden's excavation (b1) and Russell in 1960, quoting Marsden and Henderson, locates the barrow and lists no extant remains (b3). The OS in 1960 record no remains of the barrow, noting that the area has been reclaimed from moorland and was then under crop. Also noted is an amendment to Russell's grid reference, now given as SW 3869 2447 approx, and based on Henderson's sketch map (h1). Russell in 1971 lists the site and records a ring of stones surrounding two cists and two Late Bronze Age urns, but no extant remains of a barrow (b4).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. GEARY, E / OS--------------------------------<MCO26966>: During the excavation by Marsden in 1920 of a round barrow at Crean (28273), a cist measuring 0.6m square was found on the west side of the barrow with its capstone missing. The cist was full of earth and contained the rim of a Late Bronze Age vessel of course pottery (b2) which was given to the museum of the RIC by Marsden (b1, b2). Russell in 1971 lists the cist and urn in her entry for the barrow, but records no extant remains (b3).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. GEARY, E / OS--------------------------------<MCO26967>: During the excavation by Marsden in 1920 of a round barrow at Crean (28273),  an unopened miniature cist was found on the south side of the barrow. It measured 0.3m square and was full of very fine mud in which was lying a beaker-like vessel, 11.4cm high, which was given to the museum of the RIC by Marsden (b1, b2). Russell in 1971 lists the cist and urn in her entry for the barrow, but records no extant remains (b3).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. GEARY, E / OS--------------------------------

Site_name_other: CREEG MEAR BARROW - Bronze Age barrow
Site_summary: Site of a barrow destroyed in the late C17.<gg summary>: Rather little to go on and very poorly recorded. Nine coarse urns,and all contained ashes/ cremations but all destroyed by the finder in a pique of rage! Because the finder, Mitchell, was looking for lots of stones for wall making and found hardly any ! So took it out on the pots.
Site_description: Tonkin records that Creeg Mear (Great Burrow) was destroyed in the late C17 by C Mitchell, who was excavating for hedging stones. On its destruction, nine urns of very rough pottery were found within it. All were destroyed in a fit of pique since the barrow contained little stone, but led to Tonkin's belief that they contained the remains of some great leaders slain in battle, for which there is no evidence. Tonkin also mentions that the few stones that were present formed a kistvaen (b1). Nothing is visible on the site today (h1, b6).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1971. ANK/OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: The site of a barrow first recorded by an article in The Royal Cornwall Gazette 23 March 1811.<gg summary>: Urned cremation in single ribbon-handled urn
Site_description: An early reference to the barrow at Creegbrawse is made in the Royal Cornwall Gazette, 23 March 1811 which records, "On Monday the 18th of February, 1811, two labourers being employed by a person of the name of Thomas Manuell, to raze the barrow near chacewater, called Creege Broaz barrow, for the purpose of manuring a field, which he rents of Lord Falmouth, discovered a small urn at the bottom of the barrow, in the centre of its base, and 20 inches under the surface of the field. The urn was inclosed by five stones, four of which were placed on their edges, and formed a square, whilst the fifth being placed on the top became a barrier to the mingling of the superincumbent earth, with the contents of this rude sepulchre. In the urn were black ashes, and round it a considerable quantity (about 2 gallons) of ashes and human bone, in a state of great decay. The urn is made of baked clay, and of a greyish stone-colour, and in figure, resembles very much that in the 18th Plate of Borlase's Antiquities, said to be found in Perran Sands, except that it does not taper so much at the base, and is about half the size. It is 5 inches 6-8ths wide at top, 3 inches 1-4th wide at the bottom, and is 5 inches 1-4th high; the thickness is 1-4th of an inch, and it is rudely indented on the outside in a very irregular manner, with the point of some tool. It varies also from the Perran urn, in having a handle very similar to such as are now affixed to our common stone jars. The discoveres told me that a little on one side of the stones which inclosed this urn, is another very large stone, which, as they had not removed all the earth, they were not able to lift; but on my suggestion, they propose to pursue their search, and also to search amongst the ashes for coins or bits of metal, or whatever else can be discovered, the event of which, if worth communicating, you shall be apprized of---by Yours, &c.&c. T.".Lord Falmouth is identified as the occupier of "Creegbroase Downs and Roads" on the 1840 Kenwyn Tithe Map (b4).Thomas located a barrow at the top of the hill near Creegbrawse in 1850. He called it 'Creegbroas' barrow (b1) and it is later mentioned by Mclaughlin (b2). It is not detectable today (b3).

Site_summary: Crigamennis was the southernmost of a group of four barrows on Liskey Hill.<gg_summary>: EBA rc date in Quinnell 2012. Complex barrow site constructed c. 2000-1800 BC. Many activities by mourners including the central deposit. Site oriented on equinoctial sunrises & sunsets. and involved crossing water.A slate comb, possibly used to decorate pottery, and a quern fragment were recovered during the excavations.Two urns were found inverted on the periphery of the turf stack; one contained charcoal, the other burnt flint, beads and a small cone. A number of pits and charcoal patches suggested elaborate ritualsNB only tiny amounts of cremated bone (and these could even be animal)  came from inside these urns, although they were filled with large quantities of charcoal. Christie interprets these as token cremations There is also a miniature cup placed on edge of revetment and contained a food offering Note a Slate comb (possibly used to decorated the pottery) was found in the mound deposit
Site_description: Crigamennis was the southernmost of a group of four barrows on Liskey Hill that were described by Thomas in 1851 (b1). He gave its diameter as 15m.  The "Barrow" was depicted on the 1st Edition OS 25inch map of c1880  and was shown on the 2nd Edition as "Tumulus".  A small round mound is visible at this location on RAF vertical aerial photographs and was plotted by the NMP..The barrow was fully excavated by Christie in 1957 in advance of field clearance (b2, b3, h1) and no trace remains of the site today (h2). The barrow was a complex site surrounded by an irregular causewayed ditch. A central stone heap covering a hearth and an oval pit was overlain by a turf and soil mound which was stone revetted on the north and west. A narrow berm separated the revetment from the ditch. A trench cut into the natural rock on the east led into the ditch from which a ramp led up towards the central area. Two urns were found inverted on the periphery of the turf stack; one contained charcoal, the other burnt flint, beads and a small cone. A number of pits and charcoal patches suggested elaborate rituals (b3, b5).  Pollen samples from a buried soil indicated that the barrow had been constructed in a woodland clearing, with Hazel as the dominant species. No cereal pollen was present but weed seeds indicative of disturbed ground could have been due to local cultivation. The presence of  Calluna (Ling) and the podsolic nature of the soil indicated that the soil had  begun to deteriorate by the time the barrow was constructed. All the charcoal samples from the barrow itself were of Oak.A slate comb, possibly used to decorate pottery, and a quern fragment were recovered during the excavations.  An iron object, possibly the tare from a 'tare-and-feathers' (used for stone splitting in modern times) indicates later disturbance of the site.--------------------------------Site history:2: 1971. ANK/OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: One of a pair of impressive barrows situated in a prominent position on the cliff edge.<gg summary>: Primary inhumation with axe-hammerSecondary cremation with flint chip Also skull fragments with no grave goods The mound had been burnt very intensively; much blackened by fire
Site_description: One of a pair of impressive barrows situated in a prominent position on the cliff edge. Both barrows are marked on the 1963 and 1974 OS maps and the field-name 'Burrow Down' is recorded in the 1840 Tithe Award (b1). The barrows were excavated by WC Borlase in 1872 (b4) and have been mentioned or described by a number of authors (b2-b8). According to Borlase they are joined to each other on their north sides by a low semi-circular earth bank; the distance between the two being "38 paces". They are Scheduled Monuments (h1) and were surveyed by the OS in 1971 (h2). Borlase describes this barrow as being 26.3m in diameter by 4.0m high, with a depression 0.46m deep in its top. A shaft, 3.7m in diameter, was sunk from the top to the centre of the barrow. Below the turf was a 0.9m deep layer of stones, overlying a 1.5m deep layer of yellow clay, under which was a second layer of stones (some burnt), covering a large slate slab. A secondary burial, consisting of a deposit of burnt bones and ashes (and a single flint chip), was found 1.5m below the barrow surface in the yellow clay immediately over the centre of this stone, which was level, with the ground surface, about 2.7m by 3.1m by 0.6m thick and sealed a cist. The latter was aligned north-west, south-east, measured 1.57m long by 0.86m wide by 0.84m deep, and contained a contracted inhumation burial laid on a 0.15m thick pavement. The legs were bent at the knees and the arms stretched out towards the knees. An early Bronze Age perforated stone axe-hammer (4654.21) was found where the hands would have been. According to the English Heritage field monument warden (h3) the barrow is now 23m in diameter 3.7m high, with a crater in its top, 4.0m across by 1.5m deep, which is the result of the 1872 excavation. The monument is covered by grass and wild flowers, but a ploughed field lies on its inland side and the plough has clipped its rim. Shillet and quartz stones are exposed by the plough where it has cut a 0.3m verticle edge and by a 0.3m wide path around the south side. This barrow is clearly visible on vertical aerial photographs (p1, p2).--------------------------------Site history:1: 19--. UNKNOWN / IAM2: 1971. MJF / OS3: 1985. SHEPPARD, PA / FMW4: 1977. SHEPPARD, P / CCRA--------------------------------

Site_summary: Remains of a barrow excavated by WC Borlase in 1879.<gg summary>: Escalls, on Tregiffian estate, Cist with capstone dug in c. 1879; urn placed just outside the cist Miniature urn
Site_description: WC Borlase in 1881 describes his excavation in 1879 of a barrow at Escalls surrounded by a double ring of stones. One side of the area of it was almost entirely taken over by a natural rock protruding through the surface. On the south side a large rock covered a cist containing chips and two limpet shells. Outside the cist, to its south end Borlase found a little urn and in the centre of the barrow sherds of domestic pottery. The urn was found full of black earth and ashes, and ornamented by a double chevron pattern around the rim. Measuring 12cm high and 10cm diamater at the base, and 8.9cm at the mouth, it is barrel-shaped with a perforated cleat on either side and of dark and thin pottery. It had been placed mouth downwards (b1). Abercromby in 1912 records a cinerary urn from Escalls Cliff, measuring 14cm in height, in Truro museum (b8). Patchett in 1944 classifies the urn as Class C, ribbon-handled ii, Middle Bronze Age. Decoration is of the period but the shape of the urn is of the older native tradition, suggesting an example early in the series (b9). Henderson describes the barrow and mentions traces of a similar barrow and a few metres to the south (28467) (b2). The OS who surveyed the barrow at 1:2500 in 1960 found it situated on the summit of a natural round near the cliff top and sited at SW 3622 2722. It is in poor condition and consists of a mound of earth 0.7m high with a mutilated circle of retaining stones. The stones in the north-west sector are set on edge and appear to be in situ, but the remainder are recumbant. There is no trace of the cist within the barrow (h1). Geary in 1961 notes that on Dudley's corrected map (b4) a ruined tumulus is sited at SW 3605 2709. There is no sign of a barrow in this area and when interviewed she confirmed that her siting was an error for the Escalls cliff barrow (b6) (h2). Russell in 1971 lists the extant remains of a barrow at Escalls (b7). The barrow is visible on aerial photographs (p1) as a low earth mound and was plotted as part of the NMP.(b5) - Russell, V, 1960, Pers Comm to OS, , (b6) - Dudley, D, 1961, Pers Comm to OS, , --------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. PITCHER, GH / OS2: 1961. GEARY, E / OS--------------------------------<MCO26989>: Wc borlase in 1881 describes his excavation in 1879 of a barrow at escalls  (28466). On the south side of the barrow a large rock covered a cist 0.9M long by 0.46M wide in which nothing was found except for a few flint chips  (28466.11) And two limpet shells (b1).  Henderson in 1916 notes that the stones forming the cist were lying prostrate and broken (b2).  The OS in 1960 record no trace of a cist whithin the barrow (h1). Russell in 1971 lists the cists in her entry for the barrow but records no  extant remains (b4).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. PITCHER, GH / OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: <gg summary>: The site of a [EBA] barrow excavated in 1957. It had originally been excavated in 1850 and was a secondary cist burial with ribbon-handled urn.Note Several miniature cists were found in the south-east quadrant of the barrow. They contained tiny quartz pebbles, little stones and fragments of broken flint. Stains at the base of one suggests presence of organic matter- food offerings or libations Note: Cup-marked pebble/stone found immediately adjacent to the barrowAlso Stone adze at inner face of ring wall of barrow - Neolithic?
Site_description: The site of a Middle Bronze Age barrow which was damaged in 1850 and 1870, excavated in 1957 and found to contain several pits and cists. It is marked on the 1963 and 1974 OS maps. In 1850 Rodd reports a discovery by workmen. The barrow has been cut down and shaped to form part of a fence or bank, and an urn (see 4651.01) containing a cremation was found inverted inside a cist, the stones of which were replaced (b2). Further damage to the barrow was caused in 1870 by the insertion of a large concrete block for a flagpole and smaller ones for stays. There was also damage at the edges from ploughing (b3). In 1957 the remains of the barrow were excavated by Dudley (b6). The mound was shown to have originally been capped by small stones and shillet. Sections of a surrounding ring wall were found, showing it to be oval, averaging 0.6m high, and loosely built of large slabs of slate mixed with blocks of local stone. The barrow interior appeared to have been levelled in places to receive cists and pits but no primary burial was found (this was probably on the highest point, near the concrete flagstaff base). However, by analogy of construction and pottery the barrow seems to date to the Middle Bronze Age. The cist uncovered in 1850 was reclocated in 1957 and its position towards the edge of the barrow and immediatley beneath the barrow cover suggested that it was a secondary burial. The description of the cover stone given by Rodd did not correspond with the related port-hole slab found by Dudley. Several miniature cists were found in the south-east quadrant of the barrow. They contained tiny quartz pebbles, little stones and fragments of broken flint. A slight stain in the bottom may have resulted from the former presence of carbonaceous matter. Two small pits were found in the north-east quadrant. One, 20cm deep, contained no finds; the other, 30cm by 46cm and 13cm deep, was covered by a slate slab and contained tiny quartz pebbles and fragments of broken flint. A neolithic adze was also found (4651.02). The barrow is listed as extant (b7) but it is unclear what remains. An Iron Age hut circle is set into the west side of the barrow (4652).<MCO627>: A cremation urn found in 1850 inverted in a cist beneath Glendorgal barrow (4651). It has been mentioned or described by a number of authors (b1-b4). According to Patchett the urn is Bronze Age, probably a late type, after 700 BC (b5). However Thomas suggests that it might date to the Middle Bronze Age or the latter part of the Early Bronze Age. He describes the urn as roughly bucket shaped, narrowing at the base. The paste is yellowish in colour, sandy and gritted heavily with tiny pebbles and well fired. The decoration is poorly executed in scratched technique, three horizontal and irregularly disposed grooves superimposed on a continous running chevron or horizontal zig zag. The urn is now at the RIC. It is one of three Cornish urns reproduced in minature as a cross china design (late C19 to early C20 souvenirs).

Site_summary: A 'ring barrow' consisting of a circle of retaining stones and central cist.<gg summary>: Looks a bit like a stone circle. Central hearth with stones (possibly a pyre) under which was a cist with cremation and broken urn - Trevisker, and a flint knife Possible in situ pyre site (described as a hearth)
Site_description: A 'ring barrow' consisting of a circle of retaining stones and central cist , sketched by Barnicoat, is illustrated by WC Borlase (b1). He quotes the vicar of Stithians (b2) who informed him that an urn (18227) had recently been discovered "in a small stone chamber" on Goonorman Downs; probably the cist of this barrow, as noted by the OS (h1). Henderson notes that no traces of a circle of stones or cist could be found on the downs, due to their enclosure for agriculture "long ago" (b3, b4). From Borlase's illustration (b1), the kerb appears to have been approx  6.2m external diameter, and the cist approx 1.8m by 1.2m internally. This is one of a group of three alleged barrows (18226), this or another barrow being indicated by a place-name (181226.03). It is presumably the "stone circle" listed separately by Tangye (b5), and recorded (see 18228) due to a confusion with a separate stone circle (18229).(b2) - Henderson, C, 187-, Pers Comm, , --------------------------------Site history:1: 1975. JWS / OS--------------------------------<MCO643>: The discovery of an urn "in a small stone chamber" on Goonorman Downs is recorded by the vicar of Stithians (b2). WC Borlase published this report with an illustration of a "ring barrow", consisting of a retaining kerb of stones with central cist (18226.01), sketched on the downs by Barnicoat (b1). However, it is not clear whether the urn was found in this barrow, as suggested by the OS (h1), or at a separate site in the vicinity (see 18226.02) as implied by Tangye's listing (b3). A barrow in this area is also indicated by a place-name, and this may relate to either of tAnwenhese sites, or a third (18226.03).(b2) - Wright, FHA, 187-, Pers Comm, , --------------------------------Site history:1: 1975. JWS / OS--------------------------------

Site_name_other: GWITHIAN, SITE GM/V - Bronze Age barrow
Site_summary: Site GM/V at Gwithian represents an MBA barrow belonging to a group of low turf covered mounds.<gg summary>: . A larger oval hollow oriented NNE was dug 6m to the south south west, some clean sand placed within and on this was laid a skeleton, head to N, crouched on the right side. At the feet was a small pile of stones. To the north of a smaller hollow a grit hone and a rim sherd had been placed on the floor.
Site_description: Site GM/V at Gwithian represents a barrow belonging to a group of low turf covered mounds (sites GMV/V-XIV) (37053-37059) found and completely excavated by Thomas in 1955. The barrow contained a wooden platform overlaying a sandy layer and two burial pits, one of which was probably an inhumation pit, the other being a ritual pit. The excavation also encountered Thomas's Middle Bronze Age 'layer 5' and the barrow was considered to belong to this phase. The barrow measured 1.8m high and 12.2m in diameter (h1, b1). The OS  visited the site in 1962 and recorded a clearly defined circular patch of hard packed sand within an area of rough pasture (h2).--------------------------------Site history:2: 1962. QUINNELL, NV / OS--------------------------------<summary>: The monument was likened by the excavator to an attempt to copy a Scillonian entrance grave; coverd with mound of sand (some of these sealed domestic midden)

Site_summary: The internal structure of a barrow, containing two urns and a dagger, was revealed following a cliff fall in 1890.<gg summary>: A large number of grave goods were placed in this cremation urn possibly with cremated remains of more than one individual. At least one adult. Dagger is Camerton Snowshill but was worn. Awl, whetstone and miniature incense cup
Site_description: Following a cliff fall in 1890, the internal structure of a Bronze Age barrow was revealed near to Harlyn Bay. Artefacts found included a biconical two handled patterned urn 52cm high, of poor manufacture, and a bronze dagger 10cm long by 5cm thick, badly worn and with two rivets extant at the handle end. A small "incense" cup (h1) was also found inside the urn, with a bronze awl 4cm long. A schist hone 9cm long by 4cm wide and a spindle whorl of greenish yellow tone. Unfortunately, Crawford's drawings (b2) differ in detail from Patchett's (b3), so the exact natue of the finds is unclear. Some sort of stone structure was seen in the mound of sand above the urn, which was covered by a stone slab, and it seems likely that the urn was in the middle of a barrow (b4).(b4) - Hellyar, L, 1954, Pers Comm to OS, , --------------------------------Site history:1: 1954. ALFR/OS--------------------------------<MCO25890>: In describing the excavation of a barrow and cavity containing an urn (21703) iago mentioned in passing that a skeleton was discovered in the earth layer (below the sand) to the w of the barrow. It is not known why this find was apparently disregarded. No more details (b1).  <see MCO2774 for collated record>

Site_summary: A Bronze Age urn inverted over a cremation, revealed following a cliff fall in 1901.<gg summary>: the Trevisker urn had been inverted over a pile of cremated bones. Accompanied by three bronze pins, rounded pebbles and two white bone beads and faience beads
Site_description: In December 1901, a cliff fall revealed a Bronze Age urn inverted over a cremation, on the end of the small promontory in Bloodhound Cove, Harlyn Bay. The urn was excavated by Messrs Hellyar and Mallet, and from their drawings, it seems that the urn was in a pit in the sand with a slab over the top of it (b1, b2). The urn was a rather squat vessel of good quality, and in the ashes were found parts of three bronze pins. The pins have been lost, and only four sherds of the urn survive in Truro museum. Some blue beads were found with the urn, and the whole was set on a layer of white beach pebbles, which were present in great quantity, as they were used to cobble the stables (h2).(b5) - Hellyar, L, 1954, Pers Comm to OS, , --------------------------------Site history:2: 1954. ALFR/OS--------------------------------

Site_name_other: HIGHER PREDANNACK DOWNS - Bronze Age barrow
Site_summary: A barrow stood in a field called Creigullow Croft; explored by Borlase in 1871, it produced a ribbon-handled urn with ashes and burnt bones.<gg summary>: Small barrow covering a ring of stones in which centrally was a small barrel urn with two handles associated with a cremation and ashes over which was heaped white clay.
Site_description: A barrow on Higher Predannack Downs formerly stood in a field called Creigullow Croft in 1840 (b1). It was explored by Borlase in 1871, and is marked on the 1907 OS map. The barrow was 42ft (13m) in diameter and 4ft (1.2m) high, and surrounded by a ring of stones. When excavated in 1871, a ribbon-handled urn associated with ashes and burnt bones was found beneath a deposit of white clay, 3ft (0.9m) below the surface (b4, b6). According to the Checklist, the barrow was destroyed when the airfield was constructed in 1940 and the site is no longer accessible. In 1973, the OS surveyor confirmed that there is nothing visible on the ground, and that the site is partially overlaid by a metalled path.--------------------------------Site history:2: 1973. MJF/OS--------------------------------
