Site_summary: The site of a barrow, levelled in 1881, from which an urn containing human bones was recovered. <gg summary>: cremation of adult in ribbon-handled urn.3 flints and  potsherd found in the mound
Site_description: Iago records that an urn was recovered from a barrow while the mound was being levelled during agricultural operations in 1881. The mound is described as having been 35ft (10.7m) to 41ft (12.54m) diameter and contained a cairn of spar stones 3ft (0.91m) to 4ft (1.22m) high. An outer enclosing circle was formed by stones laid on their edges "not at the circumference of the mound but slightly within it". The urn stood,"mouth upward, on a stone at about the middle of the barrow about 2ft (0.63m) from the top in a space surrounded by stones and was filled with black earth. The urn contained a quantity of fibrous roots and small fragments of hard and very white bones apparently of an adult human". Three pieces of flint and a sherd of pot harder than the urn where found in the mound (b1). Hencken describes the burial as Middle Bronze Age (b2). Reed records that the barrow is plouged out (b3).

Site_summary: A barrow excavated in the late C17 containing an urn and two small drinking vessels; the location of the barrow is unknown.<gg summary>: Cremation in ribbon-handled urn accompanied by two smaller handled vessels
Site_description: A barrow on Lambourne Downs was excavated in the late C17 and the finds were described by Hals (b1 referring to Hals). The location of the barrow is totally unknown, and there are no details about it. The finds included an urn 26cm high and 25cm wide. Borlase made a sketch, and according to Hals, it was filled with ashes, broken bones and charcoal, and made of rough clay. Also found at the site were two small drinking cups of similar clay, with several handles. Hals said they were Roman paterae - a most unlikely suggestion in a Bronze Age barrow. The location of the finds at present is uncertain; they were "deposited at Pencarrow" (h1), probably they are still there.

Site_summary: The site of a barrow excavated by Croft Andrew in 1942, in advance of the construction of Davidstow airfield.<gg summary>: Summarised in Christie (1988) (Croft Andrew Site XIX (11))Cremation of one individual, possibly a sub-adult, possible in a bag - cleaned. Note the grave pit is quite big - larger and longer than would be required for a cremation. Croft Andrew thought that any other grave goods may have been removed
Site_description: The place-name of the post-medieval settlement of Larkabarrow (3456) possibly suggests the site of a Bronze Age barrow or cairn. The barrow was identified and excavated by CK Croft Andrew in 1942, in advance of the construction of Davidstow airfield (h1). Croft Andrew suggested that the barrow had been used as a landmark in laying out Larkabarrow farm, for a hedge had been built over it and it stood at the corner of several fields. The barrow had been disturbed by cultivation, and possibly robbed by hedge building, almost to obliteration on the north side. Croft Andrew found it only 18 inches (0.46m) high and suggested an original diameter of over 50 feet (15.24m). From examination of his notes, however, Christie suggests that this was originally a low oval mound 13m north to south by 11m east to west (b3). Croft Andrew's excavation was interrupted by bad weather and work elsewhere; consequently his notes are poor. He cut a main north - south section across the mound and several other trenches. Results of this work have been published by Christie (b3). The mound was built of "turf clods and a few flints" (b1). The old turf was preserved beneath it on the south. The principal feature was a stone lined grave pit, two and half feet by three and a half feet, by one foot deep (0.76m by 1.07m by 0.3m), containing the cremation of one person which may have originally been in some sort of container. The pit was corbelled over and covered by a small stone cairn. The only other finds were a few flints from the barrow floor.

Site_name_other: LOUSEY - Bronze Age barrow, Modern observation post
Site_summary: An extant Bronze Age round barrow, reused as a home guard observation post.<gg summary>: Beneath the mound were five cists which contained tiny white pebbles and ‘carbonaceous substances’ and a complex burial deposit. Were these cists associated with ritual offerings?  This consisted of an extended inhumation and a deposit of cremated bone around which were scattered sherds of two Beakers. The Beakers were comb-stamped, one also including fingernail decoration, and fragmentary,
Site_description: Lousey Barrow is a grass and scrub-covered barrow, 30m in diameter and over 3.0m high, standing on the highest point of the Tresparrett Downs. In the centre is a 1.2m deep depression caused by C17 treasure hunting and by excavation for an OS trig point (h2). No ditch is visible (h3). In September 1940, Lousey Barrow was partially excavated by C K Croft Andrew, "in an unorthodox manner", to provide a home guard observation post. The results of the excavation were described briefly by Croft Andrew in 1945, and have recently been published as fully as surviving information allows. The mound may have been built in two stages. It consisted of an inner stone cairn sealed by a clay capping, possibly the remains of a substantial turf stack. Over this, in the central area, was a second stone cairn. Both the clay capping and this may have had a stone revetment. A 1.5m to 2.1m wide berm separated the mound from the ditch. A cupped pebble, possibly a nutcracker, was found in the ditch. On the ground beneath the centre of the cairn were an extended inhumation and a cremation. In a circle around these had been scattered the sherds of two beakers and beyond this ring were five small slate-lined cists. These contained "a few tiny white pebbles and the dark stain left by the decay of carbonaceous substances" (h1). The barrow is visible as earthworks on aerial photographs (p1) and was plotted during the Cornwall NMP.--------------------------------Site history:2: 1973. DOE (MERCER)3: 1976. OS4: 1979. DOE (SHEPPARD)5: 1979. DOE (SHEPPARD)6: 1982. DOE (SHEPPARD)7: 19. NDJ, CCRA--------------------------------

Site_summary: Site of a barrow excavated by WC Borlase in 1879, in which were found five urns.<gg summary>: Five urns in small cist - only one survived and contained bones including bird bones
Site_description: On 30th October 1879 it was reported in the West Briton newspaper "Mr WC Borlase FSA still proceeds with the ardour of an enthusiast in his researches amongst the tumuli of St Just parish. Last week he opened two on South Busvargus estate. In the first he was rewarded by the discovery of five sepulchral urns, four of which had been unfortunately crushed by the falling in of the top stone of the cist, but one remained uninjured" (b2). Russell records extant remains of these barrows (b9) but the OS have not been able to trace them (h1). Patchett records that the surviving urn, which contained bird bones, is of late Middle Bronze Age type. It is now in the Cambridge University Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology (b7, b8).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. GEARY, E / OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: Site of a barrow excavated by WC Borlase in 1881.<gg summary>. Two cists found. One had been disturbed by erection of flagpole but had urn and burnt bones and pebbles and flints. Borlase also found a large stone cist 2.2m long and 1.3m wide which was empty and had never been opened. He calls it a cenotaph but it could be that the inhumation had decayed totally
Site_description: WC Borlase in 1881 records a barrow at Mayon, excavated by him, and containing a cist (28536.1) in which he found a large urn (28536.2) together with flints (28536.3), pebbles, burnt bones and charcoal. The barrow had previously been disturbed by the erection of a flagstaff in the centre (b1). A flagstaff is shown at Mayon on the OS maps of 1908 (b2) and 1938 (b4) at SW 3520 2587, which is mentioned by Henderson in his description of the mutilated barrow (b3). The OS in 1960 visited the site and found that the ground around the flagstaff has been levelled and there is no trace of a barrow. It is not absolutely certain that this is the flagstaff referred to by Borlase but it is considered the most likely. A second flagstaff at SW 3477 2621 is set in a large concrete apron on outcrop rock in front of a coastgaurd lookout (h1). Russell in 1971 lists the barrow but records no extant remains (b5).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. PITCHER, GH / OS--------------------------------<MCO27007>: WC Borlase in 1881 records a cist found by him in a barrow (28536) at Mayon, and which contained a large urn (28536.2), flints (28536.3), pebbles, burnt bones and ashes (b1). Henderson records Borlase's excavation (b2). The OS in 1960 found no trace of the cist at the site of the barrow (h1). Russell in 1971 lists the cist in her entry for the barrow (b3).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. PITCHER, GH / OS--------------------------------<MCO985>: WC Borlase in 1881 records the find of a large urn contained in a disturbed cist (28536.1) excavated by him, in a barrow (28536) at Mayon (b1). Henderson records Borlase's find of fragments of a large urn (b2). Russell in 1971 lists the find in her entry for the barrow (b3).<MCO986>: WC Borlase in 1881 records a cist (28536.1) excavated by him, in a barrow (28536) at Mayon (b1). Henderson records Borlase's find of fragments of flints, pebbles, burnt bones and charcoal (b2). Russell in 1971 lists the find in her entry for the barrow (b3).

Site_summary: The site of a barrow excavated during WW2 by Croft Andrew.<gg summary>: rather disturbed barrow but held a cremation with Bronze Age pottery. The central grave had been dug by farmer and had contained a cremation ad possibly a Bronze Age urn. Sherds of Bronze Age fabric-tempered pot came from here. Note: a large area in NE quadrant - rectangular shaped was described as a fire site. It may in fact be an in situ pyre site Note a F 4 — Wooden Shovel: (Fig. 12a). A charcoal object was found lying on theditch bottom (see plan Fig. 8) 4 ft (1.22 m) below the surface on the west side. The excavator's notes (for a lecture) describe this as 'the remains of an oaken wooden shovel . . . found in the ditch bottom, beneath all silt. The lower shaft and the edge of the blade were preserved as charcoal, having I suggest been charred to harden them. A cupmarked stone also came from ditch.A large quantity of beach pebbles was apparently found in the barrow ditch —55 pebbles being recorded on the first two days of excavation. Four quartz crystalswere also found in and over the ditch
Site_description: First recorded by Thomas c1850 (b1) and marked on early OS maps this barrow was excavated during WW2 by Croft Andrew, when an airfield was to be constructed at Nancekuke. No more than a brief note of the excavation was published by Croft Andrew (b2); but in 1985 Christie produced the fullest account which was possible from the excavator's notebooks (b3). The barrow had been ploughed out to less than 0.5m high prior to excavation, and the farmer told Croft Andrew that in 1931 he had dug into the barrow and found "a layer of black matter and a white layer which looked like rotten bone". Croft Andrew found the barrow to be surrounded by a narrow, V-shaped ditch 17m in diameter. A narrow berm separated this from a mound of very well preserved inclined turfs, of which a careful record was made. Beneath the mound a grave pit was found (already emptied by the farmer, whose account suggests it may have held a cremation), a fire site and a charcoal patch. Pieces of pottery "of Bronze Age fabric" were found, and a holed and cupped stone. The most remarkable discovery was the remains of an oak wood 'Cornish' shovel in the bottom of the ditch (b3). A collection of lithic material was deemed to relate to earlier prehistoric activity in the area (25007.1) In 1970, the site was visited by the OS, who reported no visible remains - the mound was presumably destroyed after the excavation during construction of the wartime airfield. (h2).--------------------------------Site history:2: 1970. ANK/OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: The site of a barrow demolished before 1958.<gg summary> cremation with Food Vessel and an exceptionally fine flint dagger. This site is also referred to as Pentire Glaze
Site_description: The 2nd Edition OS 6-inch map records a tumulus at New Polzeath. The OS recorded it was demolished by 1958 (h1). A site visit in 1972 revealed that there is now no trace of the barrow and its site is overlaid by a road (h2).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1958. OXFORD, DF/OS2: 1972. FLETCHER, MJ/OS--------------------------------<MCO1143>: A flint spearhead was discovered with a food vessel containing a cremation at pentireglaze during 1910. Drawings of the objects are in the antiquaries journal (b1). The extant findspot is not recorded. It is possible that the artefacts may have come from demolished barrow 26315 which was in pentireglaze (now new polzeath) (b2).(b2) - Thomas, N, 1989, Pers Comm, ,

Site_summary: Remains of a barrow, possibly recorded in 1898 as containing a cist and cremation urns.This site is also known as Gunwalloe. <gg summary>: Cist containing three small Trevisker or (one a Food Vessel) urns, each containing ashes. Like a little family plot. The cist also contained the unburnt bones of a young rabbit, three birds and a toad (possibly had been open) ; also burnt bronze object.All the pots are different and may sit on the Early-Middle Bronze Age transition
Site_description: A barrow is recorded at Pengwinion in 1898 (b1) and is mentioned by Hencken in 1932 (b2). Dowson in 1969 lists the site but records no extant remains of a barrow (b3). The OS who visited the site in 1973 found a barrow 26m in diameter and 0.8m high and note that it is conjectural that it is the 'almost levelled tumulus' recorded in 1898 where a cist (28033.1) was found which contained three cremation urns (28033.2) (h1).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1973. FLETCHER, MJ / OS--------------------------------<MCO26924>: A small cist is recorded in 1898, found in an 'almost levelled barrow' at Pengwinion and which contained three urns (28033.2). The cist was not removed (b1). The OS in 1973 note that this is the probable location of the barrow (28033) (h1).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1973. FLETCHER, MJ / OS--------------------------------<MCO1098>: The find of three Late Bronze Age urns, of ribbon handle and overhanging rim tradition, is recorded in 1898, in a cist (28033.1) on the SW face of an 'almost levelled tumulus' at Pengwinion. The urns were found in an upright position with a flat stone on the mouth of each and contained human ashes mixed with animal bones (b1). Dowson in 1969 lists the find and records the present locality as Truro Museum (b4). The OS in 1973 note that this is the probable location of the barrow (28033) (h1).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1973. FLETCHER, MJ / OS--------------------------------<MCO50252>: In early April 2006 a pottery sherd was brought into the Historic Environment Service for identification. It was a chance discovery found eroding from the public footpath running over a scheduled barrow on the clifftop, overlooking Pedngwinian CoveThe sherd is in a gabbroic admixture fabric  (local rock mixed with gabbroic clay) which is typical of Bronze Age pottery. The form is of a biconical shaped urn, roughly 12cm in diameter, and has been decorated with impressed double twist cord in a band below the rim, as a chevron pattern contained within horizontal lines. The surface of the pot had been burnished. This sherd is of Trevisker Ware and in very fresh condition with little to no abrasion suggesting there may be more of  this vessel nearby. This is found in both domestic and funerary contexts. A Middle Bronze Age date c1500-1000 BC is suggested for this ware.(C Thorpe; see Info File)--------------------------------Site history:1: 2006. SUMPTER, B--------------------------------

Site_summary: Two Bronze Age pots and associated finds found in 1949 during the removal of earth from a boundary bank.<gg summary>: Degraded inhumation with two inverted pots, one placed inside the other and one is a Food Vessel. Whetstone placed next to them
Site_description: Two Bronze Age pots were found 1949, when removing earth from the north side of an earth boundary bank. The find was investigated by Bousfield. The pots were found at the foot of the bank, set on the subsoil, and associated with many lumps of quartz 3in diameter. They were inverted, one inside the other. Associated finds included a small stone whetstone and four fragments of unburnt bone, as well as pieces of clay pipe and roofing slate. There was no evidence for a cist; the site was perhaps originally associated with a barrow (b2). The finds are at Truro Museum.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: A barrow excavated in 1751, inside which were found two urns, burnt bones and the remains of a possible dagger.Note central cist had large quantity of human bone mixed in with ashes but no obvious gg; the urns were found a little to the side of this cist
Site_description: Borlase records the excavation in 1751 of a barrow at Trelowarren, "very wide in circumference but not five feet high" (b1). A cist was found inside containing burnt bones, and two urns inverted over burnt bones were found a few feet from the cist, one on either side. Three pieces of thin brass found near the middle of the barrow are thought to be the remains of a dagger (b4). Blight places the barrow between Halligye Fogou (24963) and Trelowarren House where a large mound raised on the remains of a barrow can be seen (b2). Crawford notes that a summerhouse is built on a mound, said to be artificial, which may be a heightened tumulus (b3). The feature is shown on the OS 1963 Edition map and is listed by Dowson in 1966 as having no extant remains (b5). The mount is a tree covered subcircular mound approx 28m in diameter and 8.0m high, seemingly a folly. Mr Vyvyan the owner, stated that it was constructed with spoil from the excavations of a nearby drive and that the barrow was at SW 7164 21387. The OS were unable to check this location because the field was under crop, although they note no obvious mound and nothing visible on the air photos (h1, p2). However the barrow is visible on some aerial photographs (p1) as a low earth mound and has been plotted as part of the NMP.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1971. FLETCHER, MJ / OS--------------------------------

Site_name_other: FORE DOWN - Bronze Age cairn cemetery, Bronze Age barrow
Site_summary: Possible site of a barrow group, excavated by Croft Andrew c1942.This barrow was opened by Croft Andrew in Jun-July 1942. The mound measured 26 ft (7.9 m) across and 3 ft (0.9 m) high (Fig 82) and contained a (presumably) central cremation burial of an adult in a large handled urn, more than 30 sherds of which were retrieved. Also found were a flat bronze dagger, flints and charcoal. 14C dates recently undertaken on the cremated bone
Site_description: On the steep, south facing slope of Fore Down, there formerly existed a group of  barrows or cairns. The approximate location of the group is indicated on a map of Dudley, but she did not know their exact number or locations. She states that CK Croft Andrew excavated here, that Patchett saw the pots, and that the downland they were in was enclosed during WWII (b1). Patchett, who had information from Croft Andrew, describes the urn discovered here as markedly biconical, with large handles and with a carination at handle level. The pot had a slight cordon at the neck, and an everted rim with very slanting internal bevel. The impressed cord ornament consisted of four horizontal lines and a band of chevrons. A dagger was associated (b2). In 1973, the OS fieldworker could provide no further insights into these barrows either through fieldwork or documentary research (h2). The finds are listed by Pearce (b3) and illustrated by Christie who records that the finds, a handled urn, a dagger and a flint, were rescued by Croft Andrew from the mutilated barrow during his Davidstow Moor campaign, and which are now in Truro Museum (b4, 5, 6).--------------------------------Site history:2: 1973. MHB/OS--------------------------------

Site_name_other: BUSVARGUS - Bronze Age barrow, Bronze Age lithic scatter
Site_summary: A barrow is recorded on Busvargus Hill in which an urn was found c1900; <gg summary>: small / miniature incense urn with bones f bird and child
Site_description: Henderson, probably quoting Thomas (b1), records "in a croft close to the road" on Busvargus Hill between Tregeseal and Leswidden clay works, are the remains of a ring barrow (cairn with peristalith) 66 feet in diameter. 500 yards south in the corner of a field next the road once stood an ancient barrow. Slight traces of a mound and one large stone remain. An urn was found c1900 in excellent preservation, bearing chevron ornament. In the field to the east of the barrow many flint flakes are annually ploughed up, including a few worked flints" (b2). Russell records extant remains of a barrow (b3). A site visit by the OS in 1960 failed to locate the barrows, but it is suggested that one may be at SW 381 314 while the second could have been at SW 381 310. The present wherabouts of the urn are not known (h1). Subsequent fieldwork revealed no trace of the sites (h2).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. GEARY, E / OS2: 1975. FLETCHER, MJ / OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: An urn containing a bronze dagger and a cremation, discovered in 1964 during excavation for a swimming pool.<gg summary>: rescue excavation. This was possibly the central burial cist (with oak casket) of a barrow, as there was a surrounding ditch. inverted urn containing the incomplete cremated bone of a male c50, a small quantity of oak charcoal, and a small bronze knife-dagger. Exterior of barrow covered with quartz. 14C dates suggest 1890-1620 cal BC
Site_description: In 1964, workmen excavating for a swimming pool discovered an urn containing a worn bronze dagger, a small amount of charcoal, and a cremation. Members of CAS carried out a brief rescue excavation, following the discovery. The urn was inverted in a circular pit 2ft (0.6m) in diameter and 2ft 3in deep (0.68m), cut into the clay subsoil, which was covered by a large slate capstone. To the east of this, in the section of the excavation, was a V-shaped ditch, 5ft (1.52m) wide and 4ft 6in (1.37m) deep. This was interpreted as the quarry ditch for a covering barrow, although no traces of a mound were observed. Assuming the pit to have been at the centre, the barrow would have had a diameter of approx 50ft. There was some evidence that the barrow had been covered by quartz. The finds - a Trevisker-style ribbon handled urn with impressed cord decoration in a chevron pattern, and a 127mm long tapering knife dagger with two widely spaced rivets - suggested to the excavators a C15 BC date. The cremation was of an adult male, perhaps 50 years old (b2). The dagger and the urn are now at Truro Museum (b3).

Site_name_other: ROSEMORRAN - Bronze Age barrow, Bronze Age cist
Site_summary: A possible barrow or cist site, recorded in 1816.<gg summary>; cist with 3 urned cremations
Site_description: George John noted that three urns containing burnt human bones were found in 1816 under a large stone at Rosemorran (b1). Russell lists this as a barrow, probably located at SW 4766 3260 (b2). The source may indicate a cist site rather than a barrow.<MCO1282>: Russell (quoting b1) recorded that three urns were found at Rosemorran in 1816 (b3). These were full of burnt human bones (b4). Copeland Borlase illustrates a miniature urn "dug up on the estate of Sir John St Aubyn, west of Penzance containing human ashes." This was 5inches in diameter and 5 inches tall (b2). The present wherabouts of the finds are not known.

Site_summary: Remains of a mutilated barrow recorded by WC Borlase, in which an urn was found and sent to Lord Falmouth.<gg_summary>: the urn from barrow C was not clearly associated with hr but that recovered from barrow E (not in the HER) was (Borlase 1872, 217). This urned cremation burial is recorded in this barrow record.
Site_description: WC Borlase recorded a barrow, marked 'C' on his plan, in which an urn was found and sent to  Lord Falmouth (b1). The OS surveyed the site at 1:2500 in 1960 and recorded that the north half of the barrow survived as a mutilated mound 18m in diameter and up to 1.6m high. A trench averaging 0.7m deep curved across the barrow, the south half of which was retained by a modern field hedge. There were no traces of a surrounding ditch, and the mound, which was grass and bush covered, appeared to be of stone and earth construction (h1). White, in 1969, prior to Scheduling, noted a rather badly mutilated cairn, entirely hollowed, and growing bushes, situated in the centre of an arable field (b2). Russell in 1971 recorded the extant remains of a barrow (b3). Sheppard in 1982 reported a thick cover of hawthorn and scrub, with the field in grass and stubble (b4). The location of the barrow with its covering of scrub, can be identified from RAF aerial photographs, taken in 1946 (p1).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. QUINNELL, NV / OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: The site of a barrow destroyed in 1883, containing an urn approx 56cm high with a maximum diameter of 43cm.<gg summary>: Early-Middle Bronze Age ribbon-handled urn containing a cremation was discovered.
Site_description: 'Shepherd's House' barrow was destroyed by the farmer in 1883, when a Middle Bronze Age ribbon-handled urn containing a cremation was discovered. The urn, preserved in Truro Museum was smashed before removal, but the pieces recovered show it to be approx 56cm high with a maximum diameter of 43cm, being of deep brown, almost black fabric. It had stood upright on a clean earth floor surrounded by quartz or spar stones on the west side of the barrow. Amongst the stones was found half a smooth water-worn pebble with transverse scratches, suggested to be a strike-a-light. Also recovered was a triangular holed stone 7.6cm to 10.1cm wide and 2.0cm thick, possibly a spindle whorl (b1-b3). A field visit by the OS in 1974 revealed that the published site is now a farm track at the side of an arable field with no trace of a barrow (h1).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1974. QUINNELL, NV / OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: The site of a ditched bell barrow excavated by Dudley in 1960.<gg summary>: unurned burial with worked stones
Site_description: This ditched bell barrow was excavated in 1960 by Dorothy Dudley, in advance of road widening. Basically, it consisted of a single internment in a central pit, covered by a complex mound. The internment had been robbed; the pit it had been in was cut through an old ground surface. Over it was a mound of alternate layers of yellow sand and small stones, encircled by a ring of stake holes. A floor of flat stones surrounded the mound. Over the mound a large cairn of local stone had been built covered in turn by layers of grass sods, coarse soil and turves, retained by a fence with widely spaced posts. The top most layer consisted of subsoil from the ditch plus more stone (b1). Finds included fragments of cremated bone, charcoal and a piece of flint (in association with the central mound), 3 whetstones, a cupped pebble, and 27 worked flints (b1). Pollen analysis of material from the barrow suggested a pattern of decreasing woodland cover during the Bronze Age, hazel becoming the dominant woodland tree. No evidence was found for cultivation in the vicinity (b2, b3). There are now no remains of the barrow. When visited by the OS, its site was occupied by waste ground. Originally Scheduled (no 580), this barrow has since been de-scheduled.--------------------------------Site history:2: 1976. OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: A scheduled barrow, 15m in diameter and less than 1.0m high in the corner of a field at Tolvan Cross.<gg summary>: Near standing stone. Pit with pottery and ashes and covered with a flat slab
Site_description: Blight in 1864 records the remains of a barrow about 73m to the NW of the Tolvan (24549) measuring approx 18.3m in diameter, and the recovery of a pot from a cist. He also refers to a trough-like stone called the 'cradle' on the east side of the barrow which had been long destroyed (b2). Henderson's account also referred to the cist (b6). Dowson in 1966 records the extant remains of a barrow at this location but Quinnell in 1971 found no trace of it. In fact the barrow is still extant, sited approximately 35m east of the Tolvan; and is a Scheduled Monument. It is about 15m in diameter and less than 1.0m high (b5).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1971. QUINNELL, NV / OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: A barrow at Trannack containing a number of urns, destroyed in 1824, is recorded by WC Borlase.<gg summary>: On ground surface a nest of 5-6 urns but only 3 recorded. These 3 contained cremated bones. Of interest is that one of the urns was snugly inserted into another (both Collared urns). One literally encases the other and both had cremated bone. As the urns were of similar dimensions, this is a very snug fit and quite unlike smaller miniature cups inserted into larger vessels.In the mound was found a smoothly rounded piece of granite with a central hole. 100mm x 80mm in size
Site_description: WC Borlase records a barrow at Trannack of 2.7m diameter which was destroyd in 1824 and contained two urns, one inside the other (30587.1), together with two or three other urns and a perforated stone (30587.2) (b1). Russell in 1971 lists the site of unknown location and records no extant remains of a barrow (b3).<MCO1477>: WC Borlase records the find of two urns in a barrow (30587) at Trannack which was destroyed in 1824. The urns were placed one inside the other at a depth of 1.5m from the surface of a barrow. The inner urn measured 22.5cm high and its diameter at the mouth was 19.7cm, and it contained calcined bones. Two or three other urns were also found, the tallest measuring 33.0cm high and 22.9cm in diameter, also ashes and a perforated stone (30587.2) (b1). Russell in 1971 lists the finds in her entry for the barrow (b4).<MCO1478>: WC Borlase records the find of a perforated stone, along with urns (30587.1) in a barrow at Trannack (30587) which was destroyed in 1824 (b1). Russell in 1971 lists the finds in her entry for the barrow (b3).

Site_summary: A barrow excavated by WC Borlase in 1868 in which he found a cist containing an urn and flints.<gg summary>: flat-stone covered cist made of two layers of 4 wall stones. The urn contained the poor cremation of a small adult and two flint flakes, and was associated with other flakes and pebbles. The urn had been tightly enclosed by the slabs, and its base had been removed possibly to allow the cremation deposit to be poured into it.
Site_description: WC Borlase in 1872 describes an undisturbed barrow at Tredinney 11.5m in diameter, mounted on a pile of natural rocks and surrounded by a ring of sixteen large granite blocks set on edge. He excavated the barrow in 1868, finding a cist (28456.1) containing an urn and flints. Ashes and charred wood were found to surround a sloping rock in the centre of the barrow, which when raised revealed "nearly a cartload" of white ashes (b3). Henderson describes the barrow as being on top of Tredinney Carn between Bartinney and Chapel Carn Brea and that 45m to the north of the barrow are the remains of an ancient pack road. He notes a few stones surrounding the barrow but that the cist is longer visible (b4). Russell in 1960 locates the barrow at SW 3821 2448 and indicates extant remains (b5). The OS who surveyed the barrow at 1:2500 in 1960 record that 13 stones of the close set retaining circle still remain. Evidence of Borlase's excavation is seen as a central hollow 4.5m in diameter approached by an elbow shaped trench from the north. A large boulder on the south side of the depression and another in the centre, the latter presumably Borlase's 'sloping rock'. The barrow has a maximum height of 1.8m and the retaining circle an average diameter of 11m (h1). Russell in 1971 lists the extant remains of a barrow with interior overgrown (b6). The barrow lies within the scheduled area of a hut circle approximately 25m to the east (28457).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. GEARY, E / OS--------------------------------<MCO26991>: WC Borlase in 1872 describes a barrow at Tredinney (28456) excavated by him in 1868. He sank an oblong trench across the centre of the mound and revealed a cist 0.4m in breadth and 0.45m deep, constructed of eight stones in two layers of four each. These were fitted closely around an urn set mouth downwards, filled with bones and two chipped flints. Two more flints were also found outside the urn but within the cist. The vessel which had no bottom was brownish and not well baked. It was ornamented with a horizontal chevron pattern and had four pierced bosses or handles. Its height was 0.3m and diameter at the mouth 0.23m (b3). Patchett dates the urn to the Middle Bronze Age (b5, b6). Henderson in 1916 describes the barrows and notes that the cist is no longer visible (b4). The OS who surveyed the barrow in 1960 describe the visible entrance of Borlase's excavation but record no remains of the cist (h1). Russell in 1971 lists a cist, with the find of an urn and flints, in her entry for the barrow but records no extant remains (b7).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. GEARY, E / OS--------------------------------<see MCO3604 for collated record>

Site_summary: A barrow at Tregiffian, excavated by WC Borlase in 1879, which contained bones and an urn.<gg summary>: Chambered megalithic gallery grave overlooking coast at Whitesand Bay - reused in the Early Bronze Age with urned cremation
Site_description: A barrow at Tregiffian is described by WC Borlase in 1881 (b1) which was excavated by him in 1879. Shown on the OS map of 1906 (b3), the barrow is described by Hencken in 1932 as having a closed chamber with a probable false entrance on the east side, taking the form of a passage leading from the chamber but too small and too short to be used as such. Inside Borlase found bones and an urn (28469.2) (b6). Daniel in 1950 describes a small round barrow 6.0m in diameter containing two cists (28469.1) in a ruinous condition (b7). The barrow was Scheduled in 1958, when it was described as having been much robbed and then measuring 3.6m by 3.0m, by 0.76m high, with large stones of the chamber projecting from the north west side and the chamber itself nearly full of small boulders. The barrow is recorded as having a covering of grass and brambles and the field hard down in grass (b8). It was surveyed at 1:200 by the OS in 1960 who record it as being very mutilated and in poor condition, 0.6m high and reduced in size by ploughing (h1). Shown on the OS map of 1963 (b9) and listed in 1971 by Russell who records the extant remains of a stone structure on a slight mound (b10). Sheppard in 1980 (b11) and 1985 reports the general condition as unchanged except for erosion by animal trample of an area 3.0m by 1.2m in front of the chamber entrance (b12). The barrow is visible on aerial photographs (p1) as a low earth mound and was plotted as part of the NMP.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. PITCHER, GH / OS--------------------------------<MCO26993>: A barrow at Tregiffian is described by WC Borlase in 1881 (b1) which was excavated by him in 1879 (28469). Henderson in 1932 describes it containing a enclosed chamber with a probable false entrance on the east side inside which Borlase found bone and an urn (28469.2) (b3). Daniel in 1950 describes a very curious structure consisting of a central chamber or cist, 1.8m long by 1.2m wide and 1.4m high, with a second chamber or cist only 0.45m high adjoining it. He notes that superficially the structure resembles a miniature passage grave but agrees with Hencken (b2) that the feature is merely two cists of differing dimensions placed in juxtaposition in the barrow (b4). The OS who surveyed the barrow at 1:2500 in 1960 record that all that remains of the cist is a short north-south passageway covered by a granite slab 1.4m long and 1.3m wide, supported on its east side by two stones set on edge, and on the west by two similar but recumbant stones. One of these projects well outside the west edge of the capstone. The only other stone, which may be in situ, is set on edge to the north east of the covering slab. The chamber is open at the north end but blocked by earth and stones to the south (h1). Russell in 1971 records a chamber tomb now remaining as a stone structure on a slight mound in her entry for the barrow (b5). Barnatt in 1982 notes two unusual cists in the barrow and thinks it unlikely that it was a chambered tomb (b6).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. PITCHER, GH / OS--------------------------------<MCO1552>: A barrow at Tregiffian is described by WC Borlase in 1881 (b1) which was excavated by him in 1879 (28469). Hencken in 1932 mentions the find by Borlase of bones and pieces of a large pot, now lost, but evidently decorated with zig-zag cord marks (b2). The urn is dated by Patchett in 1946 to probable Middle Bronze Age (b3) and is listed by Russell in 1971 in her entry for the barrow (b4).

Site_summary: A barrow completely excavated in 1955, prior to destruction<gg summary>: central (probably) stone lined pit grave which had been disturbed, and a ritual pit of rectilinear form with evidence of fires in situ, and infilling of orange-brown soil to which was added fragments of white vein quartz and one slatey slab. The original land surface had been replaced over the other feature of this phase, the satellite cremation grave. The cremation deposit was of a female c25-30 with two arrow heads. Immediately below the deposit was a layer of brown friable soil containing cremated fragments of human skeletal material, and immediately above a tamped clay layer.Note :  great slab bearing cup-marks and an ‘eyebrow’ motif, also other lesser cup-marked and ornamented slabs, were incorporated in cairn-ring and bank. Cup-marked stones recovered from the disturbed central area suggested the one-time existence of a stone-built grave incorporating such elementsThis barrow is quite unusual and complex and comprises three timber stake circles surrounding each of the burials. There is evidence of quite elaborate and destructive funerary rituals (see Owoc 2000: 127, 195-198). At least one pot was smashed deliberately Five slate discs from cairn as well . Lots of quartz pebbles in cairn structure
Site_description: Tregulland barrow was completely excavated in 1955, prior to destruction. Excavation revealed a complex, multi-phase structure (b1). Phase 1 within a stake-circle was a central rectilinear pit, of which one end was disturbed. Cup-marked stones found in the infill suggested a stone-lined grave. This phase also included a satellite grave containing a cremation with two arrowheads, and a ritual pit. Phase 2 a cairn ring with a buttressing bank replaced the stake circle. Soil for the bank dug from an encircling ditch. An Early Bronze Age food vessel cremation was placed on the ground surface within the open cairn ring. Phase 3 the whole area was sealed with earth from the ditch, to form a retained bowl barrow. There are now no surface indications of the barrow site (h2).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1955. ASHBEE2: 1974. OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: One of a group of seven barrows on Treligga Common, investigated by Croft Andrew in 1941, and published by Christie in 1985.<gg summary>: This is barrow 5 and of all the Treligga sites is the hardest to reconstruct and interpret (later disturbance and poor record). Miniature vessel with cremated remains. Pot had possible mead residue. Unstratified patinated blade and pot boiler
Site_description: This barrow is one of a group of seven on Treligga Common, which is marked on the OS 2500 map of 1907 and was excavated by Croft Andrew in 1941 (h1, b1). The excavation has recently been published by Christie (b2). The site consisted of "a slate knoll having the form of a small long barrow, 180ft by 90ft by 12ft (54.8m by 27.4m by 3.7m) possibly trimmed by man, who certainly built a low wall around its brow, perhaps to retain a false top of earth and stones. Within the wall an intensive habitation had been established in the Middle Ages, and this obliterated any central deposit. But on the north side, still within the crest wall, was found a one-handled bi-conical mug which has been illustrated by Patchett. In 1976, the OS surveyor found this barrow to be a mutilated sub-oval mound approx 32m long north-south, up to 22m wide and averaging 1.3m high. The southern end was damaged by a small building and bomb craters; an excavation trench is visible near the centre (h2).--------------------------------Site history:2: 1976. MJF / OS--------------------------------

Site_name_other: TRENCREEK - Bronze Age barrow, Bronze Age findspot
Site_summary: The placename of Trencreek suggests the site of a barrow.<gg summary>: urn containing bones and ashes was taken c1724. No further detail It is likely Trevisker
Site_description: The place-name Trencreek suggests the site of a barrow (24202.1). Tonkin (b1), Hitchens & Drew (b2) and Gilbert (b3) describe a barrow from which an urn containing bones and ashes was taken c1724. There are now no visible remains of a barrow at Trencreek (h1, b4).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1977. OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: A barrow in association with the cist and crouched inhumation at Trethill (6342). No barrow is mentioned in Bates contemporary account of the discovery.<gg summary>: cist with crouched inhumation and Food Vessel <Check JRIC vol 4: 444 1961 (NS) - Dudley & Trans Plymouth Institute Vol 7: 134-136>
Site_description: Dudley lists a barrow in association with the cist and crouched inhumation at Trethill (b1) (6342). However, no barrow is mentioned in Bates contemporary account of the discovery (b2).<MCO23272>: A cist containing a crouched inhumation with food vessel was found at Trehill in 1881 by a farmer. The cist was 1.0m long, 0.93m wide and 0.85m deep. The cist was approximately 1.0m below the surface. The cist was made of four side stones and a broad cover stone of slate (probably from Whitsand Bay). The skeleton was doubled up with the arms hugging the knees, and the head in the south-east corner. The pot was close to the skull; it is said to have been of about 0.1m diameter, of rare shape, with a thick fabric and twisted cord decoration. "Several bars, like iron bars" are reported to have been found  running across the cist, beneath the capstone. Finds were apparently sent to  Plymouth Musuem but cannot now be located (b1).

Site_summary: The remains of an outlying barrow of the group on Trevellas Downs.<gg summary>: cremated bone with sherds of Beaker and pebble. Note this pit had been disturbed by mining
Site_description: Trevellas Barrow, (apparently distinct from Trevellas Great and Little Barrows) is a western outlier of the group on Trevellas Downs (19400). It was excavated in 1940 by CKC Andrew for the MOW. It was not written up at the time and the records are deficient. It was approx 8.8m diameter and 0.45m high, made mainly of turf, with an intact stony turf line at the old ground surface. Miners had dug a pit into the middle, just missing a small pit with charcoal, quartz and burnt bone, an 'intact ritual deposit' (b2). A small pit outside the barrow was also noted. Finds were sparse, a few Bronze Age sherds and a modern one, flints and charcoal. The site was recently rewritten (b4). The barrow, with recently excavated trenches, is clearly visible on air photographs (p1) as a substantial earth mound and was plotted as part of the NMP.(b5) - Christie, Pm, 1985, Pers Comm to APJ, 31/5/1985, ,

Site_summary: The site of a barrow recorded in 1848 in which two urns were found.<gg summary>: one urn (Trevisker) contained cremated bone and the other just dust (?cenotaph)
Site_description: Edmunds in 1848 records a barrow at Trevelloe removed in 1839. It lay immediately above Trevelloe Carn and covered a circular wall 1.2m high formed of large stones set on their edges. Two urns (28781.1) were discovered inside the barrow, placed mouth downwards (b1). Hencken in 1932 records the barrow which contained two barrel pots (b4). The OS in 1960 record that Trevelloe Carn is an area of very large outcroppiing rocks on a wooded slope. The area immediately above where Edmunds records the find is now a pasture field, centred at SW 4470 2615. The owner Captain Sparrow, stated that it was broken in from moorland about one hundred years ago. This is probably the site but no remains of a barrow were found (h1). Russell in 1971 lists the site but records no extant remains of a barrow (b6).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. PITCHER, GH / OS--------------------------------<MCO1696>; Edmunds in 1848 records the find of two urns, placed mouth downwards, in a barrow at Trevelloe (28781). The larger urn contained partly calcined bones and the smaller urn was half filled with fine dust (b1). Hencken mentions the find of two barrel pots at Penzance Museum (b4). Patchett in 1946 dates the urns to the Middle Bronze Age (b5). Russell in 1971 lists the find. One urn was found in a hollow in a stone, the other, the larger urn containing bones, in a pit in the rab (b8).

Site_summary: A barrow was noted in 1863 not far from the midden opposite Constantine Island. The extact location of this barrow is not known.<gg summary>: cremation in urn - no further details . Probably a Trevisker EBA urn
Site_description: A barrow was noted by Spence Bate in 1863 not far from the midden opposite Constantine Island. It was a low mound surrounded by a 30m bank, and it had been partly demolished by the farmer for the earth contents. An irregular slab was found in the middle, covering a pit 35cm across. An earthen pot was in the pit, and was part filled with calcined bones. Beneath the pot was a human canine tooth and a piece of flint. It was assumed that the pottery was of similar date to the earliest found in the midden as the fabric was similar. It seems likely that the scatter of flints noted in 1913 (21739) were from this site, after erosion had flattened the scars of demolition. The location of the midden is not known Report 2003R041 identifies three middens, one on the west side of the island and the other two on the mainland to the NW of the island. The extact location of this barrow is not known.

Site_summary: The site of a barrow, destroyed by quarrying.<gg summary> young person - 26 human teeth in a heap and a few pebbles but nothing else inside it.
Site_description: A barrow was situated at Trevose Head, 6.5m wide and 1.2m high, was built without a kerb, and contained a cist made up of five stones 0.25m by 0.5m by 0.8m which had 26 human teeth in a heap and a few pebbles but nothing else inside it. There are no references in the SMR but this appears to be due to an omission rather than that the site is unreferenced (NDJ pers comm). Destroyed by quarry.

Site_summary: Borlase records a barrow destroyed in 1750 which revealed remains of a burial in an urn
Site_description: A barrow destroyed at Trewinnard in March 1750 revealed fragments of a Bronze Age urn which are illustrated by Borlase. Borlase noted "the urne was placed on its mouth near the centre of the tumulus, which was mostly of white spar stone. Round the urne was a little septum of stones set in order, open only at one end; on top of the septum a broad flat stone, about two feet in diameter, which covered that and the urne. The bones in the urne were decayed and turned to clay" (b1, b2). There are no surviving remains (b4). The grid reference is approximate.

Site_name_other: VENNS CROSS - Bronze Age barrow, Iron Age inhumation, Early Medieval cross, Medieval cross
Site_summary: A roadside mound, removed in 1875, covered an inhumation with a bronze ring, which by analogy with similar finds from Harlyn Bay, may be Iron Age in date.
Site_description: A roadside mound at Venn's Cross near Welltown Farm was removed in 1875. Inside was found an inhumation in a grave about 4ft (1.2m) deep, with a small bronze ring amongst the bones of one hand. This and a piece of textile were presented to Truro Museum. Hencken suggests an Iron Age date for the inhumation on the basis of similar small bronze rings found with inhumations at Harlyn Bay cemetery (b2).There is also a local tradition that an upright stone stood here, which may have been the cross suggested by the place-name (b1, b2).

Site_summary: One of four or five barrows that stood on Watch Hill; excavated in 1973 prior to destruction by spoil heaps.<gg summary>: two log coffins that once contained inhumations that were degraded 'NB an Enlarged Food Vessel had been smashed and was found in the primary ditch silting fill. More than two thirds of the decorated part of the vessel is represented; the base was found in one piece; only a tiny fraction of the plain body joining shoulder and base was present. Most interiors, especially those from the upper zone, were coated with 2 to 3 mm of powdery black material. The fabric varies between 7 and 12 mm in thickness, 20 mm on the base, and is friable with many grits. The interior surface and core are black but the exterior is oxidised reddish brown to a depth of 3 to 5 mm. Both surfaces have been carefully smoothed: the grits hardly protrude.78 struck flints mainly from the turf stack. Blades and flakes mainlyAlso several stone tools from ditch fills - including whetstones and granite pebbles 19 quartz crystals were also found mainly from stack immediately above the grave - several were worn
Site_description: One of four or five barrows that stood on Watch Hill. It was described by Thomas as being 23m across (b1). On the OS visit it appeared to be 1.5m high, flat topped (possibly Henderson's flat topped beacon/barrow (b4)) defaced with a 2.0m high conical heap (h1).The total excavation of this barrow by Henrietta Miles was carried out in 1973, prior to destruction by spoil heaps. Apart from some late disturbance the barrow was found to consist of a ditch, with a pit at the north-east containing granite and seven pieces of charcoal, and with two cairn rings remaining up to 0.7m high, with entrances at the south and north (the latter blocked later). A central pit contained two wooden coffins cut from logs, packed in with granite. No bones were found but phosphate tests showed that there had been a body and pollen analysis suggested a grassy landscape. A turf mound was built above the cairn rings, after some exposure. The site was dated to the early Bronze Age by C-14 and pottery typology (h2, b6, b7, b9).The barrow is visible on aerial photographs (p1-p3) and the site is now covered by spoil heaps.The--------------------------------Site history:1: 1971. MJF/OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: Prior to excavation in 1967 the round barrow was 24.4m in diameter and 2.4m high.<gg summary>: unurned cremations and also a small piece of amber; legend (local traditions) speaks of gold from this barrowOnly one cremation had gg Plano-convex knife in mound All that is listed is that primary and secondary burials were cremations Only one had grave goods Note there is also a long barrow very close by but no burials or grave goods noted
Site_description: Prior to excavation in 1967 this round barrow was 24.4m in diameter and 2.4m high. Excavation found it to have a berm and a ditch, and mound of alternating layers of clay and soil. The central area was surrounded by a low wall of flat stones. Primary and secondary burials were cremations. Finds include an amber pin-head, a broken late Roman bead and some 'fine plaster like material possibly used as a backing for some flat metal object about 8-inches diameter'. Local tradition tells of gold from the barrow (b2). In 1976, while the nearby long barrow was being excavated, trenches were put across the site of this barrow, to see if anything remained that might be affected by the roadworks, and to find environmental evidence. The barrow had been totally removed and the ditch fill proved unsuitable for environmental samples (b5). In 1977, when visited by the OS, the site was found to consist of a slight, roughly circular, rise in the ground (bisected by a new wall on the east side of the realigned road) representing the excavated round barrow. It was 0.1m high and no longer surveyable. The site is visible on aerial photos (p1, p2) and was plotted as part of the NMP. The monument is included in the Schedule.--------------------------------Site history:2: 1975. JOHNSON N, CCRA4: 1977. OS--------------------------------

Site_name_other: TREWORRICK - Bronze Age barrow, Bronze Age cist
Site_summary: The discovery of a cist containing an urn covering interred bones, with a second urn nearby, is recorded in 1904.<gg summary> Two urned cremations in vase urns Note very few true Food Vessels from Cornwall and neither of these have handles One is an Irish vase urn and the other is a smll typical Food Vessel
Site_description: The Royal Cornwall Gazette in 1904 describes the discovery of a cist, whilst ploughing, which contained an urn inverted over interred bones. At a short distance was a second urn with a smaller quantity of bones (b1). Sheppard records no extant remains of a barrow (b3) and the OS record the field is now under permanent pasture and there is no visible trace of a barrow (h1).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1977. OS--------------------------------<MCO1761>: A food vessel found in a cist within a barrow at Treworrick, said to have been discovered by a workman whilst ploughing. It was inverted over the interred bones. Described by Patchett as the only actual food vessel to be found in Cornwall and associated with an urn of the Irish type. The vessel is of Abercromby's type C (Irish) derived from a bowl shape with two or more grooves. The paste is rough, the colour varying from yellow to a reddish tinge. The decoration covers the whole of the vessel and appears also on the internal bevel and consists of a band of vertical slashes around the body, with rouletting in a diamond pattern above and below (b2). Dimensions of the vessel are: height 16.25cm, diameter 8.13cm, and base 4.57cm (b3). The vessel is listed by Sheppard (b4) and recorded as being in Truro Museum (h1).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1977. OS--------------------------------<MCO1762>: The fragments of an urn found in a cist within a barrow at Treworrick, said to have been discovered by a workman whilst ploughing. It was found with a small quantity of interred bones. Described by Parchett as being of the Irish type with late characteristics, it has a flat topped rim and softened shoulder angle, three irregular cordons, and is undecorated (b2). The height of the urn is 34.3cm (b3). The urn is listed by Sheppard (b4) and recorded as being in Truro Museum (h1).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1977. OS--------------------------------

Site_name_other: WEST LANYON QUOIT - Neolithic chambered tomb, Neolithic barrow, Bronze Age barrow, Bronze Age chambered tomb
Site_summary: West Lanyon Quoit chambered tomb survives as a single upright 1.6m high and a 4.1m long capstone which rests against it.<gg suymmary>: Primary Neolithic burials without any grave goods noted - Disarticulated jumbled up bones of inhumation(s) in Neolithic chamber . Inc skull and long bones 2ndary cremation in urn with Cu & bronze objects (stolen)
Site_description: West Lanyon Quoit chambered tomb was revealed during the removal for compost of the earth of the covering barrow c1800 (b1). Further digging revealed a broken urn (30505.11), ashes and human bones including a skull (b1). Borlase's account of the removal of the mound (b11) records that the chamber was found with the corner stone having slipped off on the south side, which suggests that the chamber was full of mound material. It therefore appears that the tomb has been opened previously and the urn and bones found are unlikely to have been associated with the original structure (b10). The OS who surveyed the remains of the chambered tomb in 1960, record no remains of the barrow (h2). Russell in 1971 lists no extant remains of the barrow in her entry for the chambered tomb (b11). The tomb, which is oriented north-east/south-west, was found to be open at the north east end. The chamber seems to have been rectangular and measures 3.0m by 1.5m. Daniel records no remains of a barrow and only the remains of one upright stone measuring 1.5m square, which was probably the south west stone of the chamber, with the capstone leaning against it (b6). Barnatt records that two sides of the chamber were removed in 1820 and 1861 (b14). West Lanyon Quoit is shown on the OS map of 1908 (b5) and is a Scheduled Monument (b7). The OS who surveyed the site at 1:2500 in 1960 record that the upright stone is 1.6m high and 1.5m wide. The capstone, which rests against it, is 4.1m long and 2.6m wide (h2, p1). The site was revisited by the OS in 1975 when no change is recorded to the survey of 1960 (h3). It is marked on the OS map of  1963 (b8), and Russell in 1971 lists the extant remains of a capstone and one supporter (b11).  Sheppard in 1982 reports the field to be in pasture (h5, b13). The quarry is visible on aerial photographs (p1) and was plotted as part of the NMP.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1956. SAUNDERS, A / MOW2: 1960. PITCHER, GH / OS3: 1975. FLETCHER, MJ / OS4: 1979. SHEPPARD, PA / DOE5: 1982. SHEPPARD, PA / DOE--------------------------------<MCO1826>: Hitchens in 1803 records the finds of a broken urn, ashes and human bones including a skull when the chambered tomb was revealed at West Lanyon Quoit (30505) (b1). Russell in 1971 lists the finds in her entry for the barrow (b2).

Site_name_other: BOSPORTHENNIS - Neolithic chambered tomb, Neolithic cist, Neolithic barrow
Site_summary: The remains of a chambered tomb with an almost circular, displaced capstone.<gg summary>: likely that the only burial evidence is associated with the re-use of the tomb; urned cremation with accompanying vessel. Possibly in situ pyre
Site_description: Edmunds in 1848 describes Bosporthennis cromlech as a small dismounted quoit (b1) and WC Borlase who excavated the site in 1872 records the site of an urn (30729.11). He also recounts the story of a miller said to have trimmed the corner stone intending to use it for a millstone but afterwards abandoning it (b3). Daniel in 1950 thinks it should properly be classed as a large surface cist (b6). The chamber, or cist, is about 1.2m high, 0.9m wide and 1.5m long. The capstone is nearly circular and 1.5m in diameter and about 0.15m thick. The slab that forms the south-west side is 1.8m long, the supporting stone on the other side is missing, and on that side the cover stone lies prostrate on the ground. The north-west end consists of a single stone, the south-east end consists of  two stones. Around these remains is a heap of earth and stones forming the remains apparently of a barrow (30729) which once covered it (b1). The OS who surveyed the site at 1:2500 in 1961 record that Edmonds' description is correct, except that the single side stone is on the south side not the south-west as he states. This and the stone at the western end are upright and rest against each other. There are several stones at the eastern end but all are considerably smaller than that at the west, and are almost certainly not in situ (h1). Russell in 1971 lists the extant remains of a cist and displaced capstone (b7), and the OS who revisited the site in 1975 record no change from the survey of 1961 (h2). Weatherhill in 1977 suggests the monument may represent a transitional stage between the Penwith chamber tomb and a cist, being too small to be classified as the former but too large to be of the latter (h3, b8). Planned at 1:50 in 1983 by CCRA; the south-east end stone appears displaced. Small clearance stones dumped on 'capstone'. The cist appears slightly south of centre mound (h4, b10, b11, b12, b13). Bosporthennis Quoit is situated within a small rectangular field bounded by high and massively thick walls. The orthostats forming the chamber or cist are still deeply embedded in a stone and earth barrow, ovoid in plan and measuring 6.7m by 5.8m and reaching a height of 0.8m, with the scant remains of a kerb. The condition of the monument appears to have changed little since it was excavated by WC Borlase in 1872 who found sherds (30729.11) and calcined bones within the chamber (h3, b8). The site is described by Edmonds in 1848 (b1) and WC Borlase in 1872 (b3). It is also illustrated and mentioned by Blight (b2, b4). The OS in 1961 surveyed the site at 1:2500 and record a main barrow mound extending from it to the south, but nowhere more than 0.1m high, being almost ploughed out (h1, p1). The OS revisited the site in 1975 when they record no change from the 1961survey (h2). Russell in 1971 records the barrow and lists the extant remains of the cist and capstone (30729.1)(b7). The site was planned at 1:50 by CCRA in 1983 who record low kerb stones to the north and north-east; the mound was measured as 6.7m by 6.1m overall but approx 5.5m in diameter if the kerb continued its line to the south. The mound reaches approx 1.0m high (h4, b10, b11, b12, b13).

Site_name_other: CONSTANTINE ISLAND - Middle Bronze Age barrow
Site_summary: Inhumation cist burial holding the articulated skeleton of a crouched adult male set within a cairn was partially excavated in 2009. A radiocarbon date on the human bone fell between 1380-1110 cal BC.<gg_summary>: rare verified MBA burial within what is probably an earlier funerary monument (hence the broad bronze age date given to the site itself). The gg - a quartz pillow, quartz pebbles around the body - are borderline gg/props but are recorded in the ggdb based on broader evidence of the importance of quartz in this area. Other disarticulared human fragments recovered from the cist may also be associated with this burial.
Site_description: An inhumation cist burial containing the articulated skeleton of an adult male was excavated in October 2009 following its exposure by coastal erosion in 2007. The barrow is located at the western, seaward end of the island on the most exposed part and survives as a distinct knoll. The site displays two phases of activity. During the first phase a stone ring of single course slates demarcated an area, 7m in diameter and approximately 1.3m in height, of a small sandy mound overlying an original land surface. Within the sandy deposit small amounts of disarticulated human bone were found, along with shell midden material and in situ knapped flints of Early Bronze Age typology. Flints of probable Late Mesolithic/Early Neolithic date were also recovered from the old land surface beneath the sandy mound.The second phase involved the construction of a stone monument, comprising basal slates laid flat, overlying and capping part of the sandy mound. The cist, a stone-lined box of vertical overlapping slate slabs, 1.4m long by 1m wide and 0.7m deep, was constructed at the same time and is associated with the deposition of a single individual. The presence of an organic soil horizon between the primary mound and capping stones indicate that the two phases are likely to be separated by several centuries. A radiocarbon date from the human bone gave a Middle Bronze Age date 2985+/-35BP uncalibrated, 1380-1110 cal BC.Further fragmented human bone from an adult, child and sub adult were recovered from a backfill layer within the cist and as instratified finds but it is unknown whether they are related to the later phase or were disturbed from the earlier mound and redeposited.

Site_summary: The site of a group of ten barrows, all destroyed by urban development.<gg summary>: Impossible to know from which of the barrows these urns came2 Trevisker urns with cremations
Site_description: A group of seven barrows in a line with three outliers stood on the downs near Charlestown. They were investigated in 1740 by Stephen Williams (b6) and the site has now been built upon. Two urns were found in the outliers (20341.8, 20341.9). A road was cut through some of the barrows in the early C19, and revealed a number of "British instruments" (b1, b2). A map was made of this by McLaughlin (b5).<MCO440>: An urn was found in one of the barrows investigated by Williams (b1). It was found within the outer ring of stones and was under a thin slab 1.6m across. It was made of rough earth, very hard and black inside with about 8 litres of ashes inside. It was 28cm high and 23cm wide, holding about 101. It was drawn at the time by JJ Rogers and was shown with four lugs (see illustrations in SMR); some of the sherds are said to be at Truro Museum. Note that the drawings in the SMR are confined. Both the reconstructed drawings of the vessels are of one vessel, whereas the sherds are different, ie the sherds shown in relation to 54 are from this vessel; the sherd on 53 is from another vessel and the sherd shown in 135 is different again.<MCO441>: It is said that an urn was found in the demolition of one barrow in 1801, though there was no contemporary record; later records suggest that it was found in 1805 and it seems likely that it was found in one of the other barrows on Gwallen Downs, and that it was quite different from that found by Williams in 1740 (20341.10). It was classified as a late Deverel Rimbury vessel, dated after 750 BC. It was 20cm in diameter and was decorated with dots and chevrons; some remaining sherds are in Truro Museum. When found it was said to contain about 71 fragments of human bones and ashes. See note on identity of sherds, 20341.10.

Site_name_other: GOONLAZE DOWNS - Bronze Age barrow cemetery
Site_summary: A group of at least eight barrows on Goonlaze Downs.<gg_summary>: Barrow from cemetery excavated during road construction in the 1860s. No precise locational details so gg are assigned to barrow group as a whole. 'Charcoal and an urn containing a cremation were found in a pit near the centre of the barrow. The urn was deposited at Truro museum (b3), but cannot now be located'See NRHE record for additional references
Site_description: A group of barrows on Goonlaze Downs, close to Ropewalk Farm, west of St Agnes. They were first recorded by Tonkin (b1) and were also observed by Thomas (b2). Eight are extant and there are alleged to be two more that were destroyed (b3). Their unusually good preservation is presumably due to their location on a high isolated ridge; however, none of them were scheduled when one was excavated when a road was built in the 60s (h2).Two of the barrows 130m north of Ropewalk Farm were included in the Schedule on 7/5/1997. Three of the barrows, 19410.02, 19410.07 and 19410.08 were included in the Schedule on 24/11/2000.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1971. ANK/OS2: 1988. APJ/CAU--------------------------------<MCO2715>: During the building of a road in the 1860s a barrow on Goonlaze Downs was excavated. It is unknown whether it was one of the still extant group of eight, an additional one or an outlier. The best candidates are (19410.8 and 19410.9) within the group, but presumably the site is under the road somewhere.Thomas recorded eight barrows (b1) and eight are extant so perhaps it was an outlier. At all events some charcoal and an urn containing a cremation were found in a pit near the centre of the barrow. The urn was deposited at Truro museum (b3), but cannot now be located. The site of this barrow is visible as a faint circular bump in the field at this location on air photographs (p1) and was plotted as part of the NMP.<see MCO1928 for collated record>

Site_summary: Thomas records a group of four barrows at Gregwartha.<gg summary>: Information from only one barrow that was investigated. Inhumation in a cist with a dagger - ?Bronze Age.Note this is not listed in Jones and Quinnell (2013) recent synopsis of Early Bronze Age dagger burials in the south west. It is probably EBA but unsure
Site_description: Thomas records a group of four barrows at Gregwartha centred at SW 6932 3855, one of which has been completely destroyed. Thomas gives three diameters (16m, 21m and 32m) and it is suggested that in listing their dimensions he is proceeding from north to south. He records that one has a kerb of large upright stones surrounding it, though it is not certain to which he is referring. According to Hencken (b4), one barrow is said to have contained a skeleton, possibly in a long cist, perhaps with a bronze dagger. The barrow group is included in the Schedule.According to the OS, the north-western barrow (35133.01) has been destroyed (h1); the three extant barrows vary in diameter from 25m to 42m (h2) and range from 0.7m to 1.2m high (h1), increasing in size to the south east.The site is recorded by Henderson and his citation in the Parish Checklist is given as 'Antiquities II' but it is possible that 'Topography, Vol II' was intended (b7).(b7) - Parkes, C, 1990, Pers Comm, , --------------------------------Site history:1: 1971. ANK / OS2: 1973. MERCER, R / IAM3: 1975. JOHNSON, NJ / CCRA4: 1980. SHEPPARD, P / IAM5: 1983. SHEPPARD, P / IAM--------------------------------

Site_name_other: MOUNTAIN BARROWS - Bronze Age barrow cemetery
Site_summary: A group of ten barrows known locally as Mountain Barrows, some of which were excavated in the C19.<gg_summary>: Poorly recorded barrow cemetery with very little info about the provenance of finds: 'it is not certain as to which barrows the finds and features relate'. Finds associated with 'Pelynt 2 and 3' and their contexts of discovery were investigated in detail recently by Jones and Quinell (2013). It is not totally clear from this account if the cu alloy and flint daggers from Pelynt 2 (found directly above the cist) can be considered as a gg. More broadly the evidence is a bit of a mess and has to be pieced together from Antiquarian accounts.Recorded here (based mainly on Borlase 1872 and Jones and Quinnell 2013) are:1. Pelynt 2: Plano-convex knife deposited on cist above cremation burial2. Pelynt 1: Camerton-Snowshill dagger deposited on cist above cremation burial3. Urned cremation with unburnt bones (Borlase 1872, 189 following Bond 1823)4. Cremation burial with greenstone macehead (Borlase (1872, 192) following Couch 1845)5. Pyre burial with urn (Borlase (1872, 194-5) following Box 1847)6. Pyre burial with flint scraper (Borlase (1872, 196) following Box 1847)The much discussed Aegean bronze sword-hilt from Pelynt 3 is thought to be a later deposit and is not recorded here (see Childe 1951, Macnamara 1973).
Site_description: A group of ten barrows south of Wilton Mill are locally known as Mountain Barrows. Three of the barrows are shown on the OS 1813 map and several were excavated between 1834 and 1845 (b6).A series of field-names in the area surrounding Mountain Barrows refer to the barrow complex: SX 2005 5445 'Great Burrows'; SX 2010 5438 'Church Burrows'; SX 2037 5435 'Eastern Burrows'; SX2036 5445 'Burrow Meadow', and SX 2050 5433 'Burrow Moor' (b1).A number of the barrows were badly mutilated in the C19, mostly by locals, and various features and artefacts were uncovered but most were destroyed without proper recording. It is not certain as to which barrows the finds and features relate. Finds include a bronze dagger of 'Camerton-Snowshill' type, a stone macehead and a flint celt (skeuomorphic replica of an Early Bronze Age copper alloy knife-dagger found in a barrow above a cist) deposited in Truro museum. J Couch is noted as having donated to the RIC sketches of a  Celt, Spear head, and Hammer, found in barrows, in the Parish of Pelynt, Cornwall  (b11) and Messrs J D Cook, H M Lauchlan and WH Box as having donated a  Kist-Vaen, discovered by them in a Barrow in the parish of Pelynt.' (b12). Some of the finds are described in detail by Lake (b3). All contained bones and ashes; one contained an urn and another a stone cist (b6). An Aegean bronze sword-hilt is recorded as having been found in the Pelynt area but its findspot location is unknown (b10). This is not to be confused with the 'Camerton-Snowshill' dagger and is an unprovenanced artefact.The field the barrows are in has been ploughed so that they are now low, grassy mounds. Surveyed in 1971 by the OS who also found many flint flakes in the field. Other flint scatters have been noted in the vicinity (h1-h3). The ten barrows are clearly visible on aerial photographs (p1, p2) and were plotted during the Cornwall NMP.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1971. MJF / OS2: 1979. GRAY, VK, FMW / DOE3: 1985. SHEPPARD, P, FMW / DOE--------------------------------

Site_summary: <gg summary>: urned cremation but without cist or barrow seemingly . Treviisker urn
Site_description: In march, 1975 mrs. Beyboer of liskeard noticed and reported a ba urn lying in the side of a forestry cutting in largin wood. Mr. P. Trudgian and other cas members excavated the site. A burial pit 0.50M in diameter had been cut through a layer of thin top soil and a layer of earth with stone hill-wash. The urn was in 2 halves and contained cremated bone of an adult. The urn was  drawn and a detailed report was written by mr. Apsimon (b2). The urn was of the trevisker series: it is now in truro museum.

Site_summary: <gg summary> At least 2 BA skeletons with gg Other skeletons also noted bu np further detail
Site_description: Penhallurick refers to a flat-axe and skeleton dug up in 1790 in the carnon streamworks (b1). The find-spot was  not far from where a second skeleton was found by tinners in 1823 (see prn 18495). <MCO394>: A number of human skeletons have been found at Carnon Vale tin streaming works. One was associated with a bronze flat axe (40899.4) And is therefore assigned to Bronze Age. It was in good order, held down by a wooden structure when found in 1790 (b7). In 1815 another skeleton was found, associated with a wooden shovel (40899.2) And antler picks (40899.1) And is therefore also designed to the Bronze Age. A further skeleton was found in 1823, with no associated finds.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1974. -/OS--------------------------------<MCO395>: In 1790 a bronze flat axe (drawing in b7) was found close to a skeleton in tin streaming works at Carnon Vale. It was at a depth of 12m (b7). Now lost (b2).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1974. -/OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: <gg summary>: cremation of possible Neolithic date judging by grave goods
Site_description: A burial containing a polished stone axe, flint flakes and burnt material was found at trink farm in 1955. The artefacts were contained within an irregular pit circa 3ft by 5ft and 2ft deep (0.91M by 1.52M and 0.61M deep) cut into  the gravel. The axe was either of greenstone or of flint. It passed into the  collection of the late rj noall of st ives (b1).  Mr w trewella who occupied the farm at the time of the find, indicated the  findspot to the os. The area is now part of a kitchen garden and there are no surface traces (h1, b2). (b2) - Trewhella, W, 1961, Pers Comm to OS, , --------------------------------Site history:1: 1961. PITCHER, GH / OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: <gg summary>: A cist with a few pieces of burnt human bone was discovered during ploughing in 1940. With a miniature vessel
Site_description: An cist with a few pieces of burnt human bone was discovered in 1940 on Lellizzick Farm, by the farmer Mr George Carlyle. The cist, which consisted of four stones on edge covered with a slab, was found  "in the field where some years ago a burial urn was found" (b3).  The site was visited by George Penrose who, unable to carry out a thorough investigation because of the severe weather conditions, recommended that it be covered over pending further investigations. There is no record of any further work.(b2) - Hellyar, L, 1954, Pers Comm to OS, ,

Site_name_other: CHYSAUSTER - Bronze Age cairn, Bronze Age cup marked stone
Site_summary: An excavated cairn initially interpreted as a hut circle. The cairn was the focus for a number of cremations, six of which were associated with urns of Middle Bronze Age date.14C date suggest that the burials are Early Bronze Age (1950-1530 cal BC)  and 2280-1780 cal BC <gg summary>: Chysauster cairn 38. A flat-topped round kerbed cairn c6.4m in diameter with a ring kerb of granite blocks having a gap on the S c2m wide. The kerb for a while was free-standing and could have been used ceremonially before burial activity, as there was a scatter of charcoal within it. On the central EW line and equidistant from the centre were two circular arrangements of stones set on edge which overlay two pits. There were 6 pits with Trevisker urns,  3 upright, 3 inverted. Five of these contained cremation burials and 1 was empty.  They appeared set down and the cairn designed around, rather than inserted into a structure. The circular stone settings above them were visible and perhaps open for at least an early phase, but were then sealed. Three other unurned cremation deposits were also found in 3 other pits. Oak and hazel charcal recovered and crystal and flint too,Note this barrow a rather different sort of site, both in the nature of its burial deposits and artifact deposition (Figure 5.16; Smith 1996). For all the burials, it appears as though a small portion of each individual's cremated remains were scooped up from the pyre, and with the addition of one or two token items, were placed into bags or urns and buried at the cairn. Many of the individuals were sub-adult but the central pit contained an old adult . So many youthful individuals (this was also noted at Upton Pyne)
Site_description: A cairn on the slopes above Chysauster was initially interpreted as a hut circle in the 1950s during a survey by the OS. A subsequent OS visit in 1975 cast doubt on this interpretation; the surveyor then suggesting that it was in fact a clearance cairn. Excavation and survey by CAU and the CEU in 1984 proved it to be a Bronze Age funerary cairn.
