The monument is sited within a later IA/RB field system (36007.7). Excavations revealed a kerbed cairn, over 6m in diameter, comprising large granite blocks, each with one natural approximately flat surface and most of similar height, placed in position so that the flat faces made up the outer perimeter of a quite accurate circle; an apparent entrance c2m wide was incorporated on its south side. The body of the cairn was made up of sub-angular granite blocks laid mainly horizontally to produce a flattened top, level with the tops of the kerb stones. The exposed surface of one of the top stones of the infill, close to the possible entrance gap had a pecked cup-mark. The cairn was the focus for a number of cremations (9), six of which were associated with urns. The cairn had several structural phases. Within the main central body two adjacent features contained urned cremation burials and appear to have been the primary burials around which the cairn was designed. Placed outside the cairn kerb were a further six irregularly spaced satellite burials, four of which contained complete pots. Two further pits, shallow and truncated by ploughing, were located north-east of the cairn kerb with one containing a fragment of pottery.Finds included Trevisker style cremation urns, worked flint debitage, an amber bead, an ovoid slate disc, quartz crystals and a worked pebble (b7). A buried soil sampled from beneath the kerbed stones, provided a calibrated radiocarbon date 2280-1780BC. Radiocarbon dates from the cremation urns showed the monument to have been in use during the  Middle Bronze Age with the period c1800-1500 cal BC proposed as the bracket in which it was at one time built and used (b7). The site was reinstated after excavation and now sits in an area of enclosed croft (h4).Charcoal (Quercus sp.) was extracted from the top of the old land surface beneath cairn 38, context OLS 534 (7). The charcoal occurred over a fairly wide area and was scattered; ie it was not just a result of a small fire but may be the result of clearance of the woodland prior to the construction of the cairn. Radiocarbon dating from an oak sample from this deposit returned a date of 3650 80 BP (HAR-6548) - current calibration provides a date of 2_: 2280-1770 cal BC (b9).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. GEARY, E / OS2: 1975. FLETCHER, MJ / OS4: 1985. NOWAKOWSKI, J AND SHARPE, A / CAU--------------------------------

Site_name_other: RILLATON BARROW - Bronze Age cairn, Bronze Age cist
Site_summary: The Rillaton Barrow, the second largest barrow or cairn on Bodmin Moor.<gg summary> In cist on one side of barrow they found a skeleton. The cist  contained the decayed remains of a human skeleton accompanied by the Rillaton gold cup, a bronze dagger and other objects that have not survived – a decorated pottery vessel, a ‘metallic rivet’, ‘some pieces of ivory (?burnt bone polished bone)’ and ‘a few glass beads’ (or faience?). The pot and gold cup were set beneath a slab leaning against the west wall of the cist.
Site_description: The Rillaton Barrow is the second largest barrow or cairn on Bodmin Moor (the largest being that on Showery Tor). It is located towards the south-east end of a broad spur in open moorland which has been extensively exploited for minerals and stone. The barrow is a component in a major prehistoric ritual landscape which includes the Hurlers triple stone circles (1402) and Stowe's Pound (1401). One of the richest prehistoric graves in Cornwall was discovered here in either 1818 (according to Borlase), or 1837 (according to Smirke). It was found by miners (Polsue) or labourers looking for stone (Smirke). The find was not described until 1868 (Smirke). The following account is based on Borlase's report of 1872:"A pile of stones 90ft diameter covered an oblong cavity 8ft by 3ft 6in by 3ft high. Each of the sides of this grave was formed of three stones set on edge, one placed in the same manner closed each end, a long flat stone lay at the bottom and a tenth stone covered the whole. Along the floor lay the remains of a skeleton "extended". Near the breast stood an earthenware pot and within it the gold cup. A flat stone 16in square leaning diagonally against the western side of the cist covered and protected these vessels. The earthenware vessel was broken in removing it but the fragments exhibited the usual incised ornamentation of the early British pottery. Other relics were found in the same tomb, but are unfortunately mislaid - they comprised a small piece of ornamental earthenware, a bronze spearhead , ten inches long, something like a metallic rivet, pieces of ivory and a few glass beads."The gold cup, lost for many years, is the only find still remaining. It was rediscovered in King George V's dressing room, being used as a container for collar studs, and is now in the British Museum".Hencken dates the cist burial to the Early Bronze Age, but points out that it was probably not a primary feature of the cairn, as the cist was built a little above ground level into the outer edge of the mound. It is sited on the eastern side of the cairn, 1.0m below the top, and has been exposed by a pit or excavation trench. It is difficult to know to what extent it has been rebuilt but it is in good condition. Internally, it measures 2.2m by 1.1m, and it is 0.9m deep from roof to floor. The backstone, cover stone and ends consist of single slabs; the east side, exposed by the pit, has four slabs, a small gap between them allowing access to the chamber. Barnatt adds that the cist is oriented north-south. Growing on the stones within the cist is a green phosphorescent moss which was first noted in 1936 and is still visible today (ie. 2003).The barrow was surveyed by the OS in 1974 and resurveyed from the air and on the ground by the RCHME in 1985 when it was described as a turf covered cairn 34m in diameter and from 2.0m to 2.7m high, much dug into at the sides and on the top, which is about 15m across and mostly occupied by a large pit.The Rillaton Barrow was Scheduled in the mid 1950s. The Schedule was revised in March 1992.The barrow is visible on air photos and was plotted as part of the NMP.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1974. MJF / OS3: 1985. QUINNELL, NV / RCHM--------------------------------

Site_name_other: TRYE - Bronze Age cairn, Bronze Age standing stone
Site_summary: A menhir standing by a cairn, of which the latter was excavated in 1958 and 1962. A cremation and beaker vessel contained within a cist were recovered.<ggdb_summary>: EBA rc date in Quinnell 2012Cist with cremation and handled Beaker and other grave goods including rounded pebblesAlso a pit with cremated remains and broken Trevisker pots The date for the Beaker is Early Bronze Age - Beaker as past reference according to Needham
Site_description: A standing stone is recorded at Trye on current OS maps (b9). It was excavated by Pool and Russell in 1958 and 1962 (h1, h3) and subsequent reports appeared in Proceedings of the West Cornwall Field Club and Cornish Archaeology (b1-b4). Excavation showed that the menhir stood by a cairn of stones, below which was a cremation and a beaker vessel contained within a cist (31514.01). The menhir was erected before the cist but it is probable that they form a single monument. Sherds found on the surrounding soil suggest the insertion of secondary burials which have since been scattered by ploughing (b4). The standing stone is of triangular section, tapering upwards. At the base, the sides are 0.6m wide and the stone is 2.5m high. There are no surface remains of the cairn (h2). Pool and Russell record that the west side of the pit containing the menhir had been disturbed by a later horse burial (31514.02). Trye menhir is a Scheduled Monument but no HBMC record is held at CAU.--------------------------------Site history:2: 1960. QUINNELL, NV / OS--------------------------------<MCO27782>: During excavations at Trye menhir (h1,h3), a cist was found, sunk into the rab, beneath a cairn. Pool and Russell record that the cist was c1.0m east of the menhir and was formed by four granite blocks set on edge, covered by a single capstone which was in turn covered by a cairn and loose stones. Within the cist was a handled beaker found lying intact on its site (this vessel is illustrated by Clarke in b7). Fragments of cremated bone were scattered throughout. The filling and two unburnt long bones were found on the paved floor. A few beaker and Middle Bronze Age sherds were found in the cist and cairn, and amongst the cairn stones was a saddle quern (b3). Another pit was found to the south west of the cist. This contained beaker sherds and was also sealed by a capstone. Both the cist and the separate pit  were covered by the cairn and are therefore presumed to be contemporary (b4). The cist remains underground (b8).--------------------------------Site history:2: 1960. QUINNELL, NV / OS--------------------------------

Site_name_other: DULOE - Bronze Age cairn, Bronze Age stone circle
Site_summary: Duloe, the smallest stone circle in Cornwall comprising eight quartz stones, possibly the remains of an elaborate cairn.<gg summary>: More like a Encrusted Urn of EBA or transitional E-MBA date ; it has plastic decoration - horseshoe-handled urn containing cremation
Site_description: Duloe stone circle is the smallest in Cornwall and is shown on the 1st Edition OS 2500 map of c1880, described as a 'Druidical Circle'. It is slightly oval in plan and measures 11.7m by 10.2m. The circle comprises eight stones, seven of which are still standing; the northernmost stone has fallen and lies broken. All the stones are quartz and vary in height between 1.0m and 2.4m. The stone circle was reconstructed in the mid 1800s (7)WC Borlase relates two conflicting stories about the urn which was found at this site. In an account of the attempt in 1861 to re-erect three (?) fallen stones, credited to one Mr Pedlar, the urn was recovered from beneath one of the stones. A fragment of this urn is illustrated by Borlase. However, Mr NHP Lawrence of Launceston subsequently stated in a letter (to TH Bewes and seen by Borlase) that the urn was recovered from a hedge that bisected the circle when this was removed, either before 1858 or between 1861-63. Human bone was found inside the urn. Borlase inferred from these details that a burial monument or cairn had been raised inside the circle.Patchett (1946) lists the urn as Class 'G' Deverel-Rimbury style which she ascribes to the Late Bronze Age and dates to "after 750 BC".The circle is in excellent condition but recent plans to make the farm into a tourist attraction might disturb the nature of the site.The stone circle was plotted from aerial photographs (p1) during the Cornwall NMP.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1971. MJF / OS2: 1979. GRAY, VK, FMW / DOE3: 1984. SHEPPARD, P, FMW / DOE--------------------------------

Site_name_other: HARLYN BAY - Bronze Age round house (domestic), Iron Age cemetery
Site_summary: An Iron Age cemetery with over 100 graves, part of a walled structure and lots of artefacts were revealed by excavations at Harlyn Bay in 1900 and 1976<gg_summary>: c. 130 graves excavated between 1900-1906 during the excavation of foundations for a house. In his detailed rexamination of the site archive Whimster (1977; 1979) was able to reconstruct the location of 53 of these graves and to extract the basic details from a further 7 graves. Only 6 of these recorded graves were associated with grave goods. Additionally Whimster established a list of surviving grave goods from all of the graves (and possibly also from other elements of this site). These (minus the items mentioned within the six located graves) are attributed to a single grave record here. Two items most likely to be of late 1st century AD date or later (a bow brooch frag; a double segmented glass bead) are not recorded for now.Overall, Whimster (1977, 80) states that 'taken alone the Harlyn grave goods indicate a materially impoverished community whose few  ornamental possessions were obtained as a result of sporadic, wide-ranging trade with both central southern England and south-western Europe during the later centuries of the pre-Roman Iron Age.
Site_description: During site works in advance of the construction of a house at Harlyn Bay in 1900, the remains of an Iron Age cemetery were revealed. An excavation was undertaken by Mr Reddie Mallett (apparently the owner of the site) (b1), and about 110 graves were discovered. Part of a curved wall was also found,  with two burials found beneath its foundation, which were interpreted as 'votive offerings' (b9). The other burials were in graves  aligned N-S, with the head at the north, and the bodies were crouched or contracted (b1,9). The interments (not cremations) were accompanied by a range of bronze, iron and ceramic grave goods (b5,9). The 'excavation archive' now held by the Royal Cornwall Museum, in Truro (b8), consists of the excavator's notes and a guidebook written by Mr Buller in 1912 (b3), which is extremely confused. Finds from the excavation of the cemetery at Harlyn Bay in 1900 are listed separately in records detailing metalwork, pottery, stone, bone and shell because of the difficulty of associating individual finds with particular graves or excavated contexts 21700.3-.6). It appears from the original excavation archive notes that only a few of the burials had grave goods, and of those found it is not clear what proportion eventually found their way to Truro Museum.  In 1976, the site was re-examined by Rowan Whimster when the building that had been used as a museum was to be extended into a bungalow (b9). Although only a small area was excavated, the written and artefactual archives were re-examined and it was possible to clarify the interpretation of the site. However, the site archive contained details of only 40 of  the burials - the other 70 remain unlocated. The main feature revealed by Whimster was a length of drystone walling set on a clay-bonded foundation course dug into the old ground surface (b9). This was considered to be part of the same feature as that seen in 1900, which was interpreted as part of a  'ritual structure',  a conclusion accepted by Whimster.  This feature was deliberately demolished not long after construction. No new burials were found, and only one pit  from the 1900 excavations was encountered.  Because the acid soils of Cornwall destroy all traces of bone, this site, inundated by dune sand, is one of the few with surviving human skeletal material making it  one of  the most important prehistoric sites in the county.Charcoal samples from the floor of the circular building and from an old land surface prior to the inundation of the site by dune sand both gave dates in the Middle Bronze Age. The circular structure (house?) was dated to 3320-3600 BP (1820-2100 BC) and the OLS to 3460-3640 BP (1960-2140 BC).  The circular structure therefore appears to be a middle Bronze Age round house rather than an Iron age 'ritual structure'.  This highlights doubts about the accuracy of the 1900 excavation archive and also about whether Whimster's wall and the 1900 wall are in fact parts of the same structure. It also recalls Nowakowskis' discovery at Trethellan Farm,Newquay, of  Iron Age burials over the remains of a  Bronze Age village (PRN 171472).--------------------------------Site history:2: 1954. ALFR/ OS3: 1970. MJF/ OS5: 1985. SHEPPARD PA/DOE--------------------------------

Site_name_other: TREVONE - Iron Age cemetery, Romano British cemetery, Early Medieval cemetery
Site_summary: A cemetery was discovered close to the coast north-west of Trevone and was excavated by T Kent in 1848. Burials spanned the IA, RB and medieval periods.<gg_summary>: IA cist grave with gg excavated in 1955. Probably part of a broader cemetery excavated in 1948 from which there are few details and the finds are mostly RB. Only the verified IA burial is recorded here. Although the quartz pebbles and limpet shells are dismissed by Whimster and by Dudley and Jope, given the extended tradition of interring quartz pebbles with burials in Cornwall, these (but not the limpet shells) are recorded here.
Site_description: In 1848 a cemetery close to the coast north-west of Trevone was discovered and  excavated by T Kent (b1). The reasons for the work remain obscure, and the  site was never well reported. A lower row of skeletons, aligned north-south were  found with Roman artefacts, above which were a row aligned east-west, possibly of Medieval date. In 1954 a cist from the area to the north of the main cemetery was revealed in a cliff fall, and was excavated by Dudley (b3-5). It is likely  that this burial was of late iron age date, but from a different tradition to the site at Harlyn Bay. It is interesting that a site should be used as a cemetery over such a long time span, and for, presumably, both pagan and christain burials. In 1994 a human radius and ulna and fragments of long bone were found approx 100m to the north-east after ground disturbance associated with coastal protection works (37279). Although clearly out of context, this find might indicate that the cemetery extended over quite a large area.--------------------------------Site history:3: 1954. ALFR/OS4: 1970. MJF/OS--------------------------------<MCO25839>: The only clearly Iron Age feature in the extensive cemetery at Trevone was a cist found, in 1954, on the other side of the road to the area excavated by Kent in 1848 (b1,2).  It was revealed by a cliff fall and was excavated by Dudley (b3-5). It proved to be an  extended inhumation, head to the north (cf Harlyn Bay - 21700), 1.8m long and 0.5m  wide. It was under sand and shillet in a small natural hollow. The cist was made of slabs of blue slate, and had collapsed onto the body, crushing all  the bones except the legs. The occupant must have been short as the head  was 30cm from the end of the cist.The artefacts found with the  inhumation included a bronze brooch of La Tene I type, probably an early example of a local style developed from earlier wire brooches. An iron brooch of disc-footed type, with glass inserts in the disc, is in an 'early' style not otherwise current in Britain. A shale bracelet was also found, 7. 5cm internal diameter, and in very good condition. Some fragments of an iron ring, one of which had the remains of a lapped joint, were possibly parts of a bracelet, (see illustration in Info File) (b5).--------------------------------Site history:3: 1954. ALFR/OS4: 1970. MJF/OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Trollope recorded the site of probable Bronze Age burials discovered prior to 1860. He records most of them as Roman, but there were also some cists with cinerary vases; the chevron and zigzag patterns suggest Early Bronze Age in date There is no further detail
Site_description: Trollope recorded the site of probable Bronze Age burials discovered prior to 1860. "Traces of the original British occupants of the site now covered by  the upper portion of the town of Padstow were observed by Mr Kent some years  ago. These consisted of three rude and soft earthern urns disposed in a regular triangle just sunk below the 'hellas' (killas) or upper stratum of the  schist. They were from 7 to 9 inches in diameter and were filled with fragments of human bones and ashes. Externally they were scored with usual  Celtic zigzag markings, but they were in too tender a state to be preserved" (b1). See also 26411.<MCO26615>: In a letter from Thomas Kent to Dr Barham, Kent recorded "I have found in Padstow and St Minver, urns, and fragments of urns, which contained ashes of burnt bodies, some deposited in earth, some in soft killas, and some in hard  blue slate stone; one fragment of thick rude celtic (urn) with zigzag pattern and one very fine on which the zigzag pattern is done with an ear of wheat; this I take to be Roman. In one place there were 7 pits of the size of the urns  in about 12 feet square; here the urns had been removed and broken. I found only some ashes and fragments" (b1). This reference is too vague to indicate the findspots but probably refers to burials in Padstow (see 26410), Rock or on Brea hill.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Stone cist with presumed Beaker burial ; again this is near the Merry Maidens and also close other burials of Beaker & EBA date .Note also may have been under a small barrow as there are barrow here.Note fragments of a beaker but no human remains.  It is an assumed inhumation on acidic soil and the bone degraded. Note in the material (?small mound or caping) above cist were beach cobbles including a greenstone one
Site_description: A small cist at treguffian was found in the field no 3471 on the tithe map  (b1) while ploughing in 1948. It contained fragments of a beaker (281941.1) But no human remains. The cist measured 1.0M by 0.6M and 0.6M deep, sunk in the rab and lined with srones at both ends and sides, but had no bottom stone. Its small size suggests itcontained a contracted burial which had been removed by the acid soil (b4). The OS in 1960 note that the farmer at treguffian thinks the siting given by  b4 is incorrect, and give its position as sw 4311 2433. After the cist had  been visited the sides and cover were removed and dumped and the adjacent ground was broken in shortly afterwards but nothing of archaeological intersest was found (h1). Russell in 1971 lists the site but records no extant remains of a cist and  the site is now covered by earth (b5).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. QUINNELL, NV / OS--------------------------------<MCO1546>: A small cist (28194) at tregiffian, found while ploughing in 1948, contained fragments of a beaker but no human remains. Enough of the vessel was removed to make a complete section which was restored at the institute of archaeology. The inturned rim, central construction, globular body and outward splay of the neck place the beaker in phase one of abercromby's 'a' type, and the dimensions are 17.5Cm high, 13.0Cm diameter rim, and 7.9Cm diameter base (b4). The OS in 1960 record that the beaker is among a collection I st buryan church (h1). It is described and illustrated by clarke in 1970 (b5). Russell in 1971 lists the finds but records that the beaker was stolen from st buryan church museum in 1965 (b6).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. QUINNELL, NV / OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: W Borlase records the discovery in 1716 of a cist at Mayon containing an urn, human bone and a sword or dagger<gg summary>: urn in cist with cremated remains and fragments of a dagger
Site_description: William Borlase records the discovery in 1716 of a cist at Mayon. On lifting a large stone 2.1m long and 1.8m wide, workmen found a cavity lined with stone slabs measuring 0.6m long at each end, and 1.2m long on each side. In this cist was an urn surrounded by 'very large human bones' among which were several pieces of 'brass' including the point of a sword. WC Borlase, in 1872, locates the position of the cist along a  lane between Maen and Sennen. He gives this example as an instance of contracted burial (but admittedly a very doubtful one)(b3).  The find is noted by Cornish in the VCH (b4) and Hencken, who suggests that the metal artefact might be dagger rather than a sword (b5).  Russell check-lists the cist at approximately SW 3574 2566 but records no extant remains (b6).

Site_summary: <gg summary>: cremation in urn in cist with a 'leaden spoon'. The spoon sounds odd and is not recorded here. No further information. Could it be Roman if it is lead? Maybe not lead and misidentified. Argued to be Bronze Age
Site_description: Hunt recorded "at balnnon .... Some miners came upon two slabs of granite cemented together which covered a walled grave 3 feet square - an ancient kistveaen. In it they found an earthenware vessel containing some black earth and a leaden spoon. The spoon was given to mr praed of trevetha .... The  kistaen was utterly destroyed" (b1).  The exact whereabouts of the cist site ae not known (h1). Russell has listed  this information, probably erroneosly under medieval finds (b2). The  antiquarian reports would appear to refer to a bronze age burial (b3). (b3) - Thomas, N, 1990, Pers Comm, ,

Site_summary: A cist containing an urn with cremated bone, quartz pebbles and a small bronze pendant eroding from a cliff at Harlyn Bay were recorded in 1990.<gg_summary>: EBA rc date in Quinnell 2012.Note this is part of a more extensive dispersed cemetery at Harlyn Bay. Other cists have also been noted of EBA date eroding out of the cliff - eg see GGID: 10061. There is something quite special going on at Harlyn Bay - concentration of' high status' and non-local graves and objects. A cist containing an urn with cremated bone, quartz pebbles and a small bronze pendant eroding from a cliff at Harlyn Bay were recorded in 1990. It contained the remains of five individuals, four children and one adult
Site_description: In Feb, 1990, Philip Steele reported the discovery of a cist containing an urn eroding from the cliffs at Harlyn Bay following severe winter storms. CAU officers (SH, NT) visited the site, photographed and recorded the section, and took samples of the pit fill and the soil layers identified. The cist was then rapidly excavated and the urn and its contents removed.  The vessel contained cremated bone from several individuals with some animal bone, quartz pebbles, and a small bronze pendant. A radiocarbon date on the cremated bone fell in the range 2120_1880 cal BC and is a valuable addition to the small number of securely-dated Early Bronze Age burials in Cornwall with metalwork associations. This early date also makes a major contribution to the debate on the sequence of Trevisker Ware as the vessel, of gabbroic clay, has a band of incised chevron decoration. Lipid residue analysis showed traces of ruminant dairy fat (1).(See HES Project File 1990 - 029)

Parish_Community_Borough: St Marys, St Marys, Isles of Scilly
Site_summary: A cist found in 1939, 0.6m long by 0.4m wide by 0.3m deep.<gg summary>: been a completely decomposed inhumation burial of a child. A visit by Ashbee and O'Neil in 1950 produced the base of an undecorated pot of "a dark, heavily gritted ware" from apparently recent soil at its bottom. Worked flints were found in the vicinity of this cistNOTE - A few flint flakes found near the cist and these included a barbed and tanged arrowhead, a plano-convex knife and a circular scraper (8 flints in total)
Site_description: Ashbee (b2, b4) records that in 1939 Mr Joe Treneary of St Mary's examined a stone cist by the old quarry on Content farm, NE of the Telegraph Road/Town Lane junction. The grave, of granite boulders was exposed during soil removal prior to quarrying. Treneary's account indicates it was possibly covered by a small cairn. There is no definite account of the original contents which, because of the small dimensions of the cist (0.6m long by 0.4m wide by 0.3m deep), could have been a completely decomposed inhumation burial of a child. A visit by Ashbee and O'Neil in 1950 produced the base of an undecorated pot of "a dark, heavily gritted ware" from apparently recent soil at its bottom. Worked flints were found in the vicinity of this cist (7520).--------------------------------Site history:3: 1978. JGB/OS--------------------------------

Site_name_other: KNACKYBOY CAIRN - Bronze Age entrance grave
Site_summary: Knackyboy Cairn entrance grave - excavations in 1912 and 1947 produced large quantities of BA pottery.<gg_summary>: Assessments of the relationship between objects and human remains recovered from Knackyboy are speculative. Ashbee (1974, 1979) assumed that each of the reconstructable urns that were recovered contained cremated human remains. The latter do not appear to have been analysed in any detail. Many urns and fragments were recovered from a homogenous layer of ash, charcoal and cremated bone (thought to represent the cleaning up of earlier burial deposits); others may have been later offerings.All of the finds listed in O'Neil (1949) are recorded here, including 9 beads and 10 illustrated or described urns (but not, for now, the 22 reconstructable urns). These are attributed to a single grave given the vagaries regarding the no. of burials involved. None of the earlier finds are recorded given the absence of contextual detail for these.A detailed C14 dating programme in 2009 revealed that the burials/objects spanned the period c. 1750-1250 cal BC (Sawyer 2015)
Site_description: Knackyboy Cairn is an entrance grave (Daniel's no 8). It was excavated by A and J Gibson in 1912, when one or two urns were recovered. In 1947 the excavation of part of the chamber by Lewis retrieved 100cwt of pottery. This excavation was continued in 1948 by O'Neil, who revealed a chamber 3.7m long by 0.9m wide, orientated east-west and built against a natural rock outcrop. Two small orthostats defined the entrance, but no capstones remained. The contents consisted of four stratified deposits including the remains of at least 22 urns, 60 cremated individuals and other finds. In the cairn around the chamber was an internal kerb within which were two satellite burials. According to Thomas the pottery dates the cairn to the mid-2nd millenium, though O'Neil gave a date of 1200-700 BC for its use. Knackyboy Cairn now appears as a cairn 16m by 19m by 0.9m high, within which is a now incomplete kerb 7.5m diameter by 0.4m high. The chamber appears as a depression 3.0m long by 0.7m wide by 0.2m deep (h5). The monument was included in the Schedule on 24/10/1972, amended on 1/4/1996 and affirmed on 29/4/1998.The site was cleared of gorse and brambles in 2006 by Cardiff University students supervised by C Johns (HES).--------------------------------Site history:4: 1972. BUTCHER, SA / IAM5: 1978. OS-------------------------------

Parish_Community_Borough: St Martins, St Martins, Isles of Scilly
Site_summary: <gg summary>: A boat-shaped cist, 2.1m long by 1.2m wide internally and 0.8m high, surrounded by a stone kerb.; kerbed cairn.Cremation in broken urn (no further detail about type)
Site_description: Cairn 'B' (Hencken no 3, Daniel's no 3) is recorded by Russell as a small chamber in a kerbed mound. Ashbee also describes it as a chambered cairn, but O'Neil, who excavated the site in 1953, classified the tomb as a cist rather than a chamber because it seemed to be closed at both ends. It was triangular or boat-shaped, 2.4m long and 1.2m wide, aligned NNE-SSW, and without parallel in Scilly. A stone kerb surrounding the cist left room for a little filling, but there was no trace of loose stones or earth in the vicinity, suggesting that there may never have been a covering cairn or barrow. Fragments of a large Bronze Age funerary urn were in the south east corner of the cist, and flint and bone were also collected (b4-b6). In 1978  the chamber or cist was in a similar situation and as portrayed by O'Neil. Its stones are up to 1.0m high (h3). One of a group of two burials (7224). In 1988 (h4) the cairn was found to be a platform of earth and stone, 4.0m north - south by 3.4m east - west and 0.7m high. The oval kerb surrounding  it consisted of nine stones averaging 0.7m long, 0.3m wide and 0.2m high. The cist or chamber appeared boat-shaped in plan, 2.1m long and 1.2m wide internally and 0.8m high, orientated as described by O'Neil. The structure was walled by orthostats. The south end stone was however much larger than the other side slabs, and one resembled the other in-situ capstone which was 1.8m long, 1.1m wide and 0.4m thick. This southern end may therefore have been formed by the slump or deliberate displacement of a coverstone.The monument was included in the Schedule on 7/10/1976, amended on 1/4/1994, and the scheduling was revised on 21/1/1999.--------------------------------Site history:2: 1975. REES, S / IAM3: 1978. NVQ / OS4: 1988. RATCLIFFE, J / CAU--------------------------------

Site_name_other: OBADIAHS BARROW - Bronze Age entrance grave
Parish_Community_Borough: St Agnes, St Agnes, Isles of Scilly
Site_summary: A chambered cairn, 7.0m in diameter and 0.6m high.<gg summary>: Ashbee (1974) gives a complete list of the finds (b5). He believes that the contracted burial remains recorded by Bonsor are the remains of an assemblage of unburnt but disarticulate bones. Hencken suggests that the burial remains may represent simultaneous disposition of previous cremations rather than use of the chamber over a long period of time (b3). In 1967 the Isles of Scilly Museum was presented with one of the urns, containing ashesBroken pots outside the entrance (Hencken 1932: 28). A MNI of 6 inverted Trevisker urns with small knobs in chamber indicate later re-use . All placed on top of cremated remains.
Site_description: 'Obadiah's Barrow' is a chambered cairn on the south west side of Kittern Hill, 7.0m in diameter, 0.6m high, with about ten visible kerb stones in the retaining circle. The chamber, which is orientated north west/south east and extends right across the cairn, measures 5.2m by 1.4m by 1.1m high and is in good preservation. There are three capstones, one in situ, the largest of which measures 2.6m by 0.8m and 0.7m high (h2). The chamber was excavated by Bonsor, who named the entrance grave after Obadiah Hicks, with whom he lodged. The chamber has been previously disturbed at its entrance but most of it was undamaged. The deposit under capstones three, four and five was practically undisturbed and at a depth of 0.8m was a layer of hard blackish soil upon which cremation urns had been placed, one of which remained intact (b2, b3). Ashbee has published Bonsor's plan of the burial deposits which gives a  complete list of the finds (b5). He believes that the contracted burial remains recorded by Bonsor are the remains of an assemblage of unburnt but disarticulate bones. Hencken suggests that the burial remains may represent simultaneous disposition of previous cremations rather than use of the chamber over a long period of time (b3). In 1967 the Isles of Scilly Museum was presented with one of the urns, containing ashes. The entrance grave was formerly identified as Hencken 1, Daniel 5 (b3, b4). Revisited in 1988 (h4). The chamber is of carefully coursed drystone construction, with some rough dressing of the blocks apparent in places. From within the chamber the blocking stone for the entrance can clearly be seen, placed flush beneath the load bearing lintel stone (as planned by Bonsor). The monument was included in the Schedule on 7/10/1976, amended on 1/4/1994, and revised on 1/8/1996.--------------------------------Site history:2: 1975. MORELY, B & REES, S / IAM3: 1978. JGB / OS4: 1988. WATERS, A / CAU--------------------------------

Site_name_other: PARSONS FIELD - Iron Age cist, Romano British cist
Site_summary: A cemetery of ten cists all containing crouched burials and some with grave goods.<gg_summary>: Published in Whimster (1981) as Porth Cressa:10 Cist-graves and one uncisted burial discovered and excavated 1949-50. Skeletal evidence largely absent, but an important series of brooches and pottery vessels recovered. The whole burial ground was located within a prehistoric agricultural terrace that was shown to ante-date construction of graves. Numbering of graves follows Ashbee (1954) fig. 4. All cists were constructed of naturally-occurring granite boulders, used either as orthostats or for the construction of dry-stone walling. Grave-floors clay-lined. Length of cists, 1.25 m-1.75 m externally, implies crouched inhumation.
Site_description: Part of a site excavated by Ashbee (h1, b1) in 1949-50 (7591). A cist cemetery of ten cists was exposed. They lay in a depth of soil of an earlier cultivation terrace (7591.01) and were formed mainly of weathered boulders set in grave pits. All appeared to have contained crouched burials, but only no 7 had identifiable bones, because of the acidity of the soil. Six graves contained goods: Romano-British bronze brooches, Late Iron Age and early Roman pots, and oblate glass beads. A later article by Ashbee (b3) discusses constructional details of the cists and suggests they represent refugee anti-Roman tribes people who crossed to Scilly in about C1 AD.--------------------------------Site history:2: 1978. NJA/OS--------------------------------

Site_name_other: POYNTERS GARDEN - Iron Age cist, Romano British cist
Site_summary: Cists in soil retained by an apparent terrace wall, excavated by Dudley in 1960.<gg_summary>: Robinson (2007, 108) suggests that worked flints and ‘unusual pebbles’ were recovered from all five cists from this cemetery (no inhumation was recovered from cist 5). Only Burials 1 and 2 are recorded here, but the finds from the others deserve further investigation. Burial 7 contained RB material. Whimster's (1981, 369) summary is as follows>: Construction trenches for a group of houses revealed 7 cist graves, 6 of which were excavated in 1960. Full-scale excavation of the area between the trenches was not attempted and it is probable that the burial ground contained further, unlocated graves (Dudley 1961 fig. 26). No dateable material associated with burials, but pottery sherds found in adjacent area belong to first to second centuries A.D. (Dudley 1961 226-7). General similarity to Porth Cressa cemetery in terms of orientation, body position and cist construction and shape observed (although there is inconsistency between Dudley's text and cist-plan (Dudley 1961 fig. 27 and pp. 224, 228) concerning orientation).
Site_description: Part of a site excavated by Dudley (h1, b1) in 1960 (7590). Seven cists lay in soil retained by an apparent terrace wall (7590.02); all but no 8 were excavated. The cists were constructed of moorstone and beach boulders set in dug grave pits approx 0.3m deep. Ashbee (b2) says the cists may originally have had cairns over them; one of the cists at Parson's Field (7591) has a heap of stones over its coverstones. They contained crouched burials; only no 1 and no 2 had relatively complete skeletons the others were fragmentary and decayed. The only grave goods were bronze fragments and an iron pin. The cists were orientated north-south, similar to those in Parson's Field cemetery nearby (7591).--------------------------------Site history:2: 1978. NJA/OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: From C3 BC to C1 AD the terrace at Trethellan was used as a burial ground by an Iron Age community.<gg_summary>: 21 inhumation pits/graves; 14 with hr; 9 with potential gg - all but one items of metalwork. Greenstone axe from Grave pit 3032 is not recorded here (no hr and could be residual); the two graves with no hr but brooches are recorded due to the high acidity of the soil/poor condition of other inhumation burials.
Site_description: Trethellan Bronze Age village was sited on a broad south-west facing terrace overlooking the Gannel Estuary. It was occupied from the 15th to the 13th centuries BC (calibrated), after which time occupation ceased, apparently abruptly. The location appears to have remained undisturbed for  the next 900 years until, from the 3rd century BC to the 1st century AD (as indicated by the metalwork) it became a burial ground used on an occasional basis by an Iron Age community. The cemetery consisted of 21 oval, sub-oval or sub-rectangular inhumation pits, of which only 14 produced in-situ human bone, though disturbed bone fragments were found in the backfill of two graves.  Some of the graves produced metalwork which was instrumental in assessing the date and duration of this activity.  With the possible exception of one example, there were no signs of grave markers, yet there were only two cases where graves cut one another. The majority were aligned approximately north-south, with smaller shallower graves lying in the western part of the cemetery and deeper more rectangular graves clustered at the eastern end.  The burial rite was that of crouched inhumation.  Grave goods were exclusively items of personal jewellery or adornment in the form of brooches and rings mostly in the La Tene style. These suggested a date range between the 2nd century BC to the 1st century AD.  During conservation, fragments of textiles were  were noted as mineralised deposits on two iron items - in one case it was considered likely that they came from two edges of a cloak.<MCO47427>: A greenstone axe was found during the excavations at the MBA settlement at Trethellan Farm, in the upper backfill of one of the Iron Age graves. The find reveals that there had been earlier prehistoric activity on site, but little more can be said about this (b1, p12).<see MCO47457 for collated record>

Site_summary: Slate-lined cist containing human bones including skull and long bones, exposed by cliff fall in March 2014.In an cist. Although no obvious grave goods, the burial was accompanied by a large quartz-rich stone on outside of cist which was deliberately placed there and referenced - borderline or possibly not? But this burial is 14C dated and useful
Site_description: Sub-oval grave cut down into bedrock, with a rectangular cist burial constructed on the west side of the cut, aligned approximately North-South; and a large, single, sub-rounded piece of white quartz apparently placed deliberately along the outside of the east side of the cist. The cist contained human bones including the majority of the cranium in the southeast corner of the cist space, several long bones and other bones including ribs and vertebral fragments.The placement of the human remains within the cist suggests the possibility of an in-situ primary burial (particularly the relative positions of the cranium,  arm bones,  ribs and vertebral fragments). However, the possibility of the bones having been redeposited remains due to the placement of the disarticulated leg bone and hip found above the other bones.The extant disarticulated hip suggests a young female adult individual (1).Exposed following a cliff fall in early March 2014 and visited by Dr Andy Jones and Richard Mikulski of the Historic Environment Service at the request of Public Health, Cornwall Council.

Site_summary: A cairn at Cape Cornwall was destroyed prior to 1879 and an urn was found.<gg_summary>: See also MCO27268 - a very similar record but now thought to relate to a different burial (Patchett has got the two confused) . Urn at depth of nearly 3m in small cist with a large Trevisker urn
Site_description: A cairn at Cape Cornwall was destroyed prior to 1879 and an urn was found (b1). There are no extant remains (b2).

Site_summary: A cairn, 8.5m in diameter, on the edge of Boskednan stone circle.<gg summary>: disturbed cist with urn in cremation - unperforated ribbon-handles/ lugs
Site_description: WC Borlase records the remains of a barrow on the edge of Boskednan stone circle (30684) which was excavated by him in 1872. He found a cist (30683.1) containing fragments of an urn (30683.11) (b2). Blight records the cairn as having been dug into by labourers who found some urns (b1). The cairn is marked on the OS map of 1906 (b5) and 1963 (b7), and Russell in 1971 records extant remains (b8). The OS who surveyed the cairn at 1:2500 in 1975 record a diameter of 10m and height of 1.3m. It now intrudes upon the perimeter of the stone circle and the cist is not visible (h1). The OS publication of 'tumili, site of' in 1906 (b5) and 1963 (b7) may be based upon the urns said by Blight (b1) to have been found in the 1840s, though he sites them to the existing cairn. There is no evidence of any other cairn in the vicinity. Barnatt planned the site in 1982 and shows the barrow approx 3.0m south east of the stone circle; miners' pits upcast overlap the circle. The diameter is approx 8.5m (h2, b9). Visible on air photographs (p1) and plotted for the NMP.The site has a mixture of shortish grass and heathland vegetation regenerating after it was cut when CASPN were doing the work on the circle (pers comm, AP-J, 2010)--------------------------------Site history:1: 1975. QUINNELL, NV / OS2: 1982. BARNATT, J / SHEFFIELD UNIVERSITY3: 2010. AP-J, HES--------------------------------<MCO27492>: WC Borlase excavated a cairn (30683) in 1872 on the edge of Boskednan stone circle (30684) in which he found a cist. It had been rifled, probably by labourers in the 1840s but he found the fragments of an urn (30683.11) which he considered to have been originally in the cist. The cist measured 1.2m long (WNW - ESE), 0.76m wide and 0.45m deep. The cover had been removed  and quantities of charcoal were found 0.6m to the west of the cist (b2). Two side stones of the cist remained by 1906 (b4) but the OS who surveyed the cairn in 1975 found no remains extant (h1). Russell in 1971 lists the cist in her entry for the cairn (b6).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1975. QUINNELL, NV / OS--------------------------------<MCO272>: WC Borlase records the find of fragments of an urn which he recovered during his excavation of a cairn (30683) on the edge of Boskednan stone circle (30684). The fragments were found within the cairn but Borlase considered them to have originally been in the cist (30683.1) which he found had been rifled. The fragments were approximately 1.2m to the west of the cist and were formed of very coarse clay, with chevron patterns and neatly formed handles in slight relief and not perforated. The rim showed a twisted cord pattern. No bones or ashes were found within the fragments (b2). Patchett in 1946 classifies the urn to Class C ribbon handled ii of the Middle Bronze Age. It is barrel shaped, 17cm high and has raised bosses for handles. It is of coarse paste and is decorated with chevrons in three cord plait on both the inner bevel and outside at handle level. The urn is now in Penzance Museum (b6, b7). Russell in 1971 lists the find of an urn in her entry for the cairn (b8).

Site_summary: <gg summary>: A cairn excavated by WC Borlase in which was found two urns. (3rd barrow in a group; the other two were ring cairns which both showed evidence of extensive burning and ashes but no cremations or bodies - pyre sites suggests Borlase (1872: 285)It is possible that these bodies were burnt in situ with the pots being fired at the same time (fragments of bone stuck to the pot) and burnt strike a light (that may have started the fire?)
Site_description: WC Borlase in 1872 records a barrow at Bosporthennis excavated by him and in which he found two urns (30761.1). He describes a cairn 9.0m in diameter and 0.45m high, surrounded by a ring of stones set on edge, and a second inner circle measuring 2.4m in diameter in which the urn was found on a single flat stone (b1). Hirst positions a barrow at SW 4413 3667 and notes that it is possibly the remains excavated by Borlase (b3). The OS who surveyed the barrow at 1:2500 in 1961 record a low grass and gorse covered mound 0.5m high, with a single stone on the western side which seems to be all that remains of the retaining circle. Small stones are visible in a shallow excavation pit in the centre, and elsewhere on the mound, indicate that this is an overgrown cairn. They note some discrepancy between this and two other barrows opened by Borlase (30691) (500m instead of 800 paces as given by Borlase) although there is little doubt that this is a cairn excavated by him (h1). Russell in 1971 lists the extant remains of a mound with two retaining walls (b4). The OS who re-surveyed the site in 1975 add that there is no barrow at the position indicated by Hirst and it seems fairly certain that he is referring to the feature surveyed at SW 4409 3672 in 1961. Its identification is on general evidence, though it cannot be firmly established as a barrow (h2). Visible on air photographs (p1) and plotted for the NMP in 1997.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1961. PITCHER, GH / OS2: 1975. QUINNELL, NV / OS--------------------------------<MCO278>: Borlase records the find of a flint implement in the larger of the two urns (30761) at Bosporthennis, excavated by him in 1872. A small, flint implement of the type normally called an awl but in this context a strike-a-light for a funeral pyre. The marks of secondary chipping are very distinct and it has passed through the fire (b1).<MCO4189>: WC Borlase records the find of two urns standing mouth downwards beside a single flat stone in the barrow (30761) excavated by him in 1872. The urns were filled with burnt bones, but were badly crushed. In the larger urn was a flint implement (30761.2) which was also burnt (b1). The two urns, now in the British Museum, are Patchett's Class F, ribbon handles and overhanging rim tradition (the urns have no handles), late Bronze Age, probable date 600 - 400 BC (b4).

Site_summary: A platform cairn, 37m diameter in diameter and 0.3m to 0.8m high.<gg summary>: degraded inhumation (small) in cist wit two Breton style barbed and tanged arrowheads
Site_description: This cairn lies on the north facing moorland slopes of Botrea Downs at 215m above sea level. The site was partially excavated in 1826 when two barbed and tanged arrowheads were found in a small stone lined box cist measuring 0.9m by 0.5m by 0.2m set in the northern edge of the cairn (h1, b1-b3). The site was surveyed by Pitcher for the OS in 1961 when it was identifed as an earth and stone platform barrow of 37m diameter standing 0.3m to 0.8m high with the fragmentary traces of a surrounding low bank of no more than 0.2m high (h3). Traces of a cist stone in situ were extant in 1961 (h3). Resurveyed in detail by Johnson and Rose who showed areas of C19 disturbance and extant traces of a single upright slab which may be traces of the side of a cist (h5, b9-b11). Listed by Russell as a disc barrow (b8) whereas surveyed features and alter observations have classified the site as a platform barrow (h4, h6). The cairn is presently covered by low gorse, heather and moor grass and the eastern two-thirds are disturbed by presumably C19 excavation trenches and spoil heaps (h6). Scheduled Monument and part of cairn group 16252. No details about present storage of finds are given. The cairn is visible on aerial photographs (p1) as a low earth and stone mound and was plotted as part of the NMP.--------------------------------Site history:2: 1848. EDMONDS, R/-3: 1961. PITCHER, GH/OS4: 1975. FLETCHER, MJ/OS5: 1982. JOHNSON, N & ROSE, P/CAU6: 1987. PRESTON-JONES, A/HBMC--------------------------------

Site_summary: A cairn, 40m by 35m and 1.21m high.<gg summary>; cist with inurned cremation. No further details about type of urn
Site_description: One of a group of extant cairns (16252) on the moorland of Botrea Downs at 215m above sea level. The site was partially excavated in 1826 when a covered cist, 3ft 6in by 2ft, was found containing an urn filled with black earth and ashes (presumably of a cremation) (h1, b1-b4). A second cist was apparently found within this site (b3) though no further details are given. Site surveyed in 1961 and classified as a platform barrow standing up to 1.21m high and approximately 40m north-south and 35m east-west (h3). Pitcher recorded a partially elevated central area and the fragmentary traces of a low bank on its perimeter which stands up to 0.2m high (h3). Traces of two small excavation pits south-east of the centre of the cairn were noted, but no in situ stones of a cist were recorded (h3). The site is listed by Russell as a disc barrow (b6) though Fletcher suggests that it is probably a platform barrow (h4). Resurvey in 1982 by CAU details the features above and records several extant small kerb stones defining its outer rim; the excavation pits were also surveyed and the possible orthostats of at least one central cist were shown to be in situ (h5, b7-b9). HBMC visit in 1987 recorded that the site is under a blanket of moorland vegetation and that the cairn now lies in imporved pasture, whilst some care was taken to plough around the site when the surrounding area was being reclaimed in 1979-80 (h6). This is a Scheduled Monument and forms part of cairn group 16252. The cairn is visible on aerial photographs (p1) as a low earth and stone mound and was plotted as part of the NMP.--------------------------------Site history:2: 1848. EDMONDS, R/-3: 1961. PITCHER, GH/OS4: 1975. FLETCHER, MJ/OS5: 1982. JOHNSON, N & ROSE, P/CAU6: 1987. PRESTON-JONES, A/HBMC--------------------------------

Site_summary: An urn containing a plate, found in a cairn in the Cheesewring district.<gg summary>: Patchett says that the find was "a barrow consists mainly of stones and containing ashes and calcined human bones". The urn, which was destroyed during the war, was a ribbon handled urn probably 20in to 22in high, made of ordinary coarse granite clay from the locality. It was decorated with lines and chevrons, oval indentations and cord impressions, and was blackened "by the ashes of the funeral pyre. Note the urn contained a most unusual vessel - a polypod bowl Note this site is not far from the barrow of Rillaton with the gold cup
Site_description: In 1888 Plymouth Museum accessions included fragments of an an urn found during removal of a cairn "in the Cheesewring district". The urn contained another vessel described as "a small plate with a central hole, a raised rim, and four little legs". This was not preserved but Worth suggests that it may have been "a small urn or food vessel or perhaps for afternoon tea and cucumber sandwiches" (b1). Patchett says that the find was "a barrow consists mainly of stones and containing ashes and calcined human bones". The urn, which was destroyed during the war, was a ribbon handled urn probably 20in to 22in high, made of ordinary coarse granite clay from the locality. It was decorated with lines and chevrons, oval indentations and cord impressions, and was blackened "by the ashes of the funeral pyre" (b2).

Site_summary: A cairn 8.8m in diameter and enclosed by a ring of twenty stones set on edge.<gg summary>: in one of the barrows (they were a pair but one was empty) Inside he found a cist (30668.1) containing an urn (30668.11). On top of a cist, below its covering stone he found several Roman coin. But this is very odd as the vessel is Bronze AgeNote lots of ashes and burnt stones and a few pebbles and animal bones and charcoal found in the mound. Limpet shell in mound too
Site_description: WC Borlase recorded two cairns at Watch Croft (see also 30673). The south west barrow, 8.8m in diameter and enclosed by a ring of twenty stones set on edge, was excavated by him in 1863. Inside he found a cist (30668.1) containing an urn (30668.11). On top of a cist, below its covering stone he found several Roman coins (30688.12) (b1, b3). The OS surveyed the cairn at 1:2500 in 1960. It is 1.7m high and 13.0m in diameter, and consists of a circular dry stone wall of large granite blocks with loose granite rubble piled within and around it. The top is slightly inclined towards the centre and a large outcropping rock is built into the south side of the wall. The cairn is very spread and mutilated by two excavations within the walling. The natural rock and shallow depression mentioned by Borlase is just inside the north circumference of the wall. The depression may be natural as two other large rocks near the cairn here have well formed rock basins. No trace remains of the cist which Borlase discovered (h1). Russell in 1971 listed the extant remains of the cairn (b7), and the OS who revisited the site in 1975 record no change from the survey in 1960 (h2). Gerrard in 1985 recorded that the centre of the cairn had been "robbed", possibly a reference to Borlase's trench (h3, b8, b9). The cairn is visible as a stone bank forming a subcircular enclosure on air photographs (p1) and was plotted for the NMP.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. PITCHER, GH / OS2: 1975. QUINNELL, NV / OS3: 1985. GERRARD, GAM / CAU--------------------------------<MCO27488>: WC Borlase recorded a cist within a cairn (30688) at Watch Croft which he excavated in 1863. A flat stone 0.9m square covered the cist which was about 0.45m deep, and inside which he found an urn (30668.11) containing calcined bones. Under a slanting rock were more bones and a limpet shell. Quantities of ash, burnt bones, a few pebbles and charred wood were found throughout the mound. On top of the earth in the cist on which the cover stone had been resting, lay a third brass Roman coin, with several more inside the cist (30668.12, b1). The OS surveyed the remains of the cairn at 1:2500 in 1960 and recorded no surface traces of the cist (h1). Russell in 1971 lists the cist in her entry for the cairn (b7).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. PITCHER, GH / OS--------------------------------<MCO1819>: WC Borlase records the find of an urn which stood mouth upwards inside the cist (30668.1) excavated by him in 1863, in a cairn (30668) at Watch Croft. It contained calcined bones and a small flint disc, which was smashed by a workman (b1). Abercromby in 1912 describes the urn as late Bronze Age with cord marking (b5) and Parchett classifies the urn as class G, late Bronze Age, Deverel-Rimbury influence after 750 BC (b7).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. PITCHER, GH / OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: One in a group of three cairns; site now submerged by Colliford reservoir.Note the pygmy vessel comes from the turf-stack of the mound and is not directly associated with a burial. Charcoal-filled pits. There was some cremated human bone from a peripheral pit The pygmy vessel is directly above the cremation in the pit and Ann Ellison/Woodward thinks it is intentional and likely a grave good (1984: 81) Possible cenotaphs?
Site_description: This cairn is one in a group of three situated on a low spur on the slope to the west of the St Neot river. Located and surveyed by the OS during field investigation in 1973 (h1) and subsequently marked on the OS 1:10000 map (b1). Excavated in 1978 (site crivc) in advance of flooding of Colliford reservoir (h2, b2). Nevertheless, the site was visible from the air in 1979 (p1) and is depicted on the RCHM's air photo plot (h3, b3). The site of the cairn is now under water. In 1973, the OS described this cairn as in good condition, with a diameter of 7.5m and 0.6m high (h1). Excavation suggested that this cairn had been rather less carefully constructed than the others in the group, although a central pit complex was carefully made and there was evidence of precise setting-out. The body of the cairn was of turf and stone, covering a central pit containing some cremated bone. The old ground surface was preserved beneath the mound; piercing this in the centre was a stake-hole - possibly for a stake used in marking out the perimeter of the cairn. East of this a pit 0.8m in diameter and 0.35m deep had been cut in the old land surface. This was filled with charcoal (mature oak timbers, RC dated 3580+-80bp, 1630BC) and cremated human bone. The sides of the pit were burnt, either because the contents had been burnt here, or because they were deposited hot. Several stones, a layer of clay and two large stones sealed the pit. Around the pit, on the OLS were several charcoal scatters and sealing these, a layer of yellow ash. The turf stack, a very disorderly affair, was raised over this. Within it was found a small inverted pot and a cluster of stones - close together but separated by turfs and possibly not related. Around the edge of the stack a series of large stones were set, whose temporal relationship with the turf mound is uncertain. Small stones were firmly embedded in the top of most of the body of the stack, except on the SE, and above these, a layer 1-2 thick of small loosely placed stone. The cairn appears to have lain undisturbed since construction. The pot or 'pygmy cup' is fully described on pp 79-81 of the report. Flints found are probably residual mesolithic material and are described in 1786 (b2).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1973. JWS/OS--------------------------------

Site_name_other: PENINNIS HEAD - Bronze Age cairn cemetery
Parish_Community_Borough: St Marys, St Marys, Isles of Scilly
Site_summary: A group of five cairns on Peninnis Head.<gg summary>: Two bronze torcs are alleged to have come from a barrow at Peninnis Head (Borlase 1972: 162) ; not directly associated with the cremation The cist contained a heap of human bones of very large size and accompanied by flint flaketwo heavy bronze torques. The barrow was possibly built around a standing stone.
Site_description: A group of five cairns ('A-E'). 'A-D' are recorded as tumuli on the 1908 OS map, and 'A-E' as tumuli on the 1963 OS map (all but 'D' shown as site symbols). Russell only found ('B-D'). The cairns are not identifiable on air photographs. The OS field worker recorded four heather-covered cairns ('A-D') on Peninnis Head. 'E' was found to be a quarry pit. Finds now in Truro Museum (RIC) may have come from one of these cairns (7422). Revisited in 1988 (h2). All were located, and 'E' confirmed as a quarry. The cairns are situated towards the top of the hillslope at the southern end of Peninnis Head. Cairns 7420.01 - 7420.03 appear to be Scheduled.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1978. NJA/OS2: 1988. WATERS, A / CAU--------------------------------

Site_summary: An Iron Age cemetery was found at Trelan in 1833.<gg_summary>: known in published sources/in the BM as St Keverne, Trelan Bahow. Only one grave from the cemetery was recorded in reasonable detail.HOBUID_426602<NRHE HOBUID: 426602; https://www.pastscape.org.uk/hob.aspx?hob_id=426602&sort=2&type=&rational=a&class1=None&period=-800|43|IRON%20AGE|17|0&county=92104&district=92295&parish=92203&place=&yearfrom=-800&yearto=43&recordsperpage=10&source=text&rtype=&rnumber=&p=1&move=n&nor=36&recfc=0#>
Site_description: An Iron Age cemetery was found at Trelan in 1833 when a road was extended.  The graves each formed by six stones set on edge with covering stones were grouped together at a depth of 0.6m to 1m. The graves were aligned in an east - west direction. The bodies were probably unburnt. No bones survived. One grave contained a group of elaborate bronze grave goods: one elaborately decorated mirror dated to 1 AD (b8); two plain bracelets; some large rings; parts of brooches; several blue glass beads and several stone tools (b9, b3). All except tools are in the British museum.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1973. MJF / OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: <gg summary> cist with two skeletons of likely Bronze Age date. The urn was described initially as glazed but then called Bronze Age coarse and rude
Site_description: A probable bronze age cemetery is situated in the area of treworthal.  In 1826 workmen found a cist while levelling a hedge; the cist was 1m by 0.75M internally and was left in situ.  Two skeletons and an urn were found in the  cist.  Another cist was found 18m away, and some years earlier a skelton had  been found in the same field (b1-3).  The assumption that the cemetery is near treworthal is because it is known  that the peyers estate, in which these finds were made, included penhallow, crigmurian, ardevora veor and treworthel (b3).

Site_summary: A Bronze Age cemetery was discovered in 1959 at Portmellon during excavations for extensions to a house.<gg summary>: 2 cists with inurned cremations (damaged). In the cist was a blue-black grain like substance which rapidly disintegrated and may also have been part of the cremation. Or it could be a partly burnt faience object (or copper?)
Site_description: A Bronze Age cemetery was discovered in 1959 at Portmellon during excavations for extensions to a house. The site is near the summit of a steep hillside overlooking the village of Portmellon. No surface indications were visible to suggest a barrow but 0.5m below the surface two small cists were found (24009.1 and .2). Evidence would suggest a Bronze Age cemetery of indeterminate extent on the hillside. A number of shreds were found in one of the cists together with a small piece of calcined bone probably from the cremation ashes filling an urn. In the cist was a blue-black grain like substance which rapidly disintegrated and may also have been part of the cremation. A few shreds were also found in a cutting alongside this cist (b1).<MCO26194>: One of two cists uncovered during excavations for extensions to a house at  portmellon, situated near the summit of a steep hillside. No surface  indications were visible to suggest a barrow but 0.5M below the surface two small cists were found, one containing sherds and calcined bone. A second cist was found alongside, linked by two large stones (24009.2) (B1).<MCO26195>: One of two cists uncovered during excavations for extensions to a house at  portmellon, situated near the summit of a steep hillside. No surface  indications were visible to suggest a barrow but 0.5M below the surface two small cists were found. One containing sherds and calcined bone. A cist comprised a large blue-grey slate slab 0.3 X 0.5M in position and was 0.3M in width. It was separated from the second cist, 0.6M away, but linked by two  large stones, and had been cut through during excavation (b1).

Parish_Community_Borough: Forrabury And Minster, North Cornwall, Cornwall
Site_summary: An Iron Age cemetery is located within this field. Uncovered in June 2009 by topsoil strip in advance of use of land as site compound.<gg_summary (based on Jones and Jones-Lawson 2014)>: a heterogeneous group of features including stone-lined cists, slate capped and stone covered cists, other large pits, scorched pits (potentially hearths) and post holes. Of these, only two features (Fs. 1 and 16) were excavated - the rest are preserved in-situ.Five features were identified as cist graves (Fs. 1, 3, 4, 6 and 16); a further two as possible cist graves (Fs. 12 and 16). Potential grave goods (recorded here) were recovered from Fs. 1, 4 and 16. Five features were identified as stone capped graves (Fs. 2, 13, 14, 15 and 17); a further two as possible stone-capped graves (Fs. 25 and 27).Rc dates from two of the graves (ulex charcoal from  F. 16 and cremated bone from F. 15) were consistent, falling within the mid 8th to late 4th century cal BC; 752-410 cal BC and 736-404 cal BC).
Site_description: Uncovered in June 2009 by topsoil strip in advance of use of land as site compound. Approximately thirty features uncovered, perhaps fifteen of which may be Iron Age graves. These include square cist-like boxes and slab/stone-covered features. A complete iron Age pot was recovered from the end of one cist and this date is supported by radio-carbon dates from two of the other features (1). Report forthcoming.

Site_summary: Zennor Quoit, a very large chambered tomb, originally set within a low mound.<gg summary>: Unfortunately this site has suffered at the hands of random antiquarian furtlings including use of dynamite . Cremated bone and pottery has been found. Trevisker urn with cremation implies re-use in the Early Bronze Age . Gallery grave Degraded inhumation with Neolithic potteryAlso Trevisker cord-impressed pottery with cremation and a whetstone in antechamber. It is uncertain whether whetstone was associated with hr as it was found during the dynamite blasting and in the ante-chamber. It is a perforated whetstone/ hone ; a bit a of a 'speer' also found (?knife/ flint dagger? or even bronze dagger?). Many small flints - flakes and scrapers found in the eastern half of the main chamber. NB no support for Patchett's statement about remains of decayed inhumation in the eastern end of the main chamber with pot (so granitic soil that all would have been decomposed)
Site_description: W Borlase refers to Zennor Quoit as "a very large handsome cromlech". He drew and planned the site in the mid-C18 when the capstone was roughly horizontal and the chamber was set into a low stony mound approx 12.8m in diameter. By the middle of the C19, when it was described by WC Borlase, the capstone had slipped and the western upright supporting it had snapped (b2). It was planned and drawn in great detail by Lukis (1885) when the northern of the two fa ade slabs (at the chamber's eastern end) had been reduced in height by the splitting off of a post  in 1861 (b14). The most useful references are Wailes (1957) and Barnatt (1982). The latter includes an accurate modern large scale plan.As it survives today the site comprises two chambers set into a low stony mound. The main  chamber is trapezoidal with its long axis running 75 degrees to the NNE. The western end is 0.83m wide, the eastern end is 1.9m wide; the total length being 3.16m. The capstone is 5.33m by 2.9m and weighs about 9.45 tonnes. An antechamber was formed at the eastern end by two impressive portal stones.No modern excavations have been carried out but several informal diggings were summarised by Thomas and Wailes in 1967 (b10). A pot was found by a local man in the C19. Grenfell and his son dynamited their way in, in 1881 and recovered a whetstone or perforated hone which found its way to Penlee Museum in Penzance (b10). Thomas and Wailes compared the hone with others from Penwith to suggest a Bronze Age date. In 1910 R J Noall of St Ives dug in the main chamber and found eighteen flints, one a scraper, one calcined, some charcoal, some cremated bones (presumably human) and sherds from two small pots. His finds are now in the County Museum in Truro (b10). Mr Hazeldine-Warren found sherds of  well fired cord-impressed ware in rabbit holes immediately outside the entrance to the ante chamber soon after WW1. They were drawn by Patchett (b8).Hencken in 1932 claimed that the mound was still traceable (b7). The OS in 1961 believed the surface to have been "scoured for nearby walls" leaving no surveyable remains of the covering cairn. Barnatt in 1982 notes only slight hummocky ground as the remains of a mound.  His plan shows how the mound has been broken into small fragments (h3, b14).The site is a Scheduled Monument.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1961. QUINNELL, NV / OS2: 1975. FLETCHER, MJ / OS3: 1982. BARNATT, J / SHEFFIELD UNIVERSITY--------------------------------

Site_summary: <gg summary>: An exposed cist consisting of a shallow pit lined with cobble sized quartz pebbles and containing a cremation (unurned). Site exposed. Shallow pit lined with cobble sized quartz pebbles. Aside from quartz pebbles, no objects recorded. Cremated remains recovered but no details known of no. of individuals or completeness of burialsJudging by its association with other cists and burials of EBA date in the immediate vicinity, it is likely also to be of Early Bronze Age date
Site_description: The exposure of a cist  was reported to CAU by local resident Mr Van Leiden at Harlyn Bay. The remains were investigated by CAU staff (h1). The cist consisted of a shallow pit lined with cobble sized quartz pebbles and containing a cremation. It was impossible to confirm the presence of a mound because the site was set in an undulating area of sand dunes, but it appeared to be unlikely. There was no pottery or other finds associated with the cist.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: A stone cist internally measuring 0.5m x 0.43m x 0.75m set in a pit cut in the subsoil. Four slate slabs formed the sides, covered by a rounded slab, and 3 thin slabs formed the inner base. Brown soil fill with at the bottom mixed potsherds of Trevisker II type and cremated bone. The cremation was of one probable male c. 30 at least: not all bones were represented. Said to be a token burial (still over 1kg bones though) , Arm bones rather unrepresented
Site_description: In 1975 a cist was discoverd by ca butter when ploughing on hithertho rarely  ploughed field. The find was reported to lawrence house museum and the site was excavated by cas. The cist was constructed of slate and contained soil  potshreds and cremated bone. A barrel shapped or biconical vessel is  represented by the pottery. Two cord impressed lines below the rim were all that remained of the decoration. The bones represented one person. The cist was dismantled for eventual display at lawrence house museum, launceston (h1, b1).

Site_summary: <gg summary>: A stone cist was found in 1848 in the course of quarrying at Higher Spargo.Urn is called a 'buzza' and it sounds like it accompanied the cremation (surrounded by ashes) in the cist rather than contained themA second cist with another urn containing ashes was found nearby
Site_description: A stone cist was found in 1848 in the course of quarrying at Higher Spargo, and left exposed (b1). The cist contained an urn, and another urn had been found the previous year (18550), also disturbed in working the quarry (18552).<MCO765>: An urn was found in 1847 in a cavity at the bottom rocks in the course of quarrying (see prn 18552), on the estate of higher spargo (b1). Another urn was found in a cist nearby in the following year (prn 18551).<see MCO25008 for collated record>

Site_summary: A late Bronze Age pot was found upright in a cist made of flat stones at Tresawsen Farm  and the pot and surounding stones were donated to Truro museum.<gg_summary>: said to LBA by Patchett, but more likely E-MBA in date.
Site_description: A late Bronze Age pot was found upright in a cist made of flat stones about 1.20m below ground level at Tresawsen Farm.  The pottery was given to Truro museum in 1904 (b1).  The vessel was a squat barrel shape with slightly rolled rim and flattened bulging sides and with a groove below the rim.  It fits Patchett's class f, with 2 small ribbon handles and overhanging rim, made of rough crumbly reddish fabric, decorated with chevrons.  A certain amount of bone was found with the vessel, and the stones that supported the vessel were also given to the museum, (b1-4). The exact location of the cist is not presently known.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Cist with the urn contained calcined bones was about 33cm high with four lug handles and with a chevron and bad decoration around the upper quarter
Site_description: A Late Bronze Age urn was found in a cist near to Merrose at the head of a  small valley, while ploughing in 1844 (b1).  The urn contained calcined bones was about 27cm high with four lug handles and with a chevron and bad  decoration around the upper quarter (see illustration on OS card), was found  upright covered by two slates.  It is now in the Royal Cornwall Museum (b2).

Site_summary: Crushed Trevisker urn contained cremation in a fine slate cist.
Site_description: A cist at maenporth, located from local information, is listed by dowson in 1965 who records no extant remains. The remains of an urn (24460.1) are recorded as having been found inside the cist, covered by a stone slab approx 0.6m by 0.6m by 0.2m (h1).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1971. OS--------------------------------<MCO945>: A crushed urn containing a cremation covered by a stone slab was found by miss lyman in either 1936 or 1937 in a cist at maenporthy (24460). Then present location of the find is not recorded (h1). --------------------------------Site history:1: 1971. OS--------------------------------

Site_name_other: FOWEY - Bronze Age findspot, Bronze Age cist
Site_summary: A Bronze Age urn and cremation found at Fowey in the C19.
Site_description: J T Teffrey recorded that a "workman, whilst preparing ground for a new road, struck a large stone horizontally placed 3 feet below the surface. Below the stone, a pit kept open by four square stones contained an urn which unfortunately was broken whilst the cist was being opened" (b1).  Patchett lists the urn under the LBA class and Deverel Rimbury influence after 750 BC. The urn contained a cremation and the vessel is now at the RIC.  Patchett says the urn was in a slate cist in a pit 14ins (0.36m) deep, with the urn 4ft 5 ins (1.35m) from the surface. The urn is bucket shaped with an everted rim and angular bevel, height 8ins (0.203m), diameter 6ins (0.152m) base 2 6/10 ins (0.06m), no handles. It is of lightly fired but hard yellow fabric, containing large grit with some whole pebbles. Decoration consists of roughly made triangular stabs in two rows with incised chevrons below. It is similar to Deverel Rimbury bucket urns but the ornament is derived from native tradition (b6). Borlase provides an illustration of the urn (b4). Haverfield and Taylor mention a coin of Trajan and "British urn" found near Place House, Fowey (b5). These are likely to have been seperate finds: the urn being the one recorded by Treffrey ( who does not mention any coins found in association with it). The coin is recorded under prn 26751.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Beaker inhumation in cist Said to be in extended position with unusual Beaker (tea cup suggests handle) at side and a flint knife/dagger
Site_description: A cist was discovered in 1977 at tregiffian by a local farmer which contained a bronze age urn (28221.1), A skeleton (28221.2), And a stone spearhead (28221). The find was reported to the headmaster of st buryan school who  notified the museums officer of west penwith district council (b1). Dapne harris in 1979 describes the discovery which was covered by a shallow depth of soil. The cist was covered by a stone, which when removed, revealed  a hollow chamber with cobbled floor and a slight filtering of earth. On this  lay the skeleton, the pot and a stone spearhead.  The cist was filled in again after the discovery (b2).  Found very close to a similar cist (28221).  (b1) - Coles, G (Museums Officer, Penwith DC), 197-, Pers Comm, , <MCO1548>: A beaker was described by a local farmer as having been found in 1977 in a cist (28221) at tregiffian (b1). Investigated in 1979 by dapne harris who considers it to be a bronze age urn with two or three lines of cord impresses decoration. The pot was not shaped at all like a beaker but more like a tea-cup and was decorated around its fattest part near the top (b2).(b1) - Coles, G (Museums Officer, Penwith DC), 197-, Pers Comm, , <MCO1549>: A human skeleton was described by a local farmer as having been found in 1977 in a cist (28221) at tregiffian (b1). Investigated I 1979 by dapne harris who records that it lay on the cobbled floor of the cist in an extended position, with the earth beneath the skull smoothed hard (b2).(b1) - Coles, G (Museums Officer, Penwith DC), 197-, Pers Comm, , <MCO1550>: A stone spearhead was described by a local farmer as having been found in 1977 in a cist (28221) at tregiffian (b1). Investigated by daphne harris in 1979 who records that it lay on the cobbled floor of the cist to one side of the skeleton (b2).(b1) - Coles, G (Museums Officer, Penwith DC), 197-, Pers Comm, ,

Site_summary: <gg summary>: A cist, found when a hedge was demolished at Leah, is recorded in 1850 as having contained three urns with ashes (928810.1), but no remains survive. trevisker vessels
Site_description: A cist found when a hedge was demolished at Leah is recorded in 1850 as having contained three urns with ashes 928810.1) (b1).
