Russell in 1971 lists the cist but records no extant remains (b2).<MCO881>: Three urns found when a cist (28810) was discovered during the demolition of a hedge at leah are recorded in 1850 (b1). Russell in 1971 lists the find in her entry for the cist (b2).

Site_summary: Blight in 1866 records the site of a large walled grave, or cist which apparently no longer survives. Near a carved rock <gg summary>: Note this cist is situated just to the N of standing stones and to E of a IA-Roman settlement, and a chambered cairn. Also sits to the E of the standing stone known as the Blind Fiddler.Blight in 1866 records the site of a large walled grave, or cist, covered  with large granite slabs, containing an urn with ashes (28848.1), in the  vicinity of a carved rock at Goldherring
Site_description: Blight in 1866 records the site of a large walled grave, or cist, covered  with large granite slabs, containing an urn with ashes (28848.1), in the  vicinity of a carved rock at Goldherring (28827) (b1). The OS in 1960 record that the present occupier of Goldherring has never heard of the grave and the carved rock could not be found (h1).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. PITCHER, GH / OS--------------------------------<MCO633>: Blight in 1866 records the find of an urn with ashes in a cist or grave at goldherring (28848)(b1).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. PITCHER, GH / OS--------------------------------<see MCO27063 for collated record>

Site_summary: A cist is recorded at Cape Cornwall on current OS maps.<gg_summary>: Confusing record as it is similar to the cairn record from Cape Cornwall (MCO2305).
Site_description: A cist is recorded at Cape Cornwall on current OS maps (b8). Henderson noted "in the stone field wall bounding Parc-an-Chapel.  On the east and not far from the road is a recess. Below this is a cist 4'2" long, 2'8" wide and 1' high. An urn has been taken from the cist and traces of a tumlus are heaped around it" (b2).  The OS suggest this is the same cist as recorded earlier by b1. There is a discrepancy in the measurements: "a grave 3_ft long, 2_ft wide and 2ft deep, covered with a block of granite, was found when digging a foundation for a hedge at Cape Cornwall. It lay 2ft below the surface and contained two skulls and remains of urn". Patchett says the cist contained two unburnt skulls and a lba class g deverel-rimbury degenerate bucket urn, height of urn 6 17/32ins, diamter 2 9/10ins (b4). The cist is immediately west of a field wall. The capstone measures 1.2m by 1.1m and 0.2m thick. Three of the side stones are in position. The north side is missing. The internal width of the cist at the open end is 0.8m. Lack of space between the capstone and the silted up interior prevented other measurements being taken. There are no traces of a barrow (h1).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. GEARY,E/OS2: 1975. FLETCHER, MJ/OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: An Iron Age cist was recorded at Calartha in Pendeen and the urn, broken at the time of discovery, was restored and held in the RIC Truro.<gg_summary>: poor contextual detail but this site appears as a verified IA cist grave site in recent summaries of IA burial practices in Cornwall (e.g. Jones and Lawson Jones 2014).
Site_description: In 1883 Thomas Cornish recorded "at Calartha in Pendeen, a farmer taking down an old wall came upon an old cist. It was 6ft (1.83m) long 3ft (0.91m) wide and 3ft (0.91m) deep, covered with large flat granite stones, which were level with the foundation of the hedge". The urn that was in the cist was smashed by the farmer but as many of the fragments as possible were secured by the writer for restoration. The pottery was old and of good workmanship and it appeared that on restoration "the urn would be found to be of unusual shape - cylindrical".  In the cist was also found a piece of metal, probably iron as it was very much rusted (b1). This vessel is now in the R.I.C., Truro.  It is classified as early Iron Age, and recorded as found in a grave at Carlatha, Pendeen.  No information was obtainable from Carlatha farm concerning the site of the cist (h1).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. QUINNELL,NV/OS--------------------------------<MCO27285>: An urn, now at the R.I.C., Truro, was found at Calartha. It is probably from a cist (b1, b2).

Site_summary: <gg summary>: The HER says that one of the urns was placed inside the other but in fact both were inverted and one was placed above the other on a granite slab (found near surface and maybe on cist cover) or do we have a double-storeyed cist?Also note that c. 500m away the impressive gold hoard of Towednack was found in an ancient sunken way. It comprised 2 gold penannular armrings, 2 gold torcs and 3 unfinished gold rods. Original newspaper cutting states: <On Monday 19th March 1852 while some masons from St. Ives were excavating some stone near Towednack Churchtown, they came upon a vault containing two earthen vases of ancient construction. They were found in an invertedposition, and underneath were a quantity of bones and a piece of metal supposed to bea mixture of copper and tin. When found, one of the vases was entire, but the menbroke it soon afterwards. Next day the remains of the broken vase were gatheredtogether and deposited in the St. Ives Institution, with some of the bones; quite enoughof the vase remains to ascertain its size and shape, but no date or hieroglyphic is visibleeither on the piece of metal or vase. The following is the description of the vault by themen:—The upper vase was found near the surface, surrounded by loose stones, invertedon a slab of granite, and underneath a quantity of bones and bone dust. On removingthe slab, a walled vault was discovered, with a vase of a similar size and make, alsoinverted, and under which was a quantity of bones in a more perfect state. The vaultwas 3 feet 6 inches by 2 feet 6 inches, and 2 feet 4 inches in height; the size of the vaseseighteen inches high, fifteen inches over the top, and will contain about six gallons>
Site_description: A newspapaer report recorded a cist found in 1852 near towednack churchtown.  It contained two urns (one inside the other) with bones and a piece of bronze (b1, b2). The cicts was described as being 3ft 6-ins (1.07M) long, 2ft 6-ins (o.76M)  wide and 2ft 4-ins (0.71M) high (b1).

Parish_Community_Borough: St Marys, St Marys, Isles of Scilly
Site_summary: <gg summary>: A cist recorded by Borlase, in which was found an urn containing human bones. Note the vessel is a plain Collared Urn Cist near other funerary monuments and close to sea. Also found close to a standing stone (less than 500m to the south).
Site_description: Borlase (b1) records (amongst antiquities discovered between 1753 and 1758) "a plain urn, inclosing human bones, found in Mr T Smith's garden at Newfort. . . It stood upon the natural clay, inclosed in a vault". This vault, which was probably a cist, measured 1.4m by 0.6m by 0.4m deep. Its sides were faced with stone, it was covered with flat stones and was orientated NNE-SSW. Borlase's description has been quoted by Polwhele, Ashbee, and Russell. The OS fieldworker (h1) notes that Newfort (b5) or Newford (b4) is now called Lower Newford, and that Spence's survey itemises four or five cottages at Newfort - the cist undoubtedly was in the garden of one of these. The  present owner states that the farm buildings utilise the foundations of these cottages (h1).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1978. NJA/OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: <gg summary>: A cist containing bone, shell and a small funerary urn, was dicovered during ploughing in 1941.
Site_description: According to correspondance between Mr Hicks (Steward for the Prideaux Brune Estate, Padstow) and George Penrose,  the farmer at Lellizzick discovered a cist, "about four fields east of the prehistoric grave" discovered in the previous year (ie. in 1941; see 26378). The cist was covered by a white spar cap-stone measuring 22ins by 15ins and was between 5 and 6ins thick. Within the cist were traces of bone, shell and pottery. (Details in Info File)

Site_name_other: BRYHER - Iron Age cist grave, mirror, sword
Site_summary: An Iron Age stone-lined cist grave containing a sword and mirror.<gg_summary><Celtic Art db: https://doi.org/10.5284/1000086>
Site_description: The monument includes an Iron Age funerary cist near the foot of the northern slope of Samson Hill, the southernmost hill on Bryher in the north west of the Isles of Scilly. When discovered, the cist was found to have been richly furnished with an iron sword in a bronze scabbard. The cist, a box like slab built funerary structure, survives wholly beneath the surface of the modern field containing it, the upper face of its covering slabs lying about 0.4m beneath the present ground surface. The cist is defined by a wall whose main, basal, course comprises relatively large slabs, roughly 0.25m-0.6m long and mostly edge set. Above these, up to two courses of smaller slabs and rubble, generally laid flat, infill irregularities in the upper edge of the basal course and raise the wall to a fairly even upper level about 0.25m-0.3m above the cist floor deposits. The cist is roofed by several cover slabs laid flat over the wall. In some sectors the wall's upper courses project rogressively inwards towards the cover slabs, a technique called corbelling. The walling defines an ovoid internal area with a north-south long axis, approximately 1.5m long by up to 1m wide. The plan is assymetrical: the east side of the cist has a shallower concave curve than the west, and the southern end is rounded while the northern end tapers to a single transverse wall slab rising almost the full height of the cist and very distinctive for its regular rectangular shape. The deposits on the cist floor, undisturbed at the time of the cist's discovery, have a surface layer of dark silts on which is an area of modern ploughsoil which collapsed into the cist on discovery. However beyond the northern edge of that modern debris, the surface within the north of the cist includes a substantial spread of the yellow granitic subsoil locally called ram. The cist was discovered in late March 1999 when pressure from a tractor passing above it caused one of the cover slabs to be displaced and collapse into the cist interior. On removing the displaced slab, the farmer revealed the cavity of the cist and observed an object in the surface deposits. On removal the object proved to be the almost complete remains of an iron sword in a bronze scabbard. The sword had been laid along the western side of the cist with the hilt to the north. Lacking only the upper end of the hilt as originally found, the sword and scabbard together measure 0.86m long. Subsequent authoritative examination of their distinctive features indicates a broadly 3rd century BC date for the sword and scabbard. This cist is situated in a locality rich in surviving remains of funerary and settlement activity from earlier and broadly contemporary periods. Beyond this scheduling, another cist of this type occurs at present inter-tidal levels in Green Bay, 265m to the north east on the Bryher's east coast, while on Samson Hill itself, a cemetery of large Bronze Age funerary cairns extends across the summit dome and an elaborate chambered cairn is sited at Work's Carn on the southern flank. A Late Bronze Age settlement site accompanied by rich occupation and environmental deposits is exposed in the eastern cliff of Samson Hill below Bonfire Carn, while a similar site of Late Bronze Age to Iron Age date occurs in West Porth, Samson, 1.5km south of this cist.

Site_name_other: BOSILIACK - Early Bronze Age entrance grave
Site_summary: <gg summary>: An entrance grave with cremation, excavated by AC Thomas in 1984. Two radiocarbon determinations were obtained on the cremated bone giving dates falling between 1690 to 1500 cal BC.  Re-use of a chambered cairn and insertion of a Beaker cremation in a small cist structure before  the final blocking event. Cairn covering a chambered entrance grave, containing a primary deposit on the old ground surface by the junction of two side slabs. The deposit of a partial cremation and charcoal was contained in and beside a small flat-based pot of West Cornish late Neolithic and 'co-Beaker' coarse ware. The grave blocking was some time after the burial.The cremation of an adult dates to the EBA. Early funerary activity seemingly cleaned outNOTE Bosiliack is  one of 13 entrance graves known on mainland Cornwall and is the only one not to have been robbed in antiquity or excavated by antiquaries in the 19th century, although there was some disturbance by mining activity
Site_description: A 'round barrow' is recorded, located in moorland to the north west of Bosilliack, with traces of a central cist and a surrounding kerb (h1, b1). The OS surveyed the site in 1960 at 1:2500 and noted four perimeter stones retaining a mound 6.5m in diameter and 1.1m high (h2). Russell in 1971 listed the extant remains of a barrow with retaining wall and cist (b2). The site was revisited by the OS in 1975 (h3). The site was planned at 1:50 by J Ratcliffe for CCRA in 1984 who re-interpreted it as an entrance grave with a chamber orientated NW-SE defined by six orthostats with an entrance to the south east. Two large stones on the top of the mound were considered to be possible capstones (h5, b4).In 1984 the site was excavated by Charles Thomas for the ICS with help from CCRA and CAS. The intention was to investigate the relationship between the cairn and a nearby round house settlement (30462), and to obtain dating and enviromental evidence. According to Thomas, the cairn is approx 5.0m in diameter with kerbstones averaging 1.0m high with traces of walling between them. A narrow entrance passage, walled with horizontal slabs, widens to form the chamber which is sited slightly north of centre. A probable capstone was found displaced on the top of the stony mound. Excavation of the chamber produced a coarse, friable small pot, with a flat base and a simple round rim, in what he described as the "West Cornish Late Neolithic and Co-Beaker coarse ware class, now known from a number of sites and contexts". Charcoal and cremated bone were found in association with the pot in an apparently primary deposit (b1). Two radiocarbon determinations were obtained on the cremated bone giving almost identical dates, falling between 1690 to 1500 cal BC. A clay pipe stem and an iron bar were found in the chamber, presumably relating to the 'opening' of the barrow in the post-medieval period. Some kerb stones were replaced by the excavators. There is a prospecting pit immediately to the NNW of the site. Weston reported the site clear of vegetation in 1987. The excavation has not yet (2001) been published. The monument is included in the Schedule. It is also visible on aerial photographs (p1-2) and was plotted as part of the NMP.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1956. SAUNDERS, AS / MOW2: 1960. PITCHER, GH / OS3: 1975. QUINNELL, NV / OS4: 1980. SHEPPARD, PA / DOE5: 1984. RATCLIFFE, JE / ICS7: 1987. WESTON, SM / AM107--------------------------------

Site_name_other: TREGIFFIAN - Neolithic, Early Bronze Age entrance grave
Site_summary: Remains of a barrow with an entrance passage, found during excavation to incorporate cup marked stones and to contain cremated bone and an undamaged urn.The 14C date implies an EBA date for at least one of the cremations <gg summary>: Four cremations, all with grave goods including Beakers, Collared Urn and shell
Site_description: Tregiffian barrow is situated approx 100m to the SE of Goon Rith Menhir (28191) and 260m SW of the Merry Maidens stone circle (28200).  It was first recorded by WC Borlase in 1863 (b1) and was 'opened' by him in 1868. Having removed the turf from the mound he observed that "it became quite evident that that....stones had been taken from it to make the surrounding hedges and their place supplied by a pile of mud and refuse from the road" so it is difficult to be certain about the original form and ground plan of the monument.  He recorded a ring of perimeter stones and a large inclined capstone 2.7m in diameter and 0.45m thick resting on two uprights at the south and west sides and on the ground on the other side, having apparently been knocked of its supports by what he (probably mistakenly) identified as a menhir. He recorded a great quantity of ashes and bone splinters and a flint flake, but no pottery or metalwork (b2). Henderson gave the position of the barrow, which he said is still visible, as adjoining the hedge and some 90m west of the stile leading to the Merry Maidens field, and noted that the menhir referred to by Borlase had disappeared (b3). The OS surveyed the barrow at 1:2500 in 1960 and recorded the remains of the SE half of a mound which resembled a barrow. This had a maximum height of 2.0m and a diameter of approx 17m which had been augmented by the dumping of field clearance material on the NE and SW. They also recorded that the barrow was cut across by a NE- SW hedge and that there were no traces of a mound on the road verge to the NW of the hedge (h1). Tregiffian barrow was excavated by Dorothy Dudley for the MPBW in 1967 and 1968; she recorded that the barrow may have originally been 12m in diameter. A megalithic passage 4.3m long and 1.2m wide was discovered, surrounded by a setting of large granite slabs 0.9m to 1.2m high, at about 0.9m from the outer edge of this passage. The stones blocking the entrance, one of them cup marked, had been displaced by Borlase. Slightly east of the entrance a 1.1m square granite block, covered with a whole group of cup marks had been set at an angle to the entrance (28192.2). Another large cup marked stone was found lying in the SE quadrant. The floor of the passage was strewn with comminuted bone fragments and below this floor were two pits. An oval one contained charcoal, stone and cremated bone, and a round one held an undamaged urn 38cm high (h2, h3, b4, b5). A further excavation  was carried out by A Apsimon for the DOE, in 1972, to supplement Dudley's work in 1967/68. This  was confined to the completion of the plan of the chamber prior to conservation and restoration (h4, b7). Russell in 1971 listed the site and recorded the extant remains of a barrow with a stone structure (b6). Sheppard in 1982 noted that the ground on each side of the outer ring of stones had been eroded by visitors. The bare strips were approx 3.6m long by 0.6m wide (b8). The entrance grave is visible on aerial photographs. The monument was included in the Schedule on 9/12/1968 and the scheduling revised on 20/2/1996.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. QUINNELL, NV /OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: A shallow pit excavated in 1984 containing a Bronze Age cremation urn.<gg_summary>: Unusual urned cremation in pit - potentially a decent candidate for a MBA burial but Trevisker chronology is too vague to assign a specific BA date.
Site_description: A crescent of orange/black pottery weathering out of the side of a road section to a new bungalow near Trewoon was first noticed Babara Jupp in 1984  (b1). The site was visited by the CCRA in 1984 when it was identified as being of Bronze Age date (h1). During excavation by CAS/CCRA in July 1984 the base and about 20cm of the side wall of the urn was found in a shallow pit, cut into a backfilled with shillet, and not well defined. The depression cut into the natural slate at the base of the hole was quite obvious. The urn appears to have been truncated during the cutting for a new road (h2). A quantity of cremated human bone was concentrated in the bottom 20mm of the urn and a small quantity was also found in the earth around the outside of the urn (b2).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1984. HARTGROVES, S / CCRA--------------------------------

Site_name_other: TREGESEAL - Neolithic entrance grave, Bronze Age entrance grave
Site_summary: A chambered cairn up to 1.4m high, excavated in 1879 when a ribbon handled urn was found in the cist.<gg summary>:Upon floor of chamber were cremated bones,, ashes (cremations), broken pots and a perforated whetstone in the chamber and a 'Middle Bronze Age' ribbon handled urn in the cist (b9, b10, b14). The urn is now in the British MuseumCist inserted at a later date with inverted ribbon-handled urn over cremated bones
Site_description: A chambered cairn is recorded on current OS maps (b15). It is sited on a gentle slope above a valley. It is classified by Barnatt as a north entrance grave (b16). This mound was excavated in 1879 by WC Borlase. It proved to be an oval mound with a retaining wall, containing a roofed chamber and a cist outside it. Finds include sherds, ashes (cremations), a whetstone in the chamber and a Middle Bronze Age ribbon handled urn in the cist (b9, b10, b14). The urn is now in the British Museum. In 1961 the OS recorded that the barrow is 1.4m high on the SE side, 0.3m high on the NW and is much mutilated by excavation and is now overgrown with bracken and brambles. Many of the outer retaining stones are visible though some have been displaced. No trace could be seen of the inner ring. The main chamber is still much as described by Borlase. It is 3.8m long with an average width of 1.2m. The north end is covered by two stone slabs for a distance of 1.9m. The covered part has an internal height of 0.7m. The paving referred to by Borlase is possibly still under the earth which now forms the floor of the chamber. There is no trace of the platform at the north end of the chamber and the only sign of the small cist at this end is a recumbent slab, probably the floor of the cist (h1). This site should be Scheduled. The cairn is visible on aerial photographs (p1) and was plotted as part of the NMP.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. QUINNELL, NV / OS2: 1975. FLETCHER, MS / OS--------------------------------

Site_name_other: CONSTANTINE ISLAND - Iron Age hut circle
Site_summary: Two Iron Age hut circles on Constantine Island.<gg_summary>: IA cist burial within settlement context, excavated in the early 20th century. V poor contextual detail. Basic details entered.
Site_description: Constantine Island is a small peninsula 35m by 15m in size divided from the land at high tide and now suffering much erosion. The top is said to be a raised beach but this may be an illusion as the sand that spreads over the whole area has also been deposited here. In the early C20 the remains of two huts and a cremation with grave goods, were found. There are now negligible remains apart from an underlying layer of flints (21721), probably a scatter from the many well-preserved midden deposits (21730.6 and 21731). The huts and cremation were dated to the La Tene Iron Age, and probably form part of the settlement found close to the island on the mainland (21731). Crawford found a stone axe in 1921 (b4).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1901. PENROSE WILLIAMS/ WHE2: 1904. ARTHUR, JP / PRIVATE3: 1920. CRAWFORD, OGS / OS4: 1970. MJF / OS--------------------------------<MCO25847>: Penrose Williams has described a cist found on Constantine Island, the exact location of the cist is uncertain; the bones were found in a poorly cremated state and fractured by dampness. JP Arthur claims the bones were "arranged in a neat little heap between two small slabs of slate" (b1) but also has suggested a story about cannibalism following Williams observation that the bones seemed to have been cut up after death; a later specialist report clearly showed the error of this idea but continued by claiming that the body was female, of 5ft 5in height. Claims of this sort  are impossible to substantiate from bones in such poor condition. Some sherds of a black hand made pot were found in the cist, with some flint flakes and a worked piece of quartzite. The site could not be definitely located, but may have lain within one of two hollows on the island that may be the result of excavations (b10).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1901. PENROSE WILLIAMS / WWE2: 1904. ARTHUR, JP / PRIVATE3: 1920. CRAWFORD, OGS / DOE4: 1970. MJF / OS5: 1978. NDJ /CCRA--------------------------------<MCO46104>: At the northern edge of Constantine Island a pair of upright slate slabs can be seen protruding from wind blown sand deposits at a depth of approximately 2.0m below the surface. Above and to the southwest a larger flat laid slate slab rests upon the upright stones. The arrangement of stones and their position within aeolian deposits suggests a built structure and the most likely interpretation is that these stones represent a cist burial. This is likely to date to the Early Bronze Age. The cist, although visible in the cliff edge, is not at any immediate risk from erosion since it lies on the leeward side of the island. The ground around it is covered with thick grassy vegetation and this is preventing erosion on the scale apparent elsewhere on the island (b1).<MCO46105>: A polished granite implement was recovered during a field survey from an eroding cliff face on the northwestern side of Constantine Island (b1). The tool had been broken in antiquity and the sub-oval fragment recovered measured 11cm by 4cm along its longest face and tapered to a width of 2cm. It has been identified as a lapstone (Carl Thorpe pers comm) used for polishing leather. It is likely to be of prehistoric origin. The stone came from a pocket of the midden material covering the island at a depth of 0.4m below the surface. Numerous fragments of burnt bone were also recovered from the vicinity of the lapstone within the same deposit. The stratigraphy here seemed disturbed in comparison with the well-stratified midden material to either side, perhaps indicating an intrusion into the midden. This might indicate a cist burial eroding out of the cliff, and thus a Bronze Age date, although no structural features were observed. The artefact has been returned to the NT warden for the Holywell Bay - Camel Estuary area.

Site_name_other: BANTS CARN - Neolithic entrance grave, Bronze Age entrance grave
Parish_Community_Borough: St Marys, St Marys, Isles of Scilly
Site_summary: An entrance grave comprising a massive chamber encircled by two kerbs.<gg summary>: Bonsor found 4 cremations and poss Neolithic pottery. Ashbee found 140 sherds (inc some BA types) representing 11 vessels. Sawyer records this as four cremation deposits with sherds of ambiguous (Neo/BA) date - the interpretation followed here: 'four heaps of ash containing burnt bones and charcoal at the distal end of the chamber,together with fragments of pottery.' (Sawyer 2015, 54)
Site_description: Recorded as tumulus and kistuaen on the 1908 OS map and named as Bant's Carn on the 1963 OS map, this is Hencken's no 2 and Daniel's no 3. It is one of the tombs excavated by Bonsor in 1900 but not published (by Hencken) until after his death (b3). He found four cremations at the inner end of the chamber and possible neolithic pottery from its entrance. Other pottery found was of Bronze Age type. In 1970 Ashbee (b12) re-erected a fallen capstone and displaced door jamb. An area, 0.6m by 0.4m was excavated in order to reseat the jambstone in position as indicated on Bonsor's plan. About one hundred and forty sherds were recovered from the cutting, representing about eleven vessels and increasing the range found by Bonsor. Two worked flints from Bant's Carn were presented to the Isles of Scilly museum in December 1976. The OS fieldworker (h5) describes Bant's Carn as an entrance grave comprising a massive chamber encircled by two kerbs. The outer kerb is 13m diameter and  0.6m high, and the inner is 8.0m diameter and 1.0m high. The overall height of the cairn is 2.3m with the chamber 5.3m long and 1.4m by 1.4m wide, but slightly narrower at the distal end, 1.2m. The entrance grave is in excellent condition (h5). Thomas says it appears to sit on top of an earlier lynchet, in the corner of a field (7442). In 1988 (h6) the central mound bounded by the inner kerb was found to be oval in plan, 8.6m by 6.2m across and 2.3m high; its kerb beng coursed walling 1.2m high on the north west side and 0.4m high on the south east, rather than individual stones. The surrounding platform was D-shaped in plan, built out from the slope, 0.4m high on the south east (uphill) side and 1.5m high downhill and 13.2m diameter. Its kerb stones, surrounding the downhill sides, averaged 0.7m long and 0.3m wide by 0.6m high, and included a natural rock on the west side of the kerb. The chamber was boat shaped in plan, 4.9m long and 1.6m wide in the centre, 1.2m wide at either end, and 1.5m high. It was orientated ENE-WSW with the entrance at the east end. The entrance passage was 5.0m long and 1.0m wide. The walling was of coursed stone, with orthostats edging the north west of the passage into the chamber. The four capstones averaged 2.0m long and 1.1m wide and 0.25m thick. Though reconstructed, the site was apparently little damaged; a field wall has been built along and partly over the outer kerb on the south side.The monument was included in the Schedule on 11/5/1950, amended on 19/6/1980 and 1/4/1994, and the scheduling was affirmed on 16/11/1998. The grave is visible on aerial photographs (p1) and was plotted as part of the NMP.--------------------------------Site history:2: 1979. YOUNG, C / IAM3: 1958. TANGYE, M5: 1978. NJA / OS6: 1988. RATCLIFFE, J / CAU--------------------------------

Site_name_other: YELLOW ROCK CARN - Bronze Age findspot
Parish_Community_Borough: St Martins, St Martins, Isles of Scilly
Site_summary: A cremation urn was found by Lewis in a natural cleft in the rocks near Yellow Rock Carn.<gg summary>: Trevisker urn but location reminiscent of a chamber tomb. Rock cleft rather than a cist
Site_description: A cremation urn was found by Lewis in a natural cleft in the rocks near Yellow Rock Carn and was photographed by Alexander Gibson (b1, b2). From the photograph the urn appears to have been found NE of the carn where there is a  cleft of similar appearance (h1). The urn and original photograph are both apparently at the Isles of Scilly museum (JR).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1978. NJA / OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: Highgate ritual enclosure, an Early Bronze Age cremation site discovered during a watching brief in advance of the Indian Queens bypass.<gg summary>:  cremation in a decorated urn. with a bronze awl
Site_description: Highgate ritual enclosure is an Early Bronze Age site of a previously undocumented type. It was discovered during a watching brief undertaken during the initial stages of the construction of the A30 Indian Queens bypass. The site comprised an oval space, 10m by 12m, defined by a series of shallow segmented ditches and postholes forming a horse-shoe arrangement. Towards the centre lay a fairly deep pit containing a cremation in a decorated urn. The urn had been broken either before or during the act of depostion and the pit had been sealed with a black silty layer. Close by was a large quartz block embedded in the clay subsoil - possibly a marker stone. The cremation was found to include a bronze awl among the bone fragments.  There was no sign of a mound over this feature. The site lies only 50m to the north of Little Gaverigan barrow (171736).

Site_summary: A barrow excavated by Borlase in 1754, likely to have been an entrance grave, containing five urns and urn fragments.At least three of the urns contained cremated remains ; re-use of earlier Neolithic tomb (no mention of any Neolithic remains or burials etc).
Site_description: The westernmost barrow of a barrow group (29799) was excavated by Borlase in 1754. It measured 36ft (11m) diameter and approx 15ft (4.58m) high. Borlase recorded finding "a kind of cave or door vault, with a tall stone on each side and a covering stone across". A covered stone cist and a group of five urns of varying size containing bone were found. Loose bones and urn fragments were also discovered (b1). Hencken, Daniel and Barnatt suggest that this was likely to have been an entrance grave (b5, b7, b8).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. GEARY, E/OS--------------------------------

Site_name_other: CARRION ROCK - Bronze Age entrance grave
Parish_Community_Borough: St Martins, St Martins, Isles of Scilly
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Two Bronze Age urns and corroded fragments of a bronze dagger were found by Alexander Gibson in a barrow at Carrion Rock/Cruther's Neck.  Note daggers not that common as grave goods in Cornwall
Site_description: Two Bronze Age urns and corroded fragments of a bronze dagger were found by Alexander Gibson in a barrow at Carrion Rock (b1-b3). The dagger fragments are apparently in the Isles of Scilly museum. The OS fieldworker thought this was possibly the chambered barrow dug by Gibson and suggests that this was the one at Cruther's Neck (7170) (h1). However, O'Neil concluded that the find was made at Knackyboy cairn (7162). No barrow can be seen in the vicinity of Carrion Rock but this may be because the area has been thoroughly pillaged for stone (h1). The site was revisited in 1988 (h2) and no remains were found at this location (h2).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1978. NJA/OS2: 1988. THORPE, C/CAU--------------------------------

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Two Food Vessel urns containing cremated bone, ironically found while grave digging in Penzance cemetery
Site_description: Two urns were discovered during grave digging in Penzance cemetery in 1886 (b2). One of the urns was smashed and contained bones. The sexton retained part of the other (b1). Patchett lists the surviving vessell as class e (middle bronze age food vessel type). It has a wide mouth and a slight footring and the decoration is small incisions in groups (b3). The present wherabouts of the urn is not recorded.

Site_name_other: GWITHIAN, SITE GM/X - Bronze Age hearth, Bronze Age hut circle
Site_summary: House 3 on site GM/X at Gwithian is a hut circle belonging to the Middle Bronze Age.<gg_summary>: In discussing Phase 3 at Gwithian (c. 1500-1200 cal BC) Nowakowski et al (2007, 29) note that 'Each of the cremation pits contained the partial remains of a single cremated human adult with pyre goods (animal bone and marine shell) (McKinley 2004).In discussing Phase 5 at Gwithian (c. 1300-900 cal BC) Nowakowski et al (2007, 31) note that 'below-floor deposits were present in two of the structures. Beneath the laterfloor surface of one building [724] an earlier post-built structure [725] was uncovered together with internal features, finds and human burials. All appear to have been sealed deliberately beneath the later floor of structure. A group of features and finds along the northeastern side of the building included a probable wooden bowl (colour plate 11) filled with unfired clay and sealed with granite ‘chips’. A saddle quern and a pit full of stone tools all sealed by a layer ofunfired clay lay alongside. Associated with this group were two long bones of a human infant.Next to this sealed group of features was another wooden bowl alongside a group of stone tools, again both sealed by clay and again in association with human baby long bones.On the south-east side of the building were two clay-lined pits and in the northwest quadrant of the structure a complete neo-natal human skeleton was found sealed by the later floor.Only the cremation burials are entered for now. Inhumations are more depositional practices involving human bone.
Site_description: House 3 on site GM/X at Gwithian is a hut circle belonging to the Middle Bronze Age phase of occupation, lying to the south west of house 2 (37055.21). It is sub-rectangular in plan and measures internally up to 8.25m by 3.3m, with a low turf wall from 0.4m to 1.5m thick. The entrance is positioned centrally in the south-facing wall and there is a double hearth placed centrally in the south west end of the hut (b6). A wooden bowl was found adjacent to the hearth, and the skeleton of a baby was recovered from a low depression under the turf wall of this house. The OS surveyed the site in 1962 and recorded that no remains of this hut could be identified (h3).--------------------------------Site history:3: 1962. QUINNELL, NV / OS4: 1981. SHEPPARD, PA / DOE5: 1985. SHEPPARD, PA / DOE--------------------------------

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Urned cremation within hollow in cairn. Trevisker chronology is too vague to assign a specific BA date.Note animal bones were also found in the mound
Site_description: A cairn is marked at the location on current OS maps (b9). Blight recorded it as "a barrow about 45ft (13.76M) diameter and 6ft (1.83M) high. The base consisted of a circle of enclosing stones. In 1862 labourers erecting a fence cut into the barrow. It was composed entirely of stones near the centre with an urn inverted on a granite slab. It contained fragments of human bones and had been fired. There was no regular cist but stones had been built around the urn with a protecting slab on top (b1, b3). The urn was removed entire (b1, b3) and was presented to penzance museum (b2). It was recorded by patchet as class g (late ba, deveral - rimbury influence (b6, b7). Survey of the barrow indicated it is extensively robbed and mutilated and now survives as an overgrown bank up to 1.0M high on the north west and south sides. On the east side within the modern field corner (probaly the hedge bank built in 1862), there is now no trace of it (h2).

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: A dodgy sounding record. However according to Henrietta Quinnell (pers comm) the cordoned urn is potentially an Iron Age Breton import.
Site_description: Gilbert in 1817 records the find in c. 1801 Of a cave near land's end in which was an urn containing ashes, bones and brass coins (28563.1)(B1). Wc borlase in 1872 refers to an urn 14.6Cm high presented to truro museum by the rev john buller whichwas found at sennen. He qoutes gilbert and suggests the same urn (b2). Hencken in 1932 describes the pot as being of thin black ware, wheel-turned in the first century BC or later (b3). Russell in 1971 lists the find which is now in the truro museum (b4).<MCO850>: Brass coins, with ashes and bones, were found in an urn (28563) discovered in a cave at land's end c. 1801. Four coins were taken by cs gilbert and others were held dyonisius williams (b1).<see MCO849 for collated record>

Site_summary: <gg summary>: unlocated Miniature Food Vessel with cremation. The grid reference is taken from the centre of Madron parish
Site_description: WC Borlase illustrates a miniature urn with a height and diameter of 12.7Cm which was found on the St Aubyn estate and contained human ashes (b1). The urn is listed in the RIC catalogue (b2). And is described by Patchett in 1946 (b3). Russell in 1971 lists the find in unknown provenance and records no present location (b4).

Site_summary: <gg summary>: A standing stone in fields on west-facing slopes at Kerrow was excavated in 1935 when two urns were found; one placed inside the other .
Site_description: A standing stone in fields on west-facing slopes at Kerrow was excavated in 1935 by the West Cornwall Field Club (b1-2). Two urns (33486.1) were found, one inside the other, on a heap of charcoal and buried under a layer of stones at the foot of the menhir (b3-5). Listed as a menhir by Russell in 1971 (b4). Planned at 1:1000 by Sandy Gerrard and Adam Sharpe in 1984 and recorded as 1.78m high, 0.6m to 0.8m wide and 0.6m deep (h2, b6-7).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1961. PITCHER, GH / OS2: 1984. GERRARD, GAM AND SHARPE, A / CCRA--------------------------------<MCO821>: Two urns, one within the other were found beside the menhir at Kerrow when it was excavated in 1935 (b1-2). They are of middle or late Bronze Age type (b5).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1961. PITCHER, GH / OS2: 1984. GERRARD, GAM AND SHARPE, A / CCRA--------------------------------<see MCO7433 for collated record>

Site_name_other: TRESVENNACK PILLAR - Bronze Age standing stone
Site_summary: Tresvennack Pillar is a perfectly upright, well squared and symmetrical stone, 4.0m high, with an ancient vertical split going right through.<gg summary>: Cremation in large Collared Urn with handles and accompanied by Accessory vessel
Site_description: WC Borlase describes Tresvennack Pillar as a perfectly upright, well squared and symmetrical stone, 3.5m in height above ground and about 1.2m below ground. At the front of the stone two urns were discovered in 1840 (28707.1) (b1). The menhir is marked on the OS map of 1906 (b3) and was scheduled in 1950 (b5). The OS in 1960 surveyed the stone at 1:2500 and record its height as 4.0m with a split running from the top to approximately halfway down (h1, p1). Marked on the OS map of 1968 (b6) it is listed by Russell in 1971 who records extant remains (b7). Sheppard in 1981 describes a massive stone with an ancient vertical split going right through but apparently very firm and solid (h2, b8). Barnatt in 1982 notes an orientation of north/south (b9).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. PITCHER, GH / OS2: 1981. SHEPPARD, PA / DOE3: 1982. SHEPPARD, PA / DOE--------------------------------<MCO1652>: Edmunds in 1848 records the find of two urns at the foot of Tresvennack Pillar (28707) in 1840 by JNR Millett. Perhaps the largest sepulchural urn in Cornwall, was found covered by a granite slab 0.46m square and 5cm thick. The urn is 49.5cm high, 35.5cm wide at the top with a maximum diameter of 39.4cm and 19.0cm wide at the base, with two massive handles. It was found standing on its base 0.9m east of the menhir in a vault 0.9m square without any kind of cist. The pit was infilled with wood ashes and fragments of human bone, whilst larger bones and a human molar tooth were found within the vessel. A small urn half filled with a fine snuff-coloured powder and standing on its base was discovered at the same time 0.46m to the north-east of the former (b1). The urns are mentioned by WC Borlase (b2) and by Hencken (b3) and are listed by Patchett as Middle Bronze Age overhanging rim urns, now in Penzance Museum (b4). Russell in 1971 lists the find in her entry for Tresvennack Pillar (b5).<see MCO7536 for collated record>

Site_name_other: Monkton to Mount Pleasant A253 Dualling project (Area 9): Late Neolithic/Bronze Age ring ditch, burials and post alignment
Site_summary: A number of Bronze Age features were found during work on the A253 near Monkton. Two high status burials were found at the centre of a complex of burial mounds. The mounds mostly dated to the middle to late Bronze Age, and were thought to be later in date than the burials. A ring ditch formed of a circle of interconnecting pits was also found and this was dated to the late Neolithic or early Bronze Age. A number of post pits on an east-west alignment were thought to be associated with the mounds. Two beaker burials were also found cutting into these.<gg_summary>: Two Beaker period burials located immediately to the south of a major (and potentially earlier) pit-post alignment (see also MKE19914) and close to a substantial multi-period barrow (see also MKE19913).
Site_description: Area 9 of Monkton to Mount Pleasant A253 Dualling contains 2 high status burials at the centre of a later complex of burial mounds, most dating to Mid-LBA.  An early LNEO/EBA ring ditch was located here, comprising a ring of interconnecting pits. Perhaps associated with this mound was an E-W alignment of 18 post pits. These were interupted by 2 Beaker burials. (1)

Site_summary: A round barrow visible as earthworks on aerial photographs. Possibly a barrow excavated before 1876. Several burials were found, most in stone cists. Finds of more than one date suggest that some of these were later burials, possibly early medieval. Finds of pottery, in one case associated with cremated bone, are interpreted as Bronze Age cremation burials. Other finds thought to be prehistoric include flint scrapers and a carved piece of chalk.<gg summary>: One urned cremation There is no further detail about these urns although they are likely E or MBA in date. Note in the barrow were several flint scrapers, 2 dozen smooth beach pebbles and a curiously worked chalk object (size of two fists) shaped like an hour-glass with a saucer at one end & decorated at the other with 'vandyke' incisions around surface Note sounds very simiilar to MWX274. (SID_20032). Possible duplicate
Site_description: A bowl barrow presumed to be of Bronze Age origin, though excavation around 1877 recovered items of more than one date. Several inhumations were found, most in what are described as stone cists. Some or all of these are likely to be secondary burials of early medieval date - associated finds included iron arrowheads and a knife. Potsherds found just below the turf, in one case associated with cremated bone, presumably represent secondary burials of Bronze Age date. Other, probably prehistoric, finds mentioned include flint scrapers and a carved piece of chalk. Early medieval copper finds include dress pins, a ring and a ladies case for nick-nacks.The site of the barrow is visible as earthworks on aerial photographs <3> and was digitally plotted as part of the South Dorset Ridgway Mapping Project.This barrow is 15 paces in diameter and 2 feet in height. Flints in composition.  <4>

Site_summary: A Bronze Age bowl barrow situated on a ridge south of Eggardon. The mound was at first thought to be a spoil heap from quarrying but was excavated by Dorset Institute of Higher Education in 1981 and proved to be a barrow. The remains of a late Bronze Age urn, likely to have contained a cremation burial, were found at the circumference. Three extended inhumations were found in the centre of the mound. They were oriented east-west and had no grave goods, and so were thought to represent re-use of the barrow in the early medieval period.<gg_summary>: The primary grave comprises an urned cremation in collared urn which contained 'at least one other vessel'. A LBA urn was recovered from the edge of the barrow but was not directly associated with human remains so is not recorded here. The site was not fully published so no further details are available.
Site_description: Within the enclosure are several mounds which had been assumed to be spoil heaps. However on excavation the largest of these turned out to be a round barrow with remains of one late Bronze Age urn at its circumference. In the centre were three extended inhumations lying nearly east west, all without grave goods. They may well represent re-use of the barrow in Saxon times. <1>It was a large bowl barrow severely damaged by the construction of the Roman road, much material having been removed form the northern side. No further inhumations were found, but the primary cremation was located; this was a collared urn containing at least one other vessel. <2>

Site_summary: A Bronze Age bowl barrow lying inside the Iron Age hillfort on Eggardon.  In 1952 this monument was reported as being around 42 feet in diameter with a mound about 4_ feet high.  The mound is damaged, having been excavated by George Rybot 1963-66. He found the remains of at least five Deverel-Rimbury urns and one collared urn; one of these contained cremated bone, and is presumably the remains of a cremation burial.
Site_description: A Bronze Age bowl barrow lying inside Eggardon Hillfort. The barrow is visible as earthworks on aerial photographs. <1>Grinsell recorded this barrow as 14 paces in diameter and 3 feet in height, with a hollow in the centre. <3>Enclosed small flint cairn (disturbed) sherds of at least 5 Deverel-Rimbury urns and of one collared urn (possibly in soil gathered for mound which had no quarry ditch) at least one urn contained cremated bones. <4>

Site_name_other: Bronze Age bowl barrow on Beaminster Down, Beaminster
Site_summary: Bronze Age bowl barrow, one of a small group on Beaminster Down.  This is thought to be the barrow opened in 1874 by S S Cox, who found an upturned pot containing burnt bones near the centre of the mound, presumably the remains of a cremation burial. A second vessel was found at a higher level. The round mound is 15m across and visible as earthworks on aerial photographs.  It was digitally plotted during the Marshwood Vale NMP.<gg summary> One of the inverted urns lower down in the mound is a Collared Urn (id by Longworth)
Site_description: Thought by Grinsell as most likely to be the barrow opened by Cox in 1874. Cox found an inverted 'crock' containing burnt bones near the centre of the mound, and a second vessel was found at a higher level within the mound. Bronze Age bowl barrow on Beaminster Down.  The round mound is 15m across and visible as earthworks on aerial photographs (3-4).  It was digitally plotted during the Marshwood Vale NMP.

Site_summary: Bronze Age bowl barrow. This barrow was opened in 1912 by Mr J E Batchelor and Mr E A Rawlence. They found it to be 34 feet in diameter with a ring of flints, interpreted as a retaining wall. Below this was a cremation burial contained within a barrel-shaped urn, thought to be of Late Bronze Age date. Bones found in the urn were said to be those of a child.<gg_summary> No further details available. The 'Barrel urn' has since been identified as a Collared Urn vessel containing a child cremation by Longworth (No 359); Longworth 1984: 181. The remains of a possible cremation pyre were located at the centre of the barrow. Grinsell's Beaminster Barrow 5.
Site_description: The site of the discovery of an urn and burnt bones, incorrectly marked on the Ordnance Survey map, was excavated. The primary interment of the barrow was not found, beneath a circular retaining wall of flints, was a subsequent primary or secondary cremation of an infant, with ashes, enclosed in a (probably upright) barrel shaped urn, probably Late Bronze Age. <1> Identified by Longworth as a Collared UrnGrinsell records this barrow as 12 paces(?) in diameter and of uncertain height (?). <2>

Site_summary: Bronze Age bowl barrow, part of an extensive linear barrow cemetery running along the ridgeway. In 1972 this monument was reported as being around 50 feet in diameter with a mound about 2_ feet high. This barrow was opened in March 1884 by antiquarian Edward Cunnington, who found an inhumation burial in the form of a contracted skeleton with a food vessel, and a cremation burial near its feet. Visible as a cropmark on aerial photographs. The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.<gg summary>: Bincombe 53. Primary inhumation of male with Food Vessel and a secondary cremation with a  Late Bronze Age (MBA) shouldered bucket urn. Dorset Procs 1916 (vol 37) : 14; Antiq Journal vol 13: 447It was a Food Vessel (misidentified by Grinsell) and this was placed at the head of the inhumation. By the feet was an unurned cremation
Site_description: Grinsell recorded this barrow as 18 paces in diameter and 1 foot in height. He interpreted Cunnington's finds as apparently a crouched primary adult male inhumation, secondary Late Bronze Age shouldered bucket urn protected by slabs near head, at feet was a cremation, all beneath a cairn. <2>Visible as a cropmark ring ditch with a central pit on aerial photographs <4>. The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow in the Ridgeway Hill Group, Bincombe
Site_summary: Bronze Age bowl barrow. Two inhumations, thought to be adult males, were buried in the centre and had a Beaker bowl deposited with them. Other crouched burials of Bronze Age date were found, some in stone cists, and others inserted into the top of the mound; one of these with pottery of Iron Age date.Visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs. The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.<gg_summary>This is Grinsell's (1959) Bincombe barrow 11. Poor/confused excavation report, revisited by Payne (1944):A total of 8 inhumation burials were recovered from the barrow, probably representing two main periods of interment (EBA and EIA). Based on Payne's (1944) thoughtful reevaluation of the evidence, the following burials were associated with gg:Ridgeway Hill 11, Skeleton 1 (Payne 1944, 42-4): Adult male inhumation burial with pottery vessel. Slightly above the burial but thought to be associated with it was a large worked deer antler, broken in half; the parts deposited separately.Ridgeway Hill 11, Skeleton 5 (Payne 1944, 42-5): Secondary burial of a c. 11 year old boy, crouched on his RHS with a handled Beaker at his feetRidgeway Hill 11, Skeleton 7 (Payne 1944, 42-5): Primary adult male inhumation burial, powerfully built, with a rare/finely ornamented Beaker bowl by his sideRidgeway Hill 11, Skeleton 8 (Payne 1944, 42-5): Child burial, c. 10 years old, crouched on his RHS with a pierced deer horn behind his backWhimster (1981, 427) describes this as follows: Early Bronze Age barrow containing six primary or early secondary crouched inhumations. Two further inhumations have been classed as Iron Age interments on the grounds of associated coarse ware vessels of supposed Iron Age form.
Site_description: In 1972 this monument was reported as being around 27 feet in diameter with a mound about 4 feet high. In 1922 this barrow was excavated by Prideaux who found that the mound of the barrow covered a retaining circle of stones, enclosing eight inhumations. Two inhumations, thought to be adult males, were buried in the centre and had a Beaker bowl deposited with them. Other crouched burials of Bronze Age date were found, some in stone cists, and others inserted into the top of the mound; one of these with pottery of Iron Age date.Visible as an earthwork bank with enclosing ditch on aerial photographs <4>. The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.

Site_name_other: Bell Barrow in the Ridgeway Hill Group, Bincombe
Site_summary: A bell barrow excavated by the Ministry of Works in 1963.  The excavators found a stone retaining wall covered by turf and capped with chalk.  There appeared to be three primary burials, comprising inhumation burials of a woman and a child, and a cremation burial. Other cremation burials were found within the mound. In 1970 this monument was reported as being around 90 feet in diameter with a mound about 6 feet high, and a ditch 6 feet wide and 4 feet deep. The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.<gg summary>: This is Bincombe 13.  Part of an extensive barrow cemetery aligned E-W. A bell barrow containing a central primary cist with a lightly flexed female skeleton accompanied by an intact short necked Beaker, and wrapped in a shroud possibly of cloth, fastened at the neck by a bronze awl. A satellite cist contained the skeleton of a child which appeared to have been enveloped in a shroud. A satellite pit contained an unaccompanied cremation. A very large cairn had been built over these primary burials, revetted by a 0.6m high wall, 9m in diameter. This cairn contained 4 unaccompanied cremations inserted as the cairn was built. A secondary cremation was contained in an upright enlarged food vessel of massive proportions, 0.45m in diameter. A turf stack covered the cairn (which was reveted by a wall) and chalk capped the whole moundIn total there were 6 unaccompanied cremations
Site_description: Bell Barrow, excavated, in grave, primary female skeleton, slightly contracted, with short necked beaker vertical finger nail-decorated, the body probably wrapped in garment or shroud of cloth, fastened at neck by bronze awl. Pits nearby contained skeleton of child perhaps also wrapped in cloth, and a simple cremation, above these interments, a cairn in which were 4 simple cremations, there was also a secondary cremation, in upright urn of enlarged food-vessel type. Cairn revetted by wall and covered by turf stack.This barrow was 40 paces in diameter and 6 feet in height. <2>Bell barrow. 90ft. in diam and 6ft. high. The ditch was 6ft. wide and 4ft. deep. <3>The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project

Site_summary: This barrow was opened by antiquarian Charles Warne, who found a cremation burial in an up-turned bucket urn. Visible on aerial photographs as a 19m diameter cropmark ring ditch with internal mound. Digitally plotted for the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's Bincome Barrow 3 (Bincombe Hewish). No further details available beyond these sources.
Site_description: This barrow was 15 paces in diameter and 1/2 foot in height. <2>Visible on aerial photographs <4> as a 19m diameter cropmark ring ditch with internal mound. Digitally plotted for the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow, one of the Bincombe Down Group, Bincombe
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Warne found 4 inverted collared urns with cremations  beneath a cairn in a cist, and a number of later cremation burials (2 secondary LBA (sic MBA?) urns with cremations) within the mound. Visible as a cropmark on aerial photographs. The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project. Bowl barrow, now only a slight rise.<gg summary>: This is Grinsell's (1959) Bincombe 4: lots of Collared Urn cremationsOne truncated Collared Urn at top of mound has lost any associated hr. In addition to the EBA burials, Grinsell (1959, 90) mentions two upright secondary burials in [MBA] vessels. Warne does not mention the recovery of cremated bone in association with these vessels (he is very specific about the bone associated with the EBA vessels) so these are not recorded here.
Site_description: Visible as a cropmark on aerial photographs. <4> The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project. Bowl barrow, now only a slight rise.Bronze Age bowl barrow. In 1972 this monument was reported as being visible only as a slight rise. It is thought to be a barrow opened by Charles Warne,

Site_summary: One of two Bronze Age bowl barrows lying within Chalbury hillfort, visible as earthworks on aerial photographs. This barrow may be the barrow on Chalbury opened by antiquarian Charles Warne, who found two urns with burnt bones, the probable remains of at least two cremation burials.<gg summary> This is Bincombe 37. Both pots were hopelessly crushed so not identiified  other than they are Bronze Age. Large quantity of mice bones in this barrow (later colony?)
Site_description: This barrow was 22 paces in diameter and 5 feet in height. Either 37 or 38 (a cairn) was opened by CW, it contained 2 urns (hopelessly crushed) with burnt bones. <2>One of two Bronze Age bowl barrows lying within Chalbury hillfort, visible as earthworks on aerial photographs <5-7>. The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow near Gypsies Corner, Bincombe
Site_summary: Bronze Age bowl barrow. This barrow was opened in 1888 by antiquarian Edward Cunnington, who found a cremation burial. <gg summary>: This is Bincombe 59aNot much detail but 1ry cremation in barrow in poorly made urn without decoration could this be either E or MBA?? If barrows are still being constructed ex novo in Dorset in MBA perhaps we should not rule out a potential MBA date
Site_description: This barrow was 10 paces in diameter and 2(?) feet in height (1888). Opened by E Cunnington in 1888, contained (primary?) cremation, in badly-fired plain urn. <2>

Site_summary: During construction of a gas pipeline in 1971 a deep layer of black soil, several pits and a number of crouched burials were seen by E Flatters. Subsequently a small excavation was carried out at the point where occupation seemed most dense. Several levels of floor interspersed with layers containing occupation debris, a pit and hearths were recorded. One floor appeared to be made partly of slabs of shale, which the excavators suggested may have been the floor of a narrow passage. Finds included an unfinished shale armlet and a fragment of another, leading to the suggestion that there may at some time have been shale working on the site.<gg_summary>: 'a number of crouched burials, one with a bowl of the so-called 'war cemetery' type seen at Maiden Castle' (Bailey and Flatters 1972). No further details are available about these burials.
Site_description: In 1971 during construction of the trench for a gas pipeline passing east of Dorchester to the eastern end of Came Wood and then south-eastwards across the South Dorset Ridgeway along the spur to the west of Coombe Valley, Eric Flatters noticed an unusual depth of black soil east of Quarry Lodden. He also saw several pits and a number of crouched burials, one with a bowl of the so-called 'war cemetery' type seen at Maiden Castle. Subsequently small excavation was carried out at the point where observations of the trench suggested that occupation was most dense. Two trenches 3m long and 1.5m wide were excavated parallel to the pipeline trench and about 5m from it on either side. In due course the northern trench was abandoned, and the southern one extended to a 3m by 3m square. Immediately below the ploughsoil was a small area of a floor constructed of flat stones packed with puddled chalk. No dating evidence was found, but the floor was interpreted as representing the remnants of a later Romano-British level, largely ploughed out.  An accumulation of dark soil overlay a floor of compacted limestone fragments. Pottery in this dark soil was Durotrigian and Romano-British. This floor sealed a pit, the fillings of which contained a little pottery. Below the floor was a partly broken up floor of stone and shale over a thick layer of black earth and stone over another floor of large stone slabs and a hearth of puddled chalk. Three slabs of shale were found, and the excavators speculated that these may have been the floor of a narrow passageway.  The black layer and ash from the hearth contained Iron Age B and early Durotrigian pottery. Below this was a series of alternating hearths with layers of ash, down to a layer over natural limestone. At this level Iron Age A pottery was found, with fabrics and forms comparable to those at Maiden Castle, Pins Knoll and Chalbury. This pottery included heamatite-coated situlate jars and derivative types, in fabric described as hard, occasionally burnished and varying in colour from bright red to dullish brown. Finds from the site included an unfinished shale armlet and a fragment of another, leading to speculation that there may at some time have been shale working on the site.  It is not clear from the report whether any other shale objects or waste were noted. Other finds included worked bone awls and flat pieces of bone, also worked, and a bone implement possibly associated with weaving. An iron stylus and knife blade were found, and a bronze object described as a  fish  by the excavators, but which appears to be a nail cleaner. {1}

Site_name_other: One of Grinsell's Bradford Peverell Barrows 5-7a
Site_summary: Site of a probable Bronze Age bowl barrow visible as cropmarks/soilmarks on aerial photographs. One of three ploughed out barrow mounds located on a spur north-west of Penn Hill. This may be the barrow near Muckleford in which a burial with bronze dagger and a pin, and covered by a huge stone slab, was found by antiquarians.<gg_summary>: One of three ploughed out round barrows north-west of Penn Hill (see also MDOs 383-4) from which these artefacts may have been recovered (Grinsell 1959, 96). Grinsell's 'bronze knife-dagger' is actually a riveted spearhead (British Museum). The pin is most intriguing (?MBA); double-headed spiral and seems continental in inspiration Noted as a possible hoard but contemporary accounts of the excavation mention that they were found with the bones under the mighty capstone. Possibly a hoard added to an earlier inhumation burial (since cists with inhumations are not typical locally after the EBA) so the site is given a broad BA date here, as is the inhumation date.<NRHE HOBUID: 453824; https://www.pastscape.org.uk/hob.aspx?hob_id=453824&sort=2&type=&typeselect=c&rational=a&class1=None&period=None&county=None&district=None&parish=None&place=&recordsperpage=10&source=text&rtype=monument&rnumber=453824#>
Site_description: This barrow was 19 paces in diameter and 1/2 a foot in height. <2>Site of a probable Bronze Age bowl barrow visible as cropmarks/soilmarks on aerial photographs. One of three ploughed out barrow mounds located on a spur north-west of Penn Hill. <5-8><NRHE site description>: A barrow at Muckleford (SY 6393) opened by Mr Sabine in 1832 revealed a massive triangular-shaped stone placed centrally near the top of the mound. Six feet below this were human bones together with a three-rivetted spearhead and a 'double-headed pin'. (1)Grinsell refers to the spearhead as a bronze knife-dagger and the pin as possibly belonging to Late Bronze Age Central European types. (The excavation may refer to one of the barrows at SY 69 SW 41 or 57). (2)

Site_name_other: Bowl Barrow North of Forty Acre Plantation, Bradford Peverell
Site_summary: Site of a Bronze Age bowl barrow, visible as cropmarks on aerial photographs. In 1952 this monument was reported as 85 feet in diameter with a mound about 2 feet high. It is thought to have been opened in 1880 by antiquarian Edward Cunnington, who found an inhumation burial of a young person with two beakers, and a cremation.<gg summary>: Forty Acre Plantation 26. The Beakers are rather unusual in form  although not hybrids with Food Vessels. The cremation may be in the same grave as the inhumation but this is not clear.
Site_description: Site of a Bronze Age bowl barrow, visible as cropmarks on aerial photographs. The barrow is 23m across and appears to have a large central pit.  <4-5>

Site_name_other: Bowl Barrow in the Peverell Group, Bradford Peverell
Site_summary: Bronze Age bowl barrow, visible as cropmarks on aerial photographs. In 1952 this monument was reported as 100 feet in diameter with a mound about 3 feet high. This or an adjacent barrow is thought to have been opened in 1881 by antiquarian Edward Cunnington, who found a contracted burial, a handled food vessel and flint implements (serrated flint flakes).<gg_summary>: One of two adjacent barrows (Grinsell's Bradford Peverell Barrows 24 and 24a; MDOs410-1) recorded in the HER. It is not clear which of these barrows produced the handled food vessel (see also MDO411) however the grave goods have been linked to this record.
Site_description: Site of a Bronze Age barrow, visible as cropmarks on aerial photographs. The barrow is 27m across, has a berm between the outer ditch and barrow mound and appears to have a central pit. <4-5>

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow North of Whitfield Farm, Bradford Peverell
Site_summary: Bronze Age bowl barrow, visible as cropmarks on aerial photographs. A central pit can be seen on the photographs. In 1952 this monument was reported as 90 feet in diameter with a mound about 4 feet high. It was opened in 1879 by antiquarian Edward Cunnington, who found a skeleton in a large oval grave, with a bronze dagger, and other burials. This is Grinsell's Bradford Peverell Barrow 22 located north-west of Whitfield Farm and immediately south-east of a Neolithic long barrow<gg summary>: Primary inhumation in very large and deep oval grave over 2m deep. Accompanied by bronze knife-dagger. No further detail about the other burials? Other than they were accompanied by worked flint tools
Site_description: Site of a Bronze Age bowl barrow, visible as cropmarks on aerial photographs. The barrow is 23m across and appears to have a central pit. <5-6>

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow east of Whitfield Barn, Bradford Peverell
Site_summary: Site of a Bronze Age barrow, visible as earthworks on aerial photographs. In 1952 this monument was reported as 54 feet in diameter with a mound 11 feet high. It was opened in 1879 by antiquarian Edward Cunnington, who found a skeleton in a large oval grave, with a bronze dagger, and other burials.r. A coin of Tetricus was found on the surface.<gg summary>: this is Bradford Peverell G30. Primary crouched adult female interment, head facing to South, facing East, in central grave beneath cairn, secondary deposits of six cremations, pottery and small bronze knife-dagger, a beaker is also said to have come from this barrow. Lots of flint tools are recorded in the Dorset museum catalogue including adze, blade, scrapers, arrowhead and cores. Not certain whether these are from graves or in the mound. There is also a cremation burial mentioned in the catalogue
Site_description: w. <3>Site of a Bronze Age barrow, visible as earthworks on aerial photographs. The barrow mound appears to be 23m across. <4-5>

Site_name_other: Bronze Age burial, Conway Drive, Broadmayne
Site_summary: A crouched burial, associated with a shattered long-neck beaker, found in a  pit in the garden of No 22 Conway Drive, Broadmayne.Found in the same location as (and potentially associated with):<MDO518>: An undated crouched burial with no grave goods. Both crouched Beaker burials and late Iron Age burials have been found in the same area.See SID 20228 for IA burial and settlement from this site.<gg summary> Crouched inhumation with Beaker behind back. Unusual long-necked Beaker with white-infilled decoration

Site_name_other: Round barrow on Low or Louse Hill, Castleton
Site_summary: Possible barrow revealed in face of quarry, August 1915, when urn with bones (not burnt), ashes and flint flakes found. Bones and parts or urn in Sherborne Museum.<gg sumary>: Objects connected with a prehistoric burial recently found in Low Hill quarry, consisting of flint flakes, a boar's tooth, a doe-deer horn, etc, were exhibited. Capt Acland thought the interment was probably Bronze Age.

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow on Lord's Down, Dewlish
Site_summary: Bronze Age bowl barrow, one of the Lord's Down Group. In 1970 this monument was reported as 53 feet in diameter with a mound around 1_ feet high, and much ploughed. <gg summary>: Grinsell's (1959, 105) Dewlish Barrow 7 (Lord's Down):  This barrow was opened by antiquarian Charles Warne, who found a cremation burial in a cist, and with a bronze dagger, a whetstone, a bone pin and tweezers. Note the fact that this was a crutch-headed pin may indicate that it is slightly later on in the EBA. In addition, the square sectioned perforated stones (as this one is) are always associated with the later (Cam_snowshill) daggers

Site_name_other: Bowl Barrow on Lord's Down, Dewlish
Site_summary: Much disturbed bowl barrow, diameter about 85 feet, height 2 feet.<gg summary>: Grinsell's (1959, 104) Dewlish Barrow 6 (Lord's Down): primary grave contained a long-necked beaker but apparently no inhumation.  Secondary burials include the inhumation of a child associated with sherds of Beaker pottery, the cremation of a child contained within an upright Food Vessel laid in a cist, a cremation and ashes beneath an inverted Enlarged Food Vessel urn, two cremations beneath inverted urns (with horseshoe handles)  in a cist, and an intrusive Romano-British or post Roman inhumationNote at least one vessel is a Biconical Urn housed at DCM (1885.16.35)
Site_description: Opened by Charles Warne, primary grave, containing beaker probably of type A, no inhumation is mentioned from this grave, above this, a layer of mould, above this a layer of chalk rubble which contained the first secondary interment, the skeleton of a child, beneath which were fragments of a plain pot of fine reddish material (food-vessel or beaker?) in a cist formed in the top of this layer of chalk rubble was an upright plain urn, containing the second secondary interment, a cremation probably a child, this mound of chalk rubble was covered with a layer of mould, over this another layer of chalk rubble, in which was a third secondary interment, a cremation with ashes beneath an inverted (Early/Middle Bronze Age?) urn shaped like an enlarged food vessel, on the south side of this layer of chalk, and in a cist cut into it, were the fourth and fifth secondary interments, cremations beneath inverted urns (Middle Bronze Age/Late Bronze Age hybrid?) above this was the final layer of mould, in which was a probably intrusive (Romano-British or pagan Saxon?) skeleton, this barrow had clearly been begun for the reception of an interment with a type A beaker, then enlarged probably both vertically and horizontally for successive interments in the Early/Middle Bronze Age and Late Bronze Age, and last of all used for insertion of a Roman or post-Roman interment, probably more interments are in the mound that may have been missed.

Site_summary: Bronze Age bowl barrow. In 1970 this monument was recorded as 75 feet in diameter with a mound about 2_ feet high, and heavily ploughed. This is thought to be a barrow opened by antiquarian Charles Warne.<gg summary>: Grinsell's (1959, 105) Dewlish Barrow 8 (Lord's Down):  Charles Warne found a cremation burial with a bronze dagger still in its leather sheath, in a cist covered by a cairn in which were found fragments of an urn
Site_description: Grinsell recorded this barrow as 32 paces in diameter and 4_ feet high. <2>

Site_summary: Bronze Age bowl barrow. In 1970 this monument was recorded as around 50 feet in diameter with a mound about 3 feet high, and much plouched. This barrow is thought to have been opened around 1883, when a cremation burial in a Late Bronze Age bucket-urn was found.<gg_summary>: ?Secondary cremation in small knobbed MBA urn, now in Dorset County Museum. Grinsell's (1959, 104) Dewlish Barrow 1. 'Contained fine ashes' (Ackland 1908, 138).

Bowl barrow of presumed Bronze Age origin, though excavation in around 1877 recovered items of more than one date. Several inhumations were found, most in what are described as stone cists. Some or all of these are likely to be secondary burials of early medieval date - associated finds included iron arrowheads and a knife. Potsherds found just below the turf, in one case associated with cremated bone, presumably represent secondary burials of Bronze Age date. Other, probably prehistoric, finds mentioned include flint scrapers and a carved piece of chalk. Early medieval copper finds include dress pins, a ring and a ladies case for nick-nacks.This is New Barn, Abbotsbury 20a. <gg summary>: Several urns of rude construction were found in fragments beneath the turf around the barrow, and only one was complete enough at base to show the original contents of calcined bones./ There is no further detail about these urns although they are likely E or MBA in date. Note in the barrow were several flint scrapers, 2 dozen smooth beach pebbles and a curiously worked chalk object (size of two fists) shaped like an hour-glass with a saucer at one end & decorated at the other with 'vandyke' incisions around surface There were also cists with inhumations of later date (Saxon with dress pins and iron spearheads)
Site_description: A barrow at New Barn, Abbotsbury was recently opened and found to contain several interments, of persons differing in age, and apparently also in the period of their burial, most of them laid in stone cists. Several urns of rude construction were found in fragments close beneath the turf around the barrow, only one being sufficiently entire at its base to show the original contents of calcined bones. Iron finds comprised arrowheads and a knife, whilst rust stains indicated that a weapon had been laid across the chest of one of the skeletons. Copper finds included a ladies case for nick-nacks, two dress pins and a ring, and there were also several flint scrapers and a carved piece of chalk. Some of these specimens have been placed by the Earl of Ilchester in his museum at Melbury. (1) SY 597833. This barrow is listed as a bowl, but was unlocated. The urns are assumed to be either primary or secondary, with secondary or intrusive skeletons (Saxon?). (2) Situated at the south of Walls Down was a site known as The Mound according to my father who was born in 1876 and who farmed the land as did his father before him. My father is of the opinion that this is the site referred to though he knows nothing of the burials. would see the ghosts of the soldiers who were buried there. (3) SY 59278342. A grass covered flat topped mound of rather irregular shape. Diameter 14.0m and height averages 0.5m. There is no visible ditch surrounding the mound, and a straight ditch 4.0m wide and 0.4m deep situated immediately west of the barrow may be a modern track. the site indicated on the map from Authority 3 was 10.0m from present siting symbol. This mound accords with the information is Authority 3 and appears to be the barrow referred to in Authorities 1 & 2. It is of bowl type. (4) SY 59278342. Abbotsbury 20a. Listed as a bowl barrow, details as Authority 2. Finds from this barrow are now in the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. (Nothing shown at this location on OS 1st edition 1 map). (5-6) Compiler (NVQ) JOHN RIGG (JR) (NVQ) DAVID JOHN GRATY (DJG) 17-MAR-1955 - 17-MAR-1955 04-APR-1955 - 04-APR-1955 18-APR-1955 - 18-APR-1955 19-SEP-1983 - 19-SEP-1983 Vol. 1 Page(s) 50-1 Page 319 450576 450578 Related Event Records: Field observation on SY 58 SE 9 Field observation on SY 58 SE 9 Field Observation Field Observation 04 Apr 1955 - 04 Apr 1955 18 Apr 1955 - 18 Apr 1955This Barrow was 15 paces in diameter and 2 feet in height. Flints in composition. <8>

Site_summary: Bronze Age bowl barrow visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs of the 1940s. In 1972 this monument was reported as 44 feet in diameter with a mound about 6 feet high, and hollowed out in the centre. It was opened in 1867, revealing a cremation in a bucket urn.<gg_summary>: Also known as Woodstone Barrow and Woodstone Herring (Grinsell's Chaldon Herring Barrow 19). Excavation of the mound in 1867 revealed a primary cremation in an upright [MBA] bucket-urn.'It was standing on the original surface of the land, covered with the flat stone, about the centre of the barrow with fragments of bones and ashes in it, and others on the outside' (Farrar 1955, 128).
Site_description: Wardstone Barrow (NR) (1) Wardstone Barrow is a bowl barrow measuring 44ft. diameter by 4 1/2 ft. (3) or 6ft. (2) Excavation of the mound in 1867 revealed a primary cremation in an upright Late Bronze Age bucket-urn covered with a flat stone. The urn was preserved at Lulworth Castle but was destroyed by fire in 1928. (3,4) SY 793248133. Wardstone Barrow (name not confirmed) - a bowl barrow in arable but not ploughed over. Diameter 13.0m., height 1.4m. No visible ditch. Re-surveyed at 1:2500 on M.S.D. <5>The Bronze Age barrow known as the Wardstone Barrow, described above in (1), is visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs of the 1940s.
