The barrow is sub-circular and measures 13 m in diameter.  <7>  The barrow is still visible as an earthwork on the most recent comprehensive aerial photography available to the project.  <8>  This feature was digitally plotted as part of the Wild Purbeck Mapping Project.

Site_summary: One of two adjacent Bronze Age bowl barrows aligned east-west on Conygar Hill, both of which are visible as earthworks on aerial photographs and LIDAR.  Opened by antiquarian Edward Cunnington, who found a crouched burial. Near the knees of this burial was a cremation with a food vessl and six flint arrowheads. Three later cremations were found higher up the mound, one in a Late Bronze Age bucket urn.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's (1959) Dorchester Barrow 8. EBA inhumation with cremation in food vessel near the knees and six flint arrowheads; secondary cremation in MBA bucket urn. Acland 1916 also mentions 'many flint scrapers' (possibly associated with the later activity at the mound) and a large block of Portland stone (probably associated directly with the crouched inhumation). No further contextual detail.
Site_description: One of two adjacent Bronze Age bowl barrows (MDO1051 & MDO1052) aligned east-west on Conygar Hill, both of which are visible as earthworks on aerial photographs and LIDAR. {1-2}<summary> This is Dorchester 8

Site_summary: A bowl barrow situated on the shoulder of a hill. This monument was destroyed in 1885. The antiquarian Edward Cunnington described it as a mound 35 feet in diameter and 11 feet high, and recorded the finding of a cremation with a copper dagger and knife-dagger. A collared urn was found during earlier investigations.<gg summary>: Large Collared Urn containing cremation, grooved bronze dagger, flat bronze knife and also a polished flint axe that may have been deliberately broken in half before deposition with burial -possibly an ancient curated object
Site_description: Has been destroyed, excavated by E. Cunnington, primary cremation, in plain collared Early/Middle Bronze Age urn, with grooved bronze dagger, 8.75in. long and knife-dagger 3.5in. long with two rivets, there was also a flint axe which may have been ceremonially broken. (Grinsell)

Site_summary: Bowl barrow, excavated before destruction for road widening in 1937.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's Frampton Barrow 4. Poor contextual detail. Archive in Dorchester Museum.Given the vagaries of the information, the graves are recorded as follows:Grave 1: Primary crouched inhumation in central grave cut with 2 female inhumations, 2 child inhumations (description suggests multiple burials of both) and a plain beaker (all of the latter in the grave fill).Grave 2: Secondary cremation beneath inverted EBA (twisted cord decoration) urn with single plain accessory vessel in ditch enclosing the secondary mound.Grave 3: Secondary urned cremation in biconical urn with 'perhaps 3 small accessory pots nested inside one another' in ditch enclosing the secondary mound (above Grave 2).A later (potentially IA) crouched inhumation burial cut into the top of the mound was not associated with grave goods.
Site_description: Excavated in 1937 by Messers. Oliver, Selby and Kirk, before removal for road, primary crouched interment central to primary ditch enclosing mound, in grave in filling of which were bones of several females and children and a plain B2 beaker, secondary cremation, of last beneath inverted collared Early/Middle Bronze Age urn (with twisted cord decoration) which contained plain accessory vessel, below ground-level central to ditch enclosing secondary mound, above this was a secondary cremation in a biconical urn (Middle/Late Bronze Age?) and perhaps 3 small pots nested one inside the other, near surface of mound, intrusive crouched inhumation (Early Iron Age or Romano-British or less probably pagan Saxon). <3>

Site_summary: Bowl barrow, excavated before destruction for road widening in 1938.<gg summary>: This is Grinsell's (1959, 109) Frampton barrow 5. Excavated in 1938, published by Forde-Johnston in 1959. EBA burials mainly with food vessels (cremations) and inhumations with Bronze awl and one with a hybrid Beaker-FV. Note also cremation with FV and faience beads. Another cremation within an inverted Collared Urn. Note this barrow (judging by grave good pottery) has an interesting and lengthy sequence of burial
Site_description: Excavated in 1938, before removed to widen road, primary crouched adult in oval grave beneath old turf-line central to primary ditch, subsequent primary deposit of bones, largley  inarticulate, of child to North West, beneath primary mound and just within enclosing ditch, some secondary interments: (i) crouched adult with remains of square-sectioned bronze awl and object of wood, inserted in primary mound.(ii) human bones (disturbed)and parts of hybrid type beaker in filling of grave of (i), probably disturbed in digging. (iii) crouched juvenile inserted from secondary  into primary mound.(iv) above last, crouched interment with pot of food-vessel type, inserted from secondary into primary mound. (v) cremation beneath inverted food-vessel-shaped urn, covered by flint cairn. (vi) cremation with upright food-vessel and 6 segmented blue faience beads.(vii) cremation beneath inverted collared Early/Middle Bronze Age urn, perhaps later than last, intrusive crouched interment near top of mound perhaps Early Iron Age, Romano-British or pagan Saxon (Grinsell).'C(10) Barrows, in Long Plantation over 1/2 m. E. of the church, were two in number. They have been recently destroyed for a new road but were previously excavated by Messrs. Oliver, Selby and Kirk'. (1)

Site_name_other: Barrow in the Black Down Group, Kingston Russell
Site_summary: <gg summary>: 1ry cremation in a Collared Urn under small cairn A small cremation cemetery to the east of the cairn contained five token burials in small holes and the crouched inhumation of a young child with chopped off feet and with a miniature biconical urn Other burials without grave goods included Almost central pit grave with flint mound covering the skeleton of a crouched adult, probably female on its right side, head to N, 1m west of centre. Grinsell's (1959) Kingston Russell barrow 3b
Site_description: 'Some Archaeological and Historical Notes on Sites in the Bride Valley. The Excavation of a Cairn on Black Down, Kingston Russell. With a grant from the Department of the Environment investigation of the area in the vicinity of barrows 6g, 6h and 6n was continued (R.C.H.M., Dorset, Vol. II, 1970, Part 3, plan p. 460). The Royal Commission's 'ditched bowl barrow', Kingston Russell 6n, was not listed by Grinsell in "Dorset Barrows", 1959, nor in the Commission's Vol. I, 1952, but was added when the great Ridgeway Barrow Group was reconsidered as a whole for the second volume. The national grid reference is SY 578904. Excavation showed not a large bowl barrow but a small flint cairn covering a cremation contained in an overhanging-rim urn. What appeared on the surface to be a large barrow ditch was found to be the convergence of two linear ditches. A small cremation cemetery to the east of the cairn contained five token burials in small holes and the crouched inhumation of a young child with a miniature biconical urn. The feet of the child had been cut off before burial and were missing. The linear ditches were sectioned in several places but no clue to their origin was found. A detailed report will be published when the excavation is complete.' {2}Excavated, primary cremation in collared urn covered by small flint cairn, to East of barrow was a cremation cemetery of 5 token deposits in small holes, and a contracted inhumation of a child with a miniature biconical urn, the child's feet had been cut off before burial and were missing.

Site_summary: Bronze Age bowl barrow.  It is visible as earthworks on aerial photographs.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's (1959, 117; 1982, 43) Litton Cheney barrow 3: Primary inhumation without gg. Secondary cremation in an upright Deverel Rimbury urn, too crushed to be restored. In Dorset County Museum.NB grave cut for the primary inhumation from this barrow was part lined with large flints
Site_description: Site of a Bronze Age bowl barrow, excavated in 1956 {3}.  It is visible as earthworks on aerial photographs. {1}Bowl barrow, 33ft. in diam and 2.5ft. high. (2)Totally excavated and reconstituted, barrow was surrounded by wide and shallow flat-bottomed ditch, a roughly circular pit in the chalk at the centre of the mound was sterile, above it was a primary extended adult male inhumation, both hands may not have been severed and buried first but slipped through the other bones after the body had decayed and almost above the grave was a post hole , Near the surface were the remains of a secondary inurned, upright urn of D/R type, too crushed to be restored, probably Bronze Age. (4)(5)

Site_name_other: Litton Cheney: earthwork enclosure, possibly the site of a henge
Site_summary: The possible site of a Neolithic or Bronze Age hengiform monument, visible on aerial photographs and excavated in 1974.Single entrance enclosure with bank & external ditch<gg summary>: Grinsell's Litton Cheney Barrow 3a. Cremation in Collared Urn
Site_description: The possible site of a Neolithic or Bronze Age hengiform monument, visible on aerial photographs {1} and excavated in 1974 {2}.Earthen Circle, the outer circle comprised of bank with outer ditch and causeway to South South East, to West of its centre was an inner circle with outer ditch (palisade trench?) and causeway to East, this inner circle contained a pit in which burnt bones of a young adult, in  upright primary series collared urn. there were also burnt bones of three children, structurally the site is closely paralleled by Long Crichel. (Antiquity xiii 143-5)'A round platform, 42ft. in diam and a few inches high'. [3]DHER card notes DoE schedule file reference AA 60661/1

Site_summary: A single prehistoric pit containing pottery and the remains of a cremation, probably of middle Bronze Age date.
Site_description: 'Evaluation of Land Near Evershot and Stockwood, in advance of A37 Road Improvements. The evaluation of two areas adjacent to the A37 was carried out during October 1992 by mechanically-excavated transects. Area 1, comprising 6750m2 of land in pasture (centred on ST 5925 0487) north of Holywell crossroads, revealed a single prehistoric pit containing pottery, probably of Middle Bronze Age date, and a negative field lynchet. No finds or deposits were revealed in Area 2 (centred on ST 5830 0710), near Stockwood, which comprised 625 m2 of land in pasture. Area 2 is immediately adjacent to the former site of a 17th century cottage (RCHM, Dorset West Vol 1, Stockwood 5), show on the first edition OS map as Bucks Head. This derelict building is now known to  have been demolished in the late 1950s during road widening.' {1}'A37 Road Improvements, Evershot. Archaeological monitoring was carried out at four locations north of Eveshot. Area A (centred on ST 59250489), involved the monitoring of topsoil stripping in an area where a prehistoric pit had been discovered during the initial evaluation (Cox, 1993 Dorset Proceedings, 114, 234). No additional archaeological features were identified in an area covering approximately 0.5 hectares.Area B (centred on ST 599056), contained no features or finds of archaeological interest in an area of approximately 0.3 hectares.Area C (centred on ST 5901805306), involved the excavation by hand of a 2m wide section across a low bank and ditch, which forms the historic boundary between the parishes of Melbury Sampford to the west and Melbury Bubb to the east. No dating evidence was recovered from sealed deposits, although fragments of 19th century pottery were recovered from the upper fill of the ditch.Area D (Engineer's Tip centred on ST 59160570, and haul road ST 59100521 to ST 59120560). Topsoil removal of an area c. 2ha was monitored, with no archaeological features or finds observed.' {2}

Site_name_other: White Horse Hill, Bronze Age barrow
Site_summary: One of two bowl barrows on the eastern side of White Horse Hill.  Visible as earthworks on aerial photographs.<gg_summary>: See MDO1827 for the other barrow of this pair. The grave goods were only attributable to the pair, rather than to either one of them. Grinsell's (1959) Osmington Barrow 3 or 4, 122). See also Warne (1866) My own personal researches no. 5.
Site_description: One of two bowl barrows on the eastern side of White Horse Hill.  Visible as earthworks on aerial photographs. {3}Grinsell suggests that one of these barrows was probably Tumulus No 5 excavated by Warne circa 1866 at Osmington Charity Down on the Ridgeway. Warne discovered a primary cremation in a barrel-shaped urn ornamented with a chevron pattern (destroyed on exposure) which had been placed in a central cavity, 18 ins. deep, cut into the natural chalk. Two contracted secondary inhumations were also found; one situated 4ft from the summit of the mound "enclosed in a rude dome of well packed flints" and the other immediately below the surface of the barrow. {1}

Site_summary: A Bronze Age bowl barrow. In 1970 this monument was recorded as being around 54 feet in diameter with a mound about a foot high. A cremation burial was exposed by ploughing in 1988. An excavation in 1989 revealed a burial cist.<gg_summary>: The urned cremation burial from this barrow was recorded separately (MDO1895). The information from this record is as follows:Large fragments of a Middle Bronze Age bucket urn from the cremation pit of a barrow. It is grey to brown in colour and tempered with fragments of grog. The vessel is of medium size, with a simple flat topped rim. It is decorated with four simple oval vertical lugs located below the rim and by horizontal rows of finger-tip impressions just below the rim.The find record relating to this record has been attached to the barrow record in the ggdb.
Site_description: <MDO1895>: The Bronze Age Urn - Anne Woodward:(1) Large fragments of an urn, which had been broken prior to interment, were found in an apparently primary burial cist, as described above. Much of the rim and body but no fragments of the base were present. The urn is of medium size, with a simple flat topped rim (Fig. 4). It is decorated with four simple oval vertical lugs located 7 cm below the rim and by horizontal rows of finger-tip impressions just below the rim, and between the lugs. The vessel is grey to brown in colour and the fabric is tempered with a medium density of small to large fragments of grog. The urn belongs to a group of medium-sized bucket urns found in the Dorset Downs area (Ellison 1975, Dorset Downs type (d) ). A close parallel is provided by one of the urns from the Deverel Barrow itself (Milborne St Andrew Grinsell No. 14: Grinsell 1968. fig. 12 64e), and other vessels showing similar characteristics are known from the Bagber Barrow, Milborne St Andrew Grinsell No. 2 (Abercromby 1912, No. 445), Milborne St Andrew Grinsell barrow 6h/I (Ellison 1975. PI.93 lower) and the Plush barrow, Piddletrenthide Grinsell No. 10b (ibid PI.98.2 to 4, especially No. 4).The urn was found in a barrow which may have been excavated previously by Cunnington in 1818 (RCHM 1970. 212). His barrow No. 44 may have been RCHM No. (15) Or (16). However the lack of evidence for previous disturbance in the centre of the barrow now investigated suggests that this was not Cunnington's barrow No.44 which had contained a primary cremation (ibid), and that Cunnington 44 was probably RCHM No. (16), equally Grinsell No. 2. Of the three barrows excavated by Cunnington in this vicinity, all contained cremations, and two of them produced sets of urns, five from Cunnington 45 (probably RCHM [18] equals Grinsell No. 4) and a further five from Cunnington 43 (RCHM [16] or [17] equals Grinsell No. 3). There is some confusion as to which of the five urns surviving in Dorset County Museum derived from which barrow, but Acland (1908. 139) states that DCM Nos. 85 (Abercromby 1912 No. 418), 86, 87 (Abercromby 368) and 88 (Abercromby 441) were found in the same barrow. This was probably Cunnington No. 43. DCM No. 91 (Abercromby 404) may therefore have derived from the other barrow which produced urns, Cunnington No. 45, probably equal to RCHM (18). The five surviving urns are all tempered with grog, occasionally with the addition of some fragments of chalk: they include one globular urn, three lugged or cordoned buckets, of different type to that recorded in this note, and one small knobbed cup. On typological grounds it would be expected that the Piddlehinton urn would date from the Middle Bronze Age period and the radiocarbon determination confirms this. The date obtained was as follows: Har-10059               3170 = 80 BP (1200 bc = 80)Calibrated ranges:   one sigma:         1540 cal BC to 1360 cal BC                                 two sigma:         1670 cal BC to 1230 cal BCThis date correlates well with the dates from the Middle Bronze Age cremation cemetery at Knighton Heath (Grinsell 1982. 15) and with the earlier of the dates in the group of determinations obtained from the Simon's Ground cemetery (ibid) and the Deverel-Rimbury burials from the Barrow Pleck, Handley (Barrett, Bradley et al 1981. 234). Although an earlier origin for the Dorset Downs variant of Deverel-Rimbury ceramics is indicated by the single date for a bucket urn from Arne (1740 bc = 90, Grinsell op cit), the general pattern of dates now suggests that this style of pottery was most commonly produced in the 15th to 12th centuries cal BC (12th to 11th centuries bc).(2) MBA pottery exposed by ploughing.

Site_summary: A Bronze Age bowl barrow. In 1970 this monument was recorded as being around 45 feet in diameter with a mound about 3_ feet high. This barrow was investigated by the antiquarian Edward Cunnington, who found a cremation beneath a central cairn, and several other cremations within the mound.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's Piddlehinton Barrow 3 (Little Piddle Down). Cunnington Barrow 43. Five MBA urned cremations as well as one primary and two secondary unurned cremations.Some finds in Dorset County Museum. Woodward's account of the MBA pottery from another barrow of this group notes that: 'There is some confusion as to which of the five urns surviving in Dorset County Museum derived from which barrow, but Acland (1908. 139) states that DCM Nos. 85 (Abercromby 1912 No. 418), 86, 87 (Abercromby 368) and 88 (Abercromby 441) were found in the same barrow. This was probably Cunnington No. 43 [Grinsell's Piddlehinton Barrow 3].DCM No. 91 (Abercromby 404) may therefore have derived from the other barrow which produced urns, Cunnington No. 45 [this barrow, Grinsell's Barrow 4], probably equal to RCHM (18).The five surviving urns are all tempered with grog, occasionally with the addition of some fragments of chalk: they include one globular urn, three lugged or cordoned buckets ... and one small knobbed cup.'
Site_description: Opened by E Cunnington primary cremation beneath central cairn; secondary cremations, two without urns, 4 in LBA bucket urns and one in LBA Globular urn. (Grinsell 1959, 123)

Site_summary: Bowl barrow situated within a prehistoric field system. Lynchets, on either side of the barrow have clearly respected it. In 1970 this monument was reported as being around 37 feet in diameter with a mound about 5_ feet high, and damaged at the base by ploughing.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's Piddlehinton Barrow 4 (Little Puddle Hill). Cunnington Barrow 45. Although the numbers of (a) urns of each type, (b) upright/inverted urns, (c) urns with/without covering slabs is known, the correspondance of these attributes are not (no further info in Acland 1916). The recorded graves represent a 'best fit' of this evidence.Some finds in Dorset County Museum. Woodward's account of the MBA pottery from another barrow of this group notes that 'There is some confusion as to which of the five urns surviving in Dorset County Museum derived from which barrow, but Acland (1908. 139) states that DCM Nos. 85 (Abercromby 1912 No. 418), 86, 87 (Abercromby 368) and 88 (Abercromby 441) were found in the same barrow. This was probably Cunnington No. 43 [Grinsell's Piddlehinton Barrow 3].DCM No. 91 (Abercromby 404) may therefore have derived from the other barrow which produced urns, Cunnington No. 45 [this barrow, Grinsell's Barrow 4], probably equal to RCHM (18).The five surviving urns are all tempered with grog, occasionally with the addition of some fragments of chalk: they include one globular urn, three lugged or cordoned buckets ... and one small knobbed cup.'
Site_description: Opened by E Cunnington primary ? deposit of five cremations in LBA urns; four being bucket urns and the fifth a globular urn, all beneath cairn. Three of the urns were inverted; the two upright urns were covered with stone slabs. (Grinsell)

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: overarching record for unloated burials from a barrow pair on Poxwell Down. This includes:Grinsell's Poxwell Barrow 2a (Poxwell Down)/Warne's (1866) pr no. 7: possible primary cremation in LBA globular urn; seven secondaries (one with globular urn, three with bucket or barrel urns, and three with urns of unknown type.NB  Warne's account is vague - no clear sense of which of the urns was crushed/how many were actually associated with human remains. Based on Grinsell's summary, it is assumed here that all did.Grinsell's Poxwell Barrow 2b (Poxwell Down)/Warne's (1866) pr barrow no. 8: probable primary cremation beneath large (probably inverted) urn (smashed) which contained accessory vessel three inches high in which were burnt bones, possibly of a child, mixed with ashes.<grouped unlocated barrows>

Primary crouched not found but probably beneath incompletely explored cairn. In this cairn were a grooved bronze dagger, quadrangular gold plate, shale mace head with gold discs, incense cup and amber cup. Above this was a secondary cremation in Early / Middle Bronze Age urn of early type. Still higher were two secondary or intrusive skeletons in stone-lined graves. (Grinsell). Visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs {1}.  The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.The well known objects from this barrow are not associated with hr and are not recorded here (see Cooper et al 2020). The 2nry urned cremation burial is recorded.
Site_description: Bowl, 90ft. in diam and 18ft. high. Has been partly excavated by Cunnington  in 1882 without reaching the primary burial. About 6ft. from the top was a flint cairn, about 1ft. think and 8ft. in diam Below it sherds of an incense cup were scattered on a layer of white clay. Among the flints were fragments of an amber cup, and on the flints were a grooved copper dagger with traces of a wooden sheath and an attached small bronze ring. A quadrangular gold plate and a shale mace head with five gold capped bosses were also found. 1ft. higher was a cremation in a crushed collared urn on a thin layer of ashes and small flints. 4ft. higher and 2ft. from the top of the mound two stone lined graves, possibly Romano-British, lay E.-W. 4ft. apart, each with an inhumation on a fine layer of sand. The mound laregly consisted of layers of sands, clays and gravels. {3}. Visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs {2}.  The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.

Site_summary: Possible ditched bowl, and ploughed almost flat. On aerial photos it shows double ring ditches, 80ft. amd 40ft. in diam. <gg summary>: Opened in 1883 by Cunnington who found a central cairn covering two inhumations abnd an 'A' Beaker. Cremation in top of cairn and another broken urn above. About 10 inhumations, possibly Romano-British, lay 1ft. below the surface. (RCHM). No detail about type of 'urn' but likely Early (or Middle) Bronze Age. This is Winterborne St Martin 32
Site_description: Air photos show the barrow has two concentric ditches. Opened 1883 primary deposit of two inhumations and a degenerate type A beaker beneath central cairn, in the upper part of which was a secondary cremation. Immediately above this cairn was  a cremation in a broken urn 8 inches high. In the material within a foot of the surface of the barrow were about ten intrusive skeletons. (Grinsell). Visible as a cropmark on aerial photographs {1}. The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Collective record for Grinsell's (1959, 120-1) 'Near Milborne St Andrews' barrows 16f-i (unlocated barrows). Calkin (1967, 139) reviewed in detail the discordant accounts of the excavation of barrow h/i (which he concludes are the same barrow) but does not mention barrows 16f and g. He described the interments from barrow 16h/i as follows:Primary interments: 2 urned cremations in biconical urns (found by the farmer in 1864) (Durden's urn no. 139 (in the BM) and Shipp's urn described by Calkin as follows: a biconical urn with pricked vertical chevrons and two small lugs (A.428). These are recorded here as separate burialsSecondary interments: at least 43 Deverel Rimbury urns capped with a substantial layer of flints. Amongst theses, one urn (No. 150) was inverted (the rest were upright); the larger examples were capped with sandstone or flint blocks; others were on or surrounded by flints.The urns retained by Durden (20 in total) are in the Durden Collection in the British Museum. Of these, the secondary urns are summarised by Calkin as follows: '16 are buckets, including 5 with shoulder grooves. Bucket urn no. 144 has 8 repair holes. Nos. 136, 145 and 149 are globulars ... There is no mention of cremated remains with the 'secondary interments' in the excavated accounts. However Durden describes 12 of the vessels he collected as 'cinerary urns' (rather than as 'urn vases'. These are recorded here as separate burials. The remaining urns (31 of the 43 secondary urns) are not recorded here since they may well have been buried separately (as is the case elsewhere in Dorset) and cannot be verified as gg. No attempt has been made to match up the described urns with urns held by the BM (although this may be possible in some cases).The two additional unlocated barrows not mentioned by Calkin (Grinsell's Milborne Barrows 16f-g), both of which also produced grave goods (in the Durden Collection at the BM) are also recorded here.The unlocated barrows from Milborne are grouped in a similar way in the equivalent NRHE record: HOB_UID_455843:  https://www.pastscape.org.uk/hob.aspx?hob_id=455843Summary of Durden's urns (Payne 1892, 23-5)113. Cinerary Urn, black, ornamented with a band of pinched markings (pl. ii. 3) (found 1864) (bucket)114. Cinerary Urn, black (found 1864) (bucket)118. Cinerary Urn, brown (found 1864) (bucket)135. Cinerary Urn, red (found 1864) (bucket)136. Cinerary Urn, brown, with 4 cord loop holes (found 1864) (globular)139. Cinerary Urn, light brown, two false handles 13 (primary biconical urn) (found 1883/4)144. Cinerary Urn, brown, with holes each side of cracks (found 1883/4) (bucket urn with 8 repair holes)145. Cinerary Urn with cord loop holes (found 1883/4) (globular)149. Cinerary Urn, brown (found 1883/4) (globular)150. Cinerary Urn, brown (inverted) (found 1883/4) (bucket)152. Cinerary Urn, drab (found 1883/4) (bucket)155. Cinerary Urn, brown (found 1883/4) (bucket)156. Cinerary Urn, brown (found 1883/4) (bucket)<grouped unlocated barrows>
Site_description: In 1864 H Durden opened a barrow, possibly this one, in the NW of the parish and found two skeletons and at least twelve urns, mostly inverted, containing cremationsDHER record card carried a manuscript reference to Hutchins II, 604, but is unclear as to which edition (1861, 1863 or 1866). Reference is also made to a paper in the Antiquaries Journal Xiii (13), for 1933, p 445

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Grinsell's Milborne Barrow 2 (Stable/Bagber Barrow).  Also known as Bagber Barrow (Mansell-Playdell, 1896). 23 urned cremations, mostly (possibly all) in MBA bucket or globular urns.Mansell-Playdell's report for the Bagber barrow notes that 2 of the urns were inverted and 21 were upright and capped with stone slabs (sarsens or large flints) (one, presumably, the reused quernstone mentioned above). Of these urns, two were small cups. Seven of these vessels are deposited in the Dorset Co. Museum and appear in two plates in this article. At least two of the globular urns were broken then mended (probably 'with ties') prior to deposition (Acland 1908 pots 42 and 53). Mansell-Playdell also notes that the pots were poorly fired and that many were probably made freshly prior to burial, and that the two small cups contained child remains.Not possible to match inverted/upright urns to urn types to urns in Dorchester museum so these attributes are attributed arbitrarily in the ggdb (in order that they are at least represented) (partly based on plates in Mansel-Playdell 1896).
Site_description: MANSELL-PLEYDELL 1895 PART-EXCAVATEDThis is probably 'Bagber Barrow' excavated by J C Mansell-Playdell; it contained 23 urns, all with cremations, two inverted and the remainder upright and covered with slabs of sarsen or flint; the few urns to survive are of globular and 'bucket' type, and there is one small handled cup. <1>There are two additional references cited: Antiquaries Journal xiii(13) 1933, 445; and to Arch. J cxix (1962) 57, 65

Site_summary: A round barrow recorded as being almost 14 metres in diameter and over 4 metres high before it was excavated in 1824. The excavators found a semi-circle of sarsen stones and a number of cremation burials. The site of the barrow is now inside a circular stone wall.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's (1959, 120) Milborne barrow 14: All of the burials directly associated with urns and cremations are recorded here (Miles describes the burial contexts well for his time). Finds mostly in Bristol City Museum (19 urns deposited; 11 logged in the online database; http://museums.bristol.gov.uk/list.php?keyword=deverel), other than one urn (in Dorset Co. Museum).Grave and urn types are assigned based on Miles' (1826) illustrations to the burials in cists (it is possible, but less likely, that some were urns on the ground surface). He describes 21 cremations in urns in total, together with nine unaccompanied burials (not recorded here) (ibid, 23). The urns associated with cist/stone 18 containing deposits of bird bones and an unctuous organic mix are not recorded here. An additional fragment from a collared urn is recorded in Longworth (1984,187, pl. 215b. No. 424.). However its context of discovery is not clear, it is not mentioned in Miles (1926) and it is not recorded here.
Site_description: 'Deverel Barrow was opened by Miles in 1824. Inside, at ground level, was a semi-circle of sarsen stones, all except two, larger than the others, covering cists cut in chalk. (cf. W. Abbas (57) ). Near the largest stone lay a cremation, possibly primary, in an inverted collared urn surrounded by flints. The cists contained some seventeen cremations in globular and bucket urns set upright. As well, four with cremations, two without cremations, and four unaccompanied cremations lay on the barrow floor; five other cists contained only cremations.' (1)'(30) Deverell Barrow (81999900) is now almost entirely destroyed ; its site is marked by a circular walled enclosure planted with trees. Inside, the only relics are a number of large stones on a slight mound. An inscribed stone recording the excavation was setup in 1827 but it is now in fragments. Diameter at time of excavation, 54 ft., height 12ft.' (2)

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: EBA Grinsell's barrow 1 (recorded before excavation) .Proufdfoot's Barrow 2.The mound was erected  over the remains of a funeral pyre, which contained fragments of burnt bone, and over a single cremated interment of a male individual of approximately 27 years of age.  These remains were placed in a grave large enough to contain a crouchedinhumation, and were accompanied by the objects - an ogival grooved dagger, perforated whetstone and bone tweezers and decorated bone pin.
Site_description: (1) '(16) BELL BARROW (04641160), now largely flattened by ploughing, lies 45 yds. N.E. of (15). When excavated in 1959 a single cremation burial was found in a grave cut into the Chalk, with the remains of a funeral pyre beside it. Associated with the burial were artefacts of Wessex Culture type, an ogival bronze dagger, a large perforated whetstone, and remains of bone tweezers and of a decorated bone pin. (P.P.S., XXIX, n.s. (1963), 395-425). Diam. Of mound 62 ft., width of berm 14 ft.; ditch 5ft. Across and 4 ft. deep.'

Site_name_other: Bronze Age urned cremation burial, Castle Lane, Bournemouth
Site_summary: <gg summary> Double Early Bronze Age cremation burials of child & subadult within an inverted collared urn was found in 1930 during house building. The site could not be investigated at the time, so it is not known if this burial was associated with a barrow.
Site_description: A collared urn inverted over a cremation was found on 2 July 1930 by W Holly when digging the footings for a block of houses in Castle Lane. The surrounding land was flat and there was no opportunity for investigating the findspot further to determine whether this cremation was associated with a barrow or not. (1) The urn was 11 inches (28 cm) high, with overhanging rim. The fabric is reddish-brown on the outside, and it appears to show traces of a buff slip. Inside it is almost entirely black. (2)

Site_summary: A Bronze Age cremation cemetery was discovered in 1926 in Pokesdown. Forty-five cremations were excavated in 1926-7, of which eighteen were in urns.<gg_summary>: Complex site. Evidence from two main phases of excavation together with stray finds recovered in advance of the development of this area (for housing) between 1908 and 1936. Only verified urned burials from Druitt's investigations (1908, summarised in Calkin 1951) and Clay's excavations (1926) are recorded here.1908 excavations: 26 urned cremations (5 urns described in detail in Calkin 1952)1926 excavations: 18 'urned cremations' together with 26 unurned cremations, found in two main clusters (summarised in Clay 1927). Only 9 of the 'urned cremations' were directly associated with hr and Clay discusses specifically that inclusion of hr was not an essential part of the burial process. Only these 9 burials are recorded here. The others merit consideration in an anlaysis of 'cenotaph' burials.The relationship between urns and human remains is vague in all cases but it is assumed (given that the they are undoubtedly an underestimation of the overall no. of urned burials) that all recorded urns were associated with hr.NRHE_ID: 458818https://www.pastscape.org.uk/hob.aspx?hob_id=458818Finds in Christchurch Museum (Drewitt's excavations) and the British Museum (from Clay's excavations)NB Clay's (1927) 'carefully cut cists' look like pits in the site photos so are defined as such here. He also uses 'food vessel' to describe small vessels within Deverel-Rimbury urns (defined as DR accessory vessels here).
Site_description: In the autumn of 1926 an urnfield was discovered on the site of the war-time allotment gardens on the southern edge of Littledown Common. On the 1 November excavations were begun, the procedure being to clear away the whole of the top soil and then gravel down to the undisturbed sand. Work did not cease until 28 March, by which time the urnfield had been exhausted and the ground cleared for at least 30 ft beyond its limits. 45 burials were unearthed, for the most part they were irregularly placed and conformed to no formal lay-out or plan. Of the burials, 26 were by cremation only, and 18 by cremation in urns. In 2 instances the urns were associated with food vessels. Two sunken roads were discovered evidently earlier in date than the urn-field. No objects were found associated with any of the burials, but in the top soil there were flint implements, including transverse, leaf-shaped, and barbed and tanged arrow heads, and a solitary ochreous palaeolithic flake. To the west of the urnfield a bronze lead-shaped spear-head was unearthed, while farther again to the west was a built up hearth. Classified Late Bronze Age. Many urns in the British Museum. As there has been some confusion about the situation of this urnfield "I went over the site in 1937 with Mr W E S Young", foreman i/c Dr Clay's excavations. There is no doubt tht the majority of the urns were found on the land between Durrington Place and Harewood Avenue. Mr F W Robins FSA confirms this identification.The official excavations revealed 18 cremations in urns, whilst a further 26 small holes contained ashes only. The combined evidence from the Holmewood collection from Druitts diaries and other sources, gives proof for another 26 urns, with 6 more probables, making a total of at least 70 burials. We must also bear in mind that in the part of the cemetery excavated under skilled supervision, Dr Clay found 3 simple cremations for every 2 urns, so it is reasonable to infer that there were between 30-40 plain cremations in the rest of the cemetery. Thus we arrive at a total of over 100 cremations in all. The urns with 2 exceptions were all normal LBA type. (1)

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: See also MDO8446 (separate record for cremation cemetery record but with no detailed info). Six urned cremations, 10 unurned cremations. All of the vessels are lost (Calkin 1962).
Site_description: An oval barrow covering a large charcoal layer set on the old ground surface, and with a mound of sand. 16 cremations and urn burials were largely concentrated in the south east quadrant (12), with 2 just beyond the south east barrow edge, and one in each of the north west and south west quadrants. Five of the urns could be identified as barrel urns, but the pottery generally was badly disintegrated. The state of the pits suggested that the urns may have been placed inside and hot ashes poured into them, or the urns deposited filled with hot ash, since the underlying sand was very charred and caked solid. There were six urned burials (1 clearly inverted, 1 upright, the others undiscernible) and 10 simple cremations. Soil acidity had destroyed bone except one human fragment, but ashes had commonly survived. Burial 16 appears to have been the primary one (in the north west sector) and was under a few large stones.

Site_summary: A biconical urn was found in 1881 along with a cremation deposit and some large blocks of ironstone. The blocks have been suggested to represent a cist, although this is far from clear. The discovery was made at the south west end of Tuckton Bridge, during its construction.<gg_summary>: See also MDO84867 (duplicate of this record). The duplicate record includes the following useful information:<MDO84867>15:24: 20 LBA bucket urn found c 1881 near SW corner of Tuckton Bridge during bridge construction. Now at Boscombe Public Library. (1-2) (SZ 14899222) Exhibited in Boscombe Public Library in a show case. The urn is virtually complete, and cremation displayed. Show card records that it was found in 1885 near Tuckton Bridge, and presented by Clive Holland MBE JP. (3)Only the single verified urn with cremation is recorded here.
Site_description: A large slightly gritted urn of sub-biconical shape with two large and two small lugs, with its accompanying cremation and several large blocks of ironstone, which presumably formed a cist, were found in 1881 at the SW end of Tuckton Bridge (SZ 149922) during its construction. Preserved in Lansdowne Library for a number of years. (1)

Site_summary: Bronze Age bowl barrow. In 1970 this monument was reported as being about 70 feet in diameter with a mound around 8_ feet high. The barrow was excavated in 1885 by Cunnington, who found a cist burial and the burial of a child. Later burials inserted into the mound were a cremation in a large urn with a smaller vessel, and the remains of two extended burials. Near the top of the mound was a child burial of probable Roman date. Finds from Cunnington's excavations are in the Dorset County Museum. Visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs<gg_summary>: Grinsell's Portesham barrow 14 (S of Ridgeway). Primary burial with no gg; later urned cremation (E-MBA); date of extended inhumations with pots not clear (but pre Roman?).In his reassessment of antiquarian excavations in Dorset Calkin (1967, 144-5, fig. 144) summarises the burial as follows: On the floor a cist of 3 large stones over a contracted skeleton and remains of a child. At 9ft. an urn cremation no. 104 with no. 109 beside it. At 6ft. an extended skeleton in stone cist with no. 108 beside the head. At the same level, a similar skeleton under collapsed cist, with no. 103 twelve inches from the head. Near the surface a skeleton in an R-B stone-lined grave. Note the survival of the inhumationrite after the introduction of cremation.
Site_description: A bowl barrow, 28 paces in diameter and 6 ft high. Excavated and numbered Ridgeway No 8 by E Cunnington. Primary crouched but rather decomposed interment with remains of child; secondary cremation in large LBA urn with three applied fingertip decorated bands below the rim, with accessory vessel; ; two extended skeletons arranged head to feet, each with a pot at its head; intrusive child's skeleton (Romano-British) in grave composed partly of a Roman roof-slab with Roman potsherds just above. In the material of the mound was part of a saddle quern. {1, 2,}.A ditchless, grass covered bowl barrow 24.0m North-South and 22.5m East-West with a height of 2.3m in the East. Its flat top appears to result from excavations the spoil of which may have been thrown down to the south thus enlongating the barrow {3}.Bowl barrow in arable, but not ploughed over although the perimeter has been cut into by ploughing. Diameter 23.0m., height (maximum) 4.5m. No visible ditch {5}.Also visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs {6-9}, measuring approximately 23 metres in diameter. This site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.

Site_summary: Site of a bowl barrow, recorded by the RCHM as a low elongated mound and also visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs. It was excavated in 1894<gg_summary>: Grinsell's (1959, 126) Portesham barrow 2 (SE of the Helstone). Poor contextual detail. Pot described as LBA but probably EBA. In Ellison 1975 as MBA (Globular Urn). See also Abercromby (1912) vessel A.406.
Site_description: Site of a bowl barrow, visible as a low elongated mound about 16 paces across, apparently cut back when the adjoining field wall was made {2}. When excavated by Cunningham in 1894 it measured 48 feet by 16 feet by 6 feet high, and contained a Late Bronze Age primary cremation in an upright bucket, or barrel urn {1}.Field investigators comments made in March 1980 record the mound as being 16.5m. by 10.5m. height 17.m. with no visible ditch {3}.Some of the mound is visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs {4-5} on the northern side of the hedge. This site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.The barrow opened last week - August 9th and 10th - by the permission of Mr. Manfield, is exactly 130ft. south-east of the Helstone ; it has been cut away east and west to its present dimensions of 48ft. By 16ft., but was originally a round barrow of 48ft. diameter. Its height is about 6ft. at a depth of 5ft. rather more than a cart load of large rough stones was found encircling an urn. This urn was resting on the original soil with a thin stone over its mouth and contained the burnt bones. It is 12in. in height, 8in. at the mouth, 9in. at its broadest diameter, and has an incised double zigzag ornamentation near the top enclosing diamond patterns. Two small scrapers and also a rough celt were found and a small quantity of wood ashes. (6)

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Grinsell's Puddletown Barrow 25 (Duddle Dairy House). V poor contextual detail. Only two urns survive in Dorset Co. Museum; Calkin (1962, 65) mentions three urns from this site (illustrated in Abercromby 1912, 242). Only the surviving/verified urns (three in total) are recorded as burials here. Given the lack of contextual detail, all three urns are recorded in one grave, linked to an MNI of one cremation burial.
Site_description: 'A barrow formerly existed at 73469104 near Norris Mill, but it was almost entirely carted away in 1872, being composed of sand and gravel; of twelve urns which were found in the top of it, two survive in D.C.M. (Cunnington MS. No. 5; Dorset Procs. XXIX (1908), 140; B.A.P. II, figs. 424, 424a; Arch. J. CXIX (1962), 65).' (1)Two of twelve Late Bronze Age bucket urns, probably from this barrow, are in DCM (Grinsell).

Site_summary: One of three barrows situated on the Knoll. Bowl barrow, 64ft. in diam and 4ft. high (RCHM). Visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs {1}and digitally plotted for the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.Grinsell's (1959, 129) Puncknowle barrow 1. Urned cremation burial of an adult (under 30) of unknown sex. The urn had been placed upright in a small oval pit (NW of the centre of the barrow) cut into the land surface within a sub-rectangular burnt area (potentially the remains of the pyre). It was supported by stones. Fragments of cremated bone were also recovered from the pit. Most of the body parts were represented (2334g cremated bone within the urn; 72g beyond the urn). The urn was identified as a sub-biconical urn, approaching the profile of a bucket urn but with decoration similar to that found on food vessel urns (Tomalin in Greenfield 1985, 71).
Site_description: One of three barrows situated on the Knoll. Bowl barrow, 64ft. in diam and 4ft. high (RCHM). Visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs {1}and digitally plotted for the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.NW of centre primary cremation in upright biconical urn, in a small oval pit. Near centre of sub rectangular burnt area probably site of pyre. Above this was a loose cairn revetted by inward sloping cairn revetted by inward sloping slabs and covered by mound of soil. (Grinsell).

Site_summary: One of three barrows situated on the Knoll. Bowl barrow, 33ft. in diam and 5ft. high (RCHM). Visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs {1} and digitally plotted for the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's Puncknowle Barrow 2 (On The Knoll). Disturbed barrow. Poor contextual detail.NB Hedges et al (1987) comment on c14 dates from this site (OxA-840) which they describe as being 'in close accord with the pottery chronology', giving a date of c. 3350- 3250 BP.
Site_description: One of three barrows situated on the Knoll. Bowl barrow, 33ft. in diam and 5ft. high (RCHM). Visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs {1} and digitally plotted for the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.Centre had been robbed in medieval times disturbing primary interment which comprised scattered burnt bones, with sherds of large Bronze Age urn on old ground surface. Above this were the remains of a medieval cooking vessel . On south side was secondary cremation with crushed fragmentary vessel, nearby were the remains of a bucket urn. (Grinsell)

Site_summary: One of three barrows situated on the Knoll. Probable barrow, 54ft. in diam and 4ft. high. It supports a small building. (RCHM). Visible as a slight earthwork on aerial photographs {1} and digitally plotted for the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.<gg summary>: This is Grinsell's (1959) Puncknowle Barrow 3 with a tiny watchtower on top. A small cist was found containing a cremation associated with a Food Vessel (Flower pot type urn). Large Food Vessel - enlarged type over 50cm tall
Site_description: One of three barrows situated on the Knoll. Probable barrow, 54ft. in diam and 4ft. high. It supports a small building. (RCHM). Visible as a slight earthwork on aerial photographs {1} and digitally plotted for the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.Tiny building on it, site of finding of cinerary urn in 1908. (Grinsell)

Site_name_other: Bronze Age barrow Puncknowle barrow G6
Site_summary: One of 6 barrows on the top of Tulk's Hill. Bowl barrow, 33ft. in diam and 2.5ft. high (RCHM). The feature is visible on aerial photographs {1} and was digitally plotted for the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's Puncknowle Barrow 6 (Limekiln Hill). Primary MBA urned cremation burial; six secondary cremation burials not associated with ggNB Hedges et al (1987) comment on c14 dates from this site (OxA-839) which they describe as being 'worryingly too early', preferring a broad date of c. 3350- 3250 BP in accord with other dated barrows from this group.
Site_description: One of 6 barrows (barrow 'A') on the top of Tulk's Hill. Bowl barrow, 33ft. in diam and 2.5ft. high (RCHM). The feature is visible on aerial photographs {1} and was digitally plotted for the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project. Primary cremation in bucket urn surrounded by three stone slabs. The interment was covered by small cairn. Near south and west parts of circumference were six secondary cremations. (Grinsell)

Site_name_other: Burial site with late Celtic mirror, West of
Site_summary: Iron Age burial with cremation jar, bones, late Celtic mirror and other bronze objects.<gg_summary>: Finds in Dorchester Museum
Site_description: (1) Some years ago in a fall of cliff, just west of Bridport Harbour, a burial was disclosed together with a pot and metal object...a bronze mirror handle of Celtic type (1st. century A.D.) (a) Dr Bedford states that there were at least two skeletons in association with the pot - an Iron Age C bead-rim jar. He has the jaw bones, one of a muscular male, the other of an old woman with a copper stain on it. A whole lot of bronze objects were also found. The information and pot were obtained from a Mr Glenning of Bridport who cannot now be located. (1) The siting is from two snapshots taken by Mr Sapsford of the cliff fall where the finds were made. (2) The circular plate of the mirror is missing, but the groove into which it fitted and one of the rivets may be seen in the E.I.A. B case. No. 1934.8.1. (3) Presented to The Museum by The Museum Council. (Dorset County Museum) (4) No further information obtained during field investigation. (5) Full report on the mirror and other finds.  (6) The find was made by Mr S Gluning (not Glenning) whose son says that the finds were all together, although there was no visible sign of a coffin.  (7)

Site_summary: A Bronze Age bowl barrow said originally to have been around 70 feet in diameter. Much disturbed by antiquarian investigation in 1890 when what is thought to have been a cremation in a bucket urn was found beneath a cairn.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's (1959, 139) West Knighton Barrow 1. No further info.
Site_description: Site of a Bronze Age bowl barrow visible as cropmarks on aerial photographs. May be associated with another barrow (MDO20799) situated directly to the west of it. Probable primary cremation in Late Bronze Age bucket urn with four lugs. Beneath cairn. <3>

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow, one of the Culliford Tree Group, Whitcombe
Site_summary: Bowl barrow 41m in diameter visible on aerial photographs {1}  as a cropmark ring ditch with internal mound. Digitally plotted as part of the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project. <gg summary>: Secondary cremation with ashes in collared urn. Inense cup also inside with the Collared Urn cremation. Secondary (Saxon?) four extended inhumations one female with necklace of amber beads, two had gold casings. (Grinsell). Note thought by Grinsell that the primary burial was not reachedNote -  separate skeletons were found at a shallow depth near the top of the mound, all extended inhumations and one, a female, accompanied by amber beads possibly representing a necklace. Two of the beads had "gold plates on their bases". Several feet lower down in the mound was an Early Bronze Age collared urn containing ashes, calcined human bones, and a small pottery accessory vessel. The excavation appears to have continued no further. Piggott (1938: 102) included the barrow in his list of Early Bronze Age "Wessex graves", noting the presence of amber and gold in particular. However, others have suggested that the extended inhumations, and thus the amber and gold (some of the beads were gold-plated) , are of much later date, probably Anglo-Saxon. Are they EBA or Saxon?
Site_description: Bowl barrow, 94ft. in diam and  13ft. high, within tree clump enclosure, still containing trees, first planted 1740. Large trench on S. and top almost certainly dug 1858, when four secondary extended inhumations, one with a necklace of amber and two plated gold beads, and a cremation with incense cup in collared urn, were found. {2}Visible on aerial photographs {1}  as a cropmark ring ditch with internal mound. Digitally plotted as part of the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project. Secondary cremation with ashes in collared urn. Secondary (Saxon?) four extended inhumations one female with necklace of amber beads, two had gold casings. (Grinsell).<summary>: Whitcombe 1, Culliford Tree. This is part of a more extensive linear barrow cemetery that has a bank barrow at iits eastern end. Are the extended inhumations Saxon or EBA (Piggott thinks the latter). While extended positions are unusual for the EBA, they have been recorded elsewhere with high-status EBA Wessex burials (eg Bush Barrow)

Site_summary: A Bronze Age bowl barrow located on a low ridge is visible as a cropmark on aerial photographs.<gg_summary> Grinsell's (1982, 53) Whitcombe barrow 12: Crushed BA urn with burnt bones and ashes, recorded by the OS. No further details.
Site_description: A Bronze Age bowl barrow,  located on a low ridge  600 metres south of Whitcombe Farm, is visible as a cropmark on aerial photographs. Another bowl barrow is located close by (MDO20754) and may be associated with it.{1-2}Plough revealed about five yards south of centre a crushed Bronze Age urn with burnt bones and ashes. (Grinsell)

Site_name_other: Bell Barrow, one of the Came Down Group, Winterborne Came
Site_summary: Mutilated bell barrow. Visible on aerial photographs {1} as a cropmark ring ditch 48m in diameter with internal mound, ditch and central pit. The site was digitally plotted for the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping project.<gg summary>: Winterborne Came 38. A large bowl barrow with an earthen mound containing two (?)primary inhumations accompanied by parts of antlers, and two grooved bronze daggers 1.2m higher up, all south east of the barrow centre. One of the daggers is more of a knife or razor. Also a broken ring-headed dress pin
Site_description: This may be the massived barrow destroyed in the nineteenth century;  said to have contained nearly 2000 cartloads of soil. Two primary inhumations accompanied by parts of antlers, some 10ft. from the surface. 3ft. to 4ft. below were two grooved bronze daggers, the longer probably with 6 rivets, the shorter apperently tanged. All apparently SE of centre.  RCHM,II PT3,464/SDR506Probable bell barrow, 100ft. in diam and 2ft. high, but flattened by ploughing. Probably within ditch about 140ft. in diam, suggested by air photograph. Visible on aerial photographs {1} as a cropmark ring ditch 48m in diameter with internal mound, ditch and central pit. The site was digitally plotted for the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping project.<sumary>. This is Grinsell WCarne 38, Came adjoining Herrington

Site_name_other: Bell Barrow, one of the Came Down Group, Winterborne Came
Site_summary: Bell barrow on Came Down Golf Course, top of barrow used as a tee. Visible on aerial photographs {1} as an earthwork mound 29m in diameter. Digitally plotted for the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping project.<gg summary>: Grinsell's (1959, 148) Winterborne Came 18b. Inhumations and cremation in urn (2ry)
Site_description: Bell barrow, 87ft. in diam and 7ft. high, with ditch 15ft. wide, destroyed on the E. side. Berm visible only on the S. and perhaps on W. side. Top of mound used as a golf tee. Probably excavated in 1882 by Cunnington who found a few worked flints and a near-central cremation in a chalk cut hollow six inches deep, apparently beside the pyre. Visible on aerial photographs {1} as an earthwork mound 29m in diameter. Digitally plotted for the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping project.

Site_summary: Possible bowl barrow described in 1970 as being around  77 feet in diameter with a mound 6 feet high. Much damaged and crossed by the boundary of the former parish of Fordington. <gg summary>: Opened in 1880 by Cunnington who found a primary (?) contracted inhmation under a cairn, in which was possibly a cremation with part of a flint or stone axe. Also a scraper and other non-specified worked flints and fragments of an urn Inhumation seemingly lacked grave goods.
Site_description: Possible bowl barrow, about 77ft. in diam and 6ft. high. Much damaged and crossed by the boundary of the former parish of Fordington. Opened in 1880 by Cunnington who found a primary (?) contracted inhmation under a cairn, in which was possibly a cremation with part of a flint or stone axe. Primary crouched interment, probably beneath cairn, among ashes in this cairn was part of an axe of flint or stone. (Grinsell). (RCHM) Visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs {3}. The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow in the Ridge Hill group, Winterborne St Martin
Site_summary: A Bronze Age bowl barrow about 50 feet in diameter and and reduced to a very low mound by ploughing. Visible as a cropmark ring ditch with central pit on aerial photographs. The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.<gg_summary>: Unlocated barrow on Ridge Hill, Winterborne St Martin (Grinsell's barrow 89a). The information is attached here to located barrow G89 which is in the HER. Grave goods may have come from other barrows of this group but this issue is impossible to resolve so, following Grinsell, they are assigned to this barrow for the sake of simplicity. Fragmentary Cornish handled urn associated with cremation (E-MBA date)
Site_description: Bowl, about 50ft. in diam and ploughed flat. Visible as a cropmark ring ditch with central pit on aerial photographs {2}. The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project. Part of Cornish handled urn and burnt bones found on disturbed top of barrow. Perhaps this one. (Grinsell)

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow in the Eweleaze Barn group, Winterborne St Martin
Site_summary: An Early Bronze Age ditched bowl barrow, excavated in 1903. Also visible as a circular earthwork mound on aerial photographs and LIDAR<gg summary>:W St Martin G46.  primary burial with handled Beaker. and 3 infants sharing a Food Vessel. 2ndary cremation with dagger and incense cup.Points of interest - nearly 1500 flint flakes deliberately knapped over primary cairn - flakes very freshThe Incense cup with the cremation and dagger (which was jammed into cist wall) was already broken and incomplete when deposited
Site_description: An Early Bronze Age ditched bowl barrow, excavated in 1903 by Harold St George Gray and C Prideaux {1}. At the time of the excavation, the mound was 82ft. in diam and 12ft. high. The excavated ditch was flat bottomed, 10.5ft. wide and 3.5ft. deep, around original turf mound, 64ft. in diam and 9ft. hifgh, capped with chalk. N-S section across the centre revealed crouched male inhumation with handled Beaker bowl in oblong chalk cut grave, with three child inhumations and smaller jar nearby, all under flint cairn. S. of these but still N. of the apparent centre, a ring of stones enclosed a cremation, fragments of incense cup and grooved copper dagger in wooden sheath. Many flake implements, cores and flakes lay in and under the mound {2}.Primary crouched male interment aged 18-19 at time of death, with handled bowl in oblong grave; near this were the bones of three infants with a smaller food vessel. North of centre, a ring of stones enclosing bronze grooved dagger with remains of a wooden sheath, portions of an incense cup, and a subsequent primary or secondary cremation {3}.It is also visible as a circular earthwork mound, approximately 22.8 metres in diameter, on aerial photographs {4-5} and LIDAR {6} and was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow in the Eweleaze Barn group, Winterborne St Martin
Site_summary: A Bronze Age bowl barrow, part of a linear barrow cemetery. Excavated in 1905. Also visible as an earthwork and a cropmark on aerial photographs.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's (1959, 154) W St Martin 44: Two primary crouched inhumations, one with a Food Vessel (and disarticulated bones of child in grave fill) and the other unaccompanied. Both were of robust males. The one that lacked grave goods was nearly 6 feet tall and very robust. His lower jaw had been detached before the grave was backfilled.Secondary inverted Collared Urn cremation in a grass bag of a child.Note in barrow mound a large number of exquisitely worked flint tools, including 18 scrapers of a variety of types and sizes and two flaked and polished flint knives with ground and polished cutting edges (not recorded as gg)
Site_description: A Bronze Age bowl barrow, part of a linear barrow cemetery comprising bowl barrows, a pond barrow, and a quadruple bell barrow (MDO3183-91).Possible bowl barrow, only slight mound remains, 93ft. in diam and 2.75ft. high before excavation, which revealed two primary crouched male inhumations, one with fragments of food vessel and infants bones, and a secondary cremation in woven grass bag under a collared urn resting on a stone slab. Near the centre there was a circular hole, 1.75ft. in diam and 1.5ft. deep, it contained animal bones. Flint implements, cores and flakes, and a shale disc were also found within the mound. An aerial photograph shows a narrow ditch 65-75ft. in diameter {1-2}.Two primary crouched male interments (one with food vessel) and secondary cremation beneath early / middle Bronze Age collard urn. The burnt bones were wrapped in a pouch woven from some kind of grass {3}.In addition, this site is visible as an earthwork and a cropmark on aerial photographs {4-6}, with the mound measuring approximately 21 metres in diameter and an outer ditch of 2 meters. This site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.

Site_name_other: Bowl Barrow in the Wireless Station Group, Winterborne St Martin
Site_summary: The site of a Bronze Age round barrow is visible as cropmarks on aerial photographs.<gg summary>: cremation near three broken urns . This is Winterborne St Martin 5b. , two Food Vessel burials (1 inhumation and 1 double inhumation & cremation)  and 1 Biconical urn cremations
Site_description: The site of a Bronze Age round barrow is visible as cropmarks on aerial photographs. {1}Ditched bowl, 60ft. in diam and 11ft. high. Contained a central cairn, above which was a cremation near three urns, broken by four intrusive inhumations. (RCHM)

Site_name_other: Bowl Barrow in the Wireless Station Group, Winterborne St Martin
Site_summary: The site of a Bronze Age round barrow is visible as cropmarks on aerial photographs.<gg summary>: This is Bincombe 60a. Primary inhumation with Collared Urn and boar tusks etcThe Collared Urn contained a cremation and was shared by inhumation (at its feet) and cremation (container)
Site_description: The site of a Bronze Age round barrow is visible as cropmarks on aerial photographs.{1}Possible bowl, 60ft. in diam and 9ft. high. Contained a cremation with antler, ox bones and flint implements in oval grave 2ft. long by 1.5ft. deep beneath cairn. (RCHM)

Site_name_other: Pond barrow, one of the Sheep Down Group,Winterbourne Steepleton
Site_summary: Pond barrow, one of a group of several Bronze Age Barrows noted on Sheep Down. Also visible as an earthwork and a cropmark at this location on aerial photographs.<gg summary>: Although the nature of this site sounds more like a MBA urned cremation cemetery, some of the pots containing cremations were Yorkshire Food Vessels. The others were Collared Urns or developed Collared Urns. It should be noted that this pond barrow had a central depression with a flint pavement and beneath the pavement were 34 pits cut into the natural chalk. Of these 7 were unaccompanied cremations, 8 were empty pits with soil and chalk rubble. While 17 of these pits contained EBA urns, in most cases the urns were not associated with cremated bones. In only 7 cases the pits contained inhumed or cremated bone (the latter often just a small amount or 'token' deposit) with grave goods - 6 pots (Food Vessels and Collared Urns) and in one case a textile bagThis is Winterborne Steepleton Grinsell (1959) 19c.
Site_description: Site of a Bronze Age pond barrow. It is one of a group of several Bronze Age Barrows noted on Sheep Down (MDO3392-6) that lie above apparent limit of 'Celtic' fields  (MDO3414) on a broad spur running North East from the Ridgeway at about 460 ft above OD.Pond barrow. Central depression, diameter 35 ft, depth 2 ft, surrounded by bank 10 ft to 12 ft wide and 5 ins high. Excavation by H G Wakefield for the commission in 1947-8 and by R J C Atkinson in 1950 showed that a pavement of flints gathered from the top-soil largely covered the depression. Beneath and around the pavement were thirty-five pits cut into the chalk subsoil, in some cases through the pavement. Seventeen pits contained Early Bronze Age urns, two held an urn and an inhumation, one held a urn and a cremation, seven contained only cremations, and eight were filled with soil alone. The whole site had been stripped before the pavement was laid, the pits dug, and the bank built {1-2}.Later field investigations record it as having been ploughed out leaving no remains {3}.A circular hollow which may be the remains of this barrow  is also visible as an earthwork and a cropmark at this location on aerial photographs {4-5}, measuring approximately 11 metres in diameter. This site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.

Site_summary: A bowl barrow thought to have been destroyed by gravel digging before 1954.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's Warmwell Barrow 4 (North Heath).
Site_description: Parts of D/R urn with burnt bones probably from this site in DCM. (Grinsell)AP 1934.3076

Site_name_other: Blandford St Mary, Stour Park; Bronze Age Ring Ditch with Cremation
Site_summary: Excavations in advance of the development of Stour Park retail site, Blandford St Mary during 1993 revealed evidence for Late Bronze Age activity was revealed. This comprised a probable ring ditch and at least one urned cremation burial.
Site_description: Excavations in advance of the development of Stour Park retail site, Blandford St Mary during 1993 revealed evidence for Late Bronze Age activity was revealed. This comprised a probable ring ditch and at least one urned cremation burial.These features were sealed beneath a horizon of weathered gravel and comprised small pits, one of which contained an urned cremation and a section of curving ditch that may represent the remains of a destroyed round barrow [1].

Site_summary: A small pit containing sherds of a straight sided Middle Bronze Age Urn, enclosing a cremation, were found during a watching brief on the Sturminster Marshall to Blandford St Mary water main in 1991.

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow south of Coombe Bottom, Hilton
Site_summary: Bowl barrow, 68ft. in diam and 8ft. high. Has been excavated in 1916 by Maj. C. Ashburnham.<gg summary> Grinsell (1959, 164) Hilton barrow 2. A minimum of 2 males, 5 females and 1 child came from this barrow. All lacked grave goods except for the urned cremation. There was one young woman crouched inhumation with a child cremation in 1ry grave. Inverted Ridged Food Vessel with awl and female cremation. The unfurnished burials were all crouched or flexed but lacked gg so uncertain as to whether they are Beaker, EBA or much later although at least two were found at the centre of the barrow in a primary position (in primary central grave). one flint scraper found in upper grave fill but not directly associated with a burial
Site_description: Covered with firs, Barrow with two concentric ditches and a level space between them (berm?), Excavated bby Major C Ashburnham 1916-7, primary crouched interment, secondary cremation and bronze awl in inverted Early/Middle Bronze Age urn, this may have been a composite bowl-barrow not a bell barrow. (Grinsell)The barrow was excavated by Maj. C. Ashburnham and proved to be of two main periods. A primary crouched internment  in a cist cut into the natural chalk lay under a flint cairn about 38ft. in diam and surrounded by a ditch. The cairn was later enlarged to its present diameter and a second ditch was cut. Numerous inhumations and one cremation, probably all secondary, were found in the mound, and two creamtions, one with a small bronze awl, were found in ridged food vessels in the inner ditch. A large hole in the centre and an apparent berm on the w. are presumably the result of the excavation.

Site_summary: Bronze Age bowl barrow surviving as an earthwork mound and ditch. In 1972 the monument was recorded as thickly overgrown, approximately 50 feet in diameter with a mound standing some 5.5 feet high, and with a ditch 9 feet across and 1 foot deep.The record for this monument has been enhanced with support from Wessex Water.<gg summary>: Grinsell thinks this a disc barrow. Other than an urn of 'agreeable form' surrounded by 6 cremations in cists there is very little to go onThere were six separate interments/ cremations in small cists cut into chalk - burnt bones and ashes and then covered with a packing of flints. The other was in an urn in the mound
Site_description: So called Folly Barrow on Isaac Taylor Ms.Map, perhaps a disc barrow of the Dorset type, excavated, urn of an agreeable form, surrounded by 6 cremations in cists. (Grinsell)'All the barrows lie on high ground in the E. of the parish, four of them composing a group of Iwerne Hill. A small barrow was destroyed in 1846 during the ploughing of the high downland between Iwerne Hill and West Lodge; on its floor was an inverted urn covered by a quantity of black ash and surrounded by siz cremations in cists cut in the Chalk; its exact location is not known. (Hutchins III, 555; C.T.D., Pt.2, no.4; Dorset Procs., L (1928), 121; Warne, MS. Album in D.C.M., 209.)(16) Folly Barrow (88561563), bowl, about 600 ft. above O.D. on Bareden Down, on a southward-facing slope, lies just below the crest of the escarpment. It is in a small wood and is thickly overgrown. Diameter 50 ft., heigh 5_ ft.; ditch 9 ft. across and 1 ft. deep'. (1)

Site_name_other: Disc barrow, Iwerne Minster, Iwerne Down
Site_summary: A Bronze Age disc barrow on Iwerne Down, discovered and excavated by Shipp in 1846. Seven cremations were found in the mound, the central one in an urn. At the time of excavation the monument was approximately 27 feet in diameter, and stood 3 feet high; by 1986 it was no longer visible. The record for this monument has been enhanced with support from Wessex Water<gg_summary>: Grinsell's (1959, 168) Iwerne Minster Disc Barrow 4a 'West Lodge, Iwerne Down': central urned cremation surrounded by unaccompanied cremations in cistsNB Location revised in Grinsel 1982, when the barrow was also renamed 4b<awaiting further info>
Site_description: A disc barrow at West Lodge, Iwerne Down, immediately opposite the 6th milestone on the higher road between Blandford and Shaftesbury. The barrow was excavated by Shipp in 1846. It measured 3 feet high by 27 feet circumference. It had a slight surrounding bank. An inverted urn beneath the mound was covered by an immense quantity of ashes and surrounded by six cists cut in the chalk, each contained burnt bones and ashes.(1) (2) (3)"At the 6th milestone on the higher Blandford - Shaftesbury road is a grass covered mound which may be the barrow. J Rigg, 2/3/1956 (1)"This feature is now reduced to a vague unsurveyable mound approximating to the dimensions given in the field report of 2.3.56; situated in arable. No trace on either RAF (AP/RAF/1954/F22-58-1332, 63, 64) or OS (AP/OS/75-371-90, 91) air phpotographs." Desc text/OS 495/C  C/1978"Site lies immediately E of a road beyond a hedge boundary. In a field occasionally ploughed and in established grass when visited. No visible trace. 7/7/E."  Papworth MDJ/TWA/15.1.86

Site_summary: Human remains and 'British urns' found at this location in 1840.The record for this monument has been enhanced with support from Wessex Water.<gg summary>: Two urns with cremations  (nos 22 & 23) were found in this barrow in 1840. One had four cord loop holes (?Food Vessel type) . Other urns were also found but no further detail Grinsell's (1959, 116) Langton Long Blandford barrow 3
Site_description: 'A number of finds indicative of Iron Age and Romano-British settlement are known from the parish, all on the lower slopes of the Stour valley      Human remains and British urns  were found in 1840 at 90790544...' [1]

Site_summary: Destroyed in the construction of Blandford military camps.<gg_summary>: This record potentially represents Grinsell's (1959) unlocated barrows in Tarrant Hinton (suggested by the site description), although the site summary contradicts the site description (Blandford military camp is some distance south of Pimperne long barrow). Recorded here are the finds from east of Pimperne Long barrow, a barrow which contained an extended inhumation, probably primary, with 'fragments of a rude urn' at its side, covered by a cairn of flints.'
Site_description: 'In addition to five undated mounds (54), some twenty-eight round barrows occur in the parish, most of them levelled or damaged by cultivation. A few were dug into in the 19th century, and among these are two which cannot be precisely located. One of them, 'near Pimperne Long Barrow;, was small and contained at the centre an extended, probably intrusive inhumation with the head to the W.; in a cist in the Chalk near its feet lay another inhumation, proably primary (C.T.D., Pt. 2, no. 24). The other unlocated barrow, 'about _ mile E. of Pimperne Long Barrow', contained an extended inhumation, probably primary, with 'fragments of a rude urn' at its side, covered by a cairn of flints. Above the cairn was a pot containing a hoard of Constantinian coins (C.T.D., Pt. 3, no. 99; Hutchins I, 318-9). (26) Barrow (91870906) has been destroyed in the construction of Blandford military camp.' {1}

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow, one of the Launceston Down South Group, Tarrant Launceston
Site_summary: <gg_summary>: One of eighteen barrows excavated by the Piggotts in 1938 on Launceston Down/Long Crichel (Piggott and Piggott 1944 Barrow 18, 77) (Grinsell 1959 Tarrant Launceston Barrow 9, 135). Barrow covering a primary cremation, associated with a calcite double-spaced bead, in a circular grave cut into the chalk, probably Early Bronze Age (style of bead suggests EBA date)
Site_description: 'The Launceston Down South Group comprises thirteen barrows (36-44); four of them lie in the neighbouring parish of Long Crichel (see Dorset V). They are between 200 ft. and 250 ft. above O.D., and extend in an irregular line from W. to E. on the northward-facing slope of a dry combe which falls E. to the Crichel brook. All these barrows were excavated in 1938 by S. and C.M. Piggott (Arch., XC (1944), 47-80); they are no longer visible on the ground and former dimensions, etc. are recorded.(36) Bowl (95381067), covering a primary cremation, associated with a calcite double-spaced bead, in a circular grave cut into the chalk; diam. 25 ft., ht. 1 ft. (Piggott, 18).' {1}

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow, one of the Launceston Down South Group, Tarrant Launceston
Site_summary: <gg_summary>: One of eighteen barrows excavated by the Piggotts in 1938 on Launceston Down/Long Crichel (Piggott and Piggott 1944 Barrow 12, 74) (Grinsell 1959 Tarrant Launceston Barrow 3, 135). cremation, probably primary, under an inverted cinerary urn i(Collared Urn) n a shallow pit in the chalk
Site_description: 'The Launceston Down South Group comprises thirteen barrows (36-44); four of them lie in the neighbouring parish of Long Crichel (see Dorset V). They are between 200 ft. and 250 ft. above O.D., and extend in an irregular line from W. to E. on the northward-facing slope of a dry combe which falls E. to the Crichel brook. All these barrows were excavated in 1938 by S. and C.M. Piggott (Arch., XC (1944), 47-80); they are no longer visible on the ground and former dimensions, etc. are recorded.    (37) Bowl (95501069), disturbed in the past, yielded a cremation, probably primary, under an inverted cinerary urn in a shallow pit in the chalk; diam. 35 ft., ht. 1_ ft. (Piggott, 12).' {1}

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow, one of the Tarrant Launceston
Site_summary: <gg_summary>: One of eighteen barrows excavated by the Piggotts in 1938 on Launceston Down/Long Crichel (Piggott and Piggott 1944 Barrow 13, 74-5) (Grinsell 1959 Tarrant Launceston Barrow 4, 135).Crouched inhumation with leaf-shaped arrowhead (?Early Neolithic); its location however could imply it was a weapon of death, rather than gg (found in among ribs)
Site_description: 'The Launceston Down South Group comprises thirteen barrows (36-44); four of them lie in the neighbouring parish of Long Crichel (see Dorset V). They are between 200 ft. and 250 ft. above O.D., and extend in an irregular line from W. to E. on the northward-facing slope of a dry combe which falls E. to the Crichel brook. All these barrows were excavated in 1938 by S. and C.M. Piggott (Arch., XC (1944), 47-80); they are no longer visible on the ground and former dimensions, etc. are recorded.    (38) Bowl (95621064), with a primary crouched inhumation near the centre associated with a leaf-shaped arrowhead; diam. 40 ft., ht. 1 ft. (Piggott, 13).' {1}

Site_name_other: Bowl Barrow in the Launceston Down South Group, Tarrant Launceston
Site_summary: A bowl barrow recorded as being a mound around 17 feet in diameter and less than one foot high. Excavation revealed a central grave containing a crouched burial with a bell beaker, and a second burial in the form of a cremation inserted into the mound.(unurned cremation and partly dug into north corner of grave pit) <gg_summary>: One of eighteen barrows excavated by the Piggotts in 1938 on Launceston Down/Long Crichel (Piggott and Piggott 1944 Barrow 14, 75-6) (Grinsell 1959 Tarrant Launceston Barrow 5, 135).
Site_description: Primary crouched inhumation with trephined skull and Bi beaker; rough flint pick in filling of grave. Secondary cremation. (1)'(40) Bowl (95741058), containing a primary crouched inhumation with a trephined skull, associated with a bell beaker, in a central grave cut into the chalk, and a secondary cremation near it; diam. 17 ft., ht. less than 1 ft. (Piggott, 14).' (2)Tarrant Launceston Barrow 5 or 14

Site_name_other: Bowl Barrow in the Launceston Down South Group, Tarrant Launceston
