Site_summary: A bowl barrow recorded as surviving as a mound around 25 feet in diameter and one foot high. Excavation revealed that the barrow had been dug into at an earlier period, probably by an antiquarian.<gg_summary>: One of eighteen barrows excavated by the Piggotts in 1938 on Launceston Down/Long Crichel (Piggott and Piggott 1944 Barrow 16, 76) (Grinsell 1959 Tarrant Launceston Barrow 7, 135).
Site_description: Probably primary inhumation with very small degenerate type A beaker. (1)'(41) Bowl (95771060), apparently disturbed by earlier digging, probably had contained a primary inhumation associated with a small long-necked beaker; diam. 25 ft., ht. 1 ft. (Piggott, 16).' (2)Tarrant Launceston Barrow 7

Site_name_other: Bowl Barrow in the Launceston Down South Group, Tarrant Launceston
Site_summary: A bowl barrow recorded as a mound around 18 feet in diameter and one foot high.<gg_summary>: One of eighteen barrows excavated by the Piggotts in 1938 on Launceston Down/Long Crichel (Piggott and Piggott 1944 Barrow 17, 76-7) (Grinsell 1959 Tarrant Launceston Barrow 8, 135).  Excavation revealed a pit containing a crouched burial with a bronze awl and a FP beaker. Another urn was found in another part of the mound- degenerate Food Vessel.
Site_description: Primary crouched inhumation with bronze awl at feet and type A beaker touching left shoulder. Secondary Early/Middle Bronze Age urn or degenerate food vessel. (1)'(42) Bowl (95711050), containing a primary crouched inhumation, associated with a bronze awl and a long-necked beaker, in a large grave cut into the chalk. An urn of 'degenerate food-vessel' type was found in a secondary position in this grave. Diam. 18 ft., ht. 1 ft. (Piggott, 17).' (2)Tarrant Launceston Barrow 8

Site_name_other: Crichel Down Barrow Group (Long Crichel Barrow 22) Bowl Barrow
Site_summary: A bowl barrow recorded as a mound around 40 feet in diameter and two feet high, surrounded by a horseshoe-shaped ditch with a causeway on the eastern side. Excavation revealed an original cremation burial with four later cremations. A fifth cremation had been inserted near the edge of the mound at a much later date, and was interpreted as being either Romano-British or pagan Saxon.<gg_summary>: One of eighteen barrows excavated by the Piggotts in 1938 on Launceston Down/Long Crichel (Piggott and Piggott 1944 Barrow 9, 71-2) (Grinsell 1959 Long Crichel Barrow 22, 119). Barrow c. 13m in diamter, with traces of an earlier shallow ring ditch cut by the horse-shoe shaped ?MBA causeway. (Piggott 1938, fig. 7). The central cremation was not associated with grave goods. Several of the 5-6 secondary cremations were associated with small gritty sherds of [MBA] pottery (not recorded as gg). One of these secondary cremations comprised an [E/MBA] urned cremation (recorded here).
Site_description: Primary EBA cremation with four secondary MBA cremations, one of which was with a later Bronze Age (Deverell Rimbury) pot with perforated lugs.Intrusive crouched inhumation, probably IA/Romano British or pagan Saxon. (1)'(43) Bowl (95891056), yielding a primary cremation and four secondary cremations, one of them associated with an inverted sub-biconical urn (Arch. J., CXIX (1962), 41, 62). An intrusive crouched inhumation near the edge of the mound was probably Romano-British or pagan Saxon. Diam. 40 ft., ht. 2 ft., with a horseshoe-shaped ditch with a causeway on the E. (Piggott, 9; Dorset Barrows, Long Crichel, No. 22).' (2)

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: One of eighteen barrows excavated by the Piggotts in 1938 on Launceston Down/Long Crichel (Piggott and Piggott 1944 Barrow 10, 72-3) (Grinsell 1959 Tarrant Launceston Barrow 10, 135).
Site_description: EXCAVATED PIGGOTT 1938 PRIMARY CREMATION IN BARREL URN.<NRHE site description>: A bowl barrow 600 metres south of Plantation Farm. Listed by RCHME as Tarrant Launceston 49 and by Grinsell as Tarrant Launceston 10, it was excavated by S and C Piggott in 1938 (their barrow 10). At the time, the mound (which had suffered considerable damage by burrowing rabbits) measured 55 feet in diameter and stood to a height of 4.3 feet above the natural chalk. The mound was surrounded by a ditch circa 2 feet deep. In the interior, just west of centre, was a square pit circa 3.8 feet across and 0.5 feet deep dug into the ground surface below the mound. According to the Piggotts, "this was filled with material largely derived from the surface and rabbit scrapes, but was undoubtedly an original feature". At the centre, below the mound and close to the square pit was another pit, this time circular, containing a large, upright and almost complete Deverel-Rimbury urn. Within the urn were cremated bones, and a thin layer of carbonized material which probably represented traces of a wooden cover.

Site_name_other: Launceston Down North Barrow Group (Tarrant Launceston nos. 19 a-f)
Site_summary: A group of at least five small barrows examined by J H Austen in 1864. The precise location of each barrow is not known, and they are no longer visible as earthworks. A cluster of urns containing cremations was found in 1938 and interpreted as part of a cremation cemetery around the barrows.<gg_summary>: Summarised in Piggott and Piggott 1944 (50-1) and Ginsell 1959 (Tarrant Launceston Barrows 19 a-f, 136). Five small barrows with primary MBA cremations excavated by Austen in 1864. Four of the five burials were associated with gg (in Barrows 2-5). A further three cremations (and an inverted urn not associated with hr) were located close to these barrows in the side of a WWI practice trench and excavated in 1938 (Piggott and Piggott 1944 (50-1))(represented specifically by HER record MDO5080).Since the location of the separate barrows is not known, the grave goods are attributed to the barrow group as a whole. Cremations from the urnfield MDO5080 are grouped within this record since a) MDO5080 is associated with no information beyond the event date b) the Piggotts suggest that these cremations were associated directly with the barrow group - specific locational details are not given.
Site_description: 'The Launceston Down North Group comprised a cluster of at least five small barrows located around 95451145, 220 ft. above O.D. on the southward-facing slope of a dry combe falling E. to the Crichel brook; all have now been levelled by cultivation, but each barrow was examined by J. H. Austen in 1864. One yielded nothing. Another yielded a cremation, probably secondary, in an urn now lost, together with 'the point of a bronze spear or dagger'. A third barrow yielded a primary cremation in a barrel urn of 'South Lodge' type, in a pit cut in the Chalk. A fourth barrow yielded a cremation, probably secondary, in a similar urn. A fifth barrow yielded a primary cremation in a pit, and two cremations, probably secondary, above it, one of the latter having a plain urn (C.T.D., Pt. 2, nos. 36-40; Ant. J., XIII (1933), 447; Arch. J., CXIX (1962), 20, 54, 55). In 1938 four more urns, not covered by barrows but apparently part of an urnfield, were found in the vicinity of the barrow group; three of them contained cremations, one with a fragment of a bronze spearhead (Arch., XC (1944), 50, 60, 61).' (1)

Site_summary: A bowl barrow described in 1970 as being around 70 feet in diameter with a mound about 2 feet high, and heavily ploughed. The mound is damaged, presumably by antiquarian investigation, and is thought to be one of two barrows opened by Baron Hambro and William Shipp in 1860.<gg summary>: Winterborne Stickland 2. One of the urns had zigzag decoration below the rim and may be reminiscent of Collared Urn traditions. Longworth records a 1ry series CU from Winterbourne Strickland (No 525) several urns noted in mound; all coarse and rudely made.
Site_description: 'Two round barrows, almost certainly those described below, were opened by Baron Hambro and William Shipp in 1860 (C.T.D., Pt. 2, Nos. 16 and 17; Hutchins I, 331). The first, probably (19), was 14 ft. high and was composed largely of flints; in the centre 'on a raised bed of clay' was a cremation under an inverted urn; a secondary deposit of three cremations in urns had been found a few years earlier in the N. side of the mound. The second barrow, probably (18), was 5 ft. high and was composed almost entirely of large tabular flints, most of which were removed. Fragments of pottery and charcoal were found, but no interment. . . . (19) ROWBARROW (82570667), bowl, lies 600 yds. N.W. of Hedge End Farm at 400 ft. above O.D. on an E-facing slope of the same spur as (18); it has been heavily ploughed. Diam. About 70 ft., ht. 2 ft.'

Site_summary: Approximate location of a barrow, destroyed when East Down House was built in 1908. This barrow was excavated by J C Mansel-Pleydell and contained a large 'bucket' urn in a central chalk cut cist and a broken secondary globular urn.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's Winterbourne Whitechurch Barrow 5 (East Down Plantation). Finds in Dorchester Museum. 3 barrows were destroyed during the construction of East Down House. Finds were recovered during this work but only one barrow was recorded in detail (represented by this record). Stray finds, probably from the other two and from elsewhere in the vicinity are logged in MDO5350 but none were certainly grave goods so these are not recorded here. Possible pyre remains on the mound itself.
Site_description: Three barrows (86320078, 86330080 and 86340077) close together in East Down Plantation were destroyed in 1908 when East Down House was built. The northernmost, 30 ft. in diam. and 8 ft. high, was dug by J. C. Mansel-Pleydell and was found to contain a primary cremation in a large 'bucket' urn set in a central chalk-cut cist; above it lay a broken secondary globular urn; the mound appears to have contained a low internal flint wall, within which were extensive traces of fire. No details are available for the other two barrows, but a small 'bucket' urn and fragments of a globular urn may have come from them (Dorset Procs. LXXIV 1952), 104-6; Ant.J. XIII (1933), 448).' [1]This barrow was excavated by J C Mansel-Pleydell and contained a large 'bucket' urn in a central chalk cut cist and a broken secondary globular urn.[2]

Site_summary: An urned cremation burial in an inverted cinerary urn was found in 1878 in a paddock adjoining Chalbury Rectory. Possibly the site of a round barrow.<gg_summary>: described as a 'LBA' urn in the NRHE record (recorded as MBA here). Not in Grinsell and no known refs. beyond Cunnington's notebooks in Dorchester Museum and an unnamed Press cutting dated 9.1.1878 in possession of Rev. T. Brewster. Holton.
Site_description: In January 1878 a workman digging gravel in a paddock adjoining the Rectory at Chalbury found a large cinerary urn which collapsed on touching. It appeared to have been an elliptically-shaped with a major axis of 12 inches and a minor axis of 9 inches, and a depth of 10 inches. The urn, inverted and full of bones and black earth, was resting on gravel 18 inches below the surface of the ground. Its rim was marked with slanting parallel lines 3 inches long and half-inch apart.(1)Possibly the site of a round barrow. (1)

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow, one of the Handley Hill Group, Gussage All Saints
Site_summary: Bowl barrow, probably the Berendes beorh of an Anglo Saxon charter that was concerned with the boundaries of Handley.<gg summary>: Large urn (probably Collared Urn) in circular cist with ashes and bone. No further detail. this is Grinsell Gussage All Saints barrow 12
Site_description: '(62) Bowl (01391626(, some 30 yds. N.E. of (61), is probably the Berendes beorh of an Anglo-Saxon charter concerned with the boundaries of Handley (Dorset Procs., 58 (1936), 116). Almost certainly it is the barrow opened by Cunnington, c. 1800, wherein at a considerable depth he found an urn covered with large quantities of ashes and charred wood, within a circular cist. It is 95 ft. in diameter and 9 ft. high.' (2)

Site_name_other: Long barrow on Thickthorn Down, Gussage St Michael
Site_summary: A long barrow situated on the crest of the ridge between the Gussage and Crichel valleys, close to the Dorset Cursus. In 1975 the monument was described as having a well-preserved mound nearly 100 feet long, 60 feet wide and 8 feet high, within a distinct U-shaped ditch. Excavations in 1933 discovered three burials in pits dug into the mound, interpreted as secondary burials.  Each consisted of an adult skeleton, one accompanied by a child, and all were thought to be females.<gg summary> When the barrow was excavated in 1933 no primary interment was found, but Windmill Hill ware occurred at a primary level in the ditch and Peterborough ware was found at a higher level. Also two chalk phalli (alleged but could be natural ) were also found. Three secondary interments, all apparently of females, were discovered. Two were accompanied by bell beakers (Clarke, type E) and one of those with a beaker was also accompanied by the remains of a young child. Finds are in the Dorset County Museum.The poorly preserved remains of one (possibly more than one individual) lacked grave goods

Excavation of a Ring Ditch at Down Farm, Gussage St Michael<gg_summary>: Neolithic double ring ditch (probably also a mound), re-cut and immediately backfilled in the MBA with flint, D/R pottery sherds, worked flint, and cremated human bone fragments (see rc dates BM 2177R and 2178R). A series of twenty shallow ?post holes was cut into and beyond the backfilled ring ditch (grave markers?). A flint cairn was also probably constructed at this time. MBA 13 cremation pits were excavated - one within, the others to the south of the ring ditch (Barrett et al 1991, fig 5.44). Five inhumation graves were located to the west of these - 4 crouched, one extended. Three of these inhumations formed a compact group with a post at the centre. All of the burials were badly truncated. However eight of the cremation burials and one of the inhumations were potentially associated with grave goods. The head of the extended inhumation was covered with flint nodules. These are not recorded as grave goods but represent a good example of borderline grave goods. Although the site is heavily truncated, the bucket urn sherds found in a pit without cremated bones are not recorded as gg (there are too many urn deposits not associated with hr in this region in the MBA). A bronze spiral ring from the base of the ploughsoil over the southern part of the ring ditch is also potentially a ploughed out grave good but given the absence of context is not recorded as such here.
Site_description: Ring-ditch, excavated, shallow pit near centre contained chalk rubble only, the circular area, defined by ditch, (i) crouched infant burial in small pit (ii) three crouched burials, probably male, female and adolescent, differently orientated, two were from the upper fill South terminal of the outer recut and the third (which had two shell beads) was just outside the ditch, a hole (for marker post?) was associated with this group, the latest recut contained beaker sherds, flintwork, and bone and seems to have been very soon backfilled, it was capped by a flint cairn-ring containing sherds of beaker and D/R wares, South East of the ring-ditch and impinging on it was a D/R cemetery of which 9 cremations (4 in urns whose tops had been removed by the plough) where identified as well as a decayed extended inhumation whose skull was covered with flint nodules, in the ditch was a crude ring of postholes, perhaps of D/R phase.

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Pond Barrow (this record) and Cremation Cemetery (see MDO5648 - not imported into the ggdb as the record provided no additional information).This is a very important pond barrow for so many reasons. There is a concentration of young individuals from here, particularly neonates and infants up to two years old. There is a mixture of both cremations and inhumations (sometimes in the same grave) with Food Vessels and Collared Urns and there is also Beaker pottery. The burials are focused in pits along the periphery of the pond barrow which is 19m in diameter with a primary concentration in the SE side in a very tight focus and a second focus along the N side. In addition there is a knapping cluster towards the centre of the barrow with several workable nodules. An unaccompanied Food Vessel was placed in a pit in the centre of the barrow. Of further interest is the presence of four animal burials (two sheep and two ox) . Both the sheep were placed in pits diametrically opposite each other inside the barrow on the N and S side respectively. The two cattle burials were in W and E sides of barrow but buried in large pits beyond the barrow. Green 2000: 99 <Around the northern and eastern periphery of the barrow, both inside and outside the dished area, burials were encountered. Eight cremations were found in total, five within – urns), containing the remains of eight adults and three infants. Three of these were placed in elaborate funnel shaped pits, one of which was accompanied by a bronze and two bone awls. In addition there were five infant inhumations ranging in age from near-natal to two years. Two of them were provided with Food Vessels and the two- year-old by a group of rounded flints, which were almost certainly playthings. Four animal burials were also recorded, two domestic cows placed some 5m from the eastern and western edges of the hollow respectively and two sheep, one badly disturbed by ploughing, on the northern and southern rim of the feature.>
Site_description: <NRHE site description>: A pond barrow near Down Farm and 35 metres north of the Dorset Cursus (Linear 41). The barrow was excavated in 1981-2. These revealed a shallow scooped circular feature circa 20 metres in diameter and up to 32 centimetres deep. It may originally have been surrounded by an external bank, possibly separated from the hollow by a berm. The "pond" appears to have cut through some pits containing Beaker sherds (see SU 01 SW 144. A setting of four postholes occurred near the centre of the pond barrow. One contained sherds of a Food Vessel, and charcoal produced a radiocarbon date of 1500+/-50 bc (uncalibrated). Towards the western edge of the hollow was a concentration of flints representing an episode of knapping. A small cluster of inhumation and cremation burials were situated within and beyond the eastern edge of the hollow, and leading away from them and in line with one of the centre posts and 3 of the cremations were 3 pits. According to the excavators, this line ran parallel with the axis of the cursus. However, this is not possible given the southwest-northeast orientation of the cursus and the apparent northwest-southeast orientation of this line of features. The burials discovered included urned and unurned cremations of both adults and infants, plus some infant inhumations. Associated pottery included Food Vessels and Colalred Urns, and a series of Early Bronze Age radiocarbon dates were obtained from associated charcoal. Other finds with the burials included bone and bronze awls. Four animal burials were found - two cows in pits just outside the pond barrow; and two sheep just inside the northern and southern edges of the hollow respectively. Other clusters of features, mainly pits and postholes, occurred outside the pond barrow. Many are of uncertain date, though animal bone from one produced an Iron Age radiocarbon date. Generally however the end of active use of the site is marked by the infilling with a ploughsoil associated with Deverel-Rimbury sherds.

Site_summary: Bowl Barrow with adjacent urnfield<gg_summary>: Grinsell's Hampreston Barrow 10 (1982, 41); White's Barrow B (1982, 5-7): Ring ditch c. 12m in diameter with SE-facing entrance and turf-built mound. Central 4-post motuary structure - burnt down but not associated with any cremated bone. Urnfield of over 100 urned cremations together with probable unurned pit cremations. Urned cremations were interred both in pits and in shallow scoops on the ground surface (with the upper part of the pot probably protruding). Given the acidic soil conditions, it is likely that some of the cremated human bone has perished. However it is complex to distinguish between perished bone and interments made without hr, consequently only gg directly associated with hr are recorded here. Potential case study for analysing 'cenotaph' burials since some gg were almost certainly interred without hr.NB all attributions of 'young adult' are placed within the subadult category here since where there is a suggested age in White (1982) it is 14+ ; Poss unurned cremation B92 is not recorded here; unburnt flints and pot sherds within urns currently not recorded as gg (bronze fragments are as the fragmentation may be post depositional); refitting sherds from a single globular urn were recovered from burials in Barrows B, F and G (B17 Barrow B; F69 Barrow F and G33 Barrow G); pots classified by shape only (not shape/deco as in White 1982 as this throws up too many in-betweeners).  Most of the rc dates from this site are probably erroneous so are not entered here. That from the centre of this barrow is probably ok so is included.
Site_description: 'Simon's Ground Group (36-40) comprises at least five barrows at the edge of a plateau, 100 ft. above O.D., overlooking lower ground to the S. Four barrows were excvated in 1967 and 1968 by Dr. D. A. White, to whom we are indebted for information which follows; (39) has not been excavated. Barrows formerly at about SU 06170005 and SZ 06379992 had been destroyed previously. (36) Bowl (06240001), a small mound about 2 ft. high, was surrounded by a penannular ditch 4 ft. wide and 2_ ft. deep, with the causeway on the S.E. Beneath it no burial was found, but much charcoal and a central setting of four post holes in a rectangle 3 ft. by 4_ ft., possibly the foundations of a mortuary house. An urnfield of about one hundred vessels lay immediately outside the ditch on the S.  {1}

Site_summary: A Barrow with adjacent urnfield<gg_summary>: Grinsell's Hampreston Barrow 11 (1982, 41); White's Barrow C (1982, 8-12): Ring ditch c. 10m in diameter with SE-facing entrance and turf-built mound. Central burnt pit and 4-post structure. Quantities of sandstone fragments were recovered from the ring ditch, focused around the ditch terminals. Central cremation burial (Burial C48). Urnfield of 47 cremations within three main clusters, together with probable unurned pit cremations. Given the acidic soil conditions, it is likely that some of the cremated human bone has perished. However it is complex to distinguish between perished bone and interments made without hr, consequently only gg directly associated with hr are recorded here. Potential case study for analysing 'cenotaph' burials since some gg were almost certainly interred without hr.NB all attributions of 'young adult' are placed within the subadult category here since where there is a suggested age in White (1982) it is 14+; pots classified by shape only (not shape/deco as in White 1982 as this throws up too many in-betweeners)
Site_description: 'Simon's Ground Group (36-40) comprises at least five barrows at the edge of a plateau, 100 ft. above O.D., overlooking lower ground to the S. Four barrows were excvated in 1967 and 1968 by Dr. D. A. White, to whom we are indebted for information which follows; (39) has not been excavated. Barrows formerly at about SU 06170005 and SZ 06379992 had been destroyed previously. (37) Bowl (06290000), 60 yds. E.S.E. of (36), was a low mound surrounded by a ditch, 38 ft. across overall, the ditch causewayed on the S.E. Three urns which predate the construction of the barrow were found under the W. edge of the mound. Immediately outside the S. sector of the ditch nearly fifty urns were found, mostly in three groups and including a single urn within the arc of a shallow ditch open towards the main barrow.' {1}

Site_summary: A Bowl Barrow with adjacent urnfield<gg_summary>: Grinsell's Hampreston Barrow 12 (1982, 41); White's Barrows E and F (1982, 12-15): Pair of ring ditches. Barrow E was c. 23m in diameter with a turf-built mound and had no internal features. Barrow F was c. 10m in diameter with SE-facing entrance and a turf-built mound. The primary urned cremation at the centre of the mound (F48) was capped with a sandstone slab. 16 secondary burials were cut into the mound; a further three were cut into the infilled ring ditch. Linear cemetery (orientated ENE-WSW) of 77 urned cremations together with 23 probable unurned pit cremations. White (1982) suggests that small chunks of sandstone were scattered along the length of the urnfield, marking the tops of the graves. The linear cemetery is thought to be later than Barrow E but earlier than Barrow F. Given the acidic soil conditions, it is likely that some of the cremated human bone has perished. However it is complex to distinguish between perished bone and interments made without hr, consequently only gg directly associated with hr are recorded here. Potential case study for analysing 'cenotaph' burials since some gg were almost certainly interred without hr.NB all attributions of 'young adult' are placed within the subadult category here since where there is a suggested age in White (1982) it is 14+; the excavation report describes the linear cemetery orientation as N-S but this is not supported by evidence from the plans; pots classified by shape only (not shape/deco as in White 1982 as this throws up too many in-betweeners)
Site_description: 'Simon's Ground Group (36-40) comprises at least five barrows at the edge of a plateau, 100 ft. above O.D., overlooking lower ground to the S. Four barrows were excvated in 1967 and 1968 by Dr. D. A. White, to whom we are indebted for information which follows; (39) has not been excavated. Barrows formerly at about SU 06170005 and SZ 06379992 had been destroyed previously. (38) Bowl (06429987), 200 yds. S.E. of (37), comprised a low mound within a penannular ditch, with the causeway on the S.E. and measuring 35 ft. across overall. At the centre was a cremation burial in an urn; outside the ditch on the S. was an urnfield. A linear urnfield extended from near the causeway N.E to barrow (39). About ninety urns were found.' {1}

Site_summary: A bowl barrow excavated by Dr D A White in 1967 and 1968. Excavations revealed this barrow to be a low mound beneath which was a central cremation burial in an inverted urn and, beside it, a rectangular setting of four stake-holes. The barrow was enclosed in a penannular ditch causewayed on the south east. To the south of the barrow was an urnfield containing forty vessels.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's Hampreston Barrow 14 (1982, 41); White's Barrow G (1982, 16-7): Primary burial G42. Fewer burial pits (no urns or hr) in this cemetery. Given the acidic soil conditions, it is likely that some of the cremated human bone has perished. However it is complex to distinguish between perished bone and interments made without hr, consequently only gg directly associated with hr are recorded here. Potential case study for analysing 'cenotaph' burials since some gg were almost certainly interred without hr.NB all attributions of 'young adult' are placed within the subadult category here since where there is a suggested age in White (1982) it is 14+; pots classified by shape only (not shape/deco as in White 1982 as this throws up too many in-betweeners). Most of the rc dates from this site are probably erroneous so are not entered here.
Site_description: 'Simon's Ground Group (36-40) comprises at least five barrows at the edge of a plateau, 100 ft. above O.D., overlooking lower ground to the S. Four barrows were excavated in 1967 and 1968 by Dr. D. A. White, to whom we are indebted for information which follows; (39) has not been excavated. Barrows formerly at about SU 06170005 and SZ 06379992 had been destroyed previously. (40) Bowl (06499985), 40 yds. S.E. of (39), was a low mound beneath which were found a central cremation burial in an inverted urn and, beside it , a rectangular setting of four stake-holes; a penannular ditch, causewayed on the S.E., encircled the barrow. Adjacent on the S. was an urnfield containing forty vessels.' (1)

Site_summary: Four cinerary urns found in ground disturbed by rabbits. This find is likely to represent the remains of a cremation cemetery.<gg_summary>: Cremation in badly broken urn with herringbone pattern. Sounds more EBA than MBA and likely CU
Site_description: 'Four Deverel-Rimbury urns have been found by H. Sharman when rabbiting at Hampreston near Dudsbury camp (SZ 07209815). As usual they are in a very fragmentary condition, but the best preserved is a late globular urn with a sharply incised girth grooves and chevron. It is almost identical with an urn from Hillbrow, Pokesdown, Hants.'

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: One of eighteen barrows excavated by the Piggotts in 1938 on Launceston Down/Long Crichel (Piggott and Piggott 1944 Barrow 8, 75-6) (Grinsell 1959 Long Crichel Barrow 21, 118).
Site_description: 'Four barrows form part of the Launceston Down South Group, the rest of which is in Tarrant Launceston (Dorset IV, 107). They were excavated in 1938 by S. and C. M. Piggott (Arch., XC (1944), 47-80). They are no longer visible on the ground and former dimensions etc. are given. (10) Bowl (95911054), covering a large pit, beside which was a primary cremation in a barrel urn with incised chevron decoration of Cornish type; diam. 45 ft., ht. 1 ft., with a shallow ditch (Piggott, 8.)' (1)

Site_name_other: Bowl Barrow, one of the Launceston South Down Group, Long Crichel
Site_summary: Bowl Barrow contains a primary cremation pit<gg_summary>: One of eighteen barrows excavated by the Piggotts in 1938 on Launceston Down/Long Crichel (Piggott and Piggott 1944 Barrow 7, 69) (Grinsell 1959 Long Crichel Barrow 20, 118).
Site_description: 'Four barrows form part of the Launceston Down South Group, the rest of which is in Tarrant Launceston (Dorset IV, 107). They were excavated in 1938 by S. and C. M. Piggott (Arch., XC (1944), 47-80). They are no longer visible on the ground and former dimensions etc. are given.   (11) Bowl (96011053), containing a primary cremation in a central pit, with sherds of a cinerary urn in the surrounding soil; diam. 18 ft., ht. less than 1 ft. (Piggott, 7.)' (1)

Site_name_other: Bowl Barrow, one of the Launceston South Down Group, Long Crichel
Site_summary: Bowl Barrow, held a primary crouched inhumation tightly bound and apparently placed there in a bag.<gg_summary>: One of eighteen barrows excavated by the Piggotts in 1938 on Launceston Down/Long Crichel (Piggott and Piggott 1944 Barrow 5, 68-9) (Grinsell 1959 Long Crichel Barrow 18, 118).
Site_description: 'Four barrows form part of the Launceston Down South Group, the rest of which is in Tarrant Launceston (Dorset IV, 107). They were excavated in 1938 by S. and C. M. Piggott (Arch., XC (1944), 47-80). They are no longer visible on the ground and former dimensions etc. are given.   (12) Bowl (96031066), covering a large oval grave in which was a primary crouched inhumation, tightly bound and apparently placed there in a bag. Any grave goods that may have existed had been removed by earlier diggers. Diam. 22 ft., ht. under 1 ft. (Piggot, 5.)' (1)

Site_summary: Bowl Barrow incorporated a cairn of flints over a central pit which contained a bucket urn.<gg_summary>: One of eighteen barrows excavated by the Piggotts in 1938 on Launceston Down/Long Crichel (Piggott and Piggott 1944 Barrow 3, 66-7) (Grinsell 1959 Long Crichel Barrow 16, 118).
Site_description: 'Three barrows lie on the S.E. slope of a spur overlooking the Crichel valley. Excavated in 1938 by S. and C.M. Piggot (op. cit.), they have since been levelled by ploughing   (15) Bowl (96181111), incorporating a cairn of flints over a central pit which contained a bucket urn (Arch. J., CXIX (1962), 63) and a smaller accessory vessel; both were covered by a slab of Purbeck limestone; diam. 30 ft., ht. about 1 ft. (Piggott, 3.)' (1)

Site_summary: Bowl Barrow, held a primary cremation burial.<gg_summary>: One of eighteen barrows excavated by the Piggotts in 1938 on Launceston Down/Long Crichel (Piggott and Piggott 1944 Barrow 1, 63-4) (Grinsell's (1959, 118) Long Crichel Barrow 14).
Site_description: 'Three barrows lie on the S.E. slope of a spur overlooking the Crichel valley. Excavated in 1938 by S. and C.M. Piggot (op. cit.), they have since been levelled by ploughing    (16) Bowl (96241109), covering a central pit which contained the remains of a primary cremation burial associated with fragments of a bucket urn 'burnt after breaking'. Above the pit was a second cremation in a bucket urn (see also Arch. J., CXIX (1962), 63). Diam. 22 ft., ht. under 1 ft. (see Piggott, I).' (1)

Site_summary: A bowl barrow recorded as being a mound around 60 feet in diameter and three feet high. This barrow was excavated by S and C M Piggott in the 1930s, revealing two concentric ditches, one entirely under the mound, interpreted as at least two phases of construction.<gg_summary>: One of eighteen barrows excavated by the Piggotts in 1938 on Launceston Down/Long Crichel (Piggott and Piggott 1944 Barrow 11, 73-4) (Grinsell 1959 Long Crichel Barrow 23, 119).Inhumation of male with Beaker pot sherds scattered  about in gave fill and joint of pork at the feet
Site_description: 'Seven barrows are scattered on the W. side of the Crichel valley, W. of Veiny Cheese Pond; they lie at about 200 ft. above O.D., mostly on a gentlre S.E. slope. All have been damaged or levelled by ploughing and three of them (18-20) have been completely removed by excavation. Two barrows ((17) and (18)) lie close to  a linear dyke (Tarrant Launceston (16), Dorset IV, 106), and appear to have determined its alignment at the E. end.   (18) Bowl (96171149), excavated by S. and C. M. Piggott in 1938 (op. cit.), comprised a mound about 60 ft. across and 3 ft. high, associated with two concentric ditches; the latter suggest two structural phases. The inner ditch, which was deeper and more carefully cut than the outer, measured 52 ft. across overall and lay entirely under the mound; it had cut an earlier pit containing fragments of several beakers. The outer ditch lay no more than 5 ft. outside it and measured about 72 ft. across overall. A grave shaft at the centre of the barrow was cut nearly 9 ft. into the chalk and contained a primary crouched inhumation associated with pig bones. A quantity of beaker sherds was found scattered throughout the mound (Piggott, 11).' (1)

Site_name_other: Bell Barrow west of Veiny Cheese Pond, Long Crichel
Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Grinsell's (1959, 118) Long Crichel barrow 7, excavated by Green in 1959, published by Green et al (1983). Complex burial sequence comprising:Phase 1, burials 1-2: Large oval grave pit containing two tightly contracted inhumation burials and the disarticulated bones of an adult man.hr1: a woman, contracted, on her right side, bound with a leather/rawhide thong, head ENE. Squatting facets, tooth abcesshr2: a child, aged 4, on left side, head ENE, completehr3: some adult male bonesgg (hr1): a leather/rawhide thonggg (hr2): Close to the face and parallel with the body lay a thin wooden stickPhase 2, burial 3: Large grave pit dug through the primary mound and into the top of the phase 1 grave. Contained the contracted body of an adult with a flint blade, a small-eyed bone pin and a long curved wooden object. The body was enclosed by two lines of flints and covered with separate layers of chalk rubble and large flints.hr: an adult male, 36+, complete, contracted, on on right side, head SSE, worn teethgg: a flint blade (by the face); a small-eyed bone pin (amongst the bones - torso?); a long curved wooden object (alongside body, potentially a bow); grave liner - two lines of flintsPhase 3, burial 4: Small grave pit, dug within a larger pit into which was placed a plain collared urn containing the cremated remains of a young adult woman. The pit was filled with a compact mass of flints.Phase 3, burial 5: Small pit dug into the SE edge of the barrow mound containing an urned cremation burial. The cremated remains of a man were contained within an inverted collared urn. Fragments of two other, similar urns were placed around this interment.Phase 4, burials 6-10: at least five later urned cremation burials in transitional biconical/DR urns. In only two cases were direct associations between hr and gg noted (recorded here, burials 6 and 8).Burial 6: juvenille, fragments, accompanied by the base of a transitional biconical/DR urn (fingertip decoration?)Burial 7: sub-adult, partial representation, unaccompaniedBurial 8: young male, most body parts represented,  accompanied by a handled (v unusual) transitional biconical/DR urnBurial 9: no bone
Site_description: Excavated by C Green 1959 _ 1960. Small central mound contained primary crouched inhumation tightly bound with thongs. Above this was a secondary adult female inhumation accompanied by a child. The barrow had been enlarged and in the added portion were several cremations with urns of various types and also three pagan Saxon intrusive inhumations

Site_summary: Round Barrow with some middle to late Bronze Age artifacts<gg_summary>: probably the barrow represented by HOBUID_209475 (identical grid ref. and date of investigation): The description of the urn suggests that it is EBA in date.EBA Collared Urn that contained cremation of a female
Site_description: <NRHE site description>: A hybrid Middle/Late Bronze Age (sic Early Bronze Age) Collared urn with cremation found when making a road near Old Lawn Farm Buildings circa 1948. In the possession of W. Lovell, Wimborne. (1)Mr. Lovell (a) pointed out the findspot of the urn at ST 9840 0468 and stated that he had presented it to Red House Museum, Christchurch. (2)Middle /Late Bronze Age (sic Early)  Collared Urn with incised chevron pattern on the collar and a ridged shoulder highlighted with neatly impressed ovals. Found at Old Lawn Farm, circa 1948, during trenching (near ST 984047), on a slight rise which suggested a ploughed-out barrow. Part of the urn is at the Pitt-Rivers Museum, Farnham. (3)

Site_name_other: Bronze Age burial on Handley Down, Sixpenny Handley
Site_summary: A burial found during excavations by Pitt-Rivers, and described as having no obvious surface marker. A circular grave around 6 feet in diameter contained  a skeleton in a crouched position with a beaker pot decorated with fingernail impressions
Site_description: '(28) Beaker Burial (01201723), on Handley Down, 150 ft. S.W. of Wor Barrow (29), was found by Pitt-Rivers in the course of his examination of the Angle Ditch. A circular grave 6 ft. in diameter and 2_ ft. deep, unmarked by any obvious surface feature, contained a crouched inhumation accompanied by a fingernail-rusticated (Clarke, type FN) beaker. (Pitt-Rivers, Excavations IV (1898), 60, 114; D. L. Clarke, Beaker Pottery of Great Britain (1970), 479, No. 191).' (1)

Site_summary: <gg summary>: A long barrow excavated by General Pitt-Rivers in 1893-4.  Before excavation the barrow was a mound 150 feet long, 75 feet wide and 12 feet high. Removal of the mound revealed a rectangular enclosure with an entrance at one end, formed by a ditch packed with flint into which was set timber posts. Six burials lay beneath a shallow turf mound inside the enclosure. Two more Neolithic burials were placed within the ditch, and seventeen Romano-British burials were found in the mound and ditch. After excavation the barrow was re-formed into an amphitheatre for public events.Note many more new 14C dates to help with the sequence Leaf arrowhead etc
Site_description: <summary> Phase 1: burial (Fig 5a):a) mortuary enclosure construction;b) the burial of six Neolithic inhumations (primary Burials 1–6) within awooden mortuary box or chamber set within a post-built mortuaryenclosure/building. These were in various states of articulation/ diasarticulation. Phase 2: sealing the burialsPhase 3: the first moundPhase 4: the ‘enlarged’ mound Phase 5: the second Neolithic interment phase. The insertion of two further Neolithic crouched inhumations in the primary fillsof the ditch (secondary Burials adult 8 and child 9)

Site_summary: A barrow close to the edge of the Iron Age/Romano-British settlement on Gussage Hill. The barrow is reported as around 30 feet in diameter with a mound about 1_ feet high, having been much reduced by ploughing. Excavations in 1969 showed that the mound covered the remains of a cremation pyre with fragments of human bone and pottery of late Iron Age or early Romano-British type, and a flint scatter. The mound lay inside a ditch enclosing an area that was almost square with sides about 50 feet long.<gg_summary>: small square barrow associated with a scatter of cremated remains, probably representing a pyre, and sherds from a LIA/early RB bowl. The presence of a pre-barrow flint scatter and Beaker sherd could suggest that there was an earlier barrow on the site. The evidence was also disturbed considerably by antiquarian explorations.
Site_description: '(30) Barrow, probably Iron Age (98901443), on the N. Slope of Gussage Hill, was removed by excavation in 1969. It lay immediately adjacent to the boundary dyke of the Iron Age and Romano-British Settlement, Gussage St Michael (7). The mound, originally about 30 ft. in diameter, had been dug into in the past and was reduced by ploughing to 1_ ft. in height. It covered the remains of a cremation pyre among which were fragments of human bone and sherds of a pot of late Iron Age or early Romano-British type. A flint scatter was also found. The mound lay within a ditch, 4 ft. to 6 ft. wide and 2 ft. deep, almost square in plan with sides about 50 ft. in length. The S. side was parallel to and probably later than the boundary dyke (Ant. J., L (1970), 26-36).' (1)

Site_name_other: Barrow in the Thorney Down Farm Group, Sixpenny Handley
Site_summary: Barrow excavated by Pitt-Rivers in 1898, primary cremation with bone needle, burnt flint flakes, and burnt flint knife, beneath inverted Early/Middle Bronze Age collared urn in central cist, three intrusive contracted skeletons (Romano-British?) in upper levels of ditch silting<gg summary>: this is Grinsell Handley Barrow 29. 1ry burial is 1ry Collared Urn inverted over a  series of grave and pyre goods
Site_description: '(31) Bowl (99891533), was excavated by Pitt-Rivers (Excavations IV (1898), 172-81). The mound, 70 ft. in diameter and 2_ ft. high, covered a central cist in which was found a primary cremation, with a bone needle, a burnt flint knife and flakes, in an inverted collared urn (P.P.S., XXVII (1961), 294). In its upper levels the encircling ditch contained Romano-British pottery and three intrusive burials, probably of the same period.' (1)

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow on Wyke Down, Sixpenny Handley
Site_summary: A bowl barrow reported as being around 50 feet in diameter with a mound around one foot high. Excavations by Pitt-Rivers showed that the mound covered three pits containing cremation burials, two of them in collared urns.<gg summary>: This is Wyke Down 28 (Grinsell). Beneath the mound were three cremations deposits, none located centrally. One comprised an inverted collared urn over a deposit of cremated bone, placed within a pit dug into the chalk. Another pit contained a deposit of unaccompanied cremated bone. Cut into the base of this pit was another, deeper pit containing an upright collared urn, within which was a further deposit of cremated bone.
Site_description: '(35) Bowl (00461585), on the W. slope of Wyke Down, immediately S. of the Salisbury-Blandford road, was excavated by Pitt-Rivers (Excavations IV (1898), 172-81). The mound, about 50 ft. in diameter and 1 ft. high, covered three cremations in pits, none centrally placed, but all apparently primary; two were in collared urns, one of the late Neolithic or earlier Bronze Age type (P.P.S., XXVII (1961), 294); the third had no associated finds. The surrounding ditch contained fragments of comparable pottery in the lower filling, and Romano-British pottery in the upper levels.' (1)

Site_summary: A bowl barrow reported as being around 50 feet in diameter with a mound around 2 feet high. Excavations by Pitt-Rivers revealed that the barrow covered a central pit containing a cremation, and that two later cremations in urns had been inserted into the mound.<gg summary>: This is Handley Barrow 23. Note there was a number of Beaker sherds recovered from the barrow ditch. Near another barrow (24). Flat barrowsCentral primary unurned cremation and 2 secondary urned cremations. Just N of centre was a crouched inhumation with a bronze awl at the head
Site_description: (36) Bowl (01021653), about 50 ft. in diameter within the ditch and 2 ft. high, covered a cremation, probably primary, in a central pit and two secondary cremations in collared urns. A secondary, crouched, inhumation with a bronze awl was also found. (Pitt-Rivers, Excavations IV (1898), 144-7.)  (1)

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: bowl barrow and associated cremation cemetery (at least 50 urned cremations, mostly of MBA date) excavated by Pitt Rivers. The cremation cemetery is recorded separately in the HER (MDO6086) but the record includes no further information.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's Handley Barrow 24. Material from the cremation cemetery at this barrow is reassessed in Barrett et al. 1991 (see esp. table 5.8, 218 for a summary of burials and gg). They interpret it as a potentially late E/MBA (relatively small) barrow defined by a penannular ring ditch, facing south-east. 52 cremation pits were excavated, mostly beyond the outer lip of the ditch. The amount of bone in each cremation varied from 0.5g to 1085g and most of the fragments were small. The burials can be summarised as follows:1) No pottery associated: 4 burials (Barrett et al 1991 nos. 1, 28, 36[6?], 41) (not recorded here)2) Associated with pottery assemblage: 10 burials (Barrett et al 1991 nos. 2-5, 7, 13, 31, 47, 51-2) 3) Associated with two pottery vessels: 4 burials (Barrett et al 1991 nos. 9, 18, 22, 49)4) Associated with urn sherds: 8 burials (Barrett et al 1991 nos.11, 19-20, 24-5, 34, 44, 50)5) Associated with complete urns: 25 burials (2 inverted, 18 upright, 5 not specified)6) Pottery deposited with no human remains: 15 examples (not recorded here)
Site_description: (37) Bowl barrow and Urnfield (00991655), 50 yds. N.W. of (36), comprised a low mound about 23 ft. across surrounded by a small penannular ditch with a causeway on the S.W. side. Beneath the mound were three pits, two interpreted as unoccupied graves. Immediately S.W. of the barrow some fifty-two cremations were discovered, nearly all in urns. Barrel urns were most common, but a few globular urns and one collared urn were also present. (Pitt-Rivers, Excavations IV (1898), 147-57; Arch. J., CXIX (1962), 54-56.)  (1)<NRHE site description>: A  bowl barrow on Handley Hill, listed by RCHME as Sixpenny Handley 37 and by Grinsell as Handley 24. Described by RCHME as a low mound circa 23 feet across surrounded by a small penannular ditch with a causeway on the south west side, it was excavated by Pitt Rivers in 1893. Beneath the mound were 3 hollows cut into the chalk. Pitt Rivers regarded two of them as empty graves. Their fillcontained a single small ox bone and a sherd of pottery. 8 further "coarse" sherds were found immediately above one of these features. Their date is unclear. They may be of Bronze Age date. However, a sherd of Neolithic Mortlake Ware was also found on the chalk surface beneath the mound. Subsequently the mound was the focus of a cremation cemetery. Burials - more than 50 in all - may have begun in the Early Bronze Age, judging by the presence of one associated with bone tweezers and covered by an inverted collared urn. The ovewhelming majority of asociations were, however, with Deverel-Rimbury vessels. One was also associated with fragments of twisted bronze. Unburnt animal bones were present in six of the cremations. Most of the cremations were deposited outside the ditch to the west, while a smaller number were scattered to the south and east. During John Barrett and Richard Bradley's research programme focused on Cranborne Chase, the site was re-examined and the sequence and structure of burial activity analysed. In the process a series of radiocarbon dates were obtained on surviving charcoal samples from Pitt Rivers excavations. However, all dates were obtained during a period when the British Museum's radiocarbon dating results incorporated a systematic error. Only one sample was subsequenely available for re-dating, some charcoal from one of the cremations deposits. The date obtained simply confirms the Middle Bronze Age date of the cremation deposit.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: This is Grinsell's Barrow Handley 26, S of Wor barrow. 1ry burial of crouched male with shale or jet slider at hipThis could be a burial that dates to either Beaker or early phase of the Early Bronze Age ; jet slider
Site_description: Primary crouched (male?) interment with wooden or shale slider near hip

Site_name_other: Bowl Barrow, one of the Scrubbity Barrows, Sixpenny Handley
Site_summary: A bowl barrow recorded as being around 32 feet in diameter, with a mound four feet high. This barrow was excavated by Pitt-Rivers, who found a crouched burial inside a boat-shaped tree-trunk coffin.<gg summary>: This is Grinsell Scrubbity Barrows 1. Grinsell says it is a primary cremation. as indeed does Pitt-Rivers, not inhumation. Well-made large boat-shaped oak coffin. Flint knife and an incompletely finished flint axe with it,  and 595 flint flakes in the mound (that is a lot!) and 4 worn pebbles also in mound Coffin large enough to hold an inhumation so why cremation?
Site_description: Twenty-seven round barrows, several damaged or levelled by ploughing, have been recorded in the parish. Many have been excavated, most of them by General Pitt-Rivers, but very few completely. Pitt-Rivers reconstituted the barrows which he dug.   Scrubbity Barrows (43-50), a group of eight, lie on the S.W. slope of a dry valley in woodland between Woodcutts Common and Handley Common; all were excavated, but most only partially, by Pitt-Rivers (Excavations II (1888), 3-5, 32-44).   (43) Bowl (97251788), (Pitt-Rivers ix) contained a primary crouched cremation in a boat-shaped tree-trunk coffin. A flint knife and axe and hundreds of flint flakes were found in the mound. Diam. 52 ft., ht. 4 ft.  (1)

Site_name_other: Bowl Barrow one of the Scrubbity Barrows, Sixpenny Handley
Site_summary: A bowl barrow reported as being 28 feet in diameter with a mound less than one foot high. <gg summary>: This is GHrinsell Scrubbity Barrow /Handley 6.  Excavations by Pitt-Rivers revealed that the mound covered a centrally-placed burial consisting of a cremation in a collared urn. Upright urn also contained a number of flint chips covering cremated remains - deliberate cover/ protection or weighing down. This practice noted at other barrows - eg Winklebury Camp In mound - 13 flint cores in mound material ; also 303 flint flakes in mound material

Site_name_other: Bowl Barrow one of the Scrubbity Barrows, Sixpenny Handley
Site_summary: A bowl barrow excavated by Pitt-Rivers who found that the mound covered an inverted collared urn and a long pit, possibly an unused grave. In 1975 the barrow was described as an earthwork around 37 feet in diameter with a mound 2 feet high.<gg summary>: This is Handley 8 (Grinsell). In inverted Collared Urn. P-R barrow XVI. Note: Over 200 flints, mostly flakes and cores, were found in the moundThere was another grave-shaped feature nearby but it was empty. Holes in close proximity to an interment have been frequently found in barrows of the bronze age, and it has been suggested that they were made for the insertion of food, but their use is enigmatical. Depressions resembling a grave with nothing in them were found in other barrows.

A Bronze Age bowl barrow on the flood plain of the River Stour, which survives as a substantial earthwork. In 1975 this monument was recorded as around 90 feet in diameter with a mound 6 feet high, surrounded by a ditch.  There is a depression in the top, the result of part excavation carried out in 1838 by the Reverend Woolls, who found a primary cremation burial with an amber bead and possibly some secondary burials.The record for this monument has been enhanced with support from Wessex Water.<gg summary>: This is Grinsell's (1959, 132) Sturminster Marshall Barrow 1. Secondary burials may be M-LBA in date (but no gg)
Site_description: A bowl barrow 550m north east of Field Dairy Farm, on the flood plain of the River Stour 110m south of the south bank of the river. The barrow has a mound which is 30m in diameter and a maximum of 1.8m high. The top of the mound is flattened and there is a clear depression c.2m wide running from the south eastern side of the mound to its centre. The eastern side of the mound is also very uneven and both areas of disturbance probably resulted from the part  excavation carried out in 1838 by Revd Woolls. These located a primary cremation and other burnt material together with an amber bead and possibly some secondary interments. Surrounding the mound is a quarry ditch from which material was excavated during its construction. This has become infilled over the years but survives as a buried feature 3m wide.<summary>: s the Rev. Charles Wools, the then curate of Sturminster Marshall. Wools wrote that "the examination of the Barrow was continued for Eight Days with an indomitable spirit of perseverance." Work had to stop when they dug below the level of the river and the trench began to flood. A possible Bronze age cremation burial was found.Woolls wrote up the dig in a book called "The Barrow Diggers; a Dialogue in Imitation of the Grave Diggers in Hamlet"

Site_summary: A bowl barrow situated on a low spur. In 1975 this monument was reported as being an earthwork around 32 feet in diameter with a mound about 3 feet high. Antiquarian investigation in 1828 by T W Wake Smart revealed a cremation under an upturned barrel urn.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's (1959) Verwood Barrow 1: Probable primary cremation beneath inverted urn with fingertip decoration and with two repair-holes in side. Probably [MBA] The urn was covered with a slab of sandstone. Warne's Celtic Tumuli of Dorset (cpf) no. 18

A bowl barrow recorded as being around 75 feet in diameter with a mound about six feet high. Excavations in 1935 revealed that this barrow had been built in  two main phases. The first mound was about 45 feet in diameter and composed mostly of turfs, and covered a grave which once held a crouched inhumation. The mound was later enlarged, had a ditch cut around it and a cremation under a pottery urn was placed in it. This barrow was destroyed by development. It was formerly scheduled M95e.<gg summary>: Hampreston 9, Dudsbury barrow. . 1ry crouched inhumation in coffin. 2ndary cremation in enlarged Food Vessel/ transitional Collared Urn.

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow, Handley Hill, North East of
Site_summary: A round barrow of a type known as a bowl barrow. In 1975 this monument was reported as being about fifteen metres in diameter and just around one and a half metres high. The monument has been much reduced by ploughing. The antiquarian William Cunnington explored this barrow, and found two fragmentary urns, which were interpreted as the remains of a primary and secondary burial. Two skeletons, intrusive later burials, were also found.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's Handley Barrow 22 (North East of Berendes Beorh)
Site_description: '(88) Bowl (01411628), on the parish boundaries with Gussage All Saints and Sixpenny Handley; diam. 50 ft., ht. 5 ft. Excavation by William Cunnington yielded a cremation in a large 'barrel' urn, probably primary, accompanied by a smaller urn; both were fragmentary. Two intrusive skeletons were also found (Hoare, Ancient Wiltshire I, 243. Ant. J., XIII (1933), 448).' (1)

Site_name_other: Bell barrow on Bottlebush Down, Wimborne St Giles
Site_summary: A round barrow of a type known as a bell barrow. In 1975 this monument was reported as having a mound of about twenty one metres in diameter and about one and a half metres high, surrounded by a flat area (berm) about three metres wide with a four-metre wide ditch around the outside. The monument was dug into by the antiquarian William Cunnington, who found a primary cremation in a large urn, and beads of amber, shale and horn, fragments of a bronze pin, and an incense cup.<gg summary>: Grinsell's Wimborne St Giles 33a, also known as Bottlebrush Down.Large urn of uncertain type containing a cremation, amber beads, bronze dress pin and a incense cup.
Site_description: '(91) Bell (01911645), partly damaged by ploughing, yielded a primary cremation in a large urn, with beads of amber, shale and 'horn', fragments of a bronze (Unetice) pin, and an incense cup. The mound is 68 ft. across and 9 ft. high; the berm is 10 ft. across; the ditch is 12 ft.-18 ft. across and 1 ft. deep.' (1)

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow, one of the Oakley Down Group, Wimborne St Giles
Site_summary: A round barrow of a type known as a bowl barrow. This monument was reported in 1975 as being approximately twelve metres in diameter, and around half a metre high. The mound was dug into by the antiquarian William Cunnington, who found a central cremation in an up-turned collared urn. More recent excavations on the edge of the mound  revealed a post hole, which the excavators interpreted as a support for a cremation pyre. They also found a pit nearby, which contained large quantities of cremated bone and ash; this pit was outside and earlier than the ditch around the barrow.<gg summary>: THis is Grinsell's (1959) Wimborne St Giles 23
Site_description: Primary cremation in coarse inverted urn. <1>Collared Urn

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow, one of the Oakley Down Group, Wimborne St Giles
Site_summary: A round barrow of a type known as a bowl barrow. This monument was reported in 1975 as being approximately twelve metres in diameter, and less than half a metre high. The mound was dug into by the antiquarian Richard Colt Hoare; he found that it had already been disturbed, but recovered the remains of a primary cremation burial with charcoal and pottery.<gg summary>: Wimborne St Giles G21: Bowl barrow with primary cremation in a broken urn and linen cloth (like hair) with a 'round pin and an arrowhead of bone', and a grooved bronze dagger with part of wooden handle.
Site_description: Primary cremation with charcoal and potsherds in cist. Previously disturbed. Urn sherds found after ploughing. <1>

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow, one of the Oakley Down Group, Wimborne St Gile
Site_summary: A round barrow of a type known as a bowl barrow. This monument was reported in 1975 as being approximately seventeen metres in diameter, and just under two metres high. The mound was dug into by the antiquarian Richard Colt Hoare; he found a primary cremation burial with traces of cloth and the remains of an urn, a bronze dagger, a bone pin and a bone pendant.<gg summary>: This is Wimborne St Giles 20; linen bag shows micro-traditions with SID_20176 where the cremation was also wrapped in a linen cloth/ bag
Site_description: Primary cremation with broken urn and decayed linen cloth, grooved bronze dagger with part of wooden handle and a  round pin and an arrowhead of bone . Sherd of collared urn found on west side in 1968, two urns, one upright, found in west side in 1977. (1)

Site_summary: A round barrow of a type known as a bowl barrow. In 1975 this monument was reported as being around twenty two metres in diameter and two metres high. The mound was dug into by the antiquarian Richard Colt Hoare, who found a primary crouched burial with piece of deer antler with a hole made through it. More recent excavations found two secondary cremation burials in urns, and the remains of an inhumation burial just below the surface of the mound.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's (1959) Wimbourne St Giles Barrow 18.
Site_description: Primary crouched interment, head to NE with perforated antler. Two secondary Cremations in Late Bronze Age urns lying on their sides with a large layer of flints over one were found just below the surface in 1941, and nearby in 1949 an apparently unaccompanied inhumation of a young person. (1)'(98) Bowl (01761704), (Hoare No. 18) yielded a primary crouched interment associated with a perforated deer antler (Devizes Mus. Cat. 1896, No. 198).More recently, two secondary cremations in urns and an unaccompanied inhumation have been found just below the surface of the mound (Dorset Procs., 72 (1950), 92). Diam. 70 ft., ht. 7 ft.' (2)DHER record card lists DoE file ref AA 60860/1, received 16/02/54

Site_name_other: Mound, perhaps three small bowl barrows, part of the Oakley Down Group, Wimborne St Giles
Site_summary: An elongated mound, perhaps three small bowl barrows very close together. In 1975 the mound was reported as measuring approximately twenty nine metres by twelve metres, and just over one metre high. The mound was dug into by the antiquarian Richard Colt Hoare, who found three cremations: one in a cist, one in an urn with an amber bead, and one with a pair of bone tweezers in a large urn.<gg summary>: This is Wimborne St Giles 22. Initially thought by Colt Hoare to be a small long barrow but more likely three continguous small bowl barrows. The types of urns are not classified (and not listed by Longworth as Collared Urns) but likely of E-MBA in date. One cremation was unurned and lacked grave goods
Site_description: Probably three confluent small bowl barrows. Three primary cremations, 22a in cist with ashes only, 22b with large urn and bone tweezers, 22c with single amber bead in urn. <1>

Site_name_other: Bowl Barrow, Oakley Down Group, Wimborne St Giles
Site_summary: <gg summary>: this is Wimborne St Giles 19. Colt-Hoare (Anc. Wilts: 242) described the pins as 2 very small arrowheads
Site_description: Primary cremation with two perforated bone pins in cist.

Site_name_other: Disc Barrow, Oakley Down Group, Wimborne St Giles
Site_summary: <gg summary> This is Wimborne St Giles 17. Note the Collared urn has 11 perforations on the rim perhaps to tie on and to secure the linen wrapping or a cover. The Collared Urn is also unusual and highly decorated - very globular/ pot bellied in form Note micro-tradition with SID_20172 (W St Giles 20) where the cremation was also wrapped in a linen cloth
Site_description: Primary cremation wrapped in (linen?) cloth beneath very large inverted Early or Middle Bronze Age collared urn in chalk cist surrounded by a large quantity of ashes. The urn has eleven holes beneath the rim, evidently for tying on a cloth cover.

Site_name_other: Disc Barrow, one of the Oakley Down Group, Wimborne St Giles
Site_summary: <gg summary>: This si Wimborne Barrow 13 a double or bilobate barrow This had previously been disturbed but a cremation in a pit with amber button/bead was recovered by Colt-Hoare
Site_description: Two tumps, one central. In one tump primary cremation inferred with V bored amber bead made from a broken globular bead.

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Grinsell's (1959) Wimbourne St Giles Barrow 14. Of the three excavated burials and one stray find, only the cremation under an inverted urn (with cow bone) is recorded here (others are lacking either hr or objects)The inverted urn is not identified in further detail (not listed in Longworth's Collared Urns) b.However the MBA Bucket urn with raised cordoned decoration around shoulder is listed and recorded by Pitt-Rivers (1898: fig 305, 4) but this lacked cremation?
Site_description: Three cists were found. One contained a cremation and charcoal, another contained a cremation under an inverted urn, above which was the jawbone of a cow, the third contained only ashes.  Late Bronze Age banded bucket urn found in fox hole in this barrow 1898 or earlier.

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow, one of the Oakley Down Group, Wimborne St Giles
Site_summary: <gg summary>: This is Wimborne St Giles 10a-c. It may be three small conjoined barrows. Colt-Hoare (1812: 241) suggests that this gave the impression of a long barrow. There were three ?primary cremations but only one was associated with an Incense cup (very elegant)
Site_description: Perhaps three conjoined small round barrows. Three primary cremations one,in the centre, with biconical incense cup.DHER record card lists DoE file ref AA 60868/1, received 16/02/54

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow, one of the Oakley Down Group, Wimborne St Giles
Site_summary: <gg summary>: This is Wimborne St Giles 91ry male inhumation, well-adorned with grave goods and Beaker at feet (Colt-Hoare says broken at the feet of this British hero; 1812, 239). dagger at sideTwo later 2ndary inhumations placed on top of flint cairn overlying 1ry burial one with Beaker at head. Breton type arrowheads Note that rammed into flint cairn was half a stone axe (broken) and also deer antlers. Deliberate deposit or discarded after building the primary cairn?
Site_description: Primary crouched interment NE _ SW with flat four riveted gilt bronze dagger, remains of it wooden scabbard, jet or shale ornaments, four barbed and tanged arrowheads, bronze awl and remains of  drinking cup .  Among the flints of the large cairn covering this cremation were pieces of antlers and the cutting edge of a stone axe. Near top of barrow were two secondary inhumations placed NE _ SW, the uppermost skeleton with two cups of coarse workmanship Early Bronze Age? Near the feet of this skeleton was a cremation.<summary>: Interesting aside - the excavation was also notable for a "tremendous storm of thunder and lightning", during which all present were forced to hide within the barrow until the flint cairn began to collapse on them. The incident was recalled in a truly dreadful poem by the Rev. W Bowles, one of those present, which Hoare chose to publish alongside his account of the excavation.

Site_name_other: Disc Barrow, Oakley Down Group, Wimborne St Giles
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Grinsell's Wimborne St Giles 8. (also known as Woodyates 8/ Oakley Down)1ry cremation in Western barrow with amber necklace, bronze awl and small bronze dagger. This is a bilobate/ twin barrow and In E tump another 1ry cremation with beads of amber, faience and a bronze awl, with Aldbourne cup (4 footed or polypod)
Site_description: Oval twin cut across by Ackling Dyke Roman Road. West tump contained primary cremation with c 100 amber beads and some space plates of necklace, bronze awl and bronze dagger. East tump contained primary cremation with beads of amber and faience bronze awl and Aldbourne cup.

Site_name_other: Disc Barrow, Oakley Down Group, Wimborne St Giles
Site_summary: <gg summary>: This is Wimborne St Giles Barrow 7; bilobate barrow Cremation with amber beads, Disc barrow
Site_description: Two tumps, one in centre the other to W. cremation with amber beads from one mound

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Grinsell's (1959) Wimbourne St Giles Barrow 24. Five/six prehistoric burials (six including deposit of unburnt bones), four with gg.
Site_description: Primary deposit of two cremations in pits below primary mound (one with flat tanged bronze awl and stone or pottery bead) above this was a (ritual?) deposit of unburnt human bones. Three secondary cremations beneath inverted Late Bronze Age urns. Intrusive cremation probably Romano-British with sherd of New Forest ware and a coin of Valentinian I in filling. Five segmented glass beads, probably Belgic, found in the secondary mound and a mass of Roman pottery in an adjacent field bank cutting into the barrow ditch on the NE. (1)

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow, Oakley Down Group, Wimborne St Giles
Site_summary: <gg summary>: this si Wimborne St Giles 2There were two unaccompanied crouched inhumations - one 1ry and adult and one 2ry and of an infant. Sandwiched between these was a cremation with bone beads Infant very young child contracted lying N-S at depth of 1.2m below surface Adult - 3m below surface; crouched and N-S
Site_description: Primary inhumation of adult placed N-S. first secondary cremation with bone pin and lozenge shaped bone beads. Second secondary interment was an inhumation of a young person at a depth of four feet, placed N-S perhaps also Early or Middle Bronze Age.

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow, Oakley Down Group, Wimborne St Giles
Site_summary: gg summary>: Wimborne barrow 3Upright CU with cremation
Site_description: Primary cremation in upright Early or Middle Bronze Age collared urn, covered by flint cairn. (1)'(119) Bowl (02001755), (Hoare No. 3), cut away on the N. W. side by the main road, covered a primary cremation in a collared urn (Devizes Mus. Cat., 1964, No. 532); diam. About 40 ft., ht. 2 ft.' (2)

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: five burials, four (in two/three graves) with graves goods, excavated at two different times. Grave goods from earlier excavation/EBA grave in Devizes Museum.Grinsell's (1959) Wimborne St Giles barrow 4 - note that a polypod vessel with shale/jet bead and a dagger with two inhumations came from here. Polypods have Yorkshire & Irish affinities
Site_description: Primary skeleton N-S, head probably at north, at depth of 12 feet 4 inches. Above this were two more skeletons lying N-S with small four footed handled vase, black bead and bronze dagger. A secondary adult cremation in inverted Late Bronze Age urn with 11 rivet holes was found in 1950 in a rabbit barrow just below the surface with fragmentary remains of another Late Bronze Age cremation.(1)DHER record card lists DoE file ref. AA 60860/1, received 16/02/54

Site_summary: A feature described as a slight raised mound surrounded by a ditch, and interpreted as a probable bowl barrow, was destroyed by quarrying in 1905. It was reported that about 160 urns were dug up at the same time, suggesting an extensive cremation cemetery in and around the mound.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's Portland Barrow 1. Of the reputed 260 [MBA] urns recovered from this barrow cemetery, only 19 were 'saved' and deposited in the Somerset/Dorset County Museums. Four urns in Dorset Co. Museum (1907.3.3); Fifteen urns in Somerset Co. Museum. The urnfield itself is recorded separately in the HER (see MDO6528) but this record includes no additional information.Given the lack of contextual detail, the 19 verified urns are grouped here in one record with an MNI of one associated cremation burial
Site_description: PRIDEAUX as being in an area for quarrying. The slightly raised barrow was surrounded by a ditch, and contained a large number - probably 100 to 200 urn burials. In the same part of PORTLAND a dene hole was uncovered. (1)            "About 160 urns were uncovered in the course of two or three  weeks, and half the barrows are still unopened."  (2) Listed as bowl barrow, 33 paces in diameter, with a surrounding ditch. In the locality of SUCKTON QUARRY. Some 260  Late Bronze Age urns found here. Additional references (a)(b).  (3) From SUCKTHUMB or SUGDEN QUARRY: Three urns, saved when the barrow   was demolished in 1908. Over 100 urns were found. Accession No. 1907.3.3 (3 urns (bucket) in D.C.M.)  (4)  Cinerary Urns from SUCKTON QUARRY:- A - 5 3/4" high and 5" wide of reddish clay with four small knobs; B - 9" high and 6" wide unornamented; and C - of flower pot shape with finger indentations 10" high and 7" wide at maximum. The first found by PRIDEAUX and BARNES and the other two found in 1907 by PRIDEAUX. C was given to MR CORNICK of BRIDPORT in 1914. A   black urn 7" high and 4 1/2" wide with two small knobs remaining  reportedby PRIDEAUX and BARNES.  (5) (SY68737077) "The face of the quarry moves slowly and to within 100 yards at the maximum the site is as indicated on your  6" plan. I have heard of the finds but know no details" (c). The area is quarried out. There were no surface finds or traces of antiquity. [This site is referred to on SY 67 SE 24].(6) One of the 15 cinerary urns saved by Mr Prideaux in 1907 was restored and given to the Somerset County Museum in 1909, the four others that he had restored being presented to Dorset County Museum. The urn is a "flower-pot shape, height 9 3/8" having a beaded rim and two lugs below it."  (7)

Site_summary: A cist found in 1882, and two burials one in a cist the other with part of a Celtic bronze-mirror found in c.1878, found on the SE Glacis of the Verne.<gg_summary>: Whimster (1981, 348) notes that: Various inhumations in cists discovered in the area in 1734, 1860, c.1878, 1882 and 1933. One burial (c.1878) of undescribed form contained part of a later Iron Age mirror handle.No further contextual details are available.
Site_description: Three burials found on the SE Glacis of the Verne. One cist of beach-derived Portland slabs was found in 1882, 3ft under the ground in a 'glacial drift earth'. Two other burials were found in the SE Glacis c.1878. One of these was in a cist the other had part of a Celtic bronze mirror.(1)

Site_summary: The site of a ditched bowl barrow. Excavations in 1938 revealed a primary cremation and two other burials, thought to be later insertions.  The barrow was destroyed in 1947, and the site is built over.<gg summary>: Grinsell's (1959) Weymouth Barrow 20. Cremation pyre under cremation and separated from it by layer of clay. 1ry cremation with 3 riveted dagger. Above the cremation was a large mass of carbonised wood.
Site_description: Tumulus (NR) (1) Destroyed. (2) A bowl barrow, 28(?) paces in diameter and 45 ft (?) in height. Situated on clay and opened by K C Selby. The barrow contained a primary cremation with a bronze dagger and abundant charcoal. (3) Situated on a fairly level ground this barrow has been destroyed by the building of a bungalow, at the SW corner of which, what appears to be the remains of the barrow have been so much mutilated that its extent cannot be traced with any certainty, but the slight mound which is visible maybe the result of digging the foundations of the building(4) Complete destroyed. No trace remains. (5) SY 66778245, Weymouth 20. Nottington Barrow ?30 paces diameter and 4ft high, was excavated by K C C Selby and G Kirk in 1938. A probably primary cremation was found thinly covered with charcoal and accompanied by fragments of a bronze riveted dagger.  Beneath the cremation and separated from it by a thin layer of clay, were the  remains of the funeral pyre, and above the cremation was a large mass of carbonised wood.  Parts of two intrusive skeletons were found 1.5 ft below the top of the mound.  Barrow destroyed 1947.(6) Additional bibliography.    (7,8)The cruciform trench, with a wider square hole in the centre, is seen on an aerial photograph of the barrow taken in 1947 (RAF 1821-4459), since it seems improbable that the excavation trench would have remained open for nine years if it had been left alone, the possibility has been suggested that the trenches were used as an air raid shelter by the occupants of the adjacent houses.The barrow and the excavation trench are clearly visible on aerial photographs taken in 1946 and the site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project. {9}

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Finds recovered (and mostly destroyed) by agricultural labourers in the late 19th century. Of the urns discovered by the labourers, most used as targets for stone throwing ...Warne's (1866) more controlled excavations encountered the following series of burials:1) A stone lined cist containing a portion of a skeleton and a small urn filled with calcined bone and ashes (given a broad Bronze Age date here)2) 30-35 urns, all filled with the usual deposit of calcined bone and ashes. The majority of urns were placed with their mouths uppermost ... each was covered with a thin flat stone, one of which had the impression of the pot rim on its underside. None of the vessels were well-fired (a minimum of 29 graves (30 dead people) are recorded here). Three bucket urns from this site are illustrated in Calkin 1962 (32): two from Cambridge Museum of Anthropology and Archaeology and one from Dorset County Museum.The inhumations in cists noted to have been found 'beneath the urns' are not recorded since there is no evidence that these were associated with ggAn additional beaker burial was excavated in the vicinity of this site in September 1979. The exact position of this burial relative to the initial barrow is not known. However it is thought to be associated with the wider barrow cemetery.
Site_description: <NRHE site description>: About a quarter of a mile south of Chalbury and at a lower level but still on high ground lies the cemetery discovered by workmen who were removing large stones for cultivation purposes. The ground is uneven and a wall runs longitudinally over the ridge. Forty urns - of which 38 were destroyed - were found before the site was excavated by Mr Warne, Mr C. Hall and Mr Medhurst. In all some 100 urns were unearthed only a few of which survived. They all contained ashes and calcined bones and the majority were mouth upwards and covered with thin flat stone. Two identical urns were found side by side and covered by a common stone. "Cists and Kistvaens" were interspersed amidst the urns and the depths of deposits varied between 18 in. and 2ft. No metal was found. On kistvaen contained part of a skeleton and a small urn with ashes but in many cases unburnt skeletons were found lying beneath urns. Several of the cists were without urns but contained mortuary contents. "Cartloads of human bones had previously been removed from the contiguous chalk pit." (1)SY 68938339. This site was located from the topographical description contained in Auth 1. It is a prominent knoll, on a ridge, and is crossed by an East - West wall. The ground is uneven and grass covered. A disused chalk pit is situated to the immediate east and is centred at SY 69878338.There were no surface finds. (2)Typical urns from the Rimbury Urnfield. Scale approx. 1/6. Fromauthority 1. AO/55/57/5,6 and 7. (3)Work on an extension to the reservoir in 1979 revealed a quantity of human bone and fragments of Beaker pottery. Excavation of the remains (sited to SY69693346) from Woodwrd's plan) showed that the burial laid within a shallow subrectangular pit with remains of two beakers and a small bronze awl. The site had been badly eroded by ploughing, but it was shown that only one individual was present, probably male, and originally flexed with the head to the west. There was no sign of a perimeter ditch around the burial pit, but it is possible that it was originally protected by a burial mound and may therefore be the site of a ploughed out barrow. The Rimbury urnfield was also probably located within a barrow cemetery. The loss of barrows on this ridge outside the hillfort may be explained by its location within the Mediaeval open fields of Bincombe and Sutton Poyntz. These burial sites, together with the tumuli at Chalbury hillfort, (SY68SE33) can be considered to be southern outliers to the extended cemetery of the South Dorset Ridgeway. (4,5)

Site_summary: Four graves were discovered during the digging of a service trench in 1975.
