A salvage excavation revealed these burials and associated settlement were of Late Iron Age and Romano-British date.<gg_summary>: Bristow (2001) notes that: Three graves were disturbed in trenching and suggested an early 1st century AD date. Grave 1 contained a female c35-50 with fragments of a Durotrigian bowl by the head. Grave 2 was of a young person, and Grave 3 contained 2 people -  a male c20-40 and a contracted male c20-35, head to W. Sherds of typical Late Iron Age pottery were stratified in Grave 3. Grave 3 probably was in a stone cist, parts of which were associated with the first body in it. Dockrill clarifies that Grave 3 probably represents two separate interments lumped together for convenience. The later interment (Burial 4) was associated with iron nails/amorphous objects, probably representing a coffin. This could be early Roman in date but there were IA sherds in the grave fill so it is included for now.
Site_description: In 1975, during excavations for service trenches west of Lea Road, Wyke Regis, human bones and pottery were discovered by workmen. The disturbed remains of four skeletons were recovered. Two phases of activity in the area of Beachview Close were identified from the unstratified finds and excavated burials. The finds to the south of grave 1 suggested a Romano-British context  while the burials themselves  suggest an early 1st century AD date based on the pottery  associated with graves 1 and 3. S. J Dockrill (0ne of the excavators noted in his report that grave 3 exhibited  the late Iron Age Durotrigian characteristic of Burial upon the right hand side. And also that grave  3b seemed later than 3a, disturbing the stone cist and bones of the earlier burial. (1)

Site_name_other: St Alban's Street, Weymouth: Bronze Age Cremation
Site_summary: Bronze Age Cremation in an Urn, dug up in 1836, containing ashes and burnt bonesUnlikely to get any more specific detail here
Site_description: In digging a cellar at 20 Petticoat Lane (Now the Wellington Arms, 13 St Albans Street) in 1836, a rude funeral urn containing burnt bones and ashes was found in shingle 6 ft below the surface. Probably Bronze Age. (1)

Site_summary: Bowl barrow recorded as being about 10 m in diameter and one metre high. It was completely excavated in 1971 in advance of gravel quarrying. The barrow was surrounded by a ditch with a causeway to the south. Primary features included 14 Deverel-Rimbury Globular and Bucket urns, many in excellent condition, a number of unaccompanied cremations, and scattered stake-holes and pits. Also primary was a setting of six upright hearthstone slabs. A total of 48 Deverel-Rimbury urns had been secondarily inserted into the barrow or in pits to the south of the barrow. Quantities of charcoal were found as well as flints, pot sherds and ground stone objects.<gg_summary>: A total of 60 Deverel-Rimbury urns, a no. of unaccompanied cremations and pits containing large quantities of charcoal. Only 34 of the urns were directly associated with human remains (two of which were in one pit) and are recorded here. The finds are in Dorset Museum.
Site_description: Described in 1919-1923 as a ' Bowl barrow, 34 feet in diameter and 3 1/2 feet high. No ditch. Unopened.' <2>In 1955 it was described as ' a heather-covered bowl barrow with no visible ditch. The mound is 10.0m. In diameter and 1.0m. High.'  <2>Barrow G34, Knighton Heath, was totally excavated in advance of destruction of quarrying. The barrow was surrounded by a ditch with a causeway to the south. Primary features included 14 Deverel - Rimbury Globular and Bucket urns, many in excellent condition, a number of unaccompanied cremations, and scattered stake-holes and pits. Also primary was a setting of six upright hearthstone slabs. A total of 48 Deverel -Rimbury urns had been secondarily inserted into the barrow or in pits to the south of the barrow. Quantities of charcoal were found as well as flints, potsherds and ground stone objects. C-14 date from the sandcore of the mound 1205 +/- 40 (BM-871-6). (2)The barrow was de-scheduled after excavation (previously M112A).

Site_summary: Bell barrow that survives as an earthwork about 24m in diameter and two metres high, with traces a damaged irregular ditch about 3.5m wide. It may be one of the barrows excavated by J H Austen in 1847 containing a primary urned cremation and at least five intrusive inhumations burials.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's (1959) Poole Barrows 4, Cogdean Elms. One of two barrows within this group of six (see MDO6787/Grinsell's (1959) Barrow 3b for the other potential candidate) from which it is thought the burials with grave goods came. Since the true origin of the burials is impossible to determine, the graves/gg are attributed to this round barrow here.
Site_description: "BARROW HILL GROUP (SY 99 SE). Six barrows, including four bells, on flat-topped ridge above 200 ft. contour. (396-9) form a short S.W.-N.E. alignment. All but (399) have probably been excavated. Three barrows on 'Merley Heath' were excavated by Austen in 1847: two of (396-8) contained unaccompanied cremations beneath a layer of flints; and either (400) or (401) contained a primary cremation in an upright Middle or Late Bronze Age urn, and at least five intrusive inhumations on top of mound.(400) Bell (99599767).160 yds. N.W. of (399). Diam. about 50 ft., ht. 7.5 ft., with traces of a berm on S.E. and damaged, irregular ditch about 9 ft. wide." (1)In 1955 it was described as a "probable bell barrow, with slight berm on the west side. The mound is 16 metres in diameter and 2 metres high with a surrounding ditch 3.5 metres wide and 0.3 metre deep. Heavily overgrown with gorse and bracken." (2)In 1980 it was described as a "barrow, height 2 metres, diameter 24 metres, overall including a ditch 3.5 metres wide and 0.2 metres deep, on the west side, but visible as a cropmark elsewhere. The barrow is under gorse and bramble and has been mutilated sufficiently for it to be now impossible to determine whether it is a bowl or bell barrow." (2)

Site_summary: Cremation burial within an inverted Middle Bronze Age bucket urn was found by builders at 100 Willett Road, Poole in 1966.
Site_description: A human cremation in an inverted  Middle Bronze Age bucket urn was disturbed during the digging of a cess pit in the garden of 100 Willett Road, Poole in 1966. The urn was placed inverted in a small pit about 4 ft. deep. The base of the vessel had been truncated in the past.The vessel is described as being of a 'black ware, mostly gritless, with only two small lugs on opposing sides of the body'. It is now in Poole Museum. (1)

Site_summary: Probable Bronze Age cinerary urn recorded by Norman Field from Hoare's Pit, the pottery was not been kept and the identification is based on descriptions of the find.
Site_description: In 1950 an excavator-driver uncovered a large urn at a depth of 3 feet where the topsoil met the underlying gravel. The fragments were kept for some time but had been thrown away when Norman Field learnt of the discovery. The driver's description, however, indicated a vessel of about 15 to 18 inches high, ove very thick ware, rusty red in colour and of very gritty paste. It seems there were irregular finger or thumb marks around the upper part of the sides, which had a broad convex profile. A deposit of some 2 inches of charred black and grey bone was found inside. It was evidently a late Bronze Age burial urn. (1)

Site_name_other: Bronze Age cremation, Moortown Aerodrome, Poole
Site_summary: A Bronze Age cremation recorded during excavation in advance of gravel extraction at, Moortown Aerodrome, Poole.<gg_summary>: An isolated urned MBA cremation burial was identified in a trial trench during excavations as part of the Stour Valley Gravels project in 1985. Later excavations around this feature revealed contemporary settlement evidence.

<gg_summary>: Small Middle Bronze Age cremation cemetery comprising four urned cremations and two simple unurned cremations, together with a pit containing pyre debris and associated postholes. The urned and unurned burials were grouped separately. Only the plough truncated rims of the urns survive.

In garden of house. Contained in centre, a primary inhumation (perhaps headless) in hollowed tree-trunk coffin of oak, placed South East/North West, with head-end at South East. The skeleton was wrapped in deer skin sewn together, there was a cup of wood or shale near the head-end, there is also said to have been a piece of gold lace (possibly used to fasten the deer hides together) <gg summary>: This is Arne barrow 19. Oak-tree coffin with inhumation in skins and with shale cup
Site_description: Kings Barrow (NR) (1) Kings Barrow, bowl (?) (SY 92048572). Now in a garden and covered with trees and shrubs. Diameter. uncertain, ht. about 5 1/2ft. In 1767 said to be 100ft in diameter. 12ft high and apparently constructed of turves. In centre on sandy buried surface was primary inhumation (probably Wessex culture) without skull, wrapped in stitched animal skins, within a hollowed oak tree coffin 10ft long by 4ft wide by 3ft deep orientated NW-SE. Attached to one skin was gold end of the coffin was a small cup, now lost, 2ins high, and decorated with incised lines. Though described as of oak, it was more probably made of Kimmeridge shale. (Salisbury Journal 9th March 1767; Gentleman's Magazine XXVII (1767), 53-4 Hutchins I, 100, 563; W. A. M. XLIV (1928), 101-5 ad 111-17; PPS xv (1949), 101-6).(2) SY 920858. Kings Barrow, round barrow. Scheduled. (3)

Site_summary: A bowl barrow on a low rise, one of several on Roke Down. This monument is thought to have been excavated in 1840 by Wake Smart and later by Solly. Reports of the excavation describe the barrow as 4 to 5 feet high with large sarsen blocks on top. Excavations revealed a cremation under an inverted urn in a cist with three daggers, and this is thought to be the primary burial. Earlier reports refer to finds of urns and glass beads from the eastern part of the mound.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's (1959) Bere Regis Barrow 46e. The only one of six round barrows from the Roke Down Group for which it is possible to associate directly with excavated graves/grave goods. See SID72860 for the barrow cemetery record to which all other unlocated burials from this cemetery are attached.NB accounts of the excavation of this barrow are variable and conflicting. Grinsell (1959, following Hutchins) mentions BOTH a central inhumation and cremation; Warne (1866) mentions only a cremation but gives a good detailed account. This record represents a 'best fit', based on Warne (1866), since Hutchin's account is described as confused. Finds from the barrow beyond the central urned cremation associated with a dagger and two knives (including 'glass' beads and three further urns) are NOT recorded as gg here. Their association with human remains is not verified and they came from an unrecorded earlier excavation on the eastern side of the barrow mound.
Site_description: '(D) ROKE DOWN GROUP (SY 89 NW), six barrows in two clusters of three, the westernmost including two probable bells. In arable on S. slopes of Down near 200 ft. contour; all except (96) among 'Celtic' fields with (93-5) probably at field angles (see Ancient Field Group (30)). All have probably been opened. Accounts exist of six excavations hereabouts but only one can be related with certainty to a specific barrow (97), though the account in Hutchins of even this is confused (Hutchins I, 143-4; Warne, C.T.D., cpf, no. 2 and 17 n; Payne, Durden Catalogue (1892), 12-18; Abercromby II, 39 and fig. 375; Ant. J. XIII (1933), 443).

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow, one of the Bloxworth Down Group, Bloxworth
Site_summary: A disc or bell-disc barrow with berm, ditch and outer bank encircling the central mound, and around 160 feet in overall diameter. The mound had been recorded as about 4 feet high but by 1970 it was described as visible only as a slight rise. Around 1854 his monument was excavated by Shipp, who found a central cremation burial with grave goods including bone tweezers and amber beads, and four later burials in the upper parts of the mound.Secondary inhumations in mound above primary cremation - suggestive of family (2 children, adult male and adult female) at two levels higher in mound - all lacked grave goods but all were crouched and may also be EBA; all oriented E-W. Male of very large stature <gg summary>: This is Grinsell's (1959) Bloxworth 4a; disc barrow with Collared Urn cremations
Site_description: RAF CPE/UK 1934: 4128

Site_summary: Probably opened by J H Austen, primary crouched interment in deep grave cut in chalk, antler fragments, potsherds, and shale among the chalk, near centre were two subsequent primary crouched interments, one had head to North North East and was in a grave lined with flagstones at the head and foot, near the surface was an extended inhumation (Romano-British or possibly pagan Saxon)<gg summary>: This is Church Knowle 7Note two burials lacked ggOne of old male lacked grave goods - A crouched male of large stature enclosed in a square stone cist of double flags at the north and south but with open side; this is a very nice grave with all the flag lining almost like a stone coffin. Could this be a gg?Secondary off-centre  crouched inhumation in cist with displacement of lumbar vertebrae that occurred before intermentNote that the 1ry burial had a chalk seal or capping and objects (deer antlers and broken shale bracelet/pendant) were inserted into this. Are they grave goods??
Site_description: Hole in Centre, adjoins Cross-ridge dyke. Probably opened by J H Austen, primary crouched interment in deep grave cut in chalk, antler fragments, potsherds, and shale among the chalk, near centre were two subsequent primary crouched interments, one had head to North North East and was in a grave lined with flagstones at the head and foot, near the surface was an extended inhumation (Romano-British or possibly pagan Saxon).Bronze Age bowl barrow visible as earthworks on aerial photographs (2-3) and digitally plotted during the Wild Purbeck Mapping Project.<summary>: Part of  a more extensive and slightly dispersed barrow cemetery. A bowl barrow with a central primary crouched inhumation of an old male of large stature, oriented NNE, laid on its back, and set in a pit of c2.5-3m diameter x 3m deep. Over the body lumps of chalk had been carefully packed, followed by a layer of earth containing pieces of burnt wood c0.6m thick, then a thin clay coating. Among the chalk were found two pieces of stag horn, two sherds and a piece of shale.

Site_name_other: Cinerary Urn in quarry north of King Edward's Bridge, Corfe Castle
Site_summary: An inverted urn containing burnt bone was found in a chalk quarry in 1751. It is a Collared Urn with cremation of a child
Site_description: An inverted urn containing  "five gallons full of burnt bones" was found in made ground whin digging chalk in 1753 in the quarry near the lime kiln on the east side of the road immediately north of King Edward's Bridge. (1)(2)The burial is presumably Bronze Age in date. (1)

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: no info in HER record, check out latest ref. then check earlier ones as relevant:<awaiting further info>Bucknowle Farm, Corfe Castle, 1990, J. Collins, N. Field and A. Light, 117-9Bucknowle, 1989, J. Collins, N. Field and A. Light, 107Bucknowle Farm, Excavations 1988, J.Collins, et al, 110 151-152

Iron Age shale working settlement<gg_summary>: Details from the separately recorded cist burial from this site (MDO7547) are included here:<MDO7547>: An inhumation burial in a cist with grave goods, dated to the Iron Age.During excavations at Rope Lake Hole in 1979 a crouched inhumation burial in a cist associated with the shale working settlement was found. The burial contained a Durotrigian Bowl and a shale lid-like object. Aspect S. The nearest site is Metherhills, occupation debris to the NW, the nearest large settlement  probably that located by finds  at Norden to the north of this site, there are numerous smaller industrial sites in the area. The site is situated in a field regularly ploughed in ley pasture. A steep cliff to the S with the site eroding from it, a coastal footpath crosses E-W (1)
Site_description: An Iron Age and Romano-British settlement, midway between Kimmeridge and Chapman's Pool on a gently sloping piece of high ground on the cliffs above Rope Lake Hole, revealed by badgers diggings on the cliff top, from SY 93007762 to SY 93207762. Examination of the site in 1963 yielded two pieces of unfinished hand cut armlets in the Iron Age A tradition (7). Excavated by Weymouth College students in 1974. Finds indicated occupation from the Early Iron Age to the late Roman period, with evidence of a shale bracelet industry, both hand-cut and lathe turned, salt production and metal-working. Stone lined water gully identified, cut into Iron Age occupation layers. Further excavation has revealed that the earliest settlement (Iron Age to 1st century) consisted of unenclosed circular stone buildings within a system of contoured lynchet fields and work areas, overlaid in the 2nd century by a rectilinear building and yard which yielded lathe-turned shale waste and flint chisel tools representative of large-scale production of armlets (1-4). Following partial excavation in 1979 Woodward described circular huts with dry limestone sill walls ranging from 8-15m diameter and a rectilinear stone sill-wall building and yard laid out in the 2nd/3rd century (8). In July 1979 Woodward also discovered a crouched Iron Age cist burial with a Durotrigian bowl and shale lid-like object (9).  Any settlement or field system remains which may have existed to the N of the coastal path have been ploughed out. On a steep cliff slope of 20m extending for 80m along the cliff there are numerous badger diggings continuing to produce bones, fragments of IA and Ro pottery and a few shale cores, but no evidence of any structures (5). Small copper alloy brooch and the base of a small Samian cup recovered following badger activity 1992 (6).

Site_name_other: Bronze Age round barrow, Holme Heath, East Holme
Site_summary: The excavated remains of a Bronze Age round barrow is visible as an earthwork on Lidar imagery of Holme Heath. It is one of a group of three round barrows located here (MDO7627-29). This barrow was explored in the 1860s by antiquarian J H Austen, who found an inverted urn in a cist covered with a stone slab, and a second urn higher in the mound.Collared  urn covered with sandstone slab in a cist
Site_description: Group of three Barrows, lying on a gravel spur running north from Battle Plain. They were all dug into in 1860.  <1>The excavated remains of a Bronze Age round barrow, approximately 16.6.m in diameter, is visible as an earthwork on Lidar imagery of Holme Heath <6>. It is one of a group of three round barrows located here (MDO7627-29). A possible forth round barrow is located 80m to the south-west (MWX683) and may also be contemporary with them. This feature was digitally plotted during the Wild Purbeck Mapping Project.

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Grinsell's (1959) East Stoke barrow 15b
Site_description: '(22) Ditched bowl (SY 88 NE; 86878588) on Chick's Hill, a spur S. of the Frome, just over 50 ft. above O.D. Diam. about 28 ft., ht. 3 ft., before partial destruction and excavation in 1955-6. Primary cremation in inverted globular urn lay just above old surface in centre on large flints and immediately above small infilled pit containing pine and oak charcoal and burnt flints. The mound had been heaped up in stages with material from slightly irregular flat-bottomed ditch about 5 ft. wide and 3 ft. deep. Some cultivation had probably taken place in the area before the barrow was built.' (3)

Site_name_other: Bronze Age burial at Lynchard, Langton Matravers
Site_summary: In 1953 two roughly-rectangular limestone slabs were ploughed up and moved to the side of the field. Beaker/Early Bronze Age objects discovered by a Mr Lovell after ploughing, including a conical shale button, a whetstone and a flint knife, in association with purbeck stone slabs. Subsequent exploratory excavation of the findspot by J B Calkin did not identify any surviving in situ archaeological features, but recovered part of a second shale button.This was a causual discovery. No burial was found in association although this is clearly a grave good assemblage
Site_description: Beaker/Early Bronze Age objects discovered by a Mr Lovell after ploughing, including a conical shale button, a whetstone and a flint knife, in association with purbeck stone slabs. Subsequent exploratory excavation of the findspot by J B Calkin did not identify any surviving in situ archaeological features, but recovered part of a second shale button.

Site_summary: Round barrow now crowned with Obelisk.  The barrow is visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs of the 2000s.<gg_summary>: Grinsell (1959) Studland Barrow 9. Two prehistoric graves (one EBA inhumation; one MBA cremation); one early med grave.
Site_description: Hole in Centre, on Swanage boundary, opened by J H Austen 1857, in central grave, primary crouched inhumation (head to East) with handled cup of fine red ware, parts of antlers in filling of grave. In mound near centre a disarticulated skeleton with urn fragments and, slightly higher a cremation, with parts of urn, probably LBA, covered by stone slab.  (1-2)The barrow described above in (1-2) is visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs of the 2000s. The barrow measures 19 m in diameter. (3-5)  This feature was digitally plotted during the Wild Purbeck Mapping Project.

Site_summary: A Bronze Age bowl barrow, one of a group of three barrows. It had a central contracted inhumation burial with part of an antler. A secondary urned cremation burial was found in the southern side. A later intrusive extended inhumation was found in the eastern part of the barrow mound.<gg summary>: This is Swanage 5. Child inhumation with antler and a secondary Cremation with Collared Urn
Site_description: A 37 ft wide bowl barrow in which a primary contracted inhumation with an antler fragment was found in a grave cut 5 ft deep into the chalk; other antler fragments occurred within the grave fill. An extended e/w inhumation lay 2 ft beneath the top of the mound. (1-3)The extended inhumation is thought to be early medieval in date. (1)A secondary urned cremation in a collared urn was exposed on the south side of the barrow by ploughing in 1967. (4)

Site_name_other: Bronze Age ditched bowl barrow, Ballard Down, Swanage
Site_summary: A ditched bowl barrow, the eastermost of a group of three barrows. Excavation by Rev Austen in 1857 revealed primary contracted inhumation, a secondary infant inhumation, other bones and a Collared Urn.<gg summary>: swanage No 6
Site_description: The ditched bowl barrow is 48 ft in diameter and a probable contracted inhumation lay in a chalk-cut grave, 3 ft deep, with urn fragments and human bones in the fill. A child inhumation lay on the chalk at the lip of the grave and fragments of another occurred near the surface of the mound. (1)The Bronze Age pond barrow described above in (1) is visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs on Ballard Down.  The barrow is the easternmost of a group of three (see linked records).  The barrow is formed of a mound measuring 13 m in diameter, surrounded by a ditch measuring up to 2 m in width.  (2)  This site was digitally plotted during the South West Rapid Coastal Zone Assessment Survey (Dorset).

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow overlooking St Oswald's Bay, West Lulworth
Site_summary: Two bowl barrows aligned north east by south west, situated below the crest of a ridge overlooking St Oswald's Bay to the south.  The barrows were recorded by the Ordnance Survey in 1903.  They are visible as low earthworks on aerial photographs taken in 1946 and have since been plough-levelled.<gg summary>: West Lulworth Barrow 2. Upright  MBA Bucket urn. Triangular slab covered pot and sheep bones on top . Sheep bones not directly associated with the human remains and above the traingular stone
Site_description: Two bowl barrows aligned north east by south west, situated below the crest of a ridge overlooking St Oswald's Bay to the south.  The barrows were recorded by the Ordnance Survey in 1903, LV Grinsell in 1959 and the RCHME in 1970. Each has a mound composed of earth and chalk, with maximum dimensions of 30 metres and 35 metres in diameter and about 0.5 metres in height.  The larger mound is to the west.  Surround each mound is a quarry ditch.  These have become infilled over the years, but each will survive as a buried feature 2 metres wide.  The western barrow was partially excavated in 1916 by Mr VP Kitchin and Captain DA Brownsword.  Their investigation uncovered an urn containing the cremated remains of an adult woman.  The urn was situated within a cavity in natural clay with flints; it was surrounded by a lining of ash and lay beneath a triangular flat stone which was associated with sheep bones. (1-9).One of two barrows marked on the OS 1st Edition map.  They are visible as low earthworks on aerial photographs taken in 1946 and have since been plough-levelled and visible only as cropmarks (10-11).  The mounds lie in the vicinity of a number of small chalk pits and associated spoil heaps (MWX3974), some of which appear as chalk mounds of similar appearance to the barrows on the latest Google earth imagery.  It is uncertain how many are barrows and how many spoil heaps.  The features were digitally plotted during the Wild Purbeck Mapping Project.

Site_name_other: Late prehistoric bell barrow, Hambury Tout, West Lulworth
Site_summary: Bell barrow and detached burials. A mound surrounded by an outer ditch is visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs and Lidar imagery of Hambury Tout. It is considered likely to be the site of a late prehistoric round barrow. It is one of three potential round barrows located on Hambury Tout (see also MDO8243 & MDO8245).<gg summary>: West Lulworth 3a. All sounds rather unpromising due to poor excavation and recording although the crouched burial is accompanied by a Beaker. Yes Beaker inhumation  and also urns . Inhumation had injury
Site_description: Tumulus (NR) (1) Hanbury Hill ... a tumulus or circle about 10ft in diameter. of large loose stones ... a gigantic skeleton had been found there - 1791. (May apply to this tumulus which is situated on Hambury Tout). (2) A) A good example of a bell-barrow, opened by J Milner about 1790. Near to the centre was a skeleton with the feet rather drawn up, on the breast of which was a pottery vessel (not certain whether this interment was E.B.A. or very much later). Beneath this, and in the centre, were ashes. The barrow was opened very unscientifically and badly recorded. The central part of the excavation was done by treasure seekers."  'B') A bowl barrow sited at SY 81608028. Possibly opened by J Milner the same day as he dug into (a). Bones and broken urns found. (3)                                                                         'A' - A mound of diameter 22.0m, and height 2.5m. A berm 2.0m. wide is visible on all but the N. quadrant. A surrounding ditch averages 1.5m. in width, and is 0.2m. deep. Flat topped and grass covered, no surface finds were made in the vicinity of this bell barrow. 'B' - A mound of 15.0m. diameter and 0.5m. high. A surrounding ditch 1.3m. wide, and 0.25 m. deep is visible except at the NE quadrant. A hollow in the centre has a diameter of 3.5m. and a depth of 0.4m. No berm is visible. No surface finds were made in the vicinity of this bowl barrow, which is grass covered. Surveyed at SY 81628028. (4)                                                                                                                       'A'- SY 81588029; 'B'- SY 81648030). Tumuli (NR). (5)                                                                                     'A'-(40)-SY 81588030. Bell barrow, 78ft diameter and 9 1/2 ft high with traces of berm and ditch on the rounded summit of Hambury Tout. Probably opened by Milner who found a large heap of ashes under a central cairn, above which was a contracted inhumation with an urn on its chest.                                                                                                                 'B'-(41)-SY 81638030. Ditched bowl barrow, about 47ft diameter and 3ft high, much disturbed. Probably opened by Milner who found bones and urns.  (6)                                                                                                                            SY 816802-816803. Hambury Tout round barrows. Scheduled. (7)                                                                              'A'. SY 81588029. Bell Barrow, overall diameter 29.0m. including  a ditch 2.0m. wide and 0.3m. deep. The height is 3.5m. maximum and there is a berm 2.5m. wide except on the north and north-east. 'B'. SY 81648029. Bowl Barrow, diameter 18.0m. overall including a ditch 1.5m. wide and 0.3m. deep. The height is 1.0m. maximum. The ditch is not visible on the north and east sides. Resurveyable at 1/2500 on M.S.D. (8)A mound, approximately 19m in diameter, surrounded by a 1.8m wide outer ditch, is visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs (11-12) and Lidar imagery (13) of Hambury Tout. It is considered likely to be the site of a late prehistoric round barrow. It is one of three potential round barrows located on Hambury Tout (see also MDO8243 & MDO8245). This feature was digitally plotted during the South West Rapid Coastal Zone Assessment Survey (Dorset).

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow at Young Creech, Wool
Site_summary: One of two bowl barrows on a small knoll at Young Creech.  They are visible as earthworks on aerial photographs taken in 1947. In 1970 this monument was reported as being around 72 feet in diameter with a mound about 4 feet high. This barrow is thought to be one of two barrows at 'Young Creech' explored by antiquarians in the mid-19th century, when several urns containing cremations were found.<gg summary>: Church Knowle 5a. In situ cremation with polished stone bead
Site_description: One of two bowl barrows on a small knoll at Young Creech.  They are visible as earthworks on aerial photographs taken in 1947 (1) and were digitally plotted during the Wild Purbeck Mapping Project.  They are still extant on the most recent Google Earth imagery.

Site_name_other: Bowl Barrow on St Aldhelm's Head, Worth Matravers
Site_summary: A bowl barrow reported in 1970 to be around 41 feet in diameter with a mound about 5 feet high. In 1850 this barrow was excavated by Austen, who found seven or eight burials with finds including a bone pin, a green glass bead, Romano-British pottery and coins, and shale fragments. Interpreted as original burials in stone-lined cist, with later burials inserted into the mound.<gg summary>: This is Worth Matravers Barrow 3.  stone-filled complex and sub-divided cist, the remains of  seven or eight inhumations, at least three being extended. Four skulls lay together over the feet of one inhumation. The only associated finds were a round-headed bone pin and a `green glass (sic faience?) bead' with a  crushed urn, probably a degenerate short-necked beaker. Upright  stone slabs, perhaps of an original cist were associated with the burials. Shale fragments and a shale armlet in earth and stone capping above burials
Site_description: Opened by J H Austen, primary and subsequent primary inhumations, mostly in disorder, 5 or 6 in all, one with bone pin, another with pottery vessel (perhaps a Bi beaker). A green glass (?) bead was also found at the level of the skeletons, Samian sherd and 5 AE3 coins near top.<Summary>: Inhumation No 1 was on the east side of the partition and close to it, head to SSE. Over the feet of this deposit (and hence secondary) were a quantity of bones and 4 skulls (Nos 2-5) accompanied by a plain bone pin c 8cm long, all enclosed by a small cist of slanting flat stones set edgeways over them covering an area c0.6m in diameter. No 6 was a skeleton at right angles to No 1, and laid head to WSW, the head being in the east angle of another stone slab set at right angles [presumably from the subsequent description to form a T] at the north end of the main 2-slab setting ['the stone nearest the centre' Warne 58]. It was protected by large stones. In the west angle of the T, and parallel with and on the opposite side of the partition wall, head to NNW, was a female without a skull, accompanied by a small pierced green glass bead, and on the breast a small urn on its side, plain except for a row of projecting knobs a little below the rim. Stones also were packed over this deposit. No 7 was an inhumation at right angles to No 6, head to N, on its side. The whole set of deposits was covered by a stratum of clean stone c15cm thick, over which was earth and stone with many sherds, and shale fragments including part of an armlet. There were also many limpet shells and other land shells in the upper part of the mound.

Site_summary: OS28 Stourfield Barrow destroyed in 1910 when five late Bronze Age Bucket Urns (two now lost) were found.<gg_summary>: Since there is no indication of whether the urns were associated with human remains, the urns are recorded within a single grave entry (it is assumed that there was at least one cremation burial with them).
Site_description: <NRHE site description>: Stourfield Barrow. Destroyed June 1910 when 3 LBA bucket urns were found. They were repaired by W H Young of the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford and are now in the Druitt Collection, Christchurch Museum. (2)Site now built over.The 'Three Urns' from the tumulus are on show in the Christchurch Museum. (3)

Site_summary: A Bronze Age bowl barrow, surviving as an earthwork and located on the south side of Wick Lane. When visited by an Ordnance Survey field investigator in 1959, it could be seen as an elongated mound 27 metres north-south by 17 metres east-west, with a maximum height of 2.6 metres. It was described as slightly mutilated and had been planted with fir trees. There was no visible sign of a surrounding ditch, nor any trace of an excavation.<gg_summary> Substantial (undisturbed?) bowl barrow - potentially part of a wider group of barrows on land known as Barrow Plot which, together with associated graves/grave goods were removed during gravel quarrying in 1926-9. The evidence is summarised in Calkin (1951, 1962). Objects recovered during the quarrying are summarised in related records MDOs8510-4. Gg records relating to these burials (also summarised in <MDO8513>) are attached to this record. Calkin (1967, 6) summarises the site as follows: WICK (S. 5). Cremation cemetery, found during excavation of gravel at Barrow Plot, WicknLane, in 1927-9, contained 5 collared urns and at least 12 D-R urns. The site also produced a looped spearhead and numerous Neolithic & Bronze Age flints. Nearly all the material was brought to Druitt as found and recorded in his diaries. The large barrow on the east side is the property of the Druitt Trustees and has probably neverbeen excavated.In app. 1 Calkin also notes that of the 12 MBA burials, 1 was in a bucket urn, 3 in barrel urns, 2 in globular urns. No further details
Site_description: Tumulus (OE). (1) A half-mile WSW of Christchurch Priory, on the south side of Wick Lane stands one of the largest surviving barrows in the district. Formerly it was known as Green Low (a). Bowl barrow. Diameter 30 paces by 10ft. (b). (2) An elongated mound; 27 metres N-S, and 117.0 metres in an E-W direction. It has been slightly mutilated, and planted with fir trees. The barrow has a maximum central height of 2.6 metres. There is no visible surrounding ditch, or sign of excavation. (3) No change. Published 1:1250 correct. (4)

Site_name_other: Bronze Age urned cremation burial, 700 yards west of Double Dykes, Hengistbury Head: Bronze Age pottery vessel and cremation
Site_summary: A Bronze Age cremation burial in an inverted pottery vessel, possibly a collared urn, was found in 1915 in the cliff face near Hengistbury Head.
Site_description: A Bronze Age urned cremation was found in the cliff face 700 yards west of Double Dykes by Capt. Cunnington in 1915. The urn was fragmentary and was of overhanging rim type. It was inverted over the cremation burial. (1)

Site_summary: A small Bronze Age urnfield containing fourteen urned cremations was found in 1929.<gg_summary>: Only the six urns directly associated with hr are recorded as graves here. The urnfield was heavily truncated (due partly to the burial of urns in shallow hollows rather than deep pits) and was excavated on visits to the site during the construction process. Two of the urns not associated with hr were thought to be EIA/Hallstatt as the time (urns 1 and 9) leading to the suggestion that this urnfield was a late example of its kind. It is not clear which of the illustrated/described urns contained hr, were inverted/upright, etc. so these attributes are assigned equally to the five remaining illustrated urns (not 1 and 9 which definitely did not contain hr) and one un-described burial. Some urns (12 and 13, possibly more) in the British Museum (Calkin/Kinson collections): http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/search.aspx?place=26842&plaA=26842-3-2
Site_description: The remains of 14 Bronze Age cremation burial urns were found during road construction in the Kinson Manor Estate in November and December 1929. The discoveries were made and recovered by the road contractors, but were recorded by Bernard Calkin, who visited the site three or four times a week. Seven of the urns were positioned upright and three were inverted and the positions of the remainder are not known. Six of the urns had calcined bone in them and two others had only 'blackish earth'. The urns were placed in shallow holes dug into the gravels and had been severely damaged by the plough. (1)

Site_summary: Site of an Early Bronze Age round barrow excavated in 1973 in advance of redevelopment. The barrow survived as a ring ditch eleven metres in diameter. The ditch fill contained large quantities of flint flakes, seven sandstone objects and six inurned cremations.  The barrow was subsequently the focus of a Middle Bronze Age cremation cemetery with 28 burials found outside the ditch to the north-east.<gg_summary>: Of the 35 burial deposits, 34 contained urns but only 11 contained hr (and so are recorded here). Quantities of worked flint and carved sandstone objects (including quern fragments) were recovered from the ring ditch around this monument.
Site_description: This round barrow was formerly in a golf course and subsequently in a caravan park. In 1969 it was described as a level, circular platform, less than 0.1 metre in height, upon the top of a grass-covered knoll. (1)The barrow was excavated in 1973 by members of the South Wessex Archaeological Association and the Department of Archaeology, University of Southampton, in advance of redevelopment. The mound had been entirely removed by landscaping associated with the former golf course and caravan park. The sole surviving feature was the surrounding ditch, which was 11. - 2 m wide, 0.7-0.8 m deep and had an inner diameter of 11 metres. The ditch fill contained hundreds of flint flakes, seven sandstone objects and six inurned cremations. A further 28 burials were found outside the ditch to the north-east. The urns were in a very poor state due to poor manufacture and recent mechanical damage.  (2) (3)

Site_summary: A Bronze Age ditched bowl barrow on Kinson Heath, excavated in 1948 in advance of development. The barrow mound had been damaged and no trace of a central burial was revealed. A group of eleven secondary urned cremation burials were found and three small pits containing burnt material, but only one with cremated human bone.<gg_summary>: Eleven [MBA] urns, five of which contained cremations (recorded here), and three pits, two of which contained cremations. There was no evidence to date the original construction of these three barrows.
Site_description: Bronze Age ditched bowl barrow on Kinson Heath. It was excavated in 1948, in advance of development. The barrow mound was about 46 feet in diameter and had been damaged by the digging of a pit in the centre, possibly by the Home Guard in WW2. No trace of a central burial was found. The mound was constructed of layers of sand and gravel sealing an old ground surface. A group of eleven secondary urned cremation burials were found in the south east quadrant of the barrow and three small pits containing burnt material, but only one with cremated human bone. The urns were of Deverel Rimbury type. (1-2)

Site_name_other: Bronze Age cremation found at The Slope, Headswell Crescent, Bournemouth
Site_summary: Middle Bronze Age cremation burial in an inverted urn found in 1934. No trace of a barrow was found.<gg summary>: cremation under inverted Collared Urn
Site_description: Middle Bronze Age Urn found 1934, Calkin Collection, British Museum.(SZ 08559587) Middle Bronze Age Urn found AD 1934.Urn 14" high, with overhanging rim. Found in June 1934, when a drain was being laid in front of the garage of 'The Slope' Headswell Crescent, Redhill, Bournemouth. The urn was inverted over a cremation, its base being about 2'9" above the original ground level. No trace was seen of a tumulus ditch. The ground surface was quite flat.Site of find now in private gardens. [FDC 19/11/1951] (1)

Site_name_other: Bronze Age cremation burial at Cheddington Road, Bournemouth
Site_summary: Urned cremation burial containing the remains of a young adult and a child. No trace of a barrow mound.<gg summary>: This is Moordown with inverted Collared Urn in flat grave  containing two young individuals. Pot is undecorated
Site_description: A Bronze Age urned cremation burial was found in 1935 during the construction of Cheddington Road. The undecorated urn was inverted and contained the remains of a child aged about 7 years and an adult aged 18-20 years. No trace of a barrow was noted.

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Round barrow and cremation cemetery recorded separately in the Dorset HER as MDOs 8565-6. There is no info at all in the barrow record (represented here). Information relating to both the barrow and the cremation cemetery is logged in MDO8565 (representing the cremation cemetery associated with the barrow). A minimum of 102 'LBA' urns (potentially E/MBA) were recovered. Information from MDO8565 is copied into the site description field here. The two records are grouped for interpretative purposes in the ggdb.The 5 verified urned burials found in 1923 and the two examples (one collared urn with cremated bone, one globular urn) from 1873 are recorded here. Cox (1885) also notes the visual prominence of the site (sepulchral fires could have been seen from afar); that many urns were inverted, that some contained burnt bone, that all were located very close to the surface, that none were covered, and that none were associated with metalwork. Calkin (1962, 52) notes that of the 104 urns recovered from this site, 3 were globular urns. Based on this info, two of the 1923 urns are recorded as globular urns.
Site_description: <MDO8565>: (SZ 09229548) Tumulus (NR) (Site of) Urns found AD 1873. (1) The site of this discovery is a barren mound of coarse sand and gravel. Workmen engaged in 1873 in trenching discovered an urn of ancient British type, containing cinerary remains; being in an advanced state of decay; it unfortunately fell to pieces immediately the earth was cleared away. The work was continued for a few days when 96 similar urns were exhumed, all except one in the same friable condition. On top of the mound, encircled by a two foot vallum of black soil is a tumulus. Close to the trench five small urns were found, about 2 ft apart, and the same number on the east side, but not so deep in the soil. The remaining 86 were deposited nearby in parallel lines on the slope of the mound, south of the barrow in a small space of about 20 ft square. The urns measured from 6"-16" in diam 12"-18" deep, and from 1/4"-1" thick. Many of them were black in colour, others brown inclining to dark red and none contained any coin or metallic substance. (2)While digging post-holes in 1923, 2 workmen found 5 urns containing fragments of burnt bones. No objects of metal or stone were found, but flint flakes were picked up nearby. (3) No visible remains. Site of tumulus built over by modern houses and a garden covers site of urnfield. (4)

Site_summary: A prominent Bronze Age round barrow to the east of Double Dykes, Hengistbury Head. It was initially excavated in the eighteenth century, then subsequently completely excavated by Bushe-Fox in 1911, who found a 'Wessex Culture' cremation burial of within a collared urn, plus two cones of sheet gold, three amber beads and a halberd pendant of bronze and amber.  The barrow is visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs of 1945.<gg summary> Barrow 3. Rich burial of young female cremated in primary pit and covered or accompanied by a panoply of intriguing and 'high-status' objects
Site_description: A round barrow situated to the east of the Double Dykes, Hengistbury Head.  It is a prominent mound originally 30.5 m in diameter and 2.1 m high. It had been opened in the eighteenth century and an urn and some human bone recovered.  It was subsequently completely excavated by Bushe-Fox in 1911. A rich  Wessex Culture  burial was found about 4-5 m east of the apparent centre of the barrow.  This comprised an inverted collared urn buried within the mound itself, containing the cremated bones of a 20 year old woman and a series of unusual objects. These included a probable badger s tooth, an  incense cup , three amber beads, two cones of sheet gold and a  halberd pendant  of copper alloy and amber.  (1) (2) (3)It was surveyed in 1954 and described as  a heather-covered bowl barrow in fair condition. Diam 23.5m Ht 2.0m.  (4)The Bronze Age round barrow described above in (1-4) is visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs of 1945.  The barrow is formed of a sub-oval mound measuring 21 m by 18 m.  An L-shaped trench is visible in the centre of the mound, probably the result of the excavations described above in (1-3).  (5)  The site is not visible on the most recent comprehensive aerial imagery available to the project.  (6)  This site was digitally plotted during the South West rapid Coastal Zone Assessment Survey (Dorset).

Site_summary: An elongated mound bisected by a road, probably a mutilated round barrow. It was excavated by St George Gray in 1919. No trace of any burials or pottery were discovered. A Collared urn found in 1958 may be the remains of a secondary burial.  The possible remains of the barrow are visible as earthworks on aerial photographs of 1945.
Site_description: A probable round barrow surviving as a mutilated elongated mound about 22m by 17m, which is bisected by a road. It is grass covered with no visible sign of a ditch. It was excavated by St George Gray in 1919 (Mound B). No burials or pottery were recovered. 191 flints were recovered from the buried ground surface and base of the barrow. (1)(2)In 1958 a collared urn was found during the digging of a telegraph cable trench and is thought to be the remains of a secondary burial in the barrow. (1) (3)The collared urn had incised herringbone decoration and is classified as Longworth s Primary Series, form Bi. (4)The possible remains of the barrow are visible as earthworks on aerial photographs of 1945.  A sub-oval mound and two short lengths of bank are visible over an area measuring 23 m by 13 m.  (5)  The site is not visible on the most recent comprehensive aerial imagery available to the project.  (6)  This site was digitally plotted during the South West rapid Coastal Zone Assessment Survey (Dorset).

Site_summary: A Bronze Age round barrow sited on the northern part of Warren Hill, Hengistbury Head. It was excavated in 1911 by Bushe-Fox, who found potsherds, including some of collared urns, and a quantity of worked flints, some of them Mesolithic in date. No certain burial deposit was located, but some deposits of charcoal and pottery might represent disturbed secondary burials.<gg summary>: two Collared Urns likely associated cremations that were disturbed - ashes and charcoal
Site_description: A round barrow situated on the northern part of Warren Hill, Hengistbury Head.  It was about 12.8 metres in diameter and about 1.2 metres high. The barrow was excavated by Bushe-Fox in 1911. No central burial was located by the excavation, but several separate deposits in the southeast part of the mound may be the remains of disturbed secondary burials. These deposits included an extensive patch of burnt oak, another patch of burnt oak associated with pot sherds and four other deposits of pot sherds associated with black charcoaly soil. At least two collared urns were found, only one of which survives. This is an incomplete collared urn of Longworth s Primary Series, form IV.  Quantities of worked flint were also recovered, including some probable residual Mesolithic implements. (1)(2)It was surveyed in 1954 and described as "A mutilated heather-covered mound. Diam 10.0m, Ht 1.0m." (3)(4)

Site_summary: Site of a Bronze Age round barrow, excavated in 1911-12 by Bushe-Fox. No central burial was located, but at least 15 secondary cremation deposits were found, some associated with pottery vessels including collared urns. At least one urn was found beneath the ground surface under the mound. There were also small sunken pockets of burnt material. Other finds include a flint burin said to be of Palaeolithic date. Ordnance Survey field investigation in 1954 described the barrow as an earthwork mound 10 metres in diameter and 1 metre high, although it appears to have been substantially larger when excavated.  The round barrow is visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs of 1947.**Research on Hengistbury Head volumes** In Reading library Folio & std 913 4233_Hen & Std 913-32-Soc/3<gg summary>: A bowl barrow (Bushe-Fox II/Cunliffe 7) with a sand mound containing many worked flints deliberately introduced* and no central burial, but at least 7 presumed secondary burials in the western half of the mound. There were also 8 small pockets of burnt material in a tight group towards the eastern margin of the mound averaging 0.3m in diameter and 0.1-2m deep, and containing oak charcoal. At least three of the urns contained cremations, one that of an adult in a large biconical urn of Trevisker style set upright and accompanied by several flint flakes. Oak charcoal accompanied two of the urned cremations. Portions of collared urn and food vessels also were recovered from this barrow but not associated with cremations. [*The surrounding soil was bare of flint]. No evidence for a primary burtial noted
Site_description: This round barrow is situated on the northern part of Warren Hill, Hengistbury Head, one of a group of four adjacent barrows or mounds. It was about 30 metres in diameter and about 2 metres high. It was excavated as Barrow II by H. Bushe-Fox in 1911. No description of the excavation was given, but at least one urn was found at a level below the old ground surface. No central burial was found, but at least seven probably secondary burials were found in pots in the western half of the mound. In addition eight small groups of burnt material, seven in a tight group in the eastern part of the mound, may represent further uncontained cremations. The pottery recovered from the barrows included a biconical urn of the Trevisker series, part of a collared urn and two food vessels of rather crude manufacture. A large quantity of worked flint was found, most of which does not survive, but included residual Upper Paleolithic artefacts.  (1)(2)It was surveyed in 1954 and described as " A mutilated heather-covered mound. Diam 10.0m, Ht 1.0m. " (3)The round barrow described above in (1-3) is visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs of 1947.  The barrow is formed of a sub-circular mound measuring 25 m in diameter.  A linear ditch can be seen in the centre of the mound and what appears to be a cut into the south western quadrant.  These features are both probably the results of the excavations described above in (1-2).  (4)  The site is still visible on the most recent comprehensive aerial imagery available to the project.  (5)  This site was digitally plotted during the South West rapid Coastal Zone Assessment Survey (Dorset).

Site_summary: Bronze Age round barrow on north east part of Warren Hill, Hengistbury Head. It was excavated in 1919 by Harold St George Gray <gg summary>: Cremation in a collared urn was recovered from the centre of the mound. Parts of two further pottery vessels were also recovered associated with burnt material.Secondary series collared urn with a cremation set upright in the barrow floor more or less centrally in the mound. It was surrounded with a black material, possibly burnt sandy mould mixed with considerable traces of charcoal. The inside was coated with well preserved sphagnum moss.The inside of pot was covered with sphagnum moss
Site_description: This round barrow is situated in the northeast part of Warren Hill, Hengistbury Head. It was about 10.3 metres in diameter and about 0.5 metres high. It was excavated as Mound H by H. St George Gray in July 1919. He dug a trench 8.8m by 3m through this barrow, subsequently the trench was enlarged. The barrow mound was described as consisting of a layer of sand with flint pebbles with a c. 0.2m thick layer of peaty topsoil over. The mound sealed an old land surface represented by 'tufts of heather and fern'.  A single urned cremation was recovered in roughly the centre of the mound set in a small pit with the rim of the Collared Urn roughly at old ground surface level and surrounded by burnt material. This was probably the primary burial. The urn was of Longworth's Secondary Series, South-eastern Style, form Bi/ii.  Parts of two other pots were also recovered from the southern part of the barrow associated with charcoal and burnt deposits of oak and hazel. (1) (2)Grinsell described the barrow as having a slight ditch. (3) However, in 1954 the barrow was described as "A heather-covered mound, 7.5m in diameter and 0.7m high, and extensively mutilated by trenching. No trace of a ditch." (4)

Site_summary: A Bronze Age round barrow at the east end of Warren Hill, Hengistbury Head, excavated in 1919 by St George Gray. An inverted cinerary urn over a cremation was discovered near the centre of the mound. Three other burnt areas were also recorded.Poorly cremated burial
Site_description: A round barrow situated at the east end of Warren Hill, Hengistbury Head, excavated by St George Gray in July 1919. Before excavation the barrow measured 14 m in diameter and 0.7 m high. A complete cinerary urn inverted over a poorly cremated burial of a 40+ year old woman was found near the centre of the barrow. It was surrounded by burnt material. Three other burnt patches were found. Very little other pottery was recovered and is now lost. It appears to have included some Collared Urn sherds. A small fragment of Iron Age pot is also said to have been found. A large number of worked flints was recovered including some residual possibly Mesolithic flints.  (1)It was surveyed in 1954 and described as  a heather covered mound, 8.0m in diameter and 0.5m high with a large hollow in the centre  (2)

Site_summary: Four domestic beakers, fragments of 'B' , a fragment of another large unclassified beaker and three sherds of rusticated ware, an Urn or food vessel of Wessex type with a scraper and possible inhumation and a flower pot urn inverted with a cremation were found during gravel workings at Latch Farm in a number of locations over the 9 acre gravel digging area between 1927 and 1939. Palaeolithic, Mesolithic, Neolithic and Iron age artefacts were also found and noted by Druitt. The gravel pit or pits at Latch Farm extends from Cottage Houses south to Mill Road and are also known as Furzy, Lower Close Gravel Pit and Newmans Gravel Pit. The object were found in an area of Terrace 4 Gravel geology.<gg_summary>: One Beaker burial and stray EBA burials (and finds) recovered from the gravel quarry at Latch Farm, Christchurch. The E/MBA barrow and cremation cemetery excavated by Piggott in 1937 is logged separately (SID20247).
Site_description: Lower Close is the old name of the field in which Latch Farm buildings are situated. It extends from the Cottage Homes southward to Mill Road. Druitt was in close touch with the gravel workings on this land from 1927-39 when some 9 acres were dug. The following finds were made: Palaeolithic - 48 hand axes (Acheulian) Mesolithic - microcores Neolithic - fragment of rechipped axe EBA - four domestic beakers, fragments of B found 15 December, 1930 in a gravel pit a few yards east of Latch Farmhouse, fragment of farmhouse, another found with 3 sherds of rusticated ware 20 yds WNW of the barrow. E/MBA - urn or food vessel of Wessex type found with a scraper and probably with an inhumation in a pit 5 feet 6 inches deep. MBA - flower pot urn, inverted with cremation in pit 4 feet 6 inches deep within 100 of barrow. Cornish type EIA - A1 and A2 sherds found in 1927. RB - Storage jar rim, amphora stub found. (1) Gravel working has now finished in this area and the pits are now overgrown or allotments. (2) Monument Periods And Types -

Site_name_other: Bronze Age urned cremation burial behind Christchurch Station
Site_summary: A Bronze Age pottery vessel containing calcined bone was found, according to its label, behind Christchurch Station in 1886. It is now in Birmingham Museum, having been presented to the museum by a man who bought it in an antique shop in Swanage.<gg summary> Undecorated Collared Urn almost full of cremated bone
Site_description: Middle Bronze Age tripartite urn found 1886, behind Christchurch Station. Now in Birmingham Museum. (1) (SZ 15269322) Bought many years ago in a Swanage antique shop. As purchased it was labelled as being from behind Christchurch Station. Presented by the purchaser - not a local person - to Birmingham City Museum. (2) The urn, of plain coarse pottery without decoration, is 10 3/4 ins high and 8 3/4 ins broad at the top, with a lip one inch in depth. When discovered, it was nearly full of calcined bone. At Birmingham Nat Hist. Museum. (3)

Site_summary: Barrow excavated by C M Piggott in 1937 owing to its imminent destruction by gravel digging.<gg_summary>: Round barrow, associated cremation cemetery and other potentially associated burials recorded separately in the Dorset HER as MDOs 8675 (barrow) 8676 (cremation cemetery) and 8663 (stray/potentially associated Bronze Age discoveries). The central/primary burials are EBA in date; the broader cremation cemetery mostly MBA. The barrow and cremation cemetery are grouped here for interpretative reasons. Relevant details from MDO8676 are logged in the site description field. Stray burials (potentially associated with other barrows) are logged within SID20245.Due to the character of the excavation and the details given in the published report it is not possible to be entirely clear about which urns were/weren't associated with human remains. It is noted that there were 'several' urns with no human remains but only one instance is mentioned in the pottery catalogue. All urns potentially associated with hr are recorded here since it appears that most were. This includes the four urns NOT released for inclusion in the site publication, and the two food vessels directly associated with hr and eight [MBA] urns found after the main excavation. The specific form of Dev Rim pot (bucket, globular, etc.) is only assigned where this is mentioned specifically in Piggott (1938) or Calkin (1962).Note there was another Collared Urn (Longworth 1984:185, No  401) with vertical grooved lines of the collar, from a pit. But no mention of associated cremated remains
Site_description: Tumulus (OE) (Site of) (1) Site of LBA cemetery found 1937. (2) Bell-Barrow (c) Barrow excavated by C M Piggott in 1937 owing to its imminent destruction by gravel digging. Three pits revealed, two contained primary burials; the other had been refilled soon after digging. One of the primary pits contained an MBA cinerary urn with the cremated bones of two children; the other contained a cremated burial in the carbonised remains of a tree-trunk coffin, with a bronze pin, which possibly had been used to fasten the material in which the bones had been wrapped. Further excavation revealed that the southern half of the barrow had been used as an LBA urnfield with cremations totalling 90, of which only 70 were burials with urns. (1-8)<MDO8676>: (SZ 15159395) Tumulus (OE) (Site of) (1) Site of LBA cemetery found 1937. (2) Bell-Barrow (c) Barrow excavated by C M Piggott in 1937 owing to its imminent destruction by gravel digging. Three pits revealed, two contained primary burials; the other had been refilled soon after digging. One of the primary pits contained an MBA cinerary urn with the cremated bones of two children; the other contained a cremated burial in the carbonised remains of a tree-trunk coffin, with a bronze pin, which possibly had been used to fasten the material in which the bones had been wrapped. Further excavation revealed that the southern half of the barrow had been used as an LBA  urnfield with cremations totalling 90, of which only 70 were burials with urns, of barrel, bucket and globular types. A fragment of 'A' beaker was found on the old surface beneath the barrow. Representative collection of finds in RED HOUSE MUSEUM, Christchurch (d) In the following two years (1938-39) the parts of the barrow left unexcavated were destroyed in gravel digging and two MBA food vessels, one containing a child's cremation and in the barrow's centre, and eight LBA bucket urns were found (e). There is no trace of this barrow, the site falling within a disused gravel pit. (3) During gravel digging in 1936, a ridged food vessel was found inverted over a cremation 10 yds NNW of the barrow, at a depth of 4'6". In Red House Museum. (4)

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: The cremation urn recovered from this site in 1969 is recorded separately in the Dorset HER (MWX2791) but is grouped with this record in the ggdb. The relevant finds details have been copied into this record.<gg summary>: inverted Collared Urn containing remains of a child. NB. The site appears to have been the focus for some kind of late Neolithic activity prior to a mound being constructed and an urned cremation inserted during the early Bronze AgeNote J. Gardiner and others (1985) during fieldwork showed the entire mound to be covered with burnt flint, struck flakes and scrapers which had been brought to the surface by animals. The site seems to have been the focus for some kind of late Neolithic activity prior to a mound being constructed
Site_description: Ancient Pottery fragments found AD 1921 (NAT) (1) Bronze Age urn fragments, found by H. St. G. Gray 1921. Now in Taunton Museum. (2) Site excavated in autumn of 1921 by H. St. G. Gray (No report of excavation, or ref. to same is given). (3) No details have ever been given, and no report published. Finds are packed away in Taunton Museum (a). (4) SZ 16959185. Excavation of an eroded area of the 160ft. diameter mound, partially dug in 1921, produced more Bronze Age pottery and an inverted collared urn containing the cremation of a child. An amber bead was also found; other material consisted of a large number of flint flakes and artefacts of Mesolithic to Bronze Age date. (5) Monument Periods And Types.'The site of a round barrow known as Crouch Hill, located on Stanpit Marsh, was excavated by Harold St George Gray in 1921-22. In 1969 further excavation was undertaken by M Ridley. At the time of Gray's excavation, the mound was 48 metres in diameter and 1.6 metres high. No ditch was encountered in either excavation. The mound largely comprised sand, clay and turf, but had suffered severely from rabbit burrows. Because of the amount of 19th century material recovered, Gray was convinced that the mound was of modern origin, despite the quantity of prehistoric material also present within and beneath the mound. Ridley's 1969 excavation was never published, but an account of his work and a description of the finds from his and Gray's trenches was published by Cunliffe et al (1987). Gray had believed much of the pottery he found to be Bronze Age urn sherds, and although some were indeed Early Bronze Age, most were of Grooved Ware. Many of the sherds appeared as discrete deposits, some associated with flint implements. The pottery also appeared to have been deposited as sherds rather than complete vessels. A large burnt patch encountered by Gray comprised blackened sand and charcoal, with further sherds mixed in. Some small fragments of burnt material may have been bone, but Gray was unsure about their identification. (6) The 1969 excavation recovered further flints and Grooved Ware, and an almost complete inverted collared urn containing the cremated remains of a child. Large quantities of burnt flint were also found. Field-walking in 1984 across the site recovered large quantities of burnt flint, struck flakes and scrapers from the surface of the mound. Ridley also referred to the discovery of an amber bead and artefacts of Mesolithic to Bronze Age date.' (7)The site appears to have been the focus for some kind of late neolithic activity prior to a mound being constructed and an urned cremation inserted during the early Bronze Age (6).The Bronze Age barrow is visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs of 1947.  The barrow is formed of a sub-circular mound measuring 18 m in diameter.  (9)  The site is not visible on the most recent comprehensive aerial imagery available to the project.  (10)  This site was digitally plotted during the South West rapid Coastal Zone Assessment Survey (Dorset).

Site_summary: Bowl barrow containing a cremation and flint flakes.<gg_summary>: The collared urn cremation excavated in 1974 is recorded separately in the Dorset HER (MDO19458) but is grouped with this record for interpretative purposes here.<MDO19458>: Members oF South Wessex Archaeological Association discovered and excavated a cremation urn discovered protruding from the top of a bowl barrow during a survey of St Catherine's Hill in January 1974.It was an Early Bronze Age collared urn inverted with the base and some of the contents missing. Fragments of cremated bone suggested that the burial was that of a youth. The broken remains of an inverted pigmy cup were also found, as was a carbonised fragment of a hazel kernel.The urn was found on the northern face of the barrow close to the north eastern corner of the 1921 excavation trench.
Site_description: Bowl barrow. Diameter 14 paces, height 3 1/2ft. Excavated in 1921 by W.G.Wallace. Finds include a Middle Bronze Age urn of over-hanging rim type in an inverted position and containing a cremation - portions of the base and one side of the urn were missing, 2 flint flakes were found beneath the urn. (2-4) Finds in Bournemouth NH & SS Museum. (5) A bowl barrow, 12.0m. diameter, 0.8m. high, with the faint suggestion of a ditch in the south and east quadrants. (6) No change; published NSL 1:2500 survey correct. (7) A disturbed burial urn was found in 1974 protruding from the top of this heavily eroded bowl barrow. It was removed for examination and found to be an Early Bronze Age collared urn, inverted, containing a cremation burial and the broken remains of a pigmy cup. (8)

Site_summary: A Bronze Age fragmented pottery urn and a cremation burial found  in 1989 during the building of a  new Sainsbury's store. The urn was discovered inverted in the earth after the removal of the topsoil.Note the reference to this is verbal communication so unless there is something a little more concrete to go on then it's all a bit vague; Collared Urn cremation
Site_description: A Bronze Age fragmented pottery urn and a cremation, which was found by a member of the construction staff building a new Sainsbury's store at Christchurch, in the summer of 1989. He reported that it was revealed by removal of topsoil - about 300mm thick - which removed the base of the urn, since it was inverted. It has a rim diameter of 260mm and is presently in the possession of Poole Museum Services (2/91). Pers. Comm. Dai Watkins, Poole Museums Service 2/91. (1)

Site_name_other: Site of Bronze Age Round Barrow
Site_summary: Bronze Age round barrow excavated in 1941 in advance of the construction of RAF Hurn. It contained an urned cremation burial in a central pit.<gg_summary>: Also worthy of note is a) odd green-grey aquatic clay lumps in the mound construction and forming a separate 'dome' on the ground surface (these contained quantities of marine shells and also a small lump of Bathstone which must have been imported to the site); b) on the west side of the barrow 'ditch', a large number of worked and unworked flints were found, many of them apparently deliberately grouped round a greenish clay dome placed more or less in the centre of the ditch soon after the partial infilling of the ditch.
Site_description: Bronze Age turf round barrow,which survived about 12 m in diameter and 1.4 m  high before WW2. This barrow was excavated in 1941 in advance of the construction of RAF Hurn. It contained a cremation burial in a Deverel-Rimbury urn placed in a small central pit. Beside this and on the surface was a square stain about 5 mm thick which may have been the remains of folded leather or cloth. (1)

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Only two cremation burials excavated so recorded as a funerary site rather than an urnfield here. Cremation-related features. POSSIBLY component of larger funerary / cremation site?
Site_description: Two adjacent cremation related features of Middle Bronze Age date. One contained an urned cremation (possibly two individuals), the other comprised a pit containing a charcoal-rich fill and some bone, also possibly derived from two individuals. It is possible that the pit represents the remains of the pyre on which the two individuals burned in the urned cremation were buried. The fragmentary remains of another urn were noted in a truncated pit approx. 2m away, but no cremation-type deposit survived.SITE POSSIBLY REPRESENTS COMPONENT OF A LARGER CREMATION CEMETERY -THOUGH THIS COULD NOT BE EXPLORED WITHIN CONSTRAINTS OF PIPELINE ARCHAEOLOGY.A further pit was observed some 50m to the North of Southdown Farm (c300m upslope). This contained only a single diagnostic sherd of pottery, though was dated as being approx. contemporary with the cremation features.All 3 features contained traces of grain and chaff, suggestive of the presence of a nearby settlement.(1).

Site_name_other: Late Bronze Age Cremation Burial, Christchurch
Site_summary: A single disturbed Late Bronze Age cremation burial, associated with 30 sherds of pottery representing a single vessel.
Site_description: A disturbed Bronze Age Cremation Burial, associated with 30 sherds of pottery representing a single vessel, found during an archaeological evaluation.  The cremated bone recovered was in poor condition and could only be determined to be an adult/sub-adult.(1)

Site_summary: A Late Bronze Age urned cremation burial was found during an evaluation excavation by Wessex Archaeology in 2001. The Late Bronze Age urn containing cremated human bone was found just below the ploughsoil. Another similar urn was found nearby in a small scoop, but no cremated bone was found. (1)
Site_description: A Late Bronze Age urned cremation burial and possibly one other were found during an evaluation excavation by Wessex Archaeology in 2001. A Late Bronze Age urn containing cremated human bone was found just below the ploughsoil. The upper part of the vessel had been ploughed away. No visible grave cut was identified. Another urn, this one inverted, was found nearby in a small scoop, but no cremated bone was found. (1)

Site_summary: Early Middle and Late Bronze Age phases of Activity identified in Field R<gg_summary>: A single urned cremation.
Site_description: Early Bronze Age: Two small sherds of Beaker pottery found in a Roman ditch and a single sherd of biconical urn was retrieved from a scoopMiddle Bronze Age: 62 features comprising pits (and charcoal pits see WX3516), scoops, postholes, and one ditch/gully. Two 'special' deposits and five single 'pot' deposits of note and two areas of intense activity observed. One area 13m x 13m included: a shallow sub-circular gully with finds, concentrated to the centre of the ring, suggesting an industrial function; a ring of postholes with a 7m diameter, probably representing a roundhouse, two postholes were capped with a 0.1m layer of raw white clay; an oval pit with pottery from at least three vessels. The other area was 10m x 13m and included: a ring of postholes with an internal pit and three internal postholes that may have been part of an internal dividing structure; a storage pit with raw and fired clay from pottery manufacture and pottery, worked flint, burnt flint, burnt hearthstone, limestone, shale and a few fragments of bone. There was an absence of features in the south and east of the whole excavated area.Late Bronze Age: A cluster of features consisting of pits, scoops and postholes presented no discernible pattern One pit had been lined with large pieces of hearthstone. The fill was rich in charcoal and ash and there was evidence of in situ burning. Pottery fragments, raw and fired clay, charcoal, burnt hearthstone and burnt flint found in many features suggesting industrial activity. A single urned cremation was also found. The charcoal rich pot fill contained human bone, possibly from more than one body (1)

Site_name_other: Bronze Age domestic area and cremations
Site_summary: Most features of MBA date consisting of linears, pits and postholes. A complex domestic area and two cremations on the boundary of the settlement were identified<gg_summary>: The final excavation report mentions just one cremation in this area (J231), recorded here
Site_description: Early Bronze Age: no features but some worked flint including a fine tanged arrowhead found on the surface of a ditchMiddle Bronze Age: 46 features, majority associated with complex domestic area divided into three phases   Phase 1: east-west ditch across the site, max width 2m, depth 0.88m; round steep sided pit containing burnt flint and charcoal and pottery including a sherd from a large urn; three other ditches varying from 1.3m to 0.74m wide and 0.5-0.85m deep, finds included worked and burnt flint, part of a hearthstone quern and small quantities of pottery. Large flat slab of partly fired red clay retrieved   Phase 2: hut structure consisting of an eaves drip gully which enclosed 26 postholes and 7 stake holes in haphazard layout. Surviving terminal of ditch suggests and east facing entrance. Gully 0.5m wide and 0.26m deep. Central hearth of gravel cobbles et into a matrix of baked clay and charcoal. Fragments of a corrugated copper alloy bracelet found in soils above the hearth. Nearby was an area of burnt red sand. Within the hut a pit with vertical sides and a flat base may have been for storage. North-south ditch lay directly west of the hut, 1m wide and 0.65m deep on average. Contained pottery including fine Deverel Rimbury vessels and thick walled urns. Two further ditches dated to this phase on ceramic evidence   Phase 3: short period of intense activity after the hut went out of use. Pit (7.5m x 3.25m x 1.2m deep) dug 5m east of the hut. A second triangular shaped pit  (3.5m x 4.75m x 4m x 0.72m deep) contained pottery, raw clay, charcoal and a copper alloy twisted bracelet with tapered ends. Large pieces of hearthstone embedded in raw clay close by. A third pit filled with burnt flint. Spread of burnt flint in hut doorway. Rich pottery assemblage including sherds from fine globular urns, small, medium and large bucket urns.In addition:   Two cremations excavated, one with a tiny inverted pot in a pit only just large enough for the vessel and a second cremation in a vertical sided pit and a vessel decorated with applied cordon and fingerprint impressions, Two pots separated by 200m and may have been on the boundaries of the settlement area.   Two 'special' deposits in pits also revealed one with at least twelve Deverel Rimbury vessels represented and another, isolated from other BA activity, with a compact fill of 13 ceramic loom weights and sherds from two urns, one plain and one with applied cordon and fingerprints.   Cluster of pit type features, probably associated with the hut structure. In one pit two large postholes were revealed under a sticky clay fill. Pottery, burnt flint, hearthstone and clay suggest small scale industrial activity   9 charcoal pits of MBA date (see WX3516)Late Bronze Age: few features and very small amounts of pottery, generally small and undiagnostic sherds identified of fabric types

Site_summary: A probable Bell Barrow constructed in the centre of the Flagstones Neolithic enclosure in the early 2nd millennium BC. There was a central crouched inhumation burial sealed beneath a large sarsen stone. This was sealed beneath a mound constructed of chalk quarried from a surrounding ring ditch. The barrow was subsequently remodelled with the addition of material from groups of quarry pits around its circumference.<gg_summary>: Overarching site record (barrow) associated with an inhumation recorded in MDO18075 (see below).<MDO28075>: A grave was cut into the centre of the Flagstones Neolithic enclosure in the early 2nd millennium BC. It was also located in the centre of the Flagstones central ring ditch. The grave contained a crouched young adult male sealed beneath a large sarsen stone. A copper alloy rivet was found in the grave fill. A radiocarbon date of 2130-1710 cal BC at 2 sigma (HAR-9159) was obtained from the burial.A grave lay at the centre of the Neolithic segmented enclosure. It also lay in the centre of the central ring ditch and it is likely it is associated with the ring-ditch, probably originally forming part of a round barrow, now ploughed out.It comprised an ovoid pit [00430] 3m by 2.6m across with a ledge 0.6m wide and 0.2m deep on the south and a steep-sided near-circular pit 0.9m deep to the north. On the base of the pit was a badly preserved skeleton of a young adult male, perhaps originally crouched. The skeleton was sealed beneath primary silts and rubble. A large irregular unworked sarsen had been placed 0.25m above the skeleton. Above the stone were successive chalk rubble fills, much disturbed by root action. A radiocarbon date of the early 2nd millennium BC (2130-1710 cal BC: HAR-9159) was obtained from the skeleton.A copper alloy rivet was found in the upper fill of the grave pit, which also contained 66 pieces of worked flint of Bronze Age character and included a Portland Chert oblique arrowhead. There was  a range of intrusive material including a post-medieval copper alloy lace tag, an unidentified iron object, one sherd of Late Iron Age pottery, four post-medieval sherds and some ceramic building material from this pit.
