Three residual sherds of Neolithic bowl were also recovered. 16 pieces of animal bone were recovered from this pit, including cattle, pig and sheep/goat.
Site_description: A probable round barrow was found in the centre of the Neolithic enclosure and was partly revealed by excavation at Flagstones by Wessex Archaeology in 1987-1988 in advance of the construction of the Dorchester By-pass. The full circuit has not been determined. The following description is abstracted from the final published report on the site (1). The numbers in square brackets refer to context numbers quoted in the report.Ring-ditch [00165] lay in the centre of the Neolithic enclosure and was only partly within the excavated area. It appeared to be set out around a central burial [00430] which contained the crouched inhumation of a young adult male beneath a large sarsen. The ring-ditch measured about 28m in diameter and was 0.75m deep with near vertical sides and a flat base. The chalk surface within the ring ditch survived 160mm higher than the external chalk level. This has been interpreted as a protected surface formerly covered by a barrow mound. The shape of the protected chalk surface suggests this was a bell barrow.Four clusters of intersecting pits were spaced around the outer edge of the ring-ditch. These were subcircular to ovoid in plan, bowl-shaped profile and up to 2m across and 0.75m deep. Two pits in the west cluster cut the chalk rubble fills of the ring-ditch. They were generally filled with chalk rubble with secondary fills above similar to those from the ring-ditch. Fairly large quantities of Bronze Age flint were found in these pit clusters, but was particularly concentrated in the north cluster. These pits are thought to have provided additional material for recovering or re-emphasising the barrow mound, perhaps indicating the application of a fresh covering of white chalk. The date of this activity is not known.This monument is dated by the early 2nd millennium BC radiocarbon date from the central burial (2130-1710 cal BC at 2 sigma: HAR-9159). The finds from the ring-ditch and quarry pits confirm the Bronze Age date for this monument. The ring- ditch contained  a very large quantity of worked Bronze Age flint, a small quantity of Bronze Age grog tempered pottery and some animal bone. Three sherds of Bronze Age grog tempered pottery were recovered from the quarry pits.Molluscan evidence from the ring-ditch suggests that the immediate vicinity was arable during the period of silting up of the ditch, within a generally very open landscape.

Site_name_other: Late Iron Age / Early Roman Cemetery
Site_summary: A small Late Iron Age - Early Roman cemetery was found on site C during the 1966-79 excavations at Poundbury, Dorchester. Twelve oval and rectangular graves were found containing the remains of fourteen burials. These lay along or just to the west of a Late Iron Age boundary ditch, with only a single grave to the east of the boundary. Where it could be determined, the burials were either crouched or contracted. This burial group contained four adult males, four adult females, one child and two infant inhumation burials. Only two graves contained grave goods; copper alloy finger ring dated to 50BC-AD50 and a faience bead. It seems likely that these burials dated from the middle of the 1st century BC to the beginning of the 2nd century AD. They are probably contemporaneous with those found on Sites E and F, further to the NW.<gg_summary>: One of three partially excavated clusters of LIA/early Roman burials at Poundbury. 67 inhumation burials were recovered in total including women, men, children and a large number of infants and neonates. A group comprising an adult male and 22 child/neonate burials was located at the northen end of site E; a group of adult men and women - many with grave goods - was located in the southern part of Site E and in Site F; a further group of adults and infants was located in site C (c. 2-300m south of Sites E and F). In all but one case, grave goods were associated with adult inhumations (about half of these). These objects have all been dated to the period 100 BC to AD 100.
Site_description: Found during the excavations directed by Christopher Sparey Green, for the Dorchester Excavation Committee, between 1966 and 1979 during development of the Grove Trading Estate on the eastern slopes of Poundbury Camp, Dorchester (1). The numbers in square brackets below refer to the context and feature numbers used in the published report and archive (1) (2).Twelve inhumation graves containing the remains of fourteen burials were found in the southern part of Site C. These burials were all in rectangular, circular or oval graves and where it could be determined they were either crouched or contracted burials. No trace of a coffin was found in any of these graves and only two contained grave goods. Grave [C265] contained a faience bead and grave [C432] contained a copper alloy finger ring dated to 50BC-AD50. This burial group contained four adult males, four adult females, one child and two infant inhumation burials.Graves [424], [432], [453] and [459] post-dated a Late Iron Age boundary ditch. Grave [265] pre-dated the building of Roman structure R12. It seems likely that these burials dated from the middle of the 1st century BC to the beginning of the 2nd century AD. They are probably contemporaneous with those found on Sites E and F, further to the NW.

Site_name_other: Late Iron Age / Early Roman Cemetery
Site_summary: A Late Iron Age - Early Roman cemetery containing at least 42 burials was found on site E-F during the 1966-79 excavations at Poundbury, Dorchester, with a further burial found during observations of the Poundbury pipeline in 1986. The burials were mainly crouched and laid on their right sides. No single grave orientation was present, but burial with the head to the east was the most popular. Eight burials contained grave goods, of which five contained pottery vessels dating to the middle of the 1st century AD, two contained copper alloy rings dating to 50BC-AD50, and one contained a copper alloy brooch datable to 75-25BC. Animal bone was deliberately deposited in four graves.There was a concentration of infant and neonate burials found in the area of the Late Iron Age and Early Roman unenclosed settlement. It appears that stillborn infants may have been buried under the floor or walls of buildings and adults were buried outside but still close to the living area. The earliest burial is contemporary with the latest Iron Age houses and the latest with the Early Roman rectangular buildings. It seems likely that these burials dated from the middle of the 1st century BC to the beginning of the 2nd century AD. They are probably contemporaneous with those found on Site C, further to the SE.<gg_summary>: One of three partially excavated clusters of LIA/early Roman burials at Poundbury. 67 inhumation burials were recovered in total including women, men, children and a large number of infants and neonates. A group comprising an adult male and 22 child/neonate burials was located at the northern end of site E; a group of adult men and women - many with grave goods - was located in the southern part of Site E and in Site F; a further group of adults and infants was located in site C (c. 2-300m south of Sites E and F). In all but one case, grave goods were associated with adult inhumations (about half of these). These objects have all been dated to the period 100 BC to AD 100. Based on Rigby's summary of the pottery vessels in graves (102-4), graves with pottery vessels are not included here - these are all fairly securely of post conquest date.
Site_description: Found during the excavations directed by Christopher Sparey Green, for the Dorchester Excavation Committee, between 1966 and 1979 during development of the Grove Trading Estate on the eastern slopes of Poundbury Camp, Dorchester. The numbers in square brackets below refer to the context and feature numbers used in the published report and archive (1) (2).Forty-one inhumation graves, probably dating to the Late Iron Age/ Early Roman period  were found on Sites E and F; another burial was found to the north during the recording of the Poundbury Pipeline (3). These burials were  in rectangular, circular or oval graves and where it could be determined most burials were crouched, with a few contracted burials and several laid on their back with the legs drawn up, and one was prone with the legs flexed. Almost all the burials were laid on their right side. There was no single grave orientation, though burials laid with the head to the east were the most numerous, followed by those with the head to the west and to the south.  Three graves [ E1348, E1364, E1391] produced coffin nails indicating the former presence of a coffin. Eight burials contained grave goods, of which five contained pottery vessels dating to the middle of the 1st century AD, two contained copper alloy rings dating to 50BC-AD50, and one contained a copper alloy brooch datable to 75-25BC. Grave [E1348] had two pottery vessels by the head and a sheep skull deposited as grave goods. Grave [E1351] had four pots placed around the head. Grave [E135] had a pig's head buried with the body. Grave [E1367] had a pot between the arms of the burial. The infant burial in Grave [E1391] had a pot beside the head. Grave[F1402] contained articulated animal bones, presumably the remains of a joint of meat, beside the left hand and three copper alloy finger rings were found on the right hand. Grave [F1403] had a copper alloy brooch found near the left shoulder of the skeleton. Grave [F1409] had articulated animal bones near the right knee and a copper alloy ring on the left hand.A stratigraphically important group of 1 adult and 22 neonates and babies up to 1 year old was excavated in the NE corner of site E, coincident with the occupation terrace of the late Iron Age open settlement and the early Roman settlement.It appears that the majority of these burials on Sites E and F date from the middle of the 1st century to the beginning of the 2nd century AD and span the period from the currency of the latest Iron Age round-houses to that of the post-built rectangular structures in the early Roman period. The contemporaneity of graves and structures suggests a tradition of burying stillborn and very young children within the living area while adults were buried outside but still close to the settlement.

Site_summary: Evidence for a Bronze Age double ring-ditch was discovered during excavations at Alington Avenue in the SW corner of the main site. It comprised a pair of contiguous penannular ditches, forming a double or bi-lobate enclosure with a central causeway on the north side. The eastern ditch was the larger and surrounded a slight circular structure set almost centrally within it. The eastern ditch cut through the secondary fills of the long barrow. There were no other stratigraphic links with major landscape features on the site, although the same ditch was cut by a Durotrigian and a late Roman burial. It seems to have been respected by later boundary features up to the late Roman period , suggesting that it survived as an earthwork until that time at least. It contained three tightly crouched early Bronze Age inhumation burials inserted into the secondary fill of the eastern ditch. Two Iron Age pit burials were also found within the area enclosed by the eastern ditch.<gg_summary>: Overarching record for a series of inhumations associated with a round barrow. The inhumations are logged separately in the HER as MDOs18525-7 (Bronze Age) and MDOs18530-1 (Iron Age pit burials). Details of the separate inhumation records are collated within separate grave records here. None of these associated records were linked to finds records. One of the three BA inhumations and one of the two pit burials associated with the ring ditch were associated with grave goods.
Site_description: Found during a series of evaluations and excavations conducted by Wessex Archaeology at Alington Avenue, Fordington, Dorchester between 1984 and 1987. The results of the excavations have been published as a Dorset Natural History and Archaeological Society Monograph; (DNHAS Monograph 15). The numbers in square brackets below refer to the context and feature numbers used in the published report (1).Bronze Age double Ring-Ditch [2300] was located in the SW corner of the main site. It comprised a pair of contiguous penannular ditches, forming a double or bi-lobate enclosure with a central causeway on the north side. The eastern ditch [1600] was the larger and surrounded a slight circular structure [1100] set almost centrally within it. The eastern ditch [1600] cut through the secondary fills of the southern ditch [1998] of the long barrow [2000]. There were no other stratigraphic links with major landscape features on the site, although the same ditch [1600] was cut by a Durotrigian [1138] and a late Roman [1144] burial. It seems to have been respected by later boundary features up to the late Roman period , suggesting that it survived as an earthwork until that time at least. The two ditches making up the monument [1600] & [2350] abutted each other on the south side in what appeared to be a deliberate and contemporary manner, though on the north side a 2.5m causeway remained between the two terminals. The ditches appear to have been cut as a continuous single structure with no re-cuts or cleaning episodes.  The eastern ditch [1600] had an external diameter of c.37m and the western ditch [2350] had a diameter of c.30m. they both had regular steep-sided, flat based profiles along the whole of their length, reminiscent of the bipartite ring ditch further east. The depth of the ditch varied from 1m to 1.2m with a distinct step of c. 0.1m down to the base of the western ditch [2350].  The fills suggested that there may have been an external bank accompanying the ditch.There was no artefact dating evidence for the deposition of the fills but they were cut by three graves [127], [1582] & [3907], containing inhumation burials, one of which was submitted for radiocarbon dating, suggesting that by 2580-1920 cal BC the enclosure ditches were at least half filled up.The marked difference between the two areas enclosed by the two ditches was the presence within [1600] of a circular timber setting [1100], set slightly south of centre and  two Middle-Late Iron Age pit burials. Structure [1100] was 10.5m in diameter and formed by a series of stake holes linked together by a narrow, shallow trench. There were three apparent gaps in the circuit, although they may have been caused by erosion or damage. That the gaps were original however was suggested by their distribution on the NE, NW & SW sides, similar to that of the burials in ditch [1600]. The only finds from structure [1100] were a few very fragmentary animal bones.The ground plan of the monument is similar to that of a ditched double round barrow examples of which occur on the South Dorset Ridgeway. The circular stake structure [1100] may represent some form of funerary structure within which burials were placed, directly on to the ground surface, immediately prior to the construction of the mound. The three burials in ditch [1600] can be regarded as secondary burials, all inserted into secondary fills of the ditch. The late 3rd millennium date from burial [127] suggests that the Alington Avenue double barrow may be one of the earliest barrows on the Alington ridge

Site_summary: A beaker burial was found by AC archaeology during works at Dorchester Middle School, Coburg Road, Dorchester in 1998. The crouched inhumation burial aged 15-25 years with head to NW and the body facing E, with the left leg raised higher than the right was found in an oval grave. The burial was in a poor condition. A Beaker pot was placed at the feet, to the east of the body.
Site_description: A beaker burial was found by AC archaeology during works at Dorchester Middle School, Coburg Road, Dorchester in 1998 (1) (2). The crouched inhumation burial aged 15-25 years with head to NW and the body facing E, with the left leg raised higher than the right was found in an oval grave. The burial was in a poor condition. A Beaker pot was placed at the feet, to the east of the body.

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: no info in any of the HER records relating to this excavation (see events record for key details). Cremation from this round barrow is recorded separately (MDO18774). Truncated so difficult to establish whether associated pottery sherds represent grave goods.Based on Smith et al. 1993: Two cremation burials found in between ring ditches 3 and 4 from an extensive excavation. Both burials were heavily disturbed; one was potentially urned.<MDO18774> Between two of the ring-ditches were two pits containing cremations and a sherd of Middle Bronze Age pottery.
<gg_summary>: dodgy record with poor contextual detail, at least one of these graves was early Ro but the body with the small 1st century Durotrigian jar is recorded for now.
Site_description: <HER event desc.>: R.N.R. Peers and C.J. Bailey observed the excavation of a 2ft wide trench for water mains for the new Friars Close housing development` in the vicinity of Wareham Road during 1960.Inhumations, probably four in number, were observed in the trenches. The first was a large male extended W-E with the head tilted forward was observed some 44 yards from the Wareham Road. The grave had a rounded base, cut into the chalk and contained a few sherds of coarse pottery and samian but no grave goods. Human bones were also seen at two places 35 yds and 53 yds to the NNE. 6.5ft beyond the latter, human bones, of which a broken mandible was preserved, were found near a small 1st century Durotrigian jar. The jaw was of a 40+ year old male with peridontal disease. At least 7 shallow depressions, mostly saucer shaped, were observed cut into the chalk between the burials.

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: not in Whimster or Bristow - not clear why. Potentially Roman.
Site_description: <HER events description>: Observations were made by workmen whilst cutting back and concreting of a N facing scarp west of a small building used as a chlorinating room circa 1943.A crouched inhumation was found, although the remains are said to have been left in situ. However, cooking vessels placed between the knees were taken away soon after discovery.

Site_name_other: Masonic Hall, Prince's Street, Dorchester; Round barrow
Site_summary: Beaker Burial found under Masonic hall, probably originally covered by a barrow.<gg summary> cist with Beaker burial and within a ring ditch or barrow
Site_description: Found in 1902 when lowering the floor of the Masonic Hall, probably primary crouched inhumation in grave, with type B beaker by the arm, probably covered by a barrow the ditch of which was located (Grinsell).

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: LIA/early Roman inhumation cemetery excavated during the late 19th century and no detailed record survives. Whimster (1981, 345) provides a list of objects recovered some of which are clearly IA. The latter are recorded here within one grave record.NB Two additional HER records (MDOs19082-3) record ind graves with gg.
Site_description: <HER site description (within related event record)>: Three burials were found close together in elliptical graves with sides cut vertically into the chalk with heads to the W, E and probably SW. At least two were crouched on their right sides with hands touching their ankles. One of these had a bronze fibula on the forehead, probably securing a shroud, a flask by the breast and two black or grey urns touching the shins. The other had four vessels by the breast.South of these graves a circular pit, 2ft wide by 5ft deep, had a flagstone at the bottom with ox bones and bituminous material above it.Roman brick, tile and glass were found in the area [1] which was stripped to the chalk for 50ft to the south and west of the area of inhumations. No other burials were noted however, suggesting a small isolated group [2].<NRHE description>: Inhumations found in 1884 by Thomas Hardy, during building excavations for his house, Max Gate (70448991), about 1/2 mile S.E. of the Roman town. Of three burials apparently close together in 'elliptical' graves 4 ft by 2 1/2 ft., cut vertically in the Chalk, with heads W., E., and probably S.W., at least two were contracted on their right sides with hands touching the ankles. One of the latter had a bronze fibula on the skull between forehead and crown, probably securing a shroud, a flask by the breast, and two similar black or 'grey ware' urns touching the shins, with a half only of another urn beside them. The other had four vessels by the breast, also nearly upright but touching each other; two were of 'ordinary' size, two small. The burial less completely known to Hardy had 'two other urns of like description', and, it would seem, a second fibula. Two yards S. of these graves a circular pit, 2 ft. by 5 ft. deep, packed with flints, had a flagstone at bottom and above it an ox horn, with ox bones and teeth and pieces of bitumous matter. Some tile, Roman brick and glass were found in the area. Of many other skeletons, some were extended, some on their sides, with no consistent orientation. A large stone, 'set up at Max Gate as a menhir', covered one; from the brow of another Hardy took two bronze penannular brooches linked by an elaborately decorated bronze fibula of 'Maiden Castle' type with iron hinge-pin.A large pit contained remains of a horse, much ash, and an iron spear-head. The ring-neck flask of cream-coloured ware is comparable with Claudian examples form the Corfe Mullen kiln, but it may well have been prized for a generation or more before its consignment to the grave.The six black ware vessels preserved from the site are of early types not necessrily later than the 1st century A.D. These are bowls of Durotrigian classes 1, 1a, and 2; one is a globular Durotrigian bowl. The other two are small bowls or lids of less common native types - one, unburnished inside, perhaps influenced by the samian form 27, the other by form 18 or Belgic platters. Finds are in Dorset County Museum. (1)

Site_name_other: Two possible round barrows, South Walks, Dorchester
Site_summary: Two possible bell barrows set close together were discovered by Cunnington in 1864 beneath the Roman town rampart on South Walks. One barrow had a possibly primary urned cremation burial and several secondary inhumation '. There is no record of what was found in the other barrow.NOTE: The primary archive does not divulge any farther information or an image of the urn. It seems like the later inhumations in the mound all lacked grave goods
Site_description: When the Roman rampart at the east end of South Walks was levelled in 1865, Cunnington recorded two 'bell-shaped' barrows, only two feet apart. These barrows were apparently buried beneath the Roman rampart.  One barrow had a possibly primary urned cremation burial and several secondary inhumation burials buried 'sometimes singly and sometimes, two or three together'. There are no records of what was found in the other barrow. (1)

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: The two vessels recovered in 1846 are lumped within a single grave record here since their associations are unknown. The three pre-Conquest vessels recovered from a grave in 1884 are recorded separately.<Whimster 1981, 345, Allington Avenue/Wareham Road> Unknown number of earth grave inhumations discovered during railway work c.1846. Two associated pottery vessels survive in Dorset County museum. An additional grave found in 1884 contained three further Durotrigian vessels, all probably pre-Conquest.
Site_description: Inhumations and other remains were found NE of the Wareham Road (Alington Avenue) in 1846 in the making of the SW Railway cutting. Of many human bones and much black pottery from the work two late Iron Age bowls survive. Some of the discoveries came from a trench or ditch 7-8 ft deep containing much animal bones, pottery and some human teeth; this feature, running apparently NW-SE was seen again in 1884 as the cutting was widened [1].

Site_summary: One of four round barrows in a line at Thomas Hardye School. They show use in the Beaker period with crouched inhumations and then again in the EBA (Food Vessels and Collared Urns).This is the furthest west one
Site_description: <HER site description (originally within Events record): During the summer of 1994 a series of archaeological excavations and watching briefs was undertaken by Wessex Archaeology, on behalf of Dorset County Council, West Dorset District Council and The Thomas Hardye School in the vicinity of Thomas Hardye School in the southwest outskirts of Dorchseter, Dorset. The site comprises three archaeological projects that were originally administered and organised separately. These projects were Thomas Hardye School Playing Fields (Wessex Archaeology ref: 37838), Thomas Hardye School Music Rooms (Wessex Archaeology ref: 39273) and West Dorset Leisure Centre Artificial Pitch (Wessex Archaeology ref: 38074). A total of approximately 4.5 ha was investigated. The site lies on a gentle south-facing slope below a low chalk ridge between Maiden Castle and the River Frome. The north of the site lies close to the top of the ridge at about the 87 m OD contour.Geophysical survey prior to the excavation had revealed a number of linear and circular features indicateive of Bronze Age ring ditches and early field boundaries. On excavation two main foci of prehistoric activity were revealed.The remains of a substantial Bronze Age linear barrow cemetery were also recorded. These comprised five barrows of which four had surviving mound deposits. The barrows and their ditches contained burials, both cremations and inhumations, indicative of a prolonged period of use and development of the barrow cemetery. Finds, particularly the large quantities of worked flint, also suggested non-ritual use of the barrows. These barrows were significant monuments in their own right and the probably also formed part of an impressive barrow cemetery ranged along a chalk ridge to the east, including Fordington Farm barrow, Conquer Barrow and the barrow central to the Flagstones enclosure.After partial excavation of the barrows, a scheme for their preservation in situ was proposed and implemented which entailed their consolidation prior to reburial beneath up to 21.5 m of chalk.

Site_summary: One of four round barrows in a line at Thomas Hardye School. They show use in the Beaker period with crouched inhumations and then again in the EBA (Food Vessels and Collared Urns).This is the conjoined to 1004 and 1003 - unusual triple complex. It is the eastern one of the triple complex
Site_description: <her_event_desc>: During the summer of 1994 a series of archaeological excavations and watching briefs was undertaken by Wessex Archaeology, on behalf of Dorset County Council, West Dorset District Council and The Thomas Hardye School in the vicinity of Thomas Hardye School in the southwest outskirts of Dorchseter, Dorset. The site comprises three archaeological projects that were originally administered and organised separately. These projects were Thomas Hardye School Playing Fields (Wessex Archaeology ref: 37838), Thomas Hardye School Music Rooms (Wessex Archaeology ref: 39273) and West Dorset Leisure Centre Artificial Pitch (Wessex Archaeology ref: 38074). A total of approximately 4.5 ha was investigated. The site lies on a gentle south-facing slope below a low chalk ridge between Maiden Castle and the River Frome. The north of the site lies close to the top of the ridge at about the 87 m OD contour.Geophysical survey prior to the excavation had revealed a number of linear and circular features indicateive of Bronze Age ring ditches and early field boundaries. On excavation two main foci of prehistoric activity were revealed.The remains of a substantial Bronze Age linear barrow cemetery were also recorded. These comprised five barrows of which four had surviving mound deposits. The barrows and their ditches contained burials, both cremations and inhumations, indicative of a prolonged period of use and development of the barrow cemetery. Finds, particularly the large quantities of worked flint, also suggested non-ritual use of the barrows. These barrows were significant monuments in their own right and the probably also formed part of an impressive barrow cemetery ranged along a chalk ridge to the east, including Fordington Farm barrow, Conquer Barrow and the barrow central to the Flagstones enclosure.After partial excavation of the barrows, a scheme for their preservation in situ was proposed and implemented which entailed their consolidation prior to reburial beneath up to 21.5 m of chalk.

Site_summary: Barrow 1006 is situated to the east of the triple barrow complex. Two burials ; one burial (1444)  of an adult female lacking grave goods but with very large flint assemblage in the upper grave fill ; possibly 2ndary knapping and not grave goods. Pit just outside NE quadrant of barrow.Adult crouched female on right side head to SE. 14C date 21910-1850 cal BCAnother burial in centre of barrow with copper knife-dagger & antler
Site_description: <her_event_desc>: During the summer of 1994 a series of archaeological excavations and watching briefs was undertaken by Wessex Archaeology, on behalf of Dorset County Council, West Dorset District Council and The Thomas Hardye School in the vicinity of Thomas Hardye School in the southwest outskirts of Dorchseter, Dorset. The site comprises three archaeological projects that were originally administered and organised separately. These projects were Thomas Hardye School Playing Fields (Wessex Archaeology ref: 37838), Thomas Hardye School Music Rooms (Wessex Archaeology ref: 39273) and West Dorset Leisure Centre Artificial Pitch (Wessex Archaeology ref: 38074). A total of approximately 4.5 ha was investigated. The site lies on a gentle south-facing slope below a low chalk ridge between Maiden Castle and the River Frome. The north of the site lies close to the top of the ridge at about the 87 m OD contour.Geophysical survey prior to the excavation had revealed a number of linear and circular features indicateive of Bronze Age ring ditches and early field boundaries. On excavation two main foci of prehistoric activity were revealed.The remains of a substantial Bronze Age linear barrow cemetery were also recorded. These comprised five barrows of which four had surviving mound deposits. The barrows and their ditches contained burials, both cremations and inhumations, indicative of a prolonged period of use and development of the barrow cemetery. Finds, particularly the large quantities of worked flint, also suggested non-ritual use of the barrows. These barrows were significant monuments in their own right and the probably also formed part of an impressive barrow cemetery ranged along a chalk ridge to the east, including Fordington Farm barrow, Conquer Barrow and the barrow central to the Flagstones enclosure.After partial excavation of the barrows, a scheme for their preservation in situ was proposed and implemented which entailed their consolidation prior to reburial beneath up to 21.5 m of chalk.

Site_summary: Crouched burial with late Iron Age pottery.
Site_description: <Whimster 1981, 342>: Single inhumation discovered during clearance work in 1967. Skeleton of a mature adult lying on the back, with the head turned to the left. Legs missing, having been disturbed by mechanical excavator. Orientation: EAssociated objects: Six pottery vessels. Five lying in a line by the side, the sixth between the legs. Class 7 bead-rim jar; Class 1 bead-rim bowl; cordonned foot-ring bowl (imitation of Samian Drag.24); 2 shallow foot-ring bowls; shallow platter (Young, fig. 5 Nos . 1 -6).

Site_summary: Round Barrow (unlocated) Cremation Urns (24)<gg_summary>: Grinsell (1959) Arne Barrow 10a. 24 urns recovered, only one survives in Dorset Museum (Acland 1916, 46). With one exception, Warne makes no reference to the presence/absence of human bone within individual urns but notes that:a) One small urn, ornamented with fine prominent circles and complete, was completely filled with boneb) One urn was covered with an unhewn flat stonec) One urn had a cross on the interior of the baseIn the absence of more specific details, the certain urned cremation is recorded in a separate grave; the two other described pots are grouped in one record linked to an MNI of one further cremation burial (association missing). Given the vagaries involved, a broad BA date is given to the site overall.Collared urn sherds from mound are NOT recorded here - no clear association with hr
Site_description: A round barrow crowning the brow of a hill on the wild heath near Wareham, suggested by RCHM to be on Worgret Heath in the locality of other barrows (SY 98 NW 2 3 4 5) was excavated by Pennie about 1830, and later demolished for material to repair an adjoining road. Within it at different levels were twenty-four urns of cruder workmanship and material than the urns from the Deverill barrow, some containing cremations. One was ornamented with a pattern of rings or circles; another which was covered by an unhewn flat stone, bore a cross partly raised and partly incised upon the bottom. One urn survives in Dorset County Museum. (1-3)

Site_name_other: Middle Bronze Age urned cremation burials, Quarry Lane
Site_summary: The truncated remains of a possible Middle Bronze Age cremation cemetery was found at Manor Farm Quarry during archaeological evaluation by AC archaeology. Three small pits containing Middle Bronze Age pottery, one of which also contained cremated human bone were discovered. To the north of these small pits was a small ditch containing Middle Bronze Age pottery.<gg_summary>: only the pit containing both cremated remains and MBA pottery frags is recorded here.
Site_description: A pit containing Middle Bronze Age pottery and cremated human bone was found during an archaeological evaluation at Manor Farm Quarry by AC archaeology. This appears to be the truncated remains of an urned cremation burial in a small pit. Another similar small pit containing Middle Bronze Age pottery was also found and may be the remains of another urned cremation. (1)Another small pit was found during a second stage of archaeological evaluation, together with a ditch containing Middle Bronze Age pottery. (2)"

Site_summary: Late Bronze Age Bucket Urn and Cremation found 1969 ? site of Barrow
Site_description: A decorated Late Bronze Age bucket-shaped urn found during gravel extraction in 1969, was buried upright in a small pit dug into the bedrock and covered with six inches of soil. The pit was near the highest point locally and no trace of a barrow was noticed in the exposed face of the quarry, though the top of the rise is gorse covered and may conceal a small barrow. Just to the south-west of the find-spot (at about SY 875803), is a disused Army strong point. The urn is not of the ordinary Dorset Deverel-Rimbury tradition, but shows pronounced Cornish affinities (see illustration), and is only the third to be found in Dorset. The cremated remains comprised mainly of small bone slivers, also some small teeth, possibly a child's milk teeth. The urn is in Dorset County Museum. (1)

Site_name_other: Two Bronze Age Urns found at Homelands, Christchurch.
Site_summary: Two cremation urns found in 1903, probably LBA.<gg_summary>: no further details available. Almost certainly MBA in date but not identified clearly in Calkin 1962
Site_description: Two cremation urns found in 1903, probably LBA; now lost. (1) (SZ 14829281) Found when constructing Admiral Douglass house (Homelands). Dark purple in colour, the urns were perfect when found, but broken and dispersed by the finders. In Red House Museum, Christchurch. (2)

Site_name_main: Bestwall Quarry (Fields T, N and Z)
Site_name_other: Bronze Age cremation, ditches and pits
Site_summary: Sections of Bronze Age ditches and pits recorded in Fields T, N and Z during excavations at Bestwall Quarry. A single MBA cremation excavated in Field Z.<gg_summary>: A single cremation burial was excavated in Field Z consisting of poorly preserved bone within a plain vessel, this had been disturbed in antiquity.
Site_description: Section of Bronze Age ditches were recorded during excavations at Bestowal Quarry (1)Early Bronze Age: 100m length of ditch aligned SE-NW in Field T - discontinued lengths of this feature recorded in Fields J, E and P. Ditch with a steep sided and flat-based profile and contained Beaker pottery and worked flint, including 10 small thumbnail scrapers. A large oval scoop or hollow abuts this ditch and contained small amounts of charcoal, Beaker pottery and worked flint, including a barbed and tanged arrowhead and five thumbnail scrapers. In Filed Z sherds from a small EBA Beaker decorated with rows of tooth-comb ornament were an isolated find from a small scoop.Middle Bronze Age: Five ditches on a north-south alignment excavated in Field T. Six ditches excavated in Field N, four of which appeared to form the sides of a possible enclosure measuring 150m by 180m. Ditches with steeply sloping sides and flat bases. Pottery included Deverell Rimbury ware. Two ditches terminated in Field Z and another merged with a further ditch and continued westwards. MBA pottery was also retrieved from four pits, one of which contained fingerprint impressed pottery and a large amount of burnt flint and hearthstone. A single cremation was excavated in Field Z consisting of poorly preserved bone within a plain vessel, this had been disturbed in antiquity.Late Bronze Age/Early Iron Age: short length of curving gully in Field T and 9 pit type features. A cluster of pits, all circular in shape and containing large quantities of raw and fired clay and burnt hearthstone. Two loom weights were also recovered. Two isolated pits containing LBA/EIA pottery were also found in Field T. In Field N three small pits were dated to this period.

Site_summary: A probable circular enclosure consisting of a single circuit of unevenly spaced pits constructed in the late 4th millennium cal. BC. There were two larger gaps in the circuit to the north and west. Four engravings were found on the sides of four segments and three primary burials (one cremation, the remainder inhumation) were placed in the base of segments, two beneath large stone slabs and the other close to another large stone. Another burial was cut into the primary fills of another segment.There is some suggestion for an earlier stone phase to this monument with a number of pits on the edge of the ditch segments and a large number of massive stones or deliberately broken fragments of stone in the fills of the segments.<gg_summary>: This is the overarching site for the Neolithic burials with sarsen slabs from Flagstones (MDOs 18070-2).Note at the base of the central burial pit was a poorly preserved adullt sealed by a large sarsen boulder. Copper alloy rivet and tranchet arrowhead from pit infill above the head - pit infill - not direct gg.<MDO18070>: A cremation burial of an adult on the base of the segment 16 of the Flagstones enclosure. It was sealed beneath a large sarsen slab. This burial is one of three primary burials were placed on the base of segments 16, 19, and 30 of the enclosure ditch. In segment 16, on the western side of the enclosure, were found the cremated remains of an adult heaped on the base of the ditch with a large sarsen slab placed 200mm above it in the ditch fills.<MDO18071>: An inhumation of a 2-3 year old child on the base of segment 19 of the Flagstones enclosure ditch. A large slab of calcareous sandstone was found above the burial. A radiocarbon date of 3490-2930 cal BC was obtained from this burial. This burial is one of three primary burials were placed on the base of segments 16, 19, and 30 of the enclosure ditch. At the base of segment 19 were the remains of a 2-3 year old child inhumation found as a 'jumble of bones'. A large slab of calcareous sandstone was found 300mm above this burial. A radiocarbon date of 3490-2930 cal BC at 2 sigma (HAR-9158) was obtained on bone from this burial.<MDO18072>: The contracted burial of a 6-12 month old child in the base of segment 30 of the Flagstones enclosure ditch. A large sarsen was found nearby. This burial is one of three primary burials were placed on the base of segments 16, 19, and 30 of the enclosure ditch. In the west terminal of segment 30 in the north was the crushed skeleton on a 6-12 month old child and the femur of a 3-5 year old. These were not under a slab but a large sarsen fragment was found one metre away. This stone measured 610x250x110mm across. It was broken up during excavation and a small part of it was retained in the archive.
Site_description: A probably circular enclosure partly revealed by excavation at Flagstones by Wessex Archaeology in 1987-1988 in advance of the construction of the Dorchester By-pass and further parts by geophysical survey in 1992. The excavated area included slightly over half of the enclosure circuit and a further small part of the northeastern side was revealed by geophysical survey. The full circuit has not been determined.The following description is abstracted from the final published report on the site (1). The numbers in square brackets refer to context numbers quoted in the report.The enclosure is about 100m in diameter and is defined by a single discontinuous circuit of ovoid pits [00399], some of them intercutting. The segments were unevenly spaced with many intercutting pits in the northwest and southwest parts of the excavated circuit and with causeways generally 0.5-2.5m wide between pits elsewhere. There were two wider gaps in the circuit to the north and to the west, perhaps denoting entrances. A total of 39 segments were exposed by the excavation and these were generally between 1.3-3m wide, 2-5.75m long and 0.75-1.4m deep with steep, almost vertical, sides and flat bottoms. The two pits (segments 35 & 36) each side of the wide gap in the north side of the circuit were very shallow with bowl-shaped profiles. The location of four further pits was found by geophysical survey in the area behind Max Gate House. Shallow engravings were found in four of the pits in the north, northwest, south and southwest parts of the circuit (segments 4, 12, 28, 34). These engravings comprised series of curvilinear lines, criss-cross patterns or more complex shapes (2). In common with many other features at Flagstones, there was a large amount of intrusive material found in this monument, largely a result of considerable root and animal disturbance.Primary burials were placed on the base of three segments. The cremated remains of an adult beneath a large sarsen slab were found in segment 16 in the west. Close by in segment 19 were the remains of a child inhumation beneath a large slab of calcareous sandstone. In the west terminal of segment 30 in the north was the crushed skeleton on a 6-12 month old child and the femur of a 3-5 year old. These were not under a slab but a large sarsen fragment was found nearby. Three radiocarbon dates were obtained from human bone and antler from the base of the pits gave a late 4th millenium BC date.Most of the segments appear to have filled rapidly and naturally with vacuous chalk rubble containing few finds. These included some earlier Neolithic bowl sherds, worked flint, 5 antler picks, a chalk ball, and a number of fragments of sarsen, limestone and sandstone with fresh breaks and some with signs of burning. The right femur of an adult was also recovered from the primary fill. Animal bone was mainly red deer with some cattle and dog bone. A pit was cut into the primary fills of segment 14 for the burial of a 10-12 year old child inhumation. A late 3rd millenium BC radiocarbon date was obtained from this skeleton.

Site_summary: An Iron Age settlement recorded during excavations in 2008-2009 in advance of construction of the Weymouth Relief Road. Road construction affected only the western edge of the settlement, which may have been very much larger.<gg_summary>: A cemetery of 19 LIA/early Roman crouched inhumations was excavated within the vicinity of Iron Age settlement features. At least 7 of these burials were associated with grave goods and are recorded separately within the Dorset HER (MDOs37211-27, 37231). Details relating to separate graves with grave goods are included in separate grave records here.NB Only the graves that almost certainly had gg of the relevant date are included. Good potential for this site to compare overall cemetery nos. and no. burials with gg.
Site_description: In the very late Iron Age, probably during the 1st century AD, the nucleus of the settlement was levelled using stone robbed from earlier buildings and midden-like material brought from elsewhere, possible from part of the settlement outside the excavated area.  This midden like deposit (7002) was thick, varied but highly organic, and sealed several late Iron Age burials. The purpose of the levelling was unclear but seemed to mark the return of the area to agricultural use.

Site_summary: A Flat-topped grass-covered mound, interpreted as a possible Bronze Age round barrow.This is Abbotsbury 20a. This is a very intriguing barrow and attached to this barrow. It has a chalk drum Note Abbotsbury 20b is adjacent and ha a fragment of a polishing stone with a groove on its faceCremation in a Collard Urn (other urns noted too but were destroyed)There are later Saxon inhumations with grave goods (spears, brooches etc)
Site_description: A flat topped, grass covered mound situated on a hill top. Diameter 10.0m., height 1.0m. The only visible ditch is a modern one in the SE quadrant and in it is a fractured 3 water pipe which issues from the mound. Apart from the disturbance on the top of the mound, which probably results from excavation and the modern ditch referred to, the mound has not been mutilated. Its junction with the surrounding ground on the west appears to be too abrupt for the mound to be a natural feature. Immediately to the SW is a partially sunken Royal Observer Corps hut but it is considered that the mound is not spoil from this excavation. See air photograph CPE/UK/2431/3286. <1>The site is visible as earthworks on aerial photographs and was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project. <2-3>

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow, one of the Ridgeway Hill Group, Bincombe
Site_summary: Ditched barrow suggested by circular ditch with small external bank about 100 feet in diameter. Visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs. The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.<gg summary>: Bincombe 59c, Ridgeway Hill. Levelled and disturbed barrow. Human jaw (disturbed or reworked) with a bronze dagger
Site_description: The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Unlocated barrow on Cheselborne Down 8a (as stated by Grinsell (1959, 100). Not in HER. The grid reference given here is the nearest grid corner to Grinsell's barrow G8 . Small urns - hybrid E-MBA ; one had bird bones. Two urns in cists

A bowl barrow reported as being around 18 feet in diameter with a mound around 1  feet high, and surrounded by a ditch about 8 feet wide.<gg summary>: Barrow near White Horse. Opened by EC. Primary cremation in  a Collared UrnIntrusive inhumation near top of mound
Site_description: '(31) Ditched bowl (?) (71448453) 33 yds. N. of (30), crossed on W. by parish boundary with Weymouth. Diam. 18 ft., ht. 1  ft., with ditch 8 ft. wide and 6 ins. deep.' (1)

Site_summary: A possible bowl barrow 20m in diameter.  Visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs.  The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.<gg summary>: Winterborne Monkton 2, N of village. Opened in 1833-4. Central cist with cremation & ashes in upright urn with decoration. There were four secondary inhumations which had undigested stomach contents apparently, including those of wild raspberry seeds. Included two more skeletons with an urn and a bone pin.Not well recorded barrow.
Site_description: A possible bowl barrow 20m in diameter.  Visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs {1}.  The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Unlocated Winterborne Monkton, N 1e. Primary cist burial hybrid FV-Collared Urn containing a cremation and covered by a flat stoneLocation derived from that of Grinsell's (1959, 150) Winterborn Monkton barrow 1b (also in Fordington Field)

Site_name_other: Maiden Castle Long Mound, Winterborne St Martin
Site_summary: A unique Neolithic burial mound 1790 feet long flanked by parallel side ditches 60 feet apart. Visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs. The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.<gg summary>: Maiden Castle bank barrow . child with Windmill Hill Ware cup Note there were three burials . Toward E end was a primary adult male inhumation c. 25-35 years old, whose limbs and head had been 'hacked' from the body shortly after death and apparently a fruitless attempt made to extract the brain!. 10 yards to the SE was two primary crouched child inhumations aged c. 6-7 years old and one with a small cup
Site_description: A unique Neolithic burial mound 1790 feet long flanked by parallel side ditches 60 feet apart. Visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs {1}. The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.

Site_summary: A Bronze Age bowl barrow, one of a group of five barrows and part of a larger barrow cemetery extending along the Dorset Ridgeway. This monument was recorded as an extant mound by field investigators, and is visible as circular earthwork mound on aerial photographs<gg summary>: Unlocated barrow on Ridge Hill, Winterborne St Martin 91. Opened by Acland 1896. Crouched burial with antler pick. Grid ref is based on rough locational information in Grinsell 1959
Site_description: Around 34 feet in diameter with a mound about 3 feet high. A depression 24 feet in diameter and 3 ft deep lies at the foot of the mound on the northern side of the barrow. <1> <2>Bowl barrow; diameter 12.0m., height 1.5m. No visible ditch {3}.All the barrows are in an arable field. Also visible as circular earthwork mound on aerial photographs {4-7}, measuring approximately 18.8 metres in diameter. This site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow in the Rew group, Winterborne St Martin
Site_summary: Site of a possible Bronze Age bowl barrow visible as cropmarks on aerial photographs. One of a group of 6 bowl barrows located at Rew.<gg summary>: Winterborne St Martin 8a Rew Group. 3 EBA Food Vessel urns with skeletons
Site_description: Site of a possible Bronze Age bowl barrow visible as cropmarks on aerial photographs. One of a group of 6 bowl barrows located at Rew. {1}Mound, possible barrow, ploughed almost flat. (2)

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow, one of the North Hill Barrow Group, Winterbourne Steepleton
Site_summary: Site of a Bronze Age bowl barrow visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs. It is part of a group of barrows located on the summit of North Hill.<gg summary>: Winterborne Steepleton 4a.  (North Hill Group) . Primary cremation in small lugged urn and unburnt human skull placed on top of urn mouth - ?lid
Site_description: Site of a Bronze Age bowl barrow visible as an earthwork on aerial photographs. It is part of a group of barrows located on the summit of North Hill. {1}Bowl, 82ft. in diam and 7ft. high. (RCHM)

Site_name_other: Bowl Barrow on Black Down, Winterbourne Steepleton
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Winterborne Steepleton Grinsell (1959) barrow 47, the Down. (North Hill Group) . Primary cremation with perforated axe-hammer (battle axe). Potsherds in the mound. Unusual greenstone battle axe - possibly exotic

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow, one of the Thickthorn Down Group, Gussage St Michael
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Gussage St Michael 7a. Secondary cremation in cist but no gg, Primary inhumation with two flint knives
Site_description: (1) ' There is evidence of twenty round barrows in the parish, most of them levelled or badly damaged by ploughing. They are found on the two Chalk ridges which cross the parish, Week Street Down in the extreme W. and Gussage Hill in the centre.Thickthorn Down Group, comprising two round barrows (16) and (17) and two long barrows (11) and (12) is sited on the crest of the ridge; S.E. of the S.W. end of the Cursus (9).(17) Bowl (97221226), immediately N. of (11) and adjoining (16), has been damaged by a hole in the centre and by a hedge which cuts across its N.E. side; diam. 50 ft., ht. 3 ft., with a dtitch 16 ft. across.'

Site_summary: A bell barrow reported as having a mound around 66 feet in diameter and seven feet high, surrounded by a berm (flat area) about 12 feet wide with a ditch about 12 feet wide outside it.<gg summary>: Hampreston 9a. Secondary cremation in broken Collared Urn

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow, one of the Bokerley Down Group, Pentridge
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Pentridge, SW of Bokerly Down. Grinsell's (1959) barrow Pentridge 13c.  Opened by Colt Hoare. Primary deposit in cist of a red Beaker pot but this did not seemingly accompany any burial/ inhumation. Secondary cremation in a large simply ornamented urn. Note. Beaker discovered a large cist [pit], three feet deep, on the floor of which was a smaller urn of that species which I have denominated drinking cups [Beakers], coloured red, slightly glazed, and of infinitely better workmanship than the larger sepulchral urn. It is rather singular that this cup should have been deposited without its usual attendant, the skeleton". Hybrid Beaker-Food Vessel

A bronze Age Bowl barrow. In 1975 the RCHME noted that it was heavily ploughed, that its diameter was approximately 75 feet and that its mound stood some 3.5 feet high.The record for this monument has been enhanced with support from Wessex Water.<gg summary>: Badbury Barrow or Shapwick 6a. Round barrow near Badbury Rings contained several inhumations and cremations, plus a stone decorated with cup marks and representations of weapons. The 'Badbury Barrow' yielded  remarkable finds when destroyed in 1845, Under the barrow mound,  a central cairn of sandstone blocks was enclosed in a ring of flints bordered by a circular sandstone wall 30 feet in diameter, Within the cairn were at least three inhumations, apparently primary, two of them with food-vessels and one with an ornamental handled pot. Also probably in the cairn were at least fifteen cremations, a few perhaps primary, but most of them secondary, some with Food Vessels and collared urns. At the centre, a huge slab of sandstone weighing half a ton was decorated with cup marks and carvings of daggers and axes similar to those at Stonehenge. Opening another barrow in the same field, J.H. Austen found a primary cremation in a bucket urn with four lugs, in a charcoal  filled cist. Cornish style Trevisker pot

Crouched inhumation degraded but associated with wooden bier/ plank. 19 retouched flakes and an end scraper from barrow140 flint flakes and discarded cores found in the mound
Site_description: "Unrecorded Bowl Barrow, on Canford Heath, Poole (SZ03289598). This bowl barrow is situated at the end of a small spur overlooking a shallow valley, it is situated on the 55-metre contour. The barrow which has been badly mutilated by gravel workings and army practice trenches, is approx. 0.5 m high and approx. 27 m in circumference. Three flint flakes have been recovered from the remains of the mound." (1)

An external ditch is visible on its southern and eastern sides. {2} This feature was digitally plotted as part of the Wild Purbeck Mapping Project.

The barrow is sub-circular and measures 19 m in diameter.  An external ditch is visible on its southern, eastern and western sides. Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Grinsell's (1959, 103) Corfe Castle barrow 22, South of Afflington Barns (same grid ref./NRHE link but described as SE of Kingston Barn in the HER):Burial 1: 'An unusually handsome urn', inverted on two flat stones that were fitted neatly together on the floor of the barrow. Large stones (including sandstones probably from over 3 miles away) were built closely around the urn and small pieces were wedged intightly so as to fill up the cavities and to keep the urn firm in its place. Warne (1866, 58) notes that this packing might suggest that the cracks in the urn existed at the time of deposition. A thin, flat stone was placed over the urn. The urn was highly ornamented with punched circular, scored and cord impressed decoration, and four applied handles.Burial 2: A small urn cut into the mound which contained only slight traces of burnt bone. Over it was an apparently human shin bone (Warne 1866, 59)Burial 3: A small urn, inverted and cut into the mound which contained 'a few bones'. Near this was a small bone ornament (c. 3cm long) (a pin?) (Warne 1866, 59)The urns are suggested to be 'essentially British'. At least one of these is in Dorchester Museum.Burial 4 (not recorded here); Roman inhumation deposited with a penannular bronze brooch with knobbed terminals.
Site_description: <NRHE site description>: A Bronze Age bowl barrow situated on a ridge overlooking Coombe Bottom to the south east. The barrow has a mound composed of limestone rubble, with maximum dimensions of 16 metres in diameter and about 1.25 metres in height. The mound is surrounded by a quarry ditch which has become infilled over the years, but will survive as a buried feature about 2 metres wide. The barrow was partially excavated by J H Austen in 1855. A cremation within a highly decorated urn associated with stone packing was thought to represent the primary burial. Two smaller urns each containing a cremation were also identified, and an inhumation burial associated with a Romano-British penannular brooch represented an intrusive later deposit. Many of the finds discovered during the excavation are now held at the Dorset County Museum.

Site_summary: One of two mounds to the north of Coombe Bottom.  This barrow is 19m across and was visible as an earthwork on lidar imagery.<gg summary>: Corfe Castle 23, The Afflington Barrow. 1ry cremation with shale ringLater instrusive stone-lined Roman extended inhumations with ggThere were several other cists in this barrow containing crouched inhumations but no evidence of accompanying grave goods. Also burial pitsBurial pit No 7. Two skeletons lay side by side, evidently one male and one female. The right arm of the male lay across the right side of the woman. All the cists were filled with fine mould.
Site_description: One of two mounds to the north of Coombe Bottom.  This barrow is 19m across and was visible as an earthwork on lidar imagery (2).  The barrow was digitally plotted during the Wild Purbeck Mapping Project.

Site_summary: Bowl barrow, one of the two barrows known as Ferny Barrows, situated on the summit of a slight rise. In 1970 this monument was reported as being around 75 feet in diameter with a mound about 6 feet high, and damaged on the north side. The centre of the mound is also disturbed, presumably in the course of antiquarian investigation.<Grinsell's (1959, 107) East Lulworth barrows 8 and 9, Ferny Barrow (SE and NW); Warne's (1866, tovp 27-8) barrows 55-6>: Since it is unclear which burials came from which barrow, the burials from excavations potentially at both barrows are attributed to this record which relates specifically to Grinsell's (1959, 107) East Lulworth barrow 8.Miniature urn with crem ; said to be like a crucible ; also an urn embedded in sand containing cremation and under large stone ; seasand embeds the urn and associated with a large beach cobble
Site_description: They are visible as earthworks on aerial photographs, situated on the summit of a slight rise (2-3). The site was digitally plotted during the Wild Purbeck Mapping Project.

Central grave pit with was empty and phosphate analysis proved negative. Large enough for an inhumation. THis is quite acidic soil - sandy so was it decomposed?
Site_description: A Bronze Age bowl barrow is visible as an earthwork on lidar imagery on Tonerspuddle Heath.  The barrow appears to have been damaged on its southern side and is formed of two sub-oval mounds.  The mounds measure 20 m by 14 m and 12 m by 8 m.  (4) It is scheduled together with a second barrow located approximately 95 m to the north west (see linked record).  This feature was digitally plotted as part of the Wild Purbeck Mapping Project.

The top of the mound has been disturbed, possibly as a consequence of antiquarian investigation. The site of a Bronze Age bowl barrow is visible as earthworks on aerial photographs to the south of Winfrith Technology Centre.<gg summary>: Wool 5, Quarr Hill. E-MBA crem urn ; Trevisker style
Site_description: The site of a Bronze Age bowl barrow is visible as earthworks on aerial photographs to the south of Winfrith Technology Centre {3}.  It was digitally plotted during the Wild Purbeck Mapping Project.

Site_summary: Ring cairn 1 that contained cremations in pits associated with Food Vessels and Collared Urns. There are 7 14C dates too.This is one of 2 ring cairns set within hillslope of larger ritual and funerary landscape that also includes stone circles and standing stones. This one contained cremations and Collared Urns and Food Vessels. This is Moel Goedog 1A series of shallow pits and hollows - a total of 10- were excavated inside the ring cairn which was c. 7.6m in diameter. Some contained only charcoal (mainly oak) - a total of 6 did this. Pyre debris or pyre site - one pit also had burnt clay so possibly was a pyre. The other 4 contained cremated bone and pots - mainly token cremations. One Enlarged Food Vessel and two Collared Urns; all were found inverted in the pits. Only two of these were associated with cremated human bone. One cremation was unurned.
Site_description: One of the stone circles has seven remaining stones standing to a height between 9 -21 inches, with the other stones around the 20ft diameter of the circle prostrate, including the largest of the group at over 4ft long. The second 20ft diameter, western circle is less well defined with all but 3 of the stones lying prostrate or out of the circle and a large gap on the east side. <1>28 yards in circumference, this circle is one of a pair of cairn circles. The former has only about 8 stones around it, the biggest of which is a thin slab projecting 2ft above the ground. <2>(Unpublished 1977) The site is set on a small hillside amongst scattered gorse hummocks and boulders and consequently is not particularly easy to recognise. One prominent upright stone stands on the western perimeter and seven or eight  smaller stones and slabs, some leaning inwards as if partly collapsed, are ranged in a ring about 7.50m in diameter. The centre is grass grown and fairly level. Outside the circle proper the ground slopes away, but on the north side the tips of the stones protruding above the grass hint at further features, possibly a stone bank behind the uprights on the lower side. The monument has not been planned in modern times.The condition of the western circle, March 1978: The monument has been traversed by hymac (mechanical excavator) and nearly all the stones pulled out. These are scattered over the site together with some boulders which probably do not belong to the monument. The area has been ploughed. The result is that there are a number of shallow scoops (most are 5-10 cm deep) some of which may have been the settings of stones, others are where machine tracks have ripped up the turf. The main stones may be recognised with some degree of certainty but the stone holes are far from clear. Only one hole is of any depth (about 25cm) and the others consist of ill defined scoops with small stones loosened and scattered within them. By no means all these scoops contained stones. The suggested bank on the NE can still be recognized and a length of its outer edge is undamaged. With the exception of the machine tracks and stone holes (stippled on the plan) the site is still under grass. <4>Routine visit to this area revealed that some of the reinstated stones were in danger of toppling over through the action of sheep rubbing against them. <5>Excavation of Moel Goedog was made in the winter of 1978. The circle 6.5-7m in diameter originally consisted of 12 upright stones in deep holes, none more than 1m high, banked by an infill of cairn material circa 3m wide and 2 or 3 stones high. Only 3 of the upright stones remained, 4 had been pulled out in January 1978 and 5 lost many years ago, but these stone holes and packing survived. Within the central area were 9 pits, the varying levels of which suggest a long sequence of activity. Most of them contained dark earth and charcoal, one deposit contained a charred urn and another included an urn containing a quantity of cremated bones. The earliest feature was a deep pit containing a very large unfilled with charcoal and cremated bones. The upright stones were replaced and new stones found for the other post holes. The eastern circle (PRN 1009) was not investigated. <6>Impressive and well preserved monument, easily visible and complete despite previous excavation.  The incorporation of small orthostatic stones makes it more fragile than 1009 but there is no sign of stock damage (Smith, 2001).

Site_summary: DyfTryn Ardudwy is one of the principal tombs in a group of six surviving monuments that stand at medium altitudes above the sea coast in this vicinity which lies midway between Harlech and Barmouth. Two separate monuments were involved and brought together. Earlier is the western chamber with small squat oval cairn & eastern chamber with quadrangular cairn that incorporated the western complex.  Portal dolmen.Monument emptied long ago but sherd of dec Beaker found on floor of chamber.The burial rite was probably inhumation, but whether single or collective, successive or simultaneous, cannot be said.There is 1 in situ cremation associated with fragmentary Food Vessel.There was also a broken bracer in the chamber - not directly associated with a burial. The two fragments fitted together but there was still a bit missingNo evidence for the Neolithic phase of funerary evidence as it was cleared out
Site_description: A chambered long cairn is situated at 100ft above sea level close to the school in the village of Dyffryn Ardudwy. It is oriented east to west and is about 125ft long and 55ft wide at the west end and 35 ft wide at the east end. Most of the stones have been removed leaving two megalithic chambers about 30ft apart. It originally stood in a small oval mound. At some later date this was enclosed in the present long cairn with its own chamber at the east end. (Bowen & Gresham, 1967)Excavated in 1961 and 1962 by T. G. E. Powell who found some datable pottery. <2>As described. <3>As described previously.  The site lies on low slopes overlooking the coastal plain and set amongst a series of very heavily lynchetted contour fields quite possibly prehistoric in origin and providing the possibility of some environmental evidence.  The cairn is made from a mass of rounded cobbles - presumably from clearance. (Smith, 2001)

Site_summary: A layer of calcined bone mixed with charred wood and fragments of a burial urn (early Bronze Age) was found 1m east of the standing stone. The urn had originally contained the burial and it was undecorated
Site_description: The base forms a rough quadrilateral with north and southsides 1.3m wide, W side 1m wide and S side 0.6m wide. The north side rises abruptly to a sharp point. The south side rises with an overhang to a shoulder at 1.6m, and then slopes upward less steeply to the point. A layer of calcined bone mixed with charred wood and fragments of a burial urn (early Bronze Age) was found 1m east of the stone. <1>Urn fragments are now in the NMW. <2>Urn listed as Mid Bronze Age food vessel (1500-2000 B.C.) <3>Tall impressive stone with broad base and pointed apex.  E side is relatively flat and oriented almost exactly on mag. N - S.  W side is more irregular and base in plan is roughly triangular.  Views to Mynydd Mawr in E and Yr Eifl in S. (Smith, 2002)

Site_summary: <gg_summary>:http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/308082/details/PORTH+DAFARCH%2C+BARROW+I/This is Port Dafarch IThere is a possibility that Porth Dafarch I may have contained a burial of Beaker date as well as later cremation urns. It was excavated in 1848A Collared Urn held the cremated remains of an adult female with a miniature vessel & a daggerThere was also a child inhumation accompanied by a dog skeleton & a miniature vessel two urn burials , possibly placed on original ground surface. First was inverted large Collared Urn and had been protected by a flat stone on top of it with pebbles set around the rim. It contained the bones of a woman c. 23-25 years old & some dog bones and a single bronze rivet & it had been inverted over an Accessory cup which was standing upright on a small flat stone. The cup was lined with bracken and contained the incomplete skeleton of a very young child. Second urn with cremation near the first- in inverted urn and again with an accessory vessel
Site_description: Tumulus (site of). <1>Three early Bronze Age barrows set in a line running back from the sea at Porth Dafarch. They had been heavily disturbed in the Roman period, when a group of huts had been built over and around them. They were all entirely removed in the last century and the site is now covered by a road. Porth Dafarch I closest to the sea, was dug into by a farmer in search of stone in 1848 and the others were excavated in 1875 by W. O. Stanley. <3><4><6><10>There is a possibility that Porth Dafarch I may have contained a burial of Beaker date as well as later cremation urns. A stone cist, apparently of appropriate size was found somewhere beneath the cairn and though nothing was found in it, since it appeared to have been previously rifled, bones were found nearby. <2>Stanley's account of the cairn structure is somewhat confused; he states that he states that it was built of four stones but then compares it to the Early Medieval cist at Towyn y Capel which contained at least 12 slabs. Two urn burials are recorded from this barrow, both containing accessory cups. One urn, found 2ft. from the surface of the cairn contained the bones of a woman, bones of a dog, a single bronze rivet and it had been inverted over an accessory cup containing the incomplete skeleton of a very young child. The second burial was found adjacent to the first. It was in an inverted urn without any protective cist. The urn which presumably contained bone also had an accessory cup containing ashes. <5>The area around Porth Dafarch I has been much mutilated by car parking and nothing remains of the mound. <7>No further information. <8>'Odd and roughly circular arrangements of stone beneath Beaker barrows in Wales, for example Porth Dafarch... may indicate that the concept of the cairn-ring (though not its close similarity to the ring- cairn) goes back to the Beaker period.' <9>Cairn robbed for stone in 19th century. There is a cist but no finds are recorded although probably previously robbed and is probably of Beaker date, like the other cairn nearby. (Smith, 2003)

Site_summary: http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/308082/details/PORTH+DAFARCH%2C+BARROW+I/Port Dafarch II. This is barrow II with a Beaker burial of an inhumation in a stone-lined cist with a stone grave marker - orthostatShe was a young female with two Beaker pots. One Beaker substantially complete but the other was represented only by three sherds and had been fragmented in antiquity
Site_description: Tumulus (site of). <1>Three early Bronze Age barrows set in a line running back from the sea at Porth Dafarch. They had been heavily disturbed in the roman period, when a group of huts had been built over and around them. They were all entirely removed in the last century, and the site is now covered by a road. The details of this second mound are obscure because it had been disturbed at least twice: once when Romano- British huts and enclosure walls were built over it and again when three extended inhumations, probably medieval in date, were inserted into the top. The original burial, presumably central, seems to have been fairly complex. It was covered by a mound of sand, perhaps incorporating some settings of stones. The cist contained the crouched skeleton of a young woman, together with the broken remains of two Beakers. One of these is reasonably complete and may have been intact when originally deposited, but the other is represented by only three sherds. The discovery of a small undecorated collared urn not far from the primary cist suggests that the barrow was reused at the time when Porth Dafarch III and possibly I were being built. <2><3><7>One of the urns was of the S2 (W) group, the western funnel-necked variant of the developed southern type; the other indeterminate. Both went to the British Museum (Acc. Number 817-6 2/3). <4>No further information. <5>'Odd and roughly circular arrangements of stone beneath Beaker barrows in Wales, for example Porth Dafarch... may indicate that the concept of the cairn-ring (though not its close similarity to the ring- cairn) goes back to the Beaker period'. <6>Excavated in 19th & 20th century. A cist with possible stone settings and fallen standing stone, crouched burial and 2 Beakers, also a small collared urn, which shows it was re-used later. (Smith, 2003)

Site_summary: Rather little information about the human remains but they were likely inhumations in cists with Beakers or EBA vesselsCists with human bones and urns - that is the full quota of information and the pots are now lost. So not much hope. Known only from a 19th century description. (Smith, 2003)
Site_description: The site whence the Mynytho vessel came is mentioned by Peris in his note on 'Cir Ferthyr' in Arch. Camb. 5, V (1874): <1>'There is.. in the upper part of the parish of Llangian, at a small distance form the village of Pen y Graigwen (sic: Mynytho), and near the boundary of Llanbedrog, a place known as Yr Hen Fynwent (the old graveyard or burial-place) which may possible indicate the spot where a church once stood, and tradition is unanimous that such was the case. It is the belief of the neighbourhood that a church at one time existed there, and old people now living remember the place surrounded by a hedge. Within the enclosure, which was of the usual size of a churchyard, many graves were at different times found, and there is no doubt that it was at one time a place of general sepulture. Some 30 or 40 years ago, when the surrounding wastes were enclosed, several cistvaens and urns which contained human bones were discovered a few yards of this enclosed space but none actually within it.' (87-8)The enclosure of the common mentioned took place officially in 1825, but the enclosure award and map; drawn up in 1808, record several illegal enclosures dating from 1788 onwards. It is possible to reconcile the information from the above record, Daniel's note, and local tradition, to fit a site at c.SH307312.  <2>No further information available. <3>One of three find-spots of 'cynnogau' (vessels or beakers) listed by Daniel - at Bryn Bugail, Mynytho. <4>Known only from a 19th century description. (Smith, 2003)

Site_name_other: Cairn and Urn Burials, Twtil, Llaniestyn
Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Barrow with one inhumation burial (degraded) with a worked flint and two urned cremations. No further detail on the types of urns.....likely Collared Urns. The pots are now lost so the types cannot be checkedSuggestion that this barrow was in fact originally a chambered tomb
Site_description: Davies also dug into a mound called Twtil in Llaniestyn parish. In his time it measured some twenty yards by fourteen yards, being 'quite ruinous, with many of its stones having been taken away... We dug into the mound, and found in it pieces of charcoal...also, in the midst of this, we saw several flints...and in one spot we found part of an arm bone, that which is known as the radius. We are told that two vessels, containing human ashes, were found here several years ago' (154-5). The mound, presumably the remains of a chambered tomb, appears by now to have been obliterated. <1> <2>Twtil cannot be located. No further information. <3>Excavated and described in 19thC but location of site not identified apart from the place name, which has not been located. (Smith, 2003)

Site_summary: Small cairn covering two urns containing cremated human remains.Cremation burials found during the A497 road improvement scheme. The site is located in an enclosed field to the E of Afon Wen farm. It comprised a circular enclosure ditch c.28m diameter, (ditch was 1.3m wide and 0.8m deep) in the centre of which were found traces of a small cairn covering two human cremation urns. The urns (one Food Vessel and one Collared Urn) were found in inter-cutting pits at the centre of a circular ditch, c.25m in diameter, covered with a small remnant spread of stone. Both pots contained substantial quantities of bone, but no other grave goods. Radiocarbon dates recovered from the site range from CAL BC 2190 to CAL BC 1530 (beta-210121 to 210124), indicating an Early Bronze Age date. (Berks et al 2007).
Site_description: The site is located in an enclosed field to the E of Afon Wen farm. It comprised a circular enclosure ditch c.28m diameter, in the centre of which were found traces of a small cairn covering two human cremation urns. The urns were found in inter-cutting pits at the centre of a circular ditch, c.25m in diameter, covered with a small remnant spread of stone. Both pots contained substantial quantities of bone, but no grave goods. Radiocarbon dates recovered from the site range from CAL BC 2190 to CAL BC 1530 (beta-210121 to 210124), indicating an Early Bronze Age date. (Roberts, 2007)Introduction:The site is located in an enclosed field to the east of Afon Wen Farm at SH44923772. It comprised acircular enclosure ditch c.28.0m diameter, in the centre of which were found traces of a small cairncovering two human cremations in pots (Figure 5). The enclosure was unknown when the desktopassessments of the route of the road were carried out in 1993, 1996 and 1997 (GAT Report: 60, Project No. G1142; GAT Report: 224, Project No. G1429 and GAT Project No. G1513, respectively). The Royal Commission on Ancient and Historic Monuments, Wales first noted the site in 2004 as a crop mark on an aerial photograph. It was recorded as a cropmark of a sub-circular enclosure, in the region of 30m in diameter, having a rather flattened north-west face & giving indications of possible structures within; set on generally level, low-lying ground (RCAHMW NPRN 401,896, AP895046/10-11, 2004).
