The site was subsequently given a PRN by the Historic Environment Record: PRN 19659.The enclosure was not identified by the geophysical survey of the road assessment phase (GAT Project No. G1692; Stratascan Report Job Ref. 1899, August 2004). The field was excluded from survey as the new road here was to be simply an improvement of the line of the existing road and only a very narrow strip of the field was due to be affected.The enclosure ditch was discovered during the archaeological evaluation of Diversion 3 and wasidentified in Trench 7. At this stage there was little evidence from the enclosure to suggest its functionor date and it was hoped that further investigation within the proposed route of the road corridor would provide an answer (GAT Project No.: G1692; Report No.: 625). A larger area of 560 sq. m. (Trench 99) was excavated along the road improvement scheme, exposing the whole circumference of the enclosure ditch and revealing several pits and other features (Figure 5). The excavation results from Trench 99 are included in this report.Topographic location:The site lies at SH 44923772, on a fairly level slight natural terrace at the edge of an area of lowundulating land at the point where it dips in a gentle slope towards the coastal plain. This provides good views over the coast and a natural route above the marshy lowland that has long been utilised for a road and may well have been a route originating in prehistoric times. The subsoil is a silty fluvioglacial till and the soils of the area are rated as land capability Grade 2: moderate to good quality, suitable for intensive pasture with some arable (MAFF 1977, 1988).

Site_summary: <Of the eleven pits excavated at Blaen Y Cae, Gwynedd (SH 4826 4523), eight contained charcoal rich fills and of those only 3 contained human remains.  fragments was identified and a small amount of pure charcoal was found at the base of the pit. In pit 2 and 9, 1g of human bone was found in each. Whilst 4.6g was produced from pit 11. Pit 4 contained an accessory cup, the base of the pot was heavily truncated and no cremation material was found. Thus no whole cremation deposits where identified at this site. Radiocarbon sampling produced dates a range of 2100–1750 Cal BC which suggest that this site was in use for a long duration of time (Smith 2006, 18). The practice of depositing partial remains suggests that the aim of burials were in general not to hold and contain a singular dead person, but to go through a process of committing a representational substance to the ground within a process of special activity. Cremated bone came from pits 2, 6, 7, 9 and 11 but with the exception of pits 6 and 7 this amounted to a few or even less than 1 g!!><gg_summary>: only pit 6 produced both cremated bone and objects. Worth noting, however, is that the pit containing the rim of another mini inverted collared urn (pit 4) was heavily truncated. This is interpreted as a possible accessory deposit (2006, 13).
Site_description: An archaeological watching brief prior to gravel extraction identified five charcoal-filled pits and another pit containing a decorated pot of Early Bronze Age style. Exposure of a wider area revealed five more pits and several shallow hollows and spreads. Excavation revealed in total two pits with urns, three pits with cremations but no pots and six charcoal-filled pits with no pots and no cremations. Radiocarbon dates from three pits confirmed that this was a small cremation cemetery of the Early Bronze Age, in use within the period 2100-1750 BC <1>

Site_name_other: Cairn With Urn Burial, NW of Penarth, Aberdesach
Site_summary: Cist burial under cairn with child inhumation accompanied by two Beaker pots but one was very fragmentary
Site_description: The mound occupies the summit. In 1910, a stone cist was found in the centre, containing a C beaker, fragmentary bones (child). Fragments of an A beaker were found later. The cist measured 0.9m by 0.6m and 0.6m deep, the cover stone 1.6m by 0.8m (RCAHMW, 1960)The cist cover stone forms part of a modern wall. The mound now 0.5m high and 7m diameter is visible only on the SW side of the wall. <2>Remains of a cairn on local summit above the coast at Aberdesach. Visible from all directions and on skyline from NW and SE. Intervisible with burial chamber 199.  Site is very denuded and was excavated in 1910. The NE side is protected by a rough fence the SE is ploughed almost flat.  Only the portion beneath a field boundary is preserved. An electricity pole has been inserted in the northern side. (Smith, 2003)

Site_summary: This barrow/ cairn is 13.5m in diameter and 1m high. It sits in a commanding position on top of a ridge overlooking the Llyn Llywenan and the lands stretching to the Holy Island. It was already disturbed in 1870 by J Wynee Jones who found more than '1 inhumed body' and Frances Lynch says he also discovered a number of cremations. Human remains were enveloped in fibrous matts or flat wooden boards. The barrow did not cover any elaborate structure (eg kerb cairn) but there was a mass of cremated bones on the old ground surface and a large ribbed jet bead (similar to Bedd Branwen one). Note some of the pots did not contain or were not obviously associated directly with cremated bone - offerings?Bronze Age barrow near others in the vicinity<cenotaphs>
Site_description: Tumulus. <1>On arriving at Treiorwerth, the seat of the President, the visitors were received in the most cordial and hospitable manner.  During the day the excavation of a low tumulus had been going on, the result of which was the discovery of the remains of more than one inhumed body; a considerable quantity of pottery of various kinds, among which was some of substantial white ware, such as has been found in connexion with the cyttiau.  One portion was of a dark, drab colour, with patterns like the fern-leaf pattern, and chevrons surmounted with a narrow band of inclined lines.  These are not unusual patterns in early British pottery.  An ornamented bead - part of a necklace, in all probability - was picked up among the debris.  It is of a light and black substance something like jet. <2>Among the fragments of urns was one bearing a not unusual pattern of rather late kind, perhaps Romano British as the same pattern is frequently found in Brittany where it is considered to be Gallo Roman. Most important discovery was the finding of human remains so closely incorporated with a fibrous mass that the bones, which were easily distinguished, could not be separated. It was greasy to the touch and had a greasy unctuous appearance, nearly black and much darker than the soil out of which it was extricated. There were traces of neither wooden nor stone chests. <3>The cinery urn was presented to the British Museum. Various kinds of pottery and a dark coloured ornamental bead were in the possession of W. O. Stanley in 1875. Some pottery was of a substantial white-ware, thought to be roman-British 'mortaria' from Shropshire or imported from Gaul. <4>The barrow had been built as a simple cairn of large stones capped with a layer of orange/yellow clay which also filled the interstices of the cairn. It was 14.5m in diameter, the edge marked by largish stones laid flat. The cairn survived to a height of 75cm but would probably have been at least 1m originally. The centre of the barrow was entirely destroyed by the 1870 excavation and superficial disturbances were found elsewhere. An unurned cremation on the old ground surface just east of the central area, an enlarged food vessel inverted over charcoal and dark earth upright in the basal layer of the cairn at the eastern edge, suggest that the barrow was a multiple burial mound. In the eastern half four other cinerary urns were found dug into the clay capping. All except one was badly disturbed and were probably secondaries. No grave goods. Also dug into the clay capping were the inhumation cists (containing nothing because of the acidity of the soil). All had been built of thin upright stones, without a floor, but roofed by several capstones. The complete lack of finds makes it difficult to date them closely but it is possible that they belong to the roman period, a date supported by the finding of roman pottery in 1870. <5>

Site_summary: Bedd Branwen round barrow takes its name from a Mabinogion tale.  Branwen, daughter of Llyr, died of a broken heart, regretting the trouble she had caused between Welsh and Irish warriors. She was buried beside the river Alaw.However the burial mound is far older than the Mabinogion.  The central stone was erected in the late 3rd millennium BC.  Radiocarbon dates indicate that the stone had stood for centuries as an independent monument before the burial mound was constructed around it in approximately 1400 BC.  This mound (barrow) formed a cemetery for up to 12 people, who are presumed to have been wealthy due to the pottery and grave goods recovered, which included imported beads, amber and carved jet.F. M. Lynch excavated the site in 1966 and demonstrated that the mound was of complex construction.  Long after the stone had been erected, 3 urns with cremated bones and accompanying grave goods were buried.  A wide ring of stone was built over the top.  Then the area between the stone ring and the centre was filled with stone to create a cone-shaped bank.  This was covered by the earthen mound, which extended out to a retaining kerb of boulders, some of which are still visible.After the construction of the mound, at least 4 other cremation burials of similar style - and therefore probably similar date - were inserted into it.  The arrangement of the burials and their personal belongings is interesting because not one person was given the central position in the mound.  They were placed in a ring around the centre.  This suggests equality despite the variations in personal wealth demonstrated by the goods accompanying each burial.  No one was buried with a dagger, as is common in contemporary sites elsewhere in Britain.Three smaller pots containing infant ear bones were buried alongside adults' urns. This curious practice has also been found on some other sites in Anglesey.http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/302327/details/BEDD+BRANWEN+-+CAIRN+SOUTH-WEST+OF+GLANAL
Site_description: Bedd Branwen. <1>In 1813 a cist was found in the centre containing an inverted EBA cinerary urn of enlarged food-vessel type with a cremation. It is probable, but not certain, that fragments of a beaker and the unburned bones of a young man came also from this cairn. The cremation was identified as a female, and site has been associated with the legendary square grave on the banks of the Alaw where Branwen was buried according to the Mabinogion. <2>The remains of a round cairn about 120 yards in circumference and about 3ft high, the upper part having been removed. In the centre is a stone split in half, and the other stones are lying about. Condition poor. (RCAHMW, 1937)The barrow has recently been excavated. It is a multiple cist cairn with a cairn ring and at least seven contemporary burials which, on the evidence of grave goods, can be dated 1550-1400 BC. There is a central standing stone. <4>Excavation Report. <5>The beaker from Bedd Branwen is a western funnel-necked variant of late southern type, now in the British Museum. <6> It has been assumed that Bedd Branwen was a Beaker Barrow, reused at a later period, and that both the primary and the secondary burials had been disturbed in 1813. However, recent large-scale excavation of the site failed to produce any evidence for a beaker burial and, moreover, it was clear that the entire barrow had been built at a date around 1400 BC contemporary with the urn burial. One must therefore conclude that the association of the Beaker and the urn was a mistake for which the chequered history of the urn between 1813 and 1834 gave ample opportunity. The mound is designed around the central stone, which must have existed as a monument in its own right. <7>The excavation of the bronze-age burial mound produced three leaf-shaped flakes of flint and one microlith. The four pieces occurred in the turf, of which the actual mound was composed, their incorporation in the mound may well have been accidental. <8>Samples associated with Bronze Age urns and other pottery from the excavation was subjected to Carbon 14 analysis. Charcoal from the central stone yielded a date of 4923 +/- 75 b.p. predating the construction of the barrow. <9>Bedd Branwen is a typical ring cairn covered by a barrow. This type of cairn covering a series of burials is similar but not closely parallel to the Scottish enclosed cremation cemetery, the difference being that the barrow incorporates the ring cairn. <10>SH 361 849; Bedd Branwen round cairn, scheduled. <11>Round cairn 3, high surrounded by herb 70 yards in circumference. The site now appears as a grass mound about 20m across and 0.5m high with a hollow at the centre, out of which protrudes a standing stone 1.25m high by 0.75m x 0.75m which is split longitudinally. A number of kerb stones are visible around the outer edge. <12>Well preserved ring cairn covered by a barrow and incorporating a central stone. Now visible as a somewhat uneven, flat-topped mound with a slight central depression a stone (1 x 0.8 x 0.7m) stone, split down the centre. Excavated by F. M. Lynch 1967. Setting: in a flat bottomed natural bowl c.1km across, partly formed by a valley beside a small stream and locally visible from all sides. (Smith, 2003)Old HER records excavation in 1813, by an unknown individual.  No further information available. <19>The cremated remains of Richard Pierce, the former owner of the site, were deposited in a crack of the central stone of the cairn c.1970, according to the current owner. <21>

Site_summary: Note - the polished axes could be Neolithic and curated?The loopless palstave could be MBA and inserted into mound later
Site_description: A cinerary urn containing a cremation, an incense cup, two polished axes of magnesium stone and a loopless bronze palstave of Irish type were found c.1850 when grave mounds at Cerrig Ddewi were being levelled. The site is on rising ground above the Afon Cefni and a few mounds slightly raised above the level of the field still remain, one of them showing the ends of larger stones. The finds are now in care of the British Museum. <1>Urn, incense cup and palstave found in Cerrig-Ddewi and now in the British Museum. (RCAHMW, 1937)There are no traces of any mounds or disturbed ground in likely situations in the vicinity of this farm and no further information. <3>The fields round here are all permanent pasture now. The farmer at Tre Ddewi, formerly part of Cerrig Ddewi, suggests that the field in front of Fron Ddewi is dumping and may have traces of mounds or perhaps old field boundaries. Possibly aerial photographs might reveal the location of the mound or mounds. (Smith, 2003)

Site_summary: Summary of burials: 2 urns, 1 containing bronze awl and 'bronze blade' amongst burnt bones. Early  Bronze Age. (RCAHMW, 1937)
Site_description: About 1864, two urns with burnt bones were found near the landing stage for steamers at Menai Bridge. The finders destroyed one; the other has also since perished. Within one of the urns lay a bronze pin about 3.5 inches long; one end pointed, the other flat, in like fashion as bronze 'awls' often found in urns in Wiltshire. One of the urns was sketched, showing no ornament although of unusual fashion. A bronze blade was lately found amongst burned bones at the same spot 2.5 inches long, 5/8 inch breadth. <1>2 urns, 1 containing bronze awl and 'bronze blade' amongst burnt bones. Early  Bronze Age. (RCAHMW, 1937)

Site_summary: Summary of hr <Extended inhumations and 'special grave on site of Late Neolithic ceremonial complex. This complex consists of two Neolithic henge monuments and a cursus, and associated Early Bronze Age beaker burials. Cremation cemetery in and associated with the ring-ditch, although many of the cremation burials lacked discernible grave goods. Several cremations within the Henge A cremation circle were in bags and laid on or else covered by burnt wooden planks. Site F barrow - contained an unurned cremation that was loosely laid in a pit - of a young adult, possibly male. Although this lacked grave goods, another pit only 3.5m to the west contained an Inverted Food Vessel that was filled with dark organic earth and charcoal. This has not currently been treated as a grave good because there is not a direct stratigraphic or chronological association between the two features although the two are likely related. There was also a shallow pit inside Henge b with a crushed Beaker and carbonised wood but no evidence for any associated human remains and the pit was too small to have contained a (degraded) inhumation). Thus there was a great deal of ritual as well as funerary activity going on. 6 actual burials (all cremations) with grave goods or planks>
Site_description: Two henges and the U-shaped end of a cursus were discovered from the air at Llandegai, by Dr. J. K. St. Joseph in 1960. Excavations by C. Houlder revealed Neolithic and Beaker henges, each with numerous burials, a settlement site of Neolithic date, and a cursus possibly of early Bronze Age date. <1> <4> <5>The area where the henges, etc were found is now covered by buildings which have destroyed all evidence of their existence. <2>In 1975, two undated features were recorded, one was a pit containing charcoal and fire-cracked stones, the other a ditch 1m deep sealed by ploughsoil. <3> At Llandegai a wide range of cropmarks were examined, topsoil was removed, laying open the original ground surface of two ditched circles some 230' diameter, and parts of a 200' stretch of parallel ditches with a u-shaped end. <7>Five determinations have now been made by the National Physical Laboratory from charcoal specimen obtained in the recent excavations. <8>Two C14 dates. <9>Excavation between February 2005 and 2006 revealed an early Neolithic building, several groups of pits containing Later Neolithic pottery, numerous Bronze Age burnt mounds, round-houses ranging from possibly late Bronze Age in date through to the Roman period. <18>The most obvious features were a series of late Neolithic ceremonial structures consisting of two henges (features A and B) and a cursus (feature C). Henge A, nearly 90m in diameter, was bounded by a 9m wide ditch with a single narrow entrance causeway. Henge Bwas somewhat smaller with opposing entrances. Cremation burials were discovered in the vicinity of both henges. The morphology of henge A suggests that it was the earlier of the two. The Llandegai cursus (feature C) was first noted by K. St.Joseph (1961) during aerial reconnaissance. The cursus was found to consist of a parallel alignment of two 3m wide ditches linked together in a U-shaped terminus. This type of earthwork is most commonly found in Wessex and the Thames valley and is often found in association with henge monuments. The excavations did not only reveal ritual Neolithic remains. The ditch of Henge B cut through an array of rectangular post-holes probably representing the remains of two earlier buildings. Nearby rubbish pits confirmed the presence of domestic activity that could have been contemporary with the earlier Henge A.  (Hopewell and Davidson, 1999). This small monument was identified and completely excavated in 1966 and was situated west-southwest of the end of the cursus (Lynch & Musson 2001). It was roughly equidistant from the two main henges but lay south of the alignment between the cursus and Circle D. The two entrances were aligned northwest/southeast, in contrast to the two large henges (A and B) where, thought they are of different dates, both entrances faced almost due west. There is no dating evidence for the monument, but these two factors suggest that it is an addition to the prehistoric landscape, later than the cursus and Circle D and Henge B.The monument consisted of two curved ditches forming a circle 8m in diameter. The south ditch, 1.5m across and 0.48m deep, was slightly larger than that to the north. There was little indication of the position of any bank in the truncated ditch sections, but due to the lack of internal space, this may have been on the outside. There were no significant features within the 5.0m wide interior.The location of the hengiform monument is currently an access road belonging to the Wardle Storeys factory (Figure 1). (Davidson & Roberts, 2007)

Site_name_other: Cist Burial and Beaker, Site of, Llithfaen
Site_summary: There is no published information that I can find about the other two Beaker burials. It says there is a reference in PPS 1957: 69 but that is all about faience! This is a Beaker inhumation in a cist with unusual (for Wales) AOC Beaker at feet. Also unsuual is that this individual was identified as an adult male but was placed on right side (more common for females) and with head to N
Site_description: A short cist was found, inside was a flexed skeleton and an AC beaker. The beaker is now in the Bangor Museum. Two similar burials are said to have been found within 20m of the cist during the last 50 years (in 1969). <1>Mrs. Evans recalled the tradition that other burials were found in this area shortly after the building of the chapel (1882). <2>

Site_name_other: Cairn, Site of, Farm Yard Farm
Site_summary: <gg summary>: A tumulus (PRN 2465) excavated at this point in 1913 was found to contain a small central cairn covering an urn cremation; two secondary cremations were found in inverted urns, one being in a rough cist of stones. No trace of the tumulus remains. (Roberts, 1996)Further detail indicates that these are inverted Food Vessels that were found in the mound; only two are noted
Site_description: A tumulus excavated in 1913 in Ffridd Cerrig, Cae Newydd field, 700 yards SW of Farm Yard Farm. It contained a small central cairn, covering an inturned cremation. Two secondary cremations were found with inverted urns, one being in a rough cist of stones. <1>No trace. <2>A tumulus (PRN 2465) excavated at this point in 1913 was found to contain a small central cairn covering an urn cremation; two secondary cremations were found in inverted urns, one being in a rough cist of stones. No trace of the tumulus remains. (Roberts, 1996)Form of the south end of the hill looks a little barrow-like but very little of the barrow itself seems to remain.  The farmer has dug for slate in the hill top exactly where the barrow was and not found anything.  Most of barrow must have been removed in 1913 during excavation and rest has been ploughed away.  A trace of the mound may survive but this has been further disturbed by the farmer's digging.  The barrow would have had an excellent view. (Smith, 2002)

Site_name_other: Tumulus, Site of, Flagstaff Quarry, Penmon
Site_summary: Under the stones a layer of a blackish substance with small pieces of bones strewn over it. Particles of charred bone were found in a lower layer. In the N of barrow two small 'incense cups' of coarse red clay were found lying on their sides mouth to mouth with a bone pin.The bone pin had perforation in middle and is decorated and F. Lynch (1970: 156) thinks it may be a bone toggle/ belt fitting.The Accessory vessels are unusually small - miniature Accessory vessels - less than 6cm tall
Site_description: Tumulus 450yds E of Penmon Church. A scattered and shapeless low heap of stones or soil on the edge of Flagstaff Quarry, possibly that from which two middle BA incense cups were extracted circa 1889. <1>Workmen clearing away surface soil discovered a mound of loose stones, forming oblong barrow 3ft long, N to S. Under the stones a layer of a blackish substance with small pieces of bones strewn over it. Particles of charred bone were found in a lower layer. In the N of barrow two small 'cups' of coarse red clay were found lying on their sides mouth to mouth with a bone pin. <2>The two MBA incense cups possibly came from the tumulus 450yds E of Penmon Church on the edge of Flagstaff Quarry. <3>No further info available in 1970. <4>The NGR puts its position just in front of the quarry buildings. This area does not appear to have been quarried away and it is just possible that the site has been buried by spoil and still exists. (Smith, 2003)

Site_summary: http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/309540/details/Cremated bones of an adult male with small flints. Unurned
Site_description: Base of cairn c.120yds in circumference and now 2-3' high, 40yds SSW of Bryn Celli Ddu burial chamber (PRN 2964). Apparently there was originally a circle or curb of small upright stone probably set in a small ditch. (RCAHMW, 1937)Excavation in 1931 revealed a central cist about 2' x 1' and 1' 2" deep, containing only the cremated boned of a man. Near the cist on the original floor were patches of charcoal, a few fragments of cremated bone and small flints with secondary working. <2>A low ground swelling of indeterminate dimensions is all that remains of this cairn. <3>Vague rise in field c.15m diameter could be the remains of the cairn. Very denuded. Location - same local rise as Bryn Celli Ddu burial chamber which stands c. 40m to NNW. Good views all around apart from that obscured by Bryn Celli Ddu Mound. Inventory (1937) reports that there was originally a circular kerb. Excavated by Newall in 1931 revealing central cist containing 'cremated bones of a man' along with secondary cremations and flints. (Smith, 2003)

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Difficult to piece together the various accounts (the numbers vary and there is no basic grave description). White (1981) described described a tightly clustered group of seventeen urned cremations which appeared to be arranged in an arc around a hearth. She noted that twelve of the urns were inverted and three were upright.  Lynch added that three of the pits contained only vessels and charcoal (no human remains).  One of the inverted um burials had an accompanying vessel containing only a charcoal-rich earth. One of the burials was located in a cist, the other graves were 'confidently dug, straight-sided, flat-bottomed pits, closely matching the size of the urns found within them.' She noted that 'some urns had stone packing around the rim, others had stones covering the base, but only one was completely stone lined.' The fill of the grave pits consisted of charcoal flecked brown friable clay loam, some containing more charcoal than others. Charred grain and chaff of wheat and barley were found in the grave fills.Lynch (1991) describes a scattered group of eleven urned cremations associated with a line of shallow, charcoal-rich pits/scoops. Contradicting her earlier arguments, she notes that there may have been a cairn but heavy ploughing would have destroyed this. It is noted that 12 adults and 5 children (4 of which were buried with an adult) were identified from the cremated remains. One elderly woman was suffering from arthritis; 2 people had back troubles. These details are not assigned here as only in one case is info provided for which remains were associated with which grave/vessel (see figs 12a, 13a and 14a for details of the pots; see fig 12a for a cemetery plan, showing details of upright/inverted urns; see 394-5 for rc dates).The graves are labelled according to Lynch's 1991 pot numbers.A gold dress ring and an additional bone pin were found in the topsoil.
Site_description: Nineteen EBA cremation burials with collared urns. A gold ring paralleled by two similar rings in the BM from a hoard of 22 objects found at Gaerwen in about 1820. <1> <2>Cremation cemetery of Early Bronze Age date. See Transactions of the Anglesey Antiquarian Society 1999. Now visible as uneven field. <2>A cremation cemetery of the BA in which burials were urned and grouped in an arc centred on a hearth. This lay S of an unurned cremation discovered in 1978 and may indicate two periods of BA burial. The gold dress ring was found in topsoil W of the cemetery and may indicate the 'Gaerwen hoard' find spot. <3>Photo in Fi file.

Site_summary: Large inverted urn (or enlarged food vessel) found on Bryn Ifan farm in 1876. Workmen found it when they were repairing a fence. It was covering a smaller upright urn of bones. Larger urn decorated with incised herring bone pattern, lay on a rough slab (possibly a slab-lined cist or pit) http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/420338/details/BRYN+IFAN%2C+BURIAL+URN+FINDSPOT/
Site_description: Large inverted urn (or enlarged food vessel) found on Bryn Ifan farm in 1876. It was covering a smaller upright urn of bones. Larger urn decorated with incised herring bone pattern, lay on a rough slab but there was no trace of a cist. The vessel was formerly in the F. G. Wynn collection but it now lost, the smaller was destroyed at the time of discovery. (RCAHMW, 1960) <2> <3> No further information could be gained locally. <4>2 urns with bones found in 1876.  Now lost.  The exact find spot not known. (Smith, 2003)

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Poor contextual detail. Assigned generic BA date in the absence of decent evidence.
Site_description: In March 1821, 10 urns, each contained within a small covered stone cist, were found laid in a straight line about 18 inches below the surface in a field on Llystyn Farm, Dolbenmaen. They lay within a circle 15ft in diameter defined by a low stone wall. The urns fell to pieces when an attempt was made to remove them and there is no record of any fragments having been preserved, nor is there any mention of their contents except for the first which is said to have contained a small piece of copper; They are however referred to as sepulchral. G.E.Evans, Arch. Camb. 1923. <1>Hemp (<4>) stated that the exact find-spot was pointed out to him by the Rev. Henry Hughes of Bryniau 'as indicated to him by one who was present when the urns were first discovered'. This information - if reliable after the lapse of almost a century - appears to have been passed on to the Royal Commission whose OS 6" shows the find spot at SH 47974490 (<3>). <2>Sir Cyril and Lady Fox (<2>) draw a parallel between these interments and a very similar find in the Golden mile barrow (SS97NE 19), Glamorgan, which they date somewhere between 700 and 400 BC. <3>The find spot now falls within a modern gravel pit. No further siting information. <4>A linear alignment of ten stone cists containing funerary urns was located in 1821. They were excavated on the site of the present gravel diggings but are believed to have fallen to pieces when they were removed. (Richards, 1998). Site of a kerbed cairn within which was line of (10?) cists in which were 10 urns, one containing a piece of copper. All now lost. The site has been destroyed by gravel quarrying. (Smith, 2003)

Site_name_other: Two Barrows, Site of, Penmaenmawr Quarry
Site_summary: <A large number of urned and urned cremations were found during quarrying activities in a barrow. The urned cremations were all placed in an inverted position. Although possibly more than ten urned cremations were found, only 6 are documented in any degree of detail. At Least 8 unurned cremations in 2 groups ( a group of 5 and a group of 3) - just heaps of cremated bone with no associated grave goods - were also documented. Note some unusual grave goods here and a potentially unique pygmy stone egg-shaped vessel
Site_description: In 1890, a barrow, 30ft x 15ft and 3ft high was excavated at the Penmaenmawr granite works. It had been found in 1889 while trimming the side of a tramway to a new crushing mill. Another large barrow existed near it. A longitudinal trench yielded 6 cinerary urns, inverted on stone slabs. In two of them, bronze pins 1 1/2 inches long were found, in another, a pigmy cup, and in another a stone pigmy cup. Five urned cremations were found, about 36 of them within an irregularly shaped enclosure of upright stones from 18 to 30ins in height.Subsequently another urn and 3 un-urned cremation burials were found besides 3 urns (found and destroyed by workmen) one large and very small one found before the excavation took place. One cinerary urn, one pigmy cup, the stone cup and both bronze pins are in Grovesnor Museum, Chester. Two urns are in private possession, the other 6 urns found have been lost - from barrow Braich-lwyd, Penmaenmawr. <1>The pigmy cup and the two urns are at Bangor Museum. Acc No's 689, 693 respectively. Mr. I. Davies claims that one barrow was at SH 71057580 (now destroyed). The position of the 2nd barrow is not known. <2>No further information. <3>

Site_summary: <Although an incense cup was found there is no mention of human remains; these had degraded within the cist >
Site_description: Destroyed when Gorphwysfa Hotel was built (Crew 1983). It had a cist in which were found a piece of flint and a probable incense cup. Mentioned by Llwyd as being covered in white quartz. (Smith, 2003)

Site_name_other: Composite Cairn with Cist, Allt Lwyd
Site_summary: <Cairn was disturbed and mutilated. Cist with cremated bones and a flint flake said to be EBA>
Site_description: A fine round cairn on the summit of Allt Llwyd at NGR given; measures 75yds in circumference by 4ft high and retains round its edge the remains of a built ring of stones, 4ft wide, possibly bedded in clay, with an inner and outer face. The body of the mound is of base stones, and has been opened to reveal a capstone and cist which has been excavated from the W side and is reported to have contained charcoal and burnt bones. A flint flake from it is in the NMW. <1> <2>Re-surveyed at 1:2500. <3>Situated on the summit of the mountain is a ring cairn the interior of which a round cairn has been erected. The ring consists of earth and stone, largely grass covered, contrasting with the extremely bare surface of the round cairn. The centre of the latter has been hollowed out revealing a small cist. The cairn has been further mutilated by a second hollow, the spoil from which has been dumped on the NE side of the ring. The ring cairn is 20m NW-SE x 16m where best preserved. The ring is 2.3m wide and 0.4m high.The cist is orientated SSE-NNW, measuring 0.8m x 0.4m x 0.4m internally. It is formed of slabs 0.1m thick. Alongside it is a stone slab 1.3m x 1 x 0.2m which may be the capstone although surprisingly it carries an incised OS bench mark. <4>Earlier structure recorded by Gresham (No. 210) is a good example of a simple ring-cairn, though in an unusual position being on a mountain top. It has a bank of small piled stones some 2m wide and 25cm high, having an overall diameter of 24m. This is overlain on the S by two badly robbed cairns. <5>Allt Lwyd Cairn I is a large, impressive and largely intact example of a complex burial and ritual monument of the Early Bronze Age (c.2000-1500 BC). It is 23m in diameter and stands 2m high. There appear to be two main phases in the development of the cairn and the site offers an important insight into the evolution of ritual monuments during the Bronze Age. The first monument on the site was a large 'ring cairn' (a circular bank of stones) or platform cairn some 23m in diameter and 1m in height. Over this was built a prominent kerb cairn, approximately 15m in diameter  and 1.5m in height. The heap of stones, some of which  are still visible at its northern and south-western edges. This feature gives rise to the term 'kerb cairn'. In the centre of the cairn are the remains of a stone box or 'cist' which once held the body or ashes of those interred in monument. <6>Cist aligned NE - SW, c. 0.8 x 0.4.  A large, low platform - like cairn, possibly originally a low ring as previously described, rebuilt as a cairn mound later altered by a hugh robbing pit.  On the NE side is a low squarish extension or platform, possibly utilising stones from the cairn. (Smith, 2001)

Site_summary: <5 cremations associated with or contained within Food Vessels within ring cairn and the mound/ covering cairn>
Site_description: Carnedd Howel. The remains of a large circular cairn of stones and earth, about 80ft in diameter and 5ft high, on the summit of a  slight ridge at about 300ft above OD. The cairn was partly excavated circa 1869, when bronze age pottery was found. Marks of fire extended throughout the mound. <1>Fragments of a biconical cup and of six food vessels, found with cremations in a round cairn at Carnedd Howel, Llandegai. All in the Pitt Rivers Museum, Oxford. <2> <3> <4> Finds: 1) part of a Neolithic bowl with maggot ornament on the rim. 2) Bronze Age urn 8ins high. Food vessel type, decorated, containing burnt bones. 3) the base of a small food vessel, ornamented with a double ring of punched triangles. <5>The cairn is 30.0m diameter and 1.8m high. It is turf covered and has been landscaped on its N side. Surveyed at 1:2500. <6>The monument comprises the remains of a circular burial mound, probably dating to the early Bronze Age (c.2300 BC - 1400 BC). It is situated upon the summit of a low rise overlooking ground to the south and east, and is now incorporated into a domestic garden. The cairn is circular on plan and measures about 30m in diameter and up to 1.8m in height. Although modified by garden landscaping, it appears to be largely undisturbed and has a well-defined rounded profile. It was partially excavated in c.1863, when as urn (and further fragments) of early Bronze Age 'food vessel' type was discovered, alongside associated evidence of cremation burials. Part of what may be a late Neolithic bowl was also recovered. <8>Known as 'Carnedd Hywel' or 'Howel'. A personal name, which also occurs locally as Coed Hywel and Coed-Howel Mill. The cairn was excavated c. 1869. Finds included burnt bones, a Neolithic? bowl, a Food Vessel urn and a Small Food Vessel. These are in the Pitt Rivers Museum, Oxford. This is a large mound constructed of rounded stones originating from fluvio-glacial deposits.  Landowner stated that the stones are very closely and carefully packed together. Construction of a garden path, observed by GAT, exposed some boulders at the north side of the mound, certainly cairn material and possibly part of a kerb. The mound is now a garden and has been modified on its SE side where it is now revetted by a wall.  There has also been some loss of the mound near the house, to the N.  A vague linear hollow may represent an 1869 excavation trench.  The cairn is on the summit of a low rise and has excellent views, especially towards the hills to the S & E.  The view is blocked to the NW by a ridge. (Smith 2002)

Site_name_other: Barclodiad y Gawres Burial Chamber, Aberffraw
Site_summary: <Barclodiad y Gawres is a cruciform passage grave related to the famous tombs of the Boyne valley, Ireland. Originally consisting of a long narrow passage leading to a central chamber and 3 lower side chambers covered by a large circular mound, it is now partially restored and has been re-roofed with a concrete capping. Five of the stones which make up the walls of the chamber are decorated with abstract designs including spirals, zigzags and lozenges.Excavations in 1952-3 by T.G.E.Powell and G.E.Daniel revealed that a fire in the centre of the chamber had been quenched by a stew containing the bones of reptiles, fish and small animals, which were then covered with limpet shells.Two cremations of adult males were found in the west chamber associated with 2 burnt bone pins. There is a possible later insertion of a Beaker burial after the passage was deliberately closed and blocked but there are no details about the burial - just Beaker sherds>http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/95545/details/BARCLODIAD+Y+GAWRES+BURIAL+CHAMBER+%3B'THE
Site_description: The mound was originally 90ft in diameter; entrance to the chamber was from the north side by way of a passage flanked by upright stone slabs. The passage was about 20ft long and all of the roofing slabs have been removed. In the passage the small standing stone in a niche in the left hand wall should be noted. The central burial chamber was approx. polygonal in plan and some 12ft across. Three subsidiary chambers opened off the central chamber, one directly in front and one on either side. The right hand chamber retains its original blocking device of several slabs shutting it off from the central chamber. In this was found a cremated bone and portions of broken pins. The central chamber contained a hearth but was not used for actual burial purposes. Open cliff site excavated, rebuilt and re-roofed with a concrete dome in 1952-3. <1>A mound 32m in diameter has been constructed over the remains of the burial chamber to represent the original mound. It is 3.6m high with a glass top to illuminate the interior. The entrance in the N side is a reconstruction. <2>As described, contains stones with patterns on them. <3>Decorated stones as described RCAHM. A cairn lies 130m NNW of the chamber and was partly excavated in 1953. An assemblage of Mesolithic flints have been found in the field E of the chamber. <5>Excavated and restored. Because of its size it would have been quite visible locally but would have been most prominent when viewed from the sea and the location is probably related to a boat landing place in Porth Trecastell. (Smith, 2003)

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Isolated findspot, possibly from Penrhyn Mawr, Llanbadrig? Recent mentions of this find (Cooke 2014; Hadley 2016) make it clear that there is little information regarding its exact provenance and context of discovery. Only basic info is entered here. Pot may be similar to that from Plas Penrhyn, Llangeinwen but the sites are on the opposite side of Anglesey.The site is called Penrhyn Mawr here to avoid confusion between the two sites.
Site_description: A late Bronze Age urn, sadly fragmented, containing burnt bones, found at Plas Penrhyn, Llanbadrig. <1>Almost certainly identical with the urn from Plas Penrhyn, Llangeinwen (SH46SE 3). No further information. <2>

Site_name_other: Cist Burial, Site of, Rhosbeirio Farmyard
Site_summary: <A pair of barrows/cairns  - this  more southerly one contained a cist with a crouched inhumation accompanied by a late derived Beaker>
Site_description: Shortly before 1867 a stone cist was discovered in Rhosbeirio farmyard. It contained a skeleton and an A3 beaker (c.1500BC) since lost. <1>Local resident pointed out the site but there is nothing now visible. <2>The cist no longer survives and the skeleton and urn found in it are lost. (Smith, 2003)

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Lynch (1991, 199-200) summarises the site as follows: Four pots were found in-situ, inverted and without cists, of the three other pots recovered by workmen only one (no. 7) was standing upright. 'It is not certain how many of the pots contained cremated bone':Pot no. 1: contained the bones of a woman mixed with charcoalPot no. 2: the rim, found in-situ was packed with dark material including charcoal but not a trace of human bonePot no. 3: badly broken, contents not describedPot no. 4: most of its contents of earth and bone were intact (in Bangor Museum)Pot no. 5: badly broken, contents not describedPot no. 6: contained a mass of charcoal with a few tiny pieces of bonePot no. 7: contents not describedOnly the pots directly associated with human remains (Lynch 1991 Pots 1, 4 and 6) are recorded here.NB at least three of these are Collared Urns <cenotaph>
Site_description: Four urns in situ and fragments of three others were found within an area 120ft by 60ft when levelling ground for a tennis lawn in a field next to a wood and close to a house at Plas Penrhyn. The NE corner of the site was 40ft from the edge of the wood and the site was 50yds from the Menai Straits in March 1928. It is probable that at least six urns were buried in an inverted position without a projecting cist or cover stone, each burial was just under the surface and approximately at one level, which suggests an urnfield rather than a barrow. <1>Six Middle (sic Early)  Bronze Age urns, and one Late (ic transitional Early-Middle) Bronze Age encrusted urns, from a destroyed barrow are kept in Bangor Museum. (RCAHMW, 1937)The urns are still kept in Bangor Museum. <3>Site of urnfield uncovered and destroyed in 1928.  Six MBA urns in Bangor Museum. Site not visited. (Smith, 2003)

Site_name_other: Tumulus and Urn Burial, Site of, Nr.
Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Barrow that was disturbed while stone collecting for building outhouse farm buildings. Two urned cremations were found. In both cases the larger inverted Collared Urns wee set on flat stones and covered/ contained smaller highly decorated pygmy cups. These were set upright. Both the CU and the miniature cups contained cremated bones and ashes and these were interpreted as containing burials of mother and child in 1868. Analysis of the bone bore this out - one young adult c. 20-24 years old, possibly female and an infant. The infant was accompanied by the cremated remains of a small mammal, possibly a dog
Site_description: A pigmy cup, found in a tumulus near Bryn Seiont, Llanbeblig, is in the NMW. <1> <2>The cup was contained in a large cinerary urn which was destroyed at the time of discovery. Several other sepulchral vessels are said to have been found at the same time. <3>No further information. <4>19th ref.  Tumulus with 'several sepulchral urns' now all destroyed. (Smith, 2002)

Site_name_other: Urn Burial, Maes y Barcer, Caernarfon
Site_summary: <Inverted enlarged Food Vessel containing cremation>
Site_description: A Middle Bronze Age cinerary urn was found in September 1946, during the cutting of a drain on the new housing estate at Maes-y-barker, near Caernarfon. The exact site lay about 100yds NE of Maes-y-barker farm, and S of the Caernarfon-Llanberis road. The urn, which contained cremated bones, was found inverted about 18ins below the present ground level and is now in the NMW. There was no trace of a barrow. <1> <3>No further information. Area fully developed. <4>Accidental discovery of urn with cremation, now in NMW.  Site destroyed. (Smith, 2002)

Site_name_other: Tumulus and Urn Burial, Waterloo Port, Caernarfon
Site_summary: In 1853, Caernarfon railway workers discovered human remains in a gravel pit near to Waterloo Port.  This was assumed to be a burial mound, although currently there is no visible trace of such a mound.  Just days later, a bronze age urn was discovered within 3 metres of the bones.  It contained the remains of a cremation burial.  These are usually discovered underneath barrows (burial mounds) and reflect the burial traditions of the time. It was a Collared Urn
Site_description: A barrow full of supposed human bones, was found on the 27th Jan 1853 about 20yds from the shore of the Menai Straits by men employed in a gravel pit adjoining the Caernarfon railway, near Waterloo Port, Caernarfon. An overhanging rim cinerary urn of coarse red buff ware, containing a cremation, was found in the same week within. Three yards from the barow. <1>The urn is in the NMW (Acc No. 2124 40). <2>No further siting information. <3>The site of a presumed barrow where human bones were found at Waterloo Port during 19th century gravel quarrying.  The site is a pasture field where a slight depression probably marks the position of the gravel pit. There is no erosion threat to the site but the field could be suitable for building development when a watching brief would be desirable. (Riley & Smith, 1993)At about the approximate location given there is a deep linear hollow in the field about 10m long which is the only visible sign of a 'gravel pit' in this area and so is probably it.  There are various undulations in the field around it but no sign of any barrow mound. (Smith, 2002)

Site_name_other: Urn Burials, Findspot, Cae Meini, Llanidan
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Large flat cremation cemetery with Collared Urn burials. 32 burials found in 1882. Not all were accompanied or contained within pots etc. The burials were all in quite shallow pits, between 15 and 30cm below ground surface. Some cremations simply set into holes without pot. Most that were in pots were inverted Collared Urns. And many were protected by a small stone. Only 13 were well preserved enough to record well. But Law (2009) lists 19. 2 Accessory cups (inside two of the other Collared Urns) were also found.The burials were all in quite shallow pits, between 15 and 30cm below ground surface. Some cremations simply set into holes without pot. Most that were in pots were inverted Collared Urns. And many were protected by a small stone. All in small pits<Note this also encompasses a flat urnfield although it is possible that a barrow was totally flattened. There is absolutely no mention or observation of any mound however. This is important as these urned cremations were all in various shapes and styles of Collared Urns. Could this cemetery be transitional between the Early and Middle Bronze Ages? Flat cemetery and 7 cremations were placed unurned shallow small pits (c. 0.15-0.30m deep) and at least another 25-27 urned cremations. 27 pots were noted but possibly 2 had pygmy vessels within the larger urns. Most are inverted. There is information about only 17 of these vessels, but the cemetery in total comprised a MNI of 32 cremations. Apart from pots, the only other gg was a awl made of Cu and lead >
Site_description: A group of Bronze Age burials was found in 1882 in a small field belonging to a farm called Cae Meini (SH 456 681). No less than 32 cremation burials were found in a circle 36ft in diameter. 25 urns were found, 13 more or less intact, the remainder being fragments. One contained a bronze pin. Nine urns are in Bangor Museum. <1>An urnfield without a trace of a cairn. A Middle Bronze Age undecorated, fragmentary pigmy cup without a base was also found. <2>The field in which these burials were found could not be located. Mrs. H. Owen, Llangaffo knows nothing of the find on the land which forms part of Dinam. The urns are in Bangor Museum. <3>Urnfield found in 1882 but exact findspot not known. 32 cremations in a circle 36ft dia., 25 in urns, one with a bronze pin. 9 urns in Bangor Museum. (Smith, 2003)

Site_summary: <Only 2 of the 8 cists contained grave goods (pots). In all cases, due to soil acidity, the bone was totally degraded. Note one cist had an Irish-influenced Food Bowl that was set on a cushion of soil>
Site_description: A group of eight short cist graves contained within a circular area c. 10m in diameter and possibly originally under a barrow. There were 3 small cists and 5 larger ones. Two of the large cists contained pots, one Food Vessel and one Beaker but there were few other finds and no surviving human remains. (Kenney et al, 2011)

Site_summary: <1 urned cremation (CU). The other grave goods were placed next to the urned cremation. THere was the bone pommel of the dagger but where is the rest of the dagger?>
Site_description: A fine collared-rim urn containing a cremation burial associated with a bronze awl and a bone dagger pommel unaccompanied by the blade. (RCAHMW, 1964)It was found in 1958 by Mr. H. Jones when ploughing a field at Rhiw. <2>The urn was contained in a stone cist. Finds in the Museum of Wales. <3>Mr. H. Jones indicated the find spot at SH 2279 2783. <4>Improved field. No features visible. (Smith, 2003)

Site_summary: <Small Early Bronze Age cremation cemetery with interesting grave goods. These include a faience bead and a shale stud (ear or nose stud). <gg_summary>: nine pits containing cremated remains, seven containing burial urns (inverted, nine urns in total), one containing an accessory vessel. Other grave goods include a shale/jet stud and a faience bead.Cefn Cwmwd (Cuttler et al 2012), F. 1014: In pit F1014 the bone (1228g) had been placed in a reasonably intact, inverted um (Pot 3, SF287). Charcoal from the pot provided a C 14 date of 1890-1520 cal BC.
Site_description: Rhostrehwfa. Excavated as part of the A55 roadscheme (Roberts, Cuttler and Hughes 2004). Excavations produced a Bronze Age cremation pit cemetery, associated with a timber circle, and another long lived settlement dating from the later prehistoric period into the early post-Roman period. Several buildings and possible buildings identified, and a few were situated alongside a pebble trackway. Extensive nucleated settlement, pottery c. 1st to 4th AD. Pit group S16 with Neolithic pottery but radiocarbon 360BC - AD30. Pit circle S1 dated 400-160BC (this possibly the remains of a roundhouse too). Trackway forms boundary? Possible mid to late Iron Age origins for settlement, used into later Roman period.The settlement produced an assemblage of Romano-British pottery dating to later 1C to mid 4C AD, with a high percentage of fine imported wares (samian wares). The ceramics suggest a high status site, also supported by the presence of glass beads, a shale bracelet, and a coin hoard dating to the late 3C AD. Other finds include ceramic and lead spindle whorls, and worked stone objects including rotary querns and mortars. Early medieval objects also recovered in the rubble overlying the remains of the houses, including a Byzantine intaglio, an early post-Roman penannular brooch and sherd from a D ware platter (a rare imported high status ware from SW France).Excavation area: 7234m and 564m (Waddington, 2010) Excavations as part of the A55 road scheme at Cefn Cwmwd revealed a long and complex sequence stretching from the Bronze Age to the early medieval period (Roberts et al. 2004, 20). Early activity on the site took the form of an earlier Bronze Age funerary and ceremonial complex consisting of a cremation cemetery and a timber circle. The later Iron Age and Romano-British settlement consists of several broadly contemporary roundhouses located alongside a pebble trackway (Figure 6.20). They are likely to be the result of a long phase of occupation which saw the renewal and reconstruction of the roundhouses. The site was relatively rich in finds and may have been of high status in the Romano-British period due to the amount of imported samian wares recovered. A large assemblage of pottery sherds alongside a collection of glass beads, a shale bracelet, a coin hoard of the late-third century AD, ceramic and lead spindle whorls and worked stone artefacts including rotary querns and mortars, dates this phase of occupation to the later first to mid-fourth centuries AD. An early medieval phase of occupation is also represented by the objects from the rubble contexts overlying the roundhouses, including a Byzantine intaglio, an early post-Roman penannular brooch and a sherd of D-ware platter  a rare imported ware from SW France (Roberts et al. 2004, 20). This suggests that the decayed dwellings were a focus for ephemeral occupation activities between the fifth and seventh centuries AD. The settlement is characterized by clusters of dwellings and pit clusters situated either side of the cobbled trackway (S10), which was nearly 4m wide and aligned northeastsouthwest. It was largely made from two compact layers of gravel and stone, which displayed evidence of wear. A possible contemporary ditched field system, aligned eastwest, was identified to the southeast of the settlement, alongside a small ditched enclosure (S7), interpreted as an animal pen (Roberts et al. 2004, 27). Six of the settlement buildings were excavated in detail (S2, S6, S4, S5, S3, S8; (Roberts et al. 2004, 2431) and they are discussed below in chronological order.

Site_name_other: Cist with Urn, Findspot, Glan Yr Afon
Site_summary: <No further detail apart from urn (now lost) with cremation in a short cist; this could belong to any period of the Bronze Age>
Site_description: An urn containing ashes was found in a stone cist about 35 years ago (1864) while ploughing in a field on Glan-yr-Afon farm not more than 180m from the present road. The urn was broken and its contents scattered by accident just after discovery. <1>Mr. R. R. Davies owner of Glan-yr-Afon farm knows nothing of this burial. <2>An urn with ashes found whilst ploughing c.1864.  Neither urn nor cist have survived. (Smith, 2002)

Site_summary: http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/95532/details/LLIGWY+BURIAL+CHAMBER%2C+NEAR+MOELFRE/<gg summary>: From chamber, human and animal bones, flint scrapers, and fragments of pottery. Below this was a 3in thick paving stone, below which was a 9in thick layer of black soil and small stones with bones, worked flints and fragments of pottery. The bones from up to thirty people have been found in the chamber, as well as shellfish (mussels and limpets) and many animal bones. Fragments of pottery from the two different settlement periods are present; grooved ware dating to the Neolithic period and beaker ware from the early Bronze Age
Site_description: First reference to it was made by Pennant in 1781. Skinner visited it and gives some details and two sketches in his Tour Through Anglesey in 1802, in which he says the covering earth mound had been removed. Excavated in 1908, the capstone is 18ft 3in by 15ft 9in and 3ft 6in thick. The stones forming the sides are 8 in number. The capstone is supported by the two horizontal stones on each side of the entrance to the E and by a long stone set on edge on the W. The five remaining stones from 3ft to 4ft in length stand upon an artificial foundation of rough stones laid horizontally. The level of soil within the chamber was about 2ft below the capstone and about 2ft deep. Below this was a 1in thick layer of red, clayey soil with limpet shells embedded in it and immediately below it. Then came a 15in layer of black soil and stones in which was dispersed some human and animal bones, flint scrapers, and fragments of pottery. Below this was a 3in thick paving stone, below which was a 9in thick layer of black soil and small stones with bones, worked flints and fragments of pottery. At the bottom was a wet, stick soil containing a quantity of mussel shells. At a distance of about 6ft below the capstone, undisturbed soil was reached.The finds were 4 flint scrapers, flint flakes and pieces of flint; fragments of a coarse brown pottery with an incised design of zigzag lines; fragments of coarse black pottery; two fragments of ware, one piece of rim having a zigzag pattern; parts of 12 or more human jaws, a few of which later appeared to be identical to Eskimo jaw bones; and many fragments of skulls and bones, one of which was a foot bone of especial interest, being that of a six-toed individual; bones and teeth of a small ox, a sheep and a young pig; portions of the horns and bones of red and roe deer; the femur of a fox; the wing-bone of a fowl; and portions of an otter's skull.An opening was made in the soil just to the N of the cromlech and at a depth of 4ft was found black soil containing a quantity of human teeth and fragments of bone, a flint scraper, a bone pin 4 1/2ins long by 1/4in thick and pointed at one end, and some teeth of bos, pig, and dog. The soil extended only 3ft 6ins from the cromlech and suggested that an entry into the chamber may have been forced here. There is no record or tradition of the burials which have taken place here or as to the origin of this cromlech. <2>There is one feature about the arrangement of the uprights of this dolmen which appears to be exceptional. The SE supporter points almost exactly due E and on the opposite side is a flat slab pointing almost due W. On the S side, another flat slab, set at right angles to the wall of the chamber points toward the S, but movement of the capstone has shifted it slightly. These features point to an early age when some form of sun worship was practised as the equinoxes and the solstices can be ascertained by the alignment of these stones. Sir Norman Lockyer obtained a clock star alignment from an outlying stone in a neighbouring field, enabling him to suggest 1200 to 1000 BC as the date of the monuments execution. It is probable that a passage led up to the entrance and three stones found lying outside the chamber may have been used in its construction. Most of the pieces of pottery are precisely similar to those found at Din Lligwy Village. It is an equinoctial monument and is composed of carboniferous limestone throughout. A natural outcrop of large limestone slabs, lying on the surface is to be found within a few yards of the monument. <3>

Site_summary: <Two Collared Urn cremations (at least!) accompanied by other unburnt grave goods in the pots. One has a dagger and the other an exceptional needle!>NB several of the finds are illustrated
Site_description: At Bryn Crug. If there had been a barrow (crug: a mound) at the spot it had been removed when trenching during the farming operations c. 1868 revealed an inverted cinerary urn, within which was a second urn containing burnt bones, a pygmy cup, and a bronze pin, 1 1/4 in long, since lost. Another interment had been found at Crug about 1855 with urns which were said to have resembled those reported in 1868, accompanied by a small tanged bronze knife blade, a pin with a pierced flat head, and a double-looped palstave. The urns have been lost. <1>Fragments of the urns found in c. 1868 and bronze implements found in 1855 are in the National Museum of Wales; the pygmy cup is in Chester Museum. (RCAHMW, 1960)The name 'crug' refers to the large natural mound in the grounds of Crug house. There is no evidence of a 'camp' or any further siting information for the burials. <3>Illustration of bronze implements found at site. <4>Marked on OS 6 inch 1920 as Camp [O.E]. <5>The likely location for the barrow would be on top of the natural rocky mound which is now the garden at Crug House.  This is overgrown and stones have been moved to form edges to garden beds so recognising genuine remains of a damaged barrow is very difficult.  The hill has good allround views.  No additional finds to those discovered in C19th are known about by the owners. (Smith, 2002)

Site_name_other: Pant y Saer Burial Chamber, Tynygongl
Site_summary: <gg summary>:  Many fragments of human and animal bones were found and seashells. It is clear that this tomb had been re-used for burial in Beaker times. Complete beaker in the chamber and also a great quantity of fragmented human bones, chert, and flint arrowheads.http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/95529/details/PANT-Y-SAER+BURIAL+CHAMBER/
Site_description: 1 cromlech at Marvan Pant y Saer. <1>A rectangular chamber which presents its sides to the cardinal points, 8ft long by 6ft wide, its length being in direction E to W. Capstone 9ft by 9ft by 2 1/2ft thick and partly dismounted, its S corner resting on the ground. Within was a flat stone 6ft long by 2ft 3in wide narrowing to 1ft 9in wide and 7in thick, covering a cist grave which lay NW by SE, diagonal to the cromlech. Many fragments of human and animal bones were found and seashells. <2>Pany y Saer burial chamber: a rectangular chamber in a kidney shaped cairn, about 60ft by 50ft and 2 1/2ft high. Fully excavated by Lindsay Scott in 1933. Scott found a complete beaker in the chamber and also a great quantity of fragmented human bones, chert, and flint arrowheads. <3>On a limestone plateau, sloping to the S and E it consists of a burial chamber constructed over a pit and with an attached forecourt, covered by a cairn. It seems certain that the structure was built towards the close of the Neolithic period, and that interments continued to be made into the beaker period of the early Bronze Age. Condition - fair. (RCAHMW, 1937)SH 50978239 burial chamber LB. <6>Mound 0.4m high, otherwise as described. Published survey 25" revised. <8>Limestone burial chamber - massive capstone fallen to E. Edges of mound 0.4 high and clearly defined. Site partially dismantled and excavated revealing cist etc in 1933 (Scott). Now consists of two 1.3m high orthostatic slabs and a capstone leaning on these at close to 45 degrees angle. Setting: Natural terrace on hillslope no obvious reverse prospect. (Smith, 2003)

Site_name_other: Urn Burials, Site of, Pen yr Orsedd, Nefyn
Site_summary: <This is an unusual feature - one large cist containing several urns. At least 3 had cremations and these were placed in inverted large urns like beehives (Collared Urns?) and accompanied by two small pygmy cups that were empty>
Site_description: A cist containing three or four large, inverted cremation urns besides other, smaller, empty urns, was found in 1691 at Pen yr Orsedd. This place was on rising ground a furlong W of the former Plas yng Ngheidio, which stood a short distance N of the present Plas yng Ngheidio (SH 293389). The name Pen yr Orsedd is preserved by one of the houses on the N slope close by, facing the road to Morfa Nefyn, the occupier of which, Evan Thomas, recalled in 1954 the tradition that the place was an old cemetery. Nothing could be seen then at the spot. The site was visited on 22/9/1954, all that was visible was a slightly elevated field with no trace of any remains. <1>The circumstances of the discovery are preserved in a NLW manuscript possibly written by the Rev. John Lloyd, headmaster of Ruthin School (1691-1695). <2>The name Pen yr Orsedd applies to the group of buildings surrounding Bryn Berllan, the former residence of Mr. Evan Thomas, deceased. <3>No further information. <4>A National Library of Wales manuscript possibly written by the Rev John Lloyd headmaster of Ruthin school records that a cist containing three or four large inverted cremation urns was found at Pen yr Orsedd in 1691. Pen yr Orsedd was recorded as being close to Plas yng Ngheidio. The name Pen yr Orsedd is preserved by a house on the road to Morfa Nefyn and a former owner recorded that local tradition maintains that it was the site of an old cemetery. The house stands about 40m to the north of the pipeline. Bronze Age burials are frequently found in groups forming small cemeteries and often have associated barrows. (Hopewell & Smith, 2003)Several urns found in a stone cist in the 17th century. Known only from a manuscript description (NLW). (Smith, 2003)

Site_name_other: Urn Cremation, Site of, Nr. Tremvan Hall
Site_summary: <gg_summary>: basic info added. No further details available. Pretty certainly NOT Neolithic
Site_description: An urn containing cremated bone found at Tremvan Hall, Llanbedrog, is now lost. Listed under Neolithic and Bronze Age. (RCAHMW, 1964)Dr. E. H. Evans is dead. Local enquiries elicited no further information. <2>Known only from a C19th description. Exact location unknown and finds lost. (Smith, 2003)

Site_name_other: Cist Burial, Site of, Nr. Pen y Bonc
Site_summary: Accidentally discovered by farmer and very poorly recorded. No mention of a burial but possibly an inhumation which had decayed. In a rock-cut cist 1m square and covered by a capstone. F. Lynch (1970: 122) says it was covered by a barrow and this is unusual because it is a single burial then. In cist were 2 urns which fell to pieces on exposure and an elaborate crescentic spacer plate jet necklace (although the spacers were not decorated). There was also a V-perforated jet button and 2 bronze armlets. The necklace and button are in the BM.
Site_description: Bronze Age burial found AD 1828. <1>Jet necklace, v-bored jet button, 2 urns and bronze armlets. In British Museum. (RCAHMW, 1937)A rock cut grave, 3ft square with coverstone, Found at Pen-y-Bonc in 1828 contained two urns, an early Bronze Age jet necklace, a jet button and bronze armlets. The urns fell to peices and were not preserved. <3> <4>'The bronze armlets were never in the British Museum - they were lost'. No sign of a rock-cut grave. No further information on the jet necklace. <5>Known only from a C19th reference. Not located since. Important finds, now lost mean that the site needs further investigation. Called at farm to ask for information and permission to walk about but no-one in. (Smith, 2003)

Site_name_other: Urn Burial, Findspot, Pen y Bryn Manor
Site_summary: Possible cist with inverted Collared Urn cremation. It may be part of a larger flat cemetery but only this single burial was encountered during road construction
Site_description: An urn of burnt clay, inverted on a flat stone, was found at a depth of about 3ft while constructing the road to Pen-y-bryn about 1824. It contains ashes and a piece of a skull. <1>Whereabouts unknown. (RCAHMW, 1956)No further information. <3>The urn was (apparently) found during work on the top part of the road to Pen y Bryn Manor. <4>19th century ref.  Object now lost.  Apparently a flat, urnfield burial.  Exact findspot unknown. (Smith, 2002)

Site_summary: he barrow was constructed for ritual and funerary purposes in the Bronze Age (c.2300 BC - 800 BC). The artefacts recovered from excavation also indicate that it was re-used in the Early Medieval period (the latter period of the first millennium AD). The monument possesses a combination of high quality attributes and this diversity provides an insight into the ritual and funerary practices of two distinct chronological periods. It is hard to differentiate the two as there is disturbance and contamination anf the excavation is not rercorded in detail. Likely that the EBA cremations were placed unurned on the clay floor and covered by beach cobbles, some of which were also burnt. THere were two perforated stone pendants
Site_description: Excavated by Mr. W. Wynee Ffoulkes before 1874. The tumulus is approx. 12ft high and 54ft in diameter. On the S side of mound from a trench dug large quantities of charcoal was discovered with perforated stone discs (spindle whorls). Immediately 3ft 3ins below the apex a closely compacted clay floor was found, on top of which charcoal and some burnt bones as well as a small piece of corroded bronze. After digging deeper a similar clay floor was found a considerable deposit of burnt bones. With the bones were a number of small rounded pebbles and a piece of tightly rolled sheet lead formed like a plummet weight with a hole through it. Further deposits of burnt bones were found above the levels of clay flooring during further excavation suggesting the tumulus had been used as a burial place during two different periods. Wynne suggests this is site referred to as Tomen Las, mentioned in a lease of 1530. <1>There is no reason to believe Tyddyn y Domen Las is the same as Pentre farm. The tumulus us 300yds directly S of the ruins of Cymmer Abbey. <2>The mound is about 8-10ft high and much destroyed by the excavation. It is suggested that material from different periods and the secondary burials of burnt bones, during Ffoulkes' excavation, became mixed up owing to the method of working from the top downwards. <3>Survives as turf covered mound diameter of 22.0m and 14.0m and 2.3m high. <4>This large and impressive mound is in a small enclosed field immediately adjacent to Pentre farmhouse. It is sub-circular and measures 22m in diameter and 2.8m tall. The mound is built of soil and stones, and is almost entirely covered by a grass sward. Partial excavation in 1871 revealed burnt bone, structural features and artefacts including spindle whorls and lead and bronze objects. The barrow was constructed for ritual and funerary purposes in the Bronze Age (c.2300 BC - 800 BC). The artefacts recovered from excavation also indicate that it was re-used in the Early Medieval period (the latter period of the first millennium AD). The monument possesses a combination of high quality attributes and this diversity provides an insight into the ritual and funerary practices of two distinct chronological periods. A mound of this size also represents a significant and rare lowland survival.The scheduled area comprises the remains described and an area around them within which related evidence may be expected to survive. It is an irregular rectangle on plan. The boundary of the scheduled area is as follows: N edge follows the S side of the track for 18m; the W edge follows the N-S field boundary to the W for 20m; the E edge follows the N-S fence line to the E where this turns E, the boundary projects a further 8m S in a straight line; the S edge runs E-W from this point to meet the W field boundary. <6>DescriptionLarge grassed over mound apparently of stone and earth immediately adjacent to Pentre farmhouse.  Much disturbed by Ffoulkes excavation but still stands as a significant landscape feature.  No recent disturbance.  Stands above Mawddach valley on a prominent shelf below higher ground to NE. (Smith, 2001)

Site_summary: Three small stone-lined cists with Food Vessel cremations - only one recorded in any detail to be sure. Found during construction of water pipe
Site_description: During trenching for a pipeline from Cloddfa Goch in 1875, a cist was uncovered at a depth of 18ins, at the rear of the Buckley Arms Hotel at Dinas Mawddwy. Stone lined, it was 3ft long, 2ft wide at one end and 1.5ft at the other, and about 2ft deep, with a cover 4ft 9ins by 3ft. <1>The contents, apparently disturbed, including a small food vessel about 5ins high and nearly the same at its greatest diameter, ornamented with a few circular grooves. There were also traces of a cremation covered with loose gravel and sand. The urn was held by Sir Edmund Buckley. Two urns were said to have been found near this spot when excavating for railway premises, with the previous ten years. <2>Local enquiries elicit no further information regarding the various findspots. <3>Not visited, 19th century find of 3 burial urns. Exact findspot not known. No further information. (Smith, 2001)

Site_summary: Very complex and elaborate cist in barrow - excavated in 1908. The burial and grave goods are in accordance with either Late Neolithic or Beaker traditions. Body covered with leather hide and has a worn knife. The cist structure is exceptional - almost boat shaped and possibly unique (summarised Baynes 1909, 325-8)NB site name is Ty'n-Pwll, Llanddyfan in NMW
Site_description: Soil and course gravel, c.65yds circumference and 4' high. It covered a horseshoe-shaped chamber of stones packed in clay, containing a crouched burial on low platform. A finely serrated flint flake 2" long lay beside the skull. (RCAHMW, 1937)Now reduced to a ground swelling, the periphery of which cannot be readily identified. <2>Now barely recognisable and therefore of very low value. (Smith, 2003)

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Seven urned (probably secondary) cremations, one unurned cremation, some in cists, were recovered from the barrow mound. Contextual detail is provided in Baynes (1909). Five urns from this site, a bronze dagger and two chisels are noted to be in the National Museum of Wales where the site name is Ty'n-Pwll, Llanddyfan (accession no. 42.395.4/1-5 and 7-13). Several of the urns were analysed by Tellier (2015, 350).
Site_description: A cone of gravel 42' diameter, covered by a layer of stones and then by layers of sand and soil, the whole being about 90yds in circumference and 9' high. It contained 7 urn cremations, some in cists, all secondary and probably LBA. Also found an extended burial, head to the W without grave goods: probably Roman or later. (RCAHMW, 1937)3 urns lost; 5 urns, a bronze knife and 2 chisels preserved in the NMW. <2>A low oval mound 4m N-S and 32m E-W. It averages 1m in height and is flat topped. <3>A large, low mound, as previously described. There is a hint of a quarry ditch around the west and south sides. Although still a substantial earthwork, its complete robbing reduces its overall potential and value to quite low. (Smith, 2003)

Site_name_other: Round Barrow (N) NW of Pen y Gaer Hillfort, Caerhun
Site_summary: Centre excavated and burnt material and cremated bone (Tumulus F). A small piece of burnt copper found among the cremated bone and charcoal
Site_description: The northernmost of two barrows, each about 22ft diameter and 2 or 3ft high, surrounded by a shallow ditch. These were excavated in 1905. In both, the old ground surface was found to be covered with charcoal and burnt bone, with a few small fragments of copper and bronze. <1>This tumulus is on the side of the hill, which slopes gently in a N direction. In the centre it was found to be 2ft 1.5ins in height above the undisturbed ground level. Nearly the entire ground area was found to be covered with a layer of charcoal, and, incorporated with the same, numerous fragments of calcined bone, with patches of a bluish substance of a clayey appearance. A small fragment of copper was discovered amongst the charcoal and bones. The layer of charcoal rested on an undisturbed naturall clay formation. The process of burial may be convincingly arrived at from the circumstantial evidence. On the hill-side the funeral pyre was laid and lighted. The large area covered by the charcoal and the mixture of bone remains indicated that the body was cremated on the actual spot. Around the low tumulus, especially visible in the direction of the rise in the hill, is a sinking bearing the resemblance of a shallow ditch. It would appear that, after the fire had burnt down, the surrounding earth was deposited over the remains. This would account for the shallow depression surrounding the tumulus. The diameter of the tumulus is 20ft 6ins E to W, and 23ft N to S. The diameter across the depression is 33ft to 24ft. <2>The two mutilated barrows, both turf covered, are at SH 74836936 and SH 74836934. Surveyed at 25". <3>The remains of 2 round barrows are visible to the NW of the fort entrance. <4>A neat, circular, steep-sided, flat-topped grassy mound, presumably restored by Hughes after excavating.  Terraced into the slope producing a 'ditch' c.0.6m deep and 2m wide around the eastern, south and west sides. (Smith, 2002)

Site_name_other: Round Barrow (S) NW of Pen y Gaer Hillfort, Caerhun
Site_summary: Tumulus S which was disturbed and there was some cremated bone and a tiny fragment of copper - unurned cremation
Site_description: The southernmost of two barrows, each about 22ft diameter and 2 or 3ft high, surrounded by a shallow ditch. These were excavated in 1905. In both, the old ground surface was found to be covered with charcoal and burnt bone, with a few small fragments of copper and bronze. <1>This tumulus bore signs of having been disturbed. Mr. W. O. Roberts, of plas Dulyn, informed me that someone had been digging into it about two years previously. In the case of tumulus F (PRN 4558), nearly the whole original surface of the ground was exposed.A trench only from the SE was cut into this tumulus, a little further than its centre. Charcoal and calcined bone were found, similarly disposed to those in tumulus F, together with burnt stones and infinitesimal fragments of bronze. There were indications of burning at a higher level than the original ground surface, but these probably resulted from the disturbance caused by the former excavator. Tumulus S had a similar depression surrounding it to that of F. The manner of burning and burial and the construction of the mound appear to have been identical. The height from the original surface, at the centre of the tumulus, was 2ft 10ins. The diameters of the two tumuli, and the shallow depressions surrounding them, are practically identical in both instances. <2>The two mutilated barrows, both turf covered, are at SH 74836936 and SH 74836934.
