Surveyed at 25". <3>The remains of 2 round barrows are visible to the NW of the fort entrance. <4>Description as for 4558 (Smith, 2002)

Site_summary: No detail about urn etc
Site_description: (See also PRNs 3017 and 3018)Three scheduled round barrows on Mwdwl Eithin, the most northerly being 90 paces round and 9ft high, the others 70 paces by 5ft high lying 150 paces and 60 paces S of the former, the S one crossed by a fence.The central one was excavated 1911-12 and contained an unprotected central primary cremation; also two secondaries, one unprotected with two stone implements, the other beneath an urn in a rough cist. There was a retaining stone inside. <1>Round barrow surveyed at 1:2500 with diameter of 20m and height of 0.2m. Virtually ploughed out, there is no trace of a retaining circle. <2>Recent description. <3>Large but low barrow.  Broad hollow in top probably remains of excavation trench.  No stones visible.  No trace of kerb stones recorded during excavation.  Located on south-west edge of hill summit plateau. (Smith, 2002)

Site_summary: 7 'earthenware' urns with cremations - all inverted. THey were all in a dilapidated condition and fell to pieces, Uncertain as to what the urn types were. They were covered by stone pavement (capping stones?) Flat urnfield cemetery
Site_description: At least 7 cinerary urns were discovered 1875 by workmen clearing the ground for a new chapel at Ffrwd yr Hebog 1.5m from the village of Llanfachreth. The urns 'had been placed in the ground with their faces downwards without any order, at a depth of about two feet, and a sort of pavement of rough stones had been worked over the place.' The only find recorded was an unidentifiable piece of oxidised yellow metal. <1>7 cinerary urns discovered in 1875 during the construction of a chapel.  The chapel stands on a high point at the head of a valley visible from most directions.  A large mound behind the chapel is probably natural. (Smith, 2001)

Site_summary: Quite vague reference to pygmy cup and cinerary (?Collared Urn id verified from Longworth's Welsh gazetter) urn found as two separate burials and given to the NMW
Site_description: A cairn 60yds in circumference and up to 4ft high is situated on level ground at the foot of a slope. Two trenches have been dug across the mound down to ground level, and although no kerb stones are visible, the presence of some loose boulders near the excavations suggests that a kerb was encountered and destroyed. A pygmy cup and a cinerary urn found in the cairn (but not in association) were presented to the NMW by J Lee Evans in 1932. <1>The remains of this cairn are as described. Surveyed at 1:2500. <2>Badly disturbed (excavated) round cairn on a shelf at the foot of a steep slope.  Further steep slope to SE.  Prospect etc difficult to assess.  Cairn of mixed stones 0.2 - 0.6m - mainly angular but some cobbles perhaps from nearby scree.  Two trenches for a Y shape cut into corners presumably by excavation - 1930s.  No features exposed (Smith 2001).

Site_summary: Very interesting burial. The central cist is impressive and large and marked by a huge and heavy standing stone. Inside cist was a crouched inhumation of an adult with a tanged dagger & a gold ringIn the NMW as 'Tyddyn Bach Farm'. No contextual detailNMR_Wales NPRN_url: https://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/303076/details/round-barrow-tyddyn-bach#site-details
Site_description: A round cairn (or barrow) on the farm of Tyddyn Bach is about 6ft high and 90yds in circumference and lies partly beneath a field wall. It appears to be constructed of earth and has been somewhat denuded by ploughing. There is no sign of the standing stone which was removed from the top of the cairn in 1873 by the tenant of the farm, who found beneath it a cist built of stone slabs containing human bones, a bronze spearhead and a gold ring. The latter has been lost but the spearhead of a type found in association with flanged axes, is preserved at Nannau. <1>A turf covered round barrow 1.6m high, elongated, presumably by ploughing, with diameters of 20m and 28m. Surveyed at 1:2500. <2>The Tyddyn Bach round barrow is an exceptionally large, well-preserved and largely intact example of a burial monument of the Early Bronze Age (c. 2050-1500 BC). The monument is some 25m in diameter and 1.6m high and is unusual in a Welsh upland context in comprising a barrow of earth rather than the more usual cairn of stones. In 1873, human bones, a gold ring and a bronze spearhead were found in a box or "cist" underlying a standing stone at the centre of the mound. The spearhead dates to the Early Bronze Age (c. 2050 - 1700BC) and the site is one of the most important Welsh examples of a standing stone marking a burial of this period. The stone was one of only a handful of dated standing stones in Wales and is also one of the earliest. An electrotype replica of the spearhead is currently on display in the National Museum of Wales. <9>DescriptionA very large and widely spread mound.  Possibly it is a natural glacial mound into the top of which a burial and standing stone were inserted.  This is suggested by the size of the mound, the lack of any suggestion of a surrounding ditch and because the cist found in 1873 was clearly near the top of the mound as it was found during ploughing.  Also there is another similar but smaller mound in the next field to the east.  There is a shallow hollow on the east side which may be the old excavation trench.  There is no very likely former standing stone nearby.  The largest from the gate nearby was brought in living memory from the north side of the field.  The cist and finds were made by the tenant's father's great great grandfather!  Possibly some knowledge about the gold ring was withheld. (Smith, 2001)

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: (Bowen and Gresham 1967, 68-9). A  group of urns found at Pantyneuadd  in about 1885. This group included a decorated miniature accessory vessel (a type formerly called a pygmy cup or incense cup) (ibid 68), other accessory vessels and several urns with cremations. All but the first vessel were dispersed locally and have never been located. The owner of Pantyneuadd was reported as saying – ‘It was discovered, together with a number of other urns containing human ashes, some twenty five years ago at Pantyneuadd. I ought to say that another cup or two, besides the one I have, were found at the time and given to friends’ (Anwyl 1909, 162).Given the vagaries regarding numbers, and based on the details given in Bowen and Gresham 1967 (in particular 'each urn containing a cremation had a Pygmy Cup inverted at its mouth'), a MNI of 3 urned burials with accessory vessels as lids is recorded here.
Site_description: Several Middle Bronze Age cremations were found c.1884 during removal of a hedge in the garden of Pantyneuadd, Towyn. Each urn containing a cremation had a Pygmy Cup inverted at its mouth. (Bowen & Gresham, 1967)Several urned cremations found in 19th Century in a house garden. (Smith, 2001)

Site_summary: <gg_summry>: Urned cremation burial found in the late 19th century, thought potentially to be linked to an EBA cremation cemetery found around the same time in the parish but the exact location is unknown. Given this uncertainty, the separated record is retained and details of the burial are added here.
Site_description: An overhanging rim urn with cremation found 'near Tywyn', of Bronze Age date and now in the NMW. (Bowen & Gresham, 1967)The findspot of this urn has almost certainly been wrongly ascribed to the sea-front at Tywyn. In fact it was recorded only as coming from near Towyn (Bowen and Gresham 1967, 69). It is a strong possibility that it is one of the group of urns found at Pantyneuadd about 1.5m (do they mean 1.5km?)  to the east in about 1885. This group included a decorated miniature accessory vessel (a type formerly called a pygmy cup or incense cup) (ibid 68), other accessory vessels and several urns with cremations. All but the first vessel were dispersed locally and have never been located. The owner of Pantyneuadd was reported as saying   It was discovered, together with a number of other urns containing human ashes, some twenty five years ago at Pantyneuadd. I ought to say that another cup or two, besides the one I have, were found at the time and given to friends (Anwyl 1909, 162). (Smith, 2004)Not visible.  Single find, 19th century, exact findspot unknown.  Collared urn NMW. (Smith, 2001)

Site_summary: Cist with burnt bone scattered about (note also lots of amphibian - frog - bone) and rude stone tools (likely flint flakes) Note above cst capstone and in mound were a number of deer & sheep bones
Site_description: A much mutilated round cairn 68ft diameter and 4ft high, excavated Sept 1851. A cist was found on the old surface level, in which were found a number of fragments of burnt bone, some apparently human. Also found were a number of stone flakes or chips which 'closely resembled the rudest type of arrowhead or knife'. These were not retained. <1>The cover stone, roughly a parallelogram in shape, was 6ft 3ins long, 3ft 3ins at its widest and about 7ins thick. Above it were a number of deer and sheep bones. <2>A massive rubble cairn on a very clear false crest.  Excavated in 19th Century, changing the shape of the mound and uncovering a slab - lined cist, slightly West of the centre, with a massive cover slab which is now partly covered by a shelter wall and small pen or shepherds shelter (Smith 2001).

Site_summary: Cist with Collared Urn cremation
Site_description: Cist found in 1877 at back of new cottages on the slope in Abergynolwyn. It was partially covered by a capstone and contained two urns, one containing a cremation and covered by a slate stone. <1>Collar fragments of both urns in the National Museum of Wales. <2>The only cottages at Abergynolwyn which back on to a slope are those at SH67830692. No traces of a cist could be seen on the north west facing slope at SH67840689. <3>

Site_summary: No good detail about these urns - they are likely either Food Vessels or Collared Urns It is possible other cremations also existed in vicinity in larger flat urnfield (note these were encountered when digging building foundations)
Site_description: Three urns containing cremations were found in Abergynolwyn in 1833. Two came from the board school foundations and the third from just outside. The urns disintegrated upon removal but one is said to have been 'ornamented'. <1>

Site_summary: The Druids' Circle is part of a well known complex of Bronze Age ritual and ceremonial monuments on open moorland above Penmaenmawr. The circle itself consists of a ring of large stones set on the inner edge of a low stone bank, 23m in diameter, with an entrance to the west. A group of cremation burials set into three pits in the centre, dicovered during excavation by W.E.Griffiths in 1957, included the bones of young children. The ring is not a perfect circle, being slightly flattened on the north-east side where a trackway cuts across the plateau. It has been suggested that the form of the circle deliberately avoids the trackway, which therefore must pre-date the circle and may be the route along which the stone axes from the Graiglwyd axe factory were transported.Four cremations or part cremations were excavated - some  in cists and others in pits. One is unurned. Where age was noted, two were young children (10-12 years old) and 1 possible young female was also identified. They were associated with Food Vessel type urns and one also was accompanied by a bronze dagger.
Site_description: Druid's circle, about 30 upright, or formerly upright stones arranged in a circle 82ft in diamenter. Some stones have clearly been removed from the circle, and at the entrance blasting in the 19th century has largely destroyed details of construction. Below ground level at the centre of the circle was a well-built cist containing the remains of a child 10-12 years old in an inverted urn. Round the central area was a scatter of stones among which were found a plain inverted food vessel containing the cremated bones of a child of 11-13 years old accompanied by a small bronze riveted knife. (i) fragments of another urn. (ii) a cremation burial lying on a rest of sand stone loses. Miscellaneous finds included many fragments of quartz, a few flint scrapers and flakes, a roughed out axe and flakes of graig lwyd rock. <1>Full excavation report and plan. Circle erected between 1500 and 1300 BC. <2>As described by RCAHM. <3>Full descriptions in <4> <5>The druids circle can be regarded as the type site of the embanked stone circle. <6>Further description. <7>As previously described   Plan:  see excavation report (Smith 2002)

Site_name_other: Stone Circle, Cefn Coch, Above Penmaenmawr
Site_summary: Penmaenmawr Monument 280. C14 date from this site is lBA. Unurned cremations in cists; one covered with a layer of quartz pebbles.
Site_description: Stones - plan only given. (280) SH72197463 1949. <1>The site was found to contain a central circle of stones about 10ft in diameter, featureless save for a post-hole near its centre, surrounded by a bank of loose stones, perhaps the body of a cairn. On the E abuts a double row of uprights enclosing a bank of stones. In the N angle between the SE features were two three-sided cists containing cremations, one sealed with a layer of quartz pebbles; an oval hearth and a circular fire-pit full of charcoal. Finds included many quartz pebbles and a Graig Lwyd axe. Charcoal form the fire-pit gave a date of 3080+/-145 bp. <2>Axe in National Museum of Wales. <4>Some erosion around two of the outlying stones S of the circle. <5>As previously described.    Plan see RCAHM (Smith 2002)

Site_name_other: Barrow, Site of, Ty'n Coed, Pentraeth
Site_summary: <gg_summary>: The published name for this barrow is Merddyn Gwyn. It was demolished by railway construction in September 1907. The barrow began as a small ring cairn with external kerb and central Beaker burial and was later augmented in the EBA with a much larger mound and an EBA cremation with Enlarged Food Vessel and another vessel.The grave goods from this site are quite exceptional (Eg bronze knife-dagger with Beaker burial which is rare for Welsh Beaker graves). The Beaker is deformed.An extended E-W aligned inhumation was found in a off-centre grave sunk deep into ground surface. This is likely an early Medieval burial - it had no grave goods.Some of the objects are in the NMW (currently on loan).
Site_description: Barrow destroyed by railway construction, contained a beaker, bronze dagger and V-perforated button plus secondary urn with bone dagger pommel, plus other urn fragments (Hughes 1908, Arch. Camb. p. 211-20). <2>

Site_name_other: Round Barrow, Possible, Bryn Beddau Isaf
Site_summary: Pyre pit with in situ cremation and Food Vessel inverted over top
Site_description: By the farm of Bryn-beddau-isaf there is a rifled round barrow which is said to have yielded an urn and cremation, since lost. (Williams, 1922)At the grid ref given (SH5097 5967) there is a very low circular mound.  It is just below the local summit, but has a good view to the W.  A large rectangular hole has been dug in its W side.  The section has been revetted with timber.  Presumably this is a jump for horses as the paddock contains other jumps.  There are some stones visible where the feature has been cut into.  It is hard to be sure if this is just a natural undulation or the remains of the barrow. (Smith, 2002)

Site_summary: Having checked the original newspaper article, this is the full amount of detail available and there are no images to help. All we have is 'earthenware urn'. They may well be Bronze Age but that is all the information we have
Site_description: In a 1909 newspaper article, an 'oval-shaped mound' called y Gorseddau or high places/thrones was located. When it was levelled in the 19th century 'several urns containing what was believed to be cremated human remains' were uncovered. Local tradition claimed that this area was the burial place if the Roman mine captains. There were also said to be more than one mound hence 'Gorseddau' in the plural. Their location is thought to have been somewhere between Madoc Street and the railway station. Possibly flattened/demolished when the railway station was built. <1>

Site_summary: The cist burial of Gelliniog Wen is a well known site which was originally thought to be that of one of the leaders who fell in the slaughter along the banks of the Menai after the victory of Owain Gwynedd. According to tradition the battle swept across the land of Gelliniog, as the invading hosts were driven back towards the sea. However later analysis of the body and bronze sword found at the site revealed that it is more likely the burial belongs to the later prehistoric, Iron Age. The site was apparently uncovered accidentally on the 19th February 1909.<gg_summary>: Whimster 1981 summarises this burial as follows:Llangeinwen, Gelliniog Wen SH 459658 Isolated discovery in 1909 of a cist grave containing a skeleton, possibly extended, and an iron sword. Details of the grave  construction are unknown, but it is reported that the cist was covered with three stone slabs.Orientation: W Associated objects:La Tene III Iron sword, length 0.77 m, with bone hilt and leather scabbard with iron plates at the front.Fragmentary iron ring, possibly for sword-suspension.The sword and scabbard are recorded separately here.
Site_description: A cist, formed by a ledge of rock along one side, upright slabs on the other sides and covered by three large stones, was accidentally discovered in February 1909 at Gelliniog Wen (SH 4592 6577). It contained an extended inhumation with the feet to the E and was accompanied by an iron sword. Remains of leather covered in iron plates adhering to the blade, appear to be portions of the scabbard. An iron loop, or portion of a ring maximum diameter 1 1/5ins, was also found, but its position in relation to the sword was not noticed. <1>Human skeleton in cist, one side of which was formed by a natural rock ledge. The others being formed of stones. 3 cover slabs EW. Iron sword found with skeleton 2' 7 1/4" long, 4 3/4" tang. Also fragment of iron ?ring-chape. Early Iron Age. <3>A long cist grave with inhumation and iron sword. Presumably Medieval (Hughes 1909, Arch. Camb. P.28). (Smith, 2003)

Site_name_other: Market Weighton long barrow (G216 OR CCXXVI)
Site_summary: Long barrow excavated by Rolleston, contained 26 burials, some entire, others dismemebered and incomplete, some lying in five transverse trenches. The burials had been placed under and partly amongst the chalk rubble and wood, covered with sand and cremated on completion of the mound. Animal bones and pottery were found. In 1972 the mound had been greatly reduced and spread by ploughing, but was still discernible.
Site_description: Greenwell barrow CCXXVI, excavated by Rolleston, was 110ft, (33.5m) long, 75ft (22.9m) wide at the eas end and 62ft (18.9m) wide at the west. Its height ranged from 1ft 8incs to 2ft 2incs. A deposit of chalk rubble extending for 66ft (20.1m) from the east end contained 26 burials, some entire, others dismembered and incomplete, some lying in 5 transverse trenches, 2ft 10incs - 6ft 10incs long and up to 5 1/2ft deep. The burials had been placed under and partly amongst the chalk rubble and wood, covered with sand and cremated on completion of the mound. Animal bones were also found, and plain pottery, also one piece of brown coloured thong marked pottery. In 1972 the mound had been greatly reduced and spread by ploughing, but was still discernible. The pottery is now lost. <1> SE 90624096 Long Barrow excavated by Rolleston, map refernce OS 1" 98, OS 6" SE94SW, SE90624096. Finds in British Museum, refernces to publications: shown on SE94. (1953) Greenwell 'Britsh Barrows' p505. <2> Copy of Hull Museum Card entry: Excavated by Prof Rolleston of Ashmolean. Finds should be in Green Well Collection but appear to be lost, published by Greenwell in 'British Barrows'. <3> A long barrow 110ft long , 62-75ft wide and up to 2ft 2incs high, at Market Weighton. Extending for 66ft along the centre from the east end and, was a chalk deposit in which there were five treansverese trenches, varying in length from 2ft 10ins and up to 5 1/2 ft deep. Twenty six bodies, some entire, some disemembered and incomplete , and some apparently originally deposited elsewhere, as well as animal bones, were at varying depths in the chalk deposit. They had been placed in chalk rubble and wood, covered with sand and cremated on completion of the mound. Burnt chalk and earth, charcoal human and naimal bones, and a few plain pottery fragments were found in some of the trenches. Greatly reduced and spread by ploughin, but still discernible as a vague mound, with a higher content of flint nodules than the surrounding area. <4> SE 907410, Long Barrow site, scheduled. When excavated by Greenwell, it was one hundred and ten feet long and two feet high. It is now greatly reduced by ploughing, but still recognisable, 1972 <5> A trench at right angles to the east end of the 'axial flue' contained a 'plain dark coloured gritty sherd'. Another transverse trench 30 ' east of this contained a single plain frgament. 2' west of this a third trench contained three plain fragments, two red, and one a dark coloured rim fragments of a round-bottomed bowl. Close to the trench, but not in it, was aparently, a piece of beaker. The position corresponds to that of the sherds in the Kilburn Long Barrow. The pottery is lost. <6>  Long Barrow  aligned E-W, reduced by ploughing, sandy earth with chalk rubble capping; opened 23-29 September 1866 by Professor Rolleston. Burial 1 two adults and fragmentary and disarticulaed bones of one adult male, three adult females, thirteen adults and five children, burnt in situ, in axial crematorium structure  <7> Aerial photograph of the long barrow. <8> Photocopied 'A' level project included site visit accounts and photograhs held in SMR File? <9> Among the long barrows which take the more common form, the flanking ditches range from 30m to 75m in length are are spaced from 18m to 35m apart. All of the barrows are aligned roughly east to west, while those of Kilham, Willerby Wold,, Market Weighton, Cross Thorns and Heslerton, lie north east to south west. At Kilham, Rudston and Esh's Barrow, the eastern end appears to be slightly wider, and four barrows (Kilham, Willerby Wold, Market Weighton and Heslerton bank barrow) have ring ditches within 100m of their eastern ends. <10> The remains of a Neolithic long barrow excavated circa 1860; multiple inhumation burials were found with Neolithic pottery fragments. <11> Aerial photograph showing site of long barrow. <12>

Site_summary: Large La Tene square barrow cemetery originally having over 100 small barrows the majority of which have been levelled by cultivation. Many of the barrows have been excavated, including three which contained cart burials.Many of the finds from the early excavations are lost. However some of those from excavations between 1815-17 are in the Yorkshire Museum; those from the 1877 excavations are in the British Museum.British Museum site: http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/search.aspx?place=25884&plaA=25884-3-2York Museum site: https://www.yorkmuseumstrust.org.uk/collections/search/?limit=16&search_text=arras&Gs%5Boperator%5D=%3E%3D&Gs%5Bvalue%5D&Ge%5Boperator%5D=%3C%3D&Ge%5Bvalue%5D&FN=%2ASee (MonUID MHU2865/PrefRef 2865/SID40026) for the grave goods for Hessleskew Barrow. These were originally recorded in this record since this barrow is included within the broader Arras cemetery in all published accounts (e.g. Stead 1979; Whimster 1981) as the 'Charioteer's Barrow'. However the HERO requested that the information was relocated to the separate Hesslekew barrow record.<NRHE HOBUID: 64320; https://www.pastscape.org.uk/hob.aspx?hob_id=64320&sort=2&type=&typeselect=c&rational=a&class1=None&period=None&county=None&district=None&parish=None&place=&recordsperpage=10&source=text&rtype=monument&rnumber=64320#>
Site_description: Arras Iron Age Barrow Cemetery, south-west of Arras and bisected by the A1079. Originally there were over a hundred small round barrows, 8-30ft in diameter, and 1-3ft high, in this cemetery, although the majority have since been levelled by cultivation. The majority of barrows covered simple inhumations accompanied by bronze brooches, armlets and beads. Three of the burials were probably those of chieftains (one a women), as they were more richly furnished and contained the dismantled remains of chariots and horse harness and in one case the skeletons of the two ponies which had pulled the vehicle. <1>A large Iron Age cemetery lying in the vicinity of Arras and Hessleskew farms comprised at least 100 or 200 small barrows, many of which were opened in 1815-17 by E.W.Stillingfleet and B.Clarkson. Dr.Hull of Beverley also appears to have been involved at about this time. Three more were opened by the Yorkshire Antiquarian Club in 1850. Most barrows were found to contain a contracted skeleton, some with ornaments, Greenwell refers to their proximity to Bronze Age barrows. For particular discoveries of. PRNs 5923-5932. Thirty-five barrows can be plotted using O.S maps and Ms plans but only three barrows detectable by the 1950s. <2>Arras Iron Age Cemetery, 1815-17 up to 100 excavated by Rev E.W Stillingfleet, and Barnard Clarkson etc. 1850 three barrows opened by York Antiquarian Club, reported by W. Proctor. 1959, Proton Magentometer survey by Dr M.J.Aitken. I. Stead list thirty separate sites together with their finds. <3> Arras: SE 930 413. this site consisted of a large La Tene cemetery having at least 100 small barrows each covering a single contracted or extended inhumation. The majority of these barrows were excavated between 1815 and 1817 by the Rev E.W Stillingfleet and a chariot-burial was discovered in a chalk-pit here in 1876. Continuous cultivation has so levelled the site that today only three barrows cab be detected under ideal conditions. In 1959 a proton magnetometer survey, followed by selective excavation was undertaken. Two square enclosures, each defined by a ditch and each originally having had a barrow in the centre were uncovered. The first was some 40'-42' square, with a ditch 6' 8" wide and 3'-3' 6" deep. A small sherd, possibly of Iron Age date, was found in the ditch silting. At the centre of the enclosure; a now very slight mound covered a disturbed grave, orientated north to south, containing skull fragments and an iron penannular brooch. To the south, the second enclosure ('B' at SE 9310 4116) was some 34'-36' square, with a ditch 6'-7' wide and 3'-4' deep. Excavation showed that any interment must have been on or above the old ground surface and long since removed. A third square enclosure (at 'C' SE 9281 4770) was excavated by the Yorkshire Antiquarian Club in May 1850. All barrows in this group have been totally ploughed out. Published survey (25") revised. Listed by Challis and Harding under 'La Tene Burials'. <4>The 'King's Barrow', excavated by E.W. Stillingfleet and other in 1816-17, was approximately 26ft (7.8m) in diameter and covered a circular grave, 11-12ft (3.4-3.7m) in diameter by 18ins (45.7cm) deep. It contained a skeleton on its back, and, near the skull, the skulls of two pigs. On either side of the inhumation lay a horse on top of which rested a wheel. In the western half of the grave were two linch-pins, two harness loops, five terrets and two horse-bits. <5>

Site_summary: Round barrow opened in 1894.  Scheduled as Bowl barrow 130m SE of Bridge Farm.<gg_summary>: Multiple interment of Early Neolithic date with animal bone. Most of the burials lacked grave goods but Grimston Ware was found in the grave fill. The burials were dated by 14C to Early Neolithic. one skull of a male was smashed with evidence of trauma - it has been suggested this was a trophy accompanying the other burials.Separate burial of a young female had a leaf-shaped arrowhead
Site_description: <gg_site_description>: Round barrow of Neolithic origin at 47m OD close to bend of road and south of intermittent winterbourne called the Gypsey Race stream. Large round barrow c. 40m in diameter and 3m high. Excavated in 1894 by J Mortimer and it started out as a large wooden structure that had several bodies and Neolithic pottery placed on top, Excarnation platform, then covered with an earthen and chalk mound. Mound surrounded by a causewayed ditch. xcavation showed the inner core of the mound to comprise peaty soil, with an outer covering of white chalk gravel. 18 feet south-southeast of the centre, laid on the original surface, were the remains of 5 skeletons, some at least representing crouched inhumations. The skull and bones of a pig were with them, and some Neolithic potsherds were nearby. 25 to 30 feet west of the centre was an arc of shallow slots, each circa 6 feet long, up to 18 inches wide and 10 inches deep. No artefacts were in the fills. Above the ground surface, within the inner mound, were further burials. 7 feet southeast of the centre were the remains of a cremated child, and nearby were 2 unburnt skull fragments (from an adult). 9 feet east of the centre was a crouched inhumation with a leaf arrowhead by the pelvis. Just east of the centre was another crouched inhumation. Other finds recovered, presumably all from within the mound, include a sandstone pounder, a number of flints, potsherds, animal remains and a red deer antler, as well as large quantities of frog and toad remains.NOTE: The skull from the round barrow of Wold Newton revealed significant evidence of violence, including blunt force trauma, and was interpreted as a possible trophy of Burial I

Site_summary: Small Bronze Age cinerary urn found in a sandpit near Bridlington The urn, only 3" high, contained the burnt bones of a small infant. Urn in Hull Museum<gg_summary>: miniature collared urn found within a larger vessel (unspecified type) containing the remains of a young child.
Site_description: <NRHE site description>: A small B.A. cinerary urn, now in the Mortimer Museum, Hull, was found recently in a sandpit near Bridlington. It was inside a larger vessel which 'broke to pieces and was not preserved'. The small urn only 3" in height, contained the burnt remains identified, by Sir Arthur Keith as 'the bones of a small infant'.In 1960, the urn was on display at the Mortimer Museum.

Site_summary: Mortimer 280. Round barrow opened by Mortimer in 1893 contained one cremation and three inhumation burials accompanied by three food vessels, two flint knives, and other worked flints. Also two further inhumations, possibly secondary. The barrow was destroyed about 1963 and there are no visible remains.
Site_description: Early Bronze Age round barrow around 45ft across, S of Marton Hall, opened by Mortimer in 1893 (Mortimer 280). It contained one cremation and three inhumation burials accompanied by three food vessels, two flint knives, and other worked flints. Also two further inhumations, possibly secondary, including one older adult male. The barrow was destroyed about 1963 and there are no visible remains. Not visited in 2009. <6>

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW SE OF COT NAB FARM Bishop Wilton round barrow (M15)
Site_summary: Scheduled as round barrow south-east of Cot nab Farm. Mortimer 15, opened in July 1864, and reopened in August 1892, yielded 2 cremations, each one in a pit.
Site_description: Barrow 15, 63m circumference, 1.7m high, excavated 1864. Contained two cremations, one urned, near centre, each in hole 3 ft apart; one with burnt wood, elliptical incense cup bearing marks of intense heat, and flint. Other with burnt wood and carbonised shreds of coarse cloth. Four flint leaf-shaped arrowheads in mound. Barbed arrowhead, flint tools and knives and boring tool found during re-excavation, 1892. Not certain about location of these ojects and no direct association with the cremations Note that four leaf-shaped arrowheads were found in the mound implying the presence of Early Neolithic activity here too

Site_summary: Scheduled as Kitty Hill round barrow.  Mortimer C99.Primary double burial of adult female and infant. Female with bone pin. Secondary cremations x 2 and both with Food Vessels
Site_description: Bronze Age Round Barrow. Scheduled Ancient Monument CN18 <1>  SE 78015652 A round barrow (Mortimer's C99) 40ft in diameter and 3ft high, known as 'Kitty Hill' was situated a little beyond Garrowby in an angle formed by York Road and 'Awnham Beck'. Excavation in 1876 revealed many pieces of an Anglo-Saxon iron shield boss a little west of centre and near surface. A little to the south-east of centre near  the base of the barrow were a few burnt bones accompanied by crushed 'British food vase of red clay since rebuilt' In Hull museum and listed as Food Vessel. In the centre of the barrow on the old ground surface was a shallow grave containing a crouched female inhumation together with a bone pin an the remains of an infant burial. About 4ft east of centre and scooped out of the old ground surface was a dish-shaped hollow containing cremated bones and charcoal, covering several pieces of 'British food-vase'. Resting above the cremation deposit was a crushed 'vase of red clay, apparently British'.  A round barrow (Mortimer's Barrow B) adjoining 'Kitty Hill' was seen in 1876. Not excavated because of young crop and not marked on OS plans. Kitty Hill barrow (c.99) is visible on RAF air photographs but there is no trace of Mortimer's Barrow B .Fragment of an indeterminate group of Beaker (corpus No 1342) from Kitty Hill barrow C99. In Hull Museum  SE 77995651 'Kitty Hill'. On a slight rise in a flat previously cultivated area, is a turf-covered earthen mound 12m northwest to southeast by 9m transversely and 1.5m maximum height. The periphery has been encroached on by ploughing though the area is now grassland .The mound is slightly mutilated but there is no trace of excavation. No trace of other barrow was seen <2> SE 77995651 Mortimer barrow C99 survives in pasture as a mound 36 by 40 by 5ft (11m by 12.2m by 1.5m) high, excavated in November 1876, its centre contained a shallow grave on the floor of which lay a contracted inhumation. Peripheral burials comprised a cremation 4ft (1.2m) east of centre, above and below which lay pieces  of 2 red clay 'food-vases' and south east of centre, a cremation accompanied by a 'crushed British food-vase'. Near the surface of the barrow were many pieces of the iron of an Anglo-Saxon shield, and a  flat piece of iron  Later use of the mound is indicated by 'Site of a Mill' on O.S. 6in (first edition map) <3>   SE 780 565 'Kitty Hill' tumulus, scheduled Mortimer, barrow 199, with B (another barrow)adjacent <4>  Scheduled Monument amendment. Scheduled area revised, Monument Name now 'Kitty Hill Round Barrow' , National Monument number 21178 <5>  Extract from the Gazetteer of A social and Anthropological Analysis of Conversion Period and Later Anglo-Saxon Cemeteries in Lincolnshire and Yorkshire <6> The monument includes a prehistoric round barrow on the Yorkshire Wolds. The barrow mound is 2.5m high and 26m in diameter. Although no longer visible at ground level, a ditch, from which material was excavated during the construction of the monument, surrounds the barrow mound. This has become in- filled over the years but survives as a buried feature 4m wide. A brick shed which has been built over part of the north-western section of the ditch is excluded from the scheduling, although the ground beneath is included <7>

Site_summary: Round barrow excavated by Greenwell containing 5 inhumations and 1 cremation, also other bones.  Scheduled as Money Hill round barrow.<gg summary>: Food Vessel and jet/lignite necklace. Lower down, one cremation and five inhumations were found, including an adult female, and a child, both of whom had been buried with associated pottery vessels - Food Vessels. A central, wood-lined grave contained an adolescent inhumation with 124 beads around its neck and a deposit of ochre near the body. Possibly primary burialas it is the central wood-lined grave but it may have been sunk later and disturbed other burials. 17 year old female. Hands to face, jet necklace round neck; ochre by body. 4m SE of centre in pit cut into mound; aged woman with plain inverted Food Vessel at hips; child skull behind back. Child skull placed behind back of aged female with plain Food Vessel. 4m SE of centre and in pit cut into mound - degraded child c. 7-8 years old with Food Vessel under head
Site_description: <site summary>: A flat-topped round barrow, approximately 15.0m in diameter  and 0.6m high, mutilated on the S side by a modern hedge and surrounded by trees. Money Hill G121

Site_summary: Scheduled as round barrow on Metlow Hill, 300m west-south-west of Wendale Farm.Known as Bempton ; a huge amount of material was recovered from the mound of this barrow - including many flint scrapers, and flakes and  sherds of Food Vessel<gg summary>:  wood-lined grave containing the inhumation of a child about 5-6 years old and a food vessel, Only one adult cremation (note in mound a great many objects - mainly flint tools etc. 3 saws. Bronze Age round barrow on Metlow Hill at TA 20235 72985, 300m WSW of Wendale Farm, excavated between 1877 and 1889 and found to contain the remains of a stone circle or cist, at the centre of which was awhilst the mound material contained 15 flint scrapers, 3 knives, 3 saws, a broken leaf-shaped arrowhead and 3 pottery sherds.Also note a Early Neolithic leaf-shaped arrowhead came from the mound
Site_description: Bronze Age round barrow on Metlow Hill at TA 20235 72985, 300m WSW of Wendale Farm, excavated between 1877 and 1889 and found to contain the remains of a stone circle or cist, at the centre of which was a wood-lined grave containing the inhumation of a child about 5_6 years old and a food vessel, whilst the mound material contained 15 flint scrapers, 3 knives, 3 saws, a broken leaf-shaped arrowhead and 3 pottery sherds. Visible on APs. Scheduled Monument. Not visited in 2009. <12><NRHE site description>: Round Barrow finds were two Food vessels 1 type Childe B.1. and the second Childe type B.1.b., the former was found before the face of a child 5-6 yrs; body on side, head to W hands to face. The grave was 2'9" deep 4'10" long, 2' wide E-W, pointed at W end. Grave had been lined 18" deep and covered with wood, post-hole 1 1/2" diam. from barrow surface into W. end of grave. Other finds were, flint knives, flint saws, leaf-shaped arrowhead, 16 flint scrapers, pounding stone, pottery sherds. Finds now in British Museum. Excavated by W Greenwell, between 1877-89

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW 700m S OF LOW FARM (M75)
Site_summary: Scheduled as round barrow 700m south of Low Farm.<gg summary> Five inhumations  including two crouched burials and four cremations were seen.  Other finds were four food vessels, beaker, jet necklace, bronze  awl, flint implements and potsherds. Excavated over 7 days in September 1866. Under heap of cremated bone was a young woman  (no 1) in oval grave. Food Vessel in front of face . Almost central and very tightly crouched. Under female inhumation - long heap of burnt bones of adult beside Food Vessel and antler. Further down in barrow pit - female; feet placed on top of a heap of cremated bones. Female wore a jet necklace. Dog skull placed over child burial
Site_description: Five inhumations  including two crouched burials and four cremations were seen.

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW, 550m NE OF GOODMANHAM WOLD FARM Goodmanham Wold barrow (G90 OR XC)
Site_summary: Scheduled as Bowl barrow 550m north east of Goodmanham Wold Farm.<gg summary>: If this is Goodmanham 90 or XC it does contain a burial & grave goods including Food Vessels and wooden coffins.
Site_description: Greenwell's barrow XC. Bowl barrow 550m NE of Goodmanham Wold Farm. Scheduled RSM No 21155. The mound is 1.5m high with a diameter of 54m. The  ditch survives as a buried feature 4m wide. The barrow was partially excavated by Canon Greenwell in the 19th century; he found a  wood-lined grave containing a single female inhumation in a coffin accompanied by a food vessel and a flint flake

Site_summary: Aerial photographs show cropmark complex of a system of rectangular enclosures and some probable square barrows.<gg_summary>: Known as Nunburnholme Wold, Pocklington or Burnby Lane, PocklingtonSummary record as no published account
Site_description: <Pocklington Historical Society summary>: An excavation was commissioned by David Wilson Homes ahead of their Pavilion Square housing development; and the MAP Archaeological Practice team unexpectedly found a thousand artefacts, mainly Iron Age but some Saxon, from 175 burials in 87 square barrows. Grave goods included a sword, spears, knives, remains of a shield, glass and amber beads, brooches and intact pots. But perhaps the most remarkable find was in the excavation’s final days, when a chariot was uncovered in the roadside verge at the front of the development where it had somehow survived for 2,500 years, the first chariot and charioteer with two horses attached discovered in Britain since an excavation at nearby Arras in 1817. Pocklington items have been sent to the British Museum, Harvard, and universities across England for analysis, and are expected to disclose more; including hopes that DNA and isotope testing may reveal links between the Iron Age peoples of East Yorkshire and Northern France. The preliminary project report is expected to be published in 2018.

Site_summary: O.S 1853 6" shows 'Cross Bow Hill' and 'Site of Tumulus', which was apparently opened in 1819 when an internment and urn were found.Old adult with Bell Beaker
Site_description: OS 1853 6" shows  Cross Bow Hill  and  Site of Tumulus , The barrow  was recorded as standing 6ft high in 1822, when it was opened by the farmer during levelling. A vault of chalk blocks containing a beaker burial was found c 0.3m below the surface. In 1970 the barrow was recorded as being ill-defined, but surviving as a 15m diameter mound rising to 1.3m. At the time of a survey in 1997, the barrow was still under plough and was reduced to just 0.2m high at the most. It was considered that the site was not worth scheduling. Not visited in 2009. <6>

Site_name_other: NE OF LOW CALLIS WOLD ROUND BARROW (M24)
Site_summary: Round barrows, no visible remains, although aerial photograph shows ring ditch as broad soilmark.
Site_description: Barrow 24, 48ft in diameter, 2ft high, contained primary urned cremation in shallow hole, with carbonised wood, unburnt bark, probably hazel. Six flint flakes were found in the mound. Grave may have been missed in this barrow. No visible remains can be seen. <1> Mortimer barrow 24, 48ft (14.6m) in diameter by 2ft (0.6m) high, contained fragments of a large cinerary urn in a shallow hole. The urn contained calcined bones: above it fragments of carbonised wood and possible hazel bark. Six flint flakes also found in the mound. <2> Aerial photograph showing barrows and entrenchment in the parish of Bishop Wilton. <3> Pastscape Website Description. <4>

Site_summary: Round barrow excavated by Mortimer in 1866. Contained a cremation in a circular hole. Anglo-Saxon internment lay closer to the surface. Used as a beacon site in Tudor times. Mortimer 69.<gg summary>:  a primary cremation 6 ins deep in the original surface, with burnt wood and fragment of bone pin; 4 flint flakes Note a stone (flint?) macehead was recorded from this barrow - it is also known as Bishop Wilton 69 or Beacon Barrow
Site_description: Mortimer barrow 69, opened June 1866, diameter 44ft by 1ft high, containing a cremation in a circular hole, associated with part of a bone hair pin. Close to the surface lay the skull and part of the arm bone of an Anglo-Saxon interment, associated with an iron spearhead and parts of two blades belonging to a pair of iron shears. At the top lay decayed horizontal beams belonging to the Tudor beacon which was still extant in the first half of the 19th century. The mound is now completely ploughed out, but its site appears as a ring ditch, 60ft (18.3m) in diameter, on aerial photographs. <1> SE 812 563. Wilton Beacon, Mortimer Barrow 69, excavated 1866. Anglian secondary burial with iron spearhead and shears also found. No trace on the ground, 1973 (OSSI). <2> Photocopied extract referring to Mortimers excavation. <3> Cross reference MHU9922 - Site of Wilton Beacon. <4> (se 81225634) Wilton Beacon (NR) Barrow 69 - Beacon Hill, 44ft in diameter; 1 ft high, spread by ploughing. Excavated in 1866, it contained decayed beams of the beacon built in 1588; an AS inhumation with iron spearhead and remains of iron shears; a primary cremation 6 ins deep in the original suurface, with burnt wood and fragment of bone pin; 4 flint flakes. No visible remains left and the name of Wilton Beacon is no longer in local use. <5> Garrowby Wold, Bishop Wilton. Inhumation burial, secondary in barrow. Y159SE. SE812563. Mortimer (1906), p 144 Brown (1915) IV 805. 1866 Mortimer excavated Beacon Hill barrow, then 44' across and 1' high, standing in an elevated position. Near the centre of the barrow, only 6" deep, he found a skull and parts of an arm bone. Close to the side of the skull was an iron spearhead with split socket, 11" long, pointing westward. It therefore seems probable that the head was at the west end of the grave. A little further south were portions of two blades of a pair of iron shears, but most of the burial had been removed when the beacon was made (1588). The primary interment was British - ie Bronze Age. <6> Extract from the Gazetteer of A social and Anthropological Analysis of Conversion Period and Later Anglo-Saxon Cemeteries in Lincolnshire and Yorkshire <7> Pastscape record information. <8>

Site_summary: Round barrow excavated by Mortimer in June 1874 and was found to contain three crouched inhumations and a cremation. Aerial photographs show a ring ditch.Central grave with three inhumations and an unurned cremation accompanied by a Food Vessel and an inhumation with an irregularly shaped Collared Urn) l
Site_description: Grid reference of barrow SE 8211 5676. <1> Mortimer barrow C70, opened in June 1874, 31ft (9.4m) in diameter by 2ft high, contained a grave with three crouched inhumations and, elsewhere, a cremation in an urn, and a further urn. One of the inhumations was accompanied by a food-vase and small lump of block flint, the cremation being accompanied by a small pygmy cup and the bronze blade of a two edged knife. Nothing of the barrow is now visible on the ground, but a ring ditch, 60ft (18.3m) in diameter is visible on aerial photographs. <2> 'Large central grave contained three primary crouched burials, one with fragments of food vessel and a small lump of black flint. Urned cremation with bronze blade of two-edged knife and small incense cup, over grave. Food vessel of cinerary urn type found in mound'. <3> 'Cropmark of a ring ditch 30m (98.4ft) in diameter'. <4> Bishop Wilton, Callis Wold Barrow C.70. An early Bronze Age barrow, sherds of grooved ware, one with applied internal and external ribs. The decoration on the exterior consists of four V-shaped grooves. The barrow is located  in the parish of Bishop Wilton and stands on the western escarpment of the Yorkshire Wolds. <5> Photocopied extract from C.M. Piggott 'The Late Bronze Age Razors of the British Isles' in Proceedings of the Prehistoric Society Volume 12, 1946. <6> Pastscape Website description also includes SMR 715 which lies approximately 340m to the south-east of this barrow. <7>

Site_summary: <gg_summary_tg>: Barrow, attributed to the La Tene period. Mortimer C72.No idea why this had originally been dated to the Iron Age, and a square barrow. It is an EBA round barrow. Classic EBA barrow with a crouched inhumation accompanied by two animal burials (goats or sheep). Very large central grave Note the presence of three animal skeletons at feet of a crouched burial in the Early Bronze Age is quite rare!!!<gg_summary_ac>: Whimster (1981) summarises the evidence as follows: Single barrow excavated by J.R. Mortimer, 1874 (Barrow c.72). Diameter: 7.5 m; Height: 0.3 m. Central grave with a contracted inhumation accompanied by skeletons of 2 sheep or goats. Associated objects: None associated with grave, but a 'bronze coated iron terret' is reputed to have been found in the vicinity (Stead 1965, 104)In truth, the barrow could be either Bronze or Iron Age in date so has been assigned a broad date.

Mortimer C44, disturbed by workmen in 1845, explored by the Yorkshire Antiquarian Club in 1849, and re-opened by Mortimer in 1871.  Bronze Age and Anglo-Saxon burials.Note there is a glut of small cups and incense cups from this barrow. Also note jet trapezoidal pendant could be re-used from a composite jet necklace as an heirloom object
Site_description: Extract from the Gazetteer of A social and Anthropological Analysis of Conversion Period and Later Anglo-Saxon Cemeteries in Lincolnshire and Yorkshire <8> A Bronze Age round barrow survives as an earthwork and is visible on air photographs. The barrow has been excavated and found to contain two primary oval graves which contained burnt matter, flint arrowheads and pottery. Addtionally, it was contains a secondary Anglo-Saxon mixed cemetery, inhumations and cremations with grave goods.The Saxon cemetery is unusual in being devoid of child inhumations and the inhumations present not being accompanied by animal bones. There was also a distinct lack of weapon burials. The feature appears to be extant on the latest 2008 vertical photography <9> Partially extant round barrow visible as an earthwork on the Hull Valley Mapping GIS Layer <10>A Bronze Age barrow (Goodmanham LXXXIX)  is visible as earthworks on air photographs, at TA 0423 5781 at Cheesecake Hill. The barrow measures approximately 33m in diameter.  It was opened in 1845 and 1849 and completely excavated by Mortimer in 1871. Two oval graves near the centre of the tumulus containing burnt matter and a pyre but no human remains, but associated with an incense cup; flint arrowheads and sherds of 'British pottery' were found. Approximately thirty five secondary inhumations and cremations, mostly associated with Saxon grave goods were found during the three excavations.

Site_summary: Aerial photographs identified a ring ditch. Excavated in 1866 by Mortimer.<gg summary>: Dismembered or redeposited burial of an adult with animal bones and flint; unfortunately not easy to date due to lack of strictly typologically precise grave goods (mainly flint and animal bone); could be Neolithic? There was a fox or largish dog skull Note lots of finds in barrow mound - Eight slingstones. Eight possible slingstones, however unidentified so unable to confirm KN 02/08/13; One-hundred and twenty-five flint flakes. One-hundred and twenty-five handstruck flint flakes. Seven oval discs. Seven oval discs of various sizes chipped more or less round their ends. Material and function unknown (these may be flint scrapers)
Site_description: Opened by Mortimer in 1866 when it measured c.55' in diameter, 14-16" high. Contained the remains of an interment at centre which had been disturbed by digging for rabbits. Numerous finds: 125 flint flakes (handstruck), 8 slingstones, 7 oval discs, 13 pottery fragments, skull of a dog or fox, and part of the jaw of a red deer. <1> Excavation October 1866. Description: diameter of 55' and height of 14"-16". Near centre was grave containing inhumation much disturbed by digging for rabbits. Throughout the mound were numerous handstruck flakes and animal bones. <2> Barrow 77, 55ft diameter, about 16 inches high, disturbed by rabbit diggers. Excavated 1866, containing dismembered inhumation - ? Primary. Finds include 125 flint flakes, oval discs, pottery, animal bones, etc. <3> 'Tumulus' Mortimer barrow 77, excavated 1866 (when it was already badly damaged). OSSI. <4> ...B - Barrow 77, 55ft diam, about 16 ins high, disturbed by rabbit diggers. Excavated 1866, contained dismembered inhumation - ? primary. Finds include 125 flint flakes, oval discs, pottery, animal bones, etc. (2) Both barrows have been under plough for many years and no trace of either survives. (3). <5> Barrow No. 77 is at the extreme east end of the same field as the last three barrows, and close by its eastern side is a single entrenchment, which at the time of our examination (October 1st, 1866) was almost obliterated. By making a narrow cutting we obtained a section of the fosse of the entrenchment, which measured 5 feet at the top, 1 foot at the bottom, and 2 feet deep. The barrow was about 55 feet in diameter, and formed entirely of black earth to a height of 14 to 16 inches. We turned over an area of 30 feet by 19 feet in its centre and trenched the ground below as we proceeded. During this operation we picked up 125 hand-struck flakes of flint, eight slingstones, seven oval discs of various sizes chipped more or less round their ends; seven irregular lumps, and thirteen fragments of pottery. The head of a dog or fox, teeth and part of the jaw of a red deer (?), human bones, consisting of a femur, portions of a skull, and some vertebrae, were also observed. The latter seemed to be the remains of an interment near the centre, which had been disturbed and broken whilst digging for rabbits, the mound being trenched and guttered in some places to a depth of 2 feet below its base. <6>

Site_name_other: Life Hill or Sledmere round barrow  (M270)
Site_summary: Mortimer 270 and Mortimer 271. Site of two round barrows excavated by MortimerBoth barrrows had Food Vessels This is Sledmere 270 ; female inhumation with child cremation and a Food Vessel
Site_description: <site summary>:  Sledmere 270 had an antler pick and Food Vessel.  A  crouched inhumation associated with a cremation deposit, food vessel and deer antler was seen (2) Food vessel in Hull Museum (3). part of a more extensive and tightly clustered barrow cemetery -situated <100m from adjacent one. (SE 92486210) .  Barrow 270. A round barrow c 12 ins high excavated in 1885 by Mortimer.

Site_summary: Site of round barrow identified and excavated by Mortimer in 1873, 1874 and 1875.Two burials - one inhumation and one cremation. Arrowhead (unknown type) and bone pin and animal bones
Site_description: SE95905792. Barrow C64, spread by ploughing, about 18 inches high. Excavated 1873-5, mound contained considerable amount of Romano-British material - fragments two hard millstones, potsherds, animal bones, shells, etc., also BA ornamented food vessel, flint arrowhead, bone pin, urn fragments and possible disturbed inhumation. Four trenches under barrow (see plan), 50ft long filled with earthy matter; circular deposit of burnt matter at A contained fragments of burnt bone, bone pricker pointed at both ends and bronze ring. Trenches X and Y, 9ft long filled with soil, also three small cavaties at Y. Dish-shaped excavation, AA, contained dirty gravel and soil, also trench Z - more than 38 ft long (only partly explored). Circle in trench at D, contained layer 5-8 inches deep at bottom, comprising burnt wood, soil, bones mostly burnt to powder. B similar to D, contained small piece of bronze, bronze coin of "Nero Caesar Augustus", fragment of bone pin. Large pit opposite E end of trench Z contained soil with numerous bones, pieces of Roman pottery including Samian ware, sherd of black pottery with small pieces of glass adhering to it. Also carbonised wood, burnt bone, other traces of burning in several places and a few corroded nails. (Apparently a BA barrow disturbed by RB occupation). The barrow has been under plough for many years and has a slight ground swelling at the published position is now the only surface indication. <1> SE959579. "Tumulus", Mortimer barrow 164, excavated 1873 and 1875. Bronze Age and RB pottery, a Roman coin and other bronze small finds, animal bones, ditches etc. May not be a barrow, or if so, very disturbed by later occupation. Ring ditch possibly visible from the air. (OSSI; NMR 061). <2> Cross reference SMR 8179, a cropmark complex adjoining this barrow, of probable RB date. <3> (SE 95905792) Tumulus (NR) (Site of) (Not on 1855 6"). Barrow C64, spread by ploughing, about 18 ins high. Excavated 1873-5, mound contained considerable amount of Romano British material - fragments two hard mill-stones, potsherds, animal bones, shells, etc, also BA ornamented food vessel, flint arrowhead, bone pin, urn fragments and possible disturbed inhumation. Four trenches under barrow (see plan), 50ft long filled with earthy matter; circular deposit of burnt matter at A contained fragments burnt bone, bone pricker pointed both ends and bronze ring. Trenches X and Y, 9ft long filled with soil, also three small cavities at Y. Dish-shaped excavation, AA, contained dirty gravel and soil, also trench at Z - more than 38ft long (only partly explored). Circle in trench at D, contained layer 5-8 ins deep at bottom, comprising burnt wood, soil, bones mostly burnt to powder. B similar to D, contained small piece of bronze, bronze coin of "Nero Caesar Augustus", fragment of bone pin. Large pit opposite E end of Trench Z contained soil with numerous bones, pieces of Roman pottery including Samian ware, sherd of black pottery with small pieces of glass adhering to it. Also carbonised wood, burnt bone, other traces of burning in several places and a few corroded nails. (Apparently a BA barrow disturbed by RB occupation). The barrow has been under plough for many years and a slight ground swelling at the published position is now the only surface indication. <4> Extract from 'Forty Years Researches in British and Saxon Burial Mounds of East Yorkshire' (1905) by J.R. Mortimer. <5>

Site_name_other: BEAKER BURIAL, W OF MELTON HILL FARM
Site_summary: Site of inhumation, with stone bracer, bone fastener, and Beaker pottery sherds.  Discovered in 1960.Flat grave with no mound
Site_description: Beaker inhumation of a  flat grave. The bones of a skeleton, a stone bracer or archer's  wrist-guard, a bone fastener and four or five pottery sherds were found in a small grave, some 3ft deep in the side of a cutting in a new clay quarry at SE 971271. No trace of a barrow or barrow ditch was gound. The bracer, 3 3/8" x 1" is of Borrowdale stone. The pottery sherds are undecorated but of Beaker fabric. The discovery was made by Mr Jack Taylor of Elloughton early in 1960

Site_summary: Internment, with Iron Age sword and bronze scabbard, two discs and two bronze studs.  Found at a depth of 5ft when draining a field near Bugthorpe c.1860.<gg_summary>: Whimster (1981) summarises the evidence as follows: Single inhumation discovered ante-1860, but details of the burial are unrecorded.Associated objects: a) Iron sword and scabbard b) 2 bronze discs, 2 bronze studsThe finds are in the British Museum. Accession numbers 1905.7-17.1, 1905.7-17.4 and 17.5, 1905.7-17.2 and 17.3.<NRHE HOBUID: 59533; https://www.pastscape.org.uk/hob.aspx?hob_id=59533&sort=2&type=&typeselect=c&rational=a&class1=None&period=-800|43|IRON%20AGE|17|0&county=None&district=None&parish=None&place=bugthorpe&yearfrom=-800&yearto=43&recordsperpage=10&source=text&rtype=&rnumber=#>
Site_description: <NRHE site description>: Iron Age inhumation accompanied by a sword with bronze scabbard, two discs and two bronze studs were found near Bugthorpe circa 1860. The finds are in the British Museum. Accession numbers 1905.7-17.1, 1905.7-17.4 and 17.5, 1905.7-17.2 and 17.3.

Site_summary: Marginal. Site of barrow containing a skeleton ?on a sheild, and to each side a wheel, iron horse-bit and some iron rings. Some antler and a bronze case. Also found (within the wider cemetery) a bronze torque, 9 jet beads, miniature bronze axe, piece of amber, blue glass bead and a bronze ring.<gg_summary>: information for this grave was originally included with the evidence for the broader Arras cemetery (Burial A2) since it represents part of the same broad cemetery. This barrow is also included within the broader Arras cemetery in all published accounts (e.g. Stead 1979; Whimster 1981) as 'The Charioteer's Barrow'.
Site_description: <FURTHER INFO>

Site_summary: Site of two crouched inhumations, one with a beaker, were found on a building site at the foot of Spout Hill in 1950. Roman and Medieval wall footings were exposed and Iron Age, Roman and Medieval pottery was found.

Findspot of two Bronze Age food vessels and an accessory cup found during excavation of a gravel pit at Barff Hill in the 1930s.<gg_summary>: two Bronze Age food vessels and an accessory cup were recovered during quarrying in the 1930s. Manby (1973) notes that their associations were not recorded but they were almost certainly associated with inhumation burials. An MNI of one inhumation burial and the three vessels are recorded here.
Site of a beaker burial which was disturbed during gravel extraction at a pit east of Hempholme, containing bones of a young adult, pottery fragments and a flint knife.
Site_description: <FURTHER INFO>The restored Beaker, Beaker Group N3,(2)  is 8 1/8 ins high, 4-6 ins diameter at the rim, 3 1/4 ins  diameter at the base, is in Messrs C & E Granthams' Museum at  Driffield. (1-2)

Site_summary: Marginal. Findspot of a bucket-shaped urn containing a few cremated bones and two pieces of a bronze object.<gg_summary>: Locational details added to HER record based on centre of Bishop Burton village.
Site_description: A bucket-shaped urn containing a few cremated bones and two pieces of a bronze object. There is nothing to indicate that the metal fragments were originally found with the urn. The presence of the metal fragments is interesting in that another urn in the Yorkshire Museum (MHU6085) from Bishop Burton is said to have contained a bronze implement which subsequently vanished. Could these metal fragments have some relevance? It is also possible that the bucket-shaped urn is also from Bishop Burton, since there is no provenance given in the Yorkshire Museum records. Dr. Hull found several urns in barrows at Bishop Burton. (1. Yorkshire Mus. Card Index.; 2. VCH Yorkshire I, 1907, pl. opp. P. 374.) Location of finds: In Yorkshire Museum, Accn. No. 1086.47. Other information: 1. J.F.R. 14.06.1978. <1>

Site_summary: Site of round barrow, ?G79, reduced by ploughing. Earth with some chalk and flint, over bank of chalk and flint. Contained central cremation with an urn and bronze awl, pig bones also found. A secondary cremation lay on the natural surface.Etton Wold barrow - re-excavated by D Coombs in 1969.
Site_description: SE 94114384, Greenwell Barrow LXXIX, 60ft in diameter by 1 3/4 ft high, was mass of earth with some chalk and flint stones intermixed. It contained a central cremation accompanied by an urn and bronze awl, with abundant evidence of charcoal beneath the burial. Pig bones were also found. The grave appeared to be encircled by a wall of lint and chalk about 11ft (3.4m) in diameter. A secondary cremation lay on the natural surface 14ft (4.3m) south west of the centre, and food vessel and urn sherds lay in the mound material. Coombs identified barrow LXXIX with his barrow C  but such a theory seems implausible given Greenwell's assertion that his LXXIX lay about half a mile east of barrow 5731 and 5734. Coombs barrow C is only 120yards from 5731 <1> SE 941 438 , tumulus, perhaps one of those excavated by Greenwell in this area, partially destroyed <2> SE 94114383 , About two miles north of the Gardham group of barrows (SE 94 SW 7) are four more mounds, three of which were excavated by Greenwell  Barrow LXXIX, possibly the above barrow (described as about two miles north of the Gardham group, SE 941405) was 60ft in diameter and 1 3/4 ft high and contained what appeared to be a circular wall of flints and chalk about 11ft  in diameter within which the primary cremation had been carried out. A rudely made type of cinerary urn with overhanging rim, a bronze awl or drill, and animal bones accompanied the cremation  A secondary cremation was on the natural surface 14ft south south west of the centre. A flat topped round barrow in a partly mutilated condition situated on the summit of a small hill. It averages 17m in diameter and 0.5m in height <3> Aerial photographs <4> Cross reference SMR 9470, also a possible location for G79? <5> Photocopied Extract <6> Pastscape Record <7> Slide <8>

Site_summary: Site of five small round barrows. Two have been previously opened and other three excavated by Greenwell. One contained a primary inhumation in a shallow grave, another contained a primary inhumation on natural surface at the centre. The other contained a primary cremation accompained by a small vessel.No need to add extra records as only one of the barrows had burials associated with grave goods
Site_description: A group of five small barrows (all given the same HER Monument Number) lying apart from each other, about one mile NE of Etton, of which the above probably formed part. Two had been opened previously, the three remaining were excavated by Greenwell. Barrow LXXVI was 50 ft in diameter and 1 1/2 ft high. A central hollow, with charcoal along one side, contained a primary cremation carried out on the spot and was accompanied by a small miniature or pygmy vessel. A fragment of a long flint scraper and several flint chippings were in the moundG76, 77 & 78 all amalgamated; only LXXVI (G76) contained burials and grave goods. the other two just had burials

Site_summary: Round barrow 15m diameter.Double burial of adult female and child cremations in heap with beautiful flint knife, 2nd is child inhumation with a bone pin and a partial (deliberately broken before buria?l) Food Vessel
Site_description: CDG add. Part of a more extensive barrow cemetery. SE 9245 or SE 9345 Round Barrow (Greenwell 82 or LXXXII). Round barrow with two graves. One contained cremations of a woman and a child with a serrated flint knife, the other contained a crouched child inhumation covered with large blocks of flint. A bone pin and a pot fragment were found with the latter. (1-2) Flint knife fromround barrow. The two graves are set c. 2.5m apart. Possible duplicate with a number of barrows in this area. Barrow known as Etton 82.

Site_summary: Everthorpe. Food vessel, human bones and worked flint were rescued from a gravel pit.
Site_description: <FURTHER INFO>

Site_summary: Single crouched inhumation found in 1966 during gravel digging to the east of Totley's Farm.<gg_summary>: Whimster (1981) summarises the evidence as follows: Crouched inhumation found during gravel extraction, with finger-rings on the left hand. No other details obtained.Associated objects: At least 2 (?bronze) finger rings.Two additional burials not noted for comparison due to poor contextual detail.
Site_description: TA 24422758. Single crouched inhumation with three Early Iron Age finger-rings, two in position on left hand, found in 1966 during gravel digging to the east of Totley's Farm. Two other burials found earlier, in 1903 and 1911 (YAS PRN 6765 and 6768). <1> TA 244276. Crouched inhumation with three early Iron Age finger-rings, two in position on left hand. Destroyed by quarrying, 1966.  <2>

Site_summary: Approximate site of excavated barrow group, including cremation urn.Barrow 17m diameter very close to the sea and washed away
Site_description: Approximate site of excavated barrow group, including cremation urn. Not visible in 2009. Site may have been lost to erosion. <5><FURTHER INFO>

Site_summary: First excavated in the 1890s and again in 1962_6, excavated again when threatened by the sea in 1996_7, and now within a lagoon.Degraded inhumation with plain Beaker and large jet buttonhttp://www.skeals.co.uk/Articles/Archaeological%20Excavation.html
Site_description: First excavated in the 1890s and again in 1962_6, excavated again when threatened by the sea in 1996_7, and now within a lagoon. The barrow is visible as an earthwork on APs centred at TA 4086 1807. The feature measures c 17m in diameter. It overlay a Neolithic occupation site (EA119, Gazetteer reference number from the Rapid Coastal Zone Assessment Survey Part 2 Gazetteer). Excavation revealed a Beaker burial. The body was destroyed by acid ground conditions. Finds included a conical jet button and a broken beaker. The barrow consisted of two phases of clay mound built over a base of charred oak branches and logs with no trace of a ditch. Charcoal gave a radiocarbon date of c 2000 BC. Visible in 2009 as a circle of darker vegetation immediately above shoreline. Area does not seem to have eroded significantly. (Cross reference with MHU20439) <18>

Site_summary: On the beach at Kilnsea, near Hornsea a complete late Bronze Age/early Iron Age cinerary urn, together with the fragments of two others were found in 1957.
Site_description: On the beach at Kilnsea, near Hornsea a complete late Bronze Age/early Iron Age cinerary urn, together with the fragments of two others were found in 1957. Near the complete urn were a number of cobbles which appear to show signs of burning. The urn contained a handful of calcined bones. One piece may be a fragment of an oven or burnt daub rather than pottery.<NRHE site description>: TA 4224 1473. On 9 Oct 1957 Mr. R. J. W. Batchelor of the R.E. Dept. Victoria Barracks, Beverley found on the beach at Kilnsea, near Hornsea a complete I.A. 'A' cinerary urn, together with the fragments of two others. Mr. Batchelor reports that near the complete urn were a number of cobbles which appear to show signs of burning. The urn contained a handful of calcined bones.Mr. Batchelor has presented the finds to Hull Museum, and Mr. John Bartlett, Director of the Hull Museums, has written the following note of them:-1. (Fig. 9b) Urn of coarse, buff, hand-made pottery, flat rimmed, shallow finger grooves on upper part: about 11 ins. in height. No decoration. LBA or early IA A.2. (Fig. 9a) Large urn about 13 ins. in height, well baked, buff, coarsely gritted pottery; round rim, carinated shoulder: blackened on outside: Early IA A.3. (Not illustrated) Sherd of early I.A. pot with large grits: everted rim.4. (Not illustrated) Sherds, coarse, thick, fired buff and grey. Most of these may be part of the base of number 2 but one piece which is 1 1/2 ins. thick is perhaps rather a fragment of an oven or burnt daub. (1)Other References: YAS 7147 (2) <4>

Site_summary: Aerial photographs show cropmarks of square barrow cemetery. Five barrows excavated by Greenwell, and later parts of the cemetery were excavated by Stead.<gg_summary>: Aerial photographs suggest a group of at least thirteen square barrows in total. Of these, eight have been excavated; five produced grave goods (recorded here). All finds are in the British Museum (site name: Cottam)<NRHE HOBUID: 64640; https://www.pastscape.org.uk/hob.aspx?hob_id=64640&sort=2&type=&typeselect=c&rational=a&class1=None&period=None&county=None&district=None&parish=None&place=&recordsperpage=10&source=text&rtype=monument&rnumber=64640#>
Site_description: <Pastscape_summary>: Aerial photographs suggest a group of at least thirteen square barrows (La Tene) SE of Borough House. Greenwell excavated five (Nos L - LIV) in 1867 of which four were re-excavated by Stead in 1969. Mounds (A to C) are probably Greenwell's barrows (L, LI and LII).

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW (M268) & DITCH Sledmere or Garton Slack (M268)
Site_summary: Mortimer Barrow 268. Round barrow 55' in diameter and 18" high when excavated by Mortimer in 1884. Crouched inhumation with a scraper and a flint knife found. Barrow visible only as a very slight swelling in 1974.

Opened by Lord Londesborough in 1857 when it measured 150' in diameter, and about 24' high. Re-opened by Greenwell in 1887. Internments not found on either occasion. Examined by Brewster in 1967, when the mound had been destroyed. A double ring ditch was revealed. The outer ditch disturbed a crouched Long Necked Beaker burial and the central grave contained the disturbed remains of a burial.The oak coffin and the inhumation have recently been 14C dated
Site_description: <FURTHER INFO>Barrow inner ditch is 20m in diameter and 2.6m wide and 1.2m deep, while the outer ditch is 24.5m in diameter, 3.2m wide and 1.2m deep. Barrow mound is 1.5m high and 22m in diameter.

Site_summary: Excavated by Greenwell when the greater part of the northern half had already been removed. Seventeen inhumations discovered, the primary burials from the Neolithic period, with later Beaker activity. Note only that Beaker sherds were found in mound but no traces of burial. Also an inverted accessory cup and Greenwell suggests a possible cenotaph as no hr recovered. This possible cenotaph associated with inverted Accessory cup as explained by Greenwell inserted into top of barrow mound  (Accessory cup and Beaker sherds but no burial - it may have been ploughed away of cours). Not included here Note in the mound, a large quantity of Early Neolithic bowl pottery was recovered- Grimston & Towthorpe ware
Site_description: <site summary>: Cowlam LVII - one of a number of barrows. This is a large elongated round barrow (?or bank barrow) of originally Early Neolithic date with later re-use in the Bronze Age. Primary Neolithic inhumations with pottery and antler hammer. BronzeAge secondary inhumations. Mound material includes Beaker, Bronze Age, Iron Age and Roman pottery and stone, flint and bronze artifacts. A round barrow of Neolithic origin partly excavated by Greenwell in 1867. Its precise location is unclear. Greenwell's siting information is rather imprecise, and the Ordnance Survey Archaeology Division do not seem to have identified any extant or recorded mound with this barrow. The NGR recorded here is that provided by the RCHME's (now English Heritage) Excavation Index. It's source is unclear. In 1867, the mound was 56 feet in diameter and 6 feet high, although it had already suffered some damage. The principal discoveries beneath the mound were an area of chalk slab paving northwest of centre on which several crouched inhumations had been placed. Most were disarticulated or incomplete. At the centre was a similarly incomplete, disarticulated adult male with an antler macehead. Other inhumations, crouched, incomplete and disarticulated were also present. Finds included bowl sherds, a boar's tusk blade, a scraper and a leaf arrowhead. Material recovered from the mound included Neolithic bowl sherds, Beaker sherds, a bronze dagger fragment, Bronze Age to Roman potsherds and various flint and stone implements and other objects. The finds from the barrow are in the British Museum (Greenwell Collection).All identifiable burials are Early Neolithic although Beaker sherds and bronze dagger fragments were found in the mound

Site_summary: Mortimer Barrow number 210. Opened originally by Greenwell Barrow revealing oval grave at centre containing an inhumation with associated grave goods.There were six burials but only two were accompanied by grave goods. They included a battle axe, jet beads and buttons and a bronze basket ornament Note that both burials had unfinished or unworked jet objects placed behind their heads - unfinished ornaments. Micro-tradition?

A squashed oval Neolithic barrow, possibly Greenwell barrow 59, no trace can now be seen in ploughed fields. Originally 21m in diameterThe main burial consisted of an adult male, who was found layed in an oval grave surrounded on all sides, except on the top were wood had apparently been relaid. The burial was accompanied by a flint knife. Four separate inhumations were also found within the moundThese grave goods are indicative of the Neolithic period (eg Group VI chisel that was remade from an axe) and horseshoe scraper At least two of these individuals were revised and parts of bodies were taken away
Site_description: A ploughed round barrow now a slight swelling, 70ft in diameter and 1ft high; probably one Greenwell's barrows LV111 and L1X. No trace in ploughed fields. <1> Measured 70ft in diameter and around 1 ft high when examined by Greenwell. Now ploughed out. The main burial consisted of an adult male, who was found layed in an oval grave surrounded on all sides, except on the top were wood had apparently been relaid. The burial was accompanied by a flint knife. Four separate inhumations were also found within the mound. <2> Photocopied extract from 'Catalogue of the Excavated Prehistoric and Romano-British Material in the Greenwell Collection' by I.A.Kinnes and I.H.Longworth, 1985. <3> Pastscape Website Description. <4>

Site_name_other: N OF COTTAM GRANGE Cowlam round barrow (G55)
Site_summary: Aerial photographs identified a round barrowTHis si Cowlam 56 . Barrow 15m diameter and 0.5m high. fOUR OF THE 5 BURIALS WERE ACCOMPANIED BY GRAVE GOODS. oNE GRAVE CONTAINED 3 BURIALS a PRIMARY bEAKER BURIAL HAD BEEN DISTURBED BY INSERTION OF LATER bURIALS WITH fOOD vESSEL S
Site_description: 'A' - SE 98626638. A round barrow 46 ft diameter and 2 ft high excavated by Greenwell. A central secondary contracted burial had  displaced the remains of an adult cremation and infant burial which  had been accompained by a beaker and cinerary urn, fragments of which were found in the grave fill (2). Re-excavation in 1968 revealed an encircling ditch 50 ft diameter (3) <1>  One of a group of three barrows two of which were excavated by Greenwell (55-56), the other by Mortimer (no 296). Ploughed down in 1957, one extant, and two destroyed in 1961. When excavated by by Greenwell measured 50ft in diameter by 1 and a half feet high; contained two adult inhumations in a hollow at centre, one of which accompanied by a food vessel. Close to these lay the scattered bones of an adult male and child <2> The largest group of three barrows the other two of which were opened by Greenwell (no 55-56). This the third, was planted with trees at one time. Probaly the one which was extatn in 1961 <3> SE 986664 Tumuli; three mounds in a cornfield, ploughed down in 1957, one barrow extant, the others destroyed, 1961 visible from the air in the midst of other blurred circular and curving soilmarks of a dubious nature. Two dug by Greenwell, one by Mortimer. Romano-British pottery also found this area <4> Impossible to assign Greenwell number and therefore excavation details to this barrow <5> Cross reference SMR 8815 ABD SMR 8880 for other two barrows inthis group Also SMR 3450 for pottery <6> Aerial photograph <7> Photocopied Extract <8> Photocopied  extract <9>Group of three barrows clustered very closely together (c. 45-50m apart) and all assigned same monument number in PastscapeGreenwell LV. SE 98646635. A round barrow, 50 ft diameter and 1 1/2 ft high excavated by Greenwell. Two contracted (one wit.h a small food vessel) and two disturbed burials were seen (2). Re-excavation in 1968 revealed two crouched burials and remains of a beaker burial. Other finds were a bone awl, fragments of bronze (? an awl), fragments of four stone axes, and beaker and food vessel sherds. A ditch, 50 ft diameter, encircled the mound.
