Site_summary: Beaker found with skeleton.<gg_summary>: Evidence relating to two separate finds in Elloughton parish:1) Fragments from a 'Beaker drinking cup' found during gravel quarrying in 1889 (not recorded here as no mention of human remains)2) The recovery of two burials - one potentially of Beaker date (Sheppard 1923), the other of MBA date (Manby 1980, 351) during quarrying in the 1920s.The broader context of these burials is not known
Site_description: <NRHE site summary>: Fragments of a BA drinking cup were found in Mill Hill gravel pit in 1889 and presented to Hull Museum. Curiously carved shank bones of horses have also been found, as well as human bones (1). Three human skeletons, a beaker and a base found at Mr MacIlwaine's pit

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW, 440m SW OF LOW FARM Low Farm, Garton round barrow (MC53)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Site of round barrow, excavated in 1872 by J R Mortimer. The central grave contained a crouched adult inhumation with a youth beneath with grave goods of two bronze rings, a food vessel and food and ochre deposits.Double central rectangular grave burial and legs of both individuals almost touching each other. They were accompanied by many grave goods , including a composite possible headdressthere were several other inhumations without grave goods
Site_description: <site summary>: Barrow C53, 60 ft diameter (c. 18.5m). Trough-shaped central grave contained  two primary crouched inhumations, one a youth accompanied by  small flint tool, piece of coil of ammonite, spindle-formed article of jet, two bronze rings, ornamented food vessel. Between skull and food vessel a mass of porous decayed matter, probably food deposit contained ox tooth. Yellow ochre-like substance under knees.

Site_summary: <NRHE summary>: TA 13524677. Bronze Age cremation cemetery exposed during gravel working at Fosse Hill Quarry, Catfoss. Rescue excavations by Hull Museum in 1965 revealed 17 deposits, 7 of which were in a flat circular area circa 6m wide, enclosed by a penannular V-shaped ditch, 1m wide, with an entrance or causeway 0.5m wide. Twelve of the cremations were originally in bucket-shaped urns.Manby (1980) adds that three cremation pits without urns and four with urns were located within the penannular enclosure. An arc of two unurned cremations and seven urned cremations was located to the north of the enclosure ditch. One further urned cremation together with three pits containing only cremated bones and charcoal were found to the south of the ring ditch.NB possible that flints associated with these burials are residual - would be good to find out more about their relationship with the cremated remains (eg inside or outside urn).

Site_name_other: RB RELIGIOUS SITE, OVERLYING 2 BA ROUND BARROWS
Site_summary: Aerial photographs show the cropmarks of two early Bronze Age round barrows excavated 1967-9. Large quantities of Romano-British pottery were recorded above the barrows, along with possible Anglo-Saxon artefacts and an execution cemetery.<gg_summary>: Two adjacent barrows (grouped here) excavated by Bartlett and Mackay in 1967-9. Only two graves with a definitive gg associated are recorded here. Worth noting, however is the use of chalk blocks in the two 'primary' graves associated with Barrow 1. The upper half of one burial was covered in chalk cobbles; the satellite burial was lined with an oval of chalk cobbles. <borderline gg><grouped barrows>
Site_description: An article on the Anglo-Saxon execution cemertery at Walkington Wold, East Yorkshire <15>  News paper article,  ' Grisley discovery of headless bodies gives insight into justice Saxon style ' <16>

Site_summary: Beaker and food vessel found with an inhumation while constructing an air-raid shelter at Gorsehill in 1939-40.Not very much detail about find and Clarke does not record the Beaker in his 1970 corpus

<gg summary>: remains of two human skeletons with two Bronze Age pottery vessels were found whilst installing a petrol  tank, in the stackyard of Bryan Mills Farm in  1953. One pot was identified as a food vessel and is in the  private museum of C and E Grantham, North Street, Driffield; the  other was destroyed
Site_description: <FURTHER INFO>

Site_summary: Mound No 1 and Mound 2 - the only ones that contained grave goods. All the mounds had evidence of one (and in the case of Mound 4) two in situ cremations pits with piles of burnt bones and ashes
Site_description: CDG added. Four of the barrows contained cremations, together with a large urn and two other pots in one and two incense cups in another. About 300 yds from these barrows, upon the southern slope of the hill, was a slight mound which upon excavation produced two skeletons.?assign new numbers to each of these new barrows; not very helpful as the information is so vague in first place <FURTHER INFO>

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW, 450m SW OF LOW FARM (MC56)
Site_summary: C56 excavated by Mortimer in 1872.  C56, had encircling ditch 25 yds diam. Oval grave about centre contained primary crouched inhumation accompanied by bronze point of small bodkin, two flint flakes. Two dish-shaped holes near by filled with black soil. Second crouched inhumation in grave about 12 ft to SW. Small pieces burnt wood in graves.
Site_description: CDG added.  Oval grave about centre contained primary crouched inhumation accompanied by bronze point of small bodkin, two flint flakes. Two dish-shaped holes near by filled with black soil. Second crouched inhumation in grave about 12 ft to SW. Small pieces burnt wood (?burnt plank or coffin) in graves.

Site_summary: two of the three burials were accompanied by grave goods ; only the cremation lacked gg
Site_description: Part of a more extensive cemetery at Life Hill. On raised ground to N of Wetwang station; Barrow 28 lies at the centre of the group. It was opened by Mortimer between 8-10th May 1865.

Site_summary: Round barrow first excavated by Mortimer in 1868, re-excavated by Brewster in 1965-6<gg summary>: Three burials - one crouched male lacked grave goods (but could be Saxon as the skeleton was very robust)Two cremations - one possible female with jet necklace and in Collared Urn and  and one cremation in Collared Urn
Site_description: Round Barrow. SE 8242 5694, B: Barrow 114, originally 56ft in diameter large portion south side in York Road,, removed prior to excavation 1868, remainder 4ft high, Just south east of centre two crushed cinerary urns contained primary cremations, one with nine globular jet and Kimmeridge coal beads, two small beads probably of vitreous paste. Crouched burial east of centre, another to north, probably Anglo-Saxon. B: Barrow 114, known as Hollies Barrow, re-excavted 1965-6 . Contained primary inhumation without grave goods. (Note that Brewster describes the paste beads mentioned above as 'faience'). The norther half of  'B' is still discernible as a slight mound, but it does not constitute intelligible remains. Published Survey (25") revisied <1> Mortimer barrow 114, diameter 56ft. (17.1m) by 4ft (1.2m) high, was excvated in 1868 and re-excavated by Brewster 1965-6. the latter found a primary inhumation without grave gooods, the earlier finds having comprised two cremations in cinerary urns and two contracted inhumations (thought to be Anglo-Saxon). In one of the urns were nine jet beads with two faience beads <2> Extract from the Gazetteer of A social and Anthropological Analysis of Conversion Period and Later Anglo-Saxon Cemeteries in Lincolnshire and Yorkshire <3> An archaeological watching brief and an archaeological appraisal was undertaken in advance and alongside the groundwork s for a new water main along Garrowby Street, Fridaythorpe. An archaeological appraisal was undertaken in advance of the groundwork s to assess the impact of the installation of the new water main on known and unknown archaeological and heritage assets. A visit was made to the Humber Sites and Monument Record to record all of the Heritage assets within the vicinity of the pipeline. These Heritage Assets were mainly Bronze Age Round Barrows along with linear boundaries and a series of Scheduled Monuments. A series of visits were made to monitor the pipeline route which ran for 1.3km along Garrowby Street. A trench was excavated within the road verge using a small 360 excavated within a toothless bucket. Within Stone Dale lay-by. Two pits 1m by 2m and between 1.2m _ 1.4m deep were excavated either side of the road. Topsoil then solid chalk bedrock at 0.30m deep was identified. The trench ran in a westerly direction for 230m and 1.10m deep. The trench then cut across the A166 for 8m, no Roman or Medieval road surfaces were identified, possibly dues to the 20th century road construction which may have removed earlier road surfaces. Topsoil was identified within the trench to an approximate depth of 0.30m then solid chalk bedrock.  An undated ditch (possibly MHU8441)was identified, which was cut into the bedrock and extended beyond the depth of the trench which was 1.10m deep. The ditch cut was identified for approximately 300m. 560m of the trench and two pits for directional drilling for a 100m section of pipeline was excavated within an earlier PVC main which had redeposited modern deposits up to a depth of 1.10m. Along this section of the pipeline the instability of the soil meant that the trench had to be widened to 2m in sections. No evidence of Round Barrow (MHU3834) was identified due to previous ground disturbance.  No other archaeological features or artefacts were identified <4>

Site_name_other: BEAKER & AXE, FROM DESTROYED BURIAL?, GRAVEL PIT, BACK LANE
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Findspot of a Type C beaker (now in Middleton parish church), an axe and other artefacts that were found in 1895-6 from a dis-used gravel pit adjoining Back Lane, MiddletonNOTE - the axes and other artefacts were not directly associated with the Beaker burialBeaker burial if child with pot behind head. Note Other Beaker burials are known in the vicinity and may form part of a wider dispersed cemetery
Site_description: <FURTHER INFO>

Site_summary: <NRHE site summary>: Iron Age inhumation cemetery including a cart burial, and a possible Iron Age settlement discovered during 19th century railway construction.<gg_summary>: One grave; one inhumation; one object record (cart fitting) entered here.
Site_description: <NRHE site description>: A quantity of bones and rusty iron, etc, considered to be an Iron Age chariot burial by Mortimer, was found in a deep cutting between Middleton and Enthorpe stations during railway construction in 1889. Of the objects found, one only was preserved, a linch-pin 5 1/2ins long, made of iron with bronze ends. (1)At a 32ft deep cutting at Lair Hill, a little beyond Middleton (SE93034795 to SE 93394852), human remains were found in several places, as in the two previous cuttings. At the top of the hill, the section exposed as unusual depth of surface soil with several trenches 5ft deep, in which were found deer bones and horns. (2)Possibly a settlement had been sectioned, perhaps a cemetery as well. The linch-pin if found in this cutting, would suggest that one or the other may have been IA. The linch-pin is in Hull Museum. (3)Cutting indicated by Authority 2 is the only cutting between Middleton and Enthorpe stations and is about the depth indicated by Maule Cole. (4)Listed by Challis and Harding under 'La Tene Burials'. (5)

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Three or indeed four flat graves found in 1901 - with Beaker. Found during sand quarrying. (SE 94384946) A skeleton which had apparently been buried in a double-position was found at a depth of 3ft, whilst digging for sand in T Broadley Soanes garden in October 1901. With the skeleton were seven large flat pieces of jet, evidently part of a necklace. Close by this spot a skeleton of a youth of 10-12 years was found by Mr Soanes on 26 August 1902. A drinking-cup (beaker) had been placed behind the skull. (1) A little to the west of these burials a third skeleton was found in 1905 accompanied by a beaker, flint dagger, jet beads and two bone pins, flint and pyrite. The finds from this burial, with the exception of the pins, are at Hull Museum Nos 1035-38.
Site_description: <FURTHER INFO>Four burials of Beaker date all with grave goods ; all flat graves that formed small Beaker cemetery which is quite unusual

Site_summary: A crouched inhumation burial and Romano-British ditch discovered in a chalk quarry in 1921.<gg_summary>: Initially thought to be Romano-British by Sheppard (1923), later recorded as IA.
Site_description: 'An Iron Age crouched burial and a ditch of an RB settlement site, with associated domestic rubbish, found in 1921 in a chalk quarry at Middleton on the Wolds'. <1> 'A chalk-cut grave, one yard square, containing a crouched inhumation having an iron bracelet threaded with two large bone beads on its arm, was revealed during factory extensions at a quarry (c1921) - centred at SE 9423 5013. Two small pieces of iron, large bone ring made from red deer antler, fragments of pottery including those from small Roman circular dish also in grave. Two V-shaped trenches, one extending at least 11yds south from grave; the other extending 8ft south from the quarry edge and turing right angles eastward into factory. Infilling contained numerous animal bones, pot boilers, Roman pot sherds, chalk loam weight, flint pounder and a pair of bronze tweezers. Objects in Hull Museum. <2> Photocopied extract from 'Roman Remains at Middleton On The Wolds', The East Riding Antiquarian Society Volume 21 1921-1922, p.80-84. <3> Pastscape Website Description. <4>

Site_name_other: BA ROUND BARROW (M 274) Sledmere or Garton Slack  barrow (M 274)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Barrow was excavated in 1891 by Mortimer. It measured 22m diameter and 0.4m high and contained a crouched inhumation with crushed food vessel. It had been much plough-disturbed. Inhumation was in a coffin

Aerial photographs identified a ring ditch. <gg summary>: Excavated in 1874 by Mortimer. Although the burials of seven individuals were encountered (including three in a triple grave and two in a double grave), only 1 burial contained grave goods There were a number of headless and revisited burials- all quite disturbed
Site_description: Garton Slack, Barrow c.71. Examined by Mortimer in 1874 when it measured 60' diameter, 18 inches high. A central grave contained five interments, two of which were children; one adult was accompanied by a food vessel. To the north lay another two graves, one containing a crouched inhumation, the other two skeletons, one lying face downwards. <1> Round barrow (M. NO. C.71). Opened August 1874. Description: about 60' diameter, 18" high when excavated. 1) Central oval grave 9 1/2' x 6 1/2' and 4'10" deep; a) at base four crouched inhumations 2 adults and 2 children all disturbed; one of adults accompanied by a food vessel (479:42) b) immediately above a) and responsible for disturbance was secondary crouched inhumation. 2) 19' north of centre secondary ? satellite burial in grave 3' deep, crouched inhumation unaccompanied. 3) 9' north of centre, midway between 1) and 2), a third burial, possibly satellite; at base 3 1/2' down, crouched inhumation, unaccompanied; in same grave 20" below surface second crouched inhumation. In mound: two flint flakes (338:42:111) and flint punch (338:42:112). <2> (A - SE 95605817) Tumulus. NR (Site of) (Not shown on 1855 6"). A - Barrow C71; about 60 ft diameter, 18 inches high, excavated 1874. A central oval grave contained four crouched inhumations, three primary, one accompanied by a crushed food vessel, on the floor. (See Illus). Burnt pieces of human bones throughout grave. Graves B and C contained three crouched inhumations - ? all secondaries. Wood ashes found in graves... Both barrows have been under plough for many years and no trace of either survives. <3> "Tumulus" Mortimer Barrow 171, excavated 1874. Ring ditch visible. (OSSI; RAF vert.). <4> A - Barrow C71, about 60ft diam, 18 ins high, excavated 1874. A central oval grave contained four crouched inhumations, three primary, one accompanied by a crushed food vessel, on the floor. (See Illus). Burnt pieces of human bones throughout grave. Graves B and C contained three crouched inhumations - ? all secondaries. Wood ashes found in graves... Both barrows have been under plough for many years and no trace of either survives. <5> This mound was opened August 6th, 7th and 8th 1874. It measured about 60 feet in diameter, 18 inches in elevation, and had been erected on a slight natural mound. Operations were commenced on the southern margin, and continued without any discovery until reaching the centre, and here was an oval grave measuring 9 1/2 feet east and west, 6 1/2 feet across, and 4 feet 10 inches in depth. The plan (fig. 578) shows the disposition of the various interments.

Site_summary: Site of possible Bronze Age cemetery recorded at Wetwang Field.<gg_summary>: Completely messed up barrow with later Saxon interments that have thoroughly disturbed and iron objects and flints all commingled together. Near a double dyke. The one skeleton recovered sounds either IA or Saxon (?or even M-LBA?)Skykes 1794 (in Mortimer 1905: 207): <The bracelet (fig. 20], plate 51, p. 1) was found upon the wrist of the skeleton of a full-sized man, about two yards underground, by the road  side in Wetwang field, in the East Riding of the County of York, by some workmen who were digging for material to mend the road. The skeleton was laid at full length, with every bone in its proper place, and in good preservation. Some teeth which dropped out of the skull were perfectly fresh.>The armlet was stone (see Mortimer fig 507); potentially not prehistoric?
Site_description: <NRHE site description>: Flexed inhumation with a stone bracelet on wrist was found six feet below the ground surface near the roadside inWetwang field (c 1794) by workmen digging for road material. (1)A bronze ring was found in 1882, three quarters of a mile S of Wetwang Cross, "near old embankments still slightly visible". Several skeletons were seen many years ago near where the ring was found, in an old gravel pit adjoining the W side of the road to Tibthorpe (area SE 942583). Suggested by Mortimer as being the site of the inhumation mentioned by authy 1. (2)No further siting information, the name, Wetwang Field is no longer known locally, and it could not be traced through enclosure and tithe awards

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Six burials were found under this barrow but only two were accompanied by grave goods (two children)Also known as Weaverthorpe There was one multiple inhumation of crouched adult with two separate skulls at feet and a third at the chest (could these be grave goods?). Placed in oval setting of chalk blocks
Site_description: <site summary>: . Greenwell's No 47.  unsuccessfully probed by him circa 1860(2). Excavations by Brewster in 1966(3) and 1968(4) revealed an inner chalk mound 20ft in diameter and 18 ins high, capped by another mound 70 ft in diameter and 5 ft high surrounded by a ditch 7 ft wide and 4 ft deep. Just within the mound were traces of a double line of postholes 65 ft in diameter. Under the inner chalk mound were a shaft grave, 6 ft deep, containing a disturbed adult burial; a 4 ft deep oval grave containing 3 disturbed adult skeletons associated with an adult crouched inhumation enclosed by a roughly oval kerb of chalk stones capped by a small mound of clean chalk, and having 2 inverted skulls at the foot of the grave and another in front of the chest; and a smaller shallow grave containing a crouched inhumation. No grave goods were associated with any of the above burials. Cut into the side of the inner mound was a small grave containing two infant burials associated with four Beaker sherds (3), and immediately S of the shaft grave was a crouched inhumation(4)

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: LBA urned cremation deposited in a chalk structure (pit/cist?) at the centre of a circle of massive posts with an entrance to the south east. This structure was positioned centrally within an earlier henge. No detailed excavation report.
Site_description: <NHRE site description>: A circular enclosure at Paddock Hill, Thwing, originally identified as a cropmark site. Excavation was undertaken between 1973 and 1987 by T Manby, intitially under the assumption that the site was a henge. However, the excavations revealed a long and complex sequence of use of the site. The earliest activity was represented by some flints of Mesolithic date, including microliths, cores and flakes. Earlier Neolithic activity was also represented solely by artefacts, including flint arrowheads, scrapers and stone axes, plus some sherds of Peterborough Ware. The first major constructional phase occurred in the late Neolithic, when a henge comprising a circular ditch circa 60 metres in diameter with external chalk bank was created. Grooved Ware and Beaker sherds are among the finds associated with the henge, which featured opposed north-west and south-east entrances. The earlier Bronze Age is represented primarily by artefacts, including some flint implements and Food Vessel sherds. The site was extensively remodelled in the Later Bronze Age. The silted-up henge ditch was recut, and a central post circle constructed, 17 metres in diameter and surrounding a central pit containing an urned cremation. Artefacts and other debris of Mid-to-late Bronze Age were also present, including evidence for metalworking activity. Next, a more substantial enclosure was constructed comprising a ditch and internal rampart circa 115 metres in diameter, completely enclosing the earlier enclosure. The rampart featured timber revetment and was retained at its rear by a double row of posts. This enclosure also featured opposed entrances on the same alignment as the earlier henge. Roughly contemporary is a ring slot circa 25 metres in diameter, within and concentric to the earlier henge, and interpreted as a large timber building. The next (comparatively minor) use of the site occurred in the Roman period, and is mainly attested by pottery and brooches. (See TA 07 SW 42 for Anglo-Saxon phase).Report analysing the charred and mineralised plant macrofossils, which yielded evidence for crop cultivation in the Bronze Age and Anglo-Saxon periods. <35> A charcoal sample from the inner ditch N terminal was examined and hazel and alder, ash, hawthorn and oak taxa were identified. <36> Report relating to the carpentry details of mineral preserved wood on iron coffin fittings, identifying specific joints used in their construction and proposed reconstructions of three coffins. <37> Charcoal identification was undertaken from the remains of firewood from both the Bronze Age and Anglo-Saxon occupation phases of the site. <38>

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW (G60) Willy Howe or Thwing or Wold Newton barrow (G60 ot LX)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Four burials were encountered but only three were accompanied by grave goods They included two Beakers, barbed and tanged arrowheads and a jet ring<NRHE HOBUID: 79837; https://www.pastscape.org.uk/hob.aspx?hob_id=79837&sort=2&type=&typeselect=c&rational=a&class1=None&period=None&county=None&district=None&parish=None&place=&recordsperpage=10&source=text&rtype=monument&rnumber=79837#>
Site_description: <Site summary>: added. Greenwell's barrow LX: 70' in diameter and 1'9" in height. Ploughing has reduced it's height and disturbed several secondary interments. Under the mound was a ditch 4' at top, 2' wide at bottom and 2 1/2' deep. It formed a ring 19' radius. 5 1/2' E x N of centre was a male crouched skeleton. 13' 6" W-N-W of centre was an adult, at the feet was a beaker which the plough had broken. At the centre was a grave 7' diameter and at a foot from the top of the barrow was another skeleton on its left side and with the left hand on the remains of an unidentifiable article of wood. On the right arm were a jet button and resting on it, a ring with engraving and perforations. Near the feet were sherds of a beaker which belonged to an earlier burial. Several animal bones were found.

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Whimster (1981) summarises the evidence as follows: Excavation within the massive cemetery that lies in a shallow dry valley to the W of the deserted medieval village of Pockthorpe first took place in 1721 and Greenwell records that 500 barrows could once be identified from the ground, although the Ordnance Survey in a later survey plotted the positions of almost 200 barrows. Crop marks of square and apparently circular barrows can now be identified within an area measuring nearly 500 yards by 400 yards (450 x 360 m) and others have been identified in the belt of woodland lying immediately to the N. The precise limits of the burial area cannot be determined from aerial photographic evidence owing to the poor quality of recorded crop-growths. Most barrows seem to be of reasonably large size (c.301 -401 ;  9-12 m) and are very densely packed. In at least one part of the cemetery there is some evidence of a regular arrangement of barrows in lines. Stead has gathered together information relating to the excavation of 106 individual burials and his numbering sequence is followed here. Excavation took place on the following occasions: Barrow 1 excavated 1721Barrow 2 excavated pre-1830, Rev. W. DrakeBarrows 3—4 excavated 1834, John MilnerBarrow 5 excavated 1848, Rev. W. Drake and E. TindallBarrows 6—11 excavated 1849, Yorkshire Antiquarian ClubBarrows 12—14 excavated 1849 or 1850, Thomas KendallBarrows 15—28 excavated 1864, Canon W. GreenwellBarrows 29—30 excavated 1881, J.R. MortimerBarrows 31—46 excavated 1897, Mortimer, Greenwell and Thomas BoyntonBarrows 47—80 excavated 1898, Mortimer, Greenwell and Thomas BoyntonBarrows 81—93 excavated 1899, MortimerBarrows 94—95 excavated 1900, MortimerBarrows 96—98 excavated 1902, MortimerBarrows 99—106 excavated 1909, MortimerBM site: http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/search.aspx?place=26528&plaA=26528-3-2Yorkshire Museum site: https://www.yorkmuseumstrust.org.uk/collections/search/?search_text=danes+gravesNB THESE ARE THE BETTER IMAGES<NRHE HOBUID: 79634; https://www.pastscape.org.uk/hob.aspx?hob_id=79634&sort=2&type=&typeselect=c&rational=a&class1=None&period=None&county=None&district=None&parish=None&place=&recordsperpage=10&source=text&rtype=monument&rnumber=79634#>
Site_description: <NRHE site description>: Danes' Graves, an Iron Age cemetery. It is said there were originally 500 barrows, 106 of which were excavated between 1721 and 1909. The mounds, 10'-33' in diameter, 1 1/4'-5' high, contained oblong graves with rounded corners, generally 3 3/4'-7' long, 2'-4 3/4'wide and 6"- 3 1/2' deep. One grave, 9' long by 7 1/2 wide contained a (dismantled) Chariot Burial. Gravegoods (excluding the Chariot Burial) consisted of bronze, iron and jet bracelets, bronze and iron brooches and 'objects', glass beads and hand-made clay pots used as food vessels. Finds are in the British, Hull andYorkshire Museums. (2)The cemetery falls in a now thickly wooded area of deciduous trees and dense scrub. Only about 175 of the mounds are now extant and most of these are obscured by the vegetation. Where visible they appear to be constructed of mainly chalk rubble with a little earth. It is not evident which mound contained the chariot burial.Published (25") revised from recent RCHM survey. (3)

Site_name_other: LONG BARROW (G234 or CCXXXIV), MESOLITHIC OCCUPATION, BA-MED POTTERY
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Note two phases of burial activity - Early Neolithic and Early Bronze Age. Although a minimum of 11 burials were interred here, including at least one adult male, five adult females and three children, only 5 were accompanied by grave goods In EBA only gg were Food Vessels
Site_description: Long Barrow. A long barrow, now nearly ploughed down, covered a burial chamber complex; a palisade which may have been a retaining wall or a mortuary enclosure. A round barrow over the west end contained cremations, inhumations and beaker pottery.A long barrow 170 ft x 45 ft, reduced by ploughing to 3-4 ft high, excavated by Greenwell in 1868 and Manby in 1965-9. Greenwell found a 14 ft high burial chamber-like complex at its eastern end and a round barrow superimposed on its western end. Inhumations and one cremation were found. Manby exposed the outline of palisade enclosure and other post holes, conjectured as screens or buildings. Chronology of the site seems to be of three main phases:- Phase I: Two parallel ditches dug; their purpose obscured, but resembling the side ditches of Lambourn long barrow (SU 38 SW 5) in Berkshire (3).Phase II: Palisade enclosure erected. Phase III: Palisade destroyed. Mound thrown up extending beyond palisade limits. Manby suggests the site may have been a mortuary enclosure and burial chamber after a possible early shallow long barrow. Two phases of use - one Early Neolithic and with Early Bronze Age later burials

Site_summary: Round barrow, now ploughed out, two graves, one with a food vessel were found.  The barrow was surrounded by a number of shallow Medieval graves, which were presumed to relate to the use of the barrow as the site of a gallows.<Food Vessel misidentified - actually Beakers>
