Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW, E OF LIFE HILL Life Hill or Sledmere barrow (M294)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Four crouched inhumations and a cremation burial were seen. In one grave fill were fragments of an adult burial. Other finds were two food vessels, flint knives, a bronze pricker and riveted knife and a bone implement  In one grave fill were fragments of an adult burial. Other finds were two food vessels, flint knives, a bronze pricker and rivetted knife and a bone implement.
Site_description: <Site detail>: A round barrow 65 ft diameter and 2 ft high excavated by Mortimer in 1896 (M294).

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Note a MNI of five individuals were encountered, and some of these were redeposited or reworked (placed in disarticulated heaps of bones) and only two individuals were accompanied by grave goods Long barrow reused as round barrow? Oriented E-W and 42m long x 12m wide and 1.4m high. Approximate site of two long Barrows, Greenwell No 66.. Earth in the middle and chalk on either side; to the W. end there seemed to be a round barrow, in it an adult female burial with an "A" Beaker.
Site_description: <Site summry>:  Long barrow reused as round barrow? Oriented E-W and 42m long x 12m wide and 1.4m high. Approximate site of two long Barrows, Greenwell No 66.. Earth in the middle and chalk on either side; to the W. end there seemed to be a round barrow, in it an adult female burial with an "A" Beaker. Above this was a skeleton of a child, below the woman lay a wooden beam 5'9" x 9" x 4" covering a 7ft grave in which was a skeleton & "C" Beaker, and bones, of a skeleton which had been relaid after disturbance. 76ft. E. of grave were further human skeletons of a man and two children. A second mound 190ft long, 50ft wide 4ft high extended from W. end of the first. No burial found in it, but flint flakes, charcoal and pottery fragments were numerous. Animal bones, and plain dark coloured pottery Neo 'A' according to Newbigin P.P.5.3., this includes a rim of Form H and a horizontal lug. This is one of two pairs of Long Barrows at Rudston joined in V formation. The other pair form Greenwell's No 224. he principle mound was aligned east-west, with either of the two extremities being of a greater elevation than the middle part. The mound was 137 ft long with a mean breadth of 40ft, the west end was 4.5ft high and the east 5ft. The long barrow contained numerous animal bones, flint chippings, charcoal and sherds of plain, dark-coloured pottery throughout the whole of its length but principally at the level of the old ground surface. At the west end and below the centre of the round barrow was the body of a young adult women. The inhumation was 2ft above the level of the natural surface and just in front of the right tibia was a "drinking cup". At a level 6" higher (the head lying above the woman's knees) were the remains of a child aged about 8 or 9. Immediately above the head was a flint knife 1.75" long. Underneath the woman, at the level of the natural surface, was a wooden beam which covered a grave which was 7ft long, 4.5ft wide and 2ft deep. This grave contained the body of an adult of uncertain sex, behind the head was a "drinking cup" , three flint scrapers and some chippings were also found in the grave. Just beyond the feet of this inhumation were the remains of a young woman which had been disturbed and relaid. They had been placed in a heap with the skull on top of the other bones. The mound also contained the remains of a male of large stature, a child and a single piece of burnt bone.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Containing a pavement of chalk slabs with 4 adult and 1 incomplete partly disarticulated inhumations. To the east a dispersed group of incomplete partly disarticulated skeletons; 2 male, 3 female, 3 children with leaf arrowhead and bone point. Also 1 incomplete and partly disarticulated male with antler macehead, 1 male, 1 disarticulated female and many broken bones with boar tusk blade. Grimston and Towthorpe sherds in and below the moundBeaker and Food Vessels suggest that the barrow was re-used in both Beaker and Early Bronze Age periods.
Site_description: ' A Social and Anthroplogical Analysis of Conversion Period and Later Anglo-Saxon Cemetries  in Lincolnshire and Yorkshire' <11><Site summary>: This is Cowlam 67 or LXVII. Listed by Kinnes as a Neolithic round barrow perhaps modified for later burials. Round barrow - large and 31m in diameter and 2.7m high. Basal layer of 'dark fatty earth with much burnt earth and charcoal'. Possibly remains of an EN crematorium?

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Near centre an oval grave 8' x 4 1/2' at the bottom, a crouched skeleton with a whetstone.? an engraved jet ring, jet button V perforation, bronze knives. The grave extended in in length contained male skeleton and two V. jet buttons, a further shallow grave, male skeleton, bronze knife dagger, and an axe hammer. Contained six other burials, potsherds, flints, and animal bones.Note that although many grave goods were recovered, there were no pots interred with any of the burials in this barrow Also note that there is deliberate playing of objects being place in front of or behind the male inhumations - daggers in front at face with points facing away from head and strike-a-lights at chest or behind
Site_description: <Site summary>: Barrow in a seemingly isolated position and over 1km from nearest one.  Greenwell's Barrow No 68, approximate site [TA 11076647] was 40ft diam 3 1/2 ft high, the lower 18 inches of earth, upper part chalk.

Site_name_other: BARROW (G69 or LXIX), E OF SANDS WOOD
Site_summary: <gg summary>: This is an interesting site as the EBA inhumation is in an unusual position - extended. And the cremated remains of an adult male may actually accompany him as a grave good. The Food Vessel is a Vase Urn which may be more in keeping with Scottish/ Irish types.Contained extended burial (young male) touching was an adult cremation. 1.A. type  Food vessel at skeletons left side. Many flints, including 24 round scrapers. Greenwell notes this is only the fourth extended  skeleton in the 300 he had excavated. possibly coffined in restricted space - degraded wood A huge number of flint scrapers and flakes were recovered from the mound.
Site_description: <Site summary>: Greenwell's Barrow No 69. was 20m diam 1.2m high and made of earth. At centre a grave 2.2m by 1.4m with  shelving floor 1 1/4ft deep at the E end.

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Whimster (1981) summarises the evidence as follows: Millington, Grimthorpe SE 816535A group of 4 inhumations was discovered immediately behind the rampart of the Iron Age hillfort at Grimthorpe between 1868 and 1872 and reported by Mortimer. A fifth grave was located in the filling of the hillfort ditch during excavation by Stead in 1961 . Burials 1 -4 were apparently found within 3 m of one another and their proximity suggests a group of flat-graves without covering barrow mounds. This impression is reinforced by the apparent recutting of the grave of Burial is reinforced by the apparent recutting of 3 and the secondary insertion of Burial 4.Objects in British Museum: http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/search.aspx?place=107648&plaA=107648-3-2NB rc dates from Garrow et al. 2009
Site_description: <NRHE site description> An Iron Age univallate hill fort almost levelled by the plough was identified in AP's in 1958 (2). It had formerly been noted by Mortimer (1) who mentions the "filled up inner ditch of a supposed camp" in describing a burial discovered in a chalkpit within the 'camp' in 1868. The burial was associated with an iron sword, shield, spearhead etc. (Finds in the BM) Three other inhumations were unaccompanied. A trial excavation was carried out in 1958 followed by further excavations in 1961/2.The defences consisted of a single ditch 6-7 feet deep, 10-15 feet wide, with a berm on the inside 12 to 15 feet wide, behind that a timber laced bank 6 feet wide, and an entrance in the SE; enclosing approx 8 acres. (See plan). Eight four-post structures within the enclosure were interpreted as granaries. A large quantity of pottery and animal bones came mainly from the ditch. Medieval and RB pottery and a sherd of a BA collared urn, came from the surface of the interior. An unaccompanied crouched burial was found in the filling of the ditch. Stead suggests a date of 1st century BC for the warrior burial found in 1868, the decoration on the shield being La Tene Style. However, he points out that the burial, granaries and hill fort need not be contemporary. (1-4)Site is still under plough, and no intelligible remains of the work survive. In both excavation areas (see plan) the rampart is just discernible as a broad swelling, but elsewhere its course can only be envisaged from the general contour of the ground. Outline surveyed from APs (auth 3) at 1:2500. (5)Listed by Challis and Harding as a hill fort (Iron Age) composed of a timber-framed box rampart, 6ft wide and contained within its area several La Tene burials, one of which was accompained by a sword and shield. (6)SE 816 534. Grimthorpe. Listed in gazetteer as a univallate hillfort covering 3.1ha. (7)

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW (MB2), S OF MILLINGTON GRANGE
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Some unurned cremations which also lacked any other grave goods. Large and complex barrow with many individuals - both inhumations and cremations.Note one old rather gummy lady had her extracted teeth with her and placed in a string bag at her chin
Site_description: <Site summary>: Barrow consisting of gravel and turf.

Site_name_other: Maramotte Farm or Dog Hill ROUND BARROW (M276) (LATER SYKES DOG CEMETERY)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Note some finds including Beaker not ascribed to burials and from the mound. Of 8 individuals only 4 had any grave goods.  Two graves were found at the base, one contained cremated adult bones covered with flat stones and other human and animal bones, urn fragments and a fragment of a drinking vessel. The other contained three flexed adult skeletons with the bones of a young child. Flint flakes and scraper. Other skeletons and finds in the mound.
Site_description: <site summary>: Round barrow on the Maramotte Farm known as `Dog Hill' from its use as a cemetery to bury the pet dogs of the Sykes family. Excavated August 1892

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW, SE OF FORDHAM FARM Kirby Underdale or Calais Wold barrow (M86)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Round barrow on slope of Stone Dale - opened by Mortimer in 1867. It had already been investigated. wood ashes encountered at base of barrow may indicate disturbed cremation. Polished axe and flint knife found among these along with 4 scrapers

Scheduled Monument, Bronze Age round barrow excavated by Mortimer between 1860-76<gg summary>: most of the burials were accompanied by grave goods, including mainly flint flake knives and pots. Both Beakers and Food Vessels were recoveredthere are quite a number of children from this barrow (four out of the 12 individuals)
Site_description: SE 8221 5934, SE 85 NW. (SE82215934) Tumulus (NR) (Not shown on OS 6" 1854). Barrow 4. encroached on by chalk quarrying and spasmodically investigated from 1860-76. A filled in ditch encircled the barrow which contained a total of 12 inhumations and one cremation; also over 20 secondary AS burials. Central grave contained four crouched burials two drinking cups (long necked beakers illustrated), flint knives, animal bones, Four graves each contained single crouched burial; remains of child at feet of one. Three further graves were interconnected. Number of flint  knives, sherds and animal bones also in graves. Finds with AS burials include bronze circular fibula, coloured beads, bronze box, iron knife, remains of satchel. Four  beakers, groups S2 (w) (2); s1; fp. In Hull Museum, Acc Nos 202-42; 210-42; 211-42; 222-42. The southern half of the barrow has been quarried away and the surviving mound is turf covered and in poor condition, approximately 14m in diameter and 0.90m high <1> PAINSTHOPRE WOLD, BARROW 4. ROUND BARROW. Barrow encroached by chalk quarry in 1860 when number of human bones and deer antlers found. Several found by Mortimer who also noted an encircling ditch. Further encroachment in 1862 uncovered two Anglo-Saxon interments. The central grave, excavated by Mortimer in 1870 contained fragments of a beaker and detached human bines and three other skeletons with two beakers, two flint knives. In the body of the mound occurred a deposit of cremated bones, a crouched inhumation associated with a food vessel, together with a later insertion of A/S date. In 1871 a jet bead and another extended inhumation (?A/S) were found. In 1876 Mortimer excavated the remainder of the barrow and uncovered five graves all representing primary burials. Four were single inhumations while the fifth had the remains of a child at it s a feet. Two of the burials were associated with beaker pottery. At a higher level in the body of the mound occurred two later, A/S  burials one of which, lying in a crouched position and a female was associated with grave goods compressed of a bronze brooch, beads, a satchel and an iron box containing needles and thread <2> Hull Museum CarD <3> Scheduled as 'Round Barrow SW of Uncleby Wold Barn' National Monument number 21059, 19/08/92 <4> Painsthorpe Wold I Inhumation cemetery, secondary in barrow. Y 159 NE. Area SE 823582. Mortimer (1906), pp 114-17. VCH, ii, 92. Brown (1915), VI, 805. Museum: Hull, Mortimer. 1862 A chalk pit in Pudsey Plantation encroached upon a barrow, and 2 secondary burials, extended with heads to the W, were exposed. 'One occurred near the left hand margin [ ? On the W] and was at the base of the barrow. The other was near the right hand margin [? On the E side] and a little below the base of the mound'. 1870 The centre of the barrow was explored and immediately under the turf a disturbed skeleton and fragments of AS pottery were found. 1871 Further chalk quarrying exposed the leg bines of an adult 13' SW of centre of the barrow. The skeleton was found to be extended with eh head tot eh NW, the hands on the pelvis, only 6" deep. The skull had been removed, probably at the time when the barrow was planted with trees or during rabbiting.

Site_summary: Bronze Age round barrow 1.75m in height and 20m in diameter, containing a primary inhumation and a later Anglo-Saxon burial.<gg summary>The adult male had two comical jet buttons and a necklace fastener placed at his feet (not wearing them) and was accompanied by shoulder of small pig and other meat joints at feet
Site_description: <site summary>: This is barrow 200. Barrow 200, excavated 1877, contained central rock-cut grave with primary crouched burial, pig and other animal bones and three jet buttons. (One or more interments destroyed on burial of three diseased beasts, 1866). Remains of bronze dish or cup and iron spike from AS spear found

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Contained three oval graves, four primary burials, two in grave B, three with food vessels; grave goods include flint tools, bone bodkin, another fragment, beaver's tooth, etc. Also six secondary cremations, two urned (one inverted), two in hollow with burnt wood, two in heap with two flint knives. Also two crushed food vessels, one unique in design. Flint knives were a common grave good here' lots of Food Vessels and Collared Urns
Site_description: <site summary>:  Barrow 98. 48 ft diam, 3 ft high, excavated 1867. C

Site_summary: A<gg summary>:  round barrow approximately 30ft in diamater, excavated in 1867 and found to contain two inhumations along with a secondary Anglo-Saxon burial.Two burials, both with rather unremarkable grave goods, although one is accompanied by a smashed Food Vessel
Site_description: Round barrow (102), is approximately 30ft in diameter and 6-8 inches high. The site was excavated in 1867 and was found to contain a central grave with a primary crouched inhumation with five flint flakes, the remains of a second inhumation was also found with a food vessel (also classed as a primary burial). A second food vessel in fragments was found nearby as well as the lower jaw of an ox. An Anglo-Saxon secondary burial was found accompanied by a knife. <1> Photocopy from the Gazetter of Joanne Louise Buckberry Ph.D. Thesis 'A Social and Anthropological Analysis of Conversion Period and Later Anglo-Saxon Cemeteries in Lincolnshire and Yorkshire'. <2> Pastscape Website Description. <3>

Site_summary: <gg summary:> Part of the Painsthorpe Wold barrow group. This barrow was excavated by Mortimer in May 1867. Several burials were found including a youth c 10-12 years old (poss secondary) with an urn. At base of barrow in circular stone enclosure or cist were two burials; one adult and one youth. THe youth had a flint saw by face and between the two skulls was a 'drinking cup' but it was crushed (perhaps Beaker-Food Vessel hybrid). Under bones of the adult skeleton was a circular heap of cremated bones on the S side of which was a a crushed Food Vessel (probably originally inverted over the cremation). A heat-fractured flint knife was in with the cremated bones (pyre good). Two pits in barrow near tthe burials contained dark unctuous matter and unburnt bones - food and drink offerings?

<gg_summary>: Note in this barrow there were at least 7 burials - a mixture of inhumations and cremations and not all were complete. Only four were accompanied by any sort of grave goods. Also note that the barrow has two distinct phases of use - one in the Early Neolithic and the second in the Beaker-EBA. There were lots of dismembered and disarticulated human remains - piled up and scattered all over and without grave goods
Site_description: <gg_summary>. Oval barrow of Early Neolithic date - part of a wider cemetery and surrounded by Early Bronze Age barrows. The site of a round barrow of probable Neolithic origin, excavated over "four fine days in the latter part of June 1867" by Mortimer. At the time, the mound measured 60 feet in diameter and up to 34 inches high. Ordnance Survey field investigation in 1973 could find no surviving surface traces.The excavation focused on the centre of the mound. Beneath the mound and southwest of centre (southeast on the published plan) was an oval grave pit containing a deposit of cremated bone plus a quantity of unburnt human bones. South of this pit, another deposit of cremated bones lay on the original ground surface, accompanied by a burnt flint flake. A little north and to the west of the oval pit, again laid on the original ground surface, were human remains representing partial inhumations. Close to the western group were two groups of flints which included 21 flakes, leaf arrowheads, serrated flakes and a knife. Just north of these deposits was a crouched adult inhumation plus the remains of another. The mound itself contained many large flints, notably above the last-mentioned inhumations and one of the cremations. The mound also contained skull fragments of a child near its highest point, presumably a secondary burial? Other worked flints including a leaf arrowhead were also present in the mound. [NB Painsthorpe 201, previously recorded here, has now been recorded separately

Site_summary: Also known as Bishop Wilton 96.  Barrow 96 is 8m in diameter and very flat.  It is paired with Barrow 114 (which had jet & faience beads). Excavated in 1867. Dish-shaped hole near centre contained primary  cremation, wood ashes and pointed flint. Small grave to N  contained (?) primary inhumation of child; a food vessel  disturbed by plough found near surface.

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW SW OF UNCLEBY WOLD BARN (MX) (G1)
Site_summary: Scheduled Monument, Bronze Age round barrow excavated by Canon Greenwell in 1868. Large bowl barrow not far from others in vicinity. Over 28m in diameter and 0.8m high. Although originally Early Neolithic it was also used for Early Bronze Age and Saxon interments <gg summary>:scraper, axehead and a Beaker were gg with three cremations (2 adult & 1 child). Beaker not directly associated with burials bit placed upright in mound , as are many scrapers (thiumbnail etc)Originally an oval Early Neolithic barrow
Site_description: SE 82195940 SE85 NW. Greenwell, Barrow no , Round Barrow. Opened by Canon Greenwell in 1868. Measured 94ft diameter, 2' 10" high. Central grave containing at its bottom the burnt bones of an adult lying between two large flint stones one foot apart. North East of centre occurred a small polished greenstone axe, a beaker and a round flint scraper. South east of centre deposit of burnt bones of an adult accompanied by perforated bone pin <1>  Scheduled Monument Record <2>  ROUND BARROW; Visited 29.4.1967. This barrow was visible as a low mound in a grass field to the east of the road. The adjoining mound 'z' could not be seen. J D Hicks. Mortimer Group V1 barrow X is the same as  Greenwell barrow 1. Present location of finds Greenwell Collection, British Museum. Ref Mortimer '40 years' p.118. Greenwell 'British Barrows' P.135 <3>  (: SE 82195940, B: SE 82195943) Tumuli (NR). A: BA barrow, excavated by Greenwell in 1868, about 70ft diam; later extended to 94ft; used as AS cemetery; 3ft high. BA barrow contained two cremations, one in large central grave, the other in deposit of black earth with bone pin with large eye. Possible third burial with 'Beaker' fragment, stone axe and flints, thumb scrapers but no bones. Two pelvic bones of pig (?) in mound. 71 AS burials excavated, mostly on BA mound sometimes in  rows about 3ft apart; those beyond mound in graves. In varying positions including crouched burials; charcoal with most bodies. Finds:  4 bronze thread boxes, two gold pendants, brooches, buckles, beads, knives, scramasax, hone-stone and bronze bowl. Burials dated to 7th century. Most finds presented to York Museum, 1873 <4> Cross reference SMR 4212 AS cemetery ( one number allocated for the BA round barrow and one for the AS cemetery ) <5>  Scheduled amendment, National Monument Number 21058, Monument name and Scheduled area unchanged <6> Photocopied Article <7> Photocopied Article <8> Scheduled Monument Consent  to carry out a Geophysical Survey within the Scheduleing area of the Round Barrow <9> The monument includes a round barrow, situated 110 metres south-west of the Uncleby Wold Barn farm, and which is part of a large and dispersed group of barrows on the Wolds in this area. The mound is of earthen construction, twenty-eight metres in diameter, and 0.9 metres high. In common with the other barrows in this area, the original mound was surrounded by a ditch, though this is not visible and now survives as a buried feature. Antiquarian excavations in the nineteenth century showed that this mound was originally constructed in the Bronze Age but was extended in the Saxon period to create a burial mound for at least seventy-one individuals, who were buried with associated grave goods <10>

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW 700m S OF LOW FARM (M40)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Inhumation accompanied by flint knife, disc of baked clay, yellow ochre, boar's tusks, etc, at ground level just S of centre. Lower jaw of inhumation placed on chest and small ornamented food vessel inserted in upper jaw. Primary crouched inhumation, several human and animal bones scattered above and below, contained in grave. Boar's tusk, many animal bones, scattered throughout mound. A plough-levelled round barrow excavated in 1865 by Mortimer (his barrow 40). As he dug down through the centre of the mound, uncovered 2 separate inhumations. The first was a crouched inhumation, apparently lying on the old ground surface (Mortimer is not totally clear on this point). The skeleton was accompanied by numerous objects. 2 yellow quartz pebbles lay close above the left hand; a pig scapula lay over the right elbow; behind the skull were two lumps of yellow ochre, a flint knife and a perforated clay disc; in front of the skull were pieces of 2 boar's tusks; the skeleton's lower jaw had been removed and replaced by a small Food Vessel , which had two holes drilled through it. The lower jaw was nearby, lying on the skeleton's chest. Among the fill of the Food Vessel were some animal bones, while part of a pig skull and a flint scraper lay separately nearby. 5 feet north of this burial was a grave measuring 8 feet by 4 feet, and 4 feet deep. The bottom of the grave was covered by a layer some 8 inches thick comprising loose gravel and soil, and containing some human and animal bones. Resting on this layer was a crouched inhumation, at the feet of which was a human skull, minus lower jaw, resting on some human arm and leg bones, below which was the lower jaw. Scattered throughout the remainder of the grave fill were human and animal bones, the latter including pig, ox and sheep or goat.
Site_description: <site summary>:  Barrow 40, 60ft diam, 15ins high, excavated 1865.

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW 350m SE OF LOW FARM (MC52)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Note although 6 individuals were interred here, only three were accompanied by grave goods. this included a double grave where one had gg and the other did not. Flint tools - esp knives were common. No pots were noted
Site_description: CDG added. Barrow C52 had an infilled encircling ditch 77 ft diam, 6 ft wide at the top, 1 1/2 ft at the bottom and 2 1/2 ft deep. Six primary inhumations with associated finds of a flint dagger and knives, a jet button and bronze pricker point were noted

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW 420m SW OF LOW FARM (MC55)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Excavated in 1872, it contained a central semi-circular grave with a primary crouched inhumation accompanied by 2 flint flakes. In the NW quadrant of the mound, an oval grave also contained a crouched inhumation, in what appeared to have been a wooden cist/ coffin. A splinter of animal bone and an urn fragment were found in the central grave
Site_description: <site summary>: . Barrow C55, had a shallow encircling ditch 30 yds in diameter.

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW 400m SW OF LOW FARM (MC54)
Site_summary: <gg summary>:  C54 contained primary inhumation near centre at base of mound, accompanied by food vessel. Oval hole 5 ft to E filled with  black, greasy-looking soil. Flint knife, broad kidney-shaped grit-stone boulder rubbed to obtuse face each end, found in mound
Site_description: Barrow . Opened 23rd Sept 1872, about 16m in diameter

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Site of a Bronze Age round barrow, excavated in 1873 and found to contain a crouched male inhumation accompanied by a jet button, flint knife and crushed beaker.
Site_description: SE 9624 5883 Garton Slack Barrow MC61. Opened in 1873, much reduced by ploughing. A central grave contained the skeleton of a male with accompanying garve goods of a jet button, a flint knife, and a beaker. Six disc-shaped excavatios had been scooped in the subsoil, but no finds present. <1> Barrow C61 was only just discernible when excavated in 1873. A primary crouched inhumation accompanied by a jet button, a flitn knife and crushed beaker were seen. Beaker - group N2 (c) from Barrow C61, in Hull Museums, Acc 205.42. Site under plough for many years and no trace survives. <2> Round Barrow, September 1873. Before excavation barrow had been reduced to level of surrounding ground. Central rectangular grave 7'x5_', 3' deep. Male inhumation on grave floor, with Jet Button (2689:42) on left side of chest. A beaker (205:42) at pelvis, and flint knife (2686:42) at shoulder. Around grave, six possible ritual pits, contained only black soil - scooped into subsoil. <3> Barrow C61 was only just discernible when excavated in 1873. A primary crouched inhumation accompanied by a jet button, a flint knife and crushed beaker were seen. <4>

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Bronze Age round barrow excavated by Mortimer in 1873, found to contain four graves and grave goods. Note there was actually a total of five burials but only 3 were accompanied by grave goods. Two subadults lacked them. Three beakers. In Hull Museum, Acc No 183-42; 196-42; 189-42.
Site_description: Garton Slack Barrow C63. Opened by Mortimer in 1873; remains extremely slight. Barrow encircled by ring ditch, 55ft diameter, 3_, and contained four graves, two of which were without internment. Near the centre lay an internment accompanied by an incense cup and a flint knife or spearhead. To the north lay a grave containing a heap of bones which had been deliberately broken before internment. Beneath, on the grave floor, occurred a skeleton accompanied by a beaker. <1> Barrow C63, only just discernible, had an infilled encircling ditch 5ft in diameter. 7ft wide at the top, 1_ at the bottom and 3_ ft deep. Excavated in 1873, it contained four graves, one of which, 'A' contained only animal bones and a piece of worked stone. Two heaps of human bones overlay the burials in grave 'C', one of which lay on its chest. There were also considerable quantities of burnt wood in the grave. A drinking cup accompanied three of the inhumations. Other grave goods include a bone pin, polished blade flint axe, flint knife and flakes, and remains of a decayed bronze pricker: none were found in grave 'D'. Three beakers in Hull Museum Acc No. 183-42, 196-42 and 189-42. <2> Ditch enclosing barrow, diam 55", 7" wide at top, 1" at base, 3_ deep. Four Graves: A) At south - 8_" by 4_", 2_" deep contained only bones of Red Deer and stone with worked hollow. B) Near centre - 6" x 4_", 4" deepm on floor, crouched adult inhumation with beaker and flint knife. Decayed wood and 'putty' substance near foot and skull. C) North-East of centre - 6_" x 6", 4_" deep, on floor of grave at northern end, one adult crouched inhumation, female with beaker and bronze pricker. <3> Pastscape Website descrption. <4>

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW 750m S OF LOW FARM (M74)
Site_summary: There were three burials (adult female, infant and a sub-adult), but only the subadult was accompanied by any grave goods
Site_description: CDg added. Barrow 74, c.14ins high much reduced by ploughing. Three  crouched inhumations were seen. Other finds were a food vessel  and numerous flint implements. Excavated between 5th & 12th September 1988.

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW 500m S OF LOW FARM (M76)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: contained primary urned cremation near centre. Upper portion of urn removed by plough. No further finds made. Urn is a Collared Urn
Site_description: <Site summary>:  Barrow 76, sited on natural eminence, only just discernible. Excavated 1866 by Mortimer

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Site of Bronze Age round barrow (M107), opened in 1867 and found to contain five burials and grave goods. Only two of the burials were accompanied by grave goods though and one in particular had a rich set of objects.Three oval graves, A, C and F, each contained a primary crouched  inhumation; grave D contained only peat soil. Grave E, partly in the ditch contained a secondary crouched inhumation equipped in bronze and accompanied by a bronze knife - dagger and three curved pieces of bronze.  Fragments of burnt wood were noticed in most of the graves
Site_description: Opened by Mortimer in 1867; no longer visible. Revealed a ring ditch, 35ft.diameter, at the centre of which lay a large grave containing the detached bones of an adult male. The remains of a second occurred in a grave to the east, with those of a female and an infant nearby. A secondary internment in a grave cut into the ring ditch was accompanied by a bronze dagger with bone pommel together with three semi-circular shaped, decorated strips. <1> SE 9695 5798, Barrow 107, almost abliterated and about 10 ins high, was excavated in 1867. Within a filled in encircling ditch of 35ft diameter, a large grave, B, near the centre contained a dismembered inhumation, also contained fragment of Ox leg bone. Three oval graves A, C and F each contained a primary crouched inhumation; grave D contained only peat soil. Grave E, partly in the ditch contained a secondary crouched inhumation equipped in bronze and accompanied by a bronze knife - dagger and three curved pieces of bronze. Fragments of burnt wood were noticed in most of the graves. The barrow has been under plough for many years and no surface trace of it survives. See LibraryLink associated files for diagram of graves. <2> 'Reduced to 10" height by ploughing at the time of excavation; diameter of 35' within encircling ditch. Central grave robbed but contained scattered male inhumation. To the north of centre, an oval grave scooped 8" into old ground surface contained crouched adult male inhumation; unaccompanied. Similar grave to east of centre contained female adult inhumation, unaccompanied. To east of a small scopp in old ground surface contained inhumation of a child. Oval grave 5' by 8' and 2_' deep cut into ditch and therefore secondary; contained crouched adult inhumation accompanied by bronze dagger with bone pommel and rivet ornament and strip of ornamented bronze (referred to by Ashbee as a bracelet). No longer visible.' <3> Three aerial photograph showing barrows, dyke and Craike Hill settlement site. <4> There has also been two finds of bronze cuffs with tracer decoration from Bridlington and Garton Slack, barrow 107 with a flat bronze dagger. <5> Pastscape Website Record, from 2011. <6>

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW 500m SE OF LOW FARM (MC51)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Remains of four individuals were recovered but only two were associated with grave goods and in this case they both shared a single pot in a double grave!Two primary crouched inhumations, and scattered remains of another burial were seen in the mound; a cremation was found in the ditch on the N side of the barrow. Other finds were a crushed food vessel
Site_description: <Site summary>: . Barrow C51 was opened over 13th & 14th September, 1872, and is situated in a low natural chalk ridge. It had an infilled encircling ditch, 14 yds N-S x 10 yds, 7 ft wide at the top, 2 ft at the bottom and 3 1/2 ft deep.

Site_summary: Construction work at Driffield areodrome in 1938 revealed a small Iron Age cemetery of 75 square barrows containing the remains of inhumations, associated vessels, animal bone and other finds.<gg_summary, Eastburn Aerodrome>: Whimster (1981) summarises the evidence as follows: A cemetery of c.75 barrows excavated in advance of the construction of Eastburn airfield in 1938. Records of individual burials are very poor, although it appears that the majority of graves contained conventionally crouched skeletons, but that these were surrounded by circular rather than square enclosures. The cemetery had already been ploughed flat at the time of its excavation and destruction.Associated objects: 2 (possibly 3) involuted brooches; 4 pottery vessels; iron spearhead; short iron sword (in wooden scabbard); bronze bracelet; bronze toggle; 2 fragments of bronze tube (?shield fittings); fragment of sheet bronze with an embossed ring (?shield fittings); fragments of inlay (from ?brooch).Given the vagaries involved in terms of quantifying burials and grave goods, most of the above items are entered within one grave record. However, Sheppard provides further details about the objects and includes occasional titbits about their association with human remains. Separate graves are allocated where details about the relationship between an object and a body are given.Sheppard (1939, 42) also notes that: 'The other objects are various pieces of iron pyrites such as occur in the natural state in the chalk, and probably their appearance among the burials is purely accidental, though on the other hand, as Mortimer suggests, there is a possibility they may have been used for "strike-a-lights". Given the poor contextual details for these finds, they are not recorded as gg here.
Site_description: <NRHE site description>: Removal of surface soil prior to the construction of a hangar at Eastburn Aerodrome, exposed fifty TA graves, and afurther twenty-five a short distance to the E, a year later (area TA 004565 - sited from plan). Each grave 3-4 ft across and containing one, sometimes two inhumations, had a shallow encircling ditch. An iron brooch of fibula of the involuted or Beckley type, and part of another, was found at the earlier site. At the later site, these graves had an associated vessel (see illus) each containing a small pig bone, and a decorated bronze bracelet was found on the arm of a female inhumation. Further finds include the lower portion of an IA vessel, a leaf-shaped spearhead, two bronze tubes, and iron sword 28 ins long. (See plan). (1)The distinctive British La Tene metalwork is unlikely to be earlier than the 2nd c and much of it is probably of the 1st c BC. (2)

Site_summary: <gg summary>: No burial found in 1870 though a vessel  discovered in a cottage was reputed to have come from this site. Fieldwalking in 1989 produced no finds.The pot in question was an elaborate  Food Vessel but cannot be proven to be directly associated with a burial as Mortimer just found a hole and a few pieces of flint from the earlier disturbance, but no body
Site_description: <Site summary>: Round barrow first opened in 1845 and then by Mortimer in 1870. when it measured 3' high and 90' in diameter

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Opened by Mortimer in 1870. Contained a central egg-shaped grave with human and animal bones.
Site_description: <Site summary>: Part of a more extensive barrow cemetery and situated only 200m NE of another one. Barrow No. C 36 opened in 1870. In the centre was an egg-shaped grave 11' x 6' x 5' with narrow end to the west. Close to the west end of this and 2 1/2' down was a heap of bones, consisting of 3 ribs, probably belonging to a deer, 11 ribs of an ox, and an adult fibula and bones of a human foot. At the same level, about three feet south were portions of the skull of an old person. (2)

Site_summary: <gg summary>: All three burials were accompanied by grave goods, including Collard Urns, an unusual comb, awl and pricker
Site_description: <Site summary>: Opened by Mortimer in 1870 when it measured 0.35m high and 27m  diameter. A contracted inhumation with finds was found near the centre. Other cremations and urns were also found

Site_name_other: Kelleythorpe or Driffield barrow ROUND BARROW (MC38) & ANGLO SAXON CEMETERY, KELLEYTHORPE
Site_summary: A single Bronze Age round barrow with numerous associated Anglo-Saxon inhumations. Now destroyed.<gg summary>: This barrow contained at least five prehistoric burials that were buried over an extensive time-frame. There is one possible Early Neolithic burial, a Beaker burial and 2 EBA (inc Food Vessel) burials!Note this site includes the amazing Adult inhumation crouched on left side with head at E; dagger at back; beaker at feet; bracer on right forearm; hawk's head in front of body
Site_description: Ante 1851 quantities of bones said to have been ploughed up on site of barrow on a farm called Kelleythorpe. Excavations in this year by Londesborough uncovered a primary cist burial in the center, and two other internments of Beaker and Bronze Age date. 7 other skeletons, representing secondary internments of Anglo-Saxon date, also found. Further excavations by Mortimer in 1870 and 1872 uncovered 27 further A/S inhumations and one BA burial, with accompanying grave goods. <1> YAS number 9190 has two cards with different names but I have assumed that they both refer to Barrow C38. <2> The Greet's, Driffield. A barrow 4' high and situated in a field called the Greets was opened by Lord Londesborough in 1851. It contained the remains of ten skeletons, a small bronze dagger, 3 large amber beads, a beaker and a large mass of linen. RB/Saxon pottery was also found at a considerable depth. In 1870 and 1872, Mortimer discovered 28 bodies with relics and 2 cremations and a further 13 interments in 1887. The mound had first been used as an early BA burial site with secondary interments in the early Medieval period. The barrow has been destroyed. <3> Photocopied extract inc. illustration. <4> TA 017 567 "Site of Tumulus", Mortimer barrow 138 (C38?). Excavated by Londesborough in 1851, Mortimer in 1870. Destroyed by railway, 1887. The mound contained a large stone cist. There were fifty-one inhumations and two cremations in all, five being of Bronze Age date, the others Anglian secondary burials with many iron and bronze grave goods dateable to the 6th-7th centuries AD. <5> RCHM print-out. <6> Photocopied extract and illustrations. <7> Contemporary with these early axes in Yorkshire (c.1750-1600 BC) would be the tanged dagger and the gold headed rivets with the Kelleythorpe cist burial near Driffield. <8> Photocopied entry. <9> Photocopied extract. <10> Photocopied extract of a photograph showing the Silver Type D Bracteate from Kelleythorpe, Driffield. <11> Summary of round barrow at Kelleythorpe. <12> Site mentioned in 'A Comparative Study of 'Continuity' Cemeteries in Yorkshire' by Malin Holst. <13>

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Although seven individuals were buried here (inc. 3 sets of double burials) two individuals shared a Food Vessel and 2 other individuals lacked grave goods . contained two graves; (A) contained primary cremation, primary inhumation accompanied by food vessel, several flint chips. Two pieces of animal bone in grave. (B) at right angles, contained two primary crouched inhumations, accompanied by food vessel. Fragments human skull, few bones, in grave. To the S two secondary crouched inhumations, accompanied by food vessel partly destroyed by plough.
Site_description: <site summary>:  Barrow C40, 12 ins high, spread by ploughing. Excavated March 1871,

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Three burials but the disarticulated sub-adult lacked grave goods.At the centre was an oval grave containing the crouched burial of a female of middle age. Close to the face was a small rudely ornamented vase resembling an incense cup. Near the crown of the head was a Food vessel. Below at a depth of 6' was the skeleton of a man and nearby the remains of a pig. Arm and hand bones and part of a skull were nearby. (2)
Site_description: <Site summary>: This barrow, (No C.41) when opened in 1871, was almost ploughed level.

Site_name_other: BOWL BARROW W OF DRIFFIELD BECK, 220M SW KING'S MILL (MC50)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: 16 feet north of the centre at the east end were found many portions of a food vessel, ox bones and a barbed arrowhead.
Site_description: <Site summary>: . Situated c. 500m to the N of other barrows in the vicinity, on S side of the Driffield Beck stream. arrow No. C 50 was opened by Lord Londesborough in 1851 It was about 7-8 feet high and 60 feet in diameter. Near the centre was a contracted skeleton with a flint knife. Mortimer opened the mound in 1872; according to him it was largely a natural formation of chalk gravel over clay in the form of a long barrow 90ft long, 51ft across the west end and 66 feet across the east end, which was the only part that had been a little artificially raised. 16 feet north of the centre at the east end were found many portions of a food vessel, ox bones and a barbed arrowhead.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: A central oval grave contained a crouched inhumation. Further inhumations af adults and children were also found along with urn fragments and flintNote only one individual - an infant less than 3 years old - was accompanied by grave goods (a Food Vessel and a flake)
Site_description: <site summary>: Opened by Mortimer in 1873 whem it measured 182 high and 70' in diameter.

Site_name_other: SITE OF ROUND BARROW (MC58) Springwell Farm, Little Driffield
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Opened by Mortimer in 1873 when the barrow had almost been levelled. Remains of a cremation were found near the centre and a flint knife was found some distance away. The vessel is Collared Urn. Round barrow scheduled as "Eastern bowl barrow of a pair, 350m south east of Springwell Farm". Excavated in 1873, the barrow contained an urned cremation. The mound contained Roman and later pottery, animal bone, bronze and iron pieces.Cremation with flint knife with Collared urn
Site_description: <site summary>: Barrow C58 or Springwell Farm, Little Driffield, contained an urned cremation in shallow hole below centre of mound. Large flint flake.  Roman and later pottery, pieces animal bone, a thin piece of bronze and pieces of corroded iron were in the mound. The urn is described as a cinerary urn but possibly a Collared Urn

Site_summary: <gg summary>: There were 8 burials in this barrow but only 4 were associated with grave goods and in 1 case a Food Vessel was shared by two children Note four children were buried in this barrow and the rest, with the exception of one adult female, were sub-adults. So this is a barrow where those that died young predominantly were buried Grave goods mainly flint knives and Food Vessels
Site_description: <site summary>: Barrow C67; no mound visible, slight natural elevation suggested probable site of burials; excavated in May 1874. Eight inhumations excavated; seven contained in five graves. One grave contained primary crouched inhumation accompanied by three small flint knives, or spearheads. Three food vessels also in graves. Inhumation overlying grave, disturbed by plough

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW, 1km NNW OF EASTBURN WARREN FARM (M79)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Although there was a minimum of 8 individuals buried here, only 4 were accompanied by grave goods. Grave goods quite modes - flakes, pebble, animal bone although a FV and axehead (only a splinter)  also recovered There could be a primary Neolithic burial & later EBA burials
Site_description: Part of a much more extensive barrow cemetery, and situated less than 200m from other barrows. A round barrow, Mortimer's Barrow 79, excavated by him in 1866. In 1850-51, the eastern side of the barrow up to its centre was, according to Mortimer, "carted away to form a new road, consequently all the chief interments were destroyed". A witness (or participant) recalled six or seven skeletons being found. By 1866, the mound survived to a maximum height of 5 feet, but Mortimer estimated its original dimensions to have been 120 feet in diameter and 10 feet high. The quarrying of 1850-1 had apparently reached a depth of 6 feet below the original surface, completely destroying the central area. 10 feet south of the centre, and within the mound, 2.5 feet above the original surface, was an unaccompanied inhumation. 12 feet southwest of centre, and 2 feet above the original surface was a crouched child inhumation with "food-vase". 23 feet south of the centre were 3 further inhumations, one with a flint flake plus a piece of stone which had been used either as a hammer or had been worked to a cutting edge. One of these inhumations lacked its skull, while a second had other bones missing. 19 feet west of centre and 20 inches above the surface was another crouched adult inhumation. 35 feet southwest of centre and at the foot of the mound was the remains of an adult cremation. Another was nearby, but 30 feet from the centre. Beneath the mound was a circular ditch about 4 feet deep, indicating at least two construction phases for the monument. Animal bones were recovered from within the mound, while a single fragment of a polished greenstone axe was beneath the mound. In 1973, the Ordnance Survey reported that although the barrow was heavily ploughed down, the western half was still visible above ground.

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW, 1km NNW OF EASTBURN WARREN FARM (M80)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Note two distinct phases of use - the first in the Early Neolithic with a crematorium. Although  at least six individuals were interred, all lacked grave good directly associated with them. Only two individuals in total (both Beaker in date) were accompanied by grave goods
Site_description: <site summary>: . A round or squashed oval barrow of Neolithic origin, excavated in 1866 by Mortimer, when it measured 32m in diameter and up to 1m high. In 1973, the Ordnance Survey described it as being well spread by ploughing, but still a prominent feature. Beneath the mound was a linear feature (described by Mortimer as a "trough") aligned east west and defined by low banks of turf. Within it were quantities of burnt gravel, earth and flint plus burnt human bones. A pit at its eastern end was marked by two boulders and contained burnt material including charcoal. Another pit at the western end had a similar fill but included cremated human bone. 3 further pits beneath the mound also contained gravel, chalk and "dark matter". Roughly central within the trough was an oval grave pit containing the crouched inhumation of a young male with a Beaker at its feet. Mortimer regarded this burial as predating the "trough", but the reverse seems more likely.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Early Neolithic squashed oval barrow with crematorium etc; then augmented in the Beaker period and made into round barrow
Site_description: <site summary>: Barrow 81 has Neolithic origins. Excavated in 1866-7 by Mortimer. At the time, the mound was 25m in diameter and up to 0.5m high. In 1973, the Ordnance Survey noted that it was "still discernible on the ground as a large ground swelling, but its limits are undefinable". The main feature beneath the mound was a "trough" (Mortimer) or "crematorium" (Kinnes), which survived for a length of 26 feet northwest-southeast, and comprised two parallel banks of gravel, the area between which was filled with burnt gravel, charcoal, and "a continuous stratum of incinerated adult and juvenile bones". Also at the bottom of this deposit were some Early Neolithic bowl sherds. The northwest end of this feature appears to have been cut by an oval pit which contained the remains of several inhumations, one with a jet bead and another with a beaker. Further Beaker sherds were also with one of the interments. On or just above the original ground surface, roughly central and to the west of the trough was a deposit of human bones including an adult and a child. Also present was a complete articulated foot, and nearby was a flint knife. On the eastern side of the trough was a shallow pit which contained further Early Neolithic bowl sherds. South of the centre was a larger oval grave pit containing a crouched female inhumation complete except for one of its feet, in place of which were two worked flints. A bone pin was behind the head and a flint scraper near the teeth.Classified as crematorium barrow, as it had remains of cremation trench, 8m long, contained primary cremations in continuous stratum of incinerated human bones from end to end

Site_summary: <gg summary>:  Near central grave 11ft diam at top, 4ft 8ins deep with sloping sides, contained two primary cremations, one accompanied by food vessel; also primary crouched inhumation, bones of foot close by. At bottom, remains of wooden trough-shaped receptacle 2ft long, 1ft wide. Four secondary crouched inhumations, each in grave ; one accompanied by two flint flakes. Grave 'I', also contained secondary cremation, fragments of fine string, two portions woven and knitted texture. Secondary crouched inhumation of child in mound at 'A'. two secondary cremations, each in hole at 'B'.Note a total of ten burials were placed in this barrow but only five were accompanied by grave goods.  Grave goods mainly flint flakes, animal bone, although a wooden trough also recovered and a Food Vessel and Vase urn
Site_description: <site summary>: Barrow 82, 0.65m high, 33m  N-S, 30 m E-W, excavated 1867, 1874.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Round barrow identified from aerial photographs. Excavated by Mortimer in 1868 and 1872.It may have had Neolithic origins as Peterborough Ware was found; also EBA burials and indeed later use in Saxon times with Saxon times. A MNI of 8 Neolithic-EBA burials but only 6 were accompanied by grave goods Three bone pins found with infants - presumably used to fasten shroud or wrapping around them. One FV
Site_description: Garton Slack, Barrow 112. Opened by Mortimer in 1868 and 1872. Diameter 70ft, height 2 ft; had been reduced by ploughing. The central area was enclosed by a ditch 40ft diameter, 9ft wide, at the centre of which occured a shallow grave dug into the subsoil. This contained an adult inhumation with an infant beneath. To the E and W were the remains of a further two adults inhumations, associated with the fragments of food vessel. From the upper levels of the mound were found the graves of three infants each associated with a bone pin for wrapping up a shroud (?). In the upper level of the ditch occured four burials, three of which were assigned an A/S date. At its re-opening in 1872 another skeleton was found on the E margin of the mound immediately below the surface. Probably A/S in date. <1> Round Barrow (M. No. 112). Opened April 1868. Description: 20' diameter with encircling ditch 10' wide; reduced to 2' high and extended to 70' diameter at time of excavation. The 70' diameter must relate to the Anglo-Saxon stage of this barrow. 1)Burial at centre in grave 8"-10" below old ground surface - crouched inhumation of adult with infant. Three infant inhumations, two to north of 1), one to south and on old ground surface or 6" below, each accompanied by a bone pin (345:45:3). Fourth bone pin from surface (345:42:4). 5) & 6) Two disturbed adult inhumations to either side of 1); these accompanied by burnt bone, punch shaped flint (338: 42:117) and sherd of Secondary Neolithic (Peterborough) pottery (179:42). Near centre were sherds of three coarse vessels, possibly Cinerary Urns (678:42). M. suggests 5) and 6) disturbed by digging for rabbits but they are on same level as 1) and may preceed it. In the ditch fill were four Anglo-Saxon burials, one accompanied by iron knife and sharpening iron. Another Anglo-Saxon inhumation, unaccompanied, occured outside ditch but within 70' diameter. <2> Barrow 112, 70ft diameter, 2ft high, excavated 1868, 1872. Contained circular ditch 40ft diameter, 9ft wide at top, 2ft at bottom, 5ft deep, enclosing three small graves (No. 1-3) (see illus) each containing infant and bone pin. Primary crouched inhumation (No. 6) in shallow grave near centre, flanked by recently disturbed inhumations; decayed remains of infant underneath. Remains of food-vessel, burnt bone, white punch-shaped flint, nearby. Four secondary inhumations and cremation ("a") in upper part of ditch. A/S inhumation (No 8) accompanied by two corroded iron objects, probably knife and sharpening iron No 5 & 7). Probably A/S. Also (No 9) a crouched inhumation just outside ditch. Site of barrow now under plough, all traces obliterated. <3> "Tumulus (site of)" printed and shown on OS 25" map. <4> Aerial photograph showing linear features, round and square barrows, Kirkburn. <5> Garton Slack II. Inhumation burial(s), secondary in barrow. Y 161 NW. SE 950610. Mortimer (1906), pp 245-46. VCH, II, 80-81. 1868 Mortimer excavated a barrow 70' diameter, 2' high, on a natural rise. 4 secondary burials had been made in the ditch surrounding the barrow when it was three parts filled. One was of a young child, buried in a crouch position, near a few burnt bones of a young person; the second was an adult, head SE, with the legs bent back from the knees; the third, also an adult, was on the right side, head to the W, both knees bent up, and hands in front of the breast. 16" NW of the skull were traces of the bones of an infant. None of these had any relics, and were c. 18" deep from the surface, 10" into the trench.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Note the Ciollared Urns from this barrow and the one adjacent (G84) may have bee made by the same pottery -worth checking. This is part of a more extensive barrow cemetery. This barrow is 15m in diameter and 1.2m high. Two urned cremations were found upright in small pits in the mound. Both were off-centre and in Collared Urns

<gg summary>: part of barrow cemetery and situated very close to M83 or lXXXIII and indeed Greenwell suggests that the pots from both of these barrows (es Collared Urns) were made by the same potter's hand.This barrow had several cremations that were burnt in situ - it could be that some were Neolithic? Check. The barrow is 11m in diameter and 0.6m high. But it seems that they were accompanied by EBA vessels directly next to them so this could be a very localised micro-traditionFood Vessels and Collared Urns

<gg summary>part of a more extensive cemetery. Check whether pots from all these barrows show many similarities. This barrow is 14m in diameter and 0.6m high. A pile of cremated bones representing in situ cremations - both of children; 2 Collared Urns were set next to them (one on top of the other)

<gg summary>: Part of a larger barrow cemetery. This is the 4th barrow in the group. It contained an adult male who had been burnt in situ in the barrow but not so completely. All the bones and therefore the skeleton were still in the original position, crouched on right side and with knees drawn towards the head. Accompanied by a Collared Urn in front of face
Site_description: <site summary>: barrow 17m in diameter and 1.4m high

Site_name_other: TWO ROUND BARROWS (G88, G89) (G89 or LXXXIX)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: G89 is a largish barrow with several interments, 24.3m in diameter and 1.2m high. Earth and chalk layers. the mound was increased in size on at least one or more occasions. There are a lot of burials in here! Note two EBA ones are in an extended position and were buried as a pair in the central grave - unusual macehead and Collared urns and several incense cups. Note there was a  MNI of 11 individuals buried here but all bar one were accompanied by grave goods. There is perhaps a slight over-representation of incense cups from here. Some Neolithic pottery was kicking around here suggesting Early Neo activity in the vicinity or the fact that this barrow began its life in the ENEOAll sorts of interesting grave goods and a surfeit of incense cups and 2 CUNo grave goods with Barrow G88
Site_description: <site summary>: Note this monument number has been assigned to two barrows - G88 and G89. G88 - Apparently according to Greenwell, this part of the cluster was more associated with inhumation rather than cremation practices so that would be worth checking. G88 was nearly 18m in diameter and 0.6m high and has inhumation in central grave - a skull was placed above him. Unless this can be classed as a grave good, the burial was otherwise unaccompanied.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Part of wider cemetery. Barrow that is 14m in diameter and 0.3m high. This is of interest - as the pots from here are particularly well-made, exquisite and real works of art. several individuals from here. One miniature cup with lid that has resemblance to Folkton Drums

Part of extensive barrow cemetery  this one had a probably decayed inhumation with a flat rubber or polisher. <gg summary>: Previous antiquarian trench had disturbed at least five burials.  Three of the burials in the central grave were disturbed. Also an adult male in central grave without goods. An adult female with Beakers x 2 and a child with a Beaker in central grave - all the others lacked grave goods (or they had been disturbed or removed during the ancient furtlings (pre-Greenwell ones))

<gg summary>: part of more extensive cemetery. This one is pretty large and 25m in diameter but only had 1 burial - that of a strongly-built young adult male. Food Vessel, finely flaked flint knife at head, Note the Food Vessel in this barrow is very much like the one in the adjacent barrow (CIII)
Situated just a little to the west of GCII (note there are also similarities in the Food Vessels with this one). Large barrow 24m in diameter and 1.2m high.
Barrow 18m in diameter and 0.7m high. It had been previously disturbed prior to Greenwell's excavations but there was one undisturbed inhumation of a young woman with ox bonesPottery just sherds

<gg summary>: Barrow CVIII is close by and adjoining CVII. and is 12.5m in diameter and 0.3m high. Again it had also been disturbed prior to Greenwell's excavation. Disarticulated bone of a adult and a young person were found with a broken Collared Urn

Part of wider barrow cemetery excavated by Greenwell. This was 17m in diameter and 0.7m high. Earth mound. At centre of mound on natural surface were the remains of a child burnt in situ in pyre, accompanied by a Collared Urn and a burnt bone pin made from the wing bone of a bird.

Barrow CX excavated by Greenwell. It was 17.6m in diameter and 0.6m high and made of earth and chalk. Three burials of adult males, some with grave goods in this barrowAxehead from mound material directly above one of the male inhumations

Barrow CXI was 17m in diameter and 0.4m high and made of earth and chalk. Very complex series of burials here. There were 7 individuals but two of them lacked grave goods. Note that 4 individuals were buried directly on the ground surface

<gg summary>: Plough-damaged barrow c. 13m in diameter. Decayed burials with grave goods. Here two older females (both over 40 years old) were placed with disarticulated remains of children (possibly redeposited from elsewhere?). Also there was a pit nearly 1m in diameter and 1m deep, 3m SW of centre with signs of burning and containing a considerable quantity of charcoal and burnt flint. Flint knife and scraper; also bronze awl - rather modest grave goods. No discernible pots but a few potsherds found

<gg summary>: Small barrow less than 14m in diameter and 0.5m high. Made of earth and chalk. Grave on ground surface with adult male and Beaker. At centre was a female with a Food Vessel ; there were some disturbed human bones above this burial that may have been disturbed by its insertion as they were accompanied by several fragments of a Beaker. Another grave was in the centre below this disturbed burial with an old male and remains of wood under body. Another large grave next to this had an adult male also paced on wooden bier.  There was another burial of an adult male below this at the bottom of the grave but with no grave goods although animal bones were placed in grave fill - ovicaprid.

<gg summaery>: Barrow that is 18m in diameter and 0.6m high and made of earth and chalk.  Four individuals buried here ; barrow slightly plough disturbed. Note two of the burials - a child c. 8 and a woman c middle aged lacked visible grave goods Food Vessel at face of child and Collared Urn contains a cremation
<gg summary>: some interesting reburial acts in it including skull fiddling etc.Note that Beaker, Food Vessel and Collared Urn vessels all came from this barrow
Site_description: <site summary>: Very plough flattened barrow - CXV. Originally 18m in diameter but only 0.3m high

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Barrow CXVI at Kiplington racec ourse. What is intriguing is that a disarticulated adult male had his skull missing - but in adjacent barrow G115  or CXV a headless aduilt male had the skull of a different individual placed in his knees. Were parts of human being moved across adjacent barrows?Burial of female with Beaker

Barrow that is 16m in diameter and 0.8m high and made of earth, Note in the mound a number of potsherds of plain dark-coloured ware were found and these sound like there was Neolithic activity. Also found were bones of a small-sized horse (Neolithic?, if so intriguing) red-deer and pig and a very large dog (?wolf)Food Vessel
<gg summary>: Very flat barrow and only 0.15m high but 15m in diameter. One coffined body with Food Vessel found similar to previous barrow (G118)

<gg summary>: Partially excavated round barrow opened by Mortimer in 1876 revealing a food-vessel accompanying a cremation burial.Part of a more extensive barrow cemetery. Barrow C92, c  12m in diameter and 0.3m high. S of centre, few burnt bones of child (?) accompanied by remains of food vessel. Hole W of centre contained adult primary cremation, possibly few burnt bones of child. Above charcoal mixed with burnt soil. There were three individuals including a cremation of an adult but only 1 burials was accompanied by grave goods

<gg summary>: very little to go on but likely Goodmanham G117.Barrow situated close to G116. It was small, only 6m in diameter and 0,3m high. It had the burial of a female in a cist at the centre with a polished pig/boar tusk pendant at neck
Partially excavated round barrow opened by Mortimer in 1876.<gg summary>: cremation of young person with battle axe, flake & needle and a Collared Urn
Site_description: <site summary>: Barrow C89, about 14m diam, 0.35m high, originally encircled by trench. Central chalk rock-cut grave contained primary cremation placed in charcoal, accompanied by small food-vessel, three burnt flint flakes, fragments perforated axe-hammer, bone pin with hole in broad end

Site_summary: <gg summary>: A barrow once stood in the stack-yard at Old Sunderlandwick.  Browne's description states a tree-trunk coffin was found lying east to west containing three skeletons, having two skulls at E and one at W. The coffin, 6 ft long by 4 ft wide, contained no associated goods but in the earth around it were quantities of ashes

Site_name_other: SITE OF BARROW, S Brigham Ings river
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Excavation in the 1850s recovered a primary cremation and child inhumation. The barrow was opened by Messrs C & E Grantham in the mid 1850s, when half a large cinerary urn (probable  primary) cremations, and one associated with a child inhumation were recovered. Incense Cup, found inside a Collared Urn with a tooth of a wolf, from Barrow at Hutton Cranswick YAC 1851"
Site_description: <FURTHER INFO>Could this be Hutton Cranswik 1 - Isolated Bronze Age barrow (called Corps Landing) immediately on S side of Brigham Ings river. A Bronze Age round barrow is visible as an earthwork and cropmark on air photographs

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Opened by Mortimer in 1875. Near the centre was a crouched burial with a food vessel (Abercromby T.1)
Site_description: <site summary>: Barrow C86 seemingly on own on S side of Driffied Trout river.  Barrow c. 26m in diameter and 0.65m high. close to the west side of the railway, opposite Poundsworth Mill. Resurveyed at 1/2500. This barrow has been considerably spread by rig and furrow ploughing and further reduced in height by the construction of a military block house on its summit. The only re-surveyable feature is a well defined earthern platform 0.5m high.Poundsworth Mill Barrow. A 25m diameter mound, in old pasture, was threatened by levelling operations and the removal of a World War II pillbox. Excavation in 1973 produced a food-vessel, fragments of human bone and a rich pre-barrow flint industry from the Mesolithic onwards

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Excavated by Yorks Antiquarian Club in 1849; published by Proctor in 1855.Burial 1: incense cup perforated with four rows of small holes, mouth upwards, containing human bones mixed with charcoal and sandBurial 2: a large and beautiful specimen of a (probably) British urned burial (Collared Urn), mouth upwards, much damaged on removal. It contained a small undecorated, roughly made vessel.Another potential burial including a perforated boar's tusk and an additional urn, for which there is little contextual detail and no direct mention of human remains, is not recorded here.
Site_description: <NRHE site description>: A barrow, adjoining road to Skerne and sea, 1/2 mile from Hutton Cranswick. (1)A barrow situated on the high road to Skerne was partly excavated by the Yorks Antiquarian Club in 1849. Covering about half an acre, it contained urns, cremations and other funeral relics.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Bronze Age round barrow opened by Mortimer in 1892 (278) with a a WWII pillbox built on the top of the extant barrow.Food vessels with cremations. . Flint flakes, three flint knife-like articles and a sherd were found. A previous opening had removed a cremation, portions of which could be seen. To the NW of the centre were three circular dish shaped holes, two of which contained burnt bones, the other burnt soil only. At about 2 ft SE of the central hole and 3 ft above the base of the barrow stood erect a small food vessel. It had been enclosed in a wooden coffin. No trace of a burial was found. Flat topped mound, may have been used as a moot hill
Site_description: A Bronze Age round barrow is visible as an earthwork on air photographs. The feature measures approximately 28m in diameter though adjacent medieval ploughing appears to have partially spread the feature. A Second World War pillbox is visible on its summit (UID 1547980). The feature is extant on the latest 2011 specialist oblique photography <9> A Second World War pillbox is visible as an extant structure on air photographs. The pillbox is situated on a Bronze Age round barrow (UID 79286). The feature is extant on the latest 2011 specialist oblique photography <10><site summary>: Howe Hill or barrow 278 sits seemingly on its own in a slightly isolate position. Nearest barrow is over 1.2km to the NW. Sits just on the S side of the Driffield Trout stream. When this barrow, known as Howe Hill, was opened in 1892 it had already been disturbed. Its diameter is roughly 23m and its height 2.4m, although it was probably c. 2m higher

Site_summary: Isolated Bronze Age barrow (called Corps Landing) immediately on S side of Brigham Ings river. A Bronze Age round barrow is visible as an earthwork and cropmark on air photographs. The barrow mound was visible as an earthwork on 1946 RAF vertical photography but appears to have been levelled on the latest 2008 vertical photography. Oblique photography taken in 1975 revealed the mound and outer ditch as a cropmark. Excavation in the 1950s recovered a primary cremation and child inhumation. The barrow was opened by Messrs C & E Grantham in the mid 1950s. The cremation was associated with a Collared Urn but the child inhumation lacked grave goods.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Crouched skeleton with several grave goods ; and a cremation nearby with shell & greenstone bodkin or awl point (actuallya  small tanged knife) . Inhumation burial of adult  with dog skull, chisel and urn
Site_description: <site summary>: This barrow sits in an isolated position on the north hillside of Ox Lands Dale. NE of Huggate. It was 12m in diameter and 0.45m high and surrounded by an infilled ditch. Blanch M2.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: . cremation of large adult with urn and flint flakes. Primary cremation deposit, three flint flakes, in hole W of centre. Primary cremation deposit, flint knife, burnt flint flakes, in grave S of centre. Empty crushed inverted cinerary urn N side of grave. Two cremations with grave goods
Site_description: <site summary>: Partially excavated round barrow opened by Mortimer in 1876. Part of a more extensive barrow cemetery. Barrow C90, 14m diam, 0.3m high.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Cremation with Food Vessel
Site_description: <site summary>: Partially excavated round barrow opened by Mortimer in 1876. About 18m in diameter

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Barrow C96, primary cremation deposit, few pieces of burnt wood, at base near centre. Two flint knives from remains of mound. Cremation with two flint knives immediately above

<gg summary>: Contained cremation in wood ashes, one piece of burnt bone stained green by decomposition of bronze object and base of disturbed urn. remation of adult  with bones stained green (copper pyre good?) and urn; cremation accompainied by cremated bones of a small animal
Site_description: <site summary>: Kirby Underdale. M215. Mortimer barrow 215. Round barrow partially excavated in 1882. Part of a more extensive barrow cemetery. Several barrows in a small cluster situated c. 200m apart from one another on the edge of Wayrham Dale scarp. Barrow 215, excavated 1882, of slight elevation

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Site of Bronze Age round barrow, excavated by Mortimer in 1882 and found to contain cremation and inhumation burials, along with grave goods.Beaker, Food Vessel and Collared Urns all came from here - interesting burial sequences in terms of temporality
Site_description: Huggate Wold Barrow 216. Opened by Mortimer in 1882 when it stood 2ft high, 35ft diameter. The central grave contained a collard urn half filled with calcined bones of an adult, on top of which were a flint spearhead and an object in jet. At a higher level lay the contracted skeleton of a child. The main internment occurred in a shallow depression scooped out in the centre of the grave, and consisted of the contracted skeleton of a large adult accompanied by a beaker. <1> Barrow 216, excavated 1882, 55ft diameter, 2ft high. Contained central grave with primary cremation, flint spearhead or knife, jet bead. Three inhumation in graves, one flexed with crushed food vessel, flint knife; two crouched, a child unaccompanied, a primary adult with fragments of drinking cup (long necked beaker). Two beakers, groups S1: FP In Hull Museum Accession Numbers 195.42, 240.42. No visible remains in arable field. Published survey (25") revised 30/1/73.<2>  Round Barrow (M216) SE 8403 5695, Huggate Wold Group. Diameter 55', 2' high, all excavated. Large oval grave in centee of barrow measuring 8' by 7' from apex of mound. In centre of grave, in shallow hollow (presumably on floor of grave) - adult crouched inhumation with a beaker, primary burial. 1_' above, west of the centre - contracted child's inhumation. 2' above base of grave  on NNE side of grave, cutting into undisturbed barrow - concealed inhumation with flint knife and remains of beaker. 1' below apex of mound, 4' above base of grave - urn half filled with burnt adult bones, on top of which was jet bead and flint knife. Barrow also contained secondary burials. Visited on 17/06/67, stood 3" high under crop. <3> Pastscape Website Record. <4>

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW, 400m NNW OF EAST GREENWICK FARM (M235) Huggate barrow (M235)
Site_summary: Mortimer barrow 235. Scheduled as Bowl barrow 400m NNW of East Greenwick Farm.<gg summary>: Decayed burial (possibly wrapped in cloth) with flint knife. No precise dating
Site_description: Barrow (Huggate) 235. 35ft in diameter and 16 inches high was excavated in 1882. An oval grave in the centre 18 inches deep, had a film od dark soil-like matter in the bottom on which there was a small flint knife 1 3/4 inches long, and two flint flakes. There was no trace of a burial, it probably having completely decayed. A number of flint flakes were in the mound. Under stubble and now only recognisable as a superficial ground swelling. Published survey (25") revised. <1> Huggate Wold Group. Round barrow (M. no. 235). Opened August 1882. Description: at time of excavation barrow had diameter of 35 feet and height of 16 inches. Central scooped grave 18 inches deep; film of dark soot-like matter covered the bottom from which came plano-convex flint knife (377:42). With it was a hand-struck flake, and a further hand-struck flake 12 inches NW of first. 17.6.67. JD Hicks. 6" high in wheat field. Present location of finds: Hull Museum. Ref: M. 308. <2> Scheduled monument ammendment. Scheduled area unchanged (see reference 4 below), monument name 'Bowl barrow 400m NNW of East Greenwick Farm'. National Monument number: 26573. <3> Although named as a schedule ammendment (see reference 3 above), this barrow was not previously on the SMR as scheduled and did not appear in the 1994 county list. <4> Scheduled monument description. <5>

Site_summary: Mortimer barrow 242. Scheduled as Bowl barrow on Huggate Pasture, 500m north of Pasture Dale Plantation.  One of a group of barrows on Huggate Pasture.<gg summary>: Note there were two burials in this barrow - one inhumtion and one cremation, but the cremation at the centre lacked grave goods. It was first excavated in 1851 by Silburn who found a 'battle-axe' and broken urn. Re-excavated by Mortimer in 1882 who found a disturbed inhumation, also the remains of a cremation. Numerous flint flakes, a barbed arrowhead, scrapers, 2 knives, slingstones, potsherds, etc were also found in the barrow.
Site_description: <site summary>: . Barrow 242 on Huggate Pasture. It is on top of a hill with two other barrows, c. 200m & 300m to the south-east. It was 18m diam, 0.9m high,

Site_summary: <gg summary>:  Central dish-shaped excavation contained primary cremation deposit, fragment bone pin, small flint flake. Number of flint chips, tools rough-out of axe-head in mound.
Site_description: <site summary>: Barrow 236, 45ft diam, 2ft high. M236. Cremation with flint objects and a burnt bone pin & small flint flake

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Crushed cinerary (Collared Urn) urn containing an incense cup and burnt bones of an adult female and a child. Also base of a Food Vessel immediately adjacent
Site_description: CDg added. MC94.

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW 450m NE OF BLANCH FARM (M237) Blanch or Warter
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Scheduled round barrow, excavated by J.R.Mortimer in 1882. -Barrow 237, 19m in diameter and 0.6m high was excavated in 1882 and had two shallow graves containing three primary crouched inhumations (see illus). Grave goods included three food vessels and a flint scraper. A fourth food vessel was found in the mound with animal bones.Six burials (two in a double grave) but only 4 accompanied by grave goods, mainly Food Vessels
Site_description: Round Barrow. Blanch Group, Barrow 237. Oval shaped due to ploughing; diameter 60ft, height 21/2 ft when opened by Mortimer in 1882. The mound contained five burials, all inhumations- a youthin a crouched position, an adult with a child at its feet, with a second on its east side accompanied by a food vessel, a second adult in a crouched poistion near the centre of the mound accompanied by a second food vessle. A third food vessle lay north east of this <1>  Scheduled Monument Record <2>  Round Barrow: opened in August 1882. Description diameter 60ft, height 2 1/2 ft when excavated, 1) 4ft south of centre of barrow in slight hollow in old ground surface was crouched inhumation of adult  much disturbed, with child on feet 2) A little east of 1, and possibly responsible for disturbance, a few inches above old ground surface was crouched inhumation of child accompanied by food vessel, 3) About 5ft north of centre and 8 inches above old ground surface was crouched inhumation of youth. To east of this was a unassociated food vessle about 6inches above old ground surface 4) At centre of barrow in grave reaching old ground surface was crounched adult inhumation accompanied by food vessle and flint scraper, 1 is the earliest burial but due to position may not be primary which presumably was not found, 4 was definatley secondary and 2 and 3 could be secondary or satallite from mound, in addtion to animal bones and flint, came a sandstone pounder and rim sherd of food vessle <3> Now only visible as a superfical ground swelling <4> Amendment to the scheduled monument name to 'Round Barrow 450m north east of Blanch Farm' <5> National list entry <6> Pastscape record <7>

Site_name_other: Warter or Cobdale ROUND BARROW NW OF COBDALE FARM (M252)
