In the mound 12ft S of the centre, were two circular chalk discs 3/4ins thick, 3 1/2 and 4ins, in diam respectively. Also a Food Vessel but these were fragments and from the mound
Site_description: CDG added. This barrow was disturbed by Silburn. Displaced grave goods include chalk discs, coffin, flakes and scrapers. Barrow 252,15m in diam and 0.8m high, was excavated in 1882 and contained an oval grave, previously excavated by Silburn, and

Site_name_other: Cobdale Farm, Warter ROUND BARROW, 100m SW OF COBDALE FARM (M253)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Rather poorly excavated by Silburn who had left the remains of two inhumations in two graves. Thirteen potsherds, flint flakes and an ox tooth were found. Round barrow 100m SW of Cobdale Farm. Scheduled RSM No 21118. The mound is 1m high with a diameter of 25m. The ditch survives as a buried feature 4m wide. The barrow was twice opened by 19th century antiquarians; James Silburn put two E-W trenches across the mound, and in 1882 Mortimer carried out a further excavation, finding the remains of two inhumations, thirteen pot sherds, numerous worked flint flakes and an ox tooth
Site_description: <site summary>: Barrow 253, 58 ft in diam and 2 1/2 ft high, was excavated in 1882. It had been previously excavated by Silburn who had left the remains of two inhumations in two graves. Thirteen potsherds, flint flakes and an ox tooth were found. Round barrow 100m SW of Cobdale Farm. Scheduled RSM No 21118. The mound is 1m high with a diameter of 25m. The ditch survives as a buried feature 4m wide. The barrow was twice opened by 19th century antiquarians; James Silburn put two E-W trenches across the mound, and in 1882 Mortimer carried out a further excavation, finding the remains of two inhumations, thirteen pot sherds, numerous worked flint flakes and an ox tooth

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Part of a more extensive barrow cemetery.  This barrow (254) began as a Neolithic oval/round barrow with a crematorium facade trench. Then re-used in the Beaker period. Two Beakers present
Site_description: <site summary>: . Barrow 254, recognisable only as a slight rise at the perimeter, excavated ? 1882. A shallow central grave contained two crouched inhumations, each with beaker, (both of group N2 - in Hull Museum), (3) a bronze awl with one; traces of burning and calcined bones mixed with burnt soil; remains of a probable third inhumation represented by a foot; a trench on the E side of the barrow, 30 ft long, 2 1/2 ft deep, 2 ft wide - contained a crouched inhumation, sherds of a Neolithic open bowl, and traces of burning. Classified as a crematorium barrow with facade trench.

Site_summary: Site of Mortimer barrow 262. Bronze Age round barrow containing cremation with a  Collared Urn
Site_description: SE8967 5216. Blanch Group, Barrow 262. Opened by Mortimer in 1883. Approximately 10ft east of centre lay a small fragmented collared urn with the cremated bones of a young person below. <1> SE89665215 Tumulus (NR) (site of) Barrow 262 of small dimensions was excavated in 1883. A cinerary urn (collared urn illus), which was a primary cremation, was about 10ft east of the centre. A fragment of flint scraper was found in the mound. <2> Round barrow (Mortimer number 262) SE8967 5216. Excavated August 1883. Description 'of small dimensions' at time of excavation 10' east of centre on old ground surface stood a cinerary urn inverted over cremation of youth. A large flint scraper was found near centre of barrow. Location of finds: Hull museum. Ref:M.P.331. <3> (SE 89665215) Tumulus (NR) (Site of). Barrow 262, of small dimensions, was excavated in 1883. A cinerary urn (collared urn illus), under which was a primary cremation, was about 10 ft E of the centre. A fragment of flint scraper was found in the mound. No remains.At SE 8954 5218 is the cropmark of a roughly circular ringditch of about 13.5 m diameter taken to be the remains of the 'tumulus' described above. 28m to the WNW at SE 8951 5219 is a similar cropmark suggesting a second small barrow with a diameter of about 10m. At SE 8973 5229 is a third small ringditch with a diameter of about 16m. At SE 8969 5214 is a very slight and incomplete cropmark of a ringditch taken to be the remains of the barrow described above. The shape of the ditch suggests a less than regular circle with a diameter of around 30m. <4>

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Round barrow previously excavated by Silburn and then by Mortimer and known as barrow Warter 255. Inhumation with flint knife
Site_description: Barrow 255, previously excavated by Silburn c1851. A central oval grave contained the remains of a primary inhumation disturbed by Silburn. A large flint knife was found in the soil in the grave, and a few flint flakes in the mound. Site under plough, discernible only as a very slight swelling. <1> First explored by Silburn and reopened by Mortimer in 1882. The central oval grave contained the remains of an adult skeleton which had been removed and re-interred by Silburn. A circular flint knife was found in the grave fill. The mound was barely visible in 1967. <2> Description:  Slightly less than 58" diameter and 2.5" height at time of excavation. Previously excavgated by Silburn who had examined central grave containing adult inhumation. In grave fill was flint scraper. Just visible in ploughed field 3" high. Small. <3> Barrow 255, previously excavated by Silburn c. 1851. A central oval grave contained the remains of a primary inhumation disturbed by Silburn. A large flint knife was found in the soil in the grave, and a few flint flakes in the mound. Site under plough, discernible only as a very slight swelling. <4>

Site_summary: <gg sumary>: Beaker and skeletons found in 1912 in gravel pits near the disused railway line south-east of Burstwick. Roman pottery also found.No detail about the burial - only that a Beaker was found probably with an inhumation, Type N2L
Site_description: <FURTHER INFO>

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW, W OF COWLAM GRANGE (M277)
Site_summary: Scheduled as 'round barrow 700m n-e of Collingwood Farm.<gg summary>: Grave goods include decorated jet ring and flake knife. Long barrow with cremations re-used as a Bronze Age round barrow.  Beneath the mound Mortimer found a small oval pit which he said contained "evidences of an interment, possibly a child". The pit fill contained some human and animal bones as well as sherds of Neolithic pottery. Over this pit or grave were extensive traces of burning associated with a spread of charcoal and burnt human bones, covered by chalk rubble which had also been burnt. The area was interpreted as a crematorium for several individuals. Two secondary burials had been inserted into the top of the mound. Both crouched inhumations, one was associated with a flint knife and a jet pulley-ring; the other with a Food Vessel. Note the Neolithic crematorium contained several burnt individuals (exact number not disclosed or known)  but none were accompanied by discernible grave goods. Several individuals burnt in crematorium in situ
Site_description: <site summary>:  Willie Howe long barrow. A Neolithic long barrow with Early Bronze Age secondary burials. Excavated in 1892 by Mortimer, it was at that time  a mound c 17m in diameter, and 1.4m high.. However, aerial photographs suggest that the mound was of oblong shape surrounded by an unbroken ditch, although the cropmarks are not as clear as might be wished.

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Site of a beaker burial. A skeleton and a beaker were found in a sandpit during excavations in early 1920s at South Cave, Kettlethorpe. Beaker pottery in Hull Museum from sand-pit.
Site_description: <FURTHER INFO>

Site_summary: Findspot of Iron sword and bones in a chalk quarry.<gg_summary>: Iron sword, bones and bone ring, recovered during chalk quarring in 1974. No contextual detail but included in Stead's (2006) catalogue of British Iron Age swords.
Site_description: <FURTHER INFO>

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Site of a Bronze Age round barrow, excavated in 1873 and found to contain five primary crouched inhumations, two secondary inhumations and four cremation deposits.Note that there were five individuals buried in one multiple pit grave (only 2 with grave goods), a double burial (neither with grave goods) and none of the 4 unurned cremation deposits were accompanied with grave goods Grave goods included a dagger and Food Vessel and incense cup
Site_description: SE 9620 5875, Garton Slack Barrow C.62. Opened by Mortimer in 1873, measured 23yds. Diameter, height about 2ft. The central grave contained five skeletons, all interred at the same time. One, a child burial was accompanied by a food vessel, an inverted cinerary urn and two bone artefacts. Two other graves lay north-east and south-east of centre, neither of which contained internments. C.13ft. North-east of centre, in a small hole, occurred the remains of an adult cremation, near which lay fragments of the skull of a child and a small flint flake. <1> Barrow C62 was 69ft diameter and 2ft high when excavated in 1873. Five primary crouched inhumations, two secondary crouched burials and four cremation deposits were seen in the mound (see plan of mound). Other finds were bone implements, a flint knife, a food vessel and incence cup. Site under plough for many years and no trace survives. <2> Copy of the Hull Museum Card for this site. <3> See MHU4338 (Barrow MC61) for illustration mentioned reference 2 above. <4>  Barrow C62 was 69ft diameter and c 2ft high when excavated in 1873. Five primary crouched inhumations, two secondary crouched burials and four cremation deposits were seen in the mound. Other finds were bone implements, a flint knife a food vessel and incense cup. <5>

Site_summary: Square barrow measuring 13.5m by 15m, probably originally excavated in 1857 and again by Terry Manby in the 1970's?<gg_summary>: Barrow 2 (Manby 1980): One of 5 IA square barrows excavated in 1857 with finds of human and animal bone, brooches, flint implements and urns. One of these barrows was re-excavated in 1972 by Manby. The central grave was robbed but the undisturbed remains of a suckling pig were recovered. See MHU565 for the broader cemetery record. The grave goods are linked to this record.Manby notes specifically (1980, 43) that the Grindale and Huntow barrows with grave goods are one and the same thing. Whimster (1981) suggested that the barrow excavated by Manby was separate.Associated objects: Bronze brooch of La Tene II form; 2 bronze penannular brooches.
Site_description: TA 1553 8033. TA17SE. <1> "… barrows … two were excavated by Manby in 1972. TA 155 703, TA 150 704, one being a square barrow. The other a two period barrow …" <2> Grindale, North Humberside, TA 155 703. Square barrow 13.5m by 15m with previously excavated grave and a pattern of 19th century excavation trenches (AE 1972: 39). Probably a barrow excavated in 1857. See Huntow. <3> [TA 1568 7048] Tumulus {LB} [TA 1552 7033} Tumulus {LB} (site of) The feature at TA 1568 7048 no longer exists. Sources: OS 6" NSL, LS 25" (Anon, Surveyor, 1966). <4> Photocopied excavation report. <5> 'Tumulus' printed and shown on O.S. 25" first edition map. <6> Cross reference MHU565, group of square barrows (marginal) excavated 1857; MHU15543, possible settlement in the area of these barrows. <7> Colour air photo sent to unit by Mr Evans EYBC 12/92 (no AP reference), shows a roughly circular ditch surrounding the square barrow. <8> Grindale, E.R. (TA 150704). Three plough-levelled barrows were excavated by T.G. Manby for the Prehistoric Research Section of the Yorks.Arch. Soc. Barrow 2: A square ditched barrow of Arras Culture type, 13.5m by 15m internally. A central rectangular grave had been robbed. There was the undisturbed remains of a suckling pig in the south-west corner. <9> In Britain, the distribution (of early penannular brooches) is a wide one, as follows: …Hull Number 3801. Huntow, Bridlington, Yorks. A pair with elaborate pin terminals. <10>

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Excavations undertaken by Northern Archaeological Associates along the Caythorpe Gas pipeline identified a Bronze Age round barrow, believed to be originally 18m in diameter. The peripheral burial from this barrow lacked grave goods
Site_description: A Bronze Age round barrow was identified during excavations along the route of Caythorpe Gas pipeline, by archaeological contractor Northern Archaeology Associates.  The barrow lies on the south-east margin of the Rudston Beacon round barrow cemetery and opposite the southern terminus of the Woldgate cursus. Only the northern half of the barrow ditch extended into the pipeline corridor. Originally thought to be 18m in diameter, it had a central grave cut with a crouched inhumation contained in a possible coffin, along with several worked flints. A secondary crouched inhumation had been cut into the ditch on the north-west side of the barrow <1> Excavations in advance of pipeline construction in 1992. Approximately half of an Early Bronze Age ring ditch and barrow was excavated. The ring ditch was adjacent to the barrow on the North side. Only a third was excavated, it being estimated that it was 6 metres wide. No burial was recorded. The barrow was 19.2 metres in diameter with both central primary, and secondary peripheral, crouched inhumations. These features appear to be at the South-Eastern edge of the Rudston Beacon barrow cemetery <2>

Site_name_other: IRON AGE INHUMATION, S OF WOLDGATE
Site_summary: <gg_summary> One of two isolated burials (see also SID72990) and two square barrows from a wider cemetery (see SID40188) excavated during the Caythorpe Gas Pipeline project in 1992.
Site_description: <NRHE site description>: Excavations in advance of pipeline construction in 1992. Neolithic, Early and Late Bronze Age pit alignments were recorded, as well as 3 Iron Age hut circles, an inhumation, and a trackway.

Site_name_other: SQUARE BARROW GROUP, SE OF LOW CAYTHORPE DMV
Site_summary: A small group of square barrows and an east to west aligned boundary ditch to the south of the Gypsey Race. The barrows were fully excavated within the confines of the Caythorpe Gas Pipeline corridor.<gg_summary>: Three burials associated with two square barrows from a broader cemetery. Of these, two were associated with grave goods and are recorded here.
Site_description: Abramson 1996, 20: Two square barrows situated on a gravel terrace, S of the Gypsey Race were identified during the Caythorpe Gas Pipeline project in 1992.Square barrow 3190 was 4m wide and no evidence of a mound survived. Two intercutting N-S aligned graves were situated in the centre of the barrow. The earliest burial of an unaccompanied juvenille, aged 6-9 years was cut into by a second inhumation burial - a subadult, aged c. 15 years. The latter was associated with a flint flake and core and a short involuted bow brooch with mineralised fur/sheepskin and textile attached to its front.The ditch surrounding Grave 3108 had all but been destroyed. Grave 3108 was aligned E-W (1.7 x 1.1 x 0.41m deep). It contained an inhumation burial of a young man lying in a flexed position on his left hand side with his head to the west. He was associated with a worked flint.The ditch of an additional square barrow ditch to the west of the pipeline route suggests that these barrows formed part of a more extensive cemetery.

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW, W OF SUMMIT HOUSE (M238) Blanch or Warter
Site_summary: Round barrow excavated in 1882 by J.R.Mortimer<gg summary>: ast of centre lay a large excavated pit, 14ft by 6ft, 4ft to 4ft deep, which contained bone splinters and charcoal, but no internment. To the west lay an oval grave, 7ft by 5ft by 6ft deep, within which was found the skeleton of an adult male accompanied by a crushed food vessel. Beneath this lay two earlier inhumations one dismembered and disturbed by the later burial, the other complete,  in a crouched position and accompanied by an oval jet button and a triangular flint knife
Site_description: Round Barrow ( Warter or Blanch M238). Opened by Mortimer in 1882, when remains were slight. E <1>  Hull Museum Card, Finds and burials from the round barrow appear to be in the Hull Museum <2>  Barrow 238 hardly visible, excavated in 1882 An oval grave contained a primary crouched inhumation accompanied by a rushed ornamented food vessel at the top, and another at the bottom with an oval jet button and a flint knife. The dismembered bones of a third inhumation with pieces of animal bones, were scattered throughout the grave beneath the upper inhumation. Adjacent to the grave was an excavation 14ft by 6ft and 4-5ft deep containing animal bones in the filling, burnt wood and dark matter at the bottom <3> See MHU4602, ref 3 for Mortimer's plan if Barrow 238 <4>

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Possible cremation associated with a Food Vessel disturbed by later period Saxon burials
Site_description: <site summary>: Barrow at Fimber house, situated only 450m NW of another at Mill Hill. A round barrow known as "Mill Hill", 45ft diam and 1 1/2-2ft high, excavated in 1863 and 1870. It contained Medieval pottery, nails and animal bones. A central cruciform trench was found with two stages of low walling (certainly successive post-mill foundations). Fragments of a "British food-vase" were discovered under the later wall, and pieces of lias and oolite in the early wall "may have been portions of a cist

Site_name_other: BA & AS BURIALS, RB FURNACE?, ST MARY'S CHURCHYARD (MC33)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Incense cup, aces and other urns recovered along with arrowheads and skeletons. Food Vessels also recovered . Note also MN flints - possibly curated?
Site_description: Extract from the Gazetteer of A social and Anthropological Analysis of Conversion Period and Later Anglo-Saxon Cemeteries in Lincolnshire and Yorkshire <12><site summary>: Barrow with a burnt down early medieval church on top of it. Also other disturbance included Early saxon burials. This was originally a large Early Bronze Age barrow with several EBA inhumations. Excavated in July 1826

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Mortimer found a roughly central oval pit beneath the mound, within which was an adult crouched inhumation resting on "a film of dark matter". Several secondary deposits were found in the mound, including an unaccompanied food vessel, a small heap of cremated bone, another cremation deposit with part of a flint knife and a bone button, both also burnt. Nearby were some unburnt deer bones. Another unaccompanied cremation also occurred to the northeast. [NB this barrow was originally recorded as part of SE 85 NW 17. See that record for additional sources and information]
Site_description: <site summary>:  A probable Early Bronze Age round barrow excavated in 1877 by Mortimer, following the removal of a clump of beech trees from the summit of the mound. At the time it was 6 feet high. By 1994, the mound was 33 metres in diameter and 2.5 metres high, with traces of a surrounding ditch. Once again, the mound is blessed with mature tree cover.

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW, SSW OF HIGH CALLIS WOLD FARM (M23) Callis Wold 23 or Bishop Wilton barrow (M23)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: First excavation revealed an oval trough-shaped grave containing "greasy cavities", but no burial. Second excavation uncovered an elliptical rock-cut grave at the foot of the first grave, containing a crouched inhumation partly on its back with a crushed food vessel and an axe-hammer (part of a decayed handle evident). A double circle of stake holes diameter 21 1/2 ft and 28 ft surrounded the graves, the holes being 12 to 15 ins in diam on the N while the others were 3 ins. A filled-in ditch 100 ft in diam, 3 ft 9 ins deep, 9ft wide at the top and 1 ft at the bottom, surrounded the barrow
Site_description: <site summary>;  Barrow 23 is 21m in diameter and 1.2m high. It was excavated in 1865 and 1868.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Barrow 20m in diameter and 1.2m high. Food Vessel found in mound 0.3m above natural surface but with no body. Central burial of powerful male with Food Vessel and battle axe. Unusually the body was laid extended at full length in a timber-lined grave Food Vessels and flint knives and other grave goodsNote and this could be a pattern. Where we get timber-lined graves we tend to see extended burials which is otherwise a rare posture for EBA. Also the presence of the battle axe

<gg_summary>: 56 burials were excavated in total, of which 11 were associated with grave goods. An additional grave/pit had an assemblage of objects but no human remains. Finds are in Hull and East Riding Museum.
Site_description: Extensive Middle Iron Age inhumation cemetery (probably in use between c.400-200 BC) including two cart/chariot burials. The cemetery is located within a landscape of settlement, burials spanning the Neolithic to the Romano-British period.

Site_summary: Aerial photographs show cropmarks of an Iron Age square barrow cemetery, with Anglo-Saxon burials, partially excavated in  1985.<gg_summary>: of the 10 excavated graves, 5 (including one chariot burial and four ring ditches with male burials and spears) were associated with grave goods. The remaining 5 female graves had no grave goods. The other graves from the cemetery are of early medieval date. The cemetery is interesting a) for its location directly across the Gypsey Race, b) for the occurence of several 'empty' barrows and c) for teh occurence of the burials with spears in round barrows located along the Gypsey Race. The finds are in the British Museum.<NRHE HOBUID: 910820; https://www.pastscape.org.uk/hob.aspx?hob_id=910820&sort=2&type=&typeselect=c&rational=a&class1=None&period=None&county=None&district=None&parish=None&place=&recordsperpage=10&source=text&rtype=monument&rnumber=910820#>
Site_description: Aerial photographs show three areas of mainly square barrows. Those barrows along with two square enclosures, at SE 982 578 were excavated in 1985. Interpretation of aerial photograph made by R.Teal in 1991. <1> Information sheet from Humberside Archaeological Unit concerning the Excavations at Garton on the Wolds in 1985, No.8 <2> Photocopied extract from 'New Light On The Parisi', by P.Halkon, 1989, p.1-6. <3> Aerial photographs showing the square barrow cemetery along with various other features, including ring ditch, round barrow and dyke. <4> Excavation summary from I.M.Stead, 'Iron Age Cemeteries in East Yorkshire' p.17-24, figs 16-22. <5> Aerial photograph showing a possible area of square barrows, some with central pits, centred at SE 972 584. <6> An excavation directed by I.M.Stead for the British Museum discovered a chariot burial in a grave 4.0m by 2.4m and 1.4m deep, orientated north-south, at the centre of a barrow 11-12 square. The wheels had been stacked leaning against the side of the grave, their decayed wooden naves and spokes replaced in clay. The pole and axle had been buried as a single T-shaped frame, 3.0m long and 2.2m across. The flexed corpse had been buried first and the framework of the vehicle lowered on top of it. The line of the yoke placed behind the body could be distinguished by a row of five terrets, the central one being finely decorated in relief. Alongside was a pair of linch pins and two horse pits; animal bones lay in front of and behind the shoulders of the body. A box shape, 1.7m by 1.0m, traced by darker filling above the skelton, may be the body of the chariot, upturned to cover it. Five smaller square barrows each had an unaccompanied north-south crouched burial in a large and deep grave. Four similar-sized barrows within ring ditches, two having causeways, had unusual features. The burials of males, one with a sword, another with a shield, all had iron spear or javelin heads thrust or thrown into the grave, 14 in that with a sword, and 11,7 and 3 in the others. Comparable finds have been made at Burton Fleming, Wetwang Slack and Grimthorpe. An enclosure 16-18m square with an entrance to the west is unique. No Iron Age grave was found within it but its centre was occupied by two rows of Anglian burials. Three other square barrows to the north-east, also had a western entrance and one had an extended east-west inhumation with a spearhead, but with an Anglian shield handle near the left hand. See also Current Archaeology 9 (1987), 234-7 and Anglo-Scandinavian Section. During excavations by I.M Stead thirty-five Anglian inhumation burials were discovered both at the centre of a large Iron Age enclosure, in three other Iron Age barrows, and elsewhere. Most were orientated east-west and grave goods indicate a 7th century date. A young child was accompanied by a fine gold pendant with filigree ornament, a silver toilet set, three silver rings and glass beads; a woman was buried with a brooch, pendant, bead and buckle, all of silver. A fine decorated hanging bowl had been missed by grave robbers. Other unusual graves included one with a bronze cauldron and support, and another with an iron ladle and a possible socketed weaving baton. Weapons were found in five graves and tools in two, knives came from eighteen and buckles from twelve graves. Bronze staples and iron fittings indicated wooden boxes or leather bags. Animal bones were found with twelve burials, usually at the feet. These burials were apparently an extension of Mortimer's Garton Gatehouse cemetery 500m to the east. See also Prehistoric Section and Current Archaeology 9, 234-7.

Site_summary: <gg summary>:  Many of the Neolithic bodies were partial and partially disarticulated but laid out on the pavement of flat Liassic stones brought from the W Wold edge 2miles distant.At base of barrow on the linear platform of flat Liassic limestone laid flat on GS.  Covers 4m x 1m; all crouched but some part articulated & crouched in 2 neat rows & they dovetail. 10 crouched inhumations (7-16) laid on the liassic limestone platform at base of mortuary enclosure.Platform aligned E-W., and 2 rows of 5 burials on it. Few of them were accompanied by grave goods.  Adult inhumation with cinerary urn and a youth with barbed arrowhead and cremations with grave goods There was a also a series of 6 secondary burials of EBA date but again only one of these was accompanied by grave goods
Site_description: <site summary>: This forms part of a more extensive barrow cemetery at Callis Wold, and a later Roman road cuts through here. There is also a Bronze Age linear boundary ditch and barrows to N and S. This monument begins as a early Neolithic mortuary enclosure and oval barrow that is later augmented in the Beaker-Early Bronze Age

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW Callis Wold or Bishop Wilton (M100)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Round barrow, much spread by the plough, but still well defined. Excavated in 1867, it covered a central grave which contained a flexed and a crouched inhumation, secondary cremation, beakers and Neolithic-Bronze Age flint implements.. Large irregular central grave contained primary crouched and primary extended burial, fragments of drinking cups, flint flakes,animal bones, burnt wood and potsherds. At A, large empty inverted urn (illus - similar to BA vessel from Hutton Buscel, Abercromby Type 7, enlarged food vessel) left impression in clay, giving appearance of having rested on circle of wood, 18 in diam. Just south further impressions indicated remains of large oval wood receptacle, C, 3 ft 8 ins by 1 ft 7 ins, either containing, or inverted over, cremation and unburnt skull, on same level as urn. Numerous flint flakes, 3 flint knives, fragment of leaf-shaped arrowhead and large slingstone; fragment of polished axe in mound.So this was originally a Early Neolithic barrow that was later used in the Beaker and EBA periods
Site_description: <site summary>:  Callis Wold barrow 100. Close to and c. 400m NE of another at High Callis Wold, with a number of other barrows in the vicinity. This barrow was 32m in diameter and 2m high and was excavated in 1867.

Site_summary: <gg summary>:  A central oval grave lined with oak was found, containing the remains of a primary inhumation and two cremations, also a beaker sherd and a crushed food vessel. Flint implements were also found. And a natural pebble
Site_description: <site summary>:  Barrow 14 (identified as 'B' from map) diam 21m, height 1.7m, was excavated in 1864 and 1874.

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW, NE OF BISHOP WILTON WOLD FARM (M120)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Four burials but the central burial lacked grave goods . Two flint knives were found in the mound. Contained three primary crouched burials in two rock-cut graves; flint knife, bone hair-pin with double burial. Secondary crouched burial in mound with fragments of food vessel; pig bones nearby. Flint knives in mound.
Site_description: <site summary>: Barrow 120 is 21m in diameter and 0.4m high. Excavated in 1868.

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW (M143) Bishop Wilton or Bishop Wilton Wold (MC43)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: Round barrow, south east of Wold Farm, Bishop Wilton. There were five burials - two inhumations and three cremations, but only the two inhumations in the double grave were accompanied by grave goods (fragmentary Beakers etc) . Note  that a  Pygmy cup was recovered from old ground surface from beneath mound nut no discernible association with a burial. Other finds from mound included; barbed arrowhead, circular flint discs, flake saw, numerous potsherds and animal bones
Site_description: Mortimer C43. Bronze Age Round Barrow. Scheduled Ancient Monument No 15c; one barrow scheduled as one of 'three barrow at Bishop Wilton Wold' SAM 15a-c, 15a=SMR 9780 (M31), 15b=SMR 8553 (M120) <1> Mortimer barrow C43, diameter 90ft by 3ft high and opened in July 1871 contained 1 secondary cremation, 2 further cremations at the bottom of the mound, and a grave with two crouched inhumations. A dish-shaped hole in the floor of the grave contained burnt matter including human bones. A small portion of a beaker came from the side of the grave which also contained a 'boat-formed mass of black, unctuous and  much-burn't matter surrounded by rubbly chalk'. Most of the four circular flint discs, parts of three knives, and 110 potsherds, including pieces of rims of seven beakers, three 'food-vases' and the side of a pygmy cup came from the old ground surface beneath the mound. The barrow still survives (1971) as a ploughed but well defined mound, diameter 95ft (29m) by 2.5ft (0.80m) high <2> Barrow has been greatly reduced, but is still a well formed mound 0.40m high, although no ditch is now apparent <3> Scheduled Monument Amendment, Scheduled area amended; Monument name now 'Round Barrow 250m east of Wold Farm, Bishop Wilton', national monument number 21095 <4> The monument includes a Bronze Age round barrow situated on Bishop Wilton Wold, one of a group of barrows on this area of the Wolds. The barrow mound is a visible feature in the landscape, standing to a height of 1.3m, and positioned on a natural rise. The mound has been ploughed and this has resulted in its present ovoid shape. It measures 60m north-south, and 48m east-west although originally it would have been fully circular. Although no longer visible at ground level, a ditch, from which material was excavated during the construction of the monument, surrounds the barrow mound. This has become in-filled over the years but survives as a buried feature about 3m wide. The mound was excavated by J R Mortimer in July 1871 when two inhumations and three cremations were found along with worked flints and pot fragments <5>

Site_summary: Aerial photographs identified a round barrow. Note in HER this is labelled as M296 but there is no M296 (Mortimer's last barriow no is 295!)  and Greenwell 296 or CCXVVI is in Northumberland!! But this reference sounds very similar to Honey Hill barrowCluster of three barrows situated c. 45-50m apart. All given same monument number, This is B. SE 98646639. Greenwell No LVI. A round barrow, 17m diameter and 1.3m high excavated by Mortimer in 1909. Three contracted and three disarticulated burials were found (4). Re-excavation in 1968 revealed two phases of construction. Phase I. An inner mound with ring ditch 17m in diameter. Phase II. An outer casing of earth 24.5m in diameter surrounded by a ditch 9 ft across with RB and Md sherds in the silting. Three cremations. a plano-convex knife and part of a carinated vessel were also found Seven individuals but one double burial shared the grave goods and two lacked grave goods
Site_description: 'A' SE 98626638. A round Barrow 46ft diameter and 2ft high excavated by Greenwell. A central secondary contrated burial had displaced the remains of an adult cremation and infant burial which had been accompanied by a beaker and cinerary urn, fragments of which were found in the grave fill (2). Re-excavation in 1968 revealed an encirculing ditch 50ft diameter(3) 'B'and 4ft high excavated by Mortimer in 1909. Three contracted and three disarticulated burials were found(4) Re-excavation in 1968 reveled two phases of construction. Phase I. An inner mound with ring ditch 50ft in diameter. Phase II. An outer casing of earth 80ft in diameter surrounded by a ditch 9ft across with RB and MD sherds in the silting. Three cremations, a plano-convex knife and part of a carinated vessel were also found. 'C' SE 98646639 A round Barrow, 50ft diameter and 1 and half feet high excavated by Greenwell. Two contracted (one with a small food vessel) and two disturbed burials were seen (2). Re-excavation in 1968 revealed two crouched burials and remains of a beaker burial. Other finds were a bone pin, fragments of bronze and beaker sherds. A ditch, 50ft diameter, encirled the mound <1> SE 986664, Tumuli 3 mounds in a cornfield, ploughed down 1957, one barrow extant, two others destroyed. 1961 visible from the air in the midst of the the other blurred circular and curving soilmarks of a dubious nature. Two dug by Greenwell, one by Mortimer. Romano-British Pottery also found at this grid reference <2> Cross reference SMR 3467 and SMR 8880 for other two barrows in this group. Also SMR 3450 for pottery <3> Aerial photograph appear to show barrow <4>

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Two contracted (one with a small food vessel) and two disturbed burials were seen (2). Re-excavations in 1968 revealed two crouched burials and remains of a beaker burial. Other finds were a bone pin, fragments of Bronze and Beaker sherds. A ditch, 50ft diameter, encircled and mound. One of a group three barrow, two of which were excavated by Greenwell (LV-LVI), the other by Mortimer (no. 296). Ploughed down in 1957; one extant, and two destroyed in 1961. When excavated by Greenwell measured 50ft diameter and 1 and half feet high; contained two adult inhumations in a hollow at centre, one of which accompanied by a food vessel. Close to these lay the scattered bones of an adult male and child
Site_description: Round Barrow. 'C'-SE98646635. A round barrow, 50ft diameter and 1 and half feet high excavated by Greenwell. Two contracted (one with a small food vessel) and two disturbed burials were seen (2). Re-excavations in 1968 revealed two crouched burials and remains of a beaker burial. Other finds were a bone pin, fragments of Bronze and Beaker sherds. A ditch, 50ft diameter, encircled and mound <1> One of a group three barrow, two of which were excavated by Greenwell (LV-LVI), the other by Mortimer (no. 296). Ploughed down in 1957; one extant, and two destroyed in 1961. When excavated by Greenwell measured 50ft diameter and 1 and half feet high; contained two adult inhumations in a hollow at centre, one of which accompanied by a food vessel. Close to these lay the scattered bones of an adult male and child <2> The largest of a group of three barrows, the other two of which were opened by Greenwell (nos LV, LVI). This, the third was planted with trees at the time. Probably the one which was extant in 1961 <3> SE 986664 Tumuli; three mounds in a cornfield, ploughed down in 1957, one barrow extant, the others destroyed, 1961 visible from the air in the midst of other blurred circular and curving soilmarks of a dubious nature. Two dug by Greenwell, one by Mortimer. Romano-British pottery also found this area <4> Impossible to assign Greenwell number and therefore excavation details to this barrow <5> Cross reference SMR 8815 and SMR 3467 for other two barrows in this group. Also SMR 3450 for pottery <6> Aerial photograph appears to show barrow <7> Photocopied Extract and illustration <8>

Site_summary: Bowl barrow in Towthorpe Plantation, 800m north north east of Burdale North Wold<gg summary>: two burials. One cremation of child with ?coffin and flake and one inhumation of adult with lots of fine grave goods including dagger and macehead
Site_description: Round Barrow. This barrow stands in the west end of Towthorpe plantation, c.300yds north of Barrow 1. It was opened in 1870. There was no trace of a body, although a small pottery sherd was found in a depression. East south east of centre were the calcined bones of  a child in the midst of decayed wood. Beneath the centre of  the mound was a grave containing the remains of a male. Also found were flint splinters, 2 sawa, a spear-head & black flint scraper. A bronze dagger which had been ina sheath was sound by the left arm of the skeleton, and to the left of the head was a stone hammer head. A black flint knife was near the right facial bones <1> Scheduled Monument description <2> Scheduled as one of the five 'Round Barrows in Towthrope Plantation' cross reference SMR 13473, 13474, 13475, 13476, see reference two for source <3> B (SE 8813 6396) A round barrow, 132ft diameter and 12 and half feet high, excavated in 1870. A primary flexed inhumation was found accompanied by a bronze dagger, stone hammer and flint knife, Also exposed a child burial surrounded by decayed wood. Notable finds were a leaf shaped arrowhead, two flint saws spoon shaped scraper, spear head and a 2 and half inch flint knife. All these barrows are prominent mounds in good condition <4> The Wessex Culture also attracted bronze articles from continental sources and had some distinctive implements- types like the 'Bush Barrow' daggers with their grooved forces and mid ribs. Such daggers were imported into Yorkshire as they have been found with burials at   Towthorpe Barrow C39  <5> Scheduled monuments amendment.Scheduled area unchanged ; monument name now 'Bowl Barrow in Towthorpe Plantation, 800m NNE of Burdale North Wold' National Monuments no 26534 <6> Photocopy <7> The monument includes a bowl barrow in Towthorpe Plantation, situated on the county boundary line between North Yorkshire and Humberside. The barrow is one of a group of seven barrows surviving in this area, five of which are in a line along the county boundary. The barrow survives as a prominent mound up to 3m in height, and is between 34m (north-south) and 40m (east-west) in diameter. It is surrounded by a ditch 3m wide, which although no longer visible at ground level, willsurvive as a buried feature. The monument was originally part of a much larger group of 21 barrows, recorded by J R Mortimer as stretching for 7km from Wharram in the westnearly as far as Sledmere in the east, and itself forms part of a chain of barrows extending along the line of the ancient greenway now known as the Wolds Way, from Aldro to Sledmere. A depression in the centre of the mound summit attests to the fact that the barrow was excavated by J R Mortimer in 1870, who discovered the calcined bones of a child amongst some decayed wood ESE of the mound centre, about a metre from the mound base. This burial was made during the raising of the mound, following the primary interment.The primary interment was found cut into bedrock beneath the centre of the mound, and contained the remains of an extended male skeleton measuring 1.8 metres long, and orientated from head to feet, north west-south east. Finds overall included a small pot sherd contained within a depression, flint fragments, two saws, a spear-head and a spoon-shaped black flint scraper. A bronze dagger blade, contained within a much decayed bronze sheath, was found by the left arm of the skeleton, a hammer-stone to the left of the head and a black flint knife to the right of the upper jaw bone. Much of the material of the barrow mound was found to consist of local clay brought in from Burdale and Duggleby, for the purpose of the burial. Layers of this clay alternated with layers of reddish soil from the burial location, and filled the centre of the grave beneath the mound. A modern post and wire fence runs past the monument to its south side, and is excluded from the scheduling, although the ground beneath it is included <8>

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW, 150m SE OF TOWTHORPE RESERVOIR (M1)
Site_summary: A round barrow excavated in 1863 and again in 1865 by Mortimer.<gg summary>: Two burials - one cremation and one inhumation but only the inhumation was accompanied by grave goods It  was near the centre of the groups, close to High Towthorpe. It had several strata, with alternate layers of soil, organic and decayed material. At the base of a clay layer were two food vases, below ashes which probaly represented the remains of a funeral pyre. There were decayed bones and a chipped flint nearby. Also found were a dozen hand-struck flint flakes and a splinter from the cutting edge of a greenstone celt. When the barrow was reopend in 1865, a black flint knife, flint splinters and a small piece of bronze were found
Site_description: A (SE 8800 6373)   round barrow excavated in 1863 and 1865 containing a primary burial with two food vessels. Further finds were a fragment of greenstone axe, two and a quarter inc  flint knife and a dozen worked flints . 'A'  is reduced by ploughing <1>  Scheduled Monument Description <2> Mortimer barrow  1. Opened in 1863, was near the centre of the groups, close to High Towthorpe. It had several strata, with alternate layers of soil, organic and decayed material. At the base of a clay layer were two food vases, below ashes which probaly represented the remains of a funeral pyre. There were decayed bones and a chipped flint nearby. Also found were a dozen hand-struck flint flakes and a splinter from the cutting edge of a greenstone celt. When the barrow was reopend in 1865, a black flint knife, flint splinters and a small piece of bronze were found <3>  Photocopied extract <4> SMR Interpretation,  Humber Archaeology Unit undertook a Watching brief (FIM94 ) undertaken during road- widening works on B1248 to west of this barrow undercovered a number of prehistoric features in the vicinity, but none that could be said to be directly related to barrow. Cross ref SMR17981 and SMR17982  <5> Scheduled Monument amendment. Scheduled area unchanged; monument name now 'Bowl Barrow', 150m south east of Towthorpe Reservoir. National monument no 26540 <6> Bowl barrows, the most numerous form of round barrow, are funerary monuments  dating from the Late Neolithic period to the Late Bronze Age, with most examples belonging to the period 2400-1500 BC. They were constructed as earthen or rubble mounds, sometimes ditched, which covered single or multiple burials. They occur either in isolation or grouped as cemeteries and oftenacted as a focus for burials in later periods. Often superficially similar, although differing widely in size, they exhibit regional variations in form and a diversity of burial practices. There are over 10,000 surviving bowl barrows recorded nationally (many more have already been destroyed), occurring across most of lowland Britain. Often occupying prominent locations, they are a major historic element in the modern landscape and their considerable variation of form and longevity as a monument type provide important information on the diversity of beliefs and social organisations amongst early prehistoric communities. They are particularly representative of their period and a substantial proportion of surviving examples are considered worthy of protection. The monument is one of a closely associated group of barrows within and adjacent to the Towthorpe Plantation. The location of the modern county  boundary along this line of barrows offers important insight into the antiquity of land divisions in this region. Despite part excavation by J R Mortimer in 1863 and again in 1867, and the effects of ploughing over many years, the barrow still survives as a visible mound, and will contain further burials, and archaeological information relating to its construction <7>

Site_name_other: ROUND BARROW, 150m NNE OF TOWTHORPE HIGH BARN (M6)
Site_summary: <gg summary>: , excavated by Mortimer in 1863. Note although the remains of at least 9 individuals (including disarticulated remains of children & 3 adults in the mound) were buried in this barrow, only 1 was accompanied by grave goods (a Food Vessel)
Site_description: SE Mortimer Barrow 6. Scheduled round barrow. Opened in 1863. At the centre was found a skull and traces of other bones. A second body lay a little below this, and a third on th efloor of the grave. South of these were the remains od children, and three further adult bodies to the west. The barrow was reopended in 1867 and another body was found north east of centre. South West of centre was a food vase accompanying the remains of a child <1> Scheduling Description <2> 'B' (SE 8890 6398) A round barrow, 60ft diameter and 1ft  6incs high, excavated in 1863 and 1867. It contained a child burial with a food vessel. There were four other burials (one disturbed, two flexed and one crounced) and four immature burials in acommunial grave. Largely reduced by ploughing with a height of no more than 0.30m <3>  Scheduled Monument amendment. Scheduled area unchanged; monument name now 'Bowl Barrow 150m NNE of Towthorpe, High Barn' national Monument number 26539 <4> The monument includes a bowl barrow situated in a field 150m north east of Towthorpe High Barn. The  monument is one of a group of seven barrows surviving in this area, five of which lie in a line along the county boundary 300m to the north. Although altered over the years by agricultural activity which has spread the mound, the barrow is still visible as a slight mound up to 0.3m high, and 24m in diameter. It is surrounded by a ditch up to 3m wide, which although infilled by ploughing and now no longer visible at the ground level, will survive as a buried feature. The monument was originally part of a much larger group of 21 barrows, recorded by J R Mortimer as stretching for 7km from Wharram in the west nearly as far as Sledmere in the east, and itself forms part of a chain of barrows extending along the line of the ancient greenway now known as the Wolds Way, from Aldro to Sledmere. The monument was excavated twice by J R Mortimer in 1863, and again in 1867. During the first excavation, an interment, much disturbed by contemporary ploughing, was found a little below the surface in the centre of the mound, consisting of a skull and some long bones. A short way below this a second interment was found, and a third below the second on the floor of the grave. The second and third bodies had been interred flexed, with their heads to the west. To the south of the three main burials, four child burials were found near the base of the mound, consisting of four small skulls together with other bones. Three more adult skeletons were found to the west, a little beneath the base of the mound, two of which had chalk breccia placed near their heads. These lay with their heads to the north west, excepting one who had been placed with the head laying in the opposite direction. No traces of any grave offerings were found with these interments. The barrow was again excavated by Mortimer in 1867, who on this occasion found another flexed burial 3m north east of the centre, lying on its right side with head to the south. The much decayed remains of a child's body were found 3m to the south west of the centre, accompanied by a food vessel placed rim down, the only burial offering found in the monument <5>

Site_summary: Aerial photographs identified a series of square ditches and linear features.<gg_summary>: A cart burial and three adjacent square barrows (eight burials in total of which one was early medieval in date) were excavated at Kirkburn Site 1 in September 1967 (Stead 1991, 24). Two further burials were excavated at Site 2 (c. 400m to the north west but neither of these was associated with grave goods and one was of Bronze Age date.
Site_description: Area of scattered square barrows visible in fields south of road which forms part of Garton/Kirkburn parish  boundary. Also in this area one roughly circular feature - two ditches-. This may be related to the cemetery - included in this SMR at present. North of the road lies SMR 8083 -Square Barrow Cemtery - cross reference. Also cross reference SMR 4405, 4413, 4420-Tumulus in this area <1> Aerial Photographs <2> Photocopied Article <3> Excavation Summary <4> Photocpied Note <5> Correspondance <6> Photocopied Article <7> Photocopied Note <8> Aerial Photographs <9> Article in Journal 'Dating Celtic Art: a Major Radiocarbon Dating Programme of Iron Age and Early Roman Metalwork in Britain'  Full article in SMR Library <10> Internet Information <11> Slide <12> Slide<13> Internet Information <14><HER event description>: Following on from the Garton Station excavations John Dent along side the British Museum commissioned the excavation of a possible cart burial to the south of the Garton Station excavations. Prior to the excavation a fluxgate gradiometer survey  in fields to the west and south of the Garton Station excavations was carried out in order to locate another possible cart burial. In 1980 John Dent had already taken aerial photographs of the area around Garton Station and Kirkburn, round and square barrows along with other cropmarks were visible on the aerial photographs. A large enclosure was identified through aerial photographs and geophysics so excavations were concentrated around this feature. In September 1987 two open area excavations (Site 1, 1900sqm and Site 2 2,2250sqm) were opened. The stripping of Site 1 uncovered a series of  square and round barrows. A cart burial with a later Anglian Burial were identified along with two smaller round barrows, an undated quarry, linear ditches and medieval furrows . The stripping of Site 2 uncovered  a larger oval enclosure, linear ditches, a Bronze Age crouched inhumation, an Iron Age square enclosure, round barrow and early Roman horse burials. Neolithic to Roman pottery was identified along with other artefacts. As well as the two open area excavations four other square barrows were trail trenched in 1987 and two graves were identified.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Round barrow excavated by Mortimer in 1865. Barrow 32 is 245m S of 31. It is 15.5m in diameter and 0.3m high and very ploughed down. Excavated in 1865. Contained two primary crouched burials in separate graves beneath two levels of flint-paving; food vessel with one, bronze dagger and handle with the other. Two secondary inhumations above pavements, skull only remaining of one. Dish-shaped hole W of centre with burnt wood and decayed matter. Just NE, secondary cremation with burnt wood; unburnt lower jaw of dog nearby. Potsherds, including beaker, animal bones and teeth, flints, fragment of stone axe and of leaf shaped arrowhead in moundThe presence of leaf-shaped arrowhead in mound indicates an Early Neolithic set of activity in vicinity - it is beautiful arrowhead. Was this originally an oval barrow?
Site_description: Mortimer Barrow 32. SE 8107 5581. B: Barrow 32, 46ft diam, 1ft high, reduced by ploughing, excavated 1865. Contained two primary crouched burials in separate graves beneath two levels of flint-paving; food vessel with one, bronze dagger and handle with the other. Two secondary inhumations above pavements, skull only one remaining of one. Dish-shaped hole west of centre with burnt wood and decayed matter. Just north-east, secondary cremations with burnt wood; un-burnt lower jaw of dog nearby. Potsherds, including beaker, animal bones and teeth, flints, fragment of stone axe and of leaf shaped arrow hear in mound. Barrow 32-two beakers, groups S2 (w); FP. In Hull Museum ACC No 22642. 'B' is virtually destroyed and is discernible only as a superficial ground swelling <1> SE 811568 'Tumuli', Mortimer barrows 31/32 excavated 1865. The former is scheduled and visible from the air and on the ground, the latter virtually destroyed, 1973 <2> Cross reference MHU 9780, 9781, 9782, 9784 <3> Round Barrow 32: Mortimer barrow 32, diameter 46ft (14m) by 1ft (0.30m) high, opened in June 1865, contained 2 pavements of angular flints, one above the other. Below lay 2 graves each containing a contracted inhumation, one associated with a food vessel, the other a bronze dagger blade and pommel. Other burials comprised part of a human skull, a crouched inhumation and a cremations. A dish-shaped hole contained decayed matter mixed with small pieces of burnt wood...Numerous sherds, belonging to at least 7 vessels, animal bones flint discs, flakes, the broad end of a leaf-shaped arrowhead and the small end of a polished stone axe were scatted on the old surface line. Further sherds in the mound enabled a total of 8 different vessels to be recorded, 6 of which were portions of highly-ornamented beakers... The site survives merely as a slight swelling (1971); its cropmark shows as a ring-ditch, 75ft in diameter <4> NAR Listing <5> Two Bronze Age round barrows; 'A' still extant, contained a primary inhumation in a grave; 'B', now virtually destroyed, contained primary crouched inhumations with secondary cremations & inhumations; Neolithic/Bronze Age flint implements <6>

Site_summary: <gg summary>: The barrow (Greenwell 61), contained seven burials, one with a Beaker, others with flints, a jet button and an antler pick. Neolithic pits with bowl rim sherds, an arrowhead and flints were also recovered from the site. Note that Early Neolithic Towthorpe sherds were found in a pit that the barrow was later erected over implying the presence of ENEO activity in this zone. A total of seven individuals were buried in this barrow but three (one child, one old adult and one adult male, all inhumations) lacked grave goods The primary burial was with a Beaker and the others were likely EBA in date

Site_description: <site summary>: This one is LXIV (64) 23m in diameter and 0.45m high. note disturbed scattered remains of a male in mound and also fragments of a Beaker pot. Possibly the disturbed primary burial. Also a bone pin in the mound. The mound was 70ft in diameter and 2 1/2ft high at the time of Greenwell's excavation, which revealed an inner mound 18ft in diameter and 1 1/2ft high. A central grave contained a disturbed skeleton with much charcoal, and at the bottom an undisturbed burial with more charcoal and some remains of wood was seen. South of the centre and above the surface was a secondary inhumation. The body of the mound contained two beaker fragments, a bone pin, and bone and flint implements

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Note what is of interest about this barrow is that a high number of old and aged individuals (both male and female) were interred. Was this place specifically for the deposition of older members of the community (although one infant  was also noted). Out of 12 individuals, only 8 were accompanied by grave goods. A  central grave which contained an inhumation, a cremation, and, 6 ins above natural surface level, a food vessel burial in which the body was protected by two willow planks, had disturbed an earlier beaker burial (2). Ten other inhumations, some disturbed, two associated with drinking cups, and two under a mound inside the inner ditch, were seen. Another inner mound cntained no burials. A quartzite pebble macehead was found in the soil of the barrow (a). (2) Note this barrow had been disturbed by the operation of driving in stakes for sheep nets!
Site_description: <site summary>: Greenwell's No 63, now rectangular, 84 ft by 94 ft and 2 1/2 ft high, with crop marks of ring ditches, 56 ft and 115 ft in diameter, with possibly an intermediate one 82 ft in diameter; visible on APs (2). Greenwell, excavating when the mound was 78 ft diameter and 6 1/2 ft high (a), found the innermost ditch, which had unexcavated causeways, 12 to 16 ft apart, not reaching ground surfce level but forming a series of troughs round the barrow.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Round barrow excavated by Greenwell in 1860's and by Pacitto in 1968. Originally 66ft in diameter with an inner mound of 3ft. Two cists from the barrow now lie in Rudston Churchyard.Barrow had Early Neolithic activity under it It should be noted that an unbelievably huge amount of worked flint (scrapers and flakes predom) and EN pottery sherds came from the mound (see Kinnes and Longworth 1985: 61-62)Mainly Beaker burials re-using what must have been an Early Neolithic oval barrow
Site_description: Round barrow named Greenwell 62 that was excavated by him in 1869 and by Pacitto in 1968. Originally 66ft in diameter, with an inner mound of earth 3ft high capped by a layer of chalk rubble. Very little was left of the barrow in 1968, no primary burials were evident, these had probably been destroyed in antiquity. The secondary burials had been removed from the central pit in 1869, however three additional crouched inhumations were found during the 1968 works. Examination of the eastern flank of the mound in 1960 by C. and E. Grantham produced flint implements as well as Neolithic pottery. Two cists from Greenwell's excavation now lie in the village churchyard. <1> Description from N. Loughlin & K.R. Miller in 'A Survey of Archaeological Sites' from 1979. <2> A copy of the Ancient Monuments County of Humberside Scheduled Record for Rudston Beacon and round barrows to the east from the Department of Environment in 1959. <3> A copy of the Yorkshire Archaeological Society Record Card. <4> A copy of the Hull Museum Record Card. <5> A copy of a plan of the A.L. Pacitto excavation from the Yorkshire Archaeological Journal Volume 44. <6> When Greenwell excavated the barrow in 1864 he found a central grave pit cutting through the turf mound into solid chalk. It contained two cists, one with three inhumations and a beaker, the other with a cremation and beaker; between the cists and the side of the grave was a further cremation with a beaker. Four more burials, one certainly intrusive, were found above a bed of charcoal. Outside the area of the gravepit, above the old ground surface two inhumations were found, one with a food vessel. When Pacitto re-excavated the barrow in 1968 he discovered an encircling ditch and three secondary crouched inhumations within the mound. He concluded that the barrow was built on a Neolithic occupation site and that its primary burial was destroyed when the grave pit for the two cists was constructed. <7> Aerial photograph showing Rudston Beacon and round barrows to the east. <8> Cross reference with SMR 9880, 13368, 13369 and 13370, Scheduled as part of 'Rudston Beacon and round barrows to the east'. <9> 'Tumulus' printed and shown on O.S. 6" first edition map. <10> 'Tumulus' printed and shown on O.S 25" first edition map. <11> Photocopy of the Proceedings at Meetings of the Royal Archaeological Institute from 3rd December 1869, from The Archaeological Journal Volume 27, 1870. <12> Aerial photograph showing ring ditch of barrow and ditch between the barrow and the Woldgate Cursus. <13> Photocopied Excavation Report 'Rudston Barrow LXII: The 1968 Excavation by A.L. Pacitto', from The Yorkshire Archaeological Journal, Volume 44, 1972. <14> Photocopied extract and illustration from I.A. Kinnes and I.H. Longworth Catalogue of the Excavated Prehistoric and Romano-British Material in the Greenwell Collection. <15> Cross reference with SMR 9030, the Cist in Rudston Churchyard which originally came from this barrow. <16>

Site_summary: Scheduled round barrow 350m west of Cot Nab Farm.gg summary>: Cremation with Food Vessel
Site_description: Bronze Age Round Barrow.Scheduling Description SAM County Number 19a <1> One of five barrows Scheduled as one of ' five barrows at Cot Nab Farm' SAM NO'S 19A-19E, Ploughed 3ft high <2> Cross Reference SMR 9791 <3>National Archaeological Record, Mortimer Barrow C68. Ploughed down but surviving as well defined mound <4> Mortimer barrow C68, diameter 66ft (20.1m) by 4ft and 8in high and opened June 1874, contained near its apex portico's of a cinerary urn and below an eliptical grave with an adult cremation. At the south end of the grave were four holes which had apparently contained wooden stakes within the enclosure formed by the holes was full og cavaities. The barrow (1971) survives as a very much ploughed and spread mound. The site also appears as a ring ditch on aerial photographs <5> Description, diameter 6ft  6, height 4ft 8incs, 1. At centre was elliptical grave 5ft by 2ft 9incs and 2ft deep dug into old ground surface. A ridge of burnt adult bones 30incs long, lay in north east end of grave. At south east of grave were four post holes surrounding a hole about the size of a large cinerary urn and containing 'Unctuous earth', 2. At centre but near the top of the mound were some fragments of cinerary urn' <6> Aerial Photograph <7>Scheduling Amendment <8> The monument includes a prehistoric round barrow, one of a group on this part of the Yorkshire Wolds. The barrow mound is made from earth and chalk rubble, stands 0.75m high and has a diameter of 25m. The barrow is spread and slightly rounded, the result of regular ploughing over the years. A ditch, from which material was excavated during the construction of the monument surrounds the barrow mound. This has become in-filled over the years and is no longer visible at ground level, but survives as a buried feature 3m in width. The monument was investigated by the antiquarian J R Mortimer in 1874; one cremation and a number of pot sherds, thought to come from a cremation urn, were found <9>

Site_summary: Round barrow, west of Cot Nab Farm<gg summary>: Two individuals but only one with grave goods; note Food Vessel sherds in the mound Jet necklace
Site_description: Round Barrow. Scheduled Ancient Monument No 19b. One barrow scheduled as one of 'five barrows at Cot nab Farm' (SAM no's 19a-19e), ploughed but visible <1> Barrow Cemetery SMR 9791 <2>  SE 8146567  . Excavated 1866  has been so far reduced as to be distinguishable only as a broad ground swelling <3> Mortimer barrow 64, opened June 1866 and 1868 and 30ft (9.1m) in diameter by approximate 2ft (0.6m) high, contained a female inhumation in an oval grave, accompanied by the remains of a jet necklace. In the floor of the grave a circular hole contained calcined human bones. Nothing is now visible on the ground; on Aps its site marked by a ring-ditch, diameter 65ft (19.8m) <4>  Aerial Photograph <5>  Monument Descheduled <6> 'C', now destroyed, contained a rock cut grave with a crouched inhumation <7>

Site_summary: Scheduled round barrow<gg summary>: Barrow C69 is 20m in diameter and 2.3m high and was excavated in 1874. Contained 13 primary crouched burials, 1 primary cremation with food vessel on chalk slab pavement at mound base. Further three crouched burials 1 ft above base, one with food vessel, one with flint flake. Central grave H, empty. Overlaying dome-shaped pavement of flints, 38 ft diam, 5 ft high. Disturbed crouched burial at apex of mound; two urned cremations to E. Accumulation of rubbly chalk at W, probably from trench G, 23 ft long, possibly abandoned encircling trench. Finds : several flint flakes, portion of egg-shaped hammer head, barbed arrow head and animal bones.Note on the ground surface there were several burials, mainly of children, all seemingly buried at the same time and most lack grave goods - was there some kind of disaster/ epidemic/ disease causing such as terrible event?Out of the 21 individuals interred in this barrow. 11 were accompanied by grave goods,more often than not a Food Vessel . There are also some transitional FB/CU here and also intriguing as some of the cremations are actually in the FV not placed next to them, Transitional funerary practices in motion!!
Site_description: Round Barrow 300m south west of Cot Nab Farm. Scheduling Record <1> Scheduling Record <2> Cross Reference Barrow Cemetary SMR 9791 <3>  SE 81375673 (B) Excavated 1874  Ploughed down but survives as a well defined mound <4>  Mortimer barrow C69, 60ft. (18.3m) in diameter by 7.5ft, (2.3m) high and opened in June 1874, contained an adult inhumation at its apex, 2 cinerary urns containing  cremations, beneath which lay a pavement of rough angular flints covering the whole of the mond's circumference. Beneath the flints occurred three inhumations, one of which was accompanied by a food vessel, and at the base, 13 inhumations and 1 cremation. The latter was accompanied by a 'food vase'. The inhumations consisted of adults and children: one of them was accompanied by a food vessel, another by a poor flint flake. Under the centre of the barrow lay a small grave, nothing was found in it. In the mounf were several flint flakes, a portion of a hammer head and a barbed arrowhead. The barrow survives as a ploughed mound (1971), and on aerial photographs is tangential to a large ring ditch (PRN 5848) <5> Aerial Photograph <6> Scheduled Monument amendment. Scheduled area revised; monument name now 'round Barrow 300m south west of Cot Nab Farm' National Monument no 21084 <7> The monument includes a prehistoric round barrow, one of a group of barrows in this area of the Yorkshire Wolds. The barrow mound stands to a height of 1m, and has a diameter of 25m. It is evenly rounded and spread as a result of ploughing. The mound is surrounded by a ditch, which was excavated during its construction. It is no longer visible at ground level but survives as a buried feature 3m wide. The barrow mound was opened in 1874, as part of antiquarian researches by J R Mortimer, when a burial and a number of associated worked flints were found <8>

Scheduled as Bowl barrow on Huggate Wold, 400m north-north-west of Watermanhole Reservoir.<gg summary>: Likely cremation in Collared urn, but disturbed; also with a fine black flint dagger (called spearhead)
Site_description: <site summary>: . Barrow 220. A round barrow excavated in 1881 by a Mr Thomas and in 1882 by Mortimer. In 1973, the Ordnance Survey described it as a slight ground swelling of lighter soil. Details of Thomas' excavation are few. Mortimer's full account of his work is as follows: "On February 25th, 1882, we re-examined this barrow by turning over the greater portion, during which we took from the mound the larger and apparently freshly-broken portion of a fine spearhead (sic dagger) of black flint. This specimen is very thin and beautifully chipped on both sides. Whether or not Mr Thomas obtained the other portion we were not able to ascertain, neither do we know what further discovery he made in this barrow. Possibly the large cinerary urn which he took from one of the three mounds was found here".

Site_description: <site summary>: Mortimer barrow 221. Scheduled as Bowl barrow on Huggate Wold, 500m north-north-west of Horsedale Plantation.Part of a tightly clustered group of four barrows- this is barrow 221, and is set just slightly south-east of the others (75m away); it was  previously opened by J Silburn.

Site_description: <site summary>:  This is barrow 222 - part of a tight cluster of four, all situated within 50m of each other. This is 0.65m high, and had been excavated previously, results not known. A cremation apparently in a wooden receptacle, now decayed, and a badly decayed inhumation with three flint implement scrapers and flakes) were recovered.

Site_summary: Mortimer barrow 224. Scheduled as Bowl barrow on Huggate Wold, 700m north-west of Horsedale Plantation.<gg summary>:  About 8 feet east of the centre was a deposit of burnt chalk and soil mixed with calcined human bones representing the remains of several individuals. Heads of at least three adult humeri along with others were noted. A flint knife and unburnt animal bone was found . This deposit appeared to extend upwards also, almost to the apex of the mound. Burnt material was also found within the mound itself. Lying on the original ground surface at the approximate centre of the barrow was an adult male inhumation, laid on its back but with legs bent and hands raised to the head. Beside the skull was a flint knife, positioned point downwards. A cremation deposit representing the remains of an adult was found by the inhumation's right knee. 2 feet west of the skeleton was an oval pit about 3.5 feet deep and measuring 2.5 feet by 1.75 feet at the base. It featured chalk rubble, burnt earth and charcoal, but no trace of human remains. Unburnt human and animal remains were also recovered from the mound, the former perhaps representing a secondary inhumation?
Site_description: POSSIBLE LONG BARROW SEE RCHM AP PLOT<site summary>: This is Neolithic oval/ squashed round barrow, situated 170m to the NE of EBA barrow 223. A Neolithic round barrow excavated partially by Mortimer in March 1882. In 1973, the Ordnance Survey recorded it as a superficial well-spread mound of soil visible within an arable field. When Mortimer excavated the barrow, the mound was about 30 inches in maximum height. Beneath the mound, he found extensive traces of in situ burning, particularly under the eastern half of the mound.Note that barrows 223 and 227, originally recorded here, have now been recorded separately. See associated monument records.

Site_summary: <gg_summary>:  One burial lacked grave goods, the rest accompanied by Food Vessels or Collared UrnNote there are unusual transitional vessel types from this barrow

Part of a group of four barrows clustered very tightly together on top of Holm Dale escarpment. It was 0.85m high and contained four inhumations, two with food vessels and a cremation in an inverted urn. Other human bones including a skull were scattered through-out.

A circular flint flake and decayed wood was associated with one of them.

A trench extending E to W was excavated in 1882 uncovering a large grave containing 6 crouched burials. Fragments of three broken skeletons were scattered across the grave. An ornamented food vessel 6 1/4 ins high was just above the skull of interment 3. Eight feet S of the grave there was another crouched burial. A ditch encircled the barrow

Site_summary: Mortimer barrow 229. Scheduled as Bowl barrow 780m northeast of Watermanhole Reservoir.<gg summary>: It contained two crouched inhumations and a cremation. One inhumation in a central grave was associated with a deposit of bones, mostly human, interpreted as an earlier burial disturbed by the later burial or a ritual deposit. Further human bones came from the mound, also flint implements, potsherds and part of a greenstone axe. A ditch within the mound encircled the burials except for a break of 9 feet - see plan.
Site_description: <site summary>:  . This is a bowl barrow, 229. It is 21m in diameter and 1.6m high, excavated in 1882.

Site_summary: Mortimer barrow 230. Scheduled as Bowl barrow on Huggate Wold, 700m north-north-west of Watermanhole Reservoir.<gg summary>: Early Neolithic oval barrow with a later unurned cremation (undated) in the mound  A pair of primary inhumations laid beside each other, one with its head to the north, the other to the south, in a roughly central grave, each accompanied by a flint leaf-shaped arrowhead. Mortimer's re-excavation noted that the core of the mound was of bluish clay, and that this was covered with earth. He found some dispersed burnt human bones near the centre (it is not clear whether he means centrally within or beneath the mound), which he suggested was a cremation disturbed by Thomas' digging.<NRHE HOBUID: 61534; https://www.pastscape.org.uk/hob.aspx?hob_id=61534&sort=2&type=&typeselect=c&rational=a&class1=None&period=None&county=None&district=None&parish=None&place=&recordsperpage=10&source=text&rtype=monument&rnumber=61534#>
Site_description: <site summary>: . Huggate Wold  230 is a Neolithic oval barrow, situated less than 200m from several EBA barrows. A Neolithic round barrow excavated by a Mr Thomas in 1881 and again by Mortimer in 1882. In 1973, the Ordnance Survey reported that the barrow survived solely as a superficial, well-spread mound. Details of Thomas' excavation were obtained by Mortimer from a couple of the workmen involved in the excavation. They found a pair of primary inhumations laid beside each other,. [note that Huggate Wold 220 and 231 were formerly recorded together in Pastscape, but have now been recorded separately. See associated monument records]

Site_summary: Mortimer barrow 223. Scheduled as Bowl barrow on Huggate Wold, 580m northwest of Horsedale Plantation.<gg summary> Disturbed (by Silburn) burials with Food Vessel
Site_description: <site summary>:  Huggate 223 - part of a more extensive barrow cemetery. A round barrow of probable Early Bronze Age date dug into in 1851 by J Silburn and again in 1882 by Mortimer. When Mortimer excavated, the barrow survived to a height of 2.5 feet. Centrally beneath the mound he found a subrectangular grave-pit orientated north-south and measuring 7 feet by 4.5 feet, and 3.5 feet deep. Silburn had emptied the southern half of the pit during his excavation, which seems to have involved digging a small hole down throught the approximate centre of the mound. The northern half had survived this process, and Mortimer found the legs of an adult inhumation, by the feet of which were the bones of a small child. In the disturbed southern half were human and animal bones left behind by Silburn, plus one of Silburn's commemmorative strips of lead bearing his name. Circa 2 feet east of the grave-pit and about 1 foot above the pre-mound surface was an inverted food vessel. Nothing was found with it. In 1973, the Ordnance Survey recorded the barrow as a superficial, well-spread mound of lighter soil visible within an arable field. [NB this barrow was originally recorded as part of SE 85 NE 17. That record should be consulted for additional information and sources]

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Round barrow excavated in 1876. Contained a central oval grave with a primary crouched burial, food vessel and a flint tool.THE fOOD vESSEL WITH THE CHILD IS A TOTAL WORK OF ART - UNIQUE AND WITH EXCISTED DECORATION
Site_description: Barrow C97, small mound that was excavated in 1876. It was found to contain a central oval grave with a primary crouched burial, an elaborately ornamented food vessel and a flint tool. The barrow measured 18m in diameter and 0.3m in height. <1> Scheduled Monument Record from 1958, 'Four Barrows on Garrowby Wold'. This barrow was de-scheduled in 1994. <2> Cross reference with a round barrow cemetery on Garrowby Wold, SMR 4216. <3> Amendment to the List of Scheduled Ancient Monuments, de-scheduling of one of four round barrows on Garrowby Wold, barrow 46a. <4> Photocopied extract 'The Excavation of Two Bronze Age Round Barrows at Irton Moor, Yorkshire', from The Yorkshire Archaeological Journal, Volume 66, 1994. <5> 'Kitty Hill, round barrow situated behind a farmhouse at the foot of Garroby Hill. Exavated in 1876, it contained a central burial, a number of cremations, beaker fragments and part of an Anglo-Saxon shield boss. The barrow stands in a pasture field and is still several feet high'. <6> Pastscape Website description. <7>

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Scheduled monument of round barrow excavated in 1876. Contained a central rock-cut oval grave with a primary crouched burial and crushed food vessel.
Site_description: B<site summary>: arrow C98, medium sized and excavated in 1876. The barrow contained a rock cut oval grave with primary crouch burial with a crushed food vessel. Lies south-east of barrow C.97, still visible in 1967. central oval grave contained a crouched inhumation, with a food vessel nearby'. <2> Scheduled Monument Record from 1958, 'Four Barrows on Garrowby Wold'. <3> Cross reference with round barrow cemetery on Garrowby Wold, SMR 4216. <4> Artice extract 'The Neolithic Pottery of Yorkshire', from Proceedings of the Prehistoric Society, 1937. <5> Amendement to the List of Scheduled Ancient Monuments, name changed to 'Round barrow 100m north west of farm on Garrowby Hill Top'. <6> 'Kitty Hill, round barrow situated behind a farmhouse at the foot of Garroby Hill. Exavated in 1876, it contained a central burial, a number of cremations, beaker fragments and part of an Anglo-Saxon shield boss. The barrow stands in a pasture field and is still several feet high'. <7> Pastscape Website description. <8>

Site_summary: <gg summary>:  Near-central oval grave contained primary crouched burial, with food vessel and two flint tools. Pieces of burnt wood, fragments of food vessel and flint flakes in soil in grave. Bone fragments, probably human, in hole in chalk floor of grave below skeleton. Above grave, remains of primary inhumation, dark matter, fragments of bronze, probably a knife, found nearby. Mortimer barrow 63 is one of a group of four square-ditched barrows. The square ditch must relate to the secondary central inhumation and not to the primary burial with a food vessel There were three individuals but only 2 were accompanied by grave goods. There are a lot of knives here
