A small ledge had been cut into the western corner of the grave. The grave backfill contained two finds, a flint flake and a sherd of Beaker pottery, as well as mussel, whelk and oyster shells. It is thought that there was some form of grave structure of organic material, possibly a hollowed out tree trunk or a wattle-built construction
Site_description: First identified as a single ditched ring ditch located from air photographs. (1)In 2004 the Trust for Thanet Archaeology carried out a watching brief. A ring ditch and a central crouched inhumation burial were found. Worked flints, animal bones and oyster shells were found in the ditch fill. A polished Neolithic flint axe was also found in the ditch. This object may have been intentionally placed in the base of the ditch, having been discovered in the Early Bronze Age, possibly even during the digging of the barrow ditch. Other worked flint from the ditch was of Early or Middle Bronze Age date. The central grave was rectangular in plan, orientated east-north-east/west-south-west. A small ledge had been cut into the western corner of the grave. The grave backfill contained two finds, a flint flake and a sherd of Beaker pottery, as well as mussel, whelk and oyster shells. It is thought that there was some form of grave structure of organic material, possibly a hollowed out tree trunk or a wattle-built construction. The crouched inhumation was of a woman probably over the age of 40 and accompanied by a well preserved Long Necked Beaker which had been placed at her feet. The body was on its left side with the head at the northern end of the grave. The beaker had been damaged prior to deposition. A post hole was found on the edge of the ring ditch. The ring ditch was probably c.14m across. (2)

Site_summary: An Iron Age burial was excavated near Chilham Castle in 1994. During the work by Canterbury Archaeological Trust a mirror was found within an Iron Age burial with two small copper alloy objects, a late Iron Age mirror and a brooch, and a small quantity of sherds from a single cremation vessel. During subsequent excavations by Dover Archaeological group a further brooch, fragments of cremated bone and more pottery sherds from the same pot were found.<gg_summary>:<Celtic Art db: https://doi.org/10.5284/1000086>
Site_description: IA burial nr Chilham Castle, mirror found with burial, 1994 by Canterbury Arhaeological Trust. No further details available, report forthcoming from K Parfitt, CAT (1)Two copper alloy objects, a late Iron Age mirror and a brooch, and a small quantity of sherds from a single cremation vessel were found on land belonging to the Chilham Castle Estate. A small excavation of the find spot was undertaken by Dover Archaeological Group in June 1994 and uncovered a further brooch, fragments of cremated bone and more pottery sherds from the same pot. (2)

Site_summary: Neolithic to Early Roman activity at Tutt Hill, with activity focused on the Neolithic and Late Bronze Age<gg_summary>: E/MBA cremation associated with ring ditches but no gg; four M/LBA cremations at least two of which also associated with ring ditches (potentially two urned, two more with less clear-cut grave goods/pyre goods).
Site_description: The Oxford Archaeological Unit was commissioned by Union Railways (South) Ltd (URS) to conduct a field evaluation of land at Tutt Hill, Westwell, Kent.  The work was conducted in two stages: An open area excavation was carried out between 8th and 18th March 1999, following the discovery of significant archaeological remains during a watching brief on geotechnical test pits.  A second stage of evaluation was carried out in the surrounding area between 29th March and 9th April 1999.The watching brief and subsequent investigations revealed a diffuse scatter of prehistoric features, with one significant concentration of features and finds located in the main excavation area.  Twelve of the fourteen evaluation trenches contained no features at all, suggesting either that the group of pottery-rich pits in the main excavation area are the remanant of a more extensive but severely truncated site, or that they represent a verey localised area of occupation.The main excavation area was 40 m long and 20 m wide, with a 2m square extension on the south-western side.  The subsequent evaluation comprised fourteen trenches, each 30 m long and 1.8 m wide.  The only significant archaeological features comprised three pits of late Bronze Age and early Iron Age date, two of which produced substantial pottery groups, and three shallow ditches which are likely to be contemporary with the pits. (1)Subsequent general watching brief over a 1.1km stretch and a targeted watching brief of a 150m x 200m area revealed evidence of Neolithic to Early Roman activity. Two flint scatters show Neolithic - Early Bronze Age activity, with the Mid-Late Neolithic also represented by two pits. Four ring ditches representing ploughed-out roundbarrows with associated Beaker pottery date to the Late Neolithic-Early Bronze Age. These are heavily truncated, and no evidence of burials were found, though an Early-Middle Bronze Age cremation was located near the ring ditches. There was also a single Early Bronze Age pit.The Mid Bronze Age is represented by 3 sub-rectangular pits and a cremation pit contianing an inverted bucket urn.The Late Bronze Age sees the laying out of a field system, in addition to a few pits.Activity seems to decline after this, and the Mid Iron Age-Early Roman period is represented by only two pits, a cremation. A furnace-like structure at the west of the watching brief area may be Iron Age due to associate pottery finds, though these may be residual and the furnace may be much later in date.There are also a number of undated features, notable pits and a few cremations. Some medieval pottery. (2)Additional bibliogrpahy. (3-8)

Site_name_other: Bronze Age and Iron Age activity
Site_summary: Bronze Age and Iron Age features found at Chapel Mill, as part of CTRL works.<gg_summary>: Two truncated/disturbed LIA cremations - one (205) with what were almost certainly gg (burnt cu-alloy fragments, potentially from the pyre, burnt animal bone, pot); the other (213) with burnt clay (also potentially from the pyre) but no other contemporary material in the fills (there was also intrusive post-med brick). Unburnt, disarticulated human remains were recovered from a tree throw nearby and may represent an earlier/contemporary burial (it was cut by a ditch containing LIA material).
Site_description: Thirteen trenches were excavated and archaeological features were found in two of them. A ditch produced a small quantity of mid-late Iron Age pottery as well as residual Bronze Age pottery and a second, smaller ditch was aligned adjacent to and parallel with the larger ditch. This ditch produced no finds but it is also likely to be mid-late Iron Age in date. A single Bronze Age pit contained a substantial amount of pottery from a simple tub-shaped vessel that has affinities with either the Deverel-Rimbury or post-Deverel-Rimbury (Plain Ware) pottery traditions of the late Bronze Age date (1750-900 BC). (1)A strip, map and sample excavation carried out on the same site identified few new features. Two cremations were found near the Bronze Age pit, and were dated to the Iron Age on the basis of a small amount of pottery. Two parallel linear boundary ditches are thought to be of Late Iron Age date on the basis of a small amount of pottery from one of the ditches. (2-4)

Site_summary: Late Iron Age and early Romano-British features and pottery found in 1999 at site south of Snarkhurst Wood prior to CTRL works.<gg_summary>: Two LIA cremations - one (236) with 78g LIA pottery sherds, and adult male cremation (180g) and redeposited pyre material in the grave fill (not included here as no definitive gg); the second, an unexcavated feature (Context 20) with at least one burial and a pedestal urn (mentioned only in the overall publication and in the scheme-wide pottery report).
Site_description: The eastern part of the site produced evidence for a late Iron Age/early Romano-British settlement (100BC - 100AD).  Features included rectangular and subrectangular enclosure ditches and several post-hole structures, including one small, circular building with a central post, and five four-posters.  Other evidence for occupation included a small kiln or furnace associated with metal-working slag, and several storage or rubbush pits.  Burial evidence was restricted to a single cremation.  The settlement is likely to be a continuation of the site identified during construction of the M20 in the 1950's(1).(See TQ 85 NW 121 and TQ 85 NW 123)Post excavation assessment report from December 2000. 1487 pottery sherds from 74 contexts dating from Late Iron Age to pre-Flavian.  In addition a small numbers of sherds dating from AD 70-200. Cremation remains identified as possible adult male.  Cremation is undated but from context may be Late Iron Age or Roman. (3)Additional bibliography. (4-5)

Site_name_other: Iron Age and early Roman cremation burials
Site_summary: Iron Age burials classified by Whimster as No.121. Twenty-five La Tene III to late C1st AD pottery vessels were excavated from nine cremation graves in 1948.Summary from record TR 13 NE 13: C1st AD urn field - Belgic/Romano-British overlap<Whimster 1981, 475>: 121. Folkestone, Cheriton TR 19336925 La Tene III to late first century A.D. pottery vessels were excavated from 9 cremation graves in 1948. 25 further vessels, from an unknown number of graves, were accidentally encountered. Two associated brooches are 'Colchester' forms, and two othersof later first century A.D. type.<Thompson 1982, 670-1>: Most of the pottery from the burial groups together with the unassociated material is of late 1st century AD date and later but some vessels are evidently earlier (from burial groups 1 4 (and potentially also 9 but not included here as the other vessels from this grave are definitely early Roman)). Only one vessel is definitively pre-Conquest (from the builders' trench).Burial Groups 1 and 4 and the pre-Conquest urn from the builders trench is recorded here.
Site_description: TR 19273687. A C1st AD Belgic and early Romano-British cremation cemetery or urn-field was discovered in April 1948 when workmen were digging a trench for a proposed extension to a housing estate at Cheriton, Folkestone. The site, situated between Horn Street and the main Ashford Road, was discovered when large quantities of pottery was found. The Borough Surveyor granted permission for an emergency excavation to take place; the work being done by students of the Folkestone Emergency Teachers Training College under the direction of P.J Tester and H.F Bing. The pottery from nine burial groups represented c.25 vessels with five bronze brooches, one decorated with enamel, and some flint  flakes. About the same number of vessels were represented from unstratified contexts in the original trench. The pottery ranged from coarse ware, Belgic in character, to samian pottery c AD 80 - 120. Some of the burials were thus earlier than AD 43, and extended into the Roman period as late as the end of the  C1st. Burnt bones were found in, or associated with, some of the cinerary urns. The vessels from the most northerly cremations (group VIII) appear to have been placed in a small cist of wood or other perishable material, which had collapsed. Two patches of blackened sand with flakes of charcoal were found three - four feet below the surface. Ox bones, fragments of coarse pottery and corroded iron including part of a knife blade were in the sand, and may represent an occupation site pre-dating the burials.  (1) Finds from this site are on display in Folkestone Museum.  (2) TR 193369. Cheriton, Folkestone. Iron Age burials classified by Whimster as No.121. Twenty-five La Tene III to late C1st AD  pottery vessels were excavated from nine cremation graves in 1948. Twenty-five vessels from an unknown number of graves were accidentally encountered. Two associated brooches are `Colchester' forms, and two others of later C1st AD type. It is difficult to determine with any certainty the exact extent of cemetery No.121 at Folkestone.   (3) A C1st urnfield at Cheriton, on the Greensand Ridge, was discovered in 1948.    (4) TR 196370. Cheriton. Colchester brooches in two burials. Included in a list of brooches found with Aylesford culture burilas. (5) Cheriton, Folkestone. Included in a catalogue of poppy-head beakers  in Britain. (6)

Site_name_other: Late Iron Age/Romano-British settlement or villa site
Site_summary: A Late Iron Age enclosed settlement associated with a road and cremation burials. The site continued in use during the Roman period. A small settlement or a possible villa existed in the immediate vicinity. In the late 3rd or early 4th century a group of nine aisled buildings were constructed, possibly barns serving the villa/settlement.<gg_summary>: Eleven definite and six possible cremation burials were found. These were dated, on the basis of the cremation urns, to the late first century B.C. or early first century AD ... The Interim report for the evaluation (1998) notes that:Of the eleven definite cremation burials located, eight contained a single ceramic cremation urn, one contained two urns, one contained three ceramic urns and one contained three ceramic urns and a small bronze vessel. The dating of all the vessels was pre-Conquest.Contextual detail is lacking. Four 'burials' described as 'graves' but where no hr were identified are not recorded here.NB records represent a best fit of this summary given the absence of further information from Canterbury Archaeology. (e.g. it is not known which graves had loose bone and pots, which produced bone in pots).
Site_description: In 1985 Kent Archaeological Rescue Unit apparently carried out an excavation within the grounds of the Rectory. Pits and ditches of Roman date were supposedly found. It is also reported that walls of a building were found, possibly with a hypocaust. Work is also thought to have been carried out by Kent Archaeological Rescue Unit on land to the south on the medical centre and community hall site. (1)In April 1997 Canterbury Archaeological Trust carried out a watching brief began on work for new housing development at the site known as Glebeland at Harrietsham. Immediately archaeology was recovered and evaluation trenching commenced after consultation with the developer. Evidence gathered suggests that occupation of the site began in the Late Iron Age and continued into the Roman period until probably the 4thC. The site then seems to have been abandoned or contracted and a soil horizon accumulated over it. Cut into this soil horizon were the foundations of seven buildings.The settlement was found in the western side of the housing development site. A flint road bedded in chalk with side ditches (TQ 85 SE 137) aligned NE-SW led to and or through the site. To the south of the road a large N-S aligned ditch was discovered with a smaller ditch in front and a row of six post-holes probably formed a fence. This boundary ditch probably formed the beginning of the settlement. No structures were identified within the settlement area although a number of post-holes, other than the six mentioned above, were found, but with no apparent pattern. To the west of the boundary ditch a large feature was excavated which contained insufficient material to indicate that it was a rubbish or storage pit.Eleven, with a possible further six, cremation burials were found within the angle formed by the road and the boundary ditch, indicating that they were contemporary with each other. The concentration of burials in this area may be in part due to the depth of overburden being greater in this area, thus protecting it from plough damage. Of the eleven definite cremations, eight contained a single cremation, one contained two, one contained three ceramic urns and one contained three ceramic urns and a small bronze vessel. Only one of the burials had been cut by a later burial and another cut the road suggesting that it may have been in a state of disrepair at the time. (1)Geophysical survey to test for archaeological features just east of site found in 1997 during the CAT evaluation. Possible features located. (2).Predetermination evaluation on site showed that archaeological features indeed continued across this section of the field. It was not possible to identify what the features were or what age they were, other than the Late Iron Age/Romano-British road which was found where it was predicted to be and was in a good condition. (3)

Site_summary: Iron Age cremation burial found while hand-digging a grave in a new area of Ulcombe churchyard in 1995.<gg_summary>: NB A further (inhumation) burial with grave goods was found nearby in 2000 (see SID50137)
Site_description: A 'Belgic' ceramic pedestal jar and associated cremated human bone fragments were discovered by an employee of a funeral directors whilst hand-digging a grave in a recent extention of Ulcombe Churchyard. The vessel is a 'belgic' pedestal jar of type A3 (Thompson, BAR 108), and dates the cremation to between the mid first century BC to the early first century AD.The cremation is that of an adult female probably around the age of 35-45 (1).

Site_summary: Two metal brooches (Iron Age), a pin, and an inhumation with animal bone found in June 2000 by a gravedigger.NB An Iron Age cremation burial was discovered in the same grave yard in 1995 (see SID50136)
Site_description: In June 2000, Terry Standen (grave digger), located two Iron Age brooches, probably made of bronze, and a pin. Part of an inhumation with animal bone was also found. The finds could have come from a ditch. This was within c.3m of an Iron Age cremation burial found in 1995 (TQ 84 NW 51) (1).See Archaeologica Cantiana 2005, pp.181. (2)

Site_name_other: Dickson Land, rear of Canterbury Road
Site_summary: Watching brief on groundworks associated with residential development on "Dickson Land" to the rear of 48 Canterbury Road, Hawkinge. The work identified a Late IA/Early Conquest settlement with cremations/pyre deposits. Also identified were early Iron Age quarry pits and probable ovens and furnaces, together with traces of settlement. There was also evidence of possibly medieval or later field system.<gg_summary>: The evidence from this site was extremely truncated. 18 probable IA/Conquest period cremation deposits were identified in total based on the occurence of truncated pot bases/other finds/burnt material. Of these, only 3 were directly associated with human remains. Given the known occurrence of 'cenotaph' deposits in this area/period only deposits associated directly with human remains are recorded here. The evidence can be summarised as follows:LBA/EIA: one unaccompanied cremation burial (Pit 126)E/MIA: eight possible cremation burials of which five were associated with grave goods (Pits 31, 33, 37, 57, 159 within a group; Pot spread 102 isolated)(no human remains)M/LIA: five possible cremation burials (Pits 13, 27, 39, 80 and 86); 'most' associated with pottery bases from single vessels (no human remains)Belgic LIA: three possible cremation burials (Pits 55, 88 and 98), all associated with substantial quantities of pottery, in one case (Pit 55) also human remainsearly Roman: one pre-Flavian cremation burial (Pit 69) containing cremated human remains (c. 350g) and pottery from two vesselsSee MKE42998 for parent record for this site.
Site_description: Watching brief on groundworks associated with residential development on "Dickson Land" to the rear of 48 Canterbury Road, Hawkinge.  The work identified a Late IA/Early Conquest settlement with cremations/pyre deposits.  Also identified were EIA quarry pits and probable ovens and furnaces, together with traces of settlement.(TR 23 NW 207)  There was also evidence of possibly medieval or later field system.(TR 23 NW 209).A total of three ditches, two part of a possible boundary ditch, and ten pits were discovered, all of which contained pottery.  The pottery ranged from local ware to "Belgic type pottery all of which was grog tempered.  Eight of the pits contained pottery form a single vessel with tiny flecks of cremated bone.(1)

Site_summary: Bronze Age cremation and undated features found in August 2000 evaluation at Deal North Barracks.<gg_summary>: isolated (?MBA) cremation burial, found in an evaluation trench.
Site_description: During August 2000, five evaluation trenches were excavated to determine the extent of the cemetery and the general nature of any archaeological remains in the northern corner of the barracks, not previously investigated. Remains of a substantial basmented structure (identified as the former canteen) were located in one trench and four archaeological features predating the barracks complex were found in two other trenches. These features consisted of a cremation, probably dating to the Bornze Age, a pit, a ditch and a length of gully. Apart from the cremation, none of these features produced any reliable dating evidence. (1)

Site_summary: A cremation burial was found at South Willesborough close to the banks of the East Stour. A complete inverted saucepan pot of coarse "Belgic" grog-tempered ware of Middle Iron Age date was recovered close to a small concentration of Iron Age/early Romano-British pits. This pot measured 0.1m in diameter and was 0.15m deep and was removed intact. Within the pot were charcoal fragments and a small amount of cremated bone including tooth crowns. The bone was identifed as that of an infant thought to have died around the age of six months.<gg_summary>: An Iron Age cremation of an infant was also recovered, possiblyassociated with some nearby pits.
Site_description: Close to a small concentration of Iron Age/Early Romano-British pits part of an occupation site (TR 04 SW 124), a complete inverted saucepan pot (coarse "Belgic" grog-tempered ware of Middle Iron Age date) was recovered measuring 0.1m in diameter and 0.15m deep.  The pot was removed whole and its fill excavated under controlled conditions.  It was found to contain a silty sand fill with charcoal fragments and a small amount of cremated bone including tooth crowns.  The bone was identifed as that of an infant, with the age of death being around six months.  The pot appears to have been intentionally buried as part of the mortuary ritual.(1)

Parish_Community_Borough: BROADSTAIRS AND ST PETERS, THANET, KENT
Site_summary: An Early Bronze Age round barrow with multi-phased group burials.  Associated with this barrow were further burials around the site and within the ring-ditch.  Evidence of a second possible barrow was excavated nearby.  The barrow(s) may be part of a larger barrow cemetery evidence of which comes from cropmarks (TR 36 NE 407) and earlier investigations at the beginning of the 20th century.<gg_summary>: Perkins (1994) describes the site as follows: 'A round barrow (F. 298) with primary and secondary burials in a set of inter-cutting pits (F. 13/92), and associated fiat-graves (F. 200, F. 270).' Grave goods were associated with at least three of the central burials and an antler pick was found in one of the flat graves. The three large inter-cutting pits were located at the centre of the round barrow. These contained the remains of seven individuals, some crouched, others disarticulated and laid in varying orientations. A Beaker pot was deposited late in the sequence and may have been associated either with an infant (Pit B, Burial 4; facing west), or an adult (Pit C, Burial 6; facing south-east). Both of these individuals were laid on their left-hand sides. Most of a food vessel pot was deposited very early on in the sequence (in Pit B) and was completely crushed upon excavation (possibly by the addition of Burial 2). Such an association between Beakers and Food vessels is rarely encountered in burials. Gibson notes that Food Vessels themselves are rare in Southern England and rarer still in Kent (in Perkins 2004). C14 dates from the seven burials in the three intercutting pits span the period 2100 to 1496 cal BC - a considerable period. Given the complexities that exist regarding the stratigraphy of these burials, and the lack of clear correspondance between burials/pits they are all recorded here in one grave (Grave Pit 13). Grave goods are assigned to the relevant burials within the pit (based on info in Perkins 1994); separated dates are assigned to the C14 dated burials. The flat grave with the antler pick is recorded separately.
Site_description: In 1992 an evaluation excavation excavated a multi-phased beaker period burial group. At approximately TR39286635 a dense patch of flints was observed.  On excavation beaker fragments and human bones were found in an open patch surrounded by the flints.  Work uncovered a total of seven crouched burials all of which either in direct contact with the beaker or superimposed interments. The overall feature was irregular in shape  cut into the chalk. Three bowl shaped pits are presumed to have been graves cut into the floor of the feature. At a later date further burials were added. All burials are aligned n-s or nw-se and are of adults and infants.  Some have been damaged by plough and are missing bones, not necessarily as a result of this later activity.  It is thought that the burials might represent either a,  burials within the ring ditch of a round barrow or b, burials within the boundaries of a settlement and cut into the floor of a hut, paralleled at Cottington Lane, Ebbsfleet 1990. (1)Topsoil stripping and excavation in 1994.  The feature is a ring ditch of oval shape from a round barrow.  Central within the ditch is a group of three inter-cutting pits which contained seven crouched burials.  Five of which are incomplete and appear to be missing their skulls.  In one pit beneath the rib cage of one burial was a near complete undecorated beaker food vessel.  The eastern segment of the barrow ditch had been cut by a pit containing two superimposed crouch burials and a final separate crouched burial was found metres from the barrow to the nw.  Evidence from locals tells of further single burials found during the construction of the Seven Stones Estate just to the south-east. Thirty metres to the south-west part of a curving length of ditch was recorded which may have formed a circle.  A small ditch on the inside area of the ditch contained fragments of beaker sherds.  It is possible that this also formed a round barrow.(2)See also (3).

Site_name_other: Early - mid (?) Iron Age settlement and burials
Parish_Community_Borough: BROADSTAIRS AND ST PETERS, THANET, KENT
Site_summary: Excavation in 1992 -1994 uncovered Bronze Age and Iron Age sites. The early Iron Age remains spanning c. 550-350 BC. consist of parts of two apparently rectilinear enclosures formed by palisade trenches. They are sub-divided by lengths of internal ditch and part of a sub-rectangular enclosure with a recut or superimposed ditch. Within the enclosures are 2 complexes of post-holes representing hut sites or other structures. Scattered throughout the enclosures and beyond are pits. One pit contained a burial. Later the burial was partly cut by the palisaded ditch.Along the east and west boundaries of the site is a large flat bottomed feature with in sections what may be wheel ruts. It seems that this is a continuation of a feature seen in 1907 to cross the line of South Cliff Parade. Believed by Hurd who investigated this area in 1907 to be the return of a similar ditch see saw running north-east to be cut by the cliff line at Dumpton Gap.<gg_summary>: One formal pit burial together with several incidences of human remains and other fragments in pits. See also SID50104 for broader site context.
Site_description: Excavation in 1992 -1994 uncovered bronze age and iron age sites.  Early iron age remains spanning c. 550-350 BC. consist of parts of 2 apparently rectilinear enclosures formed by palisade trenches. They are sub-divided by lengths of internal ditch and part of a sub-rectangular enclosure with a recut or superimposed ditch. Within the enclosures are 2 complexes of post-holes representing hut sites or other structures. Scattered throughout the enclosures and beyond are pits. One pit contained a burial.  The bones are of good condition and of a well built adult.  Fragments of an iron buckle and a carved bone pin were found at the right and left shoulders.  The lay out of the burial, crouched, is different from the "chucked in the hole appearance" of other burials on the site.  Later the burial was partly cut by the palisaded ditch.Along the east and west boundaries of the site is a large flat bottomed feature with in sections what may be wheel ruts.  It seems that this is a continuation of a feature seen in 1907 to cross the line of South Cliff Parade at about TR39506631 and believed by Hurd who investigated this area in 1907 to be the return of a similar ditch see saw running north-east to be cut by the cliff line at Dumpton Gap at TR39536657.  The feature existed in the mid bronze age and in the form of a ditch was in use in the early iron age.  Hurd clearly thought the ditch was a defence enclosing the settlement in combination with the palisaded ditch.  It is also possible that it was just a sunken way or track running between parallel ditches.This area of excavation links up with discoveries made by Hurd (approx TR39286648) and T. C. Champion in the 1970's (TR39396629) around ten acres in total. (1-3)See also (4).

Site_summary: A Bronze Age cremation cemetery.<gg_summary>: A very fragmentary/disjointed set of evidence identified during two separate episodes of investigation at the site (in 1998 and 1999). Two possible instances of grave goods ; one recorded here, another a possible cenotaph:a) one Beaker pit with fragments of unidentifiable burnt bone together with an assemblage of fragments from two Beaker pots: RECORDEDb) one Deverel Rimbury pit from a cluster of pits thought to represent a pyre pit, a cremation pit and a marker post (no human remains were recovered): NOT RECORDED15g calcined bone was recovered from one pit from another cluster of pits, but these are thought potentially to represent unurned cremations (and so are not recorded here).
Site_description: In 1998 Archaeology South-East carried out a watching brief on topsoil stripping at Hawkinge Aerodrome. Two groups of cremations were found, dating to the Middle Bronze Age. One feature, a broad, shallow pit, contained a large quantity of burnt material, including bone. Discolouration of the natural subsoil at the base of the feature is almost certainly due to heat and it is believed that this may have been a pyre site. Nearby there was a large post hole. This may have been for a marker post. The features collectively belong to a Middle Bronze Age cremation cemetery. (1-2)

Site_summary: During construction work for a housing development a late Iron Age c. 1st century BC - 43 AD cremation burial was found. Also found were a wooden box and a bucket, a terra nigra dish, a bronze strainer bowl and a jug with an elaborately decorated handle. This evidence is seen as indicative of a high status settlement.<gg_summary>: the grave was excavated initially by the building contractors - all of the items are damaged/highly fragmented and much of the contextual detail is missing.
Site_description: During construction work on housing development a Aylesford-Swarling type (late iron age c. 1st century BC - 43 AD) cremation burial was found.  In association with the burial were a wooden box and a bucket, a terra nigra dish, a bronze strainer bowl and a jug with an elaborately decorated handle.  There was no evidence of additional burials, although the excavators suggested that the burial would imply the presence of a high status settlement. The burial is just to the north east of a later Romano-British road side settlement (TR 04 SW 117), approximately 800m east of a late iron age settlement (TQ 94 SE 37) and close to a findspot of early- mid iron age pottery (TR 04 SW 119). No further information about the burial or its goods are given.(1)Geophysical surveys (2-3).

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Two overlapping mid Bronze Age bell barrows. The earliest had been partly eroded away and the central burial cut by a later Roman Road. The later barrow, only partly within the excavation area was associated with a hearth, a possible boiling pit and a burnt mound.
Site_description: During excavation work on the line of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link, close to Springhead, two overlapping ring-ditches representing barrows were found at the head of the Ebbsfleet Valley.  The earliest had a diameter of c.18m and lay within the excavation area.  Only half of the surrounding ditch survived, due to erosion, and the central, urned cremation burial had been truncated by a later Roman road. The other barrow, size unclear, extended beyond the excavation area to the south-west.  The size of the surrounding ditch was similar to the earlier barrow which it only just overlapped.  Within the later barrow ditch a large quantity of burnt flint and charcoal was recovered.  The source of these finds were a large sub-circular hearth, a boiling pit and an associated burnt mound which had slumped into the fill of the barrow ditch.(1)

Site_summary: Late Bronze Age cremation cemetery found to the north-east of a late Bronze Age settlement (TQ 97 SE 50). Over 29 burials were recovered extending over an area of about 10 m in diameter. Many had suffered from plough damage and more burials may possibly extent northwards beyond the excavation area.<gg_summary>: Two separate cremation cemeteries - one MBA (a linear grouping of seven unurned burials); one M/LBA (a cluster of 25 burials) located within 400m of one another within the excavation area. Less than 1g burnt animal bone was recovered from three of these, otherwise unaccompanied, burials (one from the earlier cemetery, two from the later cemetery). These bone deposits were described in the published account as pyre goods. These burials could easily not be included in the ggdb but are included in case it is useful for discussions about the temporality of gg.<borderline_gg>
Site_description: Late Bronze Age cremation cemetery found to the north-east of a late Bronze Age settlement (TQ 97 SE 50). Over 29 burials were recovered extending over an area of about 10 m in diameter. Many had suffered from plough damage and more burials may possibly extent northwards beyond the excavation area. See [1 and 2].

Site_name_other: Late Neolithic or Bronze Age barrow
Site_summary: A double ring ditched barrow, just west of Whitehill Road. No primary burial was found, but a flexed adult burial was recovered cutting through the backfill of the inner ditch. No pottery was found, but an amber bead necklace was associated with the secondary burial.<gg_summary>: Beads associated with secondary inhumation dated to 1620 to 1440 cal BC
Site_description: A watching brief on groundworks for the Channel Tunnel Rail Link just west of Whitehill Road recorded the remains of an Early Bronze Age barrow (2000   1500 BC). The barrow consisted of a double ring ditch on the eastern side of the disused Gravesend West Railway cutting. No evidence was found for an overlying earth mound, which probably has been removed through a combination of ploughing and the construction of the railway cutting which had also removed part of the western side of the outer ditch. This ditch would have enclosed an area of 17m in diameter. A 2m berm separated the outer and inner ditches. No central burial was found although within the centre circle four postholes were found which may have been associated with the barrow. Cutting through the backfill of the inner ditch on the south side of the barrow was a poorly preserved flexed inhumation burial with head to the west. Around the neck area was an amber necklace. Parallel sites indicate that this burial may date to around 1600 BC.The fill of the ditches was dated using Optical Stimulated Luminescence and gave the following dates: Basal fill 15,000 BC; middle fill 5,600 BC; top fill 6,100 BC. These dates are obviously far too early. (1 & 2)Description from record TQ 56 NE 99:A double ring ditch recorded on the eastern side of the disused railway. The ditches were truncated and only survived where they were cut into the underlying chalk. The outer ditch measured 17m in diameter and varied in width from 0.45m to 1.45m and 0.15m and 0.42m deep. The inner ditch measured 11m diameter and was between 0.58m and 1.00m wide and survived between 0.16m and 0.32m deep. No stratigraphic relationship was evidence between the two ditches, due in part to the non-existence of any overlying mound. The fills of the ditches were identical. In the base of both ditches and the central area were a series of possible postholes. The only finds were some possible worked flint and 344g of burnt flint. No central burial was recovered. (3)Additional bibliography. (4)The excavation found a central post hole. This may have been for marking out the circuit of the ditch during initial construction, or for a central post marking the location of the mound. It is thought that the outer ditch of the barrow is a later addition, possibly associated with the secondary burial, and so representing a reuse of the earlier mound. The burial was C14 dated to 1620-1440 cal BC, a post-Beaker date. The barrow itself may then date to the Late Neolithic, given the apparent time that had passed between construction and the secondary burial, indicated by the level of silting within the original ditch. (5)

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Four Beaker burials underlying Roman settlement in Area 4 of the Monkton to Mount Pleasant A253 excavation project. Not currently represented in the HER although the Roman settlement is (TR 36 NW 238/MKE15647).One of these burials (Grave 751) was identified during trial trenching for the project  and is represented by this HER record). Three other contemporary burials (Graves 537, 6371 and 643) were found during the subsequent excavation and have been added to this record.
Site_description: In 1993 an evaluation on the A253 was undertaken by Trust for Thanet Archaeology. During the evaluation two inhumations were discovered in a single grave cut. The first was that of a small adult in a crouched position, head south, facing east. In front of the face was a fragmented beaker, possibly a bell beaker, point-tooth comb decoration, horizontal bands and chevrons. Towards the northern end of the grave was a stack of inarticulated skeletal material representing a second burial of one other individual. No encircling barrow ditch was found therefore it is more likely a 'flat' beaker burial. (1)During the subsequent excavation (Area 4), three additional Beaker-period burials were found. Two of these were located immediately adjacent to the initial find and contained Beaker vessels. An outlying burial, probably of the same date included traces of a plank-built timber lining.

Site_name_other: Iron Age/early Roman occupation and burials
Site_summary: Iron Age/early Roman occupation found at Waterbrook Farm in 1993 during an excavation.<gg_summary (based on Rady 1999; Wessex Archaeology 2008)>: Several possible LIA cremation burials were identified during the evaluation work but none included cremated bone; several cremation-related features were found during the subsequent excavation of Area A but none were associated with gg. Analysis of cremated bone from this site (Jones forthcoming) identified LBA burnt bone pins amongst the cremated remains. These deposits are recorded here.
Site_description: An evaluation in 1992 and a subsequent excavation in 1993, both carried out by Canterbury Archaeological Trust, at Waterbrook Farm found a possible Iron Age or early Roman enclosure. It was paritally excavated on the northern edge of the site. The part exposed consists of two ditches which form a right angle. There are two entrances at the north-east and south-west corners. A concentration of pits within the enclosed area may relate to a period of occupation. A ditch is present, its function may have been for drainage, suggesting problems with flooding during the occupation on the site. Similar drainage ditches can be found on the opposite side of the river. The settlement is mid to late 1st century with pre-Flavian pottery. (1)An evaluation in 1992 and a subsequent excavation in 1993, both carried out by Canterbury Archaeological Trust, at Waterbrook Farm found a settlement clustered around the banks of a palaeochannel. Flooding of the settlement may have been a problem, several drainage ditches were present and canalising of the river before it was eventually infilled. The main period of occupation looks to be the late Iron Age, probably about 50 years before the Roman invasion, a date dedcued from recovered ceramics. Several rubbish pits were present on this site as well as one cremation.The archaeological features represented a short lived, though it was a continuously occupied native settlement. Ceramic evidence suggests that the site was enclosed in the late Iron Age and continued in use for c.150 yrs into the Roman period with occupation mostly situated on a low rise in the flood plain. The site lay adjacent to a relict channel of the East Stour, which probably once formed an oxbow encircling the settlement on 3 sides. The abrupt termination of the occupation in the 2nd century AD may have been due to the wetness of the site. (2)An evaluation in 1992 and a subsequent excavation in 1993, both carried out by Canterbury Archaeological Trust, at Waterbrook Farm found several cremations were found during the excavation. Three cremations were excavated, all crushed but with substantially complete pottery vessels dating to before AD 70 and were discovered in the base of two ditches. They appear to be simple cremation burial with the ditch, which is not uncommon. There is no burnt bone associated with but it may have degraded. Two more possible cremation burials in a similar state were found again in the base of a ditch. A heavily truncated cremation burial was situated in the south-eastern corner of an enclosure, though the two features may not be contemporary. The original cut for the burial was filled with a charcoal deposit, suggesting the pyre for the burning was situated nearby. The cut contained a number of fragments of burnt bone and sherds of a pottery vessel, which was a 1st to 2nd century 'Upchurch ware' bowl. A cinerary vessel may have been present but no longer exists and therefore of one were present it was biodegradable. This cremation was undated. There was one other possible cremation which was isolated and heavily truncated at the eastern edge of the site. It contained charcoal ash and burnt bone, which might have been an un-closed  cremation burial. Un-closed cremation burials are quite common in rural cemetries of Romano-British date, following a tradition of Iron Age cremations without containers. (1)

Site_name_other: Bronze Age to Iron Age occupation and burials
Site_summary: Evidence of activity on the site dating from throughout the Bronze Age and the Iron Age  was found during an excavation at Margetts Pit.<gg_summary>: Four crouched inhumation burials and 12 cremation-related deposits were found. Two of the inhumations were of adult females aged c.40-45 (one radiocarbon dated to early in the Late Bronze Age – 1120-970 cal BC), the third was of an adult female aged c.20-25 whilst the fourth was of an adult male aged c.25-35. There were no associated grave goods.A small M/LBA cremation cemetery was identified in the southwest of the site. It almost certainly extends further to the south beyond the limits of this excavation. Six (possibly nine) individuals, both male and female, are represented including children and adults. Fragments of amber, probably from beads were found in two of the graves. A radiocarbon date in the Late Bronze Age (1010-840 cal BC) was obtained from one burial. Seven of the burials were possible or likely unurned cremation burials. One deposit included a complete pot and 1g burnt human bone.In truth the character of these funerary deposits is complex. The single deposit with human bone and a complete pot and the two bone deposits with amber beads are recorded here. The various deposits with burnt human bone and scraps of unburnt animal bone are not.
Site_description: In 2009 an excavation was carried out at Margetts Pit by Wessex Archaeology. Evidence for Bronze Age to Late Iron Age/early Roman activity was found across the site. The earliest phase of activity was evidenced by flint working found as residual material in a number of later features. The quality and type suggest a Late Neolithic or Early Bronze Age date for this activity. Eight abraded and probably residual sherds of Beaker or Early Bronze Age pottery (two from Collared Urns) were found in later features. Middle Bronze Age activity was attested by a small assemblage of pottery consistent with Deverel-Rimbury traditions. This was mostly spread across the western part of the site, from the ditches of a rectilinear field system, 19 pits and/or post holes and two placed vessels. There was considerable overlap with Late Bronze Age areas of activity so it is not immediately clear which features were certainly Middle Bronze Age in date. The Middle Bronze Age pits contained flints (worked and burnt) and animal bones. The post holes did not form any obvious groups or structures. The two deposited vessels appeared to be closely associated with the field system ditches. The better preserved of the two contained animal bone and worked and burnt flint. Another 65 sherds from four or five separate vessels were found in a small cut but it is not clear if they too represent vessel deposition. The rectilinear field system was orientated approximately north-northwest to south-southeast. Surviving traces included shallow ditches in both the western and eastern parts of the site. Two parallel ditches 3.5m apart may be a trackway. The absence of such ditches from the centre of the site may be the result of truncation by later ploughing. Late Bronze Age pottery was found in the ditches but could indicate simply increased activity in this later period or long-term maintenance of the field system.The Late Bronze Age saw a considerable increase in activity on the site. Ditches were added to the Middle Bronze Age field system. Numerous pits were found across the site, these occurred in clusters, groups and as isolated features. Many of the pits contained apparent deposits of domestic rubbish   animal bone, pottery and worked flint. Some pits contained substantial deposits of shale-working waste, dating from later in the Late Bronze Age. In total nearly 10kg of shale was found, including bracelet blanks, roughouts at all stages of manufacture, broken finished pieces and debitage from working. This material was associated with Late Bronze Age pottery but also with Iron Age material, and the working may therefore have been occurring at the transition of the Late Bronze Age into the Iron Age. Other pits contained instances of structured deposition, such as one pit with a pair of large red deer antlers and an amber bead fragment. A sheep/goat was buried in one pit and a possibly lead miniature wheel-shaped object was found from the top of or just above an adjacent pit. Other partial-animal burials from the site dated to this period and it is possible that several other undated examples also did. Elsewhere, three Late Bronze Age vessels appeared to have been deliberately placed in the ground. Despite the number of pits and post holes, few clearly defined structures could be identified.

Site_name_other: Late Iron Age/early Roman cremation burials
Site_summary: A scatter of cremation burials dating to the Late Iron Age and early Roman period. A pyre and a large pit were also found.<gg_summary_temp>: Five of the eight cremation burials were dated to the latest IA (1st century AD); the remainder were of early Roman date. See SID50147 for the Bronze Age cremation burials from this site.Features 148 and 150 were 1st-century AD cremation burials, each containing a single vessel: in both cases a possible butt beaker.Feature 155 was probably a disturbed Late Iron Age - early Romano-British cremation containing a single vessel.Feature 157 was a Late Iron Age cremation burial, containing probably a single vessel.Feature 154 is described as both an early 1st- century AD cremation burial within the postulated pyre site 152, and as including a late 2nd century AD vessel. It is not recorded here
Site_description: In 2000 Archaeology South-East carried out a watching brief during topsoil stripping at the Page Road development on the former Hawkinge Aerodrome.Two cremation burials with pottery from the Late Iron Age-early Roman period were found, one cremation was found in an area of modern disturbance. Five (possibly six) cremations were found dating from the Roman period. The first was found with sherds of an amphora and two flagons, with a pair of hobnailed shoes. Another shallow scoop 10m from this feature contained the remains of a dish, but no cremated remains. An oval pit contained sherds from a large storage vessel (AD 70-150) and an early 2nd century flagon. A cremation burial was found in a circular cut and was found with sherds of a butt beaker dated to the first half of the 1st century. Another such feature contained sherds from a butt beaker (AD 30-60). A third such feature had sherds from a vessel dated to the second half of the 2nd century. This was feature cut a large shallow feature measuring c.2m x c.1m which did not contain cremated remains but did have signs of in situ burning and may therefore have been the pyre site for this funeral. Stake holes associated with this may have related to the pyre structure.A large feature c.4.3m in diameter and at least 1m deep was located during bomb clearance work. It contained a large quantity of 1st to early 2nd century pottery, a La Tene brooch, a 'potin' coin and a quantity of animal bone. (1)

Site_summary: Intensive activity from the Middle Iron Age through the Roman period consisting of rubbish pits, trackways, an enclosure and fields, plus burials.<gg_summary>: Two burials dating to the Late Iron Age/Conquest period:1) A cremation burial in a pit with two fragmented vessels and two copper objects (initially described as 6 brooches and a copper alloy pestle and motar). The vessels may have been deliberately broken prior to deposition. An associated/later post hole may have served as a burial marker.2) An inhumation of an adult female. The only accompanying grave good was a copper alloy finger ring worn on the right hand.Only a post-excavation report is available so the information about objects is limited.
Site_description: Between 2009 and 2011 Archaeology South-East carried out a programme of works on land north of Leysdown Road, Warden Bay, on the site now occupied by Warden Bay Primary School and land to the east of it. From the Middle Iron Age the site was the focus for a variety of activity types. The earliest phase of this occupation consisted of numerous shallow pits and/post holes. A number of larger pits, gullies and a hearth were also found. One gully may have related to a roundhouse. Two lengths of ditch were also found and are thought to perhaps represent the corner of a field. The site later developed with the laying out of a rectilinear enclosure and a stock funnel that fed into the enclosure. This fell out of use and was replaced by an east-west droveway. This route had regular gaps along its length, suggesting entrances to fields. Another trackway was established at this time going north-south across the site. The third phase of activity in the Late Iron Age/early Roman period saw another north-south route laid out across the site, on a slightly different alignment to the earlier one. This phase of activity also featured two burials. The first was a cremation in a pit accompanied by two fragmented vessels and two copper objects (initially described as 6 brooches and a copper alloy pestle and motar (1)). The vessels may have been deliberately broken prior to deposition. The pit was associated with a later post hole that may have served as a marker for the burial. An inhumation of an adult female was also found belonging to this period; the onlyaccompanying grave good with this burial was a copper alloy finger ring worn on the right hand.The Roman period proper featured a re-cutting of the southern part of the north-south routeway and the addition of a northwest-southeast route. A small number of pits were dug and some were used for the disposal of cess as well as domestic refuse. Only two post holes were assigned to this period and it appears that no trace of structures has survived. Two plough truncated Roman vessels were found within the subsoil and possibly represent a disturbed cremation, though no trace of cremated remains was found. (2)

Site_name_other: Middle to Late Bronze Age funerary site
Site_summary: A flint filled ring ditch with five associated pits containing inverted vessels which held small amounts of cremated human remains.
Site_description: In 2002 the Trust for Thanet Archaeology carried out an excavation at the former Bon Secours Nursing Home site on London Road, Ramsgate. In one of the excavation areas, a Middle to Late Bronze Age funerary site was found. This consisted of a flint filled ring gully with a group of five associated pits containing truncated ceramic vessels. All but one of the vessels were inverted and contained small quantities of cremated human bone. The ring gully was c.4m in diameter and 20 sherds from one small Deverel-Rimbury type bowl of Late Bronze Age date were found at the base of the deposit that filled the gully. The upper surface of the fill of the gully had a densely packed flint nodule layer. This may have been a flint mound that was eroded and truncated by later activity on the site. A curvilinear ditch was also found. (1)

Site_summary: Pits, ditches and inhumations dating from the Middle to Late Iron Age.<gg_summary>: Information recorded here derives from summary accounts in Gollop and Mason (2005), Bailey (2009) and Cotton (2011). No further information was forthcoming from Canterbury Archaeology.a) A formal cemetery of eleven LIA inhumation burials dating to the period 100 BC-AD 50. The cemetery extended beyond the limits of the excavation. All of the burials were aligned N-S; one was prone, the rest supine. A pot was recovered from one grave; sheep bones from another. Only mature adults were represented. Gollop and Mason (2005) note that Bone was well preserved in all of the graves, and in one, larger than the rest (possibly the prone, muscular man with two healed fractures mentioned by Bailey 2009 who was particularly tall?), the outline of a coffin and its iron nails could be distinguished. A high incidence of disease was noted in the skeletons. One skeleton had evidence of a brain tumour, five had healed fractures (two were skull fractures), a high level of spinal anormality, squatting facets and evidence of anaemia suggest that these people worked hard!b) A crouched inhumation burial of a woman aged 26-35, c. 1.52m tall. The woman had a spinal abnormality known as 'kissing spines' (leading to an abnormally straight posture and potentially a painful back) and an arthritic right ankle (probably resulting from a sprain). She was buried with a jet bracelet/armlet, an amber bead, a polished fossil-sponge bead with an elephant tusk shell through it, and a pig tusk bead.Given the paucity of detailed evidence a 'best fit' from the summary accounts is attempted here.See also SID50209 for further EBA burials and early Ro potential extension to this cemetery.
Site_description: In 2004 Canterbury Archaeological Trust carried out an evaluation. The site was intensively occupied in the Middle to Late Iron Age and numerous features were found dating to this period. These included refuse pits, quarry pits, post alignments and linear ditches. No structural elements, apart from the post alignments, were found, though the quantity of finds suggests settlement in the immediate area. Two inhumation burials were found and further possible graves were identified. (1)

Site_name_other: Late Bronze Age/Iron Age ritual and mortuary site
Site_summary: In the Late Bronze Age a series of horseshoe shaped enclosures were constructed on the site. A large possible quarry was used for the burial of a large number of individuals over a period spanning the Late Bronze Age to Middle Iron Age.<gg_summary>: may be difficult to use this site for quantification of incidence of burials with gg vs incidence of burials overall
Site_description: In 2004/5 the site at Cliffs End Farm was excavated in advance of housing. In addition to a number of early bronze age barrows and late bronze age enclosures (the 'northern', 'central', and 'southern' enclosures) a large mortuary features was discovered.  This was more than 45m long, 15m wide and up to 1.5m deep. It extended beyond the north-eastern limits of the excavation. It may have been initially used as a quarry but was, after a period of silting, used as a burial ground. The human remains found within the feature consisted of a combination of articulated remains, redeposited (manipulated) partial articulated remains, dispersed semi-articulated remains (whole corpse and body parts) and disarticulated bones and bone fragments. Six complete skeletons were found in the north part of the site, along with the articulated remains of a partial skeleton. Seven complete articulated skeletons were found in the southern part of the pit. Each skeleton was radiocarbon dated. The Late Bronze Age remains comprise a minimum of 24 individuals (including one cremation). The Early Iron Age remains were from seven individuals and the Middle Iron Age remains represented a minimum of eight individuals. There were 15 immature individuals and 23 adults but the immature examples were mostly teenagers with the youngest c.6 years old. Apart from during the Middle Iron Age, the individuals buried were more commonly female: during the Middle Iron Age, the distribution was equal. All four of the older adults were female. The remains were also subject to strontium/oxygen isotope analysis. This showed that some of the individuals were not of local origin, having migrated during childhood. Possible origins are in higher, colder and/or more easterly areas as well as warmer and/or more westerly areas. These patterns also varied between period. Origins in the high Alps, east or north of Britain (including Scandinavia) have been suggested but Scandinavia is the favoured likely point of origin for some of the individuals. Another group possibly came from the Mediterranean.The mortuary rite performed at the site is unusual in a number of ways. The assemblage represents a large number of individuals for these periods. A review in 1995 found only nine Late Bronze Age inhumation sites in mainland Britain. This number has increased since the time of the survey but they remain rare. Known examples of Early-Middle Iron Age burials are rarer still. The group is unusual for their age, sex and geographical origins, a feature that was maintained over the extended lifetime of the burial feature. Particular practices from the site are especially unusual. There is evidence of burial of unburnt remains with subsequent manipulation, communal and individual graves, human and probably animal sacrifice, excarnation with manipulation and redeposition of partially articulated body parts and curation of individual skeletal elements, exposure with canid and possibly avian scavenging and bleaching and charring of some body parts. Most of these occurred during the Late Bronze Age, with manipulation particularly common in this phase of use. One burial in particular appears to have been the focus of activity. An elderly female had been killed probably with a sword by blows to the back of the head. It has been suggested that this was a willing sacrifice. She was laid out in the bottom of the pit with a piece of chalk against her face in her left hand whilst her right hand was positioned with the index finger pointing away from the body towards the centre of the adjacent central enclosure on the site. Two children and a teenage girl had been buried with her together with the partially articulated and re-arranged remains of an adult male.

Site_name_other: Beaker and Early Bronze Age burials, The Meads, Sittingbourne
Site_summary: Four Beaker burials, an Early Bronze Age ring ditch and burial.Two of the pots were classed as 'Accessory Vessels'. One of the burials was a cremation with a Beaker pot (possibly EBA rather than Beaker?) Beakers pot containing cremation is rare
Site_description: In 2008 Canterbury Archaeological Trust carried out a watching brief and excavation. The earliest features found were four Beaker burials. These do not appear to have been within a barrow. One of the burials was accompanied by a beaker with a cremation within it. In the Early Bronze Age a ring ditch was dug on the western part of the site. There was no central burial found but a possible off-centre burial was found. (1)The ring ditch is one of four identified as cropmarks in the area (TQ 86 SE 30).

Site_summary: A Middle to Late Bronze Age ditch and five cremations.<gg_summary>: Nine M/LBA cremations, of which one was urned. Four (including the only urned burial) were located close to a substantial field boundary. Another was relatively isolated.
Site_description: In 2009/10 Archaeology South-East carried out a strip, map and sample excavation. A north-south ditch crossed the site, 110m of its length being exposed. It is thought to have been a field ditch though no entrances to fields could be found along its length. The fill contained residual worked flints but also worked flints of the Middle to Late Bronze Age. The worked flints included a horned scraper, a concave scraper, a side scraper and two hammerstones. Five cremations were found near the ditch. All but one were unurned. The urned cremation had been deposited in a Late Bronze Age/Early Iron Age vessel. (1)

Site_summary: A Middle to Late Bronze Age ring ditch, two crouched inhumations and two cremations.<gg_summary> Small fragment of copper recovered from the isolated inhumation located c. 100m east of the ring ditch (so not directly associated).
Site_description: In 2009/10 Archaeology South-East carried out a strip, map and sample excavation. A ring ditch was found on the west facing slope of the hill brow. The ring ditch was 18m in diameter, between 1.2m and 1.6m wide and survived to a depth of 0.5m. No internal features survived. A crouched inhumation had been inserted into the ring ditch. A second crouched burial was found 100m to the east of the ring ditch. A small piece of copper alloy was found with the second burial but there was otherwise no dating evidence of either burial. They are thought to be of Bronze Age date, the first probably being inserted into the ring ditch when it was still a visible feature. Two unurned cremations were found 20m to the west of the ring ditch. (1)

Site_name_other: Beaker pits and ring ditches, Beechbrook Wood
Site_summary: Beaker (Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age) pits and ring ditches.<Need the full assessment report to complete the record. There is an error on ADS with this so cannot download it><cenotaph?>
Site_description: In 2000/1 the Oxford Archaeological Unit carried out a targeted watching brief (a strip, map and sample excavation) ahead of CTRL works. A number of Beaker pits were found along with a ring ditch. One of the pits contained a complete Beaker vessel on its side at the base of the pit. A similar vessel was found in one of the other pits. One pit contained ashy deposits with a large number of sherds of pottery, flints, a possible stone pestle and chared plant remains. These were thought to be domestic in origin and to have been deposted in separate episodes. Two small fragments of cremated human bone were found in the lower fills of one pit. This could be residual or intrusive. A fired clay object was found, it may have been made by a child and intended to represent a hedgehog. The pottery from these pits represents a minimum of 14 vessels in a range of forms in a wide variety of fabrics. It has been suggested that this is significant, representing a gathering of people from different areas with different pottery traditions. One of these pits was dug through a partially silted ring ditch. The ring ditch was 6m in diameter and had two post holes in its base. It contained a few residual pieces of Early Neolithic material, but also contained a sherd of Beaker pottery. (1-2)

Site_name_other: Multi phase occupation Site and burials
Site_summary: Excavation in 2006 discovered ex-situ lower Palaeolithic flakes, evidence of late prehistoric occupation of the site, and a number of late Iron Age and Roman burials.<gg_summary>: Two truncated Late Iron Age cremation burials - one urned, the other unurned.
Site_description: Archaeological excavation in 2006 discovered ex-situ Lower Palaeolthic flakes, deriving from fluvially deposited gravel, or being residual in tertiary contexts.  Evidence of late prehistoric occupation of the site is indicated by the prescence of pits and ditches, possibly of Late Bronze Age or Early Iron Age. A truncated Late Iron Age urned cremation burial was found and approximately 100 Roman inhumation graves were excavated (1).

Site_name_other: Late Bronze Age and  Iron Age burials
Site_summary: During A2 widening works in 2007 a range of archaeological features spanning Late Bronze Age to Post Medieval period were found across the area. Later Bronze Age enclosure ditches and unaccompanied cremations, early Iron Age storage pits and 4 post structures appeared in clusters which included placed deposits.<gg_summary>: The Late Bronze Age burials from this site were unaccompanied, and only disarticulated remains were recovered from the Middle Iron Age. This record therefore represents only the Late Iron Age burials from the site - 'two highly significant cremation burials (4298 and 4313) associated with a rich assortment of metalwork and pottery. They were dated to the late Iron Age and lay within the neck of a middle Iron Age 'banjo' enclosure, to the west of a series of contemporary pits and enclosures (see Fig. 3.38)' (Allen et al. 2012, 288).Both pits were heavily truncated.
Site_description: During A2 widening works in 2007 a number of late Bronze Age enclosures and unaccompanied cremations were discovered. These were followed by Iron Age four post structures in clusters and included  placed deposits. The placed deposits included whole pots, iron objects, charred grain and loom weights. Three particularly rich pits contained salt containers, tray fragments and pedestals which may have suggested salt manufacture?Activity on-site appears to have nucleated in the middle Iron Age when a series of enclosure ditches were dug (these were later extended). Ritual deposition occurred throughout the Iron Age. One inhumation burial came from a pit and several cremations were found, one accompanied by two pots and four brooches, two connected by a chain, the other buried in a bronze bound decorated yew bucket accompanied by four pots and a bronze sheath, probably from a drinking horn. The site was abandoned during the Roman period as later field boundaries were cut through the site (some Roman finds occurred). The area was re-used during the medieval period which produced evidence of sunken featured buildings, subrectangular pits, kilns and deneholes (1).

Site_name_other: Late Iron Age cremation burials and Iron Bloomery furnace
Site_summary: 6 cremation urns (and human remains) and an Iron Bloomery furnace were found near Jubilee Corner, Ulcombe.<gg_summary>: A further plough truncated cremation was recorded 160m from this group in 1999, close to a known Roman cremation cemetery (but definitely of Iron Age date) (Aldridge 2005, 180).
Site_description: 6 cremation urns (and human remains) were found in near Jubilee Corner Ulcombe, along with an Iron Bloomery furnace.The fabric of vessel of cremation 4 was different was the others, with a grey interior and oranger exterior made from sandy glauconitic clay.  The others were grey grogged ware. Cremation 4 contained two fragments of copper alloy may be part of a 'toilet set' and a possible brooch of the same material. Cremation 1 contain an iron rod fibula of Belgic type.Human remains - child remains (1-2 yrs, and 1-3 yrs) found in two of the urns and 4 adult remains (one possibly female).Bloomery furnace was roughly oval. Small stones had been incorporated into the base of the south-east side. (1)

Site_name_other: Bronze Age Beaker pit - A2 Pepperhill to Cobham widening scheme
Site_summary: Early Bronze Age Beaker Pit containing the fragmented remains of at least 5 vessels. One of the earliest features along the A2 scheme.A double Beaker burial, each with its own complete beaker, was discovered only 140m to the south-west during the CTRL works. he large pottery assemblage from the pit makes this an important group for the south-east of England, while the variety of finds has potential to shed light on several aspects of Beaker activity. Such rich pit deposits are not simply a haphazard collection of domestic waste, note c. 600 pieces of struck flint were also recovered from this pit which is interesting & unusual
Site_description: The early Bronze Age Beaker Pit identified on site D marks one of the earliest (confirmed) features along the whole A2 scheme. It sat on the edge of the plateau overlooking the Tollgate dry valley, a location that was  chosen in Roman times as an auspicious locality for the aristocratic high status burials. A double Beaker burial, each with its own complete beaker, was discovered only 140m to the south-west during the CTRL works, and this was the only Beaker feature found along the adjacent route. The large pottery assemblage from the pit makes this an important group for the south-east of England, while the variety of finds has potential to shed light on several aspects of Beaker activity. Such rich pit deposits are not simply a haphazard collection of domestic waste, but represnet the careful selection of materials for ritual deposition, and as such also inform us about Beaker beliefs.The Beaker pit, and the stray sherd from a nearby feature, show that Beaker settlement activity did occur in the vicinity of the burials found on the line of the CRTL, and the scatter of struck flint from Site D may prove to include further artefactual evidence from that period. Together with the occasional sherd from elsewhere along the route, particularly on Sites B and F, this does suggest a greater presence in the landscape than indicated by the discoveries along the CTRL, but only assessment will reveal the overall scales of that presence. Detailed information on the activities represented by the pit will have to await post-excavation assessment and analysis.Early Bronze Age activity is represented only by the one pit and by residual flint and a sherd. The duration of activity is therefore not likely to be very great, although it remains to be seen whether the Beaker burials and the Beaker pit are broadly contemporary, or date from different parts of the Beaker period, which spans at least 500 years. (1)

Site_name_other: Six early Bronze Age round barrows
Site_summary: During excavation in advance of new housing, 6 early bronze age barrows were discovered. The excavators suggested that barrow 1, the south-westernmost, was the initial barrow around which the others had been grouped. Each barrow survived in the form of its ditches and in four cases, an internal features, probably a grave. No traces of any mounds survived, nor could they be inferred.In 1st barrow the central  grave contained a collection of flint tools and a bronze object (too corroded for identification
Site_description: In 2004/5 the site at Cliffs End Farm was excavated. The earliest evidenced activity on the site consisted of six Early Bronze Age round barrows. Soil conditions on the site meant that bone had not survived and as such no burials were located. Despite this, the central burial of the first barrow (double-ditched, barrow 1) was located, the grave containing a collection of flint tools and a bronze object (too corroded for identification). Part of this barrow remains in situ below a tree on the site. The second barrow, to the north of the first, had a structure at its centre made up from four post holes in a rectangular arrangement. A similar structure was found at the centre of the third barrow. The fourth barrow had three ring ditches around it and again had a structure at its centre. (1)The barrows were accompanied by a substantial quantity of struck flint and pottery, all of which suggested an early bronze age date. Two of the barrows (barrow 1 and 2) also contained pottery believed to derive from Beaker vessels. (2) (3)

Parish_Community_Borough: CLIFFE AND CLIFFE WOODS, MEDWAY, KENT
Site_summary: Two intact Bronze Age vessels with associated finds suggestive of burials found when a pipeline was being laid in 1978.One is suggestive of a classic Beaker burial (without the burial- degraded inhumation?) with barbed and tanged arrowhead, bracer and a Beaker pot (East Anglian style)
Site_description: During works relating to a pipeline being laid in 1978 vessels were found upright above a possible old surface and apparently within dune sand (1). The Beaker overlay the bracer and arrowhead while the collared urn was found 2.5m away. It is thought that these must have been associated with inhumation burials that have not left any recognisable surviving trace due to leaching and the highly acidic soil. No cut features or traces of mounds were found.

Site_summary: Occupation spanning the Bronze Age to very early Roman period found in areas 3 and 4 of Brisley Farm development, Ashford, excavated from June 2001 to 15 February 2002 . Features include 204 pits, 3 well/waterholes, one sump, two pits/kilns and six pits/hearths. 462 post-holes, 59 stakeholes 5 post/stake holes, 29 postholes/pits, 2 scoops, 171 ditches excavated, 143 gullies, 27 gully-ditches, 16 ring gullies, 4 beam slots, 27 spreads, and most significantly two Iron Age weapon-burials (with grave goods) deemed to be of national importance.<gg_summary>: Two weapon burials, in poor condition due to acidic Weald clay.1) Male inhumation burial with weapons and one pot within a square-ditched enclosure dated to c.AD 10.2) Weapon burial with a brooch and three pots dated AD 30 to 50<Celtic Art db: https://doi.org/10.5284/1000086>
Site_description: Features found dating to the Middle Iron Age/Late Iron Age Transition (c.150 to 75 BC) included ditches, pits, postholes, double post-hole row, pit/well and structures, which were focused in the northern part of area 4, believed to comprise increased development of the enclosure at this time. Later ditches and structures were dated to the period 75 to 25 BC (Period IV in report), with scant evidence in area 3, suggesting the possibility of a high status settlement lying beyond the site boundary to the south west. Occupation during the very Late Iron Age/very Early Roman, dated 75 BC to AD 55, (referred to as 'Period V' in the report) saw an expansion of the site, with development south of the axial ditch [3276]. Features from this period included ditches (believed to form several enclosures, with a trackway as their locus), several pits and post-holes, several structures (believed to be dwellings or occupation sites, indicating continued development of this part of the site), spreads, two weapon burials, enclosures, pyre site or hearth and a well/shaft. Eleven pieces of glass were also recovered from area 4, all Late Iron Age or Roman in date. At least 15 special 'burial features' or deposits and other features associated with cremation including at least one pyre site were found.Weapon Burials:The most significant finds at the site were two weapon burials, deemed to be of national importance. Only nine weapon burials have been found previously in England south of the Humber, however, both sets of remains are in poor condition due to acidic Weald clay, which has led to significant deterioration. The first burial - [B20]- comprises a male inhumation (believed to be between 18 and 22 years of age) buried with weapons and one pot within a square-ditched enclosure, forming a pair with another burial -[B19]- 5m to the east. [B20] is dated to c.AD 10 via ceramics found in the grave fill. The two burials are placed within a zone of Middle/Late Iron Age settlement to the north and areas of Late Iron Age occupation and ritual activity to the south. Grave goods found alongside [B20] included a long sword and shield. Outside the 'coffin' a spear head was found lodged in the south-east wall of the grave, in addition to a Gallo-Belgic butt beaker (dated 10 BC to AD 10) and a circular ring of bronze. Found close by in a filled in ditch were broken whole pots and cattle jaws.Burial [B19] has been dated AD 30 to 50, presumed later than [B20] and shallow in depth, at ~400 to 450mm deep (at estimated Late Iron Age/Roman land surface). The accompanying grave goods were a butt beaker (AD 30 to 70), a terra negra platter with stamp [CANICOS -SN-], produced in Marne AD 20/25 to 40/45, and a small carinated cup or bowl (AD 0 to 50). With the body were a long sword with three suspension rings, a spear, a conical shield boss, a series of five iron objects lying across the line of the ankles, a single brooch on the chest and half a pigs head lying over the groin. The association of a weapon burial with a brooch and three pots is unique in Britain.Roman features at the site, dating AD 50 to 70 (Period VIa) comprised several ditches, pits, post-holes, kiln/pit and burial [B19] and [B20] enclosure ditches filling a 'ritual' enclosure ditch. During the latter period c.AD 70 to 120 (Period VIb) further ditches, pits, post-holes and a beam slot were identified. Mid Roman features -c.AD 120 to 200- comprised a trackway ditch. Several ditches were also found, believed to be modern features (AD 1800 to 2002). (1)

Site_name_other: Early / Mid Bronze Age funerary landscape, Saltwood
Site_summary: Early / Mid Bronze Age funerary landscape, and possible associated agricultural activity, Saltwood.<gg summary>:  Only one of the barrows contained a burial - a centrally-placed crouched burial. A further crouched inhumation was located equidistant between the western-most two barrows, but was not accompanied by any grave goods. Non-funerary evidence consists of a single pottery-filled pit, and a N-S aligned ditch with aligns with the eastern-most barrow is tentatively assigned to this phase.1ry burial only from r-d C10082. sub-rectangular and vertically sided grave, 0.86 m deep and aligned N-S. OLd male >50 yrs with broken but fully healed fibulaFood Vessel grave good. Not only is this rare for Kent but this one was poorly fired and wonky
