Site_description: Excavations carried out between 1998-2001 at the Saltwood Tunnel and Stone Farm Bridleway sites, by Canterbury Archaeology Trust and Wessex Archaeology, as part of the CTRL works.An Early / Mid Bronze Age funerary landscape and possible associated settlement and agricultural activity.5 Early Bronze Age ring-ditches  which suggest the denuded remains of round-barrows. 3 were annular, 1 probably originally penannular, 1 was not fully revealed by the excavation. The penannular ditch may have initially been a mortuary enclosure rather than a barrow. 4 are equally spaced c.170m apart (centre-to-centre) in a roughly E-W alignment, with the fifth spaced only 75m to the east of its neighbour. They range in diameter from 15.8m to 42.5m. Only one of the barrows contained a burial - a centrally-placed crouched burial. A further crouched inhumation was located equidistant between the western-most two barrows. Non-funary evidence consists of a single pottery-filled pit, and a N-S aligned ditch with aligns with the eastern-most barrow is tentatively assigned to this phase (though as at leat three of the barrows must have remained prominent features in the landscape into the Saxon period due to the Saxon cemeteries that formed around them (TR 13 NE 223), this assumption seems ill-formed). (1)Additional bibliography. (2-4)

Site_summary: Early / Middle Iron Age graves, Saltwood<gg_summary>: an early-middle Iron Age inhumation cemetery and a square enclosure, perhaps a mortuary enclosure  (a square barrow?), were established at some time between the 8th - 4th centuries BC. A middle Iron Age inhumation grave of 2nd to 4th century BC date also lay near the western end of the site(ADS online overall site summary (Foreman 2009): http://archaeologydataservice.ac.uk/archives/view/ctrl/sltisr/index.cfm?CFID=ea74d071-a9a4-494e-bf24-3287fbb7325a&CFTOKEN=0)There were eight possible graves of which three were associated with tiny amounts of cremated human bone (probably redeposited) and four were associated with degraded inhumation burials (Riddler, McKinley and Skittrell 2006, 6-7). Two 4th-5th century carinated pots were recovered from two separate graves  - one directly associated with an inhumation burial, another associated only with a tiny amount of (probably redeposited) cremated bone. Since the former cut into the latter and the bone survival is poor, the latter is treated as a grave good here. It is also worth noting that the cemetery and square barrow were
Site_description: Excavations carried out between 1998-2001 at the Saltwood Tunnel and Stone Farm Bridleway sites, by Canterbury Archaeology Trust and Wessex Archaeology, as part of the CTRL works.6 graves and probable graves date to this period, though only two have secure dating evidence. A ditch terminal and a pit also date to this period. (1)Additional bibliography. (2)

Parish_Community_Borough: BROADSTAIRS AND ST PETERS, THANET, KENT
Site_summary: An Early Iron Age to Middle Iron Age enclosure with possible occupation into the Late Iron Age.<gg_summary>:2003 excavation: E/MIA crouched inhumation with pottery (not certainly gg so not recorded here); two further burials in two separate pits - an adult female and a neonate. The female was accompanied by jet/faience beadsThe information entered in this record is extremely patchy and potentially inaccurate due to the lack of published evidence and the piecemeal character of evidence that is available. The Neolithic/Bronze Age 'flat grave' from the trial trenching is included with the Neolithic/Bronze Age evidence from this site
Site_description: In 1999 the Trust for Thanet Archaeology carried out an evaluation of the St. Stephen's College site. Several pits were found containing Early Iron Age and Late Iron Age pottery. A possible palisade trench was also found but did not contain any datable material. The Early Iron Age pottery was largely described as residual with most of the features dated by the Late Iron Age sherds, i.e. 150-50 BC. Despite this, it is likely that there was Early Iron Age occupation in the area dating to c.550-350 BC. (1)A joint excavation by Canterbury Archaeological Trust and the Trust for Thanet Archaeology following an evaluation and an initial strip and map phase. The final phase of excavation work was carried out by the Trust for Thanet Archaeology alone. All the work was carried out in 1999.From the Early Iron Age there was an enclosure on the site. Several possible four post structures were located within the enclosure. A number of pits were also dug during this occupation. Activity continued through the Middle Iron Age and possibly into the Late Iron Age. Material from the Late Iron Age was found in the upper fills of many older features, though some pits were located in the same area as the Early and Middle Iron Age pits, suggesting some possible continuation of occupation on the site. (2)In 2003 the land to the south was excavated by the Trust for Thanet Archaeology. The southern half of the enclosure ditch was located along with a scatter of features to the south, east and west of this. The ditch itself appears to have been dug in the Middle Iron Age. Disarticulated human bones were found within it, along with disturbed earlier material suggesting site clearance in the Late Iron Age. Other features of Early to Middle Iron Age date included large storage pits, some of which contained human remains. An adult female had been buried in one and the disarticulated remains of a neonate were found in a second. A further crouched inhumation of an adult female was found with Early to Middle Iron Age pottery. A number of pit or post alignments were found, one of which had disturbed the burial.The Late Iron Age saw further pit or post hole alignments created. Two ditches were dug at this time, one shorter and the other a boundary ditch dug across the site (it was also encountered on the site to the north). Disarticulated human bones (male and female, adult, young adult and neonate) were found in both features. A pit group dated to this period also contained disarticulated human ribs. Only three early Roman features were found, suggesting the site had gone out of use in the Late Iron Age. (3)

Site_name_other: Late Bronze Age/Early Iron Age occupation
Site_summary: Features relating to occupation in the Late Bronze Age/Early Iron Age, including two post built structures and a cremation.<gg_summary>: Four un-urned and one urned MBA cremation burial together with three smallpits containing in situ ceramic vessels (offerings?) were also identified toward the northern end of Area A2. In addition to these funerary features a number of the pits in this area contained what appeared to be ‘placed’ objects consisting of large pot sherds, animal bone, fragments of quern and other cultural material (Canterbury Archaeological Trust 2008).
Site_description: An evaluation by Canterbury Archaeological Trust in 2005 found two areas of Late Bronze Age/Early Iron Age activity. The northern area contained features relating to occupation, including two post built structures and a cremation. (1)

Site_summary: An Early Bronze Age mound that was the focus for burials throughout the Bronze Age and possibly into the Early Iron Age.<gg_summary>: Early to Late Bronze Age burials focused around a round barrow that continued to be constructed/reconfigured during this period. Only two burials (one EBA, one LBA) had grave goods.NB May be difficult to use this site for quantification of incidence of burials with gg vs incidence of burials overall (multiperiod)Booth et al (2015) identified evidence for mummification the bodies. The inhumation burials of prehistoric date (Beaker-EBA) mainly came from the barrows and in most cases were not identified with cuts, so may have been placed directly into barrow mound, with later soil layers covering them. Most lacked grave goods but most also had evidence (unusual) of low-level burning on extremities of bones and may have been smoked (mummified) prior to burial. Sherds of Beaker pottery, Food Vessel and Collared Urn were all found in mound layers but none can be ascribed as grave goods and most were worn and abraded (?plough-disturbed). Most of these individuals were young adults (17-25 years old) and had been tightly crouched or even bound in some cases on right sides. Mainly young males but also females. The probable Collared Urn burial was rather disturbed too (on periphery of mound)
Site_description: In 2008 Swale and Thames Archaeological Survey Company carried out a programme of works at Neats Court, Queenborough. A roughly circular mound 15m by 12m across and still standing 0.5m high was excavated and found to contain 14 burials, both cremations and inhumations. There was apparently no central burial and some of the burials were late additions. The mound was built in two phases, with a regular core and a more irregular capping event, with a bank around it. The mound was built in cleared woodland upon a platform deposit. Initially it was possibly only c.2m across, being constructed from turves and clay blocks of regular thickness placed horizontally. At a later date, it was expanded. Most of the burials was then made into or on this mound. Again at a later date, the mound was further enlarged. It was almost completely buried in alluvium sometime around the Late Bronze Age or Early Iron Age. At this point, the bank was enlarged, perhaps to make the mound more prominent, and further burials were inserted into the alluvial deposits. Late Iron Age or early Roman quarry pits were dug in the area, through the alluvium, and after this period the mound appears to have been completely buried by further alluvial deposits and been left under marshland pasture. (1)

Site_summary: An urned cremation of probable Late Iron Age date.<gg_summary>: A Late Iron Age urned cremation burial was exposed in Trench 6. The wall of the exposed top of the vessel, which was plough truncated, was tempered with fine flint grits and was approximately 8mm thick. The vessel contained highly fragmented burnt human bone and, where exposed beneath 0.25m of topsoil, was 0.38m in diameter and 0.24m tall.The report notes that this burial is unlikely to be isolated.
Site_description: In 2007 Kent Archaeological Projects carried out an evaluation on a water main route. An urned cremation was found in one trench, south of Macknade Farm. It was plough truncated. (1)

Site_summary: A burial with two flexed adult inhumations, one on top of the other, and the disturbed remains of an infant in the upper levels of the grave fill. Two Beaker vessels were found associated with the adults.Upper burial redeposited later and is much earlier than lower burial (also partial person and partial grave goods)
Site_description: In 1998 Museum of London Archaeology Service carried out an excavation as part of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link project. An inhumation was found, dating to the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age. The burial consisted of two flexed adults and the disturbed remains of a child aged between 3 and 5 years old who had been buried in the upper fill of the grave. The lower adult was probably female and had the head to the south. The upper adult was possibly male and had the head to the north. Both were aged between 26 and 45, based upon the condition of their teeth. The lower burial was radiocarbon dated to 2120-1780 cal BC and the upper to 2280-1980 cal BC. That the upper burial is perhaps three generations older than the lower is not explained, but could result from disturbance of the burials. A complete Beaker vessel was found associated with the lower adult. A second fragmented vessel was associated with the upper burial. No trace of a barrow was found but one could have existed and been ploughed flat over the 4000 years since the burials took place. There were a few features in the immediate area that could be of similar date and possibly related. (1-3)

Site_name_other: Early Bronze Age Cremation, Northumberland Bottom
Site_summary: An Early Bronze Age cremation in an inverted urn in a small pit.Further late Neolithic-earlyBronze Age mortuary activity is represented by a cremation burial within an inverted Collared Urn at the western end of the site near Hazells Farm, Downs Road.
Site_description: In 1998 Museum of London Archaeology Service carried out an excavation as part of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link project. A cremation burial dating to the Early Bronze Age was found. It was contained within an inverted Collared Urn in a small circular pit. The urn was a straight-sided vessel with decoration around the collar and on the rim bevel with impressed twisted cord, forming filled triangles and horizontal lines, of late style (Second Series South Eastern). (1-2)

Site_summary: A Late Bronze Age cremation.
Site_description: In 1998 Museum of London Archaeology Service carried out an excavation as part of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link project. A cremation burial dating to the Late Bronze Age was found. It was contained within an urn. (1-3)

Site_summary: An enclosed settlement was established in the Late Iron Age between Downs Road and Wrotham Road dry valleys on the west-facing hillside. The site continued in use into the Roman period, reaching its height in the late 1st century AD.<gg_summary>: Two pits containing funerary deposits focused around a LIA enclosure - one cremation deposit with simple LIA gg; another (early Roman) burial containing burnt material together with unburnt human bones from two individuals and unburnt grave goods (Askew 2006, 27).
Site_description: In 1998 Museum of London Archaeology Service carried out an excavation as part of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link project. An enclosed settlement was established between Downs Road and Wrotham Road dry valleys on the west-facing hillside. The site continued in use into the Roman period, reaching its height in the late 1st century AD.The earliest phase of activity related to a hollow way with a ditch and bank that could have been of Middle Iron Age date. In the Late Iron Age, an enclosure was laid out to the east of the hollow way. The earliest use of this may have been livestock related as there were no traces of domestic activity. The enclosure was subsequently enlarged, putting the hollow way out of use. Within this larger enclosure, there were a number of pits, ovens or kilns a possible hearth and two burials. One was cremation in a pedestal urn in a small pit on the east side of the enclosure. A copper alloy open ring was found within it. Disarticulated human remains of at least two individuals were found in a pit near the entrance on the north side of the enclosure. The pit also contained two fragments of loomweights and a Colchester type one-piece bow brooch. The pit was filled by the end of the 1st century AD. A horse burial was found on the west side of the enclosure. The animal had been 11-15.5 years old, 1.4-149m high (14-14 1/2 hands) with signs of traction and riding stresses. (1-3)

Site_name_other: Late Iron Age/early Roman ditches and cremations, 75 The Street, Hawkinge
Site_summary: Late Iron Age/early Roman ditches and later cremations of the 1st century AD.<gg_summary>: A group of four truncated Conquest-period cremation burials of which three were directly associated with human remains. Two of these were associated with Belgic pottery, potentially of LIA date (although possibly very slightly post-Conquest).
Site_description: In 2006 Archaeology South-East carried out an evaluation and an excavation. Three ditches crossing the site were dated to the Late Iron Age/early Roman period. The site was subsequently used for cremation burials. Four such burials were found in the south east corner of the site, three had accompanying vessels and one was a single urned cremation. (1)

Parish_Community_Borough: BROADSTAIRS AND ST PETERS, THANET, KENT
Site_summary: Three barrows of Late Neolithic-Early Bronze Age date and a number of crouched inhumations buried near one of the barrows.<gg_summary>:Three crouched inhumations which were in organic containers; probably degraded coffins. The only available detail is for the Causewayed ring ditch, recorded here: http://www.thanetarch.co.uk/Virtual%20Museum/3_Displays/G4%20Displays/Gallery4_Display4_Link2thanet_Link3causewayed_LinkNFB.htmReport (unavailable) is as follows: Boast E.J., Gardner O.W. and Moody G.A. 2006. Excavations at St. Stephen's College, North Foreland Broadstairs, Kent. Trust for Thanet Archaeology report.
Site_description: A joint excavation by Canterbury Archaeological Trust and the Trust for Thanet Archaeology following an evaluation and an initial strip and map phase. The final phase of excavation work was carried out by the Trust for Thanet Archaeology alone. All the work was carried out in 1999.The earliest features found on the site were three barrows and some associated graves. The 'flat-graves' consisted of crouched inhumations located to the north of the second barrow. (1)

Site_name_other: Late Iron Age-Roman occupation, Tothill Street
Site_summary: A Late Iron Age settlement that continued into the Roman period.<gg_summary>: EBA crouched inhumations, one potentially with gg (and not represented elsewhere in the HER). Early Roman inhumation cemetery not entered but possibly an extension of the LIA/early Ro cemetery represented by SID50170.Two truncated inhumation burials placed in small, shallow oval graves are attributable to the Early Bronze Age. Neither grave appears to have been associated with any other contemporary features. The northern grave was 14C dates 2000-1770 calk BC and likely the subadult was accompanied by a plough-disturbed and truncated Collared Urn
Site_description: In 2010 Museum of London Archaeology carried out an evaluation. A settlement appears to have existed on the site from the Late Iron Age into the Roman period. At least one sunken featured building was found along with numerous post holes. A large enclosure or boundary ditch crossed the site and is thought to be related to this period of activity. The settlement appears to have fallen into disuse during the late 2nd century, the large ditch having silted up by the middle of the 3rd century. An inhumation was found and, due to the presence of an iron nail, thought to this period of activity on the site. (1)

Site_name_other: Early Bronze Age burials, Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother Hospital, St Peter's Road, Margate
Site_summary: Two burials dating to the Early Bronze Age.<gg_summary_The first was in a large pit and may have been in a coffin or a hollowed log. The burial was of an adult male aged around 45 in a crouched position. Adjacent to the head was a comb decorated Beaker vessel. Other grave goods found with the burial were three barbed and tanged flint arrowheads found near the lower back, an angular flint in the chest area and a tiny fragment of amber near the head. The second grave truncated the north eastern corner of the first. The burial was of a woman aged around 30 in a very tightly crouched position. A barbed and tanged arrowhead (of Sutton 'B' type) was recovered from the soil filling the skull. The upper fill of the grave pit contained many sherds, mainly of Beaker fabrics and therefore may relate to feasting or other rituals The burials were contained within a ring ditch of a barrow
Site_description: In 2005 Archaeology South-East carried out an evaluation, finding a burial. (1)In 2005 the Trust for Thanet Archaeology carried out an excavation. Two Early Bronze Age burials were found. The first was in a large pit and may have been in a coffin or a hollowed log. The burial was of an adult male aged around 45 in a crouched position. Adjacent to the head was a comb decorated Beaker vessel. The Beaker is an early type, equating to Clarke's Wessex/Mid Rhine Group or step 3 of the Lanting and van der Waals scheme, thought to date to around 2300 BC. The skeleton though was radiocarbon dated to 1902 (+/- 33) BC. This apparently conforms to a recognised local pattern of late dates for apparently early Beaker styles. Other grave goods found with the burial were three barbed and tanged flint arrowheads found near the lower back, an angular flint in the chest area and a tiny fragment of amber near the head.The second grave truncated the north eastern corner of the first. The burial was of a woman aged around 30 in a very tightly crouched position. A barbed and tanged arrowhead (of Sutton 'B' type) was recovered from the soil filling the skull. The upper fill of the grave pit contained many sherds, mainly of Beaker fabrics and therefore may relate to feasting or other rituals carried out as part of the funeral. Worked flints were also found in this deposit. (2-3)

Site_name_other: Bronze Age barrow and cremation burials
Site_summary: A Bronze Age barrow with associated cremation burials.<gg_summary>: One in-situ urned cremation burial, three deposits of cremated human remains with significant quantities of pottery from numerous vessels.
Site_description: In 2010 Kent Archaeological Projects carried out a programme of works on a pipeline route. A Bronze Age ring ditch was found on the route. The ditch was roughly circular and c. 8m in diameter. An urned cremation burial was found within the enclosed area and is thought to be contemporary with the barrow. A second burial was found cut into the base of the ring ditch. This was a much disturbed Middle Bronze Age cremation. The ring ditch was filled with a deposit that appears to have developed over a period when the site was being used for further cremation burials. There were frequent pieces of burnt human bone, worked flint and sherds of Middle Bronze Age pottery. Two further burials were found cut into this deposit, one of which contained sherds from at least eight different vessels and the other had sherds from at least 11 vessels. Outside of the ring ditch a stone built feature was found, consisting of a linear arrangement of stones, possibly the remains of a bank that surrounded the barrow. (1)

Site_name_other: Late Iron Age-early Roman cremation cemetery
Site_summary: A Late Iron Age/early Roman cremation cemetery adjacent to a Bronze Age barrow.<gg_summary>: Four cremation burials with pots potentially dating to the LIA/early Roman period from a broader LIA/early Roman cemetery (from which most burials date to the early Roman period).
Site_description: In 2010 Kent Archaeological Projects carried out a programme of works on a pipeline route. A Late Iron Age/early Roman cremation cemetery was found. In total 17 cremation burials were excavated, most truncated by later ploughing but retaining the burial urns, some with secondary vessels. It is thought likely that the adjacent Bronze Age barrow was a reason for the siting of the cemetery. (1)

Site_name_other: Bronze Age to early iron age activity (East Kent Access Route Zone 6, Ebbsfleet Farm Cottages)
Site_summary: During the East Kent Access Route excavations a number of bronze age to early iron age features were discovered. These suggested a pattern of field boundaries and enclosures that changed alignment in the later bronze age from east-west to north-east south-west. Pits, a well, a cremation and metalworking evidence all suggest the presence of a settlement in the vicinity.<gg_summary>: Five separate Middle Bronze Age to Late Iron Age burials found in the context of extensive Bronze Age to Roman settlement activity excavated within Zone 6 of the East Kent Access Route project, representing two main phase of burial - MBA and LIA.NB May be difficult to use this site for quantification of incidence of burials with gg vs incidence of burials overall (multiperiod)
Site_description: During the East Kent Access Route excavations a number of bronze age to early iron age features were discovered (phases 2 - 4). These suggested a pattern of field boundaries and enclosures that changed alignment in the later bronze age from east-west to north-east south-west. Pits, enclosures, metalled surfaces, a well, a cremation in a collared urn and metalworking evidence all suggest the presence of a settlement in the vicinity.  A shield binding was also found from a late iron age context.Phase 3c in particular contained remains of a early to middle iron age settlement. A series of domestic enclosures and droveways were created. There were several groups of pits and postholes containing domestic waste, loomweights and quernstones. There were at least 5 discrete enclosures, each containing domestic remains such as pits, postholes, fences, round-houses and  four-post structures which were probably grain stores .As with zones 4 and 7 of the East Kent Access excavations evidence was found of the enclosure of the neck of the peninsula by an iron age ditch that was later recut during the Roman period (dated by pottery finds) , possibly with a military function (based on the 'V'shape of the Roman recut). Other finds were recovered from the early Roman period including a post-Claudian Nauheim brooch and a Colchester fibula. Once the Roman ditch was cut there was a general decline in the intensity of the use of this area with no further round houses. By the middle Roman period the pattern of enclosures and ditches had almost completely disappeared. Two sunken-features buildings were instead constructed, one close to a small cemetery on the western limit of the excavation. The building itself went out of use and an oven was constructed in the hollow. (1)

Site_name_other: Bronze Age to Roman activity, Cottington Hill
Site_summary: During excavations associated with the East Kent Access Route (2009-2011) in Zones 7 and 8 extensive archaeological remains were found dating from the Middle Bronze Age through to the Roman period. The remains consisted of numerous enclosures, trackways and ditches related to the agricultural use of the site as well as evidence of settlement in the form of a bronze age  oven, an iron age round-house and post-built structures, and cremation and inhumation burials dating to the iron age and Roman periods. Finds consisted of pottery from all periods, animal and human bone, charcoal and daub.<gg_summary>: Two adjacent inhumation graves, cut by a Late Iron Age enclosure ditch. There is some uncertainty about which sub-period of the Iron Age these belong to (probably LIA but could be earlier). Only one of these graves had grave goods. A later Bronze Age unurned cremation was also identified in this area but no Iron Age cremations (as the existing site description suggests).
Site_description: During excavations associated with the East Kent Access Route (2009-2011) in Zone 7 extensive archaeological remains were found dating from the Middle Bronze Age through to the Roman period. The middle to late bronze age period was represented by enclosures defined by parallel ditches oriented north-west to south-east.  These were truncated in the late bronze age when a number of pits were excavated which may possibly included a fire-pit, a rake-out pit and a central flue with charcoal and daub, all suggesting an oven.In the late bronze age a new field system was established consisting of double-ditched enclosures that may represent droveways. Shorter ditches divided the area into fields and paddocks. Pottery finds in the area dated the site to the late bronze age to the early iron age.During the iron age the main focus was in the north of the area. Post-built structures and a cremation burial were found within an area bounded by two trackways. Pottery dated mostly to the middle to late iron age periods. A number of iron age cremation burials and inhumation burials were also found as well as one Roman inhumation. Pottery was found from throughout the middle iron age to the Roman period with a small amount of early iron age pottery also present. During the late iron age a round-house was constructed and a series of enclosures.With the exception of a few pits, a possible well and a single inhumation burial, the majority of Roman activity was in the south of the area. Two phases of activity were observed, mostly agricultural in nature. Roman pottery and animal bone were recovered.(1)(1)

Site_name_other: Small bronze age agricultural settlement and burials
Site_summary: During the East Kent Access Route excavations (2009-2011) a small middle to late bronze age agricultural settlement was found in zone 12. The settlement consisted of ditches, gullies, pits and four cremation burials, mostly found in the western part of the zone.<gg_summary>: The three LBA cremation burials and 'cenotaph' pit from this site (Zone 12) are not recorded here as the status of the 'cenotaph' material as gg is unclear. However graves from the IA inhumation cemetery (13 graves, of which 10 were in a group and only one certainly included grave goods) are recorded here for now. This cemetery is currently recorded in the HER in a separate record as a Roman cemetery. Unaccompanied graves from the cemetery were radiocarbon dated to 410-210 and 380-200 cal BC. Isotope evidence suggests that those interred weren't born locally (Andrews et al. 2015, 154-7). Two graves with potential grave goods (an iron nail within G136033 and 10% of a shale armlet roughout in G166002) are not recorded currently.<borderline_gg>NB Quantification of incidence of burials with gg vs incidence of burials overall relates only to inhumation cemetery
Site_description: During the East Kent Access Route excavations (2009-2011) a small middle to late bronze age agricultural settlement was found in zone 12. The settlement consisted of ditches, gullies, pits and four cremation burials, mostly found in the western part of the zone. At the western end were three small ditches and two gullies. One curved in an arc and was truncated by an iron age ditch. It contained a large amount of middle bronze age pottery.Slightly to the east a pit contained 55 more sherds of middle bronze age pottery.The remaining ditches have all been dated to the late bronze age with some perhaps extending into the early iron age. They may have included a small enclosure. One feature was a large tree-throw and contained 28 sherds of middle to late bronze age pottery. Four possible bronze age cremation buirials were found. Three were located in a group. One contained 43 sherds of late bronze age pottery but no cremated bone and may have been a cenotaph rather than a burial. The other three cremations all contained bone but no dating evidence. (1)

Site_name_other: Middle iron age pits west of the trapezoidal enclosure
Site_summary: During the East Kent Access Route excavations (2009-2011) a group of middle iron age pits were discovered west of the trapezoidal enclosure. The 21 pits were in three broadly parallel lines and may have been grouped around enclosures or structures. The contained large amounts of domestic material including animal bone, pottery, fired clay, shell, spindle whorls, loomweights (or briquetage) and worked stone. The area also contained what appeared to be quarry pits and a post-built structure. Some of the pits contained human remains and skeletons.<gg_summary>: Two MIA pit burials from the same zone (Zone 13) are recorded here for now, although HER prefref TR 36 SW 387 is perhaps the most directly relevant record. Radiocarbon dates from other burials in this group spanned the period 390-180 cal BC (Andrews et al. 2015, 163-6).
Site_description: During the East Kent Access Route excavations (2009-2011) a group of middle iron age pits were discovered west of the trapezoidal enclosure. The 21 pits were in three broadly parallel lines and may have been grouped around enclosures or structures. The contained large amounts of domestic material including animal bone, pottery, fired clay, shell, spindle whorls, loomweights (or briquetage) and worked stone. The area also contained what appeared to be quarry pits and a post-built structure. Some of the pits contained human remains and skeletons including crouched and flexed inhumations. (1)

Site_summary: During the East Kent Access Route excavations (2009-2011) in zone 21 (western end) , a bronze age ring-ditch was found and partially excavated, one of a number along the chalk ridge.<gg_summary>: Four burials in pits under barrow or ring ditch  - only one was accompanied by any grave goods which included a highly unusual triple pot of FV tendency. Two burials them may be of women (aged 25–30 and 35–50) and the third was of a 9–12-month-old infant; none of these three graves, which included the one in the centre of the barrow, held any surviving artefacts. The triple pot lay in the grave of a third woman estimated from her bones to have been 17–20 years old. She lay on her side with flexed limbs, and the pot was standing by her right elbow. A conical amber button was found near her head, and fragments of copper alloy may come from a small pin.
Site_description: During the East Kent Access Route excavations (2009-2011) in zone 21 (western end) , a bronze age ring-ditch was found and partially excavated, one of a number along the chalk ridge.Only two-thirds of this ring-ditch lay within the excavation area. It was estimated to be c. 22.5m diameter with a ditch up to 2.7m wide and 1.4m deep. It contained four inhumation burials. All were crouched and included one sub-adult. One was located more centrally than the others and may have been the primary burial. One of the other three was accompanied by a 'triple miniature Food Vessel' (3 vessels?)  positioned by the right elbow, a conical amber stud and what may have been the remains of a copper alloy pin. These are taken to indicate an early bronze Age date for this burial. The three other graves were unaccompanied(1)

Site_name_other: Seven probable bronze age inhumation burials and one cremation
Site_summary: During the East Kent Access Route excavations (2009-2011) in zone 21 (western end) , seven probable bronze age inhumation burials and one cremation burial were discovered buried in an approximate line running south-west to north-east.<gg_summary>: Two separate burial episodes within a small area. Early and Middle Bronze Age ring ditches were identified more broadly. The evidence represented here comprises a single E/MBA urned cremation (1640-1460 cal BC) and a linear cemetery of six LBA inhumation burials c. 10m to the north (1060-840 cal BC). None of the latter were associated with any objects (see Andrews et al. 2015 fig. 2.14 for context).NB May be difficult to use this site for quantification of incidence of burials with gg vs incidence of burials overall (multiperiod)<add further info from publication>
Site_description: During the East Kent Access Route excavations (2009-2011) in zone 21 (western end) , seven probable bronze age inhumation burials were discovered aligned in a line running roughly south-west to north-east, possibly along the line of a fence or boundary. All the burials were flexed / crouched and none contained grave goods. A single sherd of middle bronze age pottery was recovered from the fill indicating a probable bronze age date for the group. 10 m south-west of this group another burial was found which contained a cremation burial within a middle bronze age urn.(1)

Site_summary: 3 'Belgic' cremations were observed to the rear of 4-5 Whitehall Close in 1954 by Frank Jenkins.  This is thought to relate to the building of two blocks of maisonnettes in the vicinity in December of that year.<gg_summary>: very poor contextual detail
Site_description: 3 'Belgic' cremations were observed to the rear of 4-5 Whitehall Close in 1954 by Frank Jenkins.  This is thought to relate to the building of two blocks of maisonnettes in the vicinity in December of that year.

Site_summary: The earliest features dated to the pre- and early Roman period and were two structures, B3 and B4.  A hearth was also found (1277).  16 pits and two gullies were also found within area MT. A cremation (1205) was  excavated and consisted of cremated bones contained within a pedestal urn which had been set upright in a small hole.  It predates Gullies (1210) & (1036).<gg_summary>: cremated bones contained within a pedestal urn, set upright in a small hole cut into a LIA (1st century BC) round house gully (Blockley et al. 1995, 36-7).
Site_description: Between July and October 1982 The Canterbury Archaeological Trust excavated upon the site of the current 1-6 and 10-11 Marlowe Arcade prior to redevelopment of the area.  The sitecode was MT82. The earliest features dated to the pre- and early Roman period and were two structures, B3 and B4.  A hearth was also found (1277).  16 pits and two gullies were also found within area MT. A cremation (1205) was  excavated and consisted of cremated bones contained within a pedestal urn which had been set upright in a small hole.  It predates Gullies (1210) & (1036).

Site_summary: A crouched burial of Iron Age or Belgic Date was discovered in a small trench in this carpark.  The skeleton, that of an adult female of c. 21 year was found wearing an iron bangle.
Site_description: In 1948-50 Frank Jenkins and John Boyle excavated a site on the north west side of St John's Lane.  A site code was subsequently allotted, SJL51 and the RCHME reference is 639738.A crouched burial of Iron Age or Belgic Date was discovered in a small trench in this car park. The skeleton, that of an adult female of c. 21 year was found wearing an iron bangle.

Site_summary: A Canterbury Archaeological Trust Monitoring of the work on Folkestone Transfer Pipeline uncovered various Bronze Age-Early Roman fatures and finds.<gg_summary>: one MBA cremation burial located at Church Hougham; eleven LIA cremation burials excavated at Great Hougham Court Farm, at least one (photographed in the summary article in Canterbury's Archaeology) with grave goods.The evidence is summarised in brief by Parfitt (1998) as follows:Gravel Lane, Hougham: A total of 12 burials was recovered. Although most were heavily plough-damaged, fragments of about 30 individual pots were recovered, together with quantities of cremated bone. Most of the pottery appears to be locally made grog-tempered ware and the general absence of imported Gallo-Belgic and Romanised vessels suggests that the cremetery is relative early, perhaps 50 B.C.-1 A.D. The burials fall within the well-known Aylesford burial tradition but nevertheless represent an important group, coming from an area where evidence for late Iron Age occupation has been previously absent. Investigation ofthe cemetery site showed that the burials had been cut through an earlier, ditched field system, also apparently of late Iron Age date. It seems likely that the cemetery represents a small family burial ground probably associated with a settlement area previously located (but not yet examined) further to the south-west. Two corroded copper-alloy objects recovered from the cremation cemetery (Site 3) have been cleaned and can now be recognised as typical La Tene III brooches of late Iron Age date.Church Hougham: A small circular pit containing an inverted pottery vessel covering a cremation burial was discovered near Church Hougham. The vessel has been provisionally identified as a Deverel Rimbury type bucket urn, of Middle Bronze Age date.For basic data entry, one grave record is entered for the Church Hougham MBA cremation burial; 12 incidences of human remains; 30 pots and 2 brooches are entered within one grave record until further information is available.<awaiting further info>
Site_description: A Canterbury Archaeological Trust Monitoring of the work on Folkestone Transfer Pipeline uncovered various Bronze Age-Early Roman features and finds. These are detailed below in the order they are presented in the report summary which is based on the location of the features/finds:Various features cutting natural brick earth were identified at Gravel Lane, Hougham which dated to either the Iron Age or Roman periods. Gravel Lane also saw the uncovering of a Late Iron Age cremation cemetery. A straight ditch at Hougham Court Lane was identified and given a Bronze Age/Iron Age date. A Middle Bronze Age pit cremation was identified near Church Hougham.Roman field ditches were identified near Hougham Church.A single pit with substantial pottery evidence from the Bronze Age/Iron Age was uncovered East of Plough Hill. (1)The report does not draw together this disparate feature with a cohesive interpretation of the landscape. It is simply a record of the features.

Site_name_other: Late Neolithic/early Bronze Age activity at Thanet Earth
Parish_Community_Borough: ST NICHOLAS AT WADE, THANET, KENT
Site_summary: Six ring ditches, representing the remains of ploughed burial mounds or barrows were excavated in an evaluation in 2007 and 2008. They date from the latest Neolithic to the Early Bronze Age.<gg_summary>: Grouped record for LN/EBA burials with gg at Thanet Earth. This includes burials associated with barrows 1 and 5 together with isolated Beaker/EBA burials.
Site_description: In 2007 and 2008 a programme of archaeological evaluation took place at the site which is now Thanet Earth. Six ring ditches, undoubtedly representing the remains of ploughed out burial mounds or barrows were located and mostly fully excavated (apart from baulks that were occasionally left in situ). Four (Barrows 1_4) were found in the southern part of the site, the other two (Barrows 5_6) further north and more isolated. The form of these features and their associated burials, where present, indicates that they probably date from the latest Neolithic/early Bronze Age period. Barrows 3 and 4 contained inhumation burials C_14 dated to the first half of the second millennium BC, which could imply that these were secondary insertions, although their central locations may favour a primary interpretation.      The first barrow contained a grave of a crouching adult male inhumation with associated grave goods. Barrow 2 revealed five graves adjacent to each other lying within the central area of the round barrow, forming an approximate line from near the centre south_westwards; none were well preserved and no grave goods were associated. Another barrow revealed a few scraps of badly preserved skeleton. Barrow 4 revealed a single grave located slightly off_centre (just south_west) within the interior and contained the well preserved remains of an adult (SK6245) lying crouched on the base. No grave goods were found with this burial. Barrq 5 revealed very few finds apart from seven sherds of prehistoric pottery and a fragment of worked antler.Two graves were located adjacent to each other lying slightly north of centre within the ring_ditch. Barrow 6 was a complete ring ditch but no central burial was found.    In addition to the interments in barrows, a scatter of more isolated burials of this period was located across the northern part of the site. These inhumation burials were normally accompanied by a beaker, in one instance two, but did not seem to be associated or encircled by a ditch. (1)

Site_summary: Late Iron Age -Roman features, including ditches and cremation burials were observed in an evaluation in 2007 and 2008.<gg_summary>: A rare and therefore especially significant middle Iron Age settlement was discovered on Plateau 8; intensively occupied from c.500-300 bc, this may have originated earlier and was still in use as late as c.100/75 bc. An unusual double interment within a small ring ditch has been radiocarbon dated to about the same period, and a small late Iron Age inhumation cemetery comprising twenty-nine graves (plus one cremation burial) marks another rare and important prehistoric find for the project.Summary information from Rady and Holman's forthcoming publication of this site is included here. Only burials that are almost certainly pre-Conquest are recorded here. Worth noting (but not recorded) is Conquest period cremation burial S10688 which produced a token amount of cremated human bone together with a rich and carefully layered assemblage of grave goods comprising eleven LIA/Conquest period vessels (the most recent definitely post-Conquest in origin so classified as Roman), parts of five cu-alloy brooches, and a lead spindlewhorl.
Site_description: An archaeological evaluation took place in 2007 and 2008 on the site which is now Thanet Earth. Generally, finds of this period were sparse compared with some of the other periods. There did not seem to be any concentration of activity sucah as a settlement. At least three separate hollow ways, extending across the site from east to west, one curving to the north_east, were in use during the Roman period, but almost certainly originated as routes before, probably in the Iron Age. Small groups of cremation burials were associated with one of these trackways, as was a single Roman structure. Two phases of rectilinear field system defined by ditches were also located, the earlier probably originating in the late Iron Age. Two small square enclosures were located that were associated with the earlier field system. Enclosure 10 contained three cremation burials (G8162, two of which were quite richly furnished box burials) suggesting that it was a mortuary enclosure. At least some of the burials may be related to the only definite Roman structure located on the site (SFB 1) which consisted of an isolated sunken_featured structure, similar in some ways to others previously found on Thanet, but otherwise unique. Other remains included a number of quarries and isolated pits mostly situated in the northern half of the Thanet Earth site; this concentration of remains, steadily diminishing towards the southern higher areas, is a facet of the feature distribution as a whole. (1)

Site_name_other: Bronze Age Barrow and Beaker Burial, Lyminge, Kent
Site_summary: A Bronze Age Beaker Burial and a barrow were unexpectedly discovered in an excavation at Tayne Field, Lyminge as part of the Anglo-Saxon oriented Lyminge Archaeological Project in 2014.Two phases of Bronze Age burials were found in association with the barrow.1) crouched inhumation burial on an N-S alignment accompanied by grave goods - a Beaker pot and a perforated bone ‘toggle’. Both the skeleton and associated grave goods were crushed and in a poor state of preservation due to the severity of truncation of the contemporary ground level. 2) a cluster of four urned and one un-urned cremations located at roughly the mid-point of the barrow
Site_description: A Bronze Age Beaker Burial and a barrow were unexpectedly discovered in an excavation at Tayne Field, Lyminge as part of the Anglo-Saxon oriented Lyminge Archaeological Project in 2014.The Beaker burial was located in Trench 2. It was a crouched bruial with a pottery 'accessory' vessel and a perforated bone toggle.The barrow had first revealed itself as a 20m diameter ring ditch in the geophysical survey on the site and was confirmed in April 2014 during a trial excavation. Urned and un-urned cremations were found in the midpoint of the barrow. A host of associated finds were recovered after cutting across the ring ditch including a Bronze Age copper alloy rapier or dirk, diagnostic flint and a small assemblage of animal bone as well as a copper alloy tanged chisel.(1)

Site_name_other: Bronze Age Urned and Unurned Cremations
Site_summary: During February and March 2014, an archaeological excavation was carried out on the site that would form an extension of a sand extraction quarry. An urned cremation dated to early Bronze Age and an unurned cremation provisionally dated to same period were uncovered during the excavation. Nearby are two pits which may be associated as they contain possible pyre material.<awaiting further info>
Site_description: During February and March 2014, an archaeological excavation was carried out on the site that would form an extension of a sand extraction quarry. Two cremations found within a few metres of one another alongside two pits containing probable pyre material. One cremation was urned, and comprised of an in situ cremation vessel, represented by an inverted biconnical urn, dating to the first half of the 2nd millennium BC (2000-1500 BC). The unurned cremation contained fewer bone fragments to the urned cremation and is dated provisionally to the same period as the urned cremation. Each cremation contains a single individual, representing adults or older juveniles. Two nearby pits contain possible pyre debris, as they contain charcoal similar to the samples recovered from both cremation burials, oak-rich charcoal. The gathering of the pits contianing the cremation burials and possible pyre residue are suggested to represent a small Early Bronze Age Cemetery.(1)

Site_summary: late Bronze Age cremation urn, found 1925. It is actually more likely an EBA Collared Urn cremation <gg_summary> urned cremation, potentially found in association with a Bronze Age arrowhead and biconical holed hammer or adze. Described by the excavator as LBA but (as noted in the NRHE) almost certainly E/MBA. Grinsell (1992) mentions that a beaker pot washed out of the cliff in the same area in 1975 ... (barrow?). Battle axe and arrowhead sound EBA not LBA
Site_description: [TR 13296745] Late Bronze Age remains found A.D.1922 and 1925 [NAT] [TR 13276750] Late Bronze Age cremation found A.D.1925 [NAT](1-4) A late Bronze Age hoard of 16 objects from Swalecliffe is in the British Museum.  It comprises socketed axes, swords, spearheads, winged axes and founder's metal, and was revealed in 1922 by a fall of cliff 320 yards eastwards from the boundary stone [shown on Worsfold's map at TR 13016738]. At 345 yards eastwards from the stone, a late Bronze Age cinerary urn containing calcined bone and ash, was found in 1925 (7) with a Bronze Age arrowhead and biconical holed hammer or adze nearby. [The siting on the O.S. County Series agrees with Worsfold's siting evidence for the hoard, the cremation being 25 yards away.  The incorrect siting on the O.S. N.G. Series seems to have been taken from the personal records of L.R.A. Grove which were kept on a copy of O.S.6" 1908.]    (5-7) Twelve objects from this hoard, including a winged axe and the fragments of two socketed axes are on exhibition Maidstone Museum ex. Worsfold's collection. Two looper and socketed palstaves from this hoard are in the possession of Mr. W.C. Harvey, 53 Oxford Street, Whitstable. The sites of both hoard and burial now fall on the foreshore below high water mark, but can be accurately plotted (from Worsfold's description, H.W.Ms. on contemporary plans and identification of the boundary stone) to TR 1329567478 and TR 1331567487 (the latter coincides with a Me/Ne site - see TR 16 NW 2.)   (8). Additional references (9,10). Photographs (11,12).

Site_name_other: Belgic ditch pottery & Roman pottery, small building
Site_summary: Belgic ditch pottery & Ro pottery, small building<gg_summary>: A series of belgic burial urns identified during the construction of the Maidstone by-pass. No further info available. One urn/one burial recorded here as bare minimum.
Site_description: The construction of the Maidstone by-pass has exposed two structures to the west of Hollingbourne on the Maidstone side of Musket Lane. To the north of the road Belgic pottery was found in the filling of a ditch: to the south twenty yards further west the ragstone foundations of a small building together with first and early second century Romany pottery.    (1) [Area centred TQ 8227 5500] Mr. V. J. Newbery (a) who excavated this site, states that during the construction of a cutting on the line of the Maidstone by-pass, between Musket Lane and the railway bridge, a Belgic oven base was found in the S. bank and a Belgic ditch and a series of burial urns in the N. bank (More exact siting could not be obtained.  The sherds are in the finder's possession).   (2)

Site_summary: Burnt pits and associated artefacts, Hurst Wood, found during CTRL works in 1998.<gg_summary>: Two isolated cremations - one urned, one unurned. Both potentially MBA (Champion in Andrews et al 2011, 232). NB Hurst Wood and East of Newlands are used interchangeably in the CTRL reports ...
Site_description: In 1998 the Oxford Archaeological Unit carried out an evaluation of the site prior to works associated with the Channel Tunnel Rail Link. The site was characterised by a scatter of burnt, shallow pits.  Very few artefacts were recovered from these features, but on present evidence, an Iron Age, Roman, or later date seems most likely.  The function of the pits is unknown, but their proximity to Hurst Wood seems to suggest that they may be linked to charcoal burning or woodland clearance activity.  A small assemblage of finds was recovered, including burnt and worked flints,  a small number of Bronze Age and Iron Age sherds and a single Romano-British sherd. The finds have yet to be examined in detail but the fragments are generally very small and badly abraided.  The very small number of prehistoric artefacts from the burnt pits could very well be intrusive and do not neccessarily provide a reliable date for the burnt features, although they produced no securely stratified later material. (1-2)Excavation carried out in 1998. More pits with evidence of burning found. (3-4)Additional bibliography. (5-6)

Site_summary: 44 Prehistoric and Roman cremation burials, as well as ceramics, animal bones, and metal artefacts.<gg_summary>: Of the 38 cremated human bone deposits, only one (Burial AAB) produced objects clearly of LIA date.
Site_description: From the report:"The archaeological strip, map and record excavations undertaken on the A249 Iwade bypass have successfully addressed the principal project aims and objectives.  The fieldwork has generated a large body of archaeological data representing c. 2000 years of human activity, dating primarially from the Late Neolithic to the Roman periods.  The results, although not totally conclusive, have been obtained by means of a thorough stratigraphic analysis of the site, despite the poor survival of much of the archaeology, including evidence for the truncation of features and of significant post-depositional disturbance.  These problems were compounded by the fragmented nature of the associated pottery and the low pottery sherd count for most of the non-burial pottery assemblages. (see appendices 12.2 and 12.3).Zone A, which was predominantly Roman in date, contained evidence of both settlement activity (salt-making?) and cremation burial features.  Zone B, containing only cremation burial features, was also predominantly Roman in date.  Likewise, Zone C was predominantly Roman and with the exception of one feature contained only cremation burial features.  Settlement features excavated in Zone D1 were mostly undated but possibly of Iron Age date.  Zone D2 was negative in terms of archaeology. Zone D3 contained an area of intensive multi-phase settlement activity focused on the Middle to Late Iron Age. Zone D4 was also predominantly Roman in date but also contained a high level of prehistoric activity and evidence of disturbance.The results suggest that both the Prehistoric and Roman activity (including the cremation burial activity) was focused on areas of higher ground.  This is generally the norm for the later Prehistoric period, particularly from the Middle Iron Age when hillforts become more common.  Roman activity and cremation burials on the other hand, are not usually confined to higher ground.  Another dissimilarity is the lack of associated Roman inhumation burials at the site - in east Kent a localised tradition of inhumation burials has been observed alongside the cremation rite. (East Sussex C.C. et al 2007)The ephemeral prehistoric and Roman settlement/salt-making activity on the A249 Iwade bypass was confined to the lower ground in Zone A, close to the edge of the marsh.  No further evidence was found for Late Iron Age (or other) features recorded by the Stage 4 evaluation trenches at the northern extent of Zone A, south of Cowstead roundabout.  Similarly, in contrast to the results of the initial desk based assessment and Stage 2 survey, virtually no evidence was found for Medieval or Post-Medieval activity anywhere across the stripped area of the road scheme.Evidence of small scale Early - Middle Bronze Age activity across the site was recorded by the current flint assessment (see Appendix 12.1). This was not confirmed by the results of the prehistoric pottery assessment however, which, with the exception of a small number of possible Middle or Late Bronze Age sherds, found no secure evidence of activity between the Early Bronze Age and the Middle Bronze Age.  The bulk of the prehistoric pottery was dated to the latter period.  The prehistoric pottery assessment suggested a similarity of forms with assemblages found north of the Thames, as opposed to further west; but also found similarities with Essex in terms of adopted decoration of pottery vessels.

Site_name_other: Middle Iron Age settlement and burials
Site_summary: Middle Iron Age settlement at the White Horse Stone site.<gg_summary>: The E-MIA settlement included 'a small pit associated with a deposit of charred grain, cremated human remains and a set of iron tools to the south' and 'two inhumation burials to the west, where almost all of the other (disarticulated) human remains were found' (Hayden 2006, 126).Pit burial 2296 and cremation burial 6132 were clearly associated with grave goods (ibid., 158-9). The placed human remains in pit 8012 are also recorded here, since both the human fragments and the associated objects appeared to have been carefully placed (ibid., 159). Burial 2184 is not included as the contents of this pit were not significantly different to those of other pits on the site (with the exception of loom weight and iron nail fragments) (ibid., 158). The other disarticulated human bone fragments from the site were recovered from pits in the same area and were typically associated with animal bones including types that were also restricted to this part of the site (red deer, dog). Fragments of a shale bracelet and copper alloy brooch were also recovered from these features. These are not clearly grave goods so, again, they are not included here.NB May be difficult to use this site for quantification of incidence of burials with gg vs incidence of burials overall (multiperiod)
Site_description: Excavations undertaken around the White Horse Stone site in the Medway Valley between Oct 1998-Mar 1999 by Oxford Archaeology. The site consisted of three areas along the CTRL line; from west to east: the White Horse Stone site, the Pilgrims Way site, and the West of Boarley Farm site.A settlement in the north of the White Horse Stone site was occupied from the early to middle Iron Age. This settlement consists of a central complex of intercutting pits surrounded by numerous structures, mostly four-posted, and one with a penannular ditch. Pits also surrounded the site; those on the western side contained human remains (cremated and isolated disarticulated bones), pottery and animal bone; the pits in the south contained human remains, charred grain, and a set of metal tools, deposited in pots; the pits in the east contained large quantities of iron slag (though very few iron artefacts were found on the site). Some fired clay, though a noticeable lack of loomweights. Quernstones were also noticably rare. (1)Additional bibliography. (2-3)

Site_summary: A cist was found in January 1885 in a low natural knowe on Gyron Hill. It contained an upright steatite pot full of cremated bones
Site_description: This bowl-shaped mound measures 15.0m by 15.0m and 0.55m in height. It is visible for up to 3km to the SE and for 1km to the NW. Information from the Orkney Barrows Project (JD), 1993

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Part of a more extensive barrow cluster cemetery at Queenafjold, Twatt. An earthen mound, 10m x 8.3m in diameter and 1m high, which has been excavated twice. During the first excavation, before 1930, the base of a steatite vessel, now in Kirkwall Museum, was recovered. No hr were noted to have been found with this vessel and it is not recorded here. The second excavation was undertaken by Graham and Anna Ritchie in 1967. The barrow had been built to enclose a cist, aligned NE and SW, the base of which rested on the ground level as it was at the time of building, with the slab which formed the floor of the cist lying on Layer 8. A handful of cremated bone with some few flecks of charcoal had been scattered underneath this slab.  The cist is fairly centrally located within the barrow. The cremated bones were deposited in the cist and a quantity of the charcoal of the pyre had been gathered up with the bones. Analysis of this charcoal shows that birch and hazel were among the types of wood used in the fire. A very badly burnt and crumbling pot sherd was found among the cremated remains, and a chipped stone pot-lid had been deposited in the cist presumably to accompany the burial. The cremated remains represented two individuals; one female and one male.NB noted in Moore and Wilson 1995 to have produced flat-rimmed (MBA?) pottery but not clear how this has been assigned. Ritchie and Ritchie (1974) assign the burial tentatively to the mid to late 2nd millennium BC based on the construction of the cist (much like that at the Knowes of Trotty). On this basis, the burial is given a broad mid to late 2nd millennium BC date here.
Site_description: HY22SE 36 2654 2496.   (HY 2654 2496) Tumulus (NR)  OS  6" map, Orkney, 2nd ed., (1900).   An earthen mound, 38 ft in diameter and 3 ft high, which has been excavated twice. During the first excavation, before 1930, the base of a steatite vessel, now in Kirkwall Museum, was recovered.The second excavation, currently in progress, is being conducted by Graham Ritchie (Information from a telephone call from Graham Ritchie to J L Davidson RCAHMS 20 April 1967). who has recovered a cist containing a cremation.  RCAHMS 1946; G Ritchie and A Ritchie 1975.   A barrow, as described by the Commission. Ritchie's excavation has been completed and the turves replaced. The steatite vessel base is still in Kirkwall Museum.  Revised at 1:2500.  Visited by OS (NKB) 19 May 1967.   No visible evidence.OS revision, October 1985.DESCRIPTION 2:No visible evidence.OS revision, October 1985.

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Laughton's Knowe, Holm, Orkney. Piggott (1946) summarises the evidence as follows:The bronze blade which is the subject of this note ... was found in a stone cist in a mound known as Laughton's Knowe in the parish of Holn on the mainland of Orkney (R.C. Inventory, No. 368). From the description of this mound in the Inventory it is almost certainly of prehistoric date, and it is not unlikely, therefore, that this cist and cremation represents a Late Bronze Age secondary burial inserted into an earlier mound. Within the cist, details of which have not been preserved, was a heap of cremated bones, on the top of which lay the bronze blade incased in the remains of a wooden sheath.The dating of this object is not clear - originally thought to be LBA, it assigned to the MBA in a 1960s review of Scottish BA metalwork and is given a broad BA date in the NMS database/a recent MA dissertation. It is assigned a broad BA date here. The sheath is recorded together with the razor (rather than as sep. objects)
Site_description: HY40SE 1 4826 0258.   (HY 4826 0258) Laughton's Knowe (NAT)  OS 6" map, Orkney, 2nd ed.,(1903).   Laughton's Knowe is a grass covered mound about 45 ft. in diameter and 9 ft. high.  RCAHMS 1946.   A stone cist (possibly secondary) containing a Late Bronze Age cremation burial with a bronze razor in a wooden (?hazel) sheath was found in the mound about 1916.  The razor was presented to the National Museum of Antiquities of Scotland (NMAS) by Mr P Sutherland Graeme.  C M Piggott 1950.   Laughton's Knowe a mound of earth and stone is as described above, but has been mutilated in the N and E.  Surveyed at 1/2500.  Visited by OS (RD) 28 August 1964.The razor is held in the National Museum of Scotland under accession number Royal Museum of Scotland EQ 557.J M Coles 1966.DESCRIPTION 2:Laughton's Knowe a mound of earth and stone is as described above, but has been mutilated in the N and E.  Surveyed at 1/2500.  Visited by OS (RD) 28 August 1964.

Site_name_other: SOUTH WALLS, CANTICK HEAD, SOUTH WAAS
Site_summary: <gg summary>: The monument was originally a Neolithic stalled cairn with later burials inserted in the EBA. Excavations by Orkney College  revealed under mound complex of central cists (not excavated this season) and a secondary box cist (c0.8 x 0.5 x 0.54m internally) of more typical Bronze Age type. This was the only cist to be investigated and contained a disturbed cremation burial and un-burnt human bone. A decorated rim sherd from a Bronze Age Food Vessel was also recovered.
Site_description: ND 3405 8905 Excavations from 20?30 June 2011 concluded work on this large (c11.5m wide by 1.2m high) burial mound. The established trench was extended to the E, to further investigate the partly excavated central stone-lined cist, and to expose the edge of the large central area to the N that was defined by substantial orthostats. This rubble-filled depression was previously thought to represent a large disturbed central cist.Excavations this season revealed that the first phase of the monument consisted of a small stalled Neolithic tomb measuring c3 x 2m internally with six large orthostats forming two opposing pairs of stalls. The tomb was aligned NE?SW with an entrance to the NE (unexcavated). The concentric external stone revetment walls exposed during previous seasons formed the outside of the tomb (c10m in diameter). The large central depression that was partly excavated last season (DES 2010, 132?3) turned out to be the robbed remains of the NW cell, although the inner wall had been removed. The tomb was not fully excavated, this stall was the only part to be investigated to floor level, and no human remains were recovered. A possible posthole was discovered below the robbed internal wall line, perhaps representing a construction marker, and charcoal was recovered for dating. Several cists were inserted into the mound when the Neolithic tomb was backfilled. The cists contained cremation burials and probably date to the Bronze Age. A third cist (c0.80 x 0.49 x 0.62m), which had been inserted into the top of the backfilled tomb entrance, was discovered this season. The cist had previously been disturbed and there was no evidence of a cremation burial. Unburnt human bone was found within the loose backfill, but this could have been incorporated during disturbance.The key discovery this season was the remains of an inhumation burial in the central cist. This relates to the substantial stone constructed square barrow that was built into the mound (DES 2009, 2010). The insertion of this cist involved removing and breaking several large orthostats and cutting into the backfilled Neolithic tomb. The central inhumation had been disturbed, most likely by antiquarians, and only the hands and feet remained in situ. The body was crouched and laid on the left side. The remains of a ?juvenile inhumation, also crouched and placed on the left side, was found outside the central cist to the NE, within a layer of rubble. The unburnt human bone found across the mound, especially in the N cist and around the central cist, was probably derived from these disturbed burials. The remains of the neonate burials found in 2009 to the SW of the central cist could also date to this phase (DES 2009, 141?2). These burial rites and the square barrow architecture suggest that this phase of the monument dates to the Iron Age and possibly the first few centuries AD. The 2011 excavations have confirmed the long history of construction and burial at Roeberry Barrow from the Neolithic to Iron Age, and portray the monument as a significant place for the communities at Cantick for several millennia.Archive: ORCA (currently)Funder: Orkney Islands Council, Scapa Flow Landscape Partnership (HLF) and ORCAORCA, 2011

Site_summary: Petrie (unpublished notebook - see HER) mentions that the contents were a piece of skull and some well-preserved bones and a crouched skeleton, though the account does not make clear if these were separate items or from a single cist.At least 4 individuals but only one with grave goods Short-cist
Site_description: This bowl-shaped mound measures 6.0m in diameter and 0.4m in height. It is located on the highest point of a low rise. Information from the Orkney Barrows Project (JD), 1994DESCRIPTION 3:HY22SE 30 2798 2112.   (HY 2798 2112) Tumulus (NR)  OS 6" map, Orkney, 2nd ed., (1903).   The Commission imply that this was the barrow excavated by Petrie in 1869.(information from G Petrie's Ms notebook No.9). It contained no grave.  RCAHMS 1946.   A well-shaped turf-covered barrow, 0.5m high and 8.0m in diameter, situated on a slight eminence. A small excavation trench is visible in the east side.Revised at 1/2500.  Visited by OS (NKB) 21 May 1967.'The Orcadian' described the excavation of this site, in January 1869.

Site_name_other: MILLHOUSE, SAND FIOLD, BAY OF SKAILL
Site_summary: Barrow with three cists, one of which contained beads. These may be the jet necklace reported by Low as having been found by Banks in the area. One male and one female in cist. The female was diasrticulated and placed in bag by legs of male who was in a crouched position
Site_description: HY21NW 15 2388 1913.   (HY 2388 1913) Tumuli (NR)  OS 6" map, Orkney, 2nd ed., (1903).   Three ancient burial mounds, the largest of which was opened by Sir Joseph Banks (Name Book 1880) before 1772, disclosing three cists, one of which contained beads. These may be the jet necklace reported by Low as having been found by Banks in the area.(Information from G Low 1879) The type of cists is not stated but Banks records two variations in the vicinity, one - a short cist of five rough-hewn stones, covered by a small cairn and overlaid by sand, and the other - a cist of six stones, the sixth forming the floor, inserted into the sand-hills, some times  in layers. They contained skeletons of men, women and children, but whether crouched or extended is not known.  The Commission, in 1928, found it impossible to locate the three published mounds among so many of their kind.  RCAHMS 1946.   Only two sandy grass-covered mounds can now be identified with any of those published on the OS 6" - B and C.  A - HY 2379 1912, no trace, possibly ploughed out.  B - HY 2382 1915 - a large, well-shaped circular mound, 1.8m. high, possibly a natural sand-dune.  C - HY 2389 1915 - a low spread mound, 1.2m. high, possibly a natural sand-dune.  D - HY 2394 1915 - Mrs Linklater (Information from Mrs Linklater, Millcroft, Beyskaill.) pointed out the spot where, while quarrying for sand c.1945, a mechanical excavator exposed a capstone below which was a human skull. This site occurred under a mound similar to the others, but only a fraction of its west side now remains.  Surveyed at 1/2500.  Visited by OS (AA) 20 May 1967.DESCRIPTION 2:Only two sandy grass-covered mounds can now be identified with any of those published on the OS 6" - B and C.  A - HY 2379 1912, no trace, possibly ploughed out.  B - HY 2382 1915 - a large, well-shaped circular mound, 1.8m. high, possibly a natural sand-dune.  C - HY 2389 1915 - a low spread mound, 1.2m. high, possibly a natural sand-dune.  D - HY 2394 1915 - Mrs Linklater (Information from Mrs Linklater, Millcroft, Beyskaill.) pointed out the spot where, while quarrying for sand c.1945, a mechanical excavator exposed a capstone below which was a human skull. This site occurred under a mound similar to the others, but only a fraction of its west side now remains.  Surveyed at 1/2500.  Visited by OS (AA) 20 May 1967.

Site_summary: 'B' is 43ft in diameter and about 5ft 6ins high, and has also been opened. An excavation at least 3ft deep has been made at the base, on the south side, in which an urn of steatite was found. The mound is of light coloured soil and has apparently had a kerb of fairly large stones round it.  No information about the burial
Site_description: During a visit made during the Orkney Barrows Project, it was noted that the two bowl-shaped mounds appear to be continuing to erode. The steatite urn reported during an earlier visit could not be located. Knowes of Yonbell 1: Diameter 12.0m. Height 1.0m. Some stone blocks visible. Very prominent S-SE for c.1km. Visible W for c.400m. Knowes of Yonbell 2: Diameter 12.0m. Height 1.0m. Visible for 500m to E and W. Information from the Orkney Barrows Project (JD), 1993DESCRIPTION 3:HY22SW 13 2457 2264 and 2456 2251.   (A - HY 2457 2264 : B - HY 2456 2251) Knowes of Yonbell (NR)  O.S.6"map, Orkney, 2nd ed.,(1903).   Two conspicuous burial mounds.  'A' is 53ft in diameter and from 8 to 10ft 6ins high. It has been excavated on top and at the north side but again filled in. It is said to have yielded only a few burnt bones.  'B' is 43ft in diameter and about 5ft 6ins high, and has also been opened. An excavation at least 3ft deep has been made at the base, on the south side, in which an urn of steatite was found. The mound is of light coloured soil and has apparently had a kerb of fairly large stones round it.  RCAHMS 1946.   The Knowes of Yonbell are two greatly reduced turf-covered earthen mounds.  'A' is situated conspicuously on a hill top, and now measures c.12.0m. in diameter and 1.2m. in height and is a barrow, later used as a boundary-mark.  'B', a barrow, is situated near the foot of the hill on which stands 'A', is flat-topped, and now measures c.11.0m.  in diameter and c.1.0m. high. Surveyed at 1/2500.  Visited by OS(RL) 23 May 1967.

Site_summary: Note that there were a number of pits, some with cremated bone and pyre debris (7) others with just cremated bone (1), some sterile (1); and 4 just pyre debris. Also 2 cists with cremated bone and pyre debris. Downes (2005: 151) also suggests the presence of cenotaph.There were seven mounds so these need to be divided up into their respective barrows where burials and grave goods were present.<gg_summary>: Seven mounds, grouped within an area c. 30m in diameter. The 1998 excavations comprised an L-shaped trench, positioned between Mounds 2, 4 and 5. Of these, only Mound 4 was clearly associated with potential grave/pyre goods:Mound 2: a cremation burial in a pit [1033] close to this mound was associated with a tiny fragment of pottery. It is not clear if this is burnt (hence potentially a pyre good) so it is not recorded here.Mound 4: The primary cist contained the cremated remains of at least three humans, an adult male, one older juvenile and a young child, and burnt bone from an adult sheep or goat wasalso found in the cist fill.
Site_description: These small, bowl-shaped mounds are situated in boggy ground. They form a small, compact group on a low plateau, and are not prominent in the landscape. Seven Knowes 1: Diameter 6.0m. Height 0.4m. Seven Knowes 2: Diameter 4.5m. Height 0.2m.Seven Knowes 3: Diameter 5.0m. Height 0.25m.Seven Knowes 4: Diameter 5.0m. Height 0.25m. Seven Knowes 5: Diameter 7.0m. Height 0.3m.Seven Knowes 6: measures 7.0m by 8.0m. Height 0.5m. Information from the Orkney Barrows Project (JD), 1994

Site_summary: <gg summary>: short cist containing a stone  (steatite) urn was found at the centre; however no information about the burialNote when dated, steatite urns are more often Early Bronze Age although a few also date to the Middle Bronze It is possible that the bones were degraded if inhumation. The soil here is highly acidic and the cist size is right for a crouched inhumation
Site_description: HY40SE 3 c. 463 027.   (Approx. HY 463 027) Two mounds on the farm of West Moss were opened in June 1866.  The larger, 50 ft. in diameter and 5 ft. high was of clay with a ring of boulders set within the edge.  A short cist containing a stone urn was found at the centre, 2 ft. below the top. (Information from G Petrie notebook No.9, 33).  The other, 25 ft, in diameter and 2 ft.high also contained a short cist. RCAHMS 1946.   No further information. Mounds not located.  Visited by OS (RD) 28 August 1964.DESCRIPTION 2:Excavated by George Petrie in 1866.(Information from G Petrie notebook No.9, 33).

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: The site comprises seven mounds, of which six are scheduled ancient monuments. The 2 most northerly (Mound 1 and Mound 2) were selected for excavation as they were most disturbed by rabbits and other animals. Only Mound 1 at Varme Dale contained human remains. Mound 2 was constructed over the site of a series of repeated burnings, but Jane Donwes (2005: 213-4) does not think this is a pyre site as no cremated bone was uncovered Mound 1 contained cremated bone in central cist (min 2 indiv) dated 1690-1440 BC and the secondary cist cremation dated to 1500-1290 BC. The 14C dates from Mound 2 all came from charcoal and are incredibly early (eg 3770-3630 BC).Mound 1 - two cists, both constructed on the ground surface:Cist 1: central rectangular cist 0.75 x 0.5m with 2 cremation fills. Upper fill contained 67g o cremated bone and 0.5g of charcoal. Lower fill contained 498g of cremated bone & 0.04g of hazel charcoal. they rep a MNI of 2 individuals - one adult male & a older juvenile. & burnt remains of sheep/goat & worked boneCist 2: 0.8 x 0.5m. Lots of charcoal and 497g of burnt bone from a middle-aged adult, probably male. No obvious grave or pyre goods.
Site_description: HY 40715 18796 In June 2012 brief visits were made to several scheduled sites on the S-facing slope of Enyas Hill to test their value as viewpoints for wind farm planning assessments. Varme Dale is a dispersed scheduled collection of six mounds and barrows and the visit focused on an unscheduled outlier mound at HY 40716 18792 added to the group from a 1981 account (HY41NW 2), and the highest altitude mound at 49m OD. A second smaller outlier mound, c3.5m wide by 0.3m high was noted c18m W of the first at HY 40699 18786.The various clusters of monuments are almost certainly parts of general Bronze Age activity planned to exploit the extensive panoramic outlooks across the Bay of Firth. The modern nomenclature and protective zoning tends to artificially divide the traces into segments which underplay the full spread. At a detailed level, there are differences in recognisable size, the probable content of contained cists and maybe variations in construction, but the overall pattern is a series of low earth burial mounds, 5?15m in diameter and 0.3?2.0m high. The RCAHMS records suggest Verme Dale has at least seven recognisable mounds, whilst nearby Knowes of Euro has two mounds, and West Puldrite four mounds. This gives a total of at least 13 surviving mounds, and has increased significance when the full group is viewed as a single landscape phenomenon, which may originally have contained many more elements within its zonal spread.The various hillslopes around the Bay of Firth have a very high distribution of Bronze Age mounds and tumuli and this specific Enyas hillslope gives an unexpected sightline beyond the encircling horizons to the hills of Hoy through the Finstown gap.
