In the northern excavations a square barrow and round barrow were also constructed at this time. The square barrow contained a late Iron Age inhumation and was furnished with an iron dagger and missile head. A rural farming settlement built up around the land boundaries and barrows and occupation continued until the end of the second century AD. The settlement was based around arable cultivation and livestock. Three crop driers were used between the first and second centuries AD and in the north of the site there was evidence for a system of fence-lines and droveways related to livestock management.

Site_name_other: IRON AGE, ROMANO-BRITISH AND POST MEDIEVAL FEATURES
Site_summary: <gg_summary>: possibly related to cropmark complex PRN 21672: https://www.heritagegateway.org.uk/Gateway/Results_Single.aspx?uid=MHU21672&resourceID=1043<awaiting further info>
Site_description: <Summary in Hull Daily Mail, November 2017>: The deeper of the two graves contained the remains of a man who was buried with a sword, shield and spear. The sword had been deliberately bent, which usually indicates a ceremonial event when the weapon is "killed". It is believed to be a form of religious offering, as are oxtails, which were also discovered in the graves. They were both found buried in what was likely to be an Iron Age cemetery. Northern Archaeological Associates was called in to assess the remains, which also included evidence of numerous Iron Age round houses, along with a large scattering of tools, spoons and pottery.

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Whimster (1981) summarises the evidence as follows:One of two barrows excavated by Greenwell ante-1877 and a third identified by field survey.Small barrow, diameter 21 1 , standing to a height of 21 (0.6 m). Central grave 1.9 m long, 1.3 m wide, 0.8 m deep. No bones associated, but metalwork items imply a cart burial. Associated objects: (all in British Museum) tyres, 4 iron nave-hoops (2 now lost), 2 fragmentary iron horse-bits. Further iron fragments described by Greenwell are now lost.
Site_description: <NRHE summary>: TA 0190 3908. Group of four square barrows on Westwood Common, 200m NW of Blackmill. Scheduled RSM No 26562. Three clearly square, and one sub-rectangular or nearly circular-shaped Iron Age barrow which was excavated by Greenwell in 1875, producing a fine cart burial, now in the British Museum. This barrow measures 6.5m in diameter and 0.5m in height and has the appearance of a small bowl barrow, the result of Greenwell's excavation. It was found to contain a central, oval grave containing two tyres, each with an iron hoop, and two bits as well as other pieces of iron. Bones did not survive, due to the acidity of the soil. Although Greenwell is reported to have opened other barrows on Westwood Common, it is not thought that the remaining three in this group were opened, as they appear to be undisturbed. Two square barrows lie on an E-W alignment to the N of the round barrow above. The best surviving square barrow lies 4m to the NE of the semicircular barrow opened by Greenwell. It includes a low central platform 8m square and up to 0.4m high, surrounded by a ditch 1.5m to 2m wide and up to 0.3m deep. A low bank 2.5m wide surrounds the ditch. On the W side this bank joins the E bank to this monument. The W barrow has a central low platform 9m square and up to 0.35m high, and is also surrounded by a low ditch about 0.3m deep and up to 2m wide. At a distance of 8m - 10m to the S of these two square barrows lies a third, aligned approximately centrally to their common co-joining inner bank. It consists of a central low platform about 9m square and 0.3m high, surrounded by a ditch up to 2m wide and 0.25m deep, and a low bank 2.5m wide. The N edge of the monument lies 4m - 5m to the S of the barrow excavated by Greenwell.

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: possible cart burial, summarised by Whimster as follows:Accounts by Mortimer and Proctor of the discovery of chariot wheels within barrows probably refer to a single site. Mortimer's report concerns 'iron tyres of two small wheels and many bones' found early in the 19th century at Haywold. w.Proctor refers more specifically to an excavation by Lord Burlington at Howe  hill field, where a single chariot wheel was supposed to have been found.Could relate to square barrow (cropmark?) represented by PRN 17947?
Site_description: <NRHE summary>: Many bones and two small iron tyres were noticed by a farm labourer (who worked for Mortimer in 1897) when he was a boy engaged in the removal and spreading of several barrows on land owned by Holtby of Haywold (SE 922545) near Huggate. Thought by Stead to be a possible cart-burial (Iron Age). (1-2)

Site_name_other: Iron Age/Romano-British settlement, at Dumbhill Ends
Site_summary: <gg_summary>: IA burials including fragments from a human skull, six neonate burials, and a formal burial with grave goods, found during the Hayton Landscape Project. The burials were located in the vicinity of a roundhouse within a settlement enclosure. The formal grave was positioned in the south east corner of the latter and was c14 dated to 100 cal BC to cal AD 70. This site is already in the HER as a Roman villa and findspot investigated by Peter Halkon (no associated finds or events records).

Site_name_other: TWO IA BURIALS, HAYTON FIELD FARM
Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Two formal IA burials, were located in a relatively isolated position N of a broadly contemporary settlement area. One was associated with iron tools and a knife.

Site of a Bronze Age bowl barrow. Recorded as an extant mound by RCHM and excavated in 1982. Also visible as an earthwork and cropmark on aerial photographs.<gg summary>: Excavation of a ditched bowl barrow in 1982. Several cremations in pits all of EBA date and with grave goods. Five separate unurned cremations ; all of adults and all contained within confines of two conjoined ring ditches. Grave goods included daggers, jet buttons, amber beads etcDitch base enclosure C – HAR-5622 3410+-80 (ch) 1915-1519 BCAll the objects accompanying the cremations are grave not pyre goodsNote there is not one single pot
Site_description: Recorded as an extant mound by the RCHM, measuring 40ft. in diameter and 3.5ft. high, with an excavation hollow on top {1}.Excavated by P J Woodward in 1982 {2}, concluding this was a Bronze Age bowl barrow, adjacent to a contemporary enclosure (possible saucer barrow) to the north-east. The structure of the barrow has been greatly reduced by medieval arable incursion and previous antiquarian activities.Also visible as an earthwork and a cropmark on aerial photographs {3-5}, measuring approximately 14.4 metres in diameter. This site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Ring ditch 1. Centre of ring ditch. Central burial – 2.3m long & 1.3m wide and 0.9m deep. NE-SW, Contained two cremations and two urns of Food Vessel type along with deer antler, boar’s tusks and a flint knife. The two cremations were both contained within wooden frames without bases or lids so not ‘boxed’. Bounded cremations each lay within a third much larger wooden frame. The 2 cremations were placed in the grave at separate times; one cremation partly silted over and then pit partly recut to inter 2nd deposit,

<gg_summary>: Grinsell's (1959) Winterbourne St Martin Barrow 5a. Some issues with identification due to lack of locational detail from Warne/Sydenham (see NRHE record).Complex barrow sequence - mainly secondary cremations in Collared Urns. Two primary crouched burials and a cremation and all three were in the same grave. Covered by a deliberately chipped layer of flints. Secondary cremation above chipped cairn of child with miniature pygmy cup. Extended burial. Secondary cremation in top of mound in a Collared Urn upright. Incised herringbone  with twisted cord decoration (Longworth 1984: 192, No 506). South Eastern style. 300m tallOn S side of barrow was another Collared Urn cremation (Collared Urn with Cornish influence). 200mm tall. With incised herringbone on neck & collar. (Longworth 1984: 192, No 507). Inside the urn were small faience beads, a perforated cowrie shell, a cylindrical bone bead, a faience quiot bead, a faience five-star bead, and all of these objects had been subject to action of fire. Pyre not grave goods.  Primary burials lacked grave goods
Site_description: NRHE_description: A bowl barrow, excavated by Sydenham in circa 1839-40. At the time, it was circa 18 feet high and 40 feet in diameter. The mound was covered by a layer of flints 2.5 feet thick. Below this were layers of "brown and black mould", interspersed with some thin deposits of ashes. At the centre was a cairn of flints, the lower portion of which comprised broken and chipped flints while the upper portion comprised large unbroken flints. Beneath the cairn was a chalk-cut pit containing on its floor two crouched inhumations and a deposit of cremated bone. The cairn had been piled up directly on top of these. Between the upper and lower parts of the cairn was an extended child inhumation with a small pottery vessel. Near the top of the cairn was a cremation in a collared urn. On the southern side of the mound, a foot beneath the surface (and presumably in the outer flint layer) was a biconical urn containing some cremated bone plus faience, bone and shell beads. Two more secondary cremations were found, one in a pottery vessel, the other covered by a sherd of a large vessel. Near the top of the mound was an unaccompanied extended child inhumation (Saxon?). Grinsell lists this barrow as Winterborne St Martin 5a, but suggests it is probably to be identified with one of Winterborne St Martin 1-5. RCHME suggest that it is probably one of their barrows Winterborne St Martin 107-113. Both indicate that it was probably one of the so-called Rew Group (SY 69 SW 49). Problems of identification stem from the lack of locational detail offered by Warne and Sydenham. [NB two other barrows formerly described here have now been recorded separately as SY 69 SW 90 and 91]

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Opened 1784. Primary inurned cremation with bronze pyre material. and later skeletons of man, woman and child (woman died in childbirth) covered with large stones.  Associated with two inverted urns – one with burnt bone and the other with a 3-riveted bronze dagger, antler pick near base of barrow ; said by Warne to be a foundation deposit
<gg summary>: Bincombe 49e. Excavated 1842. Two Inverted Collared Urns with cremations. Only sherds now survive
<gg summary>: Called a twin barrow or bilobate barrow. Two primary imhumations without gg. A secondary urned cremation (CU) that also contained a miniature urn (incense cup) inside larger one
<gg summary>: burial (not stated what type) in barrow and accompanied by an Armorican-style vessel Exotic object from Brittany
<gg summary>: Collared Urn cremation with whetstone and stone bead and fossil sponge

Site_name_other: Monkton (Area 3): MBA ring ditch and cremation burial
Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Small, single phase MBA ring ditch with an urned cremation burial located just off-centre. 2/3 of an extremely unusual (for Kent) large Trevisker-ware jar of Cornish origin was deposited at the base of the ring ditch; a hexagonal jet bead was recovered from the initial fill. Residue from the Trevisker jar was c14 dated to 1600-1320 cal BC.

Site_name_other: Lower part of Milborne Down, unlocated barrows Grinsell's barrows 16a-d
Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Group record for excavated but unlocated barrows, on the 'Lower Part of Milborne Down' listed in Grinsell (1959, 120 Barrows 16a-d; see also Warne barrows 22-5; Calkin 1967, 140). These could well correspond with barrows identified on Milborne Down in the HER (MDOs 4366-8 and 4365 (possibly also 4385)) and by the RCHM (1970, barrows 23-6) but it is not clear which finds came from which of these barrows and is unlikely to be determined. The grid reference provided for this record is a central point on the lower part of Milborne Down (and within the parish boundary).Only one barrow from this group produced grave goods:Grinsell's (1959, 120) Milborne barrow 16b/e: Primary cremation in urn; secondary crouched inhumation - unaccompanied. The urn is a Food Vessel-Collared Urn hybridNB Calkin (1967, 40) argues convincingly that Grinsell's Milborne barrows 16b and e are the same thing, hence the bodkin and amulet from 16e are included in this recordGrinsell's (1959, 120) Milborne barrow 16c (primary inhumation of adult placed on paved floor of barrow; apparently extended position - sandstone slabs. No grave goods but quite formal paved floor. Secondary infant inhumation accompanied by several already broken pot sherds. Antler found above burial in mound (antler picks)) is interesting to bear in mind but is not recorded here.<grouped unlocated barrows>

<gg_summary>: there is some disagreement as to which of the three barrows excavated by Mansel-Playdell on Warren Hill in 1881 produced which finds, due to the mismatch between the excavators descriptions and the barrows visible in the RCHM surveys (1970). The HER site descriptions are also awry - they do not match the descriptions in Grinsell (1959) for barrows at the same locations (the descriptions for barrows 4 and 6 are reversed, barrow 5 has no description ... MDO4362=Grinsell's barrow 4; MDO4363=Grinsell's barrow 6; MDO4364=Grinsell's Milborne barrow 5 (represented here)). Based on these vagaries a best fit has been attempted here for the barrow that produced pottery, ashes and a fossil (Ditrupa plana): Grinsell's (1959, 120) Milborne barrow 5NB Grinsell's (1959, 120) Milborne barrow 6 (not kept) contained at thick layer of ashes and burnt flint at the centre and a seemingly discarded urn, complete with lid (but not ashes) to one side (to the N) of the mound. Interesting to note but not gg

Site_name_other: Burials from antiquarian excavations associated with unlocated barrows on Keynston Down
Site_summary: <gg_summary: Overarching record for burials and grave goods from five unlocated barrows potentially within the parish of Tarrant Keyneston. Grinsell lists all as being within Tarrant Keyneston; the RCHME suggest some may be beyond the parish boundary in Tarrant Launceston or Tarrant Monkton (see site description for details). Overall, contextual details are too poor to merit attribution to specific HER monument records. These barrows equate to Grinsell's (1959) Tarrant Keynston barrows 1a-e) and RCHME's (1972) barrows 22-6:Grinsell's (1959) Tarrant Keynston barrow 1a: one of three unlocated barrows excavated by Shipp in 1846. This one produced a primary cremation in a cist with fragments of coarse urn and a later (Romano-British?) urned cremation of a child (Warne 1866, 76, Pt. 2, No. 6; Pt. 3).Grinsell's (1959) Tarrant Keynston barrow 1b: one of three unlocated barrows excavated by Shipp in 1846. This one produced an urned cremation in a cist with 'British pottery' (most likely a collared urn), ashes and charcoal (Warne 1866, Pt. 2, No. 7).Grinsell's (1959) Tarrant Keynston barrow 1c: one of three unlocated barrows excavated by Shipp in 1846. This one produced three primary cremations in cists, two secondary cremations in upright urns in 'intercommunicating cists', and one secondary cremation in a cist under an inverted urn (Warne 1866, Pt. 2, No. 8). In total, six cremation burials in separate cists, three with gg (urns)  - two upright, one inverted two Collared Urns, one of uncertain date. Grinsell's (1959) Tarrant Keynston barrow 1d: an unlocated barrow excavated by J. H. Austen in 1840. A globular urn with two lugs, pierced perpendicularly were recovered (Warne 1866, cpf, No. 30, 21). (not recorded as association with hr is unclear)Grinsell's (1959) Tarrant Keynston barrow 1e: an unlocated barrow on Keyneston Down, potentially excavated by Durden in 1840 (Payne 1892, 18). The urns are noted to have been protected by two large sandstone blocks. Two of the urns of the 'several' that were ploughed out/excavated are in the British Museum. No mention is made of human remains but based on their description as a 'sepulchural group' and the fact that the two in the BM represent a sample of many, a MNI of one cremation burial and two urns is recorded here.<grouped unlocated barrows>
Site_description: <RCHME 1972>: Five barrows survive in the N.W. of the parish, on the S. and S.E. of Buzbury Rings (16). There are records of three other barrows 'on Keyneston Down', excavated in 1846, but these almost certainly lay in Tarrant Launceston or Tarrant Monkton, for they appear to have been not more than 300 yds. from the Romano-British settlement on Blandford Race Down. One of these three barrows yielded a primary cremation with fragments of 'a coarse urn' in a cist, and a secondary cremation of a child in a two-handled vase, together with a piece of dark thick glass; a fragment of samian ware found at the side of the barrow, where the ground appeared to have been anciently disturbed, suggests that the secondary burial was Romano-British (C.T.D., Pt. 2, No. 6; Pt. 3, note on p. 76). A barrow near by yielded 'fragments of British Pottery' with ashes and charcoal, in a cist 8 ft. deep and 3 ft. in diameter (C.T.D., Pt. 2, No. 7). The third barrow yielded three cremations, probably primary, two cremations in upright urns, probably secondary, and one other, probably secondary, in an inverted urn; all were in separate cists, two of which were connected by a circular hole (C.T.D., Pt. 2, No. 8). A further barrow, perhaps in Tarrant Keyneston or Tarrant Rawston, was opened by J. H. Austen in 1840 and yielded a bowl-shaped urn with two lugs pierced perpendicularly (C.T.D., Pt. 2, No. 30).

Site_name_other: Unlocated barrow in Winterborne St Martin, Grinsell's (1959) barrow 34c
Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Grinsell's (1959, 153) barrow 34c, NW of Maiden Castle.  Primary cremation with ogival gilt-bronze  dagger and another smaller dagger placed on top of cremated bone; cremation unurned and at centre of barrow floor. Locational details taken from NRHE record although in truth, this barrow remains unlocated.<Grinsell's (1959, 153) Winterborne St Martin barrow 34c, NW of Maiden Castle>: 'a plain interment of burnt bones on the centre of the floor. In the midst of the ashes were two bronze daggers ... the larger, which was fine in preservation, was curiously wrought, chased and gilt' (Sydenham 1844, 332)
Site_description: <NRHE site description>: An unidentified round barrow excavated circa 1840 by J Sydenham. His barrow 8, it is listed by Grinsell as Winterborne St Martin 34c. Both Grinsell and RCHME suggest that it may be one of the barrows located just outside Maiden Castle, a little to the northwest (see SY 68 NE 30 and associated records). However, there were more barrows excavated in this area by Sydenham than are definitely known now, so identification is by no means certain. Sydenham described the monument as follows: "A barrow, close to [SY 68 NE 161] presented a plain interment of burnt bones on the centre of the floor. In the midst of the ashes were two bronze daggers...". This site was previously recorded as part of SY 68 NE 102. That record should be consulted for additional sources and information.

Site_summary: A small mound, 8m across is visible as earthworks on aerial photographs to the south east of Norden Wood, Church Knowle.  The mound lies in close proximity to other known prehistoric monuments and may be a Bronze Age barrow.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's (1959, 101) Church Knowle barrow 9There was a primary interment of a cremation in a pit dug in the chalk accompanied by a bronze dagger, about 1.2m south of the barrow centre, the oblong pit being oriented NW/SE. A primary mound of humus covered the pit which was filled at the lower level with dark mould and in the upper with loose chalk, earth, and flints. The later mound was built from ditch upcast (loose earth and chalk), and covered two secondary inhumations laid on the surface of the primary mound. There was a small scatter of Early or Middle  Age cinerary urn sherds (poss FV or CU) in this layer of the secondary mound. The two burials were near the barrow centre, the first being roughly NS and dismembered, some broken bones having been severely burnt, and around about much charcoal and one worked flint was found. 0.9m to the north of this was a heap of bones of an adult male, undisturbed and not burnt. No grave goods accompanied one of these. The secondary barrow was not datable unless presuming the sherds were contemporary.
Site_description: A small mound, 8m across is visible as earthworks on aerial photographs to the south east of Norden Wood, Church Knowle.  The mound lies in close proximity to other known prehistoric monuments and may be a Bronze Age barrow. The feature was digitally plotted during the Wild Purbeck Mapping Project.<NRHE site description (based on Austen 1896 and Frend 1954)>: "In May 1861 I examined the remainder of the Barrows upon Bucknowle Hill, situated at about 200 paces east of the one which I opened in a previous year (SY 98 SW 16) and which has been described in the first volume". "There are two large and two smaller with a square earthwork measuring 12 paces in diameter, which would seem to beof later date than the barrows from the fact that its south bank passes across one of them."The first barrow opened (evidently A) was "distant from the earthwork six feet towards the west". It contained, at a depth of 2' at thecentre, a crouched burial with head to NE. The space occupied by the deposit was 39" by 24" and there was a considerable deposit of black ashes "close at the back of the skeleton and extending beneath it."The barrow at SY 94588236 (A) was re-excavated in 1934-35. It was oval shaped, measuring 46' across from north to south and 50' 6"from east to west, and was surrounded by a shallow ditch about 1'9" deep and varying from 5'3" to 5'9" in width. It was found to comprise an original EBA mound built on top of a small knoll of chalk into which a cavity containing a cremation had been dug. This early mound had later been enlarged to cover new burials and provided with a ditch.The primary burial pit consisted of an oblong cavity dug 2' deep into the natural chalk, oriented NW-SE and measuring 2'6" by 3'3". It held a cremation, covered by rubble and earth mould, of bones reduced to powdery ashes. A small bronze mid-rib dagger (EBA) was found lying upon the ashes. There were two secondary burials. The first was almost in the centre of the barrow and consisted of a skeleton in a very dismembered state,oriented roughly N-S. It lay on the top of the humus near the centre of the barrow. Some of the broken bones were badly burnt and this was taken to mean that the body had been partially burnt on a small pyre (evidenced by charcoal remains) before being covered by the earth of the secondary barrow phase. The other secondary burial was at the same level and comprised a heap of bones too mixed up to indicate orientation. There was charcoal but no sign that the bones had been burnt. Some small fragments of a hand-made pot were found in the make-up of the second phase of the barrow, which Professor Stuart Piggott considered might be from a Middle to Late BA cinerary urn. A few pieces of beadrim and other coarse IA or RB wares, a worn fragment of Samian, and part of a shale bracelet were discovered in the upper filling of the ditch on the east side. (3) See also MDO7315 (the second large barrow)

Site_summary: A Bronze Age barrow 15m across is visible as earthworks on aerial photographs to the south east of Norden Wood, Church Knowle.<gg_summary>: Grinsell's (1959, 101) Knowle Hill barrow 8 See NRHE desc for more detail
Site_description: A Bronze Age barrow 15m across is visible as earthworks on aerial photographs to the south east of Norden Wood, Church Knowle (1-2).  The site was digitally plotted during the Wild Purbeck Mapping Project.<NRHE site description (based on Austen 1896)>: "In May 1861 I examined the remainder of the Barrows upon Bucknowle Hill, situated at about 200 paces east of the one which I opened in a previous year (SY 98 SW 16) and which has been described in the first volume". "There are two large and two smaller with a square earthwork measuring 12 paces in diameter, which would seem to be of later date than the barrows from the fact that its south bank passes across one of them.""The [second] large barrow situated 25 paces due south from the last (evidently B) was 47 yards in circumference and was surrounded by a ditch". The outside was found to be composed of a hardened wall of earth and chalk. Five feet south of the centre (and apparently at a depth of 5' - the passage is obscure) was a mass of black earth or charcoal in which was found a whetstone, perforated at its smaller end. Beneath this was a cist which contained a deposit of burnt bones. In the SW section of the barrow were extensive traces of similar black earth. ".(2)See also MDO7326

Site_name_other: Unlocated burials from Grinsell's (1959) East Lulworth barrows 3-5
Site_summary: <gg_summary>: overarching record for unlocated burials from three, closely grouped barrows north of Monastery Farm. Grinsell's (1959, 106) East Lulworth barrows 3-5, also 5a-d. These barrows are located separately in the HER (MDOs7645-7) but are grouped in one record in the NRHE. Since it is not possible to link excavated evidence to individual barrows, they are also grouped here. The evidence is slightly confusing but the NRHE's interpretation is that one of the three barrows (unclear which) was opened in 1790 (Warne's barrow 13); all three were probably opened in 1825-3 (Warne's barrows 51-3).<Warne (1866) barrow 13 (also probably one of Warne's barrows 51-3); Grinsell's East Lulworth barrow 5a>: burial 'in a rude cist of 'unhewn stones'. Contained an urn 'capable of holding 2 gallons, full of burnt bones and covered at the top with a thin flat stone'. The urn was of coarse black clay, potentially 'merely hardened by fire or the heat of the sun (1866, 11).<Warne (1866) barrow 51; Grinsell's East Lulworth barrow 5b>: primary cremation burial in an urn with very few ashes in a central cist, covered by a small cairn of 'rude stones'. The urn is described as 'perfectly preserved' and was deposited in a 'leaning position', resting on a large flat stone and surrounded by a dome of upright stones. The latter were apparently 'brought from the seashore, as they were ... worn with small cavities by the action of the waves'. Within the urn, loose human bones mingled with a very small portion of ashes were found.<Warne (1866) barrow 52; Grinsell's East Lulworth barrow 5c>: primary urned burial protected by a vault of large stones<Warne (1866) barrow 53; Grinsell's East Lulworth barrow 5d>: primary urned burial in a smaller barrow than the others of this group, again protected by large stones<grouped unlocated barrows>
Site_description: <NRHE site description>: Three bramble-covered, round barrows north of Monastery Farm, one of which was opened 1790 and contained a probable primary cremation in a Late Bronze Age bucket-urn placed within a cist covered by a thin stone slab.These three barrows may also have been opened 1825-32 by J F Pennie and published by Warne (b).Warne No 51: quarter of a mile from Lulworth: primary (?) cremation is urn with very few ashes, in central cist, covered by small cairn.Warne No.52: near last: primary (?) urn beneath cairn.Warne No 53: near last, but small: primary (?) beneath cairn.

Site_name_other: Unlocated burials from barrows in East Lulworth, excavated 1790 (Grinsell's barrows 5e-j)
Site_summary: <gg_summary>: overarching record for unlocated burials from barrows in the neighbourhood of East Lulworth, excavated by Milner in 1790. These are covered by Grinsell's (1959) East Lulworth barrows e-j. Warne (1866) describes the contents of 4-5 of these barrows (equivalent to Grinsell's East Lulworth barrows 5e-i) as 'nearly the same' as that described for Grinsell's East Lulworth barrow 5a that probably excavated at the same time (SID72988)). A MBA date is therfore assigned to all these burials. The only difference between these burials was that some of the urns were inverted, some upright. Only four burials from barrows similar to the East Lulworth 5a burial (of the 4-5 potentially excavated) are recorded here (East Lulworth barrows 5e-h; the MNI). Two are assigned upright urned cremation burials; two inverted.The burials from Grinsell's East Lulworth barrow 5j (Warne's barrow 12) are different in character. There were five inhumation burials with urns. One of the latter had zig-zag decoration; another was a small cup placed under the head and capped with a limpet shell.Overall, very poor contextual detail so only basic details are entered. The grid ref. is the SW corner of the OS grid square within which these barrows were probably located.<grouped unlocated barrows>
<gg_summary> One of two isolated burials (see also SID40187) and two square barrows from a wider cemetery (see SID40188) excavated during the Caythorpe Gas Pipeline project in 1992.

<gg_summar>: Recent research by Jones, Quinnell & Kirkham (2015: 157-170) has resulted in a lot more detail known. It is a cremation in an urn in a cist - unusual hybrid Trevisker vessel. This came from the discovery of a watercolour painting with further contextual detail. Borlase provided very little information A faience bead may have come from a cairn in the vicinity (or this one?)
Site_description: A late bronze age urn found at lanlawren before 1872 (b1). It is "bucket shaped", has two ribbon handles, and a band of zig-zag cord-impressed decoration below the urn. Said to be a hybid form between cornish ribbon- handled urns and deveral rimbury style (b5). Present location not known. The lanlawren urn is one of three cornish urns reproached in miniature in the late 19th and 20th centuries as souvenirs by goss china (b6).

Site_name_other: Davidstow Moor barrow cemetery barrow III/8
Site_summary: A barrow excavated during WWII prior to the construction of Davidstow airfield. The barrow does not survive.<gg_summary>: At the centre of the earthwork, elevated on a small cairn, which formed the core of a turf-built mound, was a burial, consisting of cremated and comminuted bones in a (?) leather bag, immediately beneath which had been placed two utility-stones of elvan, foreign to this site. Other small finds were rather sparse. The cremated bones represent one individual, an adult in the age group 25 — 35. There is no evidence for sex other than the large size of a canine root which could indicate a maleEBA rc dates summarised in Quinnell 2012
Site_description: The site of a barrow excavated during WWII for the Ministry of War by C K Croft Andrew.

Site_name_other: Davidstow Moor barrow cemetery barrrow XXIV/16/23
Site_summary: The site of a barrow excavated during WWII, represented only by an unsurveyable ground swelling.<gg_summary>: A round barrow, the eastern of two marked on the O.S. map, in field 783, was composed of turf clods mixed with the native clayey subsoil, but in this case the latter element predominates. The field, including the surface of the barrow, having been in cultivation for a number of years, it is not surprising that a central burial, elevated above the floor and thus brought close to the top of the mound, should have been disturbed. This interment apparently took the form of bones from a cremation, enclosed in a large urn which in turn was protected by some kind of cist, loosely built with rough lumps of quartz . . . Enough sherds were recovered to indicate a well made and carefully decorated pot very similar to that which I have since recovered from another mutilated site on Fore Down, St Cleer . . . On the floor of the barrow . . . was a large deposit of charcoal. Under the floor, near the eastern periphery, was an oblong pit large enough to take a 6-foot man fully extended. There was a general strewing of charcoal on the floor and a fair number of small finds, including flints, were picked up. A ritual pit in the floor was situated close to, but on the north side of, the urn and charcoal deposit.EBA rc dates summarised in Quinnell 2012
Site_description: A barrow excavated by CK Croft Andrew for the Ministry of Works during WWII. Its site is still identifiable, but is represented only by an unsurveyable ground swelling (h1).--------------------------------Site history:2: 1976. OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: findings from forthcoming publication of the excavation of a multi-period site including burials dating to the Neolithic, Chalcolithic, Middle Bronze Age and Middle and Late Iron Ages at Caythorpe Gas Storage works, Caythorpe, courtesy of Ken Steedman (Humber Field Archaeology).The burial evidence listed in Fraser and George (2013, 190-1) includes:2 ?E Neo burials, of which 1 was potentially associated with gg5 Beaker burials cut into a hengi-form monument, of which 2 were associated with gg3 M/LBA cremation burials, of which 2 were urned (these urns are similar to the Catfoss MBA urns but a nearby pit produced a c14 date of 920-780 cal BC)6 IA cremation burials of which 1 was potentially associated with gg5 MIA inhumation burials in square barrows, of which 1 was associated with gg4? isolated M-LIA/early Roman burials of which 3 were associated with gg
Site_description: Details from Centrica website <https://caythorpegasstorage.com/archaeology-update/>: In an area adjacent to the Gypsey Race part of a cemetery of Iron Age date (some 700 BC to AD 71) date was recorded. This consisted of five graves, some being surrounded by square ditches typical of a type only found in eastern Yorkshire. One of the graves was of a warrior and contained an iron sword and spearhead dated to some 200 to 100 BC. This is a significant discovery and is the first such sword to be recovered from an excavated grave for over 25 years.These burials are probably contemporary with an area of settlement recorded in the area of the main extension for the gas storage facility. Within this area the remains of seven roundhouses and associated structures were recorded. These were visible as circular gullies up to 15m in diameter with internal pits for timber posts, and represent circular structures of wood and clay that would probably have had a conical thatched roof. One of the houses had a low foundation wall made of chalk. Some of the gullies were inter-cutting so more than one phase of settlement is evident, which it is known extended to the south of the area investigated.Associated with the settlement were a number of other rectangular structures or enclosures, as well as pits used for the disposal of domestic refuse and a number of isolated burials, all surrounded by boundary ditches. A number of pits were also dug to the west of the area of settlement in a shallow hollow, most probably to enable the collection of water from what may have been a spring. A large saddle quern, or grinding stone, was found in the pits, which would have been used to process grain for flour. Well-preserved wood fragments were also found, showing the marks of the tools used to cut and shape them.Within this area nine isolated human burials were also found, believed to be of Iron Age or Roman date. One of the burials was found with an iron knife in a grave that was one of two that intersected each other.

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: findings from forthcoming publication of the excavation of an Iron Age cemetery at North Cave Quarry, courtesy of Ken Steedman (Humber Field Archaeology).No details were provided about the layout of these two burials beyond the fact that they were enclosed within square ditches. Based on this information a MIA date has been assigned. Publication forthcoming so no references were available.

A small mound, visible as cropmarks on aerial photographs; excavated in 1995 and found to be a multi-phased platform barrow.<gg_summary>: Formal cremation burial in cist, summarised in Nowakowski 1995; Jones 2005Hr: Almost 10kg of cremated bone from adults, juveniles and children found within the cistGg: 4 miniature urns; 2 faience beadsGrave lined with flat slates and over one hundred sparkling quartz pebblesNowakowski describes the burial as MBA, however more recent publications include it alongside EBA burials and there are definitely EBA contexts at this site (Quinnell 2012, 155)Pits elsewhere within the barrow could be viewed as 'cenotaphs' (near complete vessels in pits)
Site_description: Cropmarks of a small mound, approximately 13m across, are visible as cropmarks on vertical aerial photographs (p1). This feature was excavated by CAU in 1995 during the Probus Bypass excavations (b1) when it was proved to be a multi-phased platform barrow with internal cist.

Site_name_other: Davidstow Moor barrow cemetery barrrow XXVI/22
Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Christie 1988 notes that: Near the centre were found two pits sunk by treasure-hunters, both about 5 ft in diameter and of similar depth. From one I recovered parts of a discarded urn and from the other a fair quantity . . .  of bone . . . Potentially two phases of burial. Although Croft Andrew notes the considerable disturbance at this barrow, including possible robbing of the two central grave pits, based on his record, Christie suggests that only the upper parts of these pits were disturbed.
Site_description: During 1941 and 1942, the late C.K. Croft Andrew, working on behalf of the Ministry of Works Ancient Monuments Inspectorate, identified and examined some 28 potential barrow sites on Davidstow Moor, ahead of airfield construction. This barrow was excavated on 16 March 1942. Despite its disturbed initial appearance, Christie described its excavation as 'rewarding' (1988, 109). The complex sequence at this site potentially spans the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age and includes initial charcoal rich/flint-associated deposits; a stone circle potentially associated with a central cist and a scatter of holed and notched stones; and a Late Beaker burial deposit, ring cairn and central mound.

Site_summary: One of a group of seven barrows on Treligga Common, investigated by Croft Andrew in 1941, and published by Christie in 1985.<gg_summary>:
Site_description: This barrow is one in a group of seven on Treligga Common, which is marked on the OS 2500 map of 1907 and was excavated by Croft Andrew in 1941 (h1, b1). The results of his excavation have recently been published by Christie (b2). This was a slate cairn 28ft (8.5m) in diameter and 18in (0.45m) high, on a knoll at the outer end of Start Point. No central deposit or fire and no grave goods were found, but near the centre two parcels of calcined and comminuted bone had been deposited in crannies in the bedrock. The cairn was formed by inclined slates leaning toward centre; the margin of the cairn was defined by a ring of boulders of white quartz. Two further deposits of bone were found on the east side; analysis of the bone showed that up to five individuals were represented by the remains. In 1976, the OS surveyor found that the barrow had been completely effaced by a wartime gun pit built at its centre. No identifiable remains (h2).--------------------------------Site history:2: 1976. MJF / OS--------------------------------

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Simple MBA urned cremation burial within a pit group from the Middle Bronze Age settlement at Scarcewater Tip, St Stephen.NB Barrow 1 from this site (only tested in an evaluation trench) produced a deposit that could be viewed as a 'cenotaph' - the complete, sawn-off base of a Trevisker urn, charred material from which produced a comparable c14 date to that within the pit burial (Wk-21460; 3174+/-34 BP; 1510 to 1390 cal BC) (Jones and Taylor 2010, 34)
Site_description: Simple MBA urned cremation burial within a pit group from the Middle Bronze Age settlement at Scarcewater Tip, St Stephen.Pit group 1350 (Fig 14) (Taylor 2005, 33-4):A discrete group of pits was observed in the southeastern part of the site, 25m to the east of roundhouse 1250 ... Pits [1352], [1354], [1378], and [1384] formed a set to the northeast of the group, three of which contained two fills, whilst three of the set also contained finds of potsherds, quartz pebbles, and polished stone pebbles. Another subset was formed of the pits [1356], [1358], and [1387], to the southwest of the group. Two of these contained two fills but only one produced finds in the form of pottery. Isolated from both of these subsets were pits [1360], which contained two fills but no finds, and [1036], which contained the truncated base of a largely complete pottery vessel,  89, that appeared to contain burnt bone, possibly a cremation deposit.These isolated pits or postholes could not be interpreted as a structure, even allowing for missing/truncated features. The vessel ( 89) is likely to be Trevisker Ware and the location of the pits near to the sunken roundhouses may indicate that they were contemporary. A distinction between ritual and domestic activity is probably false as a major characteristic of the British Middle Bronze Age settlement in general is the presence of ‘ritual’ activity within the ‘functional’ settlement context (eg, bodies and other strange deposits in storage pits etc). In Cornwall human bone has rarely been found in Bronze Age contexts but human burials have been found in settlements, for example at Trethellan (Nowakowski 1991) and Gwithian (Thomas 1958).

Parish_Community_Borough: Forrabury And Minster, North Cornwall, Cornwall
Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Isolated LN/EBA pit located a field c. 150m west of the Iron Age cemetery at Forrabury. Contained 79g cremated human bone (12+ yrs), a LN/EBA leaf arrowhead (heat affected) and a quartz pebble. Interpreted in report as 'special deposit' but recorded here as borderline gg.
Site_description: Pit [101] was roughly circular in shape with a diameter of 0.42m. The pit had steep, almost vertical sides and was flat bottomed. It reached a depth of 0.12m. The pit had been cut into the natural shillet bedrock. The fill consisted of a very dark organic rich grey-brown clay loam with numerous charcoal fragments. There was also a lot of burnt bone visible. A burnt flint probable blank for a leaf shaped arrowhead of Neolithic date, and a water rounded quartz pebble were recovered from the fill. The projectile blank was set vertically in the fill, pointing downwards as if it had been thrust into the pit. (HE projects, 16, Fig. 4, Fig 14)

Site_summary: A triple-ditched barrow was visible on aerial photographs at Lord of the Manor near Ozengell, one of the Lord of the Manor barrow group. Inserted into a neolithic enclosure, the barrow's three ditches represent three different phases of construction at narrow intervals. The primary grave contained the crouched burials of a male and female but no grave goods. Secondary burials included five inhumations and a cremation accompanied by an arrowhead.<gg_summary>: This record represents one element of a monument complex that includes Neolithic ceremonial enclosures that were later augmented to form a Bronze Age barrow group. See MKE7631 for the composite (monument group) record. The info about this site is confusing, contradictory and unpublished; the account given here is a 'best fit'.Site 1/B (TR 36 NE 693/MKE99502)(Bristow Site 944): Early Bronze Age three ring ditched barrow excavated in 1976 by the Thanet Archaeological Unit. Burial G6 was a cremation of a child of a few months old in a small corded food vessel accompanied by a barbed and tanged flint arrow head (Bristow 2001) See also: http://www.thanetarch.co.uk/Virtual%20Museum/3_Displays/G4%20Displays/Gallery4_Display4_Link2thanet_Link3causewayed_LinkLOMI.htmFor further info see also:Perkins D. 2004. Oval barrows in Thanet, in Cotton J. and Field D. Towards a New Stone Age. CBS Research Report 137
Site_description: The site was excavated by the Thanet Archaeological Unit from 1976 to 1982.TR 354653. Early Bronze Age three ring ditched barrow ['B'] excavated in 1976 by the Thanet Archaeological Unit. The three ring ditches represent three phases, at fairly narrow intervals. The primary grave contained the crouched burials of a man and a woman, but no grave goods; the secondary burials consisted of five inhumations and a cremation in a cord decorated pot, accompanied by a barbed and tanged arrowhead. The final outer ditch of the third phase was wider and deeper than others, the upcast from its cutting being used to fill in the earlier ditches. This ditch remained open and its upper levels contained a series of Early Iron Age pottery, and C1st AD Romano-British pottery.(1,2)

Site_summary: A round barrow was visible on aerial photographs at Lord of the Manor near Ozengell, one of the Lord of the Manor barrow group. Excavation revealed that is was inserted into a neolithic enclosure.<gg_summary>: This record represents one element of a monument complex that includes Neolithic ceremonial enclosures that were later augmented to form a Bronze Age barrow group. See MKE7631 for the composite record. The info about this site is confusing, contradictory and unpublished; the account given here is a 'best fit'.Site 3 (TR 36 NE 695/MKE99504)(Bristow Site 891)(also in Grinsell 1992): A bowl barrow whose ditch had been re-cut long after its original excavation and was crossed by a narrow causeway at the south, with a central pit B2 containing a cremation beneath an inverted tripartite collared urn of the secondary series, SE style. A small heap of flints had been made in the centre of the pit, and the urn containing ashes and calcined bone had been placed inverted upon it. Fine dark brown soil was packed around it. Two other pits just north east of the centre contained a few flint flakes, small fragments of animal bone and charcoal. In pit B1 set in the earlier Layers 1-3 in the south east quadrant of the ditch, was found the skull of a female c12-15, presumably fleshless when buried, a rib bone inserted into the cranium through a hole in the side. The report on the skull identifies anomalies which suggest a form of microcephaly such as a dwarf would exhibit. Later ditch Layers 4-8 provided less than 50 potsherds from Iron Age onwards.NB Fisk 2006 (http://www.thanetarch.co.uk/Virtual%20Museum/3_Displays/G4%20Displays/Gallery4_Display4_Link2thanet_Link3causewayed.htm#V_Lord_of_the_Manor_I_1976) notes that The skull of small-headed female (about 12-15 years old and possibly a dwarf) was found on the base of the ditch to the east. The skull had a boar’s rib placed through the foramen magnum at the back of her head (Macpherson Grant pers commm).For further info see also:Perkins D. 2004. Oval barrows in Thanet, in Cotton J. and Field D. Towards a New Stone Age. CBS Research Report 137.
Site_description: The site was excavated by the Thanet Archaeological Unit from 1976 to 1982."The ring-ditched enclosures marked as LOM 1-6 are part of a possibly middle, certainly late neolithic to early Bronze Age ceremonial landscape in use between c. 2800-1700 BC. Of these LOM1, 2D, 3A [this site] and 2 smaller ring-ditches were entirely stripped and excavated in 1976 and 1977, LOM 5 sample trenched during the 1980s and LOM 6 remains unexcavated as a Scheduled Monument.The first main phase of later neolithic activity is represented by the large enclosures that were later occupied by barrows. LOM 1 had no internal feautres but produced large quantities of residual later neolithic worked flint and grooved ware pottery. LOM 2D [this site] was smaller but had a causewayed entrance on its south-west side and a chalk platform with a hearth area inside a small post built structure with a porch. The flint and pottery was again late neolithic. LOM 3A [this site] also had no features but produced large quantities of flint and the skull of a young woman from the primary fill of the ditch.The second main phase of neolithic activity saw the continuing use of the enclosures for social gathering and ceremonies. Fragments of beaker pottery were recovered from "the first two enclosures." LOM 1 produced sherds of finely made beakers with decoration using careful corded and comb-tip decoration dated to c. 2300-2000 BC."(4) (5)

Site_summary: A round barrow was visible on aerial photographs and was subsequently excavated at Lord of the Manor near Ozengell, one of the Lord of the Manor barrow group.<gg_summary>: This record represents one element of a monument complex that includes Neolithic ceremonial enclosures that were later augmented to form a Bronze Age barrow group. See MKE7631 for the composite record. The info about this site is confusing, contradictory and unpublished; the account given here is a 'best fit'.Site 4 (TR 36 NE 696/MKE99505)(Bristow Site 892) A bowl barrow partially destroyed by the Haine Road, containing an ovoid pit at the centre, round bottomed and measuring c1.3m x 1.1m x 0.95m deep, with a cremation accompanied by a bronze awl, and a slotted incense cup of Longworth's (1984) Whinny Liggate type. Half of the pit fill was tightly packed flints at the north end, the other half dark brown densely packed soil. In this and just above the floor was a quantity of calcined bone and the incense cup containing the awl.For further info see also:Excavations at Ozengell/Lord of the Manor, Trust for Thanet Archaeology (Perkins, D. in Archaeologia Cantiana 1990 or 1991)Perkins D. 2004. Oval barrows in Thanet, in Cotton J. and Field D. Towards a New Stone Age. CBS Research Report 137.CgMs Consulting, 2013, Archaeological desk-based assessment (including uxo risk assessment), Land at Ozengell Park, Ramsgate, Kent (Unpublished document). SKE31450
Site_description: A round barrow was visible on aerial photographs and was subsequently excavated at Lord of the Manor near Ozengell. It is one of the Lord of the Manor barrow group. The barrow is cut by the Haine Road and on excavation produced what is for Kent a fairly rare incense or 'slotted' cup.The site was excavated by the Thanet Archaeological Unit from 1976 to 1982.

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: This record represents one element of a monument complex that includes Neolithic ceremonial enclosures that were later augmented to form a Bronze Age barrow group. See MKE7631 for the composite record. The info about this complex is confusing, contradictory and unpublished; the account given here is a 'best fit'.Site 6 (TR 36 NE 697/MKE99506) - A barrow pond formed by a shallow saucer-shaped pit cut into the chalk bed rock. It was encircled by a raised bank of chalk spoil and a ring ditch. A cremation burial dated circa 1400 BC contained in a cordoned urn was found in a small pit cut into the bank.NB the pond barrow is described as Neolithic in date; the cremation cut into the bank is described as c. 1400 BC in date. Based on current knowledge/the available info an EBA date is assigned here. Recorded by CgMs as Site 6 but info on Pastscape suggests that Site 6 was unexcavated/scheduled ... The site plan available at http://www.thanetarch.co.uk/Virtual%20Museum/3_Displays/G4%20Displays/Gallery4_Display4_Link2thanet_Link3causewayed.htm#X_Lord_of_the_Manor_V_1981 supports the idea that this is Site 6 (partly removed by the railway cutting)For further info see also:Perkins D. 2004. Oval barrows in Thanet, in Cotton J. and Field D. Towards a New Stone Age. CBS Research Report 137.
Site_description: The site was excavated by the Thanet Archaeological Unit from 1976 to 1982 and also sample trenched during the 1980s."The ring-ditched enclosures marked as LOM 1-6 are part of a possibly middle, certainly late neolithic to early Bronze Age ceremonial landscape in use between c. 2800-1700 BC. Of these LOM1, 2D, 3A and 2 smaller ring-ditches were entirely stripped and excavated in 1976 and 1977, LOM 5 [this site] sample trenched during the 1980s and LOM 6 remains unexcavated as a Scheduled Monument."(4)During the early 1980’s part of the enclosure at LOM 5 (Fig. 2) was excavated. This enclosure was considered to be broadly similar to those recorded at LOM 1, 2d and 3, accordingly the enclosure was interpreted as a Neolithic Henge monument. A burial pit at the centre of the enclosure contained selected and carefully arranged bones of five skeletons which suggest the later addition of late Neolithic/early Bronze Age inhumations. Following the discovery of Anglo-Saxon burials at LOM 5 the edge of the excavation was extended south-east to the railway line and south-west towards Haine Road.A ring ditch (CgMs 6, Fig. 2), partly removed by the railway cutting, was identified to the south of LOM 5. This feature, interpreted as a Neolithic barrow pond, comprised a shallow saucer-shaped pit cut into the chalk bedrock which was encircled by a raised bank of chalk and a ring ditch.(5)

Site_summary: A round barrow was visible on aerial photographs and was subsequently excavated at Lord of the Manor near Ozengell, one of the Lord of the Manor barrow group.<gg_summary>: This record represents one element of a monument complex that includes Neolithic ceremonial enclosures that were later augmented to form a Bronze Age barrow group. See MKE7631 for the composite record. The info about this site is confusing, contradictory and unpublished; the account given here is a 'best fit'.NB This record probably represents the main barrow/henge mentioned in MKE99506. A new record (no HER equivalent) has been created for the pond barrow (Site 6).For further info see also:Perkins D. 2004. Oval barrows in Thanet, in Cotton J. and Field D. Towards a New Stone Age. CBS Research Report 137.
Site_description: <NRHE site description>: TR 357653 in 1981 where the excavation of a barrow ['C'] revealed a circular ditch of c30.0 m in diameter. Internal features included the burials of a complete ox, and, in a small central pit, carefully placed skeletal material derived from two or more adult humans, with some animal bone."The site was excavated by the Thanet Archaeological Unit from 1976 to 1982 and also sample trenched during the 1980s."The ring-ditched enclosures marked as LOM 1-6 are part of a possibly middle, certainly late neolithic to early Bronze Age ceremonial landscape in use between c. 2800-1700 BC. Of these LOM1, 2D, 3A and 2 smaller ring-ditches were entirely stripped and excavated in 1976 and 1977, LOM 5 [this site] sample trenched during the 1980s and LOM 6 remains unexcavated as a Scheduled Monument."(4)During the early 1980’s part of the enclosure at LOM 5 (Fig. 2) was excavated. This enclosure was considered to be broadly similar to those recorded at LOM 1, 2d and 3, accordingly the enclosure was interpreted as a Neolithic Henge monument. A burial pit at the centre of the enclosure contained selected and carefully arranged bones of five skeletons which suggest the later addition of late Neolithic/early Bronze Age inhumations. Following the discovery of Anglo-Saxon burials at LOM 5 the edge of the excavation was extended south-east to the railway line and south-west towards Haine Road.

Site_summary: Summary : <SW of hut on the quarry edge were the remains of a Food Vessel cremation burial that had unfortunately been damaged by the mechanical digger. Likely that originally this grave was covered by a ditchless barrow mound

<Garton Slack, Areas 1 to 33, Several grave groups that relate to discrete burials, some of which may or may not have been contained within barrows. These were highly truncated by ploughing and quarrying and hence often difficult to discern whether they may have been covered by barrow mounds. Their exact locations within the wider cemetery complex are not possible to define exactly. See individual Grave Good record sheets for further detail. They comprise: Grave Group 6 (Brewster p 202, figs 89-92)>: Tight coffined burial of adult female with head resting on white gravel pillow crouched on right side, head N. Female of c. 25 years of age. N: <rather rich grave.  180 cylindrical rolled bronze beads, flattened V-shaped jet toggle, 13 V-perforated conical jet buttons etc.Grave Group 8(i) Isolated small pit. Cremation contained within Food Vessel Grave Group 8(ii) Small pit. Containing Inhumation, possibly of a decayed infant Grave Group 13 (i) (Brewster p 444, fig 286)>: Small pit immediately adjacent to another Collared Urn cremation pit. No sign of a barrow. Collared Urned cremation. 2 small pits only 0.35m diameter with Collared Urns within. <Garton Slack, Areas 1 to 33, Grave Group 13 (ii) (Brewster p 444, fig 286)>: Small pit immediately adjacent to another Collared Urn cremation pit. No sign of a barrow. Collared Urned cremation. Possibly a ploughed out barrow with a central grave<Garton Slack, Areas 1 to 33, Grave Group 14 (i) (Brewster p 447, fig 289, 291, 307)>: Small pit with urned cremation within a miniature Food Vessel . Wide and deep Bronze Age grave and 2 separate Bronze Age cremation pits<Garton Slack, Areas 1 to 33, Grave Group 14 (ii) (Brewster p 447, fig 289, 291, 307)>:  Cremation pit 2 was smaller than cremation pit 1 and contained 2,855g of cremated bone and charcoal<Garton Slack, Areas 1 to 33, Grave Group 19. Single grave with belemnite<Garton Slack, Areas 1 to 33, Grave Group 29(i-iii) (Brewster p 557, figs 397, 398, 402)>: Garton Slack 29 lay on the southern part of the excavations, due east of Wetwang Slack sites 1, 2 & 3 and S of Garton Slack 30.  Thought that the graves on Garton Slack 29 and Wetwang Slack 1 were covered by ditchless mounds and were not in fact single graves. However due to truncation, this cannot be ascertained with confidence

gg summary: <Central grave of round barrow. Double cremation of a young adult male and an adult female with Food Vessel and awl.  GS 7 just W of GS 6. Bronze Age barrow- ditched. 1ry burial was child in central grave. 2ndary burial in pit 1m N-S & to N of central grave>

<gg_summary><<Wetwang Slack, Areas 1 to 12, Grave Groups - generic burials from the Wetwang Slack area that comprised discrete grave features, some of which may have originally been covered by small barrow mounds. These, however, were highly truncated or disturbed (ploughing, quarrying etc) thus rendering this impossible to say.They comprise:Grave Group 1 (Brewster p 602, figs 443, 444)>: Inhumation a child with a Beaker and jet objects. Isolated Beaker grave, oval in plan, 8 foot 10 inches long and 6 foot 6 inches wide and 1 foot 6 inches deep. Grave Group 8(i) (Dent D2; this paper; fig 2)>: Child inhumation with a Beaker >: Grave Group 8(ii) (Dent D2; this paper; fig 2)>: Cremation in urnGrave Group 9 (Dent D2; this paper; fig 2)>: Adult inhumation in a large plank cist Grave Group 10 (D2)>: Coffin or cist burial of adult male inhumation Grave Group 12(i) (D2)>: Large plank lined cist with adult male inhumationGrave Group 12(ii) (Dent D2; this paper; fig 2)>: Adult male with flint knife. This grave was cut by grave 12(iii)Grave Group 12(iii) (Dent D2; this paper; fig 2)>: Male inhumation with a stone battle axe and pig bones. Large plank-lined or built cist. This grave cuts 12(ii)
<Wetwang Slack, Areas 1 to 12, Grave Group 4 (Brewster p 642, figs 485, 486)>:  Wetwang Slack 4 is a large ditched Bronze Age barrow containing 9 graves. 1 of which had been disturbed

Grave Group 6 (Dent's Barrow B?) comprised two circular almost conjoined ditches. All graves were contained within the barrow and none cut its ditches. There were 6 graves. Inner barrow ditch 11.5m diameter and outer barrow ditch 14m in diameter.Burials in coffins and associated with Beakers and Food Vessels and one Collared Urn cremation

<gg_summary>: Unpublished MBA and IA funerary evidence excavated in advance of a housing development at Tregunnel Hill, Cornwall. Information from Tom Brindle, Cotswold Archaeology. MBA cremation cemetery comprising unurned cremation burials, in two cases capped with slate slabs, in one case placed upon a slate slab. EIA inhumation cemetery, again, mostly without grave goods but in one case the grave fill included a large assemblage of sea shells. A pit close to the IA cemetery produced an assemblage resembling grave goods (including a brooch type that is typically found in burial contexts) but no evidence for human remains. <cenotaph>Brindle forthcoming:MBA cremation cemetery: 'At the west of the site, in Area B, a group of cremation burials were discovered. Up to nine possible cremation burials were represented, although only three of the pits yielded bone; where charcoal was recovered from the pits, analysis has indicated that all contained redeposited pyre debris'E/MIA inhumation cemetery: 'Of six certain inhumation burials identified at the site, five were identified as being of Early Iron Age date. The position of the graves appears to be related to the Iron Age settlement (discussed below), with the burials seemingly placed at the rear of the settlement, against the boundary formed by the earlier field system. This group of burials were placed within graves of varied dimensions and shapes, including circular, oval and sub-rectangular shaped graves, with most individuals buried in crouched positions. At least one of the inhumations was a rudimentary cist burial, covered with stones'

Site_name_other: Bronze Age double ring-ditch discovered during the East Kent Access Route excavations (2009-2011)
Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Of the 8 burials (one cremation (the earliest burial); seven inhumations) associated with partially excavated Barrow 1 (also truncated by later features), only one (Burial G230115) was associated with grave goods. C14 dates on human bone from these burials spanned the period 2030 to 1430 cal BC.
Site_description: During the East Kent Access Route excavations (2009-2011) a bronze age double ring ditch was found in zone 13. The ring-ditch was situated c. 25m north-west of a second, larger ring-ditch.Barrow 1 was only partially exposed as much of the feature lay outside the excavated area. The remains of the ring-ditch to the north-west had been destroyed by a railway cutting. The outer ditch had a maximum width of c. 2.5m and a maximum surviving depth of 1.5m. It enclosed a circular area with a diameter of c. 30m. Six sections were hand-excavated and suggested that the ditch had originally been continuous. There was very little dating evidence. The fills did contain iron age pottery but this was likely ot have been intrusive as the ring-ditch was cut by various iron age features. The inner ditch was broad and shallow (up to 1.7m wide and 0.5 m deep). Several graves were found between the outer and inner ditches. These have not all been dated and some may be prehistoric but are thought more likely to be Anglo-Saxon in date. (1)

Site_name_main: Witchampton and Crichel Working Men's Club
Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Trench A within the watching brief area produced four small pits, c. 40-55cm wide x 25-45cm deep. All of the pits had been sectioned clearly by a JCB and contained Deverel-Rimbury urns. Samples were taken of the pottery and the contents of three of the urns which were left in situ. The fourth urn was removed. The urn in pit 3 was inverted. No further information is provided and no final report on the site appears to have been written. The urns were lodged with Priest's House Museum, Wimborne Minster.
Site_description: Trench A within the watching brief area produced four small pits, c. 40-55cm wide x 25-45cm deep. All of the pits had been sectioned clearly by a JCB and contained Deverel-Rimbury urns. Samples were taken of the pottery and the contents of three of the urns which were left in situ. The fourth urn was removed. The urn in pit 3 was inverted. No further information is provided and no final report on the site appears to have been written. The urns were lodged with Priest's House Museum, Wimborne Minster.

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Formal burial of a child with grave goods in the causewayed enclosure ditch of Early Neolithic date Harris (2010, 357) notes that: 'Two children aged between 5 and 12 were interred in adjacent segments of the main enclosure ditch (Fig. 1). The similarities between the burials are remarkable; both are children, both were articulated, both were covered with flint and both were deposited with artefacts. The child in segment 18 was buried with a flint flake and three tubular bone beads, two made from mammal limb bones, and one from a large bird, possibly a swan (Mercer 1980, 31). In segment 17 two chalk lumps carved with criss-crossed lines were placed behind the child’s head (Mercer 1980, 31). Both children’s appearance would have been affected by the premature fusing of their skulls (McKinley 2008, 511). What is even more striking, however, is that they were buried between 160 and 250 years apart (Healy 2004, table 1; Mercer & Healy 2008). The older burial, from phase I or II of segment 18 dates to between 3660 and 3540 cal. bc, the younger, from phase VII of segment 17, to between 3380 and 3320 cal. bc (Mercer & Healy 2008, 101). They represent the only completely articulated burials discovered in the main enclosure, in contrast to the evidence for the exposure of corpses at the site, and the extensive deposition of disarticulated human bone.NB grid reference is taken from Pastscape record for causewayed enclosure
Site_description: <Pastscape site description (causewayed enclosure)>: An Early Neolithic causewayed enclosure on the summit of Hambledon Hill, of which one third survives as earthwork and the remainder has been ploughed flat. It is interpreted as the central focus of a large complex of Neolithic monuments which occupy spurs of the hill in addition to its central summit (the hillfort spur to the north, the Shroton spur to the east, the Stepleton spur to the south, and the Hanford spur to the west). The main enclosure is one of the largest causewayed enclosures in England (circa 9 hectares), and is divided from the radiating spurs by pairs of cross-dykes which may equate to the middle and outer circuits of other complex enclosures. In 1974-86 a major programme of excavation directed by Roger Mercer examined most major earthworks on the Hill. The ditch contained placed deposits of human skulls and other bones, plus considerable quantities of animal bones. Stone axes from a variety of sources, and pottery from mainly local sources were also present. The abundant cultural material retrieved from the site has provided information about the community, including conflict, feasting, the treatment of the human corpses, exchange, stock management and agriculture. The disposal of individual artefacts and remains reflect the diverse use of the monument. Use of the enclosures and the construction of its individual parts was episodic, spread over 300-400 years, and was not representative of a lasting settlement. The relationship with Cranborne Chase to the east is highlighted by the cessation of activity on the hill in the late fourth millennium at the same time that the Dorset cursus and other monuments were built in the Chase. Renewed activity on the hill in the late 3rd and early 2nd millennia preceded occupation in the mid to late 2nd millennium, which was followed by the construction of a hillfort on the northern spur from the early 1st millennium. Later Iron Age, Romano-British, and Saxon activity has also been recorded on the hill.

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Urned cremation in a cordon-decorated urn within a small pit (F2), seemingly within a contemporary post-built structure.
Site_description: <Bristow 2001>: A possible occupation site with in Feature 2 of a partial post circle with associated pits, a cordon decorated cinerary urn associated with a deposit of cremated bone. The structure may have been ritual. The other feature group comprised heavily truncated areas of burning, suggestive of either hearths or funeral pyres. In one bowl shaped feature were four flint scrapers, a core and several waste flakes partly covered by a stone pounder of ironstone.

Site_name_other: Mid to late Bronze/early Iron Age activity at Thanet Earth
Parish_Community_Borough: ST NICHOLAS AT WADE, THANET, KENT
Site_summary: A number of features including two possible enclosures were located in an Evaluation in 2007 and 2008 <gg_summary>: Two round barrows, one containing a central cremation burial possibly containing burials dating to the Middle Bronze Age (c.1500-1100 bc) were located on Plateau 2, as well as a middle Bronze Age pond which yielded a votive palstave. Not defined as separate sites for ggdb entry
Site_description: An archaeological evaluation took place at Thanet Earth in 2007 and 2008. This period is considered here as a whole due to the difficulties of separating the various chronological sub phases. There were potentially many isolated, scattered features of this period indicating general occupation of the area, but the main elements seem to comprise two possible enclosures. a possibly later Bronze age enclosure in the extreme northern part of the site with an interrelated site wide field system, which probably represents the largest exposure of such a system in Kent to date. Two barrows (Barrows 7 and 8) and a large pond on Plateau 2 were probably also of this period . To the south on Plateau 6, two uncertainly dated enclosures (Enclosures 6 and 7) were only partially revealed but were probably prehistoric. (1)<1> Canon Scott Robertson, 2011, Excavations at Thanet Earth 2007-2008: Assessment Report Volume 1 and 2 (Unpublished document). SKE29447.<2> Canterbury Archaeological Trust, 2011, Excavations at Thanet Earth 2007 2008: Stratigraphic Report Volume 1 (DRAFT)Stratigraphic Report (Unpublished document). SKE29450.

Site_name_other: Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age inhumation burial, Harbour Approach Road, Ramsgate
Site_summary: A crouched inhumation burial of possible Late Neolithic or Early Bronze Age date was found during work on the proposed Harbour approach route. There were no associated artefacts.<gg_summary>: Subsequent excavation of the site identified 2 EBA burials within a ring ditch, one of which was certainly associated with gg, the other less clearly so (but is recorded here because of the unusual character of the objects recovered from the grave fill) (Clark et al 2019, 73-7)Two further isolated EBA burials in the northern part of the site produced no clearcut grave goods although the backfills of both graves contained mixed settlement debris (flint flakes, pot sherds, oyster/mussel shells, animal bone).
Site_description: During boreholing and trenching for a geotenchical survey a crouched buiral of possible Late Neolithic or Early Bronze Age was found within the loessic horizon. No further information is known. (1-2)Evaluation of the route of the proposed Ramsgate Harbour Approach Road revealed a crouched inhumation burial. No cultural material was found in association, but the nature of the burial suggsts that it is of Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age in date. (3)<1> ArchaeoScape Consulting, 1997, Chalk Hill (Kent) Palaeonvironmental Assessment Report (July 1997) Phase 1 Stage 2 (Unpublished document). SKE12090.<2> ArchaeoScape Consulting, 1997, Chalk Hill (Kent) Palaeonvironmental Assessment Report (June 1997) (Unpublished document). SKE12091.<3> Canterbury Archaeological Trust, 1997, An Archaeological Evaluation at Ramsgate Harbour Approach Road April - May 1997 (Unpublished document). SKE12109.

Site_name_other: Bell Barrow west of Veiny Cheese Pond, Long Crichel
Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Grinsell's (1959, 118) Long Crichel barrow 5 (Green et al 1983). Complex burial sequence comprising two beaker-associated inhumation burials; two food-vessel associated child burials (one with three interments); four later cremation burials with no grave goods.
Site_description: Excavated by C Green 1959 _ 1960.

Site_summary: <gg summary>: Fordlinton Farm round barrow was rediscovered in 1979 and excavated in 1988 prior to development. Note that two of the graves/ mortuary structures n Phase 1 were multiple deposits of ordered piles of bones in possible mortuary structures. One contained stacked piles of three individuals and the other had two.  Grave/Mortuary structure 70- was 2m long, 1.7m wide & 0.8m deep with piles of an adult male, adult female and a neonate/foetus (woman who died in childbirth), dated 2290-1970 BC (UB-3304) but no gg other than timber coffin/ wooden structure. Mortuary structure 59 (1.5 x 0,8m deep) contained diasrticulated ordered stacked remains of an adult male and a child c. 10-14 years old. Again there was a timber structure/ coffin and hr were dated to 2347-2039 (UB-3305). Gr 61 contained an adult male with a B&T arrowhead. also several cattle bones were placed around body as bones, not joints of meat (all had cut marks on them). This was cut by a pit containing an inverted Collared Urn burial with a tanged dagger

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow in the Ridgeway Hill Group, Bincombe
Site_summary: Ditched bowl barrow. This monument was recorded as 64 feet in diameter with a mound about 3  feet high before excavation in 1963. The excavators found that the barrow had been built over, and preserved, a Neolithic land surface and probable occupation site. The barrow comprised a central cairn covered with a turf stack capped with chalk. Beneath the cairn was a contracted inhumation of an adult and, separately, of a child. There were six later inhumations, one beneath a wooden slat, another of a child.<gg_summary>This is Grinsell's (1959) Bincombe barrow 15 (G15) Bowl barrow with a central primary cist grave, containing two contracted skeletons of adult males accompanied by a necked Beaker, and a satellite grave 0.75m long with a contracted infant inhumation. These were covered by a large cairn with six stratified secondary inhumations. The first was a crouched burial with a food vessel in a very deep shaft grave which re-used the slabs of the primary cist. The second disturbed the first, and was a slightly contracted inhumation with a food vessel in a slab-lined grave. The third was a slightly contracted inhumation with a 'Wessex' vase support; this was in a grave pit and above it was the fourth, in the same grave. The fifth inhumation was contracted under a wooden slat. The sixth, in a grave, was a contracted skeleton of a child 6 years old with a pierced deer-horn in hand. The cairn was covered by a turf stack, and capped with chalk. The barrow was built on a Neolithic occupation site.
Site_description: Grinsell recorded this barrow as 27 paces in diameter and 3 feet in height. <1>Visible on aerial photographs. The site was digitally plotted during the South Dorset Ridgeway Mapping Project. (2)

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: : Burial discovered during gravel quarrying at Prescott's Pit, Brough in 1891. Grave 1.2m deep with inhumation said to be adult male, with dagger (WG 2019) at side and pin (WG 2069) at shoulderSee also: https://www.pastscape.org.uk/hob.aspx?hob_id=63941&sort=2&type=&typeselect=c&rational=a&class1=None&period=-2600|-700|BRONZE%20AGE|3|0&county=1308027&district=1308027&parish=95692&place=&yearfrom=-2600&yearto=-700&recordsperpage=10&source=text&rtype=&rnumber=#
Site_description: Burial discovered during gravel quarrying at Prescott's Pit, Brough in 1891. Objects in the British Museum.

Site_name_other: Bell barrow, one of the Black Down Barrow Group, Portesham
Site_summary: Site of a Bronze Age bell barrow, one of a group of potential barrows situated on Black Down. Excavated in 1955. Now the site of a gravel pit.<gg_summary>: Three E/MBA cremation burials (also one urn deposit) found near the top of the moundThe burnt remains occupied the lower part of the vessels, but as the rims had crumbled some gravel had fallen in. All three urns were just below the surface, so that the rims had badly decayed whereas the bases were in much better condition.Grinsell's (1959, 164) Portesham barrow 2a
Site_description: Site of a Bronze Age bell barrow, one of a group of potential barrows situated on Black Down {1}Excavated by MWT and PA for Ministry of works 1955: primary inhumation not found but inferred as having been dissolved by the acid soil. Four secondary upright LBA urns (three with burnt bones) near top of mound {2}.The post-medieval gravel pit recorded to the west of this site on the 1880 OS map has since expanded, likely having destroyed any potential remains of this feature. Fragments of a possible ring ditch (MDO24666), measuring approximately 24 metres in diameter and visible as cropmarks on aerial photographs {4}, could potentially be related to this bell barrow however. It is situated 26 metres to the north-east of the coordinates for this barrow site.

Site_summary: <gg_summary>: Unlocated barrow above Newton Farm'. 10-12 urned burials were recovered from which five urns (recorded here) survive in Dorset County Museum. Grinsell's Hinton barrow 2a (1959, 115); see also Calkin (1967, 144)Locational details derived/rounded up/down to the nearest grid corner from Grinsell's Hilton barrow 2

<gg_summary>: Grouped record for unlocated barrows (1-3) at Plush Hill, Piddletrenthide. See Calkin (1967, 145), Grinsell (1959, 124) for more details. Grinsell's unlocated Piddletrenthide barrows 10b-d.Barrow 1 (10b), 30-40 urned cremation burials recovered, 16 in Ashmolean Museum recorded here (10 buckets, 6 globular). Distributed irregularly through the flint cairn; Barrow 2 (10c), 1ry globular urn cremation (DCM, A.402), firmly embedded in the soil and surrounded by large stones; Barrow 3 (10d) primary cremation in a crushed (?globular) urnOverall, 18 urns survive and are recorded as urned burials here.Locational details taken from grid ref for Plush barrow group in Pastscape<grouped unlocated barrows>

<gg_summary>: Excavated 1675 (Warne 1866 CTD (tovp 1): 1ry urned cremation with lugs (urn lost, urn type unknown but specific details so recorded here); 2ry upright urned cremation in clay lined cavity beneath cairn (urn lost, urn type unknown but specific details so recorded here); up to 16 2ry cremations in cairn, potentially MBA (bucket urn in DCM)?See also Grinsell (1959, 160) Wynford Eagle barrow 1.An MNI of three cremation burials recorded (the two described specifically and an MNI of at least one other ?MBA cremation burial, urn in DCM (see also Ellison 1975)) is recorded

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow north of Holly Brake, Charlton Marshall
Site_summary: A Bronze Age bowl barrow situated on a spur. In 1970 this monument was reported as being around 57 feet in diameter with a mound about 1  feet high, and much reduced by ploughing.<gg_summary>: Grouped evidence from 3 unlocated barrows, excavated 1811 by Mr White (Grinsell's 1959, 99 Charlton Marshall barrows 7-9). See also Warne (1866) CTD (tovp) 48-50 pp24-5. The urns from these barrows are now lost; one has been identified as a globular urn (Ellison 1975).Holly Brake Barrow 2: 1ry cremation in urn of unknown typeHolly Brake Barrow 3: 1ry cremation in upright globular urn with 4 perforated lugs (in cist)<grouped unlocated barrows>
Site_description: GRINSELL(1959) 99?EXC WHITE 1811

Site_name_other: Bowl barrow, one of the Black Hill Group, Turners Puddle
