Site_summary: A Bronze Age bowl barrow, one of the Black Hill Group, is visible as an earthwork on lidar imagery.Povington Barrow: 2ry cremation burial in biconical urn found in 1937. Urn in DCM. Grinsell's (1959, 138) Tyneham barrow 14.
Site_description: A Bronze Age bowl barrow, one of the Black Hill Group, is visible as an earthwork on lidar imagery.  The barrow is formed of a sub-circular mound measuring 13 m in diameter.  (2)  It is scheduled together with five other barrows on Black Hill (see linked records) of which five could be seen on lidar imagery.  This feature was digitally plotted as part of the Wild Purbeck Mapping Project.

Site_name_other: Bronze Age urn found at Redhill or Redbreast, Bournemouth
Site_summary: Find of a Late Bronze Age hybrid urn with sharp tooled ornament. The vessel was found either at Redhill or Redbreast, Bournemouth.Redhill, Bournemouth: Recorded in Calkin 1962, 52 as an urned cremation burial (Globular Urn). Urn now in BM. No further details
Site_description: Late Bronze Age hybrid urn with sharp tooled ornament. Found before 1935 at Redhill or Redbreast. In Calkin Collection, British Museum. (1)

Site_name_other: Late Bronze Age / early Iron Age settlement at the Corn Field, Holborough Quarry
Site_summary: A trial trenching evaluation in 2004 found extensive evidence of a late Bronze Age / early Iron Age settlement. 33 trenches were excavated and found a round house structure, three cremation burials, two ditches and twelve domestic pits as well as two modern chalk extraction pits. Most of the features were provisionally dated to the late Bronze Age / early Iron Age period (c. 900 - 600 BC). The round house was represented by 7 postholes and a drip gully. Finds from the site included pottery, bone, slag, burnt flint and daub<gg_summary>: sixteen cremation burials deposited in pits, including one MBA urned cremation, clustered along MBA land boundaries. Summaries in Canterbury's Archaeology 2004-5; McNee 2012, 249. See also sword mould deposit from this site. Enter one MBA urned cremation burial as a minimum
Site_description: In 2004 a trial trenching evaluation was carried out by the Canterbury Archaeological Trust in advance of residential development. 33 trenches were excavated, 10 of which (tr 2, 11, 12, 15, 16, 17, 20, 22, 24 and 25) produced archaeological features. Residual prehistoric pottery was found in trenches 6, 19 and 32. Several test pits were also excavated to assess the survival of palaeosoils but none were found.25 features were provisionally dated to the late bronze age / early iron age (c.900 BC - 600 BC). These include a round house, represented by 7 postholes and a drip gully and a number of other features. There were also 12 pits (trenches 2, 11, 12, 15, 17, 22 and 25) , some of which contained domestic refuse and two boundary ditches (trenches 16 and 24). Three cremation burlals were also found in trench 15. The features were concentrated on the west of the site and may represent a settlement located on the upper slopes of Holborough valley on a site overlooking the river Medway.Finds at the site included animal bone, daub, pottery, burnt flint and slag.Two chalk extraction pits were also found dating to the mopdern period (c. AD 1850+) (1)A subsequent excavation by Canterbury Archaeological Trust in 2004 found features relating to a domestic site of the Late Bronze Age. Ditches, a roundhouse, four post granaries, rubbish pits and cremations were all found. Finds included pottery, butchered animal remains, carbonised remains of pulses and grains and clay loom weights. One pit contained a number of fragments of Ewart Park sword moulds. (2)

Site_summary: <Stornoway Airport, Melbost>: MIA juvenille skeleton plus MIA pot (no more specific dating), summarised in Armit 1996, 153: 'A further inhumation found during the construction of Stornoway airport was accompanied by three vessels (now disappeared), a weaving comb, and spindle whorl; apparently a classic Iron Age assemblage (Langhorne, pers. comm.)'.  Not in Canmore. Hr in Museum nan Eilean, Stornoway. See also Tucker 2010. Not clearly within study period (could be later than AD42)Grid reference taken from Stornoway Airport grid ref (CANMORE ID 74205)

Site_name_other: BALLOWALL - Bronze Age entrance grave, Bronze Age cist
Site_summary: Ballowall Barrow (or Carn Gluze) consists of a central domed structure, containing cists and with a pit beneath, surrounded by an outer cairn also containing cists. An entrance grave is located in the external side of the outer cairn.<gg_summary>: Complex multi-phase cairn excavated by Borlase in 1878. Relevant graves include:Ballowall cist burial (Borlase 1881, 198): One of 5 'little stone cists'. This one contained an upright, small, and perfectly plain urn, filled with dark earth, charred wood and two minute fragments of burnt bone. Three other fragments from a small vessel were also recorded from this cist. Borlase also discusses the total absence of burnt bone beyond these fragments in the central part of the cairn (including, presumably, in the two other described cists with urns) (1881, 198)Ballowall chamber burial (Borlase 1881, 199): A chamber, under the floor of which were found quantities of burnt human bone mixed with pottery fragments, some curiously ornamented with dots (Borlase 1881, 199)The central grave where greasy black earth, ashes and a stone bead were found is not recorded here. Borlase (1881, 197) suggests that it may have contained a degraded extended inhumation but it is not recorded in Jones 2005 as a potential EBA inhumation burial, unlike other similar examples.
Site_description: Ballowall Barrow (or Carn Gluze Barrow) is marked as a chambered cairn on current OS maps (b11). This site was discovered under mining debris in 1878 and was excavated by WC Borlase (b1,b2,b3). The monument consists of a central domed structure, containing cists and with a pit beneath, surrounded by an outer cairn also containing cists. An entrance grave is located in the external side of the outer cairn. After excavation, Borlase conserved the mound structure to display the more prominent features. This involved building a new retaining wall which has changed the appearance of the outer mound from a round cairn to a ring cairn. Interpretation of the sequence of the site is problematic, due to the patchy antiquarian excavation records and from the restoration. Sharpe's survey (h5) and report of 1990 (b13) re-assesses the excavation record and provides alternative sequences of mound construction, postulated in the light of recent studies of entrance graves and barrows. One of the cists found within the central part of the mound was a double cist, formed with a cental granite dividing stone. Pottery finds (29786. 01) included a stone spindle whorl (or possibly a large bead), animal and human bones. The monument was included in the Schedule on 10/8/1923 and the scheduling was updated on 22/2/1996.  The site is visible on aerial photographs (p1-3) and was plottted as part of the NMP.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. GEARY, E / OS2: 1975. FLETCHER, MJ / OS3: 1981. SHEPPARD, PA / DOE4: 1985. SHEPPARD, PA / DOE5: 1989. SHARPE, A AND NOWAKOWSKI, J / CAU--------------------------------<MCO177>: Middle and late Bronze Age urns from cists were found within Ballowall Barrow and are at the RIC Truro, the Cambridge University Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology, and the British Museum. Many sherds were also found within the barrow. There are many largely late Bronze Age class G Deverel Rimbury (after 750BC). There is one documented middle Bronze Age class C ribbon handled urn (b8, b9). Scheduling revised July 1997.--------------------------------Site history:2: 1960. GEARY, E / OS3: 1975. FLETCHER, MJ / OS4: 1981. SHEPPARD, PA / DOE5: 1985. SHEPPARD, PA / HBMC6: 1989. SHARPE, A AND NOWAKOWSKI, JA / CAU--------------------------------
